name: Martin SCHULZ
text: The first item on the agenda is the debate on the council and Commission statements on the preparation of the European Council on 17 and 18 December 2015 (2015/2913(RSP)).

name: Nicolas SCHMIT
text: President-in-Office of the Council. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the agenda for the December European Council meeting will be very dense. The European Council will address fundamental issues for Europe such as migration, the fight against terrorism, economic and monetary union, the internal market, the Energy Union and climate policy, as well as the issue of the referendum in the United Kingdom. This European Council aims not only to tackle the current crises, but also aims to provide general policy directions for the future. The Council has worked all these issues, much has been done in recent months, and let me now detail the various issues. The first question is about migration. The first priority for all of us is the implementation of what we have decided. All the institutions are working hard to implement the conclusions of the European Council, but the scale of the crisis reminds us every day that this is no longer enough. Managing its immediate effects is essential, but establishing rules and enforcing them is equally essential. The aim is to examine the situation on the ground and to fill the current deficiencies in particular with regard to hotspots, relocations and returns. We must first strengthen the protection of our external borders in the Schengen area in order to stem the flow of irregular migrants. Frontex needs to be strengthened and the countries that are asking for it, such as Greece now, must be able to count on effective assistance. Maintaining the Schengen area, which must be our absolute objective, requires us to improve the management of our external borders. I believe that the Commission has made important proposals in this regard. Continued cooperation with countries of origin and transit is also crucial operationally, but also in order to address the root causes of migration. In this context, the European Council also intends to adopt conclusions on Syria, marking a determined support for all efforts towards a political process, but also expressing a willingness to fight all terrorist forces. The second question deals specifically with the fight against terrorism. After the Paris attacks, a number of measures were adopted and must now be implemented quickly. One of the most important issues is cooperation and information exchange. It is not a question of creating an agency such as the CIA, or whatever other European agency, but we need to deepen and systematise cooperation between the relevant services. The agreement on the European NRL will also play a decisive role in the fight against terrorism, and I would like to thank Mr Kirkhope and all those who have worked on an agreement on this difficult issue. In this area too, cooperation with third countries is of course an absolute necessity. The third question is about economic and monetary union. The report of the five presidents to complete it was presented last June. Since then, work has progressed well within the various council formations. The Commission presented follow-up proposals on 21 October, and you debated them yesterday in plenary. We all agree that reform of the euro area remains a necessity. The European Council is called upon to give direction to the continuation of the work, a number of issues - unfortunately we must admit - remain controversial and therefore need to be clarified quickly. The President of the European Council also wants an in-depth discussion on the basis on which the institutions can move the work forward. The fourth item on the Council's agenda concerns the internal market, which is the very foundation of European integration. The Commission has recently submitted a number of communications and reports which will be the basis of the European Council's discussions. The aim is to strengthen and deepen the internal market in several areas where there are still deficiencies. This applies to goods and services, with a new strategy, but this applies in particular and above all to the digital internal market as well as to the Union of Capital Markets. We need to revitalise the internal market in the interests of growth, competitiveness and employment.  We have all welcomed the success of COP 21 on the Energy Union and climate change. On this subject, too, there was a debate yesterday. The European Council will of course take notice of this and instruct the Council and the Commission to assess the results, particularly in light of the 2030 climate and energy framework. Now is the time for implementation and, again, Europe must also lead the way and be exemplary. The European Council will also return to the issue of the Energy Union for an in-depth discussion next March. Finally, the question of the referendum in the United Kingdom. After extensive consultations, the President of the European Council set out his intentions in a letter to his colleagues on 7 December. The December European Council is not expected to make a decision on the UK's demands; it will be an opportunity for a political discussion on all the issues raised. The form and content of a possible agreement will be developed at a later stage. In his letter to the members of the European Council, President Tusk also informed the Heads of State and Government that he had asked the Presidency to put the issue of sanctions policy against Russia on the COREPER agenda. Finally, I would like to express, once again, our thanks for the responsibility and commitment that the European Parliament has made on the many current issues and challenges, including the issue of migration.

name: Nicolas SCHMIT
text: President of the Commission. – Mr President, the main issues of discussion for tomorrow’s European Council will be the management of the refugee crisis, the implementation of our security agenda and the deepening of the Economic and Monetary Union. I said in the State of the Union speech on 9 September, and I want to repeat it, that this is no time for business as usual. No time for half-measures, no time for hesitation. I announced plans for a European Border and Coast Guard, and here we are. The Commission has now agreed those plans, and I call on Parliament and the Council to treat them as a matter of urgency. We have no time to lose when it comes to preserving the Schengen area of free movement. (Applause) For this, effective management of our external borders must be a priority. The Commission is not the government of the European Union – this seems to be news to you, Mr Farage! He would like the Commission to be the government of Europe! – (Laughter) ...but when the situation requires so, when there are threats to our ways of living together, we have to take responsibility and prepare a collective response.  We have done this for the banking system by transferring preventive and remedial mechanisms to the European level – because the crisis has shown that national authorities were left alone to deal with transnational problems. The proposal we put forward yesterday, under the leadership of my good friend Frans Timmermans and Commissioner Avramopoulos, for a European Border and Coast Guard, follows the same logic. It will bring the missing link to strengthen our external borders, so that people can continue to live and move freely within our Union. We Europeans no longer have many borders: we have one, and we have a shared responsibility to protect it. The European Border and Coast Guard is not the answer to a new need. The European Border and Coast Guard is there to repair a weakness in our Schengen system. We are completing what should have been done from the start. Member States will continue to keep their competence and sovereignty on their borders. They will continue to manage the external border day to day. The European Border and Coast Guard will assess migratory flows across the whole of the Union, identify our weak spots, and require Member States to take action when needed. Member States will be able to request joint operations and rapid border interventions. But where urgent problems persist and no action is taken, the Commission will assume its responsibility for the system as a whole and take – together with the Member States – appropriate decisions for the European Border and Coast Guard to intervene. If there is a serious problem at our external border, we cannot stand aside and do nothing. We have to act. The Commission proposes to establish a permanent staff of 1 000 and a reserve pool of at least 1 500 experts who can be deployed within 72 hours. A new European Return Office within the new Agency will accelerate the return of irregular migrants by deploying teams of specialists across the Union. A new standard travel document for return will ensure the wider acceptance of returnees by third countries.  All of you know my views on Schengen, but to avoid any doubt, let me be absolutely clear: under my leadership we will do everything possible to protect what we have built, and to make it better and stronger. (Applause) We want to defend everything that Schengen represents, and as we prepare for a new year, our determination is stronger than ever. So let me tell you: Schengen is here to stay. This is why the Commission proposes to strengthen the Schengen Border Code so that every person entering the Schengen area – whether they are an EU national or a third country national – will undergo a security check against national and European databases. And checks on all individuals will now be mandatory when exiting the European Union as well. These are the costs of a riskier world, and we cannot avoid them. Tomorrow, I will call on the European Council to respond positively and urgently to all of these proposals. Here, I want to thank this House for its support over the course of this year. Parliament worked closely with the Commission when it mattered most. You responded quickly and diligently to all of our proposals, and I count on your support as we continue our work together. The refugee crisis does not begin at Europe’s borders. Last month, we opened a new chapter in our relations with Turkey, a country that already hosts 2.2 million refugees – more than any other country in the world. The situation demands that we work together. Yesterday, the Commission adopted a Recommendation for a Voluntary Humanitarian Admission Scheme for refugees from Syria who are currently in Turkey. If our neighbour is facing a humanitarian emergency, then we have a duty to help. All 28 Member States have worked on this proposal, but it remains voluntary. Those Member States that want to help can do so. I hope that all 28 are ready to help.  Mr President, when I came to you in September, Europe was not in good shape. Our governments were very busy blaming each other, or pointing the finger at Brussels. The situation required urgent action. On 29 September, the Commission adopted a Communication outlining the immediate operational, budgetary and legal measures under the European Agenda on Migration. We concluded that the implementation of European Union Law with regard to building a Common European Asylum System had been proceeding too slowly in the Member States. As a result, on 15 October we presented a Communication setting out the next steps for the next six months. In particular, the Commission called on Greece and Italy to roll-out the remaining hotspots, to operationalise those existing, to improve the registration capacity within the Eurodac fingerprinting system and to organise the swift transfer of migrants from hotspot areas to second-line reception facilities. The situation in Greece and in Italy has improved, but there still remain things to be done. This is why I convened the leaders of the Western Balkans, to bring everyone round the table and to start a conversation. As a result, our officials now talk on a daily basis and coordinate actions across the whole of the region. I know that it will take some time before we fully control every aspect of the situation, but we are moving in the right direction. The European Union’s humanitarian assistance to the Western Balkans now stands at EUR 22 million, helping to give comfort and restore dignity to thousands of refugees along that route. But make no mistake. Progress is still too slow, and our Member States need to do more, and they need to do it quickly. While they accelerate relocations and returns, they must also agree on the crisis relocation mechanism so that Europe can react more quickly in the future. They need to agree on the safe countries of origin, so that we can increase the efficiency of the asylum system and speed up the return of irregular migrants. They need to match the funding that the European Union has mobilised for the Syria Trust Fund. And they need to deliver everything agreed at the Valletta Summit, where we launched a new partnership with our African neighbours. We need to honour all our commitments, and we need to do it now. This is the message I will take once again to the European Council tomorrow and the day after tomorrow. Monsieur le Président, Mesdames, Messieurs, les Européens veulent pouvoir continuer à vivre en sécurité dans un espace où la libre circulation contribue à leur façon de vivre, d'étudier et de travailler. Mais les images qui ont marqué cette année 2015 et resteront gravées dans leur mémoire, celles des récents événements à Paris, rappellent que le pire est toujours possible. Chaque jour à travers l'Europe, 24 heures sur 24, des hommes et des femmes, qu'ils soient policiers, gendarmes, magistrats ou juges, sont entièrement dévoués à assurer la sécurité de nos citoyens. Nous avons l'obligation de faciliter leur travail en leur donnant les outils nécessaires pour qu'ils puissent mieux coordonner leurs actions dans ce qui est, pour eux, un combat de tous les jours. Bien sûr, la sauvegarde de la sécurité est une prérogative nationale, mais il est évident qu'une meilleure coordination au niveau européen s'impose, y compris pour ce qui est de la collaboration entre les services secrets. Le terrorisme ne connaît aucune frontière et, donc, notre réponse doit être globale.  Quoi qu'en disent certains, qui se livrent à de dangereux amalgames, les terroristes voyageant vers l'Europe préfèrent le confort des avions à la précarité d'embarcations de fortune. Je me réjouis donc que nous soyons enfin parvenus à un accord sur le registre européen des passagers, et je remercie tous les acteurs du Parlement européen qui ont travaillé pour parvenir à ce résultat. Selon l'agence Europol, quelque 5 000 Européens seraient partis combattre dans des pays comme la Syrie ou l'Iraq. Certains d'entre eux sont déjà rentrés. Parmi eux, quelques-uns se sont attaqués avec une violence inouïe aux sociétés qui les ont vus naître et qui les ont vus grandir. Face à ce phénomène, nous devons adapter et intensifier l'arsenal juridique de l'Union européenne en matière de prévention et de répression des actes terroristes, y compris pour ce qui touche au financement des activités terroristes. C'est là tout l'objet de la nouvelle directive présentée par la Commission sur la lutte contre le terrorisme, que j'espère voir adoptée rapidement. Dans tous les cas, nous ne devons jamais oublier que liberté et sécurité ne sont pas antinomiques. Préserver et défendre cette compatibilité entre liberté et sécurité, c'est aussi ce qui fait notre façon de vivre ensemble. C'est une question d'identité, c'est une question de valeurs. Puisque, Monsieur le Président, le Conseil européen sera l'occasion de discuter de l'Union économique et monétaire et du marché intérieur, c'est l'occasion de rappeler que la liberté va aussi de pair avec la prospérité.  L'innovation, la croissance, l'emploi, la compétitivité n'aiment pas les frontières. Lorsque nous avons un problème dans un de nos pays, nous devons essayer d'apporter une réponse globale au problème de ce pays. Lorsque nous avons le même problème dans plusieurs pays, nous avons l'obligation d'agir – je le dis notamment en relation avec la situation grave dans laquelle se trouve la sidérurgie européenne ces jours-ci. Ce n'est pas en se repliant sur soi que l'Europe pourra répondre aux attentes des Européens, qui veulent pouvoir créer une entreprise, trouver les financements y afférents, avoir à leur disposition des marchés ouverts, des systèmes de communication et de transport performants, des approvisionnements énergétiques sûrs et des facteurs énergétiques bon marché.  C'est pourquoi, lorsque nous avons présenté notre programme de travail, nous avons insisté sur la nécessité de parfaire notre marché intérieur là où il est imparfait et de le parachever là où il est incomplet – faire l'Union du numérique, l'Union des marchés de capitaux, l'Union de l'énergie. Je me réjouis de l'accord qui a été trouvé récemment à Paris, dit "accord climatique", qui nous permettra de progresser dans ces objectifs fixés par l'Union de l'énergie, tout en renforçant notre contribution financière pour l'action climatique dans les pays en voie de développement. Ein abschießendes Wort zur Europäischen Union und zu ihrer absehbaren Zukunft. In Europa war nie etwas einfach, und in Europa wird es nie einfach sein, Dinge und Menschen, Menschen und Dinge zusammenzubringen. Aber immer wieder, wenn es Probleme gab, sind Männer und Frauen aufgestanden, weil sie nicht Geschichte erdulden wollten, sondern Geschichte gestalten wollten. (Beifall) So war es immer, und so wird es bleiben. Das Unmögliche erscheint so lange unmöglich, bis es gemacht ist. (Beifall)

name: Manfred WEBER
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has For us, 2015 was characterised by the fact that we deliver at European level. I would therefore like to express my thanks to the Commission for this year of delivery, of proposals, of presenting the ideas for the future of Europe. And we in the European Parliament have tried to give legislative backing for this, to give legislative backing. Yesterday's last proposal, Mr President, fits in seamlessly. The idea of improving the protection of external borders in order to keep Europe free at home is exactly the same logic that Europe is delivering. I would like to signal support for my group. When I hear today that there is now a debate across Europe as to whether national sovereignty is to be preserved, my group values national sovereignty, the pride of the Member States, very strongly, very highly. But the question that in Greece, Hungary, Poland, and also in Spain, the European border is not secured, but the European border is obvious. That is why we want Frontex to be strengthened. And if the citizens are asked today, they will answer: I don't really care if that regulates my nation state or anyone else. I want the law to be implemented at Europe's external border. That is what the citizens of Europe want, and that is where we should support the Commission. (Applause) On my group's mind, I would like to say that we will not be in favour of legislation on the Frontex mandate if the command issue is not resolved. The central question is: if a Member State does not implement anything at the external border, then someone else must be able to secure the borders accordingly, and that is Frontex. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report, which Secondly, I would like to thank the President-in-Office of the Council, Mr Schmit, for joining tomorrow's Council, because he has described that tomorrow you will not be presenting new ideas, new drafts for the future, but rather a balance sheet council, where we take stock of what has been achieved, because this is bitterly necessary. Please do not have any new ideas, but simply implement the points that have been agreed. I read, for example, that the Italian and British Governments are now together putting very great ideas on the table for the Lisbon issues, for the ever closer Union, for all these formulations. I have to say that we can talk about all this, but the most important thing would simply be for the Italian and British Governments to make their commitments on the Africa Fund, for the money to be made available at last, or for the relocation mechanism, namely the almost 40 000 refugees from Italy promised to be relocated, to be made at last! So we do not need new ideas, but we need the decisions to be implemented at long last. (Applause) Thirdly, I would like to make a very basic remark today also at the end of 2015, because we often discuss in the institutions between ourselves as professionals and too little in the eyes of the citizens. We all know that citizens are concerned when it comes to Europe when it comes to the further development of Europe. And that is why I would like to make an attempt today to make a call, not to talk about crisis Europe, not to talk about the concerns that Europe could fail tomorrow, as is often read in the newspapers, but i would simply like to list a few facts of what has been achieved in 2015. Ladies and gentlemen, in January 2015 we had Charlie Hebdo. Today, in these weeks, we have adopted the necessary legislative responses in the fight against terrorism – PNR, Europol mandate. In the spring and in recent years, dear friends, ladies and gentlemen, we have had thousands of deaths in the Mediterranean who have died on the run. Since the spring of this year, almost all European naval units have been deployed in the Mediterranean to rescue refugees, we have saved thousands of lives, and we now even have a robust mandate, thanks to the intervention of Federica Mogherini, to be able to combat the smugglers there. In the summer, we had Greece on the table, a truly historic issue. And, thanks to Jean-Claude Juncker, Greece has succeeded in keeping Greece in the euro area and giving the people there a stable perspective. And although even the Communists now have to carry out the necessary pension reforms in Greece, we have succeeded, thank God, in making progress there. We have had the question of Ukraine on the table all year round. Ladies and gentlemen, it is a huge success that the European Union is united in extending the sanctions, that we are united in the answer. Russian nationalism, which we unfortunately experience. We had the climate summit in Paris a few days ago. Ladies and gentlemen, without the courageous progress of our continent, including this European Parliament, on climate change, that we want to fight climate change, Paris would have been unthinkable. As Europeans, we have been the shining example of the world in the fight against climate change. Two more points: data protection: if I imagine that we are now regulating data protection, where we are trying to tame these instruments – Google and Facebook – and also to set European standards – we are doing something for the citizens. Finally, ladies and gentlemen, we have 2% economic growth in the euro area, and growth is coming back. Something is being achieved in Europe. And I would like, ladies and gentlemen, that when we talk about Europe, we do not just go from one crisis summit to another crisis summit, but that we tell our citizens that we achieve a great deal if we tackle it together. I would like to see this openness. We have achieved a great deal, including in 2015, together in Europe. And that should also be the message to the British: Member States are important, national sovereignty is important, our Member States should and must be strong. But together we are stronger! (Applause) (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: question put in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure. – Mr Weber, you are very authoritative and you express yourself like this, very strongly, as if you want to impose your point of view on us. I ask you: are you leading the largest group in the European Parliament, do you think it is right what President Juncker has presented here? For citizens of Bulgaria and Romania countries, which are not Schengen members, to have a different regime? Are Member States equal lysed in the European Union? Do you support Romania's entry into Schengen or not?

name: Manfred WEBER
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. – The first task in matters relating to the Schengen area is to preserve Schengen first of all, because of the problems we have in the Schengen area – because, unfortunately, border controls are being ramped up internally again. The proposals are a one-way move in the right direction.  My group wants Romania and Bulgaria to join the Schengen area. The progress made in both countries in recent years is considerable. I believe that both countries have a good chance of becoming members of the Schengen area in the coming months, in the next few years.

name: Gianni PITTELLA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I should like to begin by thanking Minister Nicolas Schmit and the Luxembourg Presidency for their excellent work over a particularly difficult six months.  Last Sunday, French voters stopped the far right. Be ware though, that vote is a warning to everyone. A mixture of selfishness and nationalism has slowed down the impetus that the European Commission and this Parliament have given to European action. The vote French must open the eyes of those who still have their eyes ajar.  We must act. On immigration: the Commission's proposal to set up a new European corps for the protection of external borders is a good thing, but we also need the other pillars, which are a binding mechanism for the distribution of refugees and a review of the Dublin system.  Things are not going well on the distribution of refugees. The Member States have made commitments which must be respected; the Union is a community of law and non-compliance with the commitments made leads to its disintegration. So let us relocate the refugees immediately, as has already been decided, and take new initiatives to relocate more asylum seekers. On the Dublin system: everyone has said that this system is outdated, but we need a legislative measure to achieve overcoming it. All this must be done and must be done immediately, but action is also imperative in the light of the economic crisis. In this context, we consider it a provocation to call into question the flexibility, the principle of flexibility that is inherent in the Stability Pact. We need no less but more flexibility. The Juncker plan is a jewel that cannot remain in the glassware, it has great opportunities that must be seed, that must be explained, that must be disseminated in relation to local and regional self-government, national governments and the business system.  And it is also time for this famous triple A on social dumping to be put into practice. We expect the European Commission to approve the mobility package as soon as possible and to take action on all other initiatives on the priority aspects of social policies. Taking action also means not resigning yourself to the disappearance of industries in Europe, as you have mentioned with great concern. The steel industry is threatened by commercial dumping, if we do not move immediately the European steel industry will be wiped out with the loss of thousands and thousands of jobs, we cannot fail to listen to the cry for help that comes from entrepreneurs and workers.  Mr Juncker, I am addressing you, because I know how sensitive you are to this issue and I say to you that for us Socialists and Democrats the granting of market economy status to China is premature under the current conditions. On Brexit, I repeat what I said when we were faced with grexit risk. We Socialists and Democrats will do everything we can to keep britain in the European Union. We want to help our British fellow citizens stay in the Eu ropean Union, but Cameron too must contribute clearly and constructively to the successful conclusion of the negotiations.  Mrs Weber is right, no fatalism and no resignation, the European Union is not a pile of rubble, but the problems are there and we must not put our heads in the sand. The way to really give a decisive value to 2016 is to act. We can solve these problems if we stand together, Parliament and the Commission, as we have done even more in recent months, and together with us the genuine leaders who are also there at national level who love Europe. This alliance together with our citizens can save the European design.

name: Syed KAMALL
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, for every single one of this week’s Summit items there is no simple answer, no simple soundbite, no one policy, no one Council conclusion to solve all the crises facing Europe. And far too many people offer simplistic responses: some speak of more Europe; a single EU intelligence agency; a single European army leading to a single European government. Others speak of no Europe: closing our borders completely; no entry; no migration, no cooperation. And sometimes the only voices that appear to be heard are those of the extremes. And our politics is in danger of becoming more polarised at a time when our world becomes more complex.  But these crises, they transcend the 140 characters of a tweet – do not tweet that, by the way. The migration and refugee crisis has no simple answers. There is no silver bullet. It must be tackled at source, and we must work our way to a political solution in Syria, however slowly and however frustrating that is. Not everyone who is coming here is necessarily fleeing war, but understandably seeking a better life. Who can blame them? But we simply cannot offer everyone a home, regardless of their personal circumstances. We must have clear rules in place to grant asylum to those genuinely fleeing persecution, and to return economic migrants to apply through existing immigration channels. Instead, we see one large Member State sending out a message that everyone is welcome – regardless of their personal circumstances or their reason for travelling – and then berating other Member States when they re-erect borders. We see other Member States not living up to their responsibilities to detain and process people. When they are unable to cope, they do not ask for help. So instead of all this we see kneejerk policies in the heat of a crisis, like a relocation scheme based on a simple idea but never really rooted in reality. Only 160 people have been helped through it to date. When reality bites, the rhetoric changes. So when Schengen states talk of re-erecting borders, we finally focus on strengthening the EU’s external borders with talk about a European border guard. Yes, we agree; enhancing Frontex and cooperating to help Frontex can help, but we need to be very careful about how what we agree now will work, not just for the next few months, but for the years ahead. And instead of compulsion over Member States, we need more cooperation between Member States, not using a crisis to undermine sovereignty. The same goes for the terrorism crisis we now face. We must react calmly and rationally with policies to address the threat. And yes, it is good to see some of our Member States are going after Da’esh in the Middle East, but we now need to build trust between Member States’ intelligence agencies to share data, not compel them. And we must also tackle the wider issues that lead young people to be recruited by Da’esh. The identity crisis that leaves young people vulnerable to the tactics of Da’esh will only be made worse if we seek to demonise or ostracise our Muslim communities in our countries. Now turning to the UK’s request that you reform, you may be surprised to hear that I have a few words to say about this. We all know that the majority of these requests could be accommodated relatively easily. There is some work to do to accommodate both the UK’s requests and to pursue further European reform. As a British Conservative, I am proud that it is a British Prime Minister who will deliver a referendum for the British people… (Interjection from the floor ‘Rubbish, it was UKIP!’) Dream on!  ...As a British MEP, I will help where I can with a renegotiation process and explain to colleagues here and to my voters, who will have the final say. But as leader of the ECR Group, I hope this process will act as a catalyst for EU-wide reforms. So looking at the Summit agenda, there are some tough issues that need some proper thinking and planning. 2014 was a year of a new European Parliament, a new Commission and a new Council President. But 2015 has been a year of kneejerk reactions. 2016 needs to be the year for laying the groundwork for long-term solutions based on cooperation. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: blue-card question. – Well, good morning and Merry Christmas, Mr Kamal. It is nice to be close to you, as I am normally up in the gods up there. I heard a lot about what you do not want, so I am going to try to pin you down on something you do want. I am not going to ask you about the referendum, because you have side-stepped that at least a dozen times. So what I wonder is, do you still hold with your party’s – and your leader’s – long-term aim to give full EU membership to Turkey? If that is the case, when would you like to see that happen?

name: Syed KAMALL
text: blue-card answer. – Actually, we all need to be completely honest with Turkey, and I have said this a number of times. Let us be honest: Turkey will never join the EU. I am sorry, but there are too many reasons why Turkey will not join: some of them are based on pure prejudice about their faith and about Turks; some on the fact that people believe Turkey is not in Europe; and some on the fact that people want a common foreign security policy and do not want borders with Iran, Syria and Iraq. Others worry – given the population of Turkey – about the number of MEPs they would have and about voting strength in the Council. Put all those reasons together, and we have got to stop being dishonest with Turkey. It is time for all of us to be honest and say that they will never be members of the EU.

name: Guy VERHOFSTADT
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, yesterday I posted two short films on Facebook as an introduction to today’s debate. One short film was on how Syrian refugees have been treated on the Hungarian border in recent months, and a second short film showed how Mr Trudeau, the Canadian Prime Minister, welcomed the 25 000 refugees who arrived in Canada a couple of days ago. I have to tell you that, if you look at the pictures next to each other, the difference could not be greater. It is even shocking. It is not the case that you can enter Canada without any problem. It is very clear that there are border controls in Canada, but the pictures show that they are received there in a decent way – in a human way – with compassion and not with fear or hate, by entering through a normal door and not on their knees under barbed wire, as in Europe.  So that is the main reason why, Mr Juncker, I fully applaud – and my group fully applauds – the Commission’s proposal to set up a European Border and Coast Guard to stop what is happening today, and to stop what is an insane competition between some Member States which, as in a game of ping-pong, are moving the refugees from one neighbouring border to another. It is also to stop the chaotic, not to say sometimes non—existent, management of some of our borders as, for example, in the case in Greece.  So I believe that your proposal is key. This European Border and Coast Guard is key because, without it, it could be the end of Schengen and it could also be the end of the European project. I even think that countries which do not want to participate in the European Border and Coast Guard – or are not willing to cooperate in this – have no place in the Schengen area.  So my plea to the European Council now – because the Commission has done its work – is to decide on it. You don’t do this. At any rate there is nothing about it in the conclusions – and the advantage for the Council is that they have already reached their conclusions before they meet with each other, that is the difference between them and the European Parliament; we meet and then we conclude; there they do it beforehand. In paragraph 2, they say that they are going to ‘examine’ it. Why is it not possible, Mr Schmit? Why is it not possible to decide that the European Council is in favour of a European Border and Coast Guard and then to start to examine – together with the two institutions and based on a fast-track procedure – the Commission’s proposals? No, it is not possible. It is ‘examine’. Well, I hope that you come back to debrief us on the European Council, together with Mr. Tusk, and that this will be changed in your conclusions, so that at least the principle of the Commission proposal is agreed to. That brings me to my second point: the fight against terrorism. Let me also say here that it is not your fault, I think that Mr Tusk’s services have prepared it, and the conclusions are completely weak. The only thing about the fight against terrorism is that on Thursday and Friday you are going to have enhanced information sharing. Then there are two pages about all the stuff on enhanced information sharing that you are going to do in the coming days. Well, we do not need enhanced information sharing. We need mandatory information sharing as fast as possible. That is my plea to the Commission. Is it not possible for the Commission to come forward with what I call a ‘horizontal mandatory sharing of information’ clause? You could do it by a regulation, for example. By horizontal, it means that it should apply to all databases that we process. That could be the Schengen information system, ECRIS, the Europol databases, the Frontex databases and the 28 new PNR databases. Why is it not possible for you to say in one regulation that, from now on, there will be a horizontal mandatory sharing of information flow between all these databases in Europe? That is my second point. My third and last point concerns the point made by Mr Kamall. I do not know whether he is playing Mr Jekyll or Mr Hyde, whether he is a British Conservative or the leader of the ECR group, on Brexit. My appeal, Mr Kamall, is to look at it in a positive, constructive and offensive, rather than defensive, way. In my opinion, it is an opportunity to reform Europe. So let us add to the four requests of the British Government all the in—depth reforms we desperately need in Europe: new governance for the eurozone, new tools for the geopolitical challenges we face. Why not a defence community? I agree with the British Prime Minister, Mr Cameron, when he rejects an ever-closer union. We do not need an ever-closer union. We desperately need a federal union – that is very clear – between the European Member States. That is what we need. So I agree with him.  Finally, to Mr Weber: it is true that there were good things in 2015 as well, and we have made progress, but for the sake of our health, let us make 2016 better than 2015 to make Europe great. (Applause)  (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: James CARVER
text: blue-card question. – Mr Verhofstadt, once you have stopped waving your arms around all over the place doing an excellent impersonation of a  sky-diving octopus, won’t you perhaps stop to consider the use of your words ‘EU projects’. Do you not understand, Sir, that this is not some classroom project, but actually the lives and aspirations of 500 million people from 28 very different countries? Do you not understand, Mr Verhofstadt, that you are playing Games without Frontiers? C’est jeux sans frontières!

name: Guy VERHOFSTADT
text: blue-card answer. – So I can no longer play octopus? Maybe a shark would suit you better: it could eat you up. That said, the people in Europe – the 500 million citizens in Europe – know very well that their future does not lie in retreating behind national borders. The world of tomorrow will be a world dominated by China, India, the US and the Russian Federation, and if we want to play a role we have to do it together or not at all.

name: Gabriele ZIMMER
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the Mr Juncker, you rightly said earlier that it will never be easy in Europe, it has never been and will not be in the future. But I am convinced that if now – with a quick shot – the Member States are required to be prepared to renounce their sovereignty rights in order to establish a European external border protection authority and then also to be able to act against their will and then, at the same time, to hang on to those who do not agree with it, should not be entitled to the Schengen area, then I believe that this is not constructive and that this does not contribute to creating trust between the Member States. After all, the experience of recent years has meant that we often speak with a split tongue, that, on the one hand, declarations are made, demands are made, commitments are made, pressure is put on, we do not shy away from blackmailing Member States, and, in the end, even undermining their own constitution, in order ultimately to meet the demands of the EU institutions.  For me, that is the point where I ask myself the question: what are we actually doing now? Where did we get to? Are we really on the way to stabilising the European Union and the social, political and the whole situation? Or are we now running again with waving flags in a direction that leads us to encounter more and more contradictions among the people? I believe that it is primarily a question of advancing the common path. I would also ask you to stand up for this. I would also like to make it very clear to the Council during the Council meeting that the promises made at previous summits are kept. We are talking about the hotspots, which are about providing sufficient staff to operate them in the first place. I am thinking of Greece in particular. But it is also about the commitments that people who come to Greece or to the other countries will be distributed. If only 34 people have been brought to Luxembourg so far, what does it have to do with honesty? We cannot say on the one hand that Greece has to comply with the rules, we have to enforce measures, but we leave Greece alone in resolving the great refugee issue. When it comes to honesty, I am now also asking myself about what I have heard on the question of the accession process for Turkey, namely to keep it open. I was a we dismay to see who applauded. Representatives of parties that are members of the Federal Government have applauded for saying: we are in favour, we should tell the truth. We have no chance for the future. Why then do we sit down with you and agree on things that are supposed to solve the refugee issue, look away at what is happening in Turkey? We do not comment on the issue of dealing with journalists on the crimes committed in the Kurdish regions. We accept that the Turkish authorities are asking Syrian refugees to decide whether to go to detention centres or back to Syria. What is this? Why can we stand here and say: yes, we are asking for the next chapter to be opened or we are opening it up? But let us be honest: they will never become members of the European Union. I really wonder where we are? Are we playing honestly or are we really just trying to assert our own interests, those of the big ones? What happens as a whole, what happens to our values, our demands, our vision, our vision of a just Europe, a just European Union, is a wet sweep. Thank you, such a Union, I do not want that! (Applause) (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: David COBURN
text: blue-card question. – It seems to me that you fear Mr Verhofstadt’s pan-European State Police as much as I do. It seems to be set up to cover up the EU’s disastrous immigration policy. Would you agree with me on that, Madam?

name: Gabriele ZIMMER
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. I have a significant problem, As I said, with the way in which we deal with the sovereignty of states here. But you personally do not agree on any issue.

name: Philippe LAMBERTS
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Europe still has at least one world championship title to defend, that of unfinished construction. We made a federal common currency without putting in place a federal government with a federal budget. We realize today that this does not work and we are therefore trying, in a hurry, to remedy these fundamental construction defects.  We have made a free movement zone for citizens to which we are extremely attached - as well as to the single currency - but without establishing a common management not only of borders, but also of migration and asylum policy.  So I was very honestly expecting - so I'm a little naïve, I know, the Greens are like that - that the Commission would yesterday propose a significant step forward that would allow us to remedy the problem. In other words, a step through which all of us, member states of the Schengen area, would decide to entrust to a European agency both the surveillance of our borders and the means that go with it - whether it is border surveillance, the reception and registration, of course, of asylum seekers and migrants, the fight against organised crime, especially against smugglers, rescue at sea. In short, this is what I expected.  Instead, we receive a proposal which is in fact to create a kind of emergency response body to help Member States overwhelmed by a wave of asylum or migration applications. Well, this is a situation that we obviously know and it seems to me quite natural that we should be able to go to the rescue of a Member State. But where the problem lies is that, when you read what is written in the proposal, you see that this force could be deployed in a Member State without it asking for it, but that it would be placed under its responsibility. Let me explain: a Member State would see a group of border police arrive at home who would take charge of border management without his request. Imagine for a moment that violations of European law and human rights are committed; it would be the responsibility of the Member State, which accepts this force against its will. There, it seems to me, is a fundamental manufacturing defect, which I believe is a serious offence to the most basic principles of law. So it's clear that your copy will have to be seriously reviewed if we want to make it something that holds up a little bit. In any case, Mr Juncker, I would like to remind you of one of your commitments that you have made repeatedly in this House: you have said that a legal path must be put in place - I say 'legal' - access to Europe. If you want to put an end to the smugglers' business, if you want to stop these permanent tragedies at sea, you need a legal path. And I didn't find it in what you proposed. In any case, the answer cannot be - and I would like to see it not forgotten - that of President Tusk, who, with his finest pen, wrote ten days ago that, in fact, one could perfectly envisage the imprisonment of asylum seekers in Europe for 18 months. Indeed, when you compare his attitude to that of your Liberal colleague Trudeau in Canada, you see that there is more than a nuance. I therefore find this attitude unacceptable and unworthy on the part of the President of the European Council and a member of the EPP. Finally, it is true that - I repeat Gabi Zimmer's comments on Turkey - you have the art of making the carpet in front of our friend Erdogan, this new Putin of the Sublime Gate. It's still amazing that we go to make salamalecs in front of a guy who imprisons his journalists, who dismisses his policemen and judges when they do not do what he asks them to do, who personally pursues journalists and attacks them in front of what is left of the justice system in Turkey, and who starts to wage a war against his own people, all because we want him to keep as many refugees as possible at home, I find that unworthy. I would like to make one final point. We have an agreement that we welcome, which took place in Paris last week, and I would like us not to underestimate its importance because in Europe we think that we have always been the leaders. What I see is that all the European policies adopted here have been based on the idea that climate change should be limited to two degrees - by the way, they do not even succeed. However, what has been granted to Paris is well below two degrees and as close as possible to one and a half degrees. This therefore calls for a review now - I say now - of the policies adopted by the European Union, in order to achieve the objectives we have set for ourselves. (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (in accordance with Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation))

name: Georgi PIRINSKI
text: blue-card question. – Mr Lamberts, one of the issues which are continuously being swept under the carpet is the Labour Mobility Package. You have pointed to the danger of avoiding problems that then come up into our face. Would you support the proposal for a key debate on the whole range of such issues? It is obvious that, if we are talking about a properly-functioning internal market, if we are talking about avoiding the dire problems of social injustice, we need a very serious and involved debate with the full participation of the President of the Commission and all of the responsible officials.

name: Philippe LAMBERTS
text: "blue card" answer. I fully agree with you, Mr Pirinski. I note, at least in my country, and I know that this is the case in France in particular, that the effects of social dumping that the free movement of workers allows are one of the main factors in the emergence of parties such as that of the National Front in France. This is an extremely acute concern for many of our fellow citizens, and a solution must be found.  But this cannot be done at the expense of the free movement of workers, which, for me, is a basic principle of our European Union. It must take into account the interests of both the developed countries, the Eastern and southern European Union countries. Everyone should be able to enjoy it, which is why there is no simple solution. Nevertheless, this debate is indeed extremely urgent, and I regret that the Commission has, once again, postponed this discussion.

name: Nigel FARAGE
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, another European summit and yet another power grab ... It is funny, every single time a European Union policy fails, and that is pretty often, the demand is for more centralisation and ‘more Europe’. And by any measure, the EU’s common asylum policy – albeit given rocket boosters by Chancellor Merkel – has been a dramatic failure. Not only will millions continue to come, few of whom, of course, would qualify as genuine refugees, but it has become an open invitation to terrorism. So our solution is that the EU border agency and the EU maritime services should be given powers and the ability to declare force majeure over the Member States! Incredibly, the British Prime Minister, David Cameron, is supporting this. Yet that is the same Prime Minister who is going to have a meeting with you tomorrow night to talk about our so-called renegotiation. I hope he fares better than last time. The last time he attempted this he got to speak at one o’clock in the morning, spoke for a total of seven minutes, in the middle of which the French President, Monsieur Hollande, got up and went out for a pee. So I hope they take him a bit more seriously this time, though I sense that nobody in this room is exactly quaking in their boots. After all, he has asked for almost nothing, and he is unlikely to even get that. However, I am sure we will be treated to the usual theatricals. A grave-faced Prime Minister will come back to Britain to say how tough the negotiations have been but that he will not give in, and there will be hints that, perhaps, the Prime Minister will even support Brexit if he does not get his way. I think we should take that about as seriously as when he banged the table and said he would not pay the GBP 1.75 billion surcharge 18 months ago, and then meekly obliged. In February the charade will come back: there will be a European summit and, on something minor and inconsequential, there will be a deal, and a referendum will happen in June 2016. Opposition to this project is growing right across the continent: 15% of the Hungarian population have now signed a petition against migrant quotas. We saw an extraordinary advance by the French National Front in the elections in France last week, but so far nobody has reached the tipping point. Well, the British referendum may be that moment, and the momentum is on our side. It is not just about getting back national democracy: it is about getting back national self-confidence. For those of us who believe in nation-state democracy, 2016 is a very bright dawn indeed. (Applause from certain quarters) (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". If the British people were to share your views on the European Union and on Mr Cameron's weakness, why wouldn't they have sent UKIP to the House of Commons with more than one mandate?

name: Nigel FARAGE
text: blue-card answer. – Mr Lucke, as you may or may not understand, we have a very odd electoral system in the United Kingdom. I would remind you, in the European elections, UKIP won those elections. Right across the continent we are seeing, in the centre, the left and the right, genuine opposition to the European project growing. The disappointment, Mr Lucke, is that people like you in Germany, who have been critical of so many aspects of the Union, of so much about the euro, appear not to have the courage to logically follow through your own convictions and to conclude that this project is the wrong project. What we want is a Europe of democratic nation-states, trading together, being friends together, but without the flag, without the anthem, without the Commission and without the European Parliament. (Applause from the EFDD Group)

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, ladies and gentlemen, let us run away! This could be the next theme of the European Council. Pretending to fight terrorism, the leaders of the Council do not mention the passage of hundreds or even thousands of terrorists among the flow of migrants. However, it is through this that most of the murderers of November 13 in Paris, as their leader, who transited through Greece, acted. The Schengen Treaty is at the root of our problems, and we would like to go further in a system that has failed. The same is true of economic and monetary union. The Council intends to strengthen it, while its failure is glaring. Only a policy adapted to each state, based on a concerted exit from the euro, could enable the peoples of Europe to avoid austerity, recession and sacrifice. The next Brexit issue could call into question your suicidal choices. The peoples of Europe demonstrate this in each of the elections in the Member States. Ladies and gentlemen, Europeans no longer want your technocratic, cosmopolitan and ultraliberal Europe. Europeans want a Europe of nations and freedoms: the only solution for a true future of European civilization.

name: Diane DODDS
text: – Madam President, the Council of Ministers meeting this week is viewed with a great deal of interest in the United Kingdom, and many view it as a serious test of whether these institutions are capable of change and reform. A few weeks ago David Cameron published his agenda for negotiation. It is an agenda without ambition and very far removed from his stated aims for renegotiation in his Bloomberg speech of 2013. Back then he promised opt-outs from EU legislation, control over migration, curbs on the European courts and, fundamentally, he demanded treaty change. Today he has limited himself to so-called changes that merely reflect the status quo and a vague demand for greater competitiveness within the single market. His proposals around benefit uptake have met with fierce resistance. So is this Union up for negotiation? Are the European institutions capable of change? Or as many of my constituents believe, are we simply left to pay the bill while having our concerns ignored? It is a stern test for David Cameron. It is an even bigger test for Brussels, and the scant reference to this in both the Commission and Council contributions this morning does not bode well. Many in the UK have already decided, with the polls showing growing numbers opting for Brexit. Members, the ball is in your court. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Philippe LAMBERTS
text: blue-card question. – Ms Dodds, I heard what you said. I think that your Prime Minister has got himself into a corner by asking things that he knows pretty well cannot be achieved, especially in terms of freedom of movement. I believe that the real question that the British people have to answer is whether they believe that they will be stronger on their own, being 1% of the global population, albeit with Trident submarines – I am not sure that gives you a lot – or by sharing sovereignty to be part of a bloc that can really have influence in this world. (Cries of ‘Rubbish!’ from the EFDD Group)

name: Diane DODDS
text: blue-card answer. – If I may say so, the very question mirrors the attitude of the institutions towards the British renegotiation issue. It is a matter of dilution, dilution, dilution, until you give nothing. That has the effect in the United Kingdom of growing the numbers for Brexit: you can choose which way it will go.

name: Angelika NIEBLER
text: Madam President, Mr President of the Commission, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for the work he has said on that he has been working on the work he has said. The signal that will be sent out from the summit tomorrow and the day after tomorrow will determine how we start in the new year. Is the European Union perceived as a divisive team in which every player plays his game and ends up losing everyone, or as a closed team that pursues goals together, who know what it is worth fighting for together? The Commission, Mr President of the Commission, is fighting for a common Europe, and the majority of us in the European Parliament, as well as the President-in-Office of the Council. First of all, I would like to thank the Commission, which has always stressed the commonground and is fighting for a strong Europe and which is constantly putting forward constructive proposals to tackle the enormous challenges we face – not least yesterday, with regard to European border and coastal protection. President Juncker, you mentioned Schengen. Schengen is one of our greatest achievements: freedom of movement, travel in the Schengen area without controls. Schengen presupposes securing the external border. It presupposes that it is checked that it is registered who enters the Schengen area. It has been right that hotspots should be set up at the external borders, that member states should be pushed and that help in securing the external borders should be accepted and cooperated. It is also right, as proposed yesterday, to establish a common border and coastal protection. Mr President-in-Office of the Council, you are now called upon to do so. I ask you wholeheartedly: exert pressure, apply diplomacy to persuade the Member States to send out a united signal for a common Europe tomorrow.  (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Janusz KORWIN-MIKKE
text: question asked by picking up a blue card. – In 1933, Liechtenstein refused to join the Third Reich. I understand that being attached to the Third Reich would be much more powerful and would have much greater capabilities. Liechtenstein has not joined the European Union at this time. I understand that he is having terrible difficulties in paying for energy at the moment, and there is terrible poverty in this country in general. Are you advising Liechtenstein to join the European Union?

name: Angelika NIEBLER
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur This question does not arise at the moment and will only arise if Liechtenstein so wishes.  I think it's just important for us to look forward. We had a tough 2015. We have tried to deal with the crises to the best of our knowledge and belief, including here in the European Parliament. I think we should look ahead and see how we can deliver what the people of Europe expect of us: that we can move forward with our common Europe, secure our external borders and also deal with the people in need of help who are arriving here in a humane manner.

name: Enrique GUERRERO SALOM
text: – Madam President, throughout 2015 the European Council has been changing the main focus of its concern: at the beginning of the year, it was the Greek crisis and terrorism with Charlie Hebdo; in the spring, it was the refugee and immigrant crisis; and then we also had the crisis over terrorism. But just because the focus has changed doesn't mean the crises are gone: they're all there, they're all together. And while some of them apparently do not concern us as dramatically as in the past, the economic and employment crisis, however, remains the main concern of European citizens.  Firstly, because of the legacy of the crisis itself: in terms of unemployment — it is going to be extremely serious for young people and long-term left-handers — in terms of social and territorial divergences and also in terms of loss of labour rights and wage conditions. But it's not just about the legacy. The present: our growth is weak, it is around 1.5%, half as much as in the United States; our unemployment is high, it's around 11%, twice as high as in the United States. And we are not preparing for the future either: our investment gap remains very high. The year 2015 has meant less than 2014 and 2014 less than 2013. We must therefore assume that while we do not face an economic crisis dramatically, it remains important. Finally, I would like to ask the Commission a question, to which I express my support: is it true that, after the September and November summits, at which 160 000 relocations were agreed, only one hundred have been implemented? If that is true, it is a disgrace to the Member States.

name: Anna FOTYGA
text: "We have developed the right strategy. However, its implementation is still delayed." This is a quote from President Tusk's letter inviting him to the European Council. There are many sensible proposals on its agenda, such as the PNR, but I do not include in this set the project to create a European border and coast guard. This project violates the political foundations of several countries. It is also questionable under european Union primary law. The extension of the Community method in an extremely sensitive and crucial area of security will not replace interstate solidarity. And it is the Member States that are responsible for security.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: – Madam President, a couple of months ago while referring to the European Council conclusions on the enhancement of the mandate for Frontex, I was very critical. I expected much more, and I need to applaud President Juncker today for having delivered something that is much more significant. This is an answer to the concerns of citizens, who say ‘we want Schengen’ and ‘we want security inside Schengen’. This is a proper proposal. We now expect the Council to deliver this week and approve it. Of course, this is one leg. I would like to see in the future the second leg, because talking about capacities, whether 1 000 plus 1 500 is sufficient or not, we will have to see. I am sure that we will need integrated military forces in the future. This is another element and something we should work on in the future.  A final remark on the sharing of information. The terrorist who was stopped at the Belgian border was covered by one database in connection with property crime, but he was also in the Europol database for connections to terrorist organisations. We failed. We need to connect these. This is the task for the immediate future.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: – Madam President, the approaches of this European Council are going in the wrong direction, the same direction that we saw in the debate on the state of the Union or in the revision of European neighbourhood policy, and which only aggravates the deadly crisis in this European Union.  They talk about immigration crises when it is refugee crisis – the biggest crisis since World War II – and refugees flee wars, in which we have a great responsibility to pursue other people's interests that want a destabilized Mediterranean or a burned Mashreq.  This crisis is not solved by raising the walls of the fortress; it is not solved with a superpolycy above nation-states. It is not solved by rewarding partners, such as Turkey, who use refugees as a weapon; that allow the smuggling of oil from the Dáesh; invading a country like Iraq; bombing kurds and Kurds; or that, under NATO's umbrella, provocations are allowed against a neighboring nuclear power like Russia. Nor is it solved without cooperation to mitigate economic asymmetry.  Nor is terrorism being combated by eliminating our freedoms; within the EU, asymmetric proposals, military measures or states of emergency, but with intelligence, under the protection of the rule of law, and partners that do not tolerate or promote Wahhabism are not combated; on the ground, deepening international law. They are putting nails in the coffin of the European Union , we saw it with non-solidarity in Greece – raising that fortress, taking away freedoms in the face of threats, or with an unjust economy. They are on the right track, the path of the implosion of this European Union which does not care for its peoples.  (He agreed to answer a question posed under the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Regulation))

name: Olaf STUGER
text: "blue card" question. I would like to ask my colleague something. He speaks very big words about the responsibilities we have in taking in so-called victims of war or refugees. Can I ask about the personal responsibility of my colleague? How many refugees has he taken into his home and how is that going at the moment?

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: "blue card" response. – Personal responsibility is in my political responsibility to promote one of the good things that this European Union established and which is called the right of asylum, and not the right of hatred that you promote.

name: Jill EVANS
text: – Madam President, at a date yet to be announced my constituents in Wales will be faced with a choice that will affect us for generations to come: voting on whether or not to remain in the European Union. For my party, Plaid Cymru, and for many in Wales – like local authorities, businesses and voluntary organisations – EU membership is vital in building our economy and our communities.  Wales has benefited from EU solidarity through the Structural Funds and from legislation protecting workers, the environment, our rural areas and much more. I know that Wales has a great deal to contribute to making the EU more effective and improving Europe for all our peoples. We want to engage far more directly, positively and proactively. We want to work together in the interests of peace, social justice and sustainability. There may be no decision taken this week in relation to the UK, but I want to send a strong message that we will be making a very clear and positive case for remaining in the EU in Wales’s interest and Europe’s interests. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: David COBURN
text: blue-card question. – Ms Evans, considering that your party, the Welsh Nationalists, are doing so badly in the polls in Wales and that UKIP are doing so well – and it looks as if they are going to get a lot of representation in Wales – would you not say that the Welsh people agree more with UKIP than with you?

name: Jill EVANS
text: blue-card answer. – What we need, and what we are leading, in Wales is a very factual and very honest debate on where the interests of the people of Wales lie. That has been shown clearly time and time again to be in the EU as a small successful nation with a strong economy. I have yet to hear UKIP put forward any policies that will benefit people in Wales.

name: David BORRELLI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, as external tensions and pressures multiply, Europe has no other way but to return to economic growth and resolve the ambiguity of its cultural identity.  The economic crisis has caused the middle class to shift to poverty. The myopic austerity policies have not made it possible to alleviate the suffering of many through simple and immediate solidarity measures, such as citizenship income. So many disintegrating tensions and pushes would have been avoided if more understanding had been shown towards the devastating social effects of strict policies.  The crisis has deformed Europe, which today, weaker than ever, is investing ever greater resources to defend itself against terrorist attacks and migratory pressures, but does not adequately support the main solution: economic growth. If there is growth there is room for everyone, if there is no growth, border closures will multiply. Then there is the question of cultural identity, ours are so many different cultures, they have not become more than the sum of its components, if anything, something less, much less, a frightened and fragmented society.  A Europe that is uncertain about its common good is a Europe that generates within it the seeds of radicalism, which are now increasingly difficult to combat. This year's efforts to promote growth are proving insufficient, in some ways they are exacerbating inequalities. We need to think more about the common challenges of our industrial policy, which is made up not only of services and digital, but above all of manufacturing. That is why we want to call on this summit to rediscover a concrete political vision and a moral drive capable of convincing and involving our fellow citizens so that our fellow citizens can see a European Union that is also useful to them.

name: Marcel de GRAAFF
text: – The EU Counter-Terrorism Coordinator Gilles de Kerchove proposes that Member States should take in and rehabilitate returned jihadists. Special programmes should be provided as an alternative to imprisonment.  This proposal has no respect whatsoever for the dead of Bataclan, for the dead of Sinjar, for Lee Rigby, for Muath al-Kasasbeh and for all those other victims of the beasts who are called "veterans" here. Mr President, a cunning and insane plan that puts the safety of our citizens at risk. Perpetrators of beheadings rapes, torture and slave trade are not veterans. They are enemies who spread Islam by death and death. I offer the Council of Ministers an alternative proposal: throw them out, keep them out and close all national borders.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI). Mr President, the implementation of decisions to tackle migration flows is a tombstone for Europe of solidarity, co-decisions and equal sovereign states. It turns out that institutions, elected or not, fail to understand and provide correct solutions. When the economic crisis in Greece caught them off guard to deal with it, they altruistically proposed Greece's exit from the Currency Union, with the non-paper Schäuble, at a Eurogroup meeting. Unable to control migration flows, many countries are standing fences and unilaterally abolishing the Schengen Treaty while some are discussing Greece's exit from it. Jihadists are killing innocent people and you have decided to give 3 billion euros to Turkey which helps, equips, co-targets the Islamic State. I therefore call on you to accept Turkey into Europe and all your problems will be solved automatically. Constant misjudged decisions lead to the need to find scapegoats and defendants. The countries of Europe - take notice - only with nationalist governments can get rid of this lailapa.

name: Jacek SARYUSZ-WOLSKI
text: – Mr President, as the EU Council will address the issue of the Energy Union, I would like to quote the EPP Group position on the matter, adopted unanimously in our recent strategic position paper on the external dimension of energy security. I quote: ‘We, the EPP Group, believe that the Nord Stream 2 agreement is not in line with the EU strategy of diversification of sources of supply and routes of transit of imported energy, as well as the EU’s energy security strategy and foreign security and Eastern Partnership policy goals, reinforcing the EU’s dependency on Russian gas supply’. My comment is this: Nord Stream 2 is being pursued by the Commission as a purely commercial project. My question is: if a project is negotiated in person by the President of Russia, Putin, and the Vice-Chancellor of a Member State, is such a project purely a commercial one? The Commission considers that Nord Stream requires only a legal analysis. This is fundamentally wrong; it is a geopolitical project that can be detrimental to our security. It contradicts the energy security strategy, the Energy Union itself, and the foundations of our foreign security Eastern Neighbourhood Partnership policy goals. It is in breach of European solidarity and against the spirit of the sanctions on Russia; it is harmful to the interests of Ukraine, Belarus, Poland and Slovakia; and it can be a political game-changer, reinforcing the power position of one single gas supplier, reinforcing the Union’s dependence, and further exposing Eastern Member States and their Eastern neighbours to Russia’s pressure and blackmail.   (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Blue card question. – I am very pleased that the Member has brought up this issue. This is indeed one of the most important cases. Although there is at least one ruling party in the ranks of the People's Party – fidesz led by Viktor Orban – that is constantly out of line with separate policies, separate business with Putin. With all due respect, how do you treat this within the People's Party?

name: Jacek SARYUSZ-WOLSKI
text: blue-card answer. – On energy policy, we think that the Hungarian Government is not in line with EPP priorities, both in terms of its atomic enterprise deal with Russia, and also in terms of its general line on Russia. But this does not concern the issue which I raised, which is Nord Stream 2.

name: Tanja FAJON
text: – It is clear to everyone that we have exceptional problems, because countries do not implement measures to alleviate the situation with refugees and migrants. The devil is in the details of various suggestions. Moving people, returning those who are not eligible for international protection, identification when they enter the Union – these are all ambitious proposals, but there are no steps. Schengen is at stake, countries are introducing enhanced border controls. It pains me to monitor the construction of a fence on my country's borders, people-to-people relations are strained, distrust and intolerance grow. And all because in Slovenia, too, the belief prevailed that we are left to ourselves and that we will not be able to handle a new wave of newcomers from the Balkan route. We need clear commitments from leaders at this week's summit. The countries of the Western Balkans will not be able to provide support to the pressure of refugees for no longer. Additional financial assistance will be needed. We must be aware that more than 2 million refugees remain in Turkey and that, for now, there is no end to the conflict in Syria.  We urgently need to improve the management of the Union's external borders, helping not only the countries along the Balkan route, but the preservation of the Schengen area. And that must be our advantage, not the dangerous attempts to create a mini Schengen that will break europe. Freedom of movement is a symbol of our integration. Colleagues, the dignity of Europe will only survive if we act in solidarity and humanely. Today's Europe is no longer a Europe of solidarity. It is a Europe of indifference. We make history here and it's up to us to make 2016 a better year. I therefore call on the European Union Summit to take full responsibility for the implementation of all the commitments and for Schengen to remain as we know it. (The speaker agreed to accept the question raised by raising the blue card (Rule 162(8)).

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: question posed by raising the blue card. Thank you very much for accepting the blue card. Mrs. Fajon, I want to ask you something very simple. You talk about the need for freedom of movement, about solidarity in Europe, about the need to respect our relationships and values. I agree with you that we have problems with migrants, but do you agree with me that the placement of razor wire that the Slovenian government places all over the border, from the Mura to the Adriatic Sea, and especially in the part where you yourself know that there will never be migrants, and that is in the territory of Istria and Gorski Kotar, do you really think that this is completely unnecessary?

name: Tanja FAJON
text: The answer to the question raised by raising the blue card. - Dear Colleague. It hurts me the same way you do when I look at fences at our borders. It hurts people on both sides of our border. But that's exactly what I'm warning you. The unresponsiveness of European governments, the irresponsibility of a range of European politicians. Also directly in our neighbourhood, in Hungary. So do it again. Only together can we calm the situation. With good cooperation, especially between neighbouring countries. And Schengen must remain as we know it. Fences, wires must become part of the past.

name: Vicky FORD
text: – Mr President, tomorrow European leaders will discuss the single market, migration and Brexit. British voters are split 50:50. The single market has made it easier to trade in 28 countries with 500 million consumers and I would like to see it more dynamic, but unless substantial changes are made, Britain will vote to leave. The UK will not join the euro, it cannot be part of the ever closer union or the social pillar, and it is vital that countries outside the eurozone cannot be discriminated against by a cartel of those within. This is a key point in the British negotiation.  On migration, the region I represent has experienced more EU migration than any other part of the UK.
