Free movement is a cherished right, but unlimited access to healthcare welfare has proved unsustainable and builds resentment. In two years’ time Britain may well have voted to leave. I urge leaders to please listen carefully to our requests and try to make progress.

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: Mr President, it is clear that Europe must regain its capacity to act; we've wasted a lot of time. So it's more than urgent.  Yes, of course, we have to control our own borders. This debate is still surreal; It's a no-brainer! If we fail to do so, Schengen will die! Schengen goes hand in hand with the control of our external borders. All the great powers of the world operate that way. We have been asking for years for a coastguard and border guard corps. I hope we will finally go in that direction.  Yes, we also need a harmonised European asylum policy. What about? What about the necessary revision of Dublin? What about the list of safe countries, which is still not on the table, when we have been talking about it for many months?  Finally, and to move very quickly, yes, the European Union must work on an end to the crisis and a political outcome for Syria. We have to give opportunities to this country, it is vital. But all this, and I say this to the Commission, as in the Council, we will only do so if there is a shared political will between the Commission and all the Member States. (The speaker agreed to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation))

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: "blue card" question. Mrs de Sarnez, it was Mr Verhofstadt who proposed a European anti-terrorist agency. Do you think that this is a good proposal and that we will ultimately have to implement it, taking into account all the terrorist attacks that have taken place in Europe?

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: "blue card" answer. "Dear colleague, it is obvious that terrorists are playing with borders and that we have work to do together from that point of view. Cooperation between all intelligence services must be strengthened and improved. There needs to be mandatory data sharing for anything that is sensitive data. I also want to add the pooling of a file of foreign fighters, which does not yet exist at the time I am speaking to you.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: – Mr President, Mr Juncker said that these are times of change. I can't agree more, although I think we differed quite a bit on what that means.  We need a change in Europe's model: to build a social Europe that restores its founding values of democracy, well-being and social rights. We also need a change in foreign policy: a policy that is based on democracy, human rights and development.  We have a responsibility to design a policy of welcoming refugees who have been escaping war and terror. Here we will be in favour of all humanitarian measures that go in this regard. However, the solution to the refugee crisis and the problem of terrorism goes through a just peace in the Middle East that stabilizes the area. We do not want social democratic or conservative leaders who compete with the far right in the free display of military might or in the cutting of freedoms and rights. We need a European Union that will help to pacify and democratise this region with the weapons of politics and not with the weapons of war.  If we do not want Euroscepticism, disaffection towards the European project, we cannot allow Europe to continue to become synonymous with social cuts, job precariousness and mass impoverishment. Today there are 23 million jobless people in the European Union and almost 10% of poor workers. We don't want any more makeup from the same policies for economic elites! That is what they are proposing to us again with their project to strengthen economic and monetary union.  We need a 180-degree shift, democratise the European Central Bank and boost job creation through an ambitious public investment plan, and use those resources to create millions of jobs in sectors such as the green economy, new technologies, care or public services. European Socialists can choose between Jeremy Corbyn's path – betting on social Europe, opposing TTE, seeking peace in the Middle East – or continuing to support austerity policies that benefit that 1% that concentrates a third of wealth in Europe, while condemning social majority to take on their excesses.

name: Ska KELLER
text: – Mr President, First Vice-President Timmermans said yesterday that the problem we have in Europe is the many irregular entries, and that these need to be stopped. But those people who are coming irregularly are refugees, and refugees are in need of protection. Refugees are not the problem we have in Europe. The problem we have is the distribution of refugees and the lack of solidarity. We cannot turn refugees away if we are to follow our own laws and our own morals. But this is exactly what the Commission is not proposing to do with the new Frontex mandate, because Frontex, in coordination and cooperation with third countries, will make sure that those people in need of protection will never make it to European shores. This is already happening. But in future the closing of borders will even be mandatory for Member States. Member States who do not close their borders completely will be punished. On the other hand, we see a resettlement proposal. That is very nice, but resettlement will be voluntary. Why is it that Europe can always agree to make closing borders mandatory but, when it is about welcoming refugees, it is up to every Member State to decide if they want to? This Commission proposal is simply a new Troika, this time for borders. This is not the face of Europe that I want to see.  * **

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: I would like to greet in the gallery a group of young firefighters from the island of Korcula and the Peljesac Peninsula in Croatia, who fought against the fire this summer and saved many lives. We thank them and greet them affectionately. * **

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: – Indeed, the agenda for the Council of Europe will probably be plentiless, but in this case I would like to ask perhaps not on the subject. Can it be constructive? And that's why. It is as if all important topics are to be covered, unfortunately without distinction or focus on the most important. Maybe because we are still unable to find a common denominator to identify that most important topic. Which one: refugees, a planned referendum in Britain, or maybe euro zone affairs and its recession, or maybe the situation in Syria, maybe ukraine, the fight against terrorism, the management of the migration crisis, relations between the European Union and Russia, the development of the NORDSTREAM pipeline or the UK's proposals for reform of the Euro Union. In the light of the Communication from the Commission, the European Council will examine the issues of completing the European single market in all its aspects. The European Council will also discuss the energy union, the Digital Single Market and the Capital Market Union based on smart climate policy. I believe that the agenda for the European Council must be much more specific and, in principle, focused solely on a few problems. Today, in my understanding, the problem number one in Europe is the migrant crisis. It is in this context that we are looking for the best answers and opportunities to solve the problem. Not suitable quota, let's look for another option. We do not like border control, let us offer other solutions. Britain's questions about the referendum seem problematic, let us look for a sensible answer to them. However, to come together again, to turn once again into a problem without offering a concrete, expeditious action plan for a solution is a hoax for society.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. Terrorism has now entered Europe. The currency is collapsing, and for a few months now we have had a migration of peoples of almost biblical proportions. The reaction of the European nomenklatura, the Heads of State or Government, is to show complete unplannedness. Almost like a heap of chickens, they're tinkering around without developing a plan. First of all, it was said that all migrants can come in. Then it was said: But not everyone can come in. Then they said: let us close the borders. Then the borders were reopened. Then they said that Schengen would be suspended. Then Schengen will apply again. Then they said that Dublin would be suspended. Then Dublin will be back. Now, at least, it has been agreed to protect the external borders. I take a cautiously positive view of this.  However, if this Europe does not succeed in being able to protect our identity, that we can protect the diversity of our cultures, then this Europe will also fail, and then you, who are causing all this chaos, will be made the gravediggers of European identity.

name: Bruno GOLLNISCH
text: Mr President, the European Council on 17 and 18 December will first address the problems of terrorism and mass immigration. It took the attacks in France and the influx of more than a million immigrants for the Brussels bureaucracy to become aware of the porous external borders of Europe. But this awareness does not extend to internal borders. How much credibility then will be given to your proposals? Mr.  Juncker said there was a need to maintain a balance between security and freedom, but some measures are more dangerous to freedoms than effective for security. I am thinking of the systematic, centralised, computerised exploitation of passenger data, which will of course end up selling off, on demand, to third countries seeking all other interests. Or the regulation of weapons, which will of course spare terrorists, who rarely ask the prefecture for permission to hold Kalashnikovs.  The breeding ground on which terrorism thrives is within the European Union and it is it that has helped to install it, without consulting the citizens.

name: Alain LAMASSOURE
text: Mr President, yes to the European Border and Coast Guard Corps, yes to the strengthening of Europol, yes to aid to Turkey, Jordan, Lebanon to ensure the accommodation and security of Syrian refugees, yes to aid to Africa, after the Europe-Africa summit in Valletta, after COP21, to help African states prevent migration, fight terrorism and develop their economies without compromising the environment. Yes, 100 times yes. But with what money?  These are Community competences, they are Community decisions, and the European budget no longer has a round! One of the lessons to be learned from these crises is that the multi-year budgetary framework decided for 7 years, frozen for 7 years, thus fixed on yesterday's priorities, is totally unsuited to today's emergencies and puts us in a dilemma: either we draw from cohesion funds, and we sacrifice the poorest regions of us, or - that is what is happening - we are creating ad hoc funds. , trust funds, small satellite budgets against which there is no effective parliamentary control, either here or in national parliaments. This dilemma is unacceptable. Next year should be devoted to the revision of the multi-year framework. Let us take this opportunity to question the very principle of this rigid framework. We will not build Europe by sacrificing the poor or sacrificing democracy. (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation))

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: blue-card question. – Mr Lamassoure, I would like to ask you a question. A few months ago, here in this Parliament, we evaluated the accession of Turkey. We evaluated the accession of Turkey, both internally and externally, and it was disappointing for human rights, and of course for the continuing illegal occupation of Cyprus. Now, due to the influx of refugees, the Commission wants to open up new chapters.  I would like your opinion on that. Is this consistent with our values and principles? Is it right for the Commission to do what it is about to do?

name: Alain LAMASSOURE
text: "blue card" answer. I do believe that two things must be clearly distinguished: on the one hand, the assistance that Turkey needs and which we must give it to deal with the refugee problem humanely, and, on the other hand, the problem of Turkey's application for membership in the European Union. We know, and Mr Kamall has said very brilliantly, that Turkey will never enter the European Union because there will not be the necessary consensus of the 28 European peoples to extend the Union to Turkey. I therefore regret that confusion is re-emerging these days between these two subjects.

name: Knut FLECKENSTEIN
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for his work and for the work he has The Chamber is relatively empty, which roughly indicates how high the expectations are for the Council. I would like to thank Minister Schmit and Minister Asselborn very warmly. I do not remember that a presidency had to break up in such a way that it had to present such unsatisfactory results and so little common ground here, and that was not because of your efforts. It has not been a good year for the EU. While the Commission and Parliament are looking for European solutions and have also found some, the Council presents itself as the addition of 28 Member States. There are two things to add: some of these EU saboteurs come back home and then scold Brussels. That cannot be a solution. The bit that was then decided is being implemented badly, slowly or not at all. Who paid into the funds? How many of the 160,000 refugees are distributed? Where are the 400 police officers to help Slovenia? Where are the hotspots in Greece? Nor is it enough for a Commissioner to fly to Greece, to Lesbos, to say that this camp is now called a hotspot, but that it also includes a little more. I hope that this will happen very soon.  There is a lack of common will and an efficient management. Instead, we are preparing for negotiations with Prime Minister Cameron. In order to win elections, he has promised a referendum and we must now help him get off the horse again. I warn against the role model danger for other states. I would ask you to be very careful with this issue. We want Britain to stay in the EU because we would be poorer without Britain. But everything has its limits: we must not shake up freedom of movement, nor are we Social Democrats prepared to accept the old ideology that the market regulates everything again on the pretext of competitiveness. I hope you will get a quick result – not because Mr Cameron has a party conference, but because I find it boring to hear a speech from Mr Farage every time, which is not addressed to us at all, but to the BBC, and after that they are all out there. Maybe the camera can show that.

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has The British Prime Minister has presented his demands for reform of the European Union. The leader of the Liberal Group, who once again shines through his absence, was right to say that the other states should also come and come up with proposals for reform. There are indeed some things to reform. There is, for example, the European Central Bank, which must once again be traced back to the tasks for which it is actually responsible: monetary policy.  The European Central Bank is not responsible for acting as a lender to indebted countries every month. This is also part of the European Union's reform agenda. There is the European stabilisation mechanism, which is a permanent breach of the non-assistance clause. This is also one of the necessary reforms for us to abolish this stabilisation mechanism, because it is contrary to the Treaty. We believe that powerful states, such as Germany, should be penalised for their current-account surpluses in Europe. Such a view is anti-competitive and anti-performance. This needs to be reformed. We cannot implement such measures. Ultimately, it is also necessary for us to give every state in Europe the right to decide freely on its currency whether it wants to enter the euro or leave the euro.

name: Maite PAGAZAURTUNDÚA
text: – Mr President, the Council moves from summit to summit and seems to be ticking many squares, but this is not the case. It reassures the public of each country.  There are one million two hundred thousand refugees fleeing wars and persecutions within Europe. But following the real relocation and resettlement data is very complicated, because it is not in the interest of saying aloud that it is about two hundred, 0.001%. We de facto assume the helplessness and overcrowding of people who carry all the traumas of war and the vexes of flight.  We don't want to see that they're like us, we're even stigmatizing them; and there are many countries, including mine, that use excuses not to accept quotas, without that having consequences. There are also minimal amounts of the planned trust funds, and the World Food Programme was left to nothing and refugees from Syria fled Turkish camps.  The model set by the Commission is possible because Dublin has not been changed; and now will hotspots become retention fields? Will those border cops serve to hold them? Will we only be effective in returning? Is this the story we want to write? Is this the story we're going to tolerate? It is a question for the Commission and for the Council.  (She agreed to answer a question posed under the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Regulation))

name: Kazimierz Michał UJAZDOWSKI
text: question asked by picking up a blue card. – Madam President, most politicians, including The President of the European Council Donald Tusk, believe that the system of relocation on a top-down basis is no longer valid, and you insist on this solution – have I understood you well? Isn't it better to look for more flexible forms with the consent of states that will have a real effect, rather than insisting on a solution that has proven completely inadequate and infunctional?

name: Maite PAGAZAURTUNDÚA
text: "blue card" response. – Mr Ujazdowski, the important thing is to find solutions. It's not that we're stubborn, it's that we have to move from words to deeds, because these people need to be welcomed. Because otherwise we would have to tell the public that we renounce our international humanitarian law, that we renounce what we have accepted, such as the fundamental values of welcome from those fleeing war.  Flexible or non-flexible? What matters here is doing things, not hiding from them.

name: Molly SCOTT CATO
text: – Mr President, I have chosen to speak about the very real risk that my country may soon leave this Union. David Cameron wants us to believe his renegotiation vision is the only show in town when it comes to EU reform. His pro—austerity, regulation—light, anti—migration rhetoric is more nightmare than vision and it appears he now wants to export and inflict this nightmare on the rest of Europe. But it is clear that his fake negotiation is unravelling.  His pledge to reduce red tape sees him doing his bit for the corporations eager to eliminate anything that stands in the way of their profits. His support for dodgy trade deals, like TTIP, shows that he is happy to see a race to the bottom on workers’ rights, environmental protection and health standards.  But many in the UK want to be part of a genuinely reformed Europe with a stronger, more effective European Parliament with greater decision-making powers and scrutiny over the Commission and Council. Greens say ‘yes’ to the EU, ‘yes’ to real reform and ‘yes’ to upholding the rights of all citizens, which Mr Cameron seems so keen to bargain away.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that the European Union is a monster, a monster has been created over the decades and this is a monster that unfortunately eats, drinks and sleeps, and the others obviously do what they want.  We are a European Union that is not even united for the bidet; you only have to go around Europe, many countries do not even have the bidet and then we talk about education and hygiene. But hygiene is talked about here and also about nutrition because it has to be said, to impose that you have to eat insects. But it is the European Union itself that says: Europeans are beginning to learn how to eat insects; but let's take the milk out of the cheese, pull the grapes out of the wine. But you're crazy, you're crazy! That is to say, someone like Juncker in my opinion – unfortunately he has left, even though he has changed hairstyles I have acknowledged the same – is one who has to go to the psychologist, because you cannot manage a European Union in this way.  We have Islamic terrorists coming. So I propose the European Guantánamo, I am going to be the director; Six months and islamic terrorists will no longer come to Europe, I assure you, the European Guantánamo!

name: Elisabetta GARDINI
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I was listening to the debate and i was reminded of a debate we had in November 2012, Angela Merkel had come to meet Parliament, and there was a great deal of reflection on what the European model is and we remembered – we were still a Europe of 27, we were about to welcome Croatia as the 28th full member of the European Union – that we represent 10% of the world's population , just over 20% of world GDP and 50% of social spending. And it was reflected that while we wanted to defend this model, we certainly had to change something to continue to support such an expensive model.  It is clear that what we are facing today is blowing up the bench, because it is a social model. I understand that so many people in the world can aspire to this model, but if we risk not being able to support it for our citizens, you will understand that we cannot offer it with the most goodwill. So it is empty to chimera those expressed by those who would like to welcome everyone and open the doors to everyone. Unfortunately, we have to put in place rules that we have to decide that we only welcome those who really run away from war and control our borders.  But there's one more thing that worries me, we have to support our economy. So, too much rhetoric about this Paris Agreement. I would ask you to monitor well what voluntary commitments countries are making because they must be of equivalent weight, otherwise we will be afflicting the competitiveness of our industry. That said, nothing is easy, but we are here to work and give answers.

name: Maria João RODRIGUES
text: – Mr President, the European project is confronted with several crises, and we need a paradigm shift that is based on the very clear idea that we have reached a point where only real European solutions can work. It is up to the Commission, the Members of the European Parliament and the Members of the European Council to tell this to the citizens. Many of them cannot understand how we have reached this point. We need to protect the Schengen area by building up a real European border, manage migration and the hosting of refugees, cope with pressures from the big powers such as China, and overcome the eurozone crisis. I would like make a final remark on the roadmap to completing economic and monetary union. If you want this roadmap to work, you need to make sure that upward economic and social convergence will be properly supported by a banking union and a fiscal capacity.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: - Mr. President, the migrant crisis has exposed major differences in attitudes about the reception of migrants between Member States. The time has come for these attitudes to finally align so that the crisis can be managed responsibly and effectively. This meeting is an ideal opportunity for an agreement that will guarantee coordination and cooperation instead of placing barbed wire fences on internal borders.  Slovenia arbitrarily placed a wire on the border with Croatia that did not deter any migrants, but because of it wild animals have been killed en masse for days, so our public witnesses scenes that are not beable for civilized Europe. Also, part of this wire is located on Croatian territory and threatens to become the subject of an interstate dispute that no one needs at the moment.  Agreement on managing the migrant crisis at the highest level is therefore necessary to preserve peace and stability, as if we continue in this direction, we will soon undo all the positive effects of European integration and take the continent back 20 years.

name: Janice ATKINSON
text: – Mr President, ahead of the Council meeting I am going to read a letter that I have written to Mr Tusk on behalf of the UK: ‘Dear Mr Tusk, as your special relationship with Mr Cameron clearly isn’t working and his so—called negotiations with you have collapsed like a pack of cards, I thought it might be helpful to outline what the British people actually want from the EU. Trade: as we are the second largest economy in the Union, we must be able to negotiate our own free- trade agreements, because one Commissioner for 28 states does not fit all. Agriculture:  a common agricultural policy costs us more to feed our own people and keeps developing countries, like Africa, in poverty. Fisheries: we want to take back control of our own territorial waters, restore our fishing fleets and protect our own fishing stocks. Justice: we do not want, and accept, a separate court in Luxembourg overruling the UK judiciary and directly elected Members of Parliament. Migration control: well, you know what the British people want here. We must have control over who comes to Britain and that is non-negotiable. You cannot deliver on this, so therefore we will Brexit’.

name: Esteban GONZÁLEZ PONS
text: – Mr President, last weekend the terrorists killed again, this time two policemen at the Spanish embassy in Kabul and, so far, no one has mentioned them in this House. If we resign ourselves to the terrorist attacks being a daily thing, in the end they will win the game and, beating us, they will win over freedom.  Europe is built and has always been built with more Europe. That is why we support the Commission's project to create a European Union coast and border guard. With no internal borders, there are no longer any external borders. There are borders of Europe. Everybody's borders.  We cannot talk about external borders as anything other than internal borders because there are no: we need to talk about borders. And the Portuguese, Spanish, Italian, Greek border is also the German border, the Belgian border and the French border; and Belgians, French and Germans are as interested as Spaniards, Portuguese, Italians and Greeks in defending that border because they are borders of all and their strengthening and security concern us all.  That is why it makes sense that all of us, also the countries of the interior, have an interest in having borders defended well and, if one country does not do its job defending its border, the others have a legitimate right to participate in the defence of that border, which is not that country's, it is everyone's. There are no longer borders of countries: there is only one border that is common, European and everyone's. Europe grows up like children: when it has a fever; But it grows.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Of course, Mrs González Pons, we all join in the grief of the families of the two Spanish agents killed in front of the Spanish Embassy in Kabul.

name: Kathleen VAN BREMPT
text: – It is the last Council this year under the Luxembourg Presidency and it has been a terrible year. We don't have to explain that, we all know that. There is, of course, a very important bright spot, and that is the climate agreement, with an incredibly clever Luxembourg Presidency and an incredibly clever Commission who have worked well together. That deserves all the credit. But that also means turning that into even more ambitious targets. That is something that you need to have a good conversation about at the Council.  I would also like to use this to talk about something else and to turn to the Commission in particular. There is a new report from Amnesty International on the situation of refugees in Turkey and that is shocking, if I may say so. Human rights are being violated on a large scale and at the very least the idea is being raised that this is also being done with support, not with our support, but with financial support from the European Union. We cannot always debate human rights with fine words here and not agitate in Turkey, where it is necessary. So I ask the Commission and, of course, the Council to take the necessary action on this matter.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by We are on the cusp, very serious. There is nothing to hide. I think it is necessary to find a healthy compromise between what most eu countries want and what a minority is ready for, that is what some have already said here. Let us take decisions that will be accepted by governments and societies, and I stress the societies of the Member States, especially those countries that have never had a colony and which are today to pay interest on this. And if we are talking about European solidarity, let us talk about it broadly, also in the context of energy policy. I have the impression that there are double standards here. There is EU solidarity. Yes, we are talking about it when there is a question of immigrants and refugees, but we do not want to talk about it in the context of, for example, Nord Stream and the second Nord Stream strand.

name: Mariya GABRIEL
text: Mr President, yes, this Council meeting is an opportunity to take stock of a year in which much has been done, but also to see realistically the work that still needs to be done. Our area of freedom, security and justice is being tested on both fronts of migration and terrorism. We must strengthen it and defend it against those who use fear as a political argument for simplistic solutions. As far as migration is concerned, the Union has reached real milestones in one year. I am thinking here of the Frontex budget, Operation Sophia, the Valletta summit, the Western Balkans route, the proposal for the new European border and coastguard agency. The implementation, on a specific and public timetable, of all these different elements requires unrelenting work. As far as the fight against terrorism is concerned, our citizens are still waiting for concrete measures. It is quite anachronistic to think in terms of national security. Which Member State can now claim to guarantee its security on its own? No. At the same time, European cooperation does not imply the absence of responsibility of each Member State. Four things to remember in the immediate future: automated cross-checking of the various European and national databases, better exploitation by Member States of the Europol file on foreign fighters, more offensive work in the production of counter-speech and rapid implementation of the PNR. Finally, four aspects not to be lost in the area of our cooperation with third countries: no blank cheque, increased support for Lebanon and Jordan, extreme vigilance for what is happening in the Sahel and North Africa and a little more concrete in the fight against the smuggling of migrants.  (The speaker agreed to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation))

name: Ana GOMES
text: blue-card question. – I have no doubt that you are a committed European and I very much agree with what you said that there should be no exploitation of fear when dealing with the fight against terrorism and, at the same time, our responsibility to welcome refugees or migrants. But that is not what Mr Tusk has been doing when he made these nasty statements about the need to have migrants and refugees in detention for over 18 months. I did not hear anyone from any political family repudiate that – or is it just a nasty competition between him and another nasty Donald?

name: Mariya GABRIEL
text: "blue card" answer. I think we have to distinguish the two logics: on the one hand, the intergovernmental logic, with the statements that are made by the Council, which is the responsibility of the Member States, and, on the other hand, the Community logic of the message we are sending here in the European Parliament, the pro-European message, the need to have a common response, to defend our values.  I think that, compared to criticisms such as those just heard, the limits of the intergovernmental approach should be clearly clarified in order to continue to move forward constructively and more concretely.

name: Dame Glenis WILLMOTT
text: – Mr President, it will not surprise anyone that I have long been a critic of David Cameron’s reckless approach to the EU. I still find it hard to believe that Britain, as a proud nation respected for its skills in diplomacy and influence throughout the world, finds itself in a situation where its position as a global leader could be under threat. But there are signs that the Prime Minister may be starting to understand that his strategy of taking our country to the brink of exit may not be a wise one. I desperately hope that sanity prevails and that a sensible deal will be reached, but regardless of what happens in the negotiations, Britain is better off in the EU and the EU is better off with Britain as a member. So I am proud that the Labour Party will be campaigning hard to make sure that Britain remains in the EU. Labour will fight to safeguard jobs. Labour will fight for security. Labour will fight to protect working rights for British people, British families and British workers. Labour will fight to keep Britain’s rightful place at the heart of the EU. (Applause)

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: – Mr President, I would like to thank the Commission and Mr Juncker for their deep commitment to preserving the Schengen system. This is very important not only for the future of some of us, but for the future of Europe.  I also share his view that, in the current difficult situation, we must act together. Each of us should assume part of the responsibility for dealing with this crisis. Only together can we make it. If we make it, this will make us stronger. Each crisis that we overcome, each programme we solve will make Europe stronger. We badly need it to be able to deal with challenges in the future.  I very much welcome the proposal of the Commission to improve the protection of our borders. This is exactly what people are legitimately asking for: to make sure that Europe protects its borders. We cannot give people the excuse that decision-making is complicated and that there are constraints in domestic policy; we must just act. I am very grateful that the Commission has finally done so. At the same time I was surprised to learn how weak our information system is on the borders of the Schengen area. We must improve it. We must have the available information and we must know who is in, and who is out. We must solve it smartly as soon as possible. As our Chair, Mr Weber, mentioned, we have a plan. We have a plan that is feasible and good. We must just fulfil it; there is no excuse for not doing so. We will support the Commission, and I hope we will succeed and get the situation on the migration crisis under control.

name: Pervenche BERÈS
text: Mr President, I agree with President Jean-Claude Juncker, when he says that the time is not half-measures. However, he should listen to Mr. Weber's response, which is that we do not need new ideas. I do not know what he is referring to, but what I do know is that, if we do not want half-measures, member states must support, implement, the Commission's new proposal to move Frontex towards a tool to complement Schengen and allow our borders to be guarded.  Having said that, the Commission must engage with the same urgency, with the same determination to sustain fiscal capacity, a budgetary capacity of the euro area, because otherwise there will be no Capital Markets Union, nor convergence. And in this respect, it is much more than half measures that we need to convince the Member States, to rebuild the European spirit, at a time when everyone is going to be engaged in a negotiation as difficult as negotiating for or against Brexit.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: – Mr Vice-President of the Commission, dear Fellow Members, Every crisis is an opportunity. The migration crisis is also an opportunity for us for the EU to take on itself and put those things, those important values, at the forefront of what we have built the whole European Union on, what we believe in, and we are using our common sense to solve the problem. So that we are not controlled by events, but by us.  I am convinced that if we bury our heads in the sand during this process, we will achieve nothing but obstruct our clarity. I am also convinced that if, in solving the problem, if we hear an opinion we do not like, we start pointing fingers at each other or initiating impeachment, we will move the process towards chaos.  Schengen must remain, say, and more and more states are calling for the temporary reintroduction of border controls. Why is it wrong for schengen defenders to comply with EU law? Why is it good that if they do enough, they will be prosecuted for misconduct, just like they are against my country. Overzealousness, stupidity, orders? I don't know. I don't know the reasons, but conflicting speech and action are always harmful. I think we need strict, fair, enforceable and enforced rules. A common solution that everyone can and wants to achieve equally.

name: Patrizia TOIA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, it is right to know the identity of those who enter our space, but it is essential that this common responsibility should be on the whole of immigration policy, from control, reception, integration and repatriation, otherwise things do not work, other than union.  So are the commitments made on hotspots, relocations and returns. In short, they are phases of a single process, if they do not all work at the same time the mechanism becomes ingstas. I speak for Italy, we have done heroically, I would like to stress, our part, when Europe was blind, silent, did not see and did not feel and we are doing our part on hotspots. But it's relocation that doesn't work, 186 people relocated, people I stress and not numbers, people out of 40,000 expected. It is a disgrace, other than accusing Italy. This is the world going backwards. When I hear Italy being accused, I think this: the world is going backwards.  And to Mrs Weber, who likes to give the votes, I would like to ask what vote she has given her colleague Mr Orbán, that of barbed wire, the one who laughs at European rules, I hope a vote of disqualification. We note that Dublin is dead, it cannot be the geographical that decides where a refugee will live, it must be our European policy of solidarity and a common policy. Let us do things decisively, otherwise it will be another blow to Europe's credibility and we Pro-Europeans would become allies and accomplices of those forces that we feel in this House that are against Europe, they are for the disintegration of Europe.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: – Mr President, first of all I would like to make it clear that the position of the Commission and, in particular, of its President here today on Schengen, is absolutely fundamental and I hope that the Council will be able to follow this position. This statement by President Juncker that under no means will he accept a limitation and schengen conditioning is as important as President Draghi's statement, when he said that he would not drop the euro under any case and would do whatever was necessary for the euro to remain. Schengen and the euro are two fundamental pillars of the European Union and the European Council must show signals as strong as those that the Commission has been able to give. I would also like to deal with another point which has not been well addressed here today and which has to do with deepening economic and monetary union. The Commission is already taking steps towards the third pillar of the Banking Union - precisely the Deposit Guarantee Scheme - and it is essential that the Council leave the ambiguous position, the equivocal position it has been in so far and that it moves forward, knowing that a single resolution mechanism will now be advanced from January 2016, which is capable of , in the first half of 2016, set up the third pillar of the Banking Union, the Deposit Guarantee System. Without this the euro is not a real currency, it needs this system of complete and closed banking union. This is what we expect from the Council this December 2015.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: – Mr President, I am in love with the families of the deceased military in Kabul.  Ladies and gentlemen, some are determined to paint reality in the colours of recovery and, in the meantime, Mr Juncker himself, a few days ago, acknowledged that we have not yet overcome the economic crisis – the millions of families in Europe, who have long suffered from the policies of cuts and austerity, are well aware of this.  The famous Juncker Plan or the Stability Pact are important instruments, but if we do not understand the need for fiscal momentum, we will be doing a weak favor. If we are not ambitious, if we do not make progress on measures in the social sphere, such as the European minimum wage framework, we will be in charge of resignation.  Today, recovery is slow and insufficient, and let's consider one thing: recovery, either fair or it won't be.  And now is the time to be courageous, to move forward with an economic and social agenda that restores the values of Europe that we need today.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: "Mr. President, we have said that no country can guarantee its own security. Yesterday we said we need a European answer to the European question. It is true that today we are trading europe's future with these policies and we are responsible for what will happen in 2016 and beyond.  This morning Mr Juncker said that the European Commission is not a European government, but that when there are challenges and threats, then we act as a European government. The fact is, we all need help, that we need to coordinate our policies. We do not want, none of us want Schengen to fail and it is clear that Schengen is in danger and therefore we must adopt measures.  However, there are two different criteria in Europe, countries in the south and countries of the north, rich countries and poor countries, Schengen countries and outside Schengen. In particular, I come from Croatia, which is outside Schengen. How can you and do you intend to help Mr. Timmermans to get Croatia, Bulgaria and Romania into Schengen as soon as possible and that we finally know clearly what is the external border of the European Union and what borders do we protect? Then there will be no wire between Slovenia and Croatia, between two sovereign European states, then we will not have to talk about the wire. I believe we will then better regulate these issues. I therefore ask you to allow entry into Schengen and other countries as soon as possible.

name: Péter NIEDERMÜLLER
text: – Today, we all see that the migration crisis, the refugee issue, is a real turning point in the history of Europe, the European Union. But not because of the number of refugees, but because we are faced with the fact that there are Member States, governments and politicians who are exploiting the issue of refugees to create fear and hatred. They pursue a populist policy whose sole purpose is to crush the European Union and revive selfish nationalisms that so often put Europe in danger. There are also those among Europe's leaders who are not looking for real solutions to political and economic challenges, but are baking their own political roasts. When the President of the Council talks about the closure of refugees, he does not serve, but destroys, European unity. Those of us who believe in Europe must now show political strength and moral courage. We will definitely oppose far-right and populist politics, because one day we will wake up to the fact that Europe is over and that there are nothing left but hateful nationalisms. It is not the refugees that should save Europe, but this populist politics.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – A Uachtaráin, cuireann an chaint faoi Brexit i gcuimhne dom dán i mo theanga dhúchais féin a deireann: ‘cad é sin don té sin nach mbaineann sin dó’. Agus i slí amháin ní bhaineann sé sin linn, ach i slí eile baineann sé.  Dar ndóigh, is iad muintir na Breataine a dhéanfaidh an cinneadh ag deireadh na dála ach ó thaobh na hÉireann, tá dlúthghaol idir sinne agus an Bhreatain le fada an lá. Thángamar isteach san Aontas ar an lá céanna agus tá súil agam go bhfanfaidh an Bhreatain san Aontas an fhad agus a bheimidne ann, agus is sin go deo.  Dá bhfágfadh an Bhreatain an tAontas, chuirfeadh sé isteach go mór ar gheilleagar na hÉireann, agus ar chúrsaí i réigiún na Teorann ach go háirithe. Freisin, ní bheadh sé oiriúnach dá bhfágfadh an Bhreatain agus iad ar an tír is mó san Aontas ó thaobh daonra de agus an Béarla mar theanga na hEorpa de facto. Dá bhrí sin, iarraim ar an gCoimisiún éisteacht le David Cameron agus gach iarracht a dhéanamh teacht ar chomhréiteach leis.

name: Paul TANG
text: – Of all the issues, one, the British referendum. Donald Tusk wants a conversation about British wishes without taboos. That is undoubtedly very good for the atmosphere of the conversation, but as a starting point dangerous.  The desire to reduce the rights of EU migrants runs counter to the idea of free movement. It would be better to tackle the shadow side of free movement, the blatant exploitation, the unfair competition. It is therefore disappointing that the Commission has not yet come forward with a proposal for a revision of the Posting of Work Directive. Having said that, a conversation about reasonable wishes is more than welcome. We would like to see a Europe that offers space for national individuality, which even protects, so that a large majority of Great Britain feels at home in the European Union. That message must be the outcome of a conversation, so that David Cameron and his people can finally and with conviction finally and with conviction run a yes campaign.

name: Tunne KELAM
text: – Mr President, I have three points. Firstly, I would like to thank the Commission for its bold border guard initiative and I insist that the Member States overcome their differences and approve it, this weekend if possible.  Secondly, the Syrian crisis should not take attention away from Ukraine and the continuing Russian aggression. Let us remember that Mr ‘Brute’ Putin has broken the system of international security, continues to break it and views the West, not as his partner, but as his adversary. Therefore any hesitations about the continuation of sanctions would undermine the very political and moral credibility of the EU. Mr Putin is, unfortunately, not part of the solution. He remains part of the problem. Thirdly, I would like Nord Stream 2 to be assessed by the Council on the basis of Commissioner Arias Cañete’s arguments from October. It is clearly not a private deal but a political project to weaken Ukraine and deepen dependence on Russian gas for all of us.  Finally may I wish both the Commission and the Council an invigorating Christmas spirit of hope, persistence and, last but not least, satisfaction.

name: Iliana IOTOVA
text: Mr President, it is important to ask ourselves today: have we managed to create a holistic European policy in 2015 to manage the migration crisis? Eight Council meetings were needed to adopt the "urgent measures" proposed by the Commission and approved by Parliament. The crisis today would not have been so deep if these measures had been implemented on time. In fact, 2015 was only the preparatory year for holistic migration policy. From now on, we must act. The Commission's proposal to strengthen border controls had been long overdue. The protection of the Schengen area is the highest priority, as the President of the European Commission told us this morning. But why, Mr Timmermans, are Bulgaria, Romania and Croatia excluded from the framework of the new agency when their borders are also the external borders of the Union? They are thus transformed into a "buffer zone" which will have to assume all migrants who cannot enter the Schengen states, but who also cannot return to where they came from. By applying the principle of 'double standards', we are once again in danger of facing an even greater migration crisis in the Balkans, with consequences for the whole of Europe.

name: David McALLISTER
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. The summit will deal with the forthcoming British referendum on Thursday, as we have heard several times this morning. We have an important task ahead of us: on the one hand, to support the British Government, to successfully campaign for remain in our European Union in the referendum, and, on the other, not to call into question the achievements of successful European integration.  In my view, the December Council is only a stopover. In the end, the legal and political details and the precise design of the agreement will be crucial. All parties involved can and should be prepared to make a constructive contribution here. The European People's Party will do so in any case. In my view, it would be good if we could then find a reasonable compromise in February, so that we can soon have clarity. 'Say yes to Bremain. Say no to Brexit'.

name: Sylvia-Yvonne KAUFMANN
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the The protection of the EU's external borders is a common European task. The last weeks and months have shown that without joint action, chaos and national selfishness will win. It is therefore fundamentally important to improve border management across the EU. However, strong border protection must not lead to the sale of fundamental rights. Refugees must continue to be able to apply for asylum in the EU, and people fleeing war must be protected in accordance with international law. The revision of the Dublin system and a permanent and mandatory distribution key for refugees based on genuine solidarity are necessary. Above all, however, what we need is determination and action rather than words. The loss of confidence in Europe is now becoming threatening because governments simply do not implement decisions and because they do not act together. The European Community must not degenerate into a community of mistrust. I therefore call on the governments to take your responsibilities and prove that Europe stands for freedom, humanity, tolerance and solidarity.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Mr President, I wanted to thank President Juncker and now I thank his Vice-President for presenting the European Commission's external border control plan. President Juncker has said that freedom and security must come in conjunction, they must complement each other, they cannot be one without the other. I would like to say that I think the same thing. Solidarity cannot be without an accent on security, right at this time of migration crisis. I am therefore very glad that the Commission has taken up its responsibility and put forward solutions to the common protective forces for the external border. I would also encourage him to say that, of course, if the Member States do not have sufficient opportunities to protect the external borders of the Schengen area, then they must accept European common assistance and a common solution.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: – Of course, one minute cannot comment on the full content of the forthcoming summit, but rather I would like to say something that accompanies the summits more generally. And that's a lot of marketing, a lot of pre-summit performances, but basically no results. This summit will also end with you coming up with proposals that you are well aware will not be approved by the Member States. After the summit, the Presidents of the Member States will come before the cameras of their televisions and say that Europe has failed. It is your duty to create a debate in advance, and only when it is clear that a proposal has the ability to be successful, then to speak to it in public. People ask us what we are doing in our institutions. What the European Union is doing, because they see no results. So give the Prime Ministers the greetings that we wish them a nice Christmas, but that they make decisions that people will be convinced will actually be introduced to reality.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Mr President, despite the various well-wishers in Greece, despite the efforts of the Commission's political friends in Greece, the masks have fallen off. Everyone now knows that the European Coast Guard and Border Guard, the new Frontex, will have the first and final say in the management and guarding of the Greek border. The new Frontex will have the right to unilateral intervention in cases of crises caused by refugee flows at the Greek-Turkish and Greek-Macedonian borders. The new Frontex is a State in state, and will have the right, unilaterally, to decide on interventions on the territory of the Member States, and thus of Greece, assisted either by Bavarian, German and French border guards, as Mr Weber wanted, or by third-country forces such as Turkey and Skopje. Greece should not accept the re-infringement of its sovereign rights by the new Frontex. If Greece has a choice between granting its sovereign rights to guard its borders in order to remain in Schengen, then it must choose to leave Schengen here and now.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: GUE/NGL). Mr President, while we are debating here, the tragedy in the Mediterranean continues. Last night, human lives were lost again. The refugee crisis will not be addressed by repressive measures to intercept refugees and turn Europe into a fortress. The European Council should focus on strengthening rescue forces and refugee support measures and, above all, should set up permanent relocation mechanisms.  The proposal to make Frontex a joint border and coast guard body, which will act even without the approval of the Member States, will lead to the restriction of the sovereignty of states and to the violation of the Union's proclaimed principles of solidarity and protection of refugees. Equally dangerous is the role of Guardian of the European Union given to Turkey, at a time when human rights violations, the killings of demonstrators and arbitrary arrests of journalists continue in the country. The only solution is to support the States, particularly in the Mediterranean, which are facing serious flows of refugees, and to strengthen them so that they can deal with the refugee crisis with a humanitarian approach.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: – Even in this so-called flagship debate, which deals with the most important and topical issues of the European Union, there are so woefully few of us that Mr Juncker seems to have either got bored at half-time, or felt lonely or afraid, but he left anyway, so I ask his deputy the following. Have the European Union and the specialised bodies of the Member States learned the technical lessons of the tragic terrorist attack in Paris? How did the perpetrators get to Europe? What data and information did the Member States or the European Union know about these perpetrators? From a professional point of view, have they acted professionally from a secret service, terrorism prevention, law enforcement and crime prevention point of view? How was it supposed to go? What is the European Union doing to prevent such further tragic acts? The road is clearly not to be partlessly interrogated and monitored by citizens who have nothing to do with acts of terrorism.

name: Frans TIMMERMANS
text: First Vice-President and Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I will be brief, as per your request. In the course of history we Europeans have been incredible at creating results. We are creative, we are adaptable, and, in the course of our history, we have also been very good at destruction and at killing each other. Nobody does it better than we do. And we have learned, after two failed attempts – fortunately – at collective suicide, that working together is a lot better than trying to do it on our own and looking for confrontation. This year has seen a perfect storm. On top of an economic crisis and a banking crisis, which had already eaten away at people’s self—confidence, came the huge challenge of the terrorism crisis, and, on top of that, the refugee crisis. No wonder that many Europeans are unhappy with the present situation.  But it is my profound belief that looking for solutions individually, at the expense of other Europeans, against other Europeans, is moving back to a part of our history I thought we had left behind us forever. We will only come out of these crises if we work together. That is the spirit with which the Commission has made the proposals. Are the proposals perfect? I do not pretend they are, but they are a positive step toward solving a problem at our borders. They are a positive step towards showing European citizens that we need to solve this together. If Member States have better solutions, better options, please put them on the table. We are not dogmatic about them. Let me say one thing to conclude. We need to do a better job of protecting our external borders. There is no contradiction between being Europeans and being protective of our external borders. We are a community of values based on solidarity, and solidarity is something that means that you stick together. It does not mean what I hear Ms Keller say, namely that we should have a European Union without borders. That is elitist populism. We cannot survive without borders. We have to select, at our borders, who has the right to international protection, and who does not have the right to international protection and should be returned to their countries. The only way we can maintain solidarity in our society for people who deserve international protection is to ensure that the people who get it deserve it. Otherwise, we will undermine even the support for those who need international protection. Let us be under no illusion about that.  (Applause)

name: Nicolas SCHMIT
text: President-in-Office of the Council. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, first of all I thank you for these debates and the messages that have been sent to the European Council. As the draft conclusions of the European Council have been mentioned, I would say that if we implement all that is in this draft conclusions, if we adopt and implement it, we will have made great progress, real progress. And among these advances, what is crucial is to preserve both the free movement of European citizens and their security. European citizens want both. It is up to us to guarantee them that freedom and security. We need to accelerate the implementation of everything that has been decided, quickly and efficiently. It is true that the time is not for half-solutions, for half measures. But when we look back a few months, has Europe been immobile, has nothing been done, has nothing been adopted? No! Thanks to Parliament, we have a long list of achievements, progress, such as the NRL, data protection, the platform against illegal work, etc. So Europe is not immobile. But it is true that we have been caught off guard by this tragedy at our borders, by the crisis in Syria, by the migration crisis, and perhaps it is because we have forgotten that European integration is a response to the tragic dimension of history, the Vice-President of the Commission has, in a way, also recalled it : two world wars, an economic crisis, fascism, Auschwitz. We may have forgotten that history remains tragic, as Raymond Aron put it during the Soviet invasion of Afghanistan. So we have to find that task, that spring to decide together, to achieve together, because, indeed, the challenges are considerable. All those who preach national or nationalist withdrawal are illusionists, who ignore both the magnitude of the issues and the lessons of history. I can tell you that the Presidency, until the last hour, will commit itself, also at the next European Council, as it did during these few months, to a Europe that is united, strong, capable of acting and respectful of its values.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Thank you very much for your support.

name: András GYÜRK
text: Writing. – In recent weeks, representatives of some Western governments have proposed the creation of a mini Schengen area covering only a few typically founding Member States. It is striking that the proposal would exclude central and eastern European member states from free movement, while these are the very countries that adhere to the Schengen Agreement in the strictest terms and have protected the Union's external borders from uncontrolled immigrants. Central Europe's commitment to Schengen is shown by the fact that the Visegrad Cooperation countries jointly patrol the southern borders of the Schengen area and the Union, the Serbian-Hungarian and Croatian-Hungarian borders, and participate with more than 300 border guards in controlling Greece's borders.  Unilaterally changing the Schengen area is an unfair and absurd idea, an even worse response to an earlier bad political decision, and which clearly wants to punish Those Member States that are effective in combating illegal immigration. The free movement provided for by the Schengen Convention is one of the most important achievements of the European Union, the dismantling or restriction of which would cause immeasurable economic damage throughout the continent. The reintroduction of border controls would not only make life difficult for millions of European citizens, but would also seriously damage international transport, industry, trade or tourism. For all these reasons, we expect the European Council to stand up in the strongest possible light in favour of preserving the Schengen system and ensuring strict security at the Union's external borders.

name: Alfred SANT
text: in writing. – It is obvious that the European Union needs a functioning migration and asylum policy to underpin the Schengen system. We obviously do not have it. The proposal to create a new, stronger Frontex is another proposal in firefighting mode. It aims to staunch the flow of migrants and refugees that has become uncontrollable in past months. We obviously need stronger, more effective border controls. We also need first greater coherence in the formulation of migration policies. These cannot be simply packaged in beautiful statements about solidarity and European values, while lacking the tools to manage them. Nor can migration policies simply be declared unilaterally, provoking greater problems, and then expecting border states to assume full responsibility. The latter would then need to mobilise additional own financial resources, even as Dublin 2 remains in force. Even less acceptable is the concept of a new Frontex that would have the power to override national competences. Most states at the EU’s so-called external borders are small and have limited resources. What is being proposed, unless radically amended, amounts to a further reduction of their sovereignty without any transparent counterbalancing measures that would ensure the burdens of immigration are being contained and fairly distributed.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. – The European Union (EU) is making plans for new border and coastal security forces that can intervene even without the consent of their European countries. The proposal is justified by the restoration of European security, threatened by the migration crisis. The European Commission has proposed transforming the Border Agency Frontex into the European Border and Coast Guard Agency, doubling its budget and staff numbers, and providing more powers to the institution. The agency is estimated to have a fund of €322 million by 2020. This idea of deploying border and coastguard teams "when a Member State cannot or does not take the necessary measures" and therefore putting the Schengen area at risk with a rapid reaction force of 1,500 guards is totally unacceptable. It shows that the Commission remains blind and unintentionally understanding the nature of the situation and implements the necessary measures. Insisting on repressive measures reveals a complete inmanity and at the same time a complete lack of strategic vision. But it also reveals the true nature of this process of European integration with which we must break with the struggle of peoples.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. I would ask you to take a seat. Maybe we can play a little video first. (A short video is playing.) (Applause) Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. It is an extraordinary honour for me, on behalf of this year's Sakharov Prize winner Raif Badawi – who cannot be with us today because he has freely expressed his opinion and because he has called for freedom of thought, because he has been sentenced to ten years in prison and 1 000 lashes, and because we have received the dramatic news that he has now been placed in solitary confinement in an additional way. , and that is why he cannot receive the Sakharov Prize in person today – that is why it is an honour and a pleasure for me to welcome his brave and great wife – you, Mrs Ensaf Haidar – here in the European Parliament today in the place of your husband. Welcome! (Applause) Among the many guests who today give us the honour of attending this Sakharov Prize 2015 award, many representatives of the Diplomatic Corps, are two guests with us, whom I welcome equally warmly. I have agreed with Mrs Haidar that I am also offering this welcome on her behalf to Olga Schorina of the Boris Nemtsov Foundation and to Maria Alejandra Aristigueta, the representative of the Venezuelan opposition. These two groups were in competition. Welcome, ladies and gentlemen, to this award ceremony! (Applause) Thank you, ladies and gentlemen, for being with us. Through you, Mrs Haidar, we would like to honour your husband's courageous struggle. Mrs Haidar, I would like to pay you personally, your family, your children, all your friends, first of all in the dignity, courage and determination you have shown in the struggle to get your husband home, where three young children aged 12, 11 and eight are waiting for their father to return. Because of death threats, including against you personally, you had to flee with your children to Canada, where you were granted asylum and from where you wage your tireless fight for your husband's freedom, where you give him a voice while he is prevented from using his own voice. And that is why, on behalf of all of us here, I once again call on King Salman to pardon Raif Badawi and release him immediately and without conditions and to have him returned to his family. (Applause) Despite a high risk, Raif Badawi, as a blogger, bravely tried to promote free thinking. He has perceived nothing but his right to freedom of expression, and through his blog he has filled a gap, a gap in a country where there is a vacuum in a country where there is a vacuum for freedom of expression due to the lack of a free press. Raif Badawi raised his vote for the right, the human right, to express his opinion freely. He called for a society in his country that is open to the views of others. As he said to you from prison when he dictated over the phone the foreword to the book containing his collected writings: He is committed to enlightening his community and tearing down the walls of ignorance. Its aim is to question the inviolability of clergy in his country and to guarantee respect for freedom of expression and belief and to guarantee respect for women's rights and the protection of minorities and fundamental civil rights to each individual. With this in mind, Raif Badawi founded the Internet Forum "The Saudi Liberals" in 2006 to discuss publicly the need for reforms at the religious, cultural and political levels in a discussion forum. Two years later, the government forced him to close the forum. But he hasn't given up. On the contrary, he came back with a new Internet forum, the "Free Saudi Liberal Network". This network had tens of thousands of members discussing religion and politics. And when the so-called Arab Spring appeared in the region, there was a lively debate in this network and on this platform. The closure of Badawi's website was a great loss for freedom of expression in his country. He wasn't just censored. We all know that he was imprisoned, and he received the first 50 lashes in the face of a roaring crowd. His flogging shocked the whole world. Everywhere, people took to the streets and used social media – his tool – to condemn this cruelty. After international ostracism and poor health Raif's further lashes were provisionally suspended. Raif Badawi has become a symbolic figure and an inspiration to all those who fight for fundamental rights not only in the region, but far beyond the world. Indeed, Raif Badawi is not alone in this fight. His own lawyer, Waleed Abu al-Khair, 36, is serving a 15-year prison sentence. As the founder of the Observatory for Human Rights, he was convicted, among other defendants, of tweets denouncing human rights abuses. In October this year, Dr. Abdulkarim Al-Khodr, co-founder of the Saudi Association for Civil and Political Rights, was imprisoned as the tenth founding member of the organization. He was sentenced to eight years in prison and a 10-year travel ban. Just a few weeks ago, Ashraf Fayadh, a young poet and curator of exhibitions, was sentenced to death for apostasy, a renunciation of faith. His trial was denounced worldwide for the lack of a fair trial and a lack of legal assistance. Ali Mohammed An-Nimr is 21. He was not yet 18 years old when he was arrested for demonstrating for equal rights in Saudi Arabia. That is why he is sentenced to death with subsequent crucifixion. We are concerned and shocked by the reports that this sentence is to be carried out in the next few days. As we have done for Raif Badawi, in a European Parliament resolution we called on the Saudi authorities, and I do so on behalf of all of us here and in public: release Mr Ali Mohammed An-Nimr! Lift the death sentence! Look away from this cruel punishment! (Applause) These cases are just a few of the many cases of political prisoners subjected to inhumane treatment, humiliation and the death penalty. We now urge the Saudi authorities to put an end to the systematic repression of peaceful expressions of opinion and finally to comply with the many international obligations that the country has ratified: for example, the Convention against Torture – ratified by Saudi Arabia – the Convention on the Rights of the Child and the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination against Women. The international community, as well as Saudi society, have the right to place higher demands on the Saudi authorities, as the country has been elected a member of the UN Human Rights Council. It has been stressed that the deplorable human rights situation certainly does not fit with the responsibility that the country has assumed within the framework of the United Nations. In the country that has become a member of the United Nations Human Rights Council, 150 people have been executed this year alone. The society in Saudi Arabia demands public communication: Saudi society has the highest number of active social media users worldwide. But the Internet is heavily censored, with 400,000 websites blocked alone. Worse still, those who use the Internet and social media to express their thoughts freely are severely punished. However, we are ready for dialogue, not only as the European Parliament, but also for the international community. A dialogue on human rights between the EU and Saudi Arabia, supported at parliamentary level, could help to improve the situation, promote mutual understanding and support reforms. Certainly, there have been some positive developments. The Council of Ministers has approved a law on private associations and organisations, which I hope will soon also allow non-governmental organisations to work in the country itself and to have unhindered access to civil society. There has been little progress on women's suffrage, but the country is a long way from equality for women. We are fighting for equality between men and women and against all forms of discrimination. And we call on Saudi Arabia to honour its commitments and finally abolish the male guardianship system towards women. This does not belong in the 21st century! (Applause) Mrs Haidar, ladies and gentlemen, ladies and gentlemen, ladies and gentlemen, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioners for their excellent work and for their excellent work. No terror, no criminal law that inhumanely, will prevent us from fighting for human rights. And no security argument, no arms deal and no oil trade must stop us from doing so. As Raif Badawi put it: "Freedom of expression is the air that a thinker breathes, just as it is the fuel that ignites the fire of his ideas." Ladies and gentlemen, it is a special honour for me to receive the Sakharov Prize for Spiritual freedom of the European Parliament to Raif Badawi in 2015. And I very much hope that in the near future we will be able to receive him personally here in our Chamber. (Applause)

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: Wife of Raif Badawi (official translation of Arabic original). – Mr President, honourable Members of the European Parliament, I thank you for being here this afternoon. It is an honour for me to be in your Hemicycle. It would of course have been nicer if my husband could have received the prize personally, but if I may, I would like to ask you to respect one minute’s silence as a tribute to those who lost their lives in France and elsewhere. What my husband would like would be a minute’s silence paying tribute to these victims. (The House rose and observed a minute’s silence) Honourable President, Members of the European Parliament, I stand today on solid ground in front of you, the representatives of the great European nation, to express my great honour at being here, firstly as a representative of my husband Raif Badawi, and because I am in the Chamber of the largest and most important forum for democracy in the world. Ladies and gentlemen, allow me to begin my speech with my husband Raif Badawi’s article: Freedom of expression is the air that a thinker breathes; the fuel that ignites his ideas. Through the ages, societies have progressed only through their thinkers. From among the ideas and philosophies available, people can choose their own way of thinking and use it to embark upon the seas of science, progress, civilisation and prosperity. Societies and human rights groups around the world call upon Arab regimes for greater reform in the area of freedom of expression, believing it to be a simple human right. You are a person, so you are entitled to express yourself and think however you want. You also have the right to say what you are thinking about, to believe, to love and to hate, to be a liberal or an Islamist. Arab thinkers, or at least those who are free thinking, have got used to camouflaging their ideas in order to get them through. Those ideas that are free and enlightened are considered blasphemous in the ideology adopted by Arab societies, in which every free thought is decadence and a diversion from the true path. Is this normal? Of course not. Both sides – Arab thinkers and society – operate outside the realm of normalcy. Thinkers should reveal their ideas with complete honesty and courage even if they contain mistakes, or if they go against the intellectual tide. And they must keep themselves open to listening to the opinions of others so that they can criticise them constructively in a creative dialogue that aims to develop their ideas, and not reject them simply because of a difference of opinion. Observers of Arab society can see overwhelmingly that it is reeling under a theocratic regime that will only hear the words ‘Yes, Sir’ spoken to its clergy. This society has undoubtedly mastered the art of displaying religious observance to the clergymen to the extent that their fatwas and interpretations of Islam have become absolute truth − even sacred truth. Yet as soon as a free thinker starts to reveal their ideas, you will see hundreds of fatwas accusing them of being an infidel just because they had the courage to discuss religious topics. I am really worried that Arab thinkers will migrate in search of fresh air and to escape the sword of the religious authorities. Raif predicted here, before his imprisonment, that the clerics constrain the thinkers just because they undermine their role, as they are living on lies and exhibit hypocrisy towards the public. Raif Badawi, a young Saudi man, has been in jail since 2012 on charges of insulting the Islamic religion. The first sentence passed against him was the death penalty for apostasy. In the past year he was sentenced to a cruel and inhuman punishment: 10 years in prison, a fine of USD 300 000 and 1 000 lashes which were set to be administered weekly in a public square, 50 lashes per week each Friday after prayers. In addition, he is banned from using any media outlets and from travelling abroad for 10 years after being released from prison. Raif is not a criminal or a rapist. Raif is a writer and a free thinker: that is all. Raif Badawi’s charge and crime are that he is a free voice in a country which does not accept anything other than the single opinion and the single thought. Raif has never been a criminal, thug or drug dealer, so the Saudi authorities should not be dealing with him as a criminal who deserves to be punished, flogged and jailed for a very long time. Raif is only a man who thinks and translates his thoughts onto paper. He dreams of a beautiful world and looks forward to it. He wants us to respect differences in a country where there is only single-mindedness, only one thought and only one religion. His thinking aloud annoyed them, so they created an icon of freedom of him, not just in Saudi Arabia, but throughout the world as well. Raif Badawi is just a Muslim thinker who refused to be part of the herd, following the clerics living outside time and governing by a law of injustice and tyranny. He was brave enough to raise his voice loudly to say no to their barbarism and insolence. That is why they flogged his frail body with their whips of ignorance. 50 lashes was sufficient to give rise to mass protests which still continue in Korea, Australia and even Canada, with everyone chanting ‘I am Raif’, despite their different races. Awarding the Sakharov Prize to Raif Badawi is a historic and noteworthy day. It is, Mr President, an act of bravery by you and by all those who voted for Raif beneath this great dome.
