This prestigious award is the 15th international award granted to Raif in less than a year. He is the first person from the Gulf Arab region to be awarded the Sakharov Prize. Ladies and gentlemen, let me thank all of you for this opportunity and this honour. And I will conclude with Raif Badawi’s words: ‘We want life for those who wish death to us; and we want rationality for those who want ignorance for us.’ (The House accorded the speaker a standing ovation)

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report, which I think I would like to thank Mrs Haidar once again on behalf of all of you. I had the opportunity to have a long conversation with Mrs Haidar before the speech. Ms. Haidar told me about her three children – a girl of twelve, a boy of eleven, and a girl of eight – waiting for their father in Canada. Mrs Haidar told me that every time Mr Badawi calls her, he asks a question: do the children not forget me? I believe that we can all understand what this means for a father, but also for a mother who, in these circumstances, has to make a phone call with her husband, who asks this question. She told me, no, I tell him that every time, the children don't forget you. No one forgets you. Our ceremony today was a contribution to the fact that the children also know that the Father is not forgotten. We fight for him. And To you, Mrs Haidar, I think everyone in this room admires your great courage. Thank you for your speech. (Applause)

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: The next item is the vote. (For the results and other details of the vote: see Minutes)

name: Reinhard BÜTIKOFER
text: – Madam President, in the middle of the text I propose to add a sentence which reads, ‘urges China to reconsider its stance and calls on all the parties including China to respect the eventual decision of UNCLOS’.

name: Edouard MARTIN
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, my intervention will be very quick. I would just like to welcome the presence in the Chamber of a delegation of steel trade unionists from Germany, Luxembourg, France and Belgium. Before voting on this report on the development of base metals, especially steel, which is undergoing an unprecedented crisis, I wanted to welcome the presence of these people among us and thank them for their support.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: That concludes the vote.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. I voted against this report because it entails increasing the president's mandate to ensure the continuity of the functioning of the European Banking Authority. We cannot positively sanction the management of this Authority because it is a fundamental part of the European Financial Supervision System. This system implies a transfer of sovereignty in the field of financial supervision to authorities that lack true democratic control, resulting in financial supervision designed according to the interests of large financial sector companies. Regular financial supervision is essential to ensure the interests of the European working classes, and Andrea Enria's current mandate has proved not to guarantee the possibility of developing a public banking that can serve the interests of Europeans. That is why I have decided to vote against this report.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. The purpose of this report is to renew for five years the mandate of the President of the European Banking Agency (EBA), which is under the control of the ECON Committee.  I voted in favour of this text. This agency has the merit of counterbalance to the European Central Bank (ECB), which is trying to take over the powers of the EBA. As a reminder, the EBA is responsible for coordinating banking supervision for non-systemic eu-sized banks, while systemic banks are overseen by the ECB.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ This vote was taken by secret ballot. However, in the interests of democracy I should confirm for the benefit of my constituents that I voted against.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. On 8 September 2015, the EBA Board of Supervisors submitted a proposal to extend the term of office of the current PRESIDENT of the EBA, Andreos Enrios, for a further five years. November 17, 2015 The Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs held a hearing with the current President of the EBA, Andrea Enria, during which the Chairman gave an introductory speech and answered questions put by committee members. I support the proposal to extend the term of office of THE PRESIDENT of the EBA, Andrea Enrios, for a further five years.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. The three reports filed by Roberto Gualtieri are aimed at renewing for five years the mandates of the presidents of the three agencies under the control of the ECON Committee: the European Banking Agency (EBA), the European Financial Markets Authority (ESMA) and the European Insurance and Occupational Pensions Authority (AEAPP). I voted in favour of extending Andrea Enria's term as head of the European Banking Agency (EBA) for five years. The EBA provides a useful counterweight to the ECB, which has been constantly using the powers of the EBA, which is tasked with coordinating banking supervision for non-systemic banks in the Union.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. Andrea Enria, Current President of the European Banking Authority, was appointed in 2011 for a five-year term. In accordance with the regulatory requirement, the EBA's Supervisory Authority Council may propose once the extension of the President's term for five years with confirmation from the European Parliament.  This request was made and the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, after hearing from the person concerned, gave a very positive opinion. I approved this extension.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. – Since we oppose the mandate and activity of these three supervisory agencies, we have also opposed the extension of the mandate of their respective presidents.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report on the extension of the mandate of the President of the European Banking Authority. It was appointed after an open selection procedure and the Supervisory Board of the Authority proposed extending its mandate, so that it would continue to work on it and a true European Banking Authority be built.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. I voted in favour of extending the mandate of the President of the European Banking Authority (EBA), Andrea Enria. I consider that the EBA is a real counterweight to the all-powerful ECB, which has repeatedly tried to take over the prerogatives of the European Banking Authority, which is responsible for coordinating banking supervision for non-systemic banks in the European Union. In order to carry out this mission, the EBA therefore needs stable leadership and management and that is why I have spoken in favour of extending the mandate of its president.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 Although there is nothing objective to justify my opposition to the renewal of Andrea Enria as President of the European Banking Authority, I opposed this measure in order to express my disagreement with the economic policies of the European institutions.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I have supported the extension of Andrea Enria's term of office as Chairman of the European Banking Authority for another five years considering the support received by the European Parliament's Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs following his appearance on 17 November and having passed the scrutiny carried out by the members of that committee.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because it supported the extension of the term of office of the President of the European Banking Authority (EBA). The EBA Chairperson was appointed by the EBA Board of Supervisors in 2011, following an open selection procedure, for a term of five years, which may be renewed once, subject to the consent of the European Parliament. On 8 September 2015, the EBA Board of Supervisors submitted a proposal to extend the term of office of the current President of the EBA, Andreos Enrios, for a further five years and informed the European Parliament accordingly, and Parliament therefore approved the extension of the term of office.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: Writing. I also supported the proposed extension of the mandate of the President of the European Banking Authority (EBA) on the basis of the findings of the EBA Board of Supervisors and their proposal to extend the mandate of Mr Andrea Enrii for a further five years. Mr. Enria has done a great job to the next, and he has convinced me with his work, so I have no reason not to trust him for another five years.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. The purpose of this report is to renew for five years the mandate of the President of the European Banking Authority, who coordinates banking supervision for non-systemic banks in the Union and provides a counterweight to the ECB, which tends to grant itself prerogatives that are not its own. That is why I voted for this proposal.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 I am in favour of the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament to extend the mandate of the President of the European Banking Authority. Given that the necessary steps and the related steps in this proposal have been taken and the decision of the committee responsible, ECON, was to give another five-year term to the current EBA President, Andrea Envia, I believe that it is necessary to take an affirmative position and allow a natural continuation of the management of the European Banking Authority.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 The first President of the EBA was appointed in 2011. The Board of Supervisors may renew the term of office of Andrea Enria, who is currently in office, for a further five years. It is clear that, for our part, more than a critical position towards Mr Enria, what determines our choice of vote is the critical orientation that characterises our delegation and the whole group of which we are a member. Our position, which is totally contrary to the economic policies of the European institutions, can only be opposed to the renewal of the office in question.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 After careful consideration and vote in plenary, I voted in favour of the report on the renewal of the mandate of the President of the European Banking Authority. Indeed, I believe that the correction of macroeconomic imbalances is based on strengthening governance and coordinating economic policies, in order to make effective use of the Stability and Growth Pact.  The European Banking Authority (EBA) has the task of ensuring an effective and uniform level of regulation and supervision in the European banking sector. It is therefore necessary to prevent macroeconomic imbalances, first and foremost by strengthening and stability of economic governance, ensuring the continuity of the action of the authorities involved. The renewal of the mandate of the EBA President-in-Office goes in this direction, helping to ensure the integrity, efficiency and smooth functioning of the banking sector. It is not permissible to underestimate the consequences of the economic fragility that imbalances in a non-harmonised banking sector can produce, and the maximum cohesion of the three supervisors must therefore be guaranteed, in order to support the creation of the single body of rules in the banking sector in order to ensure a level playing field and high protection for depositors, investors and consumers.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. – I voted against the extension of the term of office of the Chairperson of the European Banking Authority as I have grave concerns with the EBA. A number of these regulatory bodies were set up after the financial crash, the stated aim being to regulate the financial markets so that another financial crash would not happen. Of course, robust regulation is required but there are critical concerns with these bodies. There is a huge democratic deficit running through these bodies and, moreover, a number of legal concerns have been voiced. The bodies have very fragile legal foundations and a number of legal experts have stated that the setting-up of such bodies was done outside of the confines of EU Treaty Law. To explain simply, when an EU body is being set up, you have to first go back to the primary treaties which founded the EU and look at the Treaty Provisions. If there is no provision in the Treaty to set up such an initiative, then it can be declared as ultra vires, i.e. be outside of EU law and have no legal foundation. Therefore, it was for these reasons that I voted against the extension of the EBA.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the extension of the term of office of the Chairperson of the European Banking Authority, Andrea Enria, for another five-year term as both his hearing in the Economic and Monetary Affairs Committee was successful and his activities during the current term in office were satisfactory.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament's ECON Committee held a single hearing of the candidates, and then voted last week to renew its mandate. The vote against stems firstly from the almost automatic way in which the renewal took place and, secondly, from the fact that the added value of the Authority has so far been marginal. A real debate and a real analysis would have been necessary.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 Taking into account the proposal of the Board of Supervisors of the European Banking Authority (EBA) of 8 September 2015 to extend the term of office of the President of ESMA for a further five years (C8-0313/2015), as well as Article 48(4) of Regulation (EU) No 1782/2003, 1093/2010 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 24 November 2010 on the establishment of a European Supervisory Authority (European Banking Authority), we agree with the extension of the mandate of the Eba President.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The proposal to extend the term of office of the President of the European Banking Authority is a formal procedure without any particular implications. However, since I was opposed from the outset to the creation and operation of this principle, I preferred to abstain from voting on this proposal.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: in writing. I voted in favour of reconfirming Andrea Enria's mandate as President of the EBA for a further five years; I also considered the hearing on 17 November 2015 to be exhaustive, during which Enria made a preliminary statement and answered all the questions put to him by the members of the committee.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because, given that the EBA Board of Supervisors has proposed renewing the mandate of Andrea Enria, President-in-Office of the EBA, for a further five years, and has informed the European Parliament, as a member of the EPP, I approve of the proposal to renew the mandate and take this opportunity to express my sincere wishes for good work. , which I am sure will carry out with dedication and great commitment.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 I welcome the renewal of the appointment of Andrea Hernia to the prestigious and important position of President of the European Banking Authority.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this extension on the basis of a decision dated 8 September 2015 by the Board of Supervisors of the EBA proposing to extend the term of office of Andrea Enria, the incumbent Chairperson of the EBA, by another five-year term. The Board of Supervisors of the EBA is best placed to judge the competence of the person and alternative scenarios.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. \u2012 A Microprudential Supervision System at European level was created at the end of 2010, consisting of the European Banking Authority (EBA, based in London), the European Financial instruments and markets Authority (ESMA, based in Paris) and the European Insurance and Occupational Pensions Authority (EIOPA, based in Frankfurt).  In 2011, the Presidents of the three Authorities were appointed, for a five-year term renewable only once. The respective boards of supervisors have proposed renewing the mandate to both Andrea Enria (EBA), Gabriel Bernardino (EIOPA) and also Steven Maijoor (ESMA). The European Parliament's ECON Committee only held a hearing of the candidates, and then voted last week to renew the mandate for all three by a very large majority. We voted against, firstly because of an almost automatic method of renewal with no real reasons; Moreover, the role and value of these authorities has so far proved to be rather marginal, and therefore to continue in the path of five unsatisfactory years certainly does not seem the best decision that could be taken. So even today I am voting against.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. I voted against this report because it entails increasing the president's mandate to ensure the continuity of the functioning of the European Banking Authority. We cannot positively sanction the management of this Authority because it is a fundamental part of the European Financial Supervision System. This system implies a transfer of sovereignty in the field of financial supervision to authorities that lack true democratic control, resulting in financial supervision designed according to the interests of large financial sector companies. Regular financial supervision is essential to ensure the interests of the European working classes, and Andrea Enria's current mandate has proved not to guarantee the possibility of developing a public banking that can serve the interests of Europeans. That is why I have decided to vote against this report.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: Writing. – The European Banking Authority is an EU authority tasked with ensuring an effective and consistent level of prudential regulation and supervision throughout the European banking sector. The objectives of the Banking Authority are to maintain financial stability in the EU and to ensure the efficiency and orderly functioning of the banking sector. Parliament's report on the extension of the term of office of the President of the European Banking Authority (EBA) endorsed the proposal of the EBA Board of Supervisors to extend the term of office of the current President, Andrea Enria, for a further five years. Prior to its plenary decision, Parliament's Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs heard the President of the EBA and subsequently approved the proposal. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the reappointment of the Chairperson of the European Banking Authority. In 2011, Andrea Enria was selected to be the Chairperson of the European Banking Authority for Five years. I voted in favour of extending Enria’s mandate for another five years. Prior to this decision, the Parliament invited Enria to the Committee on Economic Affairs in November of this year, where Enria answered many questions in a satisfactory manner.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This report proposes the positive opinion of the European Parliament on the extension of the mandate of the President of the European Banking Authority (EBA), Andrea ENRIA, for a further five-year period.  According to European rules, the EBA president is elected by the Supervisory Authority Council. The latter is also entitled to reappoint the President for an additional term, which requires prior evaluation and approval by the European Parliament.  On 17 November, members of the European Parliament auditioned the President-candidate. Since it has met the expectations of MEPs, I support this report which is in favour of extending its mandate.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. The aim of this report is to renew the mandate of the President of the European Banking Authority (EBA), which is a significant counterweight to the ECB's excessive power to coordinate banking supervision. Attached to a balance between the various European institutions, although denouncing the excessive power that they have in general, I voted for this report.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 We are voting against the extension of the term of office because the person in question does not fulfil the conditions required for that post.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. I voted against this deliberation because I do not want to support the policy of the European financial institutions.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: in writing. – I voted against as I believe this position should not exist in the first place.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the extension of the term of office of the President of the European Banking Authority.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the extension of the term of office of the President of the European Banking Authority (EBA) because that person does not fulfil the conditions required for this position.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ Having regard to the proposal of the Board of Supervisors of the European Banking Authority (EBA) of 8 September 2015 to extend the term of office of the Chairperson of the EBA by another five-year term (C8-0313/2015) and following the ECON Hearing, I support the extension of the term for Andrea Enria as Chairperson of the EBA.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. \u2012 The first President of the EBA was appointed by the EBA Board of Supervisors in 2011 after an open tender procedure for a five-year term of office, in accordance with Article 48(2) of Regulation (EU) No 1093/2010; Whereas Article 48(4) of Regulation (EU) No 1093/2010 provides that the EBA Board of Supervisors may, taking into account the assessment referred to in this provision, extend the term of office of the President once, subject to the strengthening of the European Parliament; Whereas on 8 September 2015 the EBA Board of Supervisors proposed an extension of the term of office of Andrea Enria, President-in-Office of the EBA, for a further five years and informed the European Parliament accordingly; Whereas on 17 November 2015 the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs heard Andrea Enria, President-in-Office of the EBA, give an opening statement and answered questions put by the members of the Committee.  It approves the proposal to extend the term of office of Andrea Enria, President of the EBA, for a further five-year period and instructs its President to forward this decision to the Council, the Commission, the EBA and the Government of the Member States. In view of the above, I voted in favour of extending the term of office of the President of the European Banking Authority (EBA).

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. I voted in favour of extending the term of office of the President of the European Banking Authority (EBA) considering that 5 years ago he was elected after an open process and that the EBA Board of Supervisors proposed extending Andrea Enria's term of office for another five years.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Writing. I voted in favour of extending the term of office of the Chairman of the European Banking Authority (EBA) as I believe that staffing and a rigorous continuation of work are right and important.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Writing. After an in-depth review, I have agreed to extend the term of office of the Chairman of the European Banking Authority.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. ‒ Following a hearing in the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs on 17 November 2015 with Andrea Enria, the incumbent Chairperson of the European Banking Authority, at which he made an opening statement and then responded to questions from the members of the Committee, I decided to give my support the  extension of the term of office of the Chairperson of the EBA.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. Since we oppose the mandate and activity of these three supervisory agencies, we have also opposed the extension of the mandate of their respective presidents.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the reappointment of the Chairperson of the European Banking Authority. In 2011, Andrea Enria was selected to be the Chairperson of the European Banking Authority for five years. I voted in favour of extending Enria’s mandate for another five years. Prior to this decision, the Parliament invited Enria to the Committee on Economic Affairs in November of this year, where Enria answered many questions in a satisfactory manner

name: Nathan GILL
text: in writing. ‒ Secret Ballot!  Why oh why do the EU fear transparency?  We voted against!

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for the report, having regard to the proposal of the Board of Supervisors of the European Banking Authority (EBA) of 8 September 2015 to extend the term of office of the Chairperson of the EBA by another five-year term (C8-0313/2015)

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 Since we did not support the creation of the European Supervisory Authorities (ESA), we will not support the (re)appointment of presidents either.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted to support this report as I believe the decision to approve the proposal for the extension of the term of office of Andrea Enria as Chairperson of the EBA by another five-year term is appropriate.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the extension of the term of office of the Chairperson of the European Banking Authority (EBA).

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted to extend the mandate of the President of the European Banking Authority (EBA), as this allows Mr Andrea Enri to continue his work over a period of five years. Such a thing is in line with Regulation (EU) No 100/2013. 1093/2010, i.e. the EBA Board of Supervisors decided to extend Mr Enri's term after adequate assessment of his fitness and effectiveness. Therefore, I support the positive opinion of the European Parliament's Economic and Monetary Policy Committee.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Roberto Gualtieri's report on extending the mandate of the President of the European Banking Authority. The latter was satisfied at its hearing by the European Parliament's Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs.  This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. There is nothing against the previous Presidency, so I am voting in favour of extending the mandate.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. On 8 September 2015, the EBA Board of Supervisors proposed renewing the mandate of its Chairman. In view of the sensitive supervisory role played by the EBA in ensuring the financial stability of the euro area, and noting the careful direction already taken by President Andrea Erria, I have decided to give a favourable opinion on the renewal of its mandate. I congratulate the President and wish him well in his work.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. We are voting in favour of the renewal of Andrea Enria as President of the European Banking Authority (EBA) for a five-year term. The EBA provides a counterweight to the ECB, which has consistently arrogated powers that come back to the EBA.  For the record, the EBA is responsible for coordinating banking supervision for non-systemic banks in the Union, which are under the supervision of the ECB.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the fact that, following the committee hearing, in the S&D Group we consider it necessary to extend the mandate of the President of the European Banking Authority, which was approved by a large majority of the rest of the political groups.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: in writing. This report is due to the need for approval of the decision of the Board of Supervisors of the European Banking Authority (EBA) of 8 September 2015 to extend the mandate of the President of the European Banking Authority.  The first EBA president was appointed by the EBA Board of Supervisors in 2011, following an open selection procedure, for a five-year term. Article 48(4) of Regulation (EU) No 1093/2010 provides that the EBA Board of Supervisors, taking into account the analysis by the Board of Supervisors, may once extend the mandate of the EBA President, subject to ratification by the European Parliament. The Board of Supervisors proposed the renewal and, on 17 November 2015, the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs held a hearing with Andrea Enria, the current president of EBA, at which he made a preliminary statement and then responded to questions from the members of the committee. As there is a consensus on the President's action, I vote in favour of the proposal to extend Andrea Enria's term as president of EBA for another five years.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I supported the extension of the five-year term of office to European Banking Authority (EBA) President Andrea Enria, recommended by the EBA Supervisory Board. The EBA is an independent body but is accountable to the European Parliament, the Commission and the Council. Its main objectives are to maintain financial stability in the EU and to ensure the integrity, effectiveness and proper functioning of the banking sector.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Banking Authority was set up at the beginning of 2011 to deal with the regulation and supervision of the banking system of the Member States of the European Union. Its functioning, especially after the 2008-2009 crisis, which, as a result of which has also largely led to this, through reform from the Committee of European Banking Supervisors, is centred on guaranteeing financial stability in our community, both within and outside the euro area. Given that, following his first appointment, the term of office of the President of the European Banking Authority can be extended for a further 5 years and Andrea Enria has been sufficiently quality and productive since 2011, it was logical to express confidence in him and extend his term of office until 2021.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report because I do not agree with the extension of the term of office of the President of the European Banking Authority.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted to approve the proposal for the extension of the term of office of Andrea Enria as Chairperson of the EBA by another five-year term.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I voted to extend the mandate of Andrea Enria, the President of the European Banking Authority (EBA).  The EBA is normally responsible for coordinating the supervision of non-systematic banks in the European Union, in partnership with the European Central Bank (ECB). Yet the ECB continues to take over the powers of the EBA.  In accepting the extension of the mandate of its President, we express our support for this institution in the face of the excesses of the ECB.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing. \u2012 The Board of Supervisors of the European Banking Authority (EBA) proposes to renew the mandate of the EBA President, Andrea Enria, for a further five years. The commentary report, which I support by voting in favour, approves the continuation of the President's mandate, recalling Article 48(4) of Regulation (EU) No 1093/2010 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 24 November 2010, which, precisely, grants this power to the Supervisory Authority of the European Banking Authority.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. There are no objections to the previous Presidency. I agree with this report.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. The European Banking Authority (EBA) was set up in 2011. Its mission is to contribute to the stability and efficiency of the financial system in the short, medium and long term, including by improving the functioning of the internal market, through a "satisfactory, effective and coherent" level of regulation and supervision. Vast program!  This authority is notably responsible for underestimating the recapitalisation needs of European banks, taking into account only the depreciation of sovereign debts on their balance sheets and leaving aside the effects of the economic crisis and the specific situations of certain countries (such as the explosion of the housing bubble in Spain).  Its president, Andrea Enria, formerly head of banking supervision at the Bank of Italy, has been at the helm of the EBA for five years. I'm voting against extending his term.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 The Board of Supervisors of the European Insurance and Occupational Pensions Authority (EIOPA) presented on 30 September 2015 a proposal to extend the term of office of the President of EIOPA for another five years. The European Parliament voted in favour of the proposal and I followed the direction of voting in agreement with the proposal to extend the mandate.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ Following on from the Board of Supervisors of the EBA’s proposal to extend Andrea Enria’s term of office, as well as his successful hearing before the ECON Committee I was happy to support this extension.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. In the wake of the banking and financial crisis, the European Union has set up the European Banking Authority, which is responsible for ensuring a high level of regulation and prudential supervision in order to ensure financial stability within the European Union and the smooth functioning of the banking sector.  This independent authority has been chaired by Andrea Enria since its inception in 2011. As he is responsible to the European Parliament, we have voted to extend his mandate. His background and experience convinced me to approve this new mandate.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: Writing. \u2012 The report proposes extending the term of office of the Chair of the European Banking Authority for a further five-year term. In 2011, the Board of Supervisors of the EBA appointed the first chair, Andrea Enria, following an open selection procedure. The Council of the Institutions has the possibility to take account of the evaluation and to extend the term of office once. The proposal was made by the Council of The Authorities, the President-in-Office was heard, made an opening statement and answered all questions accordingly. In view of the fulfilment of the necessary conditions for extending the term of office, I agree with the approval of the proposal.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Gualtieri report because I support the extension of the term of office of the Chairperson of the European Banking Authority.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Banking Authority was set up by Regulation (EU) No 1093/2010 of the European Parliament and of the Council adopted on 24 November 2010. Its President Andrea Enria was appointed by the EBA Board of Supervisors in 2011 after an open tender procedure for a five-year term of office. Under that Regulation, the Board of Supervisors may extend the term of office of the Chairman once, provided that this decision is confirmed by Parliament. By decision of the Board of Supervisors on 8 September, it proposed extending the term of office of the Incumbent President. The Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs heard Andrea Enria on 17 November and in her report recommended to Parliament that parliament confirm the decision of the Board of Supervisors. I voted accordingly.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: In writing. It is proposed to vote in favour of the renewal of Andrea Enria's mandate as EBA President for five years. The EBA and its president provide a counterweight to the ECB, which has repeatedly arrogated powers that come back to the EBA.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. \u2012 In 2011, the first President of the European Banking Authority (EBA) was appointed by the Board of Supervisors for a term of five years, in accordance with Article 48(2) of Regulation (EU) No 1093/2010, and it is possible to extend its term of office for another five years, provided that it is confirmed by the European Parliament in accordance with paragraph 4 of that article. To this extent, the extension of the mandate of the current President of the EBA, Andrea Enria, was proposed. Consequently, the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs held a successful hearing in which President Andrea Enria delivered an initial statement, following questions raised by the members of the committee. I shall vote in favour of this report, in so far as it complies with the criteria legally required for the extension of the term of office of the President of that institution.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. The proposal to reappoint Andrea Enria as EBA President for five years is a good proposal.  The EBA provides a counterweight to the ECB, which has consistently arrogated powers that went to the EBA (responsible for coordinating banking supervision for non-systemic EU banks, which are under the supervision of the ECB). Andrea Enria has secured her mandate correctly. I'm voting for an extension of his term.

name: Claude MORAES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report which ratifies the ECON committee decision to extend the term of office of Andrea Enria as Chairperson of the EBA by another five-year term.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the extension of the mandate of the President of the European Banking Authority (EBA).  Andrea Enria, the first president of this banking authority, was appointed in 2011 for a five-year term by the Board of Supervisory Authorities following an open selection process. The Board requested that this term be extended for five years. After a hearing of the current President-in-Office, the European Parliament's Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs approved the request.  I voted in accordance with the opinion of this committee. The mandate of President of this authority can only be renewed once, with the agreement of the European Parliament.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for the the extension of the term of office of the Chairperson of the European Banking Authority (EBA).

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 I have no doubt that you agree with me that the work done so far by Andrea Enria as President of the EBA has been excellent. That is why I urge you to vote together in a positive way for its confirmation for the next five years. I would like to take this opportunity, if the outcome of the vote is expected, to wish him well in his work.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ Taking into account the proposals and positions of the EBA Board of Supervisors on extending the five-year term for incumbent Andrea Enri, I support Robert Gualtieri's report. Years of previous experience at the Italian and European central bank makes Andrea Enri a person whose expertise and knowledge meet the needs of such an important body.  The European Banking Authority is an independent EU body tasked with ensuring a consistent level of regulation and oversight of the European banking sector. Priority objectives are to ensure financial stability, ensure integrity, efficiency and proper functioning of the banking sector.  In addition to its responsibility to the European Parliament, the Council of the European Union and the European Commission, the EBA presents as its main mission a set of prudential rules aimed at helping to create a level playing field and to provide high protections towards savers, investors and consumers. Due to the importance of the functions performed by this body, it is necessary to have a person whose expertise has been verified on several levels.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. The proposal to renew Andrea Enria's mandate as EBA President for five years is a good proposal.  The EBA provides a counterweight to the ECB, which has consistently arrogated powers that went to the EBA (responsible for coordinating banking supervision for non-systemic EU banks, which are under the supervision of the ECB).  Andrea Enria has secured her mandate correctly. I am therefore voting for the extension of his mandate.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒ Since the first EBA President was appointed by the EBA Board of Supervisors in 2011 following an open selection procedure for a period of five years in accordance with Article 48(2) of the EA. Regulation (EU) No 2020/2013 1093/2010, and that Article 48(4) of the Regulation (EU) No 2020/2013 1093/2010 stipulates that the EBA Board of Supervisors may once extend the term of office of EBA President, at the proposal of the EBA Supervisor, I accept a proposal to extend Andrea Enria's term as EBA president for the next five years.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. - I support MEP Robert Gualtieri's report on extending the mandate of the President of the European Banking Authority, at the proposal of the European Banking Authority's Board of Supervisors. The first EBA President was appointed by the EBA Board of Supervisors in 2011 following an open selection procedure for a period of five years, while Article 48(4) of the EA Regulation (EU) No 2020/2013 1093/2010 stipulates that the EBA Board of Supervisors may once extend the term of office of eba president.  Taking into account the fact that the Economic and Monetary Policy Committee held a hearing of Andrea Enria, I consider it justified to extend the mandate of EBA President Andrea Enria for the next five years. Since all legal and procedural norms have been respected, I support the extension of the mandate of the former EBA President, Andrea Enria.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 The EBA is an EU agency charged with implementing a set of standard rules to regulate and monitor the work of the banking sector in all EU countries. Its aim is to create an efficient, transparent and stable single market in EU banking products. Its Chairman leads the discussions at meetings of the EBA Council, in which the supervisory authorities of all EU countries participate. I congratulate the President of the EBA, Andrea Enria, on the renewal of his mandate, wishing him well in the hope that he will be able to play his role with the utmost independence and transparency.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. We were asked to vote on the extension of the EBA president's term. It's a common procedure. It is good that Parliament has control over the functioning of the bodies dependent on the institutions.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. Today I voted in favour of the proposal to extend Andrea Enria's term as President of the European Banking Authority for a new five-year term.  As a reminder, the European Banking Authority is an independent authority of the European Union which works to ensure an effective and consistent level of prudential regulation and supervision throughout the European banking sector. Its main objectives are to maintain financial stability in the European Union and to ensure the integrity, efficiency and smooth running of the banking sector.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. \u2012 This Decision of the European Parliament extends the mandate of the current President of the European Banking Authority, Andrea Enria, for another five years. Its previous appointment was made through an open and transparent selection procedure and Article 48(4) of Regulation (EU) No 1093/2010 clearly provides for the possibility of an extension.  The European Parliament's decision and there are no constraints to the renewal of its mandate are necessary, I have given my vote in favour.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. – Since we oppose the mandate and activity of these three supervisory agencies, we have also opposed the extension of the mandate of their respective presidents.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. I voted against this report because it entails increasing the president's mandate to ensure the continuity of the functioning of the European Banking Authority. We cannot positively sanction the management of this Authority because it is a fundamental part of the European Financial Supervision System. This system implies a transfer of sovereignty in the field of financial supervision to authorities that lack true democratic control, resulting in financial supervision designed according to the interests of large financial sector companies. Regular financial supervision is essential to ensure the interests of the European working classes, and Andrea Enria's current mandate has proved not to guarantee the possibility of developing a public banking that can serve the interests of Europeans. That is why I have decided to vote against this report.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: in writing. ‒ In principle I object to the authority of the EU regulators and so cannot support the extension of the term of office. So I voted against this proposal.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ After the hearing with Andrea Enria, the incumbent Chairperson of the EBA, at the Committee of Economic and Monetary Affairs, I am confident in his competence and I wish him well in his future.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 In 2011, the first President of the European Banking Authority (EBA) was appointed, following an open selection procedure for a term of five years.  Pursuant to Article 48(4) of Regulation (EU) No 1093/2010, the Board of Supervisors of EBA may, taking into account the evaluation, extend this term of office of the President of EBA once, subject to confirmation by the European Parliament. On 8 September 2015, the Board of Supervisors of EBA proposed extending the term of office of EBA President-in-Office Andrea Enri for a further five-year period and also informed the EP thereof. Subsequently, on 17 November 2015, the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs held a hearing of the President-in-Office of the EBA, during which Andrea Enria made an opening statement and was then given the opportunity to be asked questions to which he also answered. On the basis of a recommendation from the Council and a hearing in committee, the European Parliament has decided to extend the term of office of the President of the European Banking Authority.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: Writing. \u2012 This is a valid position, the extension of which I support.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. ‒ I support the extension of Mr Andrea Enria's term as President of the European Banking Agency since, on 17 November 2015, he was elected president of the European Banking Agency. The Economic and Monetary Policy Committee held a hearing of Andrea Enria, the current President of the EBA, at which he made a recital and then satisfactorily answered questions from the members of the Committee.

name: Catherine STIHLER
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour to extend the term of office of Andrea Enria, the incumbent Chairperson of the European Banking Authority, following his statement and replies to questions posed by fellow MEPs in the hearing in the European Parliament Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs in November.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. ‒ The European Banking Authority (EBA) was established on 24 November 2010 under Article 48(4) of the EA. Regulation (EU) No 2020/2013 1093/2010 on the proposal of the European Parliament and the Council. The eba's first president was appointed by the EBA Board of Supervisors in 2011 following an open selection process for a period of five years. As Article 48(4) of the Regulation (EU) No 2020/2013 1093/2010 stipulates that the EBA Board of Supervisors may once extend the term of office of eba president, on the basis of the abovementioned 8 September 2015, the EBA Board of Supervisors proposed to extend the term of office of Mr Andrea Enria, the current President of the EBA, for the next five years. I support the European Parliament's first reading proposal to extend the mandate of Mr Andrea Enria, as EBA President for a second five-year term, as he has demonstrated the commitment and level of expertise needed to carry out the work so far. In addition, as it is a relatively new body, continuity in the form of extension of mandates opens the perspective of consistent implementation and achievement of the set objectives in the set framework.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal to extend the term of office of the EBA President, given that the current President has so far proved to be a sufficiently qualified person to perform this post.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. \ i voted in favour of extending the mandate of the President of the European Banking Authority (EBA). In September this year, the EBA Board of Supervisors proposed extending the mandate of current EBA President Andrea Enrii, who took office in 2011, for a further five years. As he has also successfully served a hearing on the committee responsible for the European Parliament, I supported the extension of the mandate.

name: Kay SWINBURNE
text: in writing. ‒ The Chairman of the EBA has had an unprecedented amount of work to do during his first mandate due to the many level 2 measures that the EBA has drafted. Given this work is still on-going and at a crucial stage, I am happy to approve the current chairman for a second mandate in order to ensure continuity to the legislative process.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 We did not support the creation of the European Supervisory Authorities (ESA) because we disagree with the way they operate. That is why we did not even support the reappointment of presidents.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 This person does not meet the conditions required for this position.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. Parliament voted in favour of extending the mandate. I also voted in favour of this election.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of prolonging the term of office of the Chairperson of the European Banking Authority (EBA). Mr Andrea Enria was appointed to this position in 2011, and in September 2015 the Board of Supervisors of the EBA proposed to extend his term of office by another five-year term. Before taking up the Chairmanship of EBA, Mr Enria was the Head of the Regulation and Supervisory Policy Department at the Bank of Italy. He had previously served as Secretary General of the Committee of European Banking Supervisors, the predecessor of EBA, and worked in the European Central Bank.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. I voted to extend the mandate of Andrea Enria, the current President of the European Banking Authority (EBA), as proposed by the EBA Board of Supervisors. I believe that that body in direct relationship with the President can assess its qualifications and abilities to perform that function in a quality way, since it is his responsibility to prepare the work of the Committee and to chair the meetings of the Board of the Administrative Authority.  I believe that MEPs need to confirm another mandate to Enria, as it is obvious that the Board of Supervisors considers him the most suitable candidate and have full confidence in his work in creating an effective framework for the European Union single market in the field of banking. In addition, if it does not fulfil its tasks effectively, the European Parliament may relieve it of its duties following a decision of the Board of Supervisors.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. I supported the report on the extension of the mandate of the President of the European Banking Authority (EBA) because Article 48(4) of Regulation (EU) No 1093/2010 provides that, taking into account the assessment provided for in the provision, the EBA Board of Supervisors may, once and again, extend the term of office of the President of eba, subject to the prior approval of the European Parliament.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. – Since we oppose the mandate and activity of these three supervisory agencies, we have also opposed the extension of the mandate of their respective presidents.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. \u2012 Under Regulation (EU) No 1093/2010, the EBA Board of Supervisors may, taking into account the assessment referred to in this provision, extend the term of office of the President once, subject to the strengthening of the European Parliament. The reportter, Andrea Enria, president of the EBA, proposed extending her term of office for a further five-year period. I voted in favour.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. – Since we oppose the mandate and activity of these three supervisory agencies, we have also opposed the extension of the mandate of their respective presidents.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour because I approve the proposal for the extension of the term of office of Andrea Enria as Chairperson of the EBA by another five-year term. The European Banking Authority (EBA) is an independent EU Authority which works to ensure effective and consistent prudential regulation and supervision across the European banking sector. Its overall objectives are to maintain financial stability in the EU and to safeguard the integrity, efficiency and orderly functioning of the banking sector. This authority plays an important and responsible role and after the hearing with Andrea Enria, the incumbent Chairperson of the EBA, at which he made an opening statement and then responded to questions from the members of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs and after a careful evaluation, I believe the approval was justified.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. Taking into account that the European Banking Authority has proposed extending Mr Enria's mandate and that the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs has approved this proposal, I consider it necessary to vote in favour of that decision.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. 'I voted in favour of the five-year extension of the mandate of the President of the European Banking Authority, because this seemed to me to be the most appropriate choice.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. \u2012 This is an extension of the mandate for the position of president of an institution that was created as part of an economic integration process with which we do not agree. We have nothing against the person itself, nor is it relevant for us to give an opinion on their personal and professional qualities. We are sure that it will faithfully carry out the functions for which it will be in charge, that is, to contribute to consolidating the class dominance of the financial sector and the large economic groups that effectively command this EU.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. There are no objections to the previous Presidency. I agree with this report.

name: Marco ZANNI
text: in writing. \u2012 A Microprudential Supervision System at European level was created at the end of 2010, consisting of the European Banking Authority (EBA, based in London), the European Financial instruments and markets Authority (ESMA, based in Paris) and the European Insurance and Occupational Pensions Authority (EIOPA, based in Frankfurt). In 2011, the Presidents of the three Authorities were appointed, for a five-year term renewable only once. The Board of the European Banking Authority has proposed renewing the mandate to Andrea Enria. The European Parliament's ECON Committee only held a hearing of the candidate, and then voted last week to renew the mandate by a very large majority.  I voted against, firstly because of an almost automatic method of renewal with no real motivation; Moreover, the role and value of these authorities has so far proved to be rather marginal, and therefore to continue in the path of five unsatisfactory years certainly does not seem the best decision that could be taken.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. The first President of the EBA was appointed in 2011 for a five-year term. The EBA is part of the European Financial Supervision System (ESFS). The EBA's express objective is to ensure consistent and effective prudential regulation and supervision throughout the European banking sector. In this sense, it aims to identify vulnerabilities in order to be able to repair the banking sector and increase confidence in it. Creating the illusion that the problems that led to the 2007/2008 financial crisis are resolved, the ESFS has not changed the fundamental issue of financial speculation, as it has not put an end to derivatives markets and tax havens and has not established the separation of commercial banking from investment. History will show that the creation of these European authorities was of little value.

name: Milan ZVER
text: Writing. I support the European Parliament's decision to extend Andrea Enrie's mandate as President of the European Banking Authority (EBA) because Mr Enria has successfully answered all the questions and concerns of the members of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. I voted against this report because it entails increasing the president's mandate to ensure the continuity of the functioning of the European Insurance and Pensions Authority. We cannot positively sanction the management of this Authority because it is a fundamental part of the European Financial Supervision System. This system implies a transfer of sovereignty in the field of financial supervision to authorities that lack true democratic control, resulting in financial supervision designed according to the interests of large financial sector companies. It is essential to regulate the sector to ensure the interests of the European working classes, and Gabriel Bernardino's current mandate has shown that it does not shield and extend public pension systems that can serve the interests of Europeans. That is why I have decided to vote against this report.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. This report proposes to reappoint the President of AEAPP (European Insurance and Occupational Pensions Authority) for a period of five years. I abstained, as Gabriel Bernardino's presidency did not call for any particular comment.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ This vote was taken by secret ballot. However, in the interests of democracy I should confirm for the benefit of my constituents that I voted against.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. On 30 September 2015, eiopa's Board of Supervisors submitted a proposal to extend the term of office of the current PRESIDENT of EIOPA, Gabriel Bernardino, for a further five years. November 17, 2015 The Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs held a hearing with the current chairman of EIOPA, Gabriel Bernardino, during which the Chairman gave an introductory speech and answered questions from committee members. I support the proposal to extend the term of office of EIOPA President Gabriel Bernardino for a further five years.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. The three reports filed by Roberto Gualtieri are aimed at renewing for five years the mandates of the presidents of the three agencies under the control of the ECON Committee: the European Banking Agency (EBA), the European Financial Markets Authority (ESMA) and the European Insurance and Occupational Pensions Authority (AEAPP). If I voted to extend the mandate of the current President of the European Banking Authority (EBA), I preferred to abstain for the extension of Gabriel Bernardino's term as head of the European Insurance and Occupational Pensions Authority (AEAPP).

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. Gabriel Bernardino, AEAPP's current president, was appointed in 2011 for a five-year term. In accordance with the regulatory requirement, the AEAPP Supervisory Authority Council may propose a five-year extension of the President's term once with confirmation from the European Parliament. This request was made and the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, after hearing from the person concerned, gave a very positive opinion. I approved this extension.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. – Since we oppose the mandate and activity of these three supervisory agencies, we have also opposed the extension of the mandate of their respective presidents.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report on the extension of the mandate of the President of the European Banking Authority for Insurance and Retirement Pensions. It was appointed after an open selection procedure and the Supervisory Board of the Authority proposed extending its mandate to continue working on it and to build a true European Banking Authority for Insurance and Retirement Pensions.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. I preferred to abstain on this report which concerned the extension of the mandate of the President of the European Insurance and Occupational Pensions Authority. Of course, Mr Bernardino seems to be in compliance with the objectives set by the European Insurance and Occupational Pensions Authority and his mandate does not call for any particular comment. However, I reject the role played by this agency, which is currently aiming for harmonisation at European level.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 Although there is nothing objective to justify my opposition to the renewal of Gabriel Bernardino as President of the European Insurance and Occupational Pensions Authority, I opposed this measure in order to express my disagreement with the economic policies of the European institutions.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I have supported the extension of Gabriel Bernardino's term as chairman of the European Insurance and Pensions Authority for another five years considering the support received by the European Parliament's Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs following his appearance on 17 November and having passed the scrutiny by the members of that committee.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because it was approved by Parliament for the extension of the term of office of the President of the European Insurance and Occupational Pensions Authority (EIOPA). Eiopa's Chair was appointed by eiopa's Supervisory Board in 2011, following an open selection procedure, for a term of five years, which may be extended once, subject to the agreement of the European Parliament. On 30 September 2015, eiopa's Board of Supervisors submitted a proposal to extend the term of office of the current PRESIDENT of EIOPA, Gabriel Bernardino, for a further five years and informed the European Parliament accordingly, and parliament therefore approved the extension of the term of office.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: Writing. I also supported the proposed extension of the mandate of the President of the European Insurance and Occupational Pensions Authority (EIOPA) on the basis of the findings of the EBA Board of Supervisors and their proposal to extend the mandate of the previous President of EIOPA, Gabriel Bernardin, for a further five years. Mr. Bernardino has done a great job to this past, and he has convinced me with his work, so I have no reason not to trust him for another five years.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. The purpose of this report is to renew for five years the mandate of the President of the European Insurance and Occupational Pensions Authority, which is an independent advisory body to the European Parliament. The main objective of AEAPP is to improve the protection of policyholders and beneficiaries of pension plans.  I abstained on this proposal in light of the profile of the current President.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the report on the extension of the term of office of the current President of the European Insurance and Occupational Pensions Authority (AEAPO), namely Mr Gabriel Bernardino, because his reappointment as a management gives the institution a continuous framework for the way of driving, with no possibility of syncope.  EIOPA has as its core responsibilities supporting the stability of the financial system, the transparency of financial markets and products, and the protection of insurance consumers and members and beneficiaries of private pension schemes.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 The first President of EIOPA was appointed in 2011 for a five-year term. The Board of Supervisors of EIOPA may renew the mandate of Gabriel Bernardino, currently in office, for a further five years. It is clear that, for our part, more than a critical position towards the current President, what determines our choice of vote is the critical orientation that characterises our delegation and the whole group of which we are a member. Our position, which is totally contrary to the economic policies of the European institutions, can only see us opposed to the renewal of the office in question.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the proposal to renew the mandate of the President of the European Insurance and Occupational Pensions Authority (EIOPA). I believe that dr. Bernardino finds a positive assessment of the work and results achieved over the past five years, as well as the prospects and plans of the organization for the future. A positive opinion also shared by the Steering Committee of the European Insurance and Pensions Authority, which decided to reconfirm Dr Gabriel Bernardino as president of the organisation for a new five-year term.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. – I voted against the extension of the term of office of the Chairperson of the European Insurance and Occupational Pensions Authority (EIOPA). A number of these regulatory bodies were set up after the financial crash, the stated aim being to regulate the financial markets so that another financial crash would not happen. Of course, robust regulation is required but there are critical concerns with these bodies. There is a huge democratic deficit running through these bodies and moreover, a number of legal concerns have been voiced. The bodies have very fragile legal foundations and a number of legal experts have stated that the setting up of such bodies was done outside of the confines of EU Treaty Law. To explain simply, when an EU body is being set up, you have to first go back to the primary treaties which founded the EU and look at the Treaty provisions. If there is no provision in the Treaty to set up such an initiative, then it can be declared as ultra vires i.e. be outside of EU law and have no legal foundation. Therefore, it was for these reasons that I voted against the extension of the EIOPA.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the extension of the term of office of Gabriel Bernardino as the Chairperson of the European Insurance and Occupational Pensions Authority following his hearing in the Committee of the Economic and Monetary Affairs. The evaluation of his work was positive and the Board of Directors of EIOPA was also satisfied with Mr Bernardino keeping his post.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 As with the renewal of the presidency of the other two authorities, I believe that everything has happened too hastily, taking renewal for granted. I have therefore voted against this.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 Considering that the first President of the ESAES was appointed by the Board of Supervisors of the ESAES in 2011, following an open selection procedure, for a period of five years, in accordance with Article 48(2) of Regulation (EU) No 1782/2003, Whereas Article 48(4) of Regulation (EU) No 1094/2010 should therefore be amended accordingly. 1094/2010 provides that the Board of Supervisors of the EAES, having taken into account the assessment referred to in that provision, it may extend the term of office of the President of the EAEC once, subject to ratification by the European Parliament and, finally, bearing in mind that on 30 September 2015 the Board of Supervisors of the EAEC proposed extending the term of office of Mr Gabriel Bernardino, President of the EESA, for a further five years, informing the European Parliament the decision to extend the term of office.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The proposal to extend the term of office of the President of the European Insurance and Occupational Pensions Authority is a formal procedure with no particular implications. However, since I was opposed from the outset to the creation and operation of this principle, I preferred to abstain from voting on this proposal.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of reconfirming Gabriel Bernardino's term as President of EIOPA for another five years. I also considered the hearing that took place on 17 November 2015 to be exhaustive, during which Bernardino made a preliminary statement and answered all the questions put to him by the members of the committee.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because, considering that the EBA Board of Supervisors has proposed renewing the mandate of Andrea Enria, President-in-Office of the EBA, for a further five years, and has informed the European Parliament. Furthermore, in view of the fact that the mandate of the President of the EBA can be renewed once, subject to confirmation by the European Parliament, I would like to take this opportunity to congratulate and wish him well in his work on the important task he will carry out, as usual, with great commitment.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 I congratulate him on the renaming of the mandate of EIOPA President Gabriel Bernardino, wishing him a good job that will certainly lead to excellent results.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. – I voted in favour on the basis of a positive recommendation on 30 September 2015 by the Board of Supervisors of the EIOPA proposing the extension of the term of office of Gabriel Bernardino, the incumbent Chairperson of the EIOPA by another five-year term, following response to questions from the members of the Economic and Monetary Affairs Committee on 17 November 2015. The Board of Supervisors of the EIOPA is best placed to judge the competence of the person and alternative scenarios.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. \u2012 A Microprudential Supervision System at European level was created at the end of 2010, consisting of the European Banking Authority (EBA, based in London), the European Financial instruments and markets Authority (ESMA, based in Paris) and the European Insurance and Occupational Pensions Authority (EIOPA, based in Frankfurt).  In 2011, the presidents of the three Authorities were appointed, for a five-year term renewable only once. The respective boards of supervisors have proposed renewing the mandate to both Andrea Enria (EBA), Gabriel Bernardino (EIOPA) and also Steven Maijoor (ESMA). The European Parliament's ECON Committee only held a hearing of the candidates, and then voted last week to renew the mandate for all three by a very large majority. We voted against, firstly because of an almost automatic method of renewal with no real reasons; Moreover, the role and value of these authorities has so far proved to be rather marginal, and therefore to continue in the path of five unsatisfactory years certainly does not seem the best decision that could be taken. So even today I am voting against.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. I voted against this report because it entails increasing the president's mandate to ensure the continuity of the functioning of the European Insurance and Pensions Authority. We cannot positively sanction the management of this Authority because it is a fundamental part of the European Financial Supervision System. This system implies a transfer of sovereignty in the field of financial supervision to authorities that lack true democratic control, resulting in financial supervision designed according to the interests of large financial sector companies. It is essential to regulate the sector to ensure the interests of the European working classes, and Gabriel Bernardino's current mandate has shown that it does not shield and extend public pension systems that can serve the interests of Europeans. That is why I have decided to vote against this report.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: Writing. – The Frankfurt-based European Insurance and Occupational Pensions Authority (EIOPA) was established in 2010 to prevent the risk of destabilisation of the insurance sector. EIOPA promotes cooperation between national authorities and ensures the consistent application of EU legislation in the insurance and occupational pension sectors in EU Member States. In September 2015, the EIOPA Board of Supervisors recommended that the term of office of EIOPA President-in-Office Gabriel Bernardino be extended for another five years and informed the European Parliament of its proposal. Parliament's Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs (ECON) heard the President-in-Office of EIOPA and adopted a report extending the term of office of the current President of the Office. According to the ECON report, the EP plenary adopted a five-year extension of the office of the President of EIOPA. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the reappointment of the Chairperson of the European Insurance and Occupational Pensions Authority. In 2011, Gabriel Bernardino was selected to be the Chairperson of the European Insurance and Occupational Pensions Authority for five years. I voted in favour of extending his mandate for another five years. Prior to the vote Parliament invited Bernardino to the Committee on Economic Affairs in November where no major issues came up.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This report proposes the positive opinion of the European Parliament on the extension of the mandate of the President of the European Insurance and Occupational Pensions Authority (AEAPP), Gabriel BERNARDINO, for a further five-year period.  According to European rules, the president of AEAPP is elected by the Board of the supervisory authority. The latter is also entitled to reappoint the President for an additional term, which requires prior evaluation and approval by the European Parliament.  On 17 November, members of the European Parliament auditioned the President-candidate. Since it has met the expectations of MEPs, I support this report which is in favour of extending its mandate.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 We are voting against the extension of the term of office because the person in question does not fulfil the conditions required for that post.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: in writing. – I voted against as I believe this position should not exist in the first place.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the extension of the term of office of the President of the European Insurance and Occupational Pensions Authority.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the extension of the term of office of the President of the European Insurance and Occupational Pensions Authority (EIOPA) because that person does not fulfil the conditions required for this post.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ Having regard to the proposal of the Board of Supervisors of the European Insurance and Occupational Pensions Authority (EIOPA) of 30 September 2015 to extend the term of office of the Chairperson of the EIOPA by another five-year term (C8-0314/2015) and following the ECON hearing, I support the extension of the term of office of Gabriel Bernardino as Chairperson of the EIOPA.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. \u2012 The first President of EIOPA was appointed by the EIOPA Board of Supervisors in 2011 after an open tender procedure for a five-year term of office, in accordance with Article 48(2) of Regulation (EU) No 1094/2010; Whereas Article 48(4) of Regulation (EU) No 1094/2010 provides that the EIOPA Board of Supervisors may, taking into account the assessment referred to in this provision, extend the term of office of the President once, subject to the strengthening of the European Parliament; Whereas on 30 September 2015 the EIOPA Board of Supervisors proposed an extension of the term of office of Gabriel Bernardino, President-in-Office of EIOPA, for a further five years and informed the European Parliament accordingly; Whereas, on 17 November 2015, the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs heard Gabriel Bernardino, President-in-Office of EIOPA, give an opening statement and answer questions from the members of the Committee. It approves the proposal to extend the term of office of EIOPA President Gabriel Bernardino for a further five-year period and instructs its President to forward this decision to the Council, the Commission, EIOPA and the Governments of the Member States. In view of the above, I voted in favour of the report on the extension of the term of office of the President of the European Insurance and Occupational Pensions Authority (EIOPA).

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. I voted in favour of extending the term of office of the President of the European Insurance and Pensions Authority (EESPJ) considering that he was appointed by the EESPJ Board of Supervisors in 2011, following an open selection procedure, and considering that the EPPO Board of Supervisors proposed extending Gabriel Bernardino's term of office for another five years.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Writing. I voted in favour of extending the term of office of the Chairman of the European Insurance and Occupational Pensions Authority (EIOPA) as I believe that staffing and rigorous continuation of work are right and important.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Writing. After an in-depth review, I have agreed to extend the term of office of the Chairman of the European Insurance and Occupational Pensions Authority.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. ‒ Given the satisfactory results of the hearing on 17 November 2015 in the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs  with Gabriel Bernardino, I decided to give my support to the extension of the term of office of the Chairperson of the European Insurance and Occupational Pensions Authority (EIOPA).

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. Since we oppose the mandate and activity of these three supervisory agencies, we have also opposed the extension of the mandate of their respective presidents.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the reappointment of the Chairperson of the European Insurance and Occupational Pensions Authority. In 2011, Gabriel Bernardino was selected to be the Chairperson of the European Insurance and Occupational Pensions Authority for five years. I voted in favour of extending his mandate for another five years. Prior to the vote Parliament invited Bernardino to the Committee on Economic Affairs in November where no major issues came up.

name: Nathan GILL
text: in writing. ‒ Secret Ballot!  Why oh why do the EU fear transparency?  We voted against!
