text: Writing. \u2012 In a secret ballot, MEPs extended the term of office of Steven Maijoor as President of the European Securities and Markets Authority (ESMA) for a further term of office of five years. ESMA President Mr Steven Maijoor was appointed in 2011 following an open selection procedure for a period of five years. Pursuant to Article 48(2) of Regulation (EU) No 1095/2010, ESMA's Board of Supervisors, taking into account the evaluation, has proposed to extend the term of office of esma's Chairperson once, subject to confirmation by the European Parliament. On 17 November 2015, the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs held a hearing of ESMA's President-in-Office, Steven Maijoor, during which he made a statement and then answered questions from committee members. As the committee approved the proposal, it submitted a motion for a resolution to the European Parliament for approval.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the extended term of office of Steven Maijoor as President of the European Securities and Markets Authority (ESMA) for a further five-year term, because during his time in office he has contributed to the stability of the European Union's financial system, as well as to improving investor protection and contributing to the stability of financial markets.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. ‒ I supported the proposal to extend the mandate of the President of the European Securities and Markets Authority (ESMA), Steven Maijoor, taking into account the report of the Economic and Monetary Policy Committee. Namely, 24 September 2015 The ESMA Board of Supervisors proposed extending the mandate of Steven Maijoor, the current President of ESMA, for the next five years and informed the European Parliament.

name: Catherine STIHLER
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour to extend the term of office of Steven Maijoor, the incumbent Chairperson of the European Securities and Markets Authority (ESMA), following his statement and replies to questions posed by fellow MEPs in the hearing in the European Parliament Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs in November.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. ‒The European Securities and Markets Authority (ESMA) was established on 24 November 2010 under Article 48(4) of the EAB. Regulation (EU) No 2020/2013 1095/2010 on the proposal of the European Parliament and the Council.  The first Chair of ESMA was appointed by the ESMA Board of Supervisors in 2011 following an open selection procedure for a period of five years. As Article 48(4) of the Regulation (EU) No 2020/2013 1095/2010 provided that the ESMA Board of Supervisors, taking into account the assessment, may once extend the term of office of the President of ESMA, on the basis of that 24 September 2015, the ESMA Board of Supervisors proposed the extension of the term of office to Mr Steven Maijoor, the current President of ESMA, for the next five years. I support the Proposal for a Decision of the European Parliament at first reading on the extension of the mandate of Mr Steven Maijoor, as President of ESMA for a second five-year term, as he has demonstrated in his work so far the commitment and level of expertise necessary to carry out the work. In addition, as it is a relatively new body, continuity in the form of extension of mandates opens the perspective of consistent implementation and achievement of the set objectives in the set framework.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of extending the term of office of the President of the European Securities and Markets Authority (ESMA). Esma's Board of Supervisors proposed in September this year to extend the mandate of the current PRESIDENT OF ESMA, Steven Maijoor, for a further five years. Mr Maijoor has also successfully served a hearing on the committee responsible for the European Parliament, and I therefore support the extension of the mandate.

name: Kay SWINBURNE
text: in writing. ‒ The Chairman of the ESMA has had an unprecedented amount of work to do during his first mandate due to the many level 2 measures that the ESMA has drafted. Given this work is still on-going and at a crucial stage, I am happy to approve the current chairman for a second mandate in order to ensure continuity to the legislative process.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 We did not support the creation of the European Supervisory Authorities (ESA) because we disagree with the way they operate and for the same reason we will not support the reappointment of their presidents either.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 This person does not meet the conditions required for this post.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. Parliament voted in favour of extending the mandate. I also voted in favour of this election.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of another five-year term in office for the Chairperson of the European Securities and Markets Authority (ESMA), following a proposal by its Board of Supervisors of September 2015. Mr Steven Maijoor was appointed the first Chairperson of the ESMA in 2011. Before joining ESMA, Steven Maijoor was Managing Director at the AFM, the Dutch financial markets regulator and prior to that he was the Dean of the School of Business and Economics at Maastricht University, having pursued a long career in academia.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. I voted to support the extension of the mandate of Steven Maijooor, President of the European Securities and Markets Authority (ESMA), proposed by the Board of Supervisors. As the European Union securities market regulator, ESMA has made numerous progress and significant achievements.  In my view, on the basis of these results, the Board of Supervisors has decided to extend the mandate of the President of ESMA, who has demonstrated his or her ability to run this highly important organisation during the past term, which bases its responsibility on the clear objective of protecting investors and ensuring the stability of financial markets.  I supported the new five-year term of ESMA President with confidence in the decision of the Board of Supervisors, which, during the 9 months before the end of his previous term, positively assessed the results achieved in the first term and how these duties and requirements were achieved in the coming years, and I believe that he will continue to perform his function effectively.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. I supported the report on the extension of the mandate of the President of the European Securities and Markets Authority (ESMA) because Article 48(4) of Regulation (EU) No 1095/2010 provides that, taking into account the assessment provided for in the provision, ESMA's Board of Supervisors may, subject to the assessment provided for in the provision, extend the term of office of the President of ESMA once, subject to prior approval by the European Parliament.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. – Since we oppose the mandate and activity of these three supervisory agencies, we have also opposed the extension of the mandate of their respective presidents.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. \u2012 Under Regulation (EU) No 1095/2010, the Board of Supervisors may, taking into account the assessment referred to in this provision, extend the term of office of the President once, subject to the strengthening of the European Parliament. The reporter, Esma President Steven Maijoor, proposed extending his term of office for a further five-year period. I voted in favour.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. – Since we oppose the mandate and activity of these three supervisory agencies, we have also opposed the extension of the mandate of their respective presidents.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour because I approve the proposal for the extension of the term of office of Steven Maijoor as Chairperson of the ESMA by another five-year term. ESMA is an independent EU Authority that contributes to safeguarding the stability of the European Union’s financial system by enhancing the protection of investors and promoting stable and orderly financial markets. It achieves this by: assessing risks to investors, markets and financial stability, completing a single rulebook for EU financial markets, promoting supervisory convergence and directly supervising credit rating agencies and trade repositories. This authority plays an important and responsible role and after the hearing with Steven Maijoor, at which he made an opening statement and then responded to questions from the members of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs and after a careful evaluation, I believe the approval was justified.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. Taking into account that the European Securities and Markets Authority has proposed extending Mr Maijoor's mandate and that the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs has approved this proposal, I consider it necessary to vote in favour of that decision.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. 'I voted in favour of the five-year extension of the mandate of the President of the European Securities and Markets Authority, as this seemed to me to be the most appropriate choice.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. \u2012 This is an extension of the mandate for the position of president of an institution that was created as part of an economic integration process with which we do not agree. We have nothing against the person itself, nor is it relevant for us to give an opinion on their personal and professional qualities. We are sure that it will faithfully carry out the functions for which it will be commanded, i.e. to contribute to consolidating the class dominance of the financial sector and the large economic groups that effectively rule this EU.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. There are no objections to the previous Presidency. I agree with this report.

name: Marco ZANNI
text: in writing. \u2012 A Microprudential Supervision System at European level was created at the end of 2010, consisting of the European Banking Authority (EBA, based in London), the European Financial instruments and markets Authority (ESMA, based in Paris) and the European Insurance and Occupational Pensions Authority (EIOPA, based in Frankfurt).  In 2011, the presidents of the three Authorities were appointed, for a five-year term renewable only once. The Board of the European Financial Instruments and Markets Authority has proposed renewing the mandate to Steven Maijoor. The European Parliament's ECON Committee only held a hearing of the candidate, and then voted last week to renew the mandate by a very large majority.  I voted against, firstly because of an almost automatic method of renewal with no real motivation; Moreover, the role and value of these authorities has so far proved to be rather marginal, and therefore to continue in the path of five unsatisfactory years certainly does not seem the best decision that could be taken.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. The first president of ESMA was appointed in 2011 for a five-year term. ESMA is one of three authorities that are part of the European System of Financial Supervision (ESFS). ESMA aims to safeguard the stability of the EU financial system by ensuring the integrity, transparency, efficiency and smooth functioning of securities markets, as well as enhancing investor protection. Creating the illusion that the problems that led to the 2007/2008 financial crisis are resolved, the ESFS has not changed the fundamental issue of financial speculation as it has not put an end to derivatives markets and tax havens and has not instituted the separation of commercial banking from investment. History will show that the creation of these European authorities was of little value.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. \u2012 On the basis of Article 23 of the Europol Decision, it is considered to be the Council's responsibility to conclude international agreements with third countries or international organisations. Agreements are generally based on a mutual commitment to the exchange of operational, strategic or classified information. The proposal presented by the rapporteur, Mr Fontana, calls for the establishment of a new form of cooperation with the State of Bosnia-Herzegovina. I have chosen to abstain, in view of the fact that negotiations on a reform of the JHA decision establishing Europol were completed on 29 November. As a result of these changes, new and stricter rules will soon be applied. I therefore felt it appropriate to postpone the creation of new cooperation until a later date, so that the new rules could also be applied to the new agreements.

name: Tim AKER
text: in writing. – UKIP does not oppose the concept of sharing intelligence with neighbouring countries. However we have concerns that Europol is an organisation that should not be the agency in charge. Only bilateral deals with sovereign states should govern these arrangements.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. We voted against the ratification of this Agreement on Operational and Strategic Cooperation between the European agency Europol and Bosnia Herzegovina. We oppose it because of our position contrary to the existence of that agency and because of the limited democratic guarantees presented by the Agreement, which has no mechanism for monitoring the activities of the agency or Bosnian forces in the context of joint actions.

name: Louis ALIOT
text: In writing. I abstained on the report on operational and strategic cooperation between Bosnia and Herzegovina and Europol. While this report aims to improve efficiency in preventing and combating serious forms of crime, it also provides for information exchange and provisions for the exchange of personal data, which is unacceptable to me.  Moreover, these agreements seem to be in the run-up to the potential accession of Bosnia and Herzegovina, but I am totally opposed to this enlargement.

name: Lynn BOYLAN
text: in writing. – I voted against proposed cooperation between Europol and Bosnia and Herzegovina on the basis that it advocated the expansion of the operational field of Europol. Serious concerns have been expressed about the lack of political or judicial accountability Europol is subjected to. Furthermore, the sharing of sensitive, at times, personal, data of European citizens with third countries is something I found impossible to endorse.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. This report concerns the procedure for concluding an agreement on operational and strategic cooperation between Europol and Bosnia and Herzegovina. This agreement is intended to improve the effectiveness of prevention and the fight against serious forms of crime.  This cooperation includes exchanges of information on expertise, general reports, results of strategic analyses, criminal investigation procedures, methods of crime prevention, etc. The agreement also proposes participation in training activities, the provision of advice and support from Europol in certain criminal investigations.  Unfortunately, the text of the agreement contains provisions for the exchange of personal data. This is not acceptable, as is the idea underpinned by the report, namely the accession of Bosnia and Herzegovina to the European Union. I have therefore chosen to abstain on this text, which has some interesting proposals but unfortunately has two aspects which we cannot support.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ Whilst I support strategic co-operation, I do not support Europol.  I therefore abstained on this vote.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal for operational and strategic cooperation between Bosnia and Herzegovina and Europol. I support the calls on the Commission to assess the provisions of the Cooperation Agreement, in particular those relating to data protection, after the entry into force of the new Europol Regulation.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. On the grounds that Bosnia and Herzegovina is a potential candidate state and a close neighbour of the European Union, Europol has initiated the process of concluding an agreement on operational and strategic cooperation with Bosnia and Herzegovina, in order to improve efficiency in preventing and combating serious forms of crime. Unlike the agreement with the United Arab Emirates, this draft includes provisions for the exchange of personal data.  The rapporteur, my colleague from the Northern League Lorenzo Fontana, has been forced into this report, which is unacceptable, because the conclusion of this agreement is in line with Bosnia and Herzegovina's accession to the European Union.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. – We voted against this report since the European Parliament and the Council have entered into informal negotiations on a new Europol Regulation (2013/0091 (COD)), in which the procedure for concluded international agreements, as well as the relevant provisions and guarantees for the protection of the personal data of European citizens, are significantly amended. This report concerns the adoption of an Agreement on Operational and Strategic Cooperation between Europol and Bosnia and Herzegovina, which aims at the exchange of information, including expertise, general status reports, strategic analysis results, information on criminal investigation procedures, information on crime prevention methods, training and the provision of advice and support in individual criminal investigations. However, such agreements may relate to the exchange of operational, strategic, technical or classified information. The Agreement on Operational and Strategic Cooperation also includes the exchange of personal data. As there are no guarantees regarding the freedom and protection of personal data among others, we voted against it.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: in writing. U2012 National security is a concept surpassed by the threat of international terrorism. The creation of a European intelligence system requires widespread connections between all police officers operating on the European continent. This agreement with Bosnia and Herzegovina is therefore a step in the right direction.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. I abstain on this report on operational and strategic cooperation between Bosnia and Herzegovina and Europol.  Indeed, while this text starts from a good intention - namely, to improve efficiency in preventing and combating serious forms of crime - the proposed measures do not seem relevant to me. The agreement contains provisions relating to the exchange of personal data which are unacceptable. Indeed, the fight against crime does not justify this truly liberticidal measure for our fellow citizens; let us start by applying the laws in force, zero tolerance in criminal matters and, above all, contrary to the objective of this report, let us stop this forced enlargement which only increases the risks associated with this europe. Finally, it should be remembered that Bosnia and Herzegovina unfortunately remains today a narco-state and that its structural instability does not allow for future accession to the European Union.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 Given Bosnia and Herzegovina's geographical position and strategic role in the Balkans, I believe that greater cooperation between bosnia and herzegovina and Europol will ensure more effective policies and actions to combat organised crime. For all these reasons, I voted in favour of this text.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. By this Resolution, Parliament transfers to the Council its position on the Council's decision approving the conclusion by the European Police Office (Europol) of the Agreement between Bosnia and Herzegovina and Europol on Operational and Strategic Cooperation. Bosnia and Herzegovina suffers from significant problems of organised crime, which is why the Council considered it appropriate to authorise the cooperation agreement with Europol, with a view to pursuing VAT fraud and money laundering more effectively, among others. However, the possibility of personal data being transferred to Bosnia Herzegovina by the EU is disturbing. Therefore, and although Parliament intends to request the Commission, if adopted, to assess the provisions contained in the cooperation agreement, in particular those relating to data protection, and, if appropriate, to make a recommendation that the opening of an international renegotiation of the agreement be authorised, the Socialist Group has not considered these safeguards sufficient , so he has decided to vote against it.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because it has supported the european police office (Europol) to conclude an agreement on operational and strategic cooperation between Bosnia and Herzegovina and Europol. Under EU law, Europol must conclude agreements with third countries included in the list established by Decision 2009/935/JHA. The purpose of such agreements shall be to support and strengthen the actions of the competent authorities of the Member States and cooperation between them in the field of preventing and combating organised crime, terrorism and other serious crimes affecting two or more Member States and may relate to the exchange of operational, strategic or technical information, including personal data and classified information. Bosnia and Herzegovina is included in the list established by Decision 2009/935/JHA and, therefore, in order to increase the effectiveness of the prevention and combating of serious forms of crime, in particular given that Bosnia and Herzegovina is a potential candidate country and a close neighbour of the Union with a high level of communication and numerous exchanges, Europol has initiated a procedure for the conclusion of the Operational and Strategic Cooperation Agreement between Bosnia and Herzegovina and Europol. Parliament agrees with it.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. \u2012 The cooperation agreement between Bosnia and Herzegovina and Europol is an act to be welcomed, useful in the context of better strategic and operational cooperation between the Member States of the European Union and allied countries with a view to greater efficiency in the fight against terrorism, mafias, smuggling and international crime.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. With Bosnia and Herzegovina's accession to the European Union as its focus, Europol has initiated the process of concluding an agreement on operational and strategic cooperation with the European Union, which aims to increase efficiency in the fight against crime and prevention in a country that is particularly affected by this scourge.  This cooperation includes exchanges of information on criminal investigation procedures as well as methods of crime prevention. The agreement also includes exchanges of personal data.  We are opposed to any enlargement of the European Union and therefore to the accession of Bosnia and Herzegovina. Nevertheless, I believe it is important in the current context to strengthen our cooperation in the fight against crime. I therefore abstained on this text.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 The Agreement on Operational and Strategic Cooperation aims to support and strengthen the work of the competent authorities of the Member States and their mutual cooperation in preventing and combating organised crime, terrorism and other serious forms of crime affecting two or more Member States. It also involves the exchange of operational, strategic information, including personal data and classified information. According to Decision 2009/935/JHA, Bosnia and Herzegovina is among the countries with which Europol will conclude such operational and strategic cooperation agreements. I was in favour of the Report on Operational and Strategic Cooperation between Bosnia and Herzegovina and Europol in order to increase effectiveness in preventing and combating serious forms of crime, in particular given that Bosnia and Herzegovina is a potential candidate state and a close neighbour of the Union, with which it has many links and exchanges.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. – UKIP does not oppose the concept of sharing intelligence with neighbouring countries. However we have concerns that Europol is an organisation that should not be the agency in charge. Only bilateral deals with sovereign states should govern these arrangements.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Report on the draft Council implementing decision approving the conclusion by the European Police Office (Europol) of the Agreement on Operational and Strategic Cooperation between Bosnia and Herzegovina and Europol, as it will help in providing a closer police cooperation between the two sides and improve security in the region.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 The report concerns the proposal for a strategic cooperation agreement between Europol and Bosnia and Herzegovina which also provides for the exchange of sensitive personal data. It is therefore very important to ensure that the agreement is concluded within the framework of the new Europol regulation, which recalls the new European data protection legislation, which will be approved shortly. We therefore felt that it was appropriate to wait before approving the cooperation agreement, which is also absolutely important. I therefore abstained.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 We support the report on the draft Council Implementing Decision approving the conclusion by the European Police Office (Europol) of the Operational and Strategic Cooperation Agreement between Bosnia and Herzegovina and Europol; Having regard to the Council's draft (10509/2015), having regard to Article 39(1) of the Treaty on European Union, as amended by the Treaty of Amsterdam, having regard to Article 9 of Protocol No 1 to the Treaty on European Union, 36 on the transitional provisions, pursuing which it was consulted by the Council (C8-0276/2015), and finally having regard to Decision No 136/2004/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council of 22 December 2002 on the implementation of the common agricultural legislation (C8-0276/2015). Council Regulation (EC) No 2009/371/JHA of 6 April 2009 establishing a European Police Office (Europol) and in particular Article 23(2) the same way. We are therefore in favour of supporting the resolution.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The conclusion of operational and strategic cooperation between Bosnia and Herzegovina and Europol is proposed on the basis of the Europol Regulation, as it is currently in force. However, the European Parliament and the Council have entered into informal negotiations on a new Europol regulation, in which the conclusion of international agreements and the relevant provisions and guarantees for the protection of the personal data of European citizens are increased compared to what is currently in force. Informal negotiations are close to completion and it would therefore be much preferable for the proposed international agreement to be concluded after the new regulation comes into force, in order to ensure fundamental rights more effectively. That is why I voted against this proposal.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal concerning the approval of the conclusion of the agreement on operational and strategic cooperation between Bosnia and Herzegovina and Europol, which includes personal data. The information in question could be related to specialist knowledge, general situation reports, strategic analysis results, information on criminal investigation procedures and crime prevention methods, as well as supporting information in individual criminal investigations. Parliament also considered it appropriate for the Council to avoid approving the draft decision until the entry into force of the new Europol regulation.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. \u2012 Europol, as an information analysis centre that seeks to provide support to Member States, has at its disposal a number of instruments, including cooperation with third countries through cooperation agreements. It is up to Parliament, for the time being, to give an opinion only.  The agreement with Bosnia, the neighbouring country located between Member States, is therefore of particular importance. Without prejudice to its usefulness, the rapporteur correctly suggests that the Commission review it in the light of Europol's future legal basis. I therefore support the conclusion of the agreement in the proposed terms.

name: Birgit COLLIN-LANGEN
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report because we should step up exchanges between Bosnia and Herzegovina as a direct neighbouring state and Europol. This cooperation will facilitate the exchange of specialist knowledge, the results of strategic analyses, information on criminal investigation procedures and information on prevention methods. This can help effectively combat serious crime.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 I agree with mr Fontana's report on the draft agreement on operational and strategic cooperation between Bosnia and Herzegovina and Europol, as also agreed with the Council.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. We voted against the ratification of this Agreement on Operational and Strategic Cooperation between the European agency Europol and Bosnia Herzegovina. We oppose it because of our position contrary to the existence of that agency and because of the limited democratic guarantees presented by the Agreement, which has no mechanism for monitoring the activities of the agency or Bosnian forces in the context of joint actions.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: Writing. \u2012 Under the current Council Decision on Europol, the Council, after consulting the European Parliament, must approve the conclusion of international cooperation agreements with third countries or international organisations. With a view to effective action and prevention against organised crime, based on the importance of concluding an agreement on operational and strategic cooperation, according to Europol, a potential future EU Member State of Bosnia and Herzegovina and currently a neighbouring State of the Union. The European Parliament has today given its consent to the conclusion of the agreement.

name: Daniel DALTON
text: in writing. ‒ I very much welcome this cooperation agreement between Europol and Bosnia-Herzegovina. The need for more international cooperation in the fight against serious crime and terrorism has been highlighted by recent tragic events in Europe. This is especially the case within Europe, where the current migration crisis has demonstrated the difficulty national border authorities have in monitoring and preventing the movement of unauthorised individuals. This agreement allows for the exchange of specialist knowledge, strategic analysis, information on crime prevention methods and support in individual criminal investigations, a useful tool for both Bosnia-Herzegovina and Europol. The benefits of this deal to European security are clear, and I am happy to support it in today’s vote.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This report is part of the consultation process and concerns the conclusion by the European Union of a new agreement to strengthen police cooperation between Europol and Bosnia and Herzegovina.  We insisted that in the future the rules should include a revision clause for such agreements and for Parliament to have a say. The aim of MEPs is to ensure that the parties to the agreement fully comply with data protection standards and European police standards.  Considering that this report is balanced, I voted for it.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. I supported this report on the conclusion of an operational and strategic cooperation agreement between Bosnia and Herzegovina and Europol. The aim of this agreement is to improve our exchanges with Bosnia and Herzegovina, the neighbouring country of the European Union, in order to prevent and combat organised crime, terrorism and other forms of crime.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. This report focuses on promoting the prevention and fight against organised crime in Bosnia. Any form of coordination to promote the fight against the development of criminal organizations is of course commendable. A fortiori here, Bosnia being a potential candidate for membership in the European Union. Although we condemn the constant extension of the field of the fight against the European Union, it is already important to combat its consequences. However, the exchange of personal data is an attack on the freedoms that the National Front and I have always fought against. Opposed to the enlargement of the Union and the exchange of personal data, I voted against this report.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported my colleague Fontana's report on the conclusion of a cooperation agreement between Europol and Bosnia and Herzegovina, which I believe will be useful for safeguarding the security of European citizens. The conditions of cooperation include the exchange of strategic information, information on criminal investigations, exchange of personal data, as well as methods for the conversion of criminal offences.  In today's situation where the security and integrity of the EU is threatened, we must use all possible tools to cooperate with neighbouring countries to strengthen the fight against cross-border and organised crime.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. I abstained on this deliberation because I do not want a rapprochement between Bosnia and Herzegovina and the European Union.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. \u2012 This report proposes the establishment of a strategic cooperation agreement between Europol and Bosnia and Herzegovina, which aims at exchanging information, including specific knowledge, general reports on the situation, the results of the strategic review, information on criminal investigation procedures, information on crime prevention methods, training, advice and support in criminal investigations.  Like other EU agencies, Europol is a structure designed to enforce the path of federalisation. Since its creation, it has been given powers that attack the sovereignty of states, developing their activity without any democratic control. We believe that Europol should not overdo it with the national police.  This proposal for a cooperation agreement is another step in the process of integration of Bosnia and Herzegovina, while still being able to set up an act of interference and pressure on bosnia and herzegovina. In the assessment of this report, our principle dwellers are naturally weighing against the federalisation of home affairs and justice and, in particular, our position on Europol. We voted against it.

name: Raffaele FITTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the agreement on operational and strategic cooperation between Bosnia and Herzegovina and Europol, as I believe that there is a need to strengthen cooperation between bosnia and herzegovina and the European Agency in order to achieve more effective results in the field of combating crime.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: in writing. – I voted against the legislative resolution because it is unrealistic.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 The current situation in the European Union as well as in the global global context requires the adoption of decisions involving cooperation with third States or international organisations pursuant to Article 23(2) of the Council Decision. Such cooperation and agreements may concern the exchange of strategic professional or operational information as well as classified information. Such agreements also include the exchange of personal data. From an operational point of view, we consider it necessary for EUROPOL to cooperate strategically with Bosnia and Herzegovina.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 Europol's cooperation with Bosnia and Herzegovina is motivated by clear operational needs. According to Europol, Bosnia and Herzegovina, given its position and strategic role in the Balkans, plays an important role in implementing stronger policies in the fight against organised crime.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Bosnia and Herzegovina is not a state in which fundamental rights, the rule of law, the independence of the press and the media are respected and protected. It is a transit station and training base for jihadists, a man of extreme Islamic elements, a country in which black money is laundered and where human trafficking is ingests, a state in general disintegration due to differences between the federations (Serbs, Croats and Vogomiles). In this light, any strategic cooperation carries risks, especially when we talk about the exchange of classified information and personal data. For the above reasons I am voting against this report.

name: Mariya GABRIEL
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this report because the conclusion of an agreement between BiH and Europol is key to deepening cooperation between the country and the European Union. I believe that the Operational and Strategic Cooperation Agreement has added value as it aims to strengthen cooperation between the EU and third countries to prevent and combat serious crimes of an international nature through the exchange of operational, strategic and technical information, including personal data and classified information. It will allow effective counter-terrorism measures to be taken by regulating the European Police Service's relations with a strategic partner in the Western Balkans such as Bosnia and Herzegovina.  In conclusion, I welcome this agreement because it underlines the progress made by BiH in some areas in terms of the country's inclusion in European values.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: in writing. ‒ With today’s vote we approve the conclusion of the Agreement on Operational and Strategic Cooperation between Europol and Bosnia-Herzegovina. This agreement has the objective of supporting and strengthening action and mutual cooperation in preventing and combating organised crime, terrorism and other forms of serious crime, through the exchange of operational, strategic or technical information, including personal data and classified information. We support today’s resolution, given that Bosnia-Herzegovina is a potential candidate state and a close neighbour of the Union, with which Bosnia-Herzegovina has many links and exchanges.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the opportunity and need for cooperation between Bosnia and Herzegovina and Europol. Today more than ever, there is a need to deepen international cooperation to address the security challenges ahead.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Writing. Bosnia and Herzegovina is becoming increasingly important for the successful fight against organised crime. Closer cooperation is therefore important and forward-looking.

name: Nathan GILL
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP does not oppose the concept of sharing intelligence with neighbouring countries. However we have concerns that Europol is an organisation that should not be the agency in charge. Only bilateral deals with sovereign states should govern these arrangements.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. U2012 We voted against this report since the European Parliament and the Council have entered into informal negotiations on a new Europol Regulation (2013/0091 (COD)), in which the procedure for concluded international agreements, as well as the relevant provisions and guarantees for the protection of the personal data of European citizens, are significantly amended. This report concerns the adoption of an Agreement on Operational and Strategic Cooperation between Europol and Bosnia and Herzegovina, which aims at the exchange of information, including expertise, general status reports, strategic analysis results, information on criminal investigation procedures, information on crime prevention methods, training and the provision of advice and support in individual criminal investigations. However, such agreements may relate to the exchange of operational, strategic, technical or classified information. The Agreement on Operational and Strategic Cooperation also includes the exchange of personal data. As there are no guarantees regarding the freedom and protection of personal data among others, we voted against it.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ My vote was decided by the fact that it would be much preferable for this proposed international cooperation agreement to be adopted after the new Europol Regulation has entered into force, following the new enhanced procedure and abiding by the rigorous new provisions and safeguards.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted to support this report because I approve the Council draft. I also agree that the Commission should assess the situation, after the entry into force of the new Europol Regulation, of the provisions contained in the cooperation agreement, in particular on data protection. Lastly I agree the Commission should inform Parliament and the Council of the outcome of this assessment and, if appropriate, submit a recommendation for an authorisation to open international renegotiation of the agreement.

name: Brice HORTEFEUX
text: In writing. I supported the adoption of MEP Lorenzo FONTANA's report on operational and strategic cooperation between Bosnia and Herzegovina and Europol. The rapporteur had proposed the rejection of the agreement, in line with his party's traditional position that rejects any form of cooperation between security authorities at European level, but was put in the minority during the vote in the Parliamentary Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs (LIBE). Yet the flow of information and the sharing of information are, in my view, essential to identifying and tracking down criminals and terrorists. I am convinced that the potential of the Europol agency to gather and aggregate information from national authorities is under-exploited. That is why, unlike the rapporteur, I supported the agreement to establish operational and strategic cooperation between the Bosnian authorities and Europol, which is essential in the fight against organised crime, terrorism and other equally high-priority areas.

name: Filiz HYUSMENOVA
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the report on the draft Council decision approving the conclusion of the Agreement on Operational and Strategic Cooperation between BiH and Europol, as I believe that the only way to effectively prevent and combat organised crime is by sharing the information available.  The events of recent months have unequivocally shown that cooperation between the services and the exchange of operational and strategic information is crucial for a timely response to transnational criminal networks.  I therefore believe that the sharing of information between Europol and candidate member countries in the EU neighbourhood must be supported for the sake of our common objective – the establishment of an area of justice, freedom and security.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted according to the recommendation of the political group.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted against the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the Council's draft implementing decision authorising the European Police Office (Europol) to conclude an Operational and Strategic Cooperation Agreement between Bosnia and Herzegovina and Europol, while strengthening the European Parliament's role in the process in question and encouraging enhanced security measures and allowing for a thorough analysis of the Agreement, which at the same time represents the position of the ALDE Group.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. –  UKIP does not oppose the concept of sharing intelligence with neighbouring countries. However we have concerns that Europol is an organisation that should not be the agency in charge. Only bilateral deals with sovereign states should govern these arrangements.

name: Petr JEŽEK
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of Parliament's recommendation to conclude a strategic cooperation treaty in the fight against serious crime and terrorism between the United Arab Emirates and the European Police Office (Europol), as I consider strengthening police cooperation with partners in the Middle East to be entirely desirable given the security situation. I understand the argument that an amendment to the EU Regulation (2013/0091(COD)) will soon be approved, which will allow direct control of the European Parliament over the assessment of Europol's cooperation agreements with the authorities of third countries. However, this legislative act will not take effect until 2017. In view of the current situation in Europe, I have therefore decided not to delay the conclusion of this treaty.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the Fontana report on operational and strategic cooperation between Bosnia and Herzegovina and Europol.  Indeed, although the rapporteur had initially proposed to reject the agreement to establish operational and strategic cooperation between the Bosnian authorities and Europol, it was put in a minority, so that the report put to the vote now reflects the position of the EPP Group.  This cooperation agreement should make it possible to better combat transnational crime. To act against this scourge it is necessary to strengthen collaborations between third countries and the European Union, which will be the case with this agreement. That decision was adopted, which I welcome.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which aims to improve efficiency in the prevention and fight against crime between the European Union and Bosnia and Herzegovina by signing cooperation agreements between Europol and Bosnia and Herzegovina.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. The Commission is invited to assess the provisions of the Cooperation Agreement, in particular on data protection, after the entry into force of the new Europol Regulation. A new assessment of the situation should lead to the opening of a renegotiation of the agreement at international level. I am therefore voting in favour of this report.

name: Béla KOVÁCS
text: Writing. – Operational and strategic cooperation between Bosnia and Herzegovina and the European Police Office (Europol) is absolutely justified, since, following the recent war, the authority of the State has not been restored at the previous level, so organised crime is strong. I voted in favour of this report, especially given that these criminal groups have also gained significant positions in the EU, so concerted action against them is very timely.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. This draft concerns the proposal to approve the conclusion of an agreement on operational and strategic cooperation between Bosnia and Herzegovina and Europol on personal data. This precise historical situation requires us to cooperate closely with the countries of the Balkan peninsula, which have become a crossroads of migratory flows towards Europe. From this point of view, I hope that this agreement will be a step towards ever closer cooperation and that it will allow future integration with the whole area.  I have decided to give my positive opinion because I believe that this agreement will allow both parties to conduct more accurate investigations through the exchange of operational, strategic, technical and/or classified information.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. I abstained on the report on operational and strategic cooperation between Bosnia and Herzegovina and Europol.  This agreement includes provisions for the exchange of personal data. This is unacceptable. Moreover, the conclusion of this agreement is in line with the potential accession of Bosnia and Herzogovine to the European Union. However, the National Front is opposed to this enlargement.  However, I condemn the attitude of the Socialist Group in the vote on this report. The vast majority of Socialist MEPs refused to take part in the vote as the rapporteur is a member of the ENL group. This bigotry is the reason why I abstained instead of voting against the report.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I abstained on this report. Certainly, it claims to fight terrorism. But it allows for the exchange of personal data in an excessively reckless manner.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: in writing. This Resolution approves the draft Council for the conclusion by the European Police Office (Europol) of the Agreement between Bosnia and Herzegovina and Europol on Operational and Strategic Cooperation after analysing the various Council decisions, the relevant article of the EU Treaty and the report of the LIBE Commission.   The Resolution also calls on the Council to keep Parliament informed of future changes and to assess the provisions contained in the cooperation agreement and to report them to Parliament and the Council.  I believe that this is a positive resolution and I voted accordingly.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. The Agreement on Operational and Strategic Cooperation between Bosnia and Herzegovina and Europol defines the rules for the exchange of data and confidential information, the provision of knowledge and training and support in certain criminal investigations.  The purpose of signing the agreement is to co-operation with each other in preventing and combating all forms of crime and terrorism and to strengthen the activities of the BiH authorities.  I supported representative Lorenzo Fontana's report because I think this is important co-operation given the current security situation in Europe and the fact that BiH borders Croatia, which is a member state, but also since BiH is a potential member state.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: Writing. \u2012 The signing of the Agreement on operational and strategic cooperation between Bosnia and Herzegovina and Europol is an important step not only in promoting the integration of this Western Balkan country with our community, but, in principle, a perfectly logical action that will promote closer cooperation in the prevention and fight against organised crime, in the fight against terrorism, etc. That is why it was so important to vote in favour of this draft Council implementing decision, which will allow Europol to sign the agreement. Which, by the way, will also include the possibility of exchanging personal data and classified information – is certainly a necessary step today, when organised crime and, in particular, the threat of terrorism have been greatly intensified. It should be added, in the context of combating the terrorist threat, that some of the weapons and other resources used in the Member States of the European Union came directly from bosnia and herzegovina' territory. To a large extent, this is also why the signing of this cooperation agreement is so important and necessary.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: Writing. \u2012 The conclusion of this agreement opens up law enforcement opportunities in the fight against serious international crime and terrorism, both in creating a secure Europe and in cooperation with this potential candidate country. At the same time, Europol will receive expert assistance and support to the Authorities of Bosnia and Herzegovina.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report on the draft implementation of a Council decision approving the conclusion by the European Police Office (Europol) of the operational and strategic cooperation agreement between Bosnia and Herzegovina and Europol, because it is neither complete nor documented.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome this new agreement establishing police cooperation between Europol and Bosnia Herzegovina to step up the joint fight against organised crime, terrorism and other forms of serious international crime.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I abstained on this report by a Member of our ENF group on operational and strategic cooperation between Bosnia and Herzegovina and Europol.  Although this text is well-intentioned, namely to improve efficiency in preventing and combating serious forms of crime, the proposed measures do not appear to be relevant. One of the reasons for my opposition is that this agreement contains provisions relating to the exchange of personal data, which cannot be accepted. This exchange represents an attack on the freedom of our citizens, which we cannot tolerate, even to fight crime. Rather than threatening the freedom of our citizens, we should start by enforcing existing laws, zero tolerance in criminal matters and, above all, by stopping this forced enlargement which only increases the risks.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on operational and strategic cooperation between Bosnia and Herzegovina and Europol.  On the basis of Decisions 2009/371/JHA and 2009/934/JHA, Europol is required to conclude agreements with third states which are included in a list established precisely by Decision 2009/934/JHA, including Bosnia and Herzegovina. The aim of these agreements is to prevent and combat organised crime, terrorism and other serious crime affecting two or more States and which may concern the exchange of operational, strategic and technical information.  Precisely in order to ensure effectiveness in preventing and combating serious crime, Europol has undertaken the procedure for concluding an agreement on operational and strategic cooperation between Bosnia and Herzegovina and Europol (the so-called operational and strategic agreement), which provides for exchanges of information, including strategic analysis results, information on criminal investigation procedures, crime prevention methods and the provision of advice in support of individual criminal investigations.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing. \u2012 The draft to which Mr Fontana's report refers, which I support by voting in favour, concerns the proposal to approve the conclusion of an agreement on cooperation between Bosnia and Herzegovina and Europol. This would be strategic cooperation based on the exchange of useful information and results of strategic analyses, information on criminal investigation procedures and crime prevention methods. The report is particularly accurate in that it further underlines the desirability of approving the draft only after the entry into force of the Europol Regulation.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: in writing. My support for the European Parliament's Resolution on the conclusion by the European Police Office (Europol) of the Agreement with Bosnia and Herzegovina on Operational and Strategic Cooperation.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. The Commission is invited, inter alia, to assess the provisions of the Cooperation Agreement, in particular on data protection, after the entry into force of the new Europol Regulation. A new assessment of the situation should lead to the opening of a renegotiation of the agreement at international level. I am in favour of this and I therefore agree with the report.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. The European Police Office Europol enters into agreements with certain third countries for mutual cooperation in the prevention of organised crime, terrorism and the exchange of personal data.  This is an agreement with Bosnia and Herzegovina. It comes at a time when a review of Europol is under way, including on the procedures for concluding such international agreements and to ensure better guarantees on the use of personal data.  I have no hope for this new legislation amended by the right. I vote against it mainly because the exchange of data across the board between agencies and systems with different mandates (Europol, Frontex, VIS, Eurodac) is against fundamental rights. I am doing so because no real justification has been given for this agreement with Bosnia and Herzegovina. Let us first allow this country to establish a functioning state.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I chose to support this resolution as it aims to ensure that the competent and relevant authorities designated by Bosnia and Herzegovina and Europol share information. This interconnectivity enables border guards to identify people with either fraudulent or no documents.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. Parliament was consulted on the future international agreement establishing operational and strategic cooperation between Europol and Bosnia and Herzegovina.  However, this agreement should be based on the future Europol regulation, which will give the European Parliament more powers and ensure better safeguards, particularly in the area of personal data protection.  I am against the conclusion of such an agreement until the new Europol regulation is in force. Although totally in favour of cooperation between Europol and Bosnia and Herzegovina, we wanted to send a clear signal and defend Parliament's role on such essential issues as cooperation in the fight against crime and trafficking.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 The Council submitted a draft decision approving the agreement concluded by Europol on operational and strategic cooperation between Bosnia and Herzegovina and the European Police Office (Europol). Under the current rules, approval is the authority of the Council, but it must consult Parliament on this. In its report, the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs recommends that Parliament approve the Council's draft decision. I voted in favour of the proposal accordingly.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: In writing. In order to improve efficiency in preventing and combating serious forms of crime, and in particular in view of the fact that Bosnia and Herzegovina is a potential candidate state and a close neighbour of the European Union, Europol has initiated the process of concluding an agreement on operational and strategic cooperation with Bosnia and Herzegovina. The terms of cooperation governed by the operational and strategic agreement provide for exchanges of information that may include expertise, general reports, results of strategic analyses, information on criminal investigation procedures and information on crime prevention methods, participation in training activities, and the provision of advice and support in specific criminal investigations. In addition, the agreement includes provisions for the exchange of personal data. This is unacceptable. Moreover, the conclusion of this agreement is in line with the potential accession of Bosnia and Herzegovina to the European Union. However, we are opposed to this enlargement.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. \u2012 The Agreement on Operational and Strategic Cooperation aims to support and strengthen the action of the competent authorities of the Member States and their mutual cooperation on the prevention and combating of organised crime, terrorism and other serious forms of crime affecting two or more Member States and may focus on the exchange of operational, strategic or technical information, including personal data and classified information.  Europol shall conclude agreements with third states which have been included in the list set out in Decision 2009/935/JAI. Bosnia and Herzegovina is included in this list. I support the conclusion of the Agreement with the purpose of increasing the effectiveness in preventing and combating crime, and in particular given that Bosnia and Herzegovina is a potential candidate state and a close neighbour of the Union.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. Europol has initiated the process of concluding an agreement on operational and strategic cooperation with Bosnia and Herzegovina. The terms of cooperation governed by the operational and strategic agreement provide for information exchange and provisions relating to the exchange of personal data. This is unacceptable. Moreover, the conclusion of this agreement is in line with the potential accession of Bosnia and Herzegovina to the European Union. I am opposed to this enlargement. That is why I am abstaining on this report.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which deals with operational and strategic cooperation between Bosnia and Herzegovina and Europol. The aim is to improve the fight against transnational crime by improving cooperation between the Bosnian authorities and the European Police Office.

name: Alessandra MUSSOLINI
text: in writing. \u2012 Current contingencies dictate the need to ensure full intra- and non-European sharing and adequate exchange of information in order to effectively combat cross-border criminal networks.  That is why I have decided to support the report signed by Mr Fontana, who supports the Council's decision to authorise an agreement negotiated by Europol, the European Police Office, and Bosnia and Herzegovina, a candidate country to join the Community family.

name: József NAGY
text: Writing. \u2012 If Europol is to continue to perform its main task, i.e. to effectively combat serious forms of international crime and to prevent organised crime, then we must support any cooperation that allows it to do so. I voted in favour of the adoption of this report so that, in future, Europol can take more effective action on cross-border crime, which also affects Bosnia and Herzegovina.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this report that will strengthen the means of exchanging personal data and classified information, and that will ultimately increase data protection in Member States.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. I would have agreed to cooperation between Europol and Bosnia and Herzegovina, as the current fight against Islamist terrorism urgently needs to focus on the Balkans as a transfer route and place of origin for illegal weapons. This can only be achieved through cooperation with regional partners.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 Not supported. The European Parliament and the Council have concluded new regulation for Europol. An agreement on operational and strategic cooperation between Bosnia and Herzegovina and Europol should be concluded once the new Europol regulation on the process of concluding international agreements has entered into force. Then the personal data of European citizens would be more protected and a two-party cooperation agreement within a more secure framework.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: Writing. – I voted in favour of this report. I support the conclusion of an agreement on operational and strategic cooperation between Bosnia and Herzegovina and Europol.  In particular, this Agreement will strengthen the actions of the competent authorities of the Member States and cooperation between them in the fields of preventing, preventing and combating organised crime, terrorism and other serious crime. It should be noted that Bosnia and Herzegovina is a potential candidate country and a neighbour of the EU. It is therefore important to continuously expand cooperation, in particular to ensure effective prevention and combating of serious crime.  The Operational and Strategic Cooperation Agreement will ensure the efficient and secure exchange of operational, strategic or technical information, including personal data and classified information.

name: Margot PARKER
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP does not oppose the concept of sharing intelligence with neighbouring countries. However we have concerns that Europol is an organisation that should not be the agency in charge. Only bilateral deals with sovereign states should govern these arrangements.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 We all agree on the importance and quality of the work done by Europol. The extension of its cooperation network to Bosnia and Herzegovina is undoubtedly an added value not only for the European Police Office, but for Europe as a whole, especially with regard to the sensitivity of the development of relations with the Balkans. I am voting in favour.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. I support the report on the Council's draft implementing decision authorising Europol to conclude an agreement on operational and strategic cooperation between Bosnia and Herzegovina and Europol. I believe that this is a positive step due to the fact that after Croatia joined the European Union in 2013, Bosnia and Herzegovina became the first neighbour of the European Union.  Europol's objectives are complementary to the broader objectives both sides want to achieve, namely the fight against organised crime, corruption, terrorism, human trafficking or financial malfeasance. This agreement will encourage much-needed exchange of information, knowledge, status reports, results of strategic analyses, information and criminal investigation procedures and the involvement of participants in the training and consultation system.  In addition, existing regional threats (terrorism, illegal oil trade, human trafficking, destabilisation of political systems and migration) require significant engagement by the European Union institutions with a view to stabilising the area and reducing the pressure of challenges towards the European continent. In Bosnia and Herzegovina, there is a threat of radicalisation by terrorist groups linked to regional conflicts in the Middle East, and this procedure enables preventive action towards them.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. Europol has initiated the process of concluding an agreement on operational and strategic cooperation with Bosnia and Herzegovina.  The terms of cooperation governed by the operational and strategic agreement provide for information exchange and provisions relating to the exchange of personal data. This is unacceptable. Moreover, the conclusion of this agreement is in line with the potential accession of Bosnia and Herzegovina to the European Union. I am opposed to this enlargement.  That is why I am abstaining on this report.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. – I support the report of my colleague Lorenzo Fontana. Professional, effective and efficient work of police and judicial bodies for the purpose of establishing the rule of law in the entire territory of BiH is one of the key determinants of the reform agenda agreed among all actors and institutions of BiH. In this regard, the entry into force of the operational agreement with Europol will be a major step towards meeting the key reform objectives that are a priority for bosnia and herzegovina's application for MEMBERSHIP in the European Union as soon as possible.  It is therefore necessary for Parliament to show support for BiH's European future when agreeing on this agreement, taking into account that the Strategic Agreement with Europol was concluded back in 2007, and only after the agreement of the two entities is approached to conclude the operational programme. An agreement defining stronger international co-operation between Europol and BiH authorities in preventing organised crime, terrorism and other serious crimes will allow BiH to strengthen its institutions in the fight against corruption and the construction of a legal state.  In the context of several terrorist attacks that have befallen BiH in the past year, and the growing threat of terrorism inside and outside the EU's borders, I would address the importance of focusing the work of the competent authorities on better sharing operational, strategic and technical information, including personal data and classified information, to combat radicalism and terrorist operations.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 This draft concerns the proposal to approve the conclusion of an agreement on operational and strategic cooperation between Bosnia and Herzegovina and Europol, which includes personal data.  The European Parliament and the Council have opened informal negotiations on a new Europol regulation (2013/0091(COD)), which provides for significant changes to the procedure for concluding international agreements. Once the new Europol regulation enters into force, Parliament's favourable opinion will be necessary for any EU police cooperation agreement with third countries.  This report considers it appropriate for the Council to avoid approving the draft decision on operational cooperation with Bosnia and Herzegovina until the entry into force of the new Europol Regulation. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: Writing. \u2012 I support cooperation between Europol and Bosnia and Herzegovina. This country in the Western Balkans is one of the countries threatened by radical Islam, which is why I consider coordination between the EU and Bosnia and Herzegovina in the security area to be much needed and suitable for further deepening.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. This strategic agreement is a necessary instrument to strengthen our cooperation with Bosnia and Herzegovina in the prevention and fight against terrorism and crime. I do not understand why we would reject it, as the rapporteur originally proposed. It's an irresponsible attitude. Our countries have a great interest in developing their relations in this area, because unfortunately terrorism and crime know no borders.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒  UKIP does not oppose the concept of sharing intelligence with neighbouring countries. However we have concerns that Europol is an organisation that should not be the agency in charge. Only bilateral deals with sovereign states should govern these arrangements.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this draft decision adopting the rules of application governing Europol's relations with its partners, including the exchange of personal data and classified information, including Articles 5 and 6. The European Commission will assess, after the new Europol regulation comes into force, the provisions contained in the cooperation agreement, in particular those relating to data protection.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. \u2012 The EU has established a number of agreements to strengthen and support the action of the competent authorities of the Member States, as well as their mutual cooperation in preventing and combating organised crime, terrorism or other forms of serious crime affecting their Member States. With Bosnia and Herzegovina in a special position as a neighbouring country of the Union and a potential candidate for accession, it has been placed on the list of countries with which the EU had intentions of concluding agreements to combat organised crime.  I therefore believe that the conclusion of this agreement on operational and strategic cooperation between Bosnia and Herzegovina and Europol is beneficial in increasing the effectiveness in preventing and combating crime, and the 'Operational and Strategic Agreement' is also crucial, which is why I voted in favour.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the draft Council implementation decision, which approved the conclusion by the European Police Office (Europol) of the agreement on operational and strategic cooperation between Bosnia and Herzegovina and Europol. The decision asks the Commission to assess, after the new Europol regulation comes into force, the provisions contained in the cooperation agreement, in particular those relating to data protection, as well as to inform Parliament and the Council of the conclusions of this assessment and, if necessary, to make a recommendation to authorise the opening of an international renegotiation of this agreement.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. – We voted against this report since the European Parliament and the Council have entered into informal negotiations on a new Europol Regulation (2013/0091 (COD)), in which the procedure for concluded international agreements, as well as the relevant provisions and guarantees for the protection of the personal data of European citizens, are significantly amended. This report concerns the adoption of an Agreement on Operational and Strategic Cooperation between Europol and Bosnia and Herzegovina, which aims at the exchange of information, including expertise, general status reports, strategic analysis results, information on criminal investigation procedures, information on crime prevention methods, training and the provision of advice and support in individual criminal investigations. However, such agreements may relate to the exchange of operational, strategic, technical or classified information. The Agreement on Operational and Strategic Cooperation also includes the exchange of personal data. As there are no guarantees regarding the freedom and protection of personal data among others, we voted against it.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. We voted against the ratification of this Agreement on Operational and Strategic Cooperation between the European agency Europol and Bosnia Herzegovina. We oppose it because of our position contrary to the existence of that agency and because of the limited democratic guarantees presented by the Agreement, which has no mechanism for monitoring the activities of the agency or Bosnian forces in the context of joint actions.

name: Remo SERNAGIOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 The text voted on today concerns the conclusion of an agreement on operational and strategic cooperation between Europol and Bosnia and Herzegovina in the fight against crime and terrorism. The terms of the agreement provide for the exchange of information on criminal investigation procedures and classified documents, as well as the provision of advice and support. I have chosen to vote in favour of this report in order to increase the effectiveness in preventing and combating the most serious forms of international crime in Europe and Bosnia and Herzegovina.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: in writing. ‒ I wish for Bosnia to work with the nations of Europe on a bilateral basis and not through the mechanisms of the EU so I abstained on this vote.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 The current security situation in Europe not only requires intensive cooperation between Member States, but it is also essential to involve neighbouring or candidate countries. I therefore welcome the cooperation agreement between Bosnia and Herzegovina and Europol, even though, according to the faction's guidance, we did not support the report. Bosnia and Herzegovina will thus join other EU states in preventing and combating organised crime, terrorism and other serious forms of crime. Cooperation will consist in the exchange of information and personal data. The country will exchange professional information, general events reports, the results of strategic analyses, information on criminal investigations and crime prevention methods with Europol. Bosnia and Herzegovina specialists will be able to participate in training and will be entitled to support from European partners regarding individual investigations. In today's interconnected world, cross-border cooperation between the security services is an essential preconditions for preventing attacks by various radical groups. On the basis of this cooperation with Bosnia and Herzegovina, Europol will have more information on the Balkan route, which is also crucial for the protection of the EU's external borders.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. \u2012 On the basis of Council Decision 2009/934/JHA adopting implementing rules governing Europol's relations with partners, Europol may conclude strategic or operational agreements with third countries or international organisations. It may conclude strategic agreements only after approval by the Council, after consulting the Management Board of Europol.  In addition, operational agreements require the Council, through the Europol Management Board, to obtain the opinion of the Joint Supervisory Body of Europol in so far as the agreement concerns the exchange of personal data. These agreements aim to support and strengthen the activities of the competent authorities of the Member States and their mutual cooperation in the prevention and fight against organised crime and other forms of serious crime.  The report concerns the approval of the conclusion of an agreement on operational and strategic cooperation between Bosnia and Herzegovina and Europol, including, inter alia, provisions on the exchange of personal data. The report calls for the approval of the Council's draft and encourages the Commission to assess the provisions of the agreement, in particular the data protection provisions, after the entry into force of the new Europol Regulation (2013/0091 (COD)).  I agree with the latter, but i dispute the Council's draft because of concerns about the use and transfer of personal data. I believe that, by approving this agreement, it would be reasonable to wait for the entry into force of the new General Data Protection Regulation. For the sake of the above, I voted against the report.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: Writing. \u2012 Constructive cooperation that can help Bosnia and Herzegovina in the fight against organised crime and unfair financial practices.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. ‒I support the report on the Council's draft implementing decision authorising the European Police Office (Europol) to conclude an Operational and Strategic Cooperation Agreement between Bosnia and Herzegovina and Europol taking into account Council Decision 2009/371/PUP of 6 April 2009 establishing the European Police Office (Europol), in particular Article 23(2) of the EIA).

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. On 6 April 2009, on the proposal of the Council, the European Union established the European Police Office, and on 30 November of the same year, the Council adopted a Decision on the setting of lists of third states (including Bosnia and Herzegovina) and organisations with which Europol concludes agreements.  The international agreement aims to reduce crime rates and exchange personal data and classified information. Due to the cross-border nature of many criminal activities and organised crime groups, enhanced regional and international cooperation should be established to better respond to Member States' requests for police and judicial cooperation.  I fully support the Council Decision at first reading, which approves the conclusion of the Agreement on Operational and Strategic Cooperation between Bosnia and Herzegovina and Europol, because I believe that establishing enhanced regional and international cooperation can make great progress in combating criminality.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal and welcome the cooperation between Bosnia and Herzegovina and Europol.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the draft Council implementing decision approving the conclusion of an agreement on operational and strategic cooperation between Bosnia and Herzegovina and the European Police Office (Europol) by Europol. The objective of this international agreement is to reduce the crime rate through the exchange of personal data and classified information.
