Due to the cross-border nature of many criminal activities and organised crime groups, we need enhanced regional and international cooperation. This will enable a better and more effective response to member states' requests for police and judicial cooperation.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Bosnia and Herzegovina is not a state in which fundamental rights, the rule of law, the independence of the press and the media are respected and protected. It is a transit and training station for jihadists, a man of extreme Islamic elements, a country in which black money is laundered, human trafficking is ingests and which is generally in the process of disintegration due to differences between the federations (Serbs, Croats and Vogomiles). In this light, any strategic cooperation carries risks, especially when we talk about the exchange of classified information and personal data.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. – The European Union supports cooperation with Bosnia and Herzegovina and the country's efforts to strengthen its internal institutions. One of the problems that the entire Western Balkans region is currently facing is the still high level of organised crime and illicit trafficking networks, as well as a predisposition to the use of their territories by international terrorist networks. The European Union, through its specialised Europol structure, can provide important assistance to the specialised structures of the Bosnian State in combating these negative phenomena. The Bosnian State may also be actively involved in Europol's actions to combat illicit networks operating in the region.  However, in order to achieve and deepen cooperation, it is necessary to conclude an agreement on operational and strategic cooperation between Europol and the Bosnian authorities. This agreement is to incorporate regulations on the exchange of personal data and classified information, with the protection of those personal data. The agreement will be subject to permanent evaluation by the European institutions in order to avoid leaks of personal data. The adoption of this agreement is a win for Europol's work and deserves to be supported.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. With regard to the vote on the draft Council implementation decision, which approved the conclusion by the European Police Office (Europol) of the agreement on operational and strategic cooperation between Bosnia and Herzegovina and Europol, I followed the first vote in the committee responsible for the substance.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Strategic cooperation in the fight against serious crime and terrorism between Bosnia and Herzegovina and Europol and voted in favour of the cooperation. Such agreements between Europol and third countries have the objective of supporting and strengthening action by the competent authorities of the Member States and their mutual cooperation in preventing and combating organised crime, terrorism and other forms of serious crime affecting two or more Member States, and may concern the exchange of operational, strategic or technical information, including personal data and classified information.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒ In light of the latest terrorist threats and three terrorist attacks that have taken place in Bosnia in a short period, and taking into account the fact that Europol was established in 1992 precisely with the aim of preventing and combating organised international crime and terrorism in the European Union, and since Europol's fundamental task is precisely to support national police authorities in individual Member States of the Union through the collection of , analysing and sharing information and coordinating operations, I wholeheartedly support this cooperation agreement between Europol and Bosnia and Herzegovina. The agreement contains provisions concerning the exchange of information, specialist knowledge, reports on the general situation, the results of strategic analyses, information on criminal investigations and methods of crime prevention, participation in training activities and provisions on advice and support in individual criminal investigations. In addition, the agreement also contains a provision on the exchange of personal data, which I also consider extremely positive in the prevention of crime and terrorism.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. The report on the draft Council implementing decision approving the conclusion of an agreement on operational and strategic cooperation between Bosnia and Herzegovina and the European Police Office (Europol) by Europol was supported.  I believe that closer cooperation between Europol and Bosnia and Herzegovina is needed, and this report also calls on the Commission, following the entry into force of the new Europol Regulation (2013/0091(COD)), to assess the data protection provisions and, if necessary, to submit a recommendation to authorising the opening of renegotiation of the agreement.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. – We voted against this report since the European Parliament and the Council have entered into informal negotiations on a new Europol Regulation (2013/0091 (COD)), in which the procedure for concluded international agreements, as well as the relevant provisions and guarantees for the protection of the personal data of European citizens, are significantly amended. This report concerns the adoption of an Agreement on Operational and Strategic Cooperation between Europol and Bosnia and Herzegovina, which aims at the exchange of information, including expertise, general status reports, strategic analysis results, information on criminal investigation procedures, information on crime prevention methods, training and the provision of advice and support in individual criminal investigations. However, such agreements may relate to the exchange of operational, strategic, technical or classified information. The Agreement on Operational and Strategic Cooperation also includes the exchange of personal data. As there are no guarantees regarding the freedom and protection of personal data among others, we voted against it.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. \u2012 I did not take part in the vote on the agreement on operational and strategic cooperation between Bosnia and Herzegovina and the European Police Office (Europol) because of the far-right rallyer.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. – We voted against this report since the European Parliament and the Council have entered into informal negotiations on a new Europol Regulation (2013/0091 (COD)), in which the procedure for concluded international agreements, as well as the relevant provisions and guarantees for the protection of the personal data of European citizens, are significantly amended. This report concerns the adoption of an Agreement on Operational and Strategic Cooperation between Europol and Bosnia and Herzegovina, which aims at the exchange of information, including expertise, general status reports, strategic analysis results, information on criminal investigation procedures, information on crime prevention methods, training and the provision of advice and support in individual criminal investigations. However, such agreements may relate to the exchange of operational, strategic, technical or classified information. The Agreement on Operational and Strategic Cooperation also includes the exchange of personal data. As there are no guarantees regarding the freedom and protection of personal data among others, we voted against it.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour on this matter because I believe that a new agreement establishing police cooperation between Europol and Bosnia Herzegovina to step up the joint fight against organised crime, terrorism and other forms of serious international crime is necessary. This agreement governs operational and strategic cooperation which entails exchanging information such as specialist knowledge, general situation reports and strategic analyses, but could also include the exchange of personal data and classified information and I believe this is needed in order to ensure greater safety and cooperation among countries and Europol.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. \u2012 Our position has always been very critical of europol's establishment since its inception (July 1999). We have always denounced potential access to individual freedoms through the manipulation of personal data. This organisation, formed outside of any parliamentary or judicial control, reflects, in the broadest possible way, the democratic deficit of this European Union. In this sense, this agreement is only aimed at strengthening an institution created on the backs of citizens and enhancing its deeply undemocratic character, representing another step in this escalation against the individual rights and freedoms of European citizens.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. The Commission is invited, inter alia, to assess the provisions of the Cooperation Agreement, in particular on data protection, after the entry into force of the new Europol Regulation. A new assessment of the situation should lead to the opening of a renegotiation of the agreement at international level. I am in favour of this and I therefore agree with the report.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. \u2012 This report proposes the establishment of a strategic cooperation agreement between Europol and Bosnia and Herzegovina, which aims at the exchange of information, including specific knowledge, general reports on the situation, the results of the strategic review, information on criminal investigation procedures, information on crime prevention methods, training, advice and support in criminal investigations.  Like other AGENCIES in the European Union, Europol is a structure designed to impose the implementation of the path of federalisation. Since its inception, the EU has given it powers to attack the sovereignty of states, developing its activity without any democratic control.  We believe that Europol should not overdo it with the police authorities and their activities, and we advocate cooperation between the internal security structures of the various countries. By the foregoing, vote against.

name: Tim AKER
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this legislative vote to approve the use of funds from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. The Irish government have applied for EUR 442,293 from this EU fund to help 108 workers who have lost their job. UKIP oppose the use of this fund as British taxpayers are being made to pay EU dole money for poor economic decisions in other countries.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report as it allows the mobilisation of EUR 442 293 following the dismissal of 108 workers at PWA International Ltd., Ireland. This mobilization of funds aims to mitigate the disastrous social consequences of the economic crisis of the capitalist system. While these funds are unable to solve the problems of these Irish workers in view of the high unemployment rates in that country, they at least give the possibility of alleviating a small part of the human drama. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Louis ALIOT
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund following a request from Ireland. This European Fund was set up to provide assistance to workers suffering the consequences of a crisis in a given sector or changes in the economic structures of Member States linked to international competition.  The aim here is to mobilise the Fund for 108 workers laid off by PAW International, a company in the repair and installation sector of machinery and equipment. Assistance will also be provided to 108 young "NEETs" (young people without a job, without a diploma and without training).  I am therefore in favour of this aid for the reintegration of these workers into the labour market and for financial support for these young people, who are in fact suffering the disastrous consequences of European economic policies.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. In response to the upheavals affecting the organisation of international trade and the increase in global competition, PAW International, which operates in the machinery and equipment repair and installation sector, has laid off 108 employees working south of Dublin. Following this decision, the Irish authorities requested the mobilization of the Globalisation Adjustment Fund to the tune of 442,293 euros.  As a reminder, this Fund, subject to exceptional circumstances justifying it, helps workers who are facing the crisis in a given sector and/or the economic changes linked to international competition.  Workers must not pay the price of an increased globalization that too often takes place in the benefit of a global hyperclass that cares little about the consequences of its actions. That is why I voted in favour of this text.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ The principle of subsidiarity dictates that decisions should be taken at the closest possible level to the citizen – in this case at regional or national level. Therefore, these projects should not be funded by the European Union. It is absurd that the arbiters of whether this funding should, or should not, be given are Members of the European Parliament with no detailed knowledge of the situation. This project may well be of benefit to the people of Ireland, but I am not best placed to judge. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund should be scrapped, which would give money back to the Member States to decide for themselves about the appropriateness of such funding. Consequently, I had no option but to vote against – even though this may be a worthwhile project.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal to mobilise the EGF for Ireland's needs in order to support the integration into the labour market of workers made redundant as a result of the economic crisis. Ireland submitted an application to EGF/2015/006 IE/PWA International for financial support from the EGF following the dismissal of 108 employees from PWA International Ltd in the field of repair of machinery and equipment. The Irish authorities have stated that the redundancies of PWA International are due to the closure of PWAI as the company has decided to consolidate its operations in North America and Asia as a result of a new trend to move the RCR closer to the global aviation development centres and the negative impact of global trade agreements. Personalised services intended to be provided to redundant workers include guidance and career planning, EGF training grants, training and further education programmes, higher education programmes and limited-period benefits.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. Following the dismissal of 108 workers south of Dublin by PAW International, a company operating in the machinery and equipment repair and installation sector, the Irish authorities requested assistance from the Globalisation Adjustment Fund.  This fund allows, "under certain [less and less] exceptional circumstances", to help workers suffering the consequences of a crisis in a given sector, or economic changes linked to international competition.  I voted in favour of providing 442,293 euros in aid to the 108 workers who have been made redundant for their reintegration into the labour market, as well as support for 108 young "NEETs" (young people without jobs, without a diploma and without training). I therefore voted in favour of this report, knowing that this 'adjustment fund' is only a bad thing: if it really wants to combat the deleterious effects of globalisation, the European Union must renounce the dogma of the free movement of goods and people and no longer stand in the way of the implementation of protectionist measures. Yes, it is the causes of these mass layoffs that should be tackled by protecting European employees from savage globalisation.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. I approved this intervention of 442,293 euros from the EGF to help the socio-professional reintegration of 108 workers who lost their jobs in the Irish company PWAI active in the aircraft maintenance and repair sector. This intervention will also enable the employment support of 108 young people under the age of 25 who have no job, no diploma or training.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. – This dossier will also be supported favorably. In this case, the Irish companies concerned do not reach the threshold of more than 500 dismissed and it has resorted to seeing these as a new episode that accumulates to previous processes. Conservative groups have complained about this point. Undoubtedly, it is better to have these funds to alleviate consequences, in this case in the sector of mechanical repair and maintenance, than not. We consider that globalisation adaptation funds involve mitigation mechanisms but not a solution, but we consider that, in the absence of alternatives posed by the European model, this is better than nothing.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: in writing. We agree with the mobilization of the resources of this fund in this case, and with the application to it of exceptions on the number of IE/PWA dismisses. I also welcome the rapid assessment of the problem and equally rapid implementation of the mobilization, because the specialization in the area of aeronautical maintenance activities, which are very prone to relocation, has had a huge impact on the area.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. I have obviously supported this report on the granting of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to the 108 employees of PWA International Ltd, a maintenance, repair and overhaul company. Victims of a redundancy plan, these Irish employees are suffering the full brunt of the massive shift of this sector to Asia, where production and labour costs are lower. However, despite obstacles related to trade agreements, on October 10, 2013, when PWAI's Board of Directors announced a phased closure plan over an 18-month period, with the final closure scheduled for June 2015, it also confirmed that the decision to close the PWAI site was not due to employees at all. , as productivity and efficiency had increased and all important targets had been met or exceeded, such as annual revenues, benefits, environmental health and safety and quality.  New proof, if it were still needed, that it is not an inability of European companies and workers to adapt to globalisation that leads to deindustrialization, but rather this savage globalisation which, without considering even the good economic and social results, destroys everything in its path.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 PWA International is yet another case where single market malfunctions have led to a business crisis and the loss of 108 jobs. With my vote, I support the mobilisation of the EGF to the amount of EUR 442 293 in favour of the 108 redundancies in this company. The Globalisation Adjustment Fund remains a key instrument for supporting citizens, and the EU should first of all combat market distortions as a whole rather than just trying to treat the victims of its reckless policies.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report mobilising the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in the amount of EUR 442 293 in relation to redundancies made by PWA International, which operates in division 33 rev. 2 of NACE in south Dublin ('Repair and installation of machinery and equipment').

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because it supported the granting of support from the European Globalisation Fund to 108 redundant workers from The Irish company PWA International Ltd (PWAI) (Repair and installation of machinery and equipment). Ireland specialised in the repair, maintenance and overhaul sector in the 1990s, which was a useful activity at the time, but the new trend to move these activities closer to the centres of global aviation development, i.e. Asia, and the negative impact of global trade agreements have made such activities particularly vulnerable. The sector has been hit hard in Europe, particularly in Ireland, following the closure of SR Technics in 2009, the loss of approximately 1 520 jobs in 2014 by Lufthansa Technik Airmotive Ireland.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) was set up to provide additional support to workers affected by the consequences of major structural changes in world trade. On 6 November, the Commission adopted a proposal for a decision on the use of the EGF for Ireland to support the reintegration into the labour market of workers made redundant from PWA International Ltd and the integration into the labour market of 108 young people not in employment, education or training. On the basis of the relevant provisions of the EGF Regulation, the Commission concluded that the conditions for the financial contribution from the EGF were fulfilled for the application.  Personalised services for redundant workers include five types of measures: (i) career guidance, career planning and career development, (ii) EGF training support, (iii) training and further education programmes, (iv) higher education programmes and (v) limited-time grants. On the basis of the above, I voted in favour of the adoption of the proposal.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: Writing. This time, meps also supported the granting of aid to Ireland from the Globalisation Adjustment Fund, albeit on a very small scale. With these funds, Ireland will also formally say goodbye to the aviation parts industry and will devote funds to the retraining of workers. In Slovenia, too, we should monitor developments in industrial activity more actively, because I am convinced that we have similar cases where adjustment to market conditions is taking place more slowly than jobs are being replaced. Here, too, the assistance of this fund and its related activities would be welcome.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. \u2012 As in the past for Alitalia employees, it is right that Irish workers in the affected production facilities should also benefit from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund so that they can be effectively assisted in their reintegration into the labour market, updating their training and giving them economic support at the same time. It is therefore appropriate to mobilise the EGF in order to make a financial contribution to workers in companies that have suffered serious problems as a result of these phenomena.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. This proposal aims to provide Ireland with a financial contribution of more than EUR 442,000 from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, following the dismissal of 108 employees by a company operating in the repair and installation of machinery and equipment. This assistance is intended to facilitate the reintegration of laid-off workers.  These layoffs are directly related to the current economic crisis and unfair competition from emerging countries. On the one hand, this request, made by the Irish authorities, fulfils the conditions for the granting of financial contributions from the WEF. On the other hand, we believe it is important to help laid-off Irish workers who are suffering, as in France, the disastrous consequences of savage globalisation. That is why I voted for this text.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 By mobilising the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF), 108 redundant workers of PWA International in Ireland and one of its suppliers will benefit from personalised aid and services for their retraining. The budget for this aid is EUR 737 156, of which 60 % will be the EGF contribution, i.e. EUR 442 293. With the unemployment rate increasing in those regions and opportunities in the maintenance, repair and overhaul sector and in the wider manufacturing sector are increasingly scarce, former PWA International workers face increased competition for jobs and an increased risk of going into long-term unemployment. I voted in favour of this report because I believe that support measures for redundant employees are absolutely necessary in order to integrate them into the labour market.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 Vote in favour. There are 108 redundancies in the "Repair and installation of machinery and equipment" sector, amounting to EUR 442 293. PWAI was founded in 1989 as a joint venture between United Technologies Corporation and Lufthansa Technik Airmotive Ireland. In the 1990s Ireland specialized in the maintenance, repair and overhaul of aircraft, which was very useful to it at that time, but made it particularly vulnerable to the recent tendency to place maintenance, repair and overhaul in the vicinity of expanding centres of world air transport, namely Asia, and the negative effects of global trade agreements.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. MEPs voted to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in favour of the sacked employees of PWA International in Ireland. The amount allocated is 442,293 euros. 108 laid-off workers will receive training aimed at reintegrating into the labour market and finding a job.  Ireland's request justifies the intervention of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund given the importance of Asian competition in the maintenance, repair and overhaul of machinery and equipment.  I voted in favour of this report, which shows the Union's solidarity in the face of certain negative consequences of globalisation on employment.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of this report in order to support the reintegration into the labour market of 108 workers made redundant as a result of globalisation by IE/PWA International, a company operating in the field of repair and installation of machinery and equipment. The recent tendency to place the maintenance, repair and overhaul of machinery and equipment in the vicinity of expanding centres of world air transport, namely Asia, has made this sector very vulnerable in Ireland. The negative effects of world trade agreements have worsened this situation of vulnerability.  I also note that the maintenance, repair and overhaul of machinery and equipment has been hard hit in Europe, particularly Ireland, with the closure of SR Technics in 2009 and Lufthansa Technik Airmotive Ireland in 2014, which led to the loss of around 1 520 jobs. The vote in favour of this report will make it possible to facilitate the rapid reintegration into working life of these redundant workers through personalized accompanying actions. I regret that Italian companies do not benefit adequately from this fund because of the lack of support from local institutions.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this legislative vote to approve the use of funds from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. The Irish Government has applied for € 442,293 from this EU fund to help 108 workers who have lost their jobs. UKIP opposes the use of this fund as British taxpayers are being made to pay EU dole money for poor economic decisions in other countries.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of Ireland receiving European Globalisation Adjustment Fund money following an application for a financial contribution from the EGF following redundancies in one company and supplier in Ireland. The application is considered admissible since the redundancies have a serious impact on employment and the economy.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 We support the report and the purpose it serves. We agree that the pre-existing unfavourable situation in the region, combined with the accumulated result of the closure of three major companies in this sector in a short period of time, as well as the fact that there are no longer any employers left in the MRO sector in Ireland, may justify derogating from the 500 redundancies threshold set out in Article 4(1) of the EGF Regulation. In this respect, we reiterate our recommendation to the Commission either to clarify the derogation criteria laid down in Article 4(1) of the EGF Regulation or to lower the threshold of 500 redundancies. Finally, we welcome the fact that, in order to provide workers with assistance as soon as possible, the Irish authorities decided to launch the implementation of personalised services to affected workers on 22 May 2015, well before the decision on EGF support for the proposed coordinated package.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The proposal to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund at Ireland's request is a legitimate move aimed at tackling the problems caused by ever-changing conditions in the context of global competition. As this Globalisation Adjustment Fund is by definition intended to support population groups facing labour problems as a result of globalisation, I believe that this proposal has a reasonable basis and we must support it for the benefit of workers in parts of Ireland. That is why I voted in favour of it.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of mobilising the EGF in favour of Ireland. This measure refers, within the framework of the 2015 budget, to the mobilisation of the Fund for a total amount of EUR 442 293. The request is based on the reintegration into employment of workers made redundant by PWA International Ltd, an economic company classified in NACE Rev. 2 Division 33 ("Repair and installation of machinery and equipment"), as well as the integration into the labour market of 108 young people who are unemployed and not enrolled in education or training courses (NEETs).  It should be noted that the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) was set up to provide support to workers affected by major changes in the structure of world trade. Among the causes of the crisis is the closure of PWAI following the decision to consolidate the company's operations in North America and Asia, as a result of the tendency to place maintenance, repair and overhaul activity near expanding centers of world air transport and the negative effects of global trade agreements.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was established in 2006 to provide additional assistance to workers affected by the consequences of major changes in the structure of international trade and to help them reintegrate into the labour market. From 1 May 2009, the scope of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund has been extended to include support for workers made redundant as a direct result of the economic, financial and social crisis. At a time when Europe is in the face of a financial, economic and social crisis, with unemployment being one of the main consequences, the European Union should use every means at its service to react, in particular as regards the support to be provided to people who have been left without a job. I therefore supported this report on mobilising EUR 442,293 for Ireland with the aim of supporting the 108 workers made redundant at PWA International Ltd (PWAI).

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was created in order to provide additional support to workers suffering the consequences of major structural changes in world trade flows. On 6 November the Commission adopted a proposal for a Decision mobilising the EGF for Ireland in order to facilitate the reintegration into employment of workers made redundant by PWA International Ltd, as well as the integration into the labour market of 108 unemployed young people and NEETs. I support this proposal because the Commission has concluded that the application complies with all the applicable provisions of the EGF Regulation, thus fulfilling the conditions for financial assistance from the Fund in question.  According to the Irish authorities, the event that led to the redundancies at PWA International coincides with the closure of PWAI following the decision to move certain activities such as maintenance, repair and overhaul to North America and Asia.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. – I am voting in favour on the assumption that the rule of one-size-fits all should not apply for small states all the time and at all costs. The case of Ireland is a case in point whereby 108 redundancies in a sensitive sector proved enough grounds for the qualification of the case as ‘exceptional circumstances’ qualifying the reason for a contribution of EUR 442 293 under that Regulation. The fact that 108 young people not in employment, education or training (NEETs) under the age of 25 on the date of submission of the application will also have access to personalised services co-financed by the EGF is a further incentive for me to vote in favour of hope towards their future. My vote also reflects Ireland’s determination to do its part too through the implementation of five types of measures for redundant workers covered by such application based on a programme similar to the EGF programme for SR Technics which led to positive outcomes.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report as it allows the mobilisation of EUR 442 293 following the dismissal of 108 workers at PWA International Ltd., Ireland. This mobilization of funds aims to mitigate the disastrous social consequences of the economic crisis of the capitalist system. While these funds are unable to solve the problems of these Irish workers in view of the high unemployment rates in that country, they at least give the possibility of alleviating a small part of the human drama. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was set up to provide additional support to workers affected by the consequences of major structural changes in world trade. On 6 November 2015, the Commission adopted a proposal for a decision to use the EGF for Ireland to support the reintegration into the labour market of workers made redundant from PWA International Ltd in sector 33 under NACE Rev. 2 ("Machinery, equipment, equipment repair, commissioning") and the integration into the labour market of 108 young people (NEETs) who are not employed, in education or training. The Irish authorities claimed that the redundancies at PWA International were due to the closure of PWAI following the company's decision to consolidate its North American and Asian operations due to the trend towards the deployment of MRO activities alongside global aviation hubs and the negative effects of world trade agreements. The Commission has concluded that the conditions for a financial contribution from the EGF are fulfilled for the application and was therefore approved today by the EP, which I voted in favour of. An important element of the application is that personalised services co-financed by the EGF will also be accessed by 108 young people who are not employed, in education or training and who were under 25 years of age at the time the application was submitted.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which presents an application for the use of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in order to assist former employees of PWA International Ltd in Ireland following the redundancy of 500 employees due to major structural changes in world trade patterns. The funds will go towards the reintegration of these persons back into the job market. I believe that workers who end up becoming redundant due to global economic trends, which they have no control over, need at least to be given the help to find alternative employment as soon as possible.

name: Daniel DALTON
text: in writing. ‒ There is no such thing as public money, so it is essential that EU expenditure is closely scrutinised on the basis of value for money for taxpayers and I do not believe the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is an efficient tool that offers value for money in terms of reintegrating redundant workers back into labour market. The United Kingdom Government has never availed itself of funding under the EGF due to its inefficiency and I believe it is time that money spent under the EGF was put to better use. For these reasons I cannot support this report.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This legislative report proposes the mobilization of EUR 442,293 from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (WEF) for the 108 licensees of PWA International Ltd in Ireland (supplier and repairer of aircraft) between December 2014 and April 2015.  The WEF helps people who have lost their jobs as a result of major structural changes in international trade as a result of globalization or the global economic and financial crisis. The EGF has a maximum annual budget of 150 million euros for the period 2014-2020.  Considering that one of the aims of the European Union budget is to promote the transition of sectors in decline towards a more sustainable economic model, I supported this report.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. I supported the mobilization of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EMF) to help 108 employees who were laid off in Ireland following the closure of PWA International. The mobilization of the WEF will ensure the financing of a set of personalized services to ensure the reintegration of these workers into the workforce.

name: Jean-Paul DENANOT
text: In writing. This request for EMF is derogatory to the files usually submitted by Member States with respect to the number of employees impacted by the transfer of the activities of PWAI, which specialises in aircraft engine maintenance, repair and overhaul, to its customers in North America and Singapore.  Nevertheless, I supported it because it is the future of employees who will be offered ways to accompany their retraining, knowing that a hundred young people in the NEET category will have the opportunity to acquire an initial vocational training that they currently lack.  Beyond that, however, I wonder about a fund , particularly interesting and useful - which intervenes in hindsight and in too long a time frame. I call for more anticipation from the European Union on these developments in sensitive sectors already identified (food industry, textiles, machinery and equipment, information and communication, etc.).  In the field of activity under consideration, aeronautics, the Union must seek to distinguish itself by positioning its industry (and worker training) on the materials of tomorrow, a way of anticipating the international situation in order to position itself in emerging and more promising markets.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this request made by Ireland for redundancies in the aircraft maintenance sector at PWA International and at one of its suppliers. Indeed, the technological transition to next-generation aircraft explains the decline in demand for PWAI's activities in Ireland and the relocation of these activities outside the European Union. The world's air fleet of the future is likely to be dominated by narrow-body, one-way aircraft of the Airbus 32 type. This growth is expected to come from Asia, where the aviation sector is booming and older aircraft types need to be replaced by narrow-body types. Europe, and Ireland in particular, has therefore been severely affected by the tendency to locate maintenance, repair and overhaul activities near aviation expansion centres and by the negative effects of global trade agreements.  The aim is to help 108 sacked employees. The assistance will amount to EUR 442,293 and will enable the co-financing of active labour market measures focusing on training, orientation and career planning.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. This report aims to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in Ireland, following the dismissal of 108 employees in Dublin by PAW International.  More than 442,000 euros are to be allocated to these graduates for their reintegration into the labour market. This allowance also includes unemployed, ungraded and untrained youth. Attached to the defence of workers affected by the throes of globalization, I supported this report.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 In this case, half a million euros are allocated by the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to reintegration of 600 workers into the labour market in Ireland. The European Union must support growth and job creation, but in a proactive way and here the investment does not match the result. So I fundamentally vote against this fund, as I have done now.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The Irish authorities have applied for a financial contribution of EUR 442 293 from the EGF for 108 redundant workers. Ireland plans to allocate this money for training and supplementary education programmes, guidance, career planning and development and higher education programmes for the redundant. The money from the Adjustment Fund should basically be given to the dismissed and not to reintegration or retraining programmes. We don't need skilled unemployed people.

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) was set up to provide additional support to workers affected by the consequences of major structural changes in world trade. On 6 November, the Commission adopted a proposal for a decision on the use of the EGF for Ireland to support the reintegration into the labour market of workers made redundant from PWA International Ltd and the integration into the labour market of 108 young people not in employment, education or training. This is the 16th request to be examined in the framework of the 2015 budget and a total of EUR 442 293 from the EGF will be used for Ireland. On the basis of the relevant provisions of the EGF Regulation, the Commission concluded that the conditions for the financial contribution from the EGF were fulfilled for the application. Personalised services for redundant workers include five types of measures: (i) career guidance, career planning and career development, (ii) EGF training support, (iii) training and further education programmes, (iv) higher education programmes and (v) limited-time grants. On the basis of the above, I voted in favour of the adoption of the proposal.

name: Jill EVANS
text: in writing. ‒ The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was set up to provide additional assistance to workers who have lost their jobs as a result of major structural changes in world trade patterns. It is a means by which the EU can give valuable help to local economies hard hit by company closures, and so I voted in favour of this application. I regret that the UK Government has not taken advantage of this fund in Wales.

name: Fredrick FEDERLEY
text: Written. "Our belief is that prosperity is created through free trade and fair competition. That is why we are opposed in principle to the European Globalisation Fund, which we believe is an expression of protectionism. We have previously accepted that the Fund has been used as a mere emergency measure at a time of deep economic crisis, as a means of confronting people's sense of hopelessness and the alienation that follows in the wake of the crisis and which risks further reinforcing the wave of nationalism and xenophobia that is spreading in Europe. However, particularly in the light of the Swedish National Audit Office's analysis, which states that the Fund even has a negative effect on the return to work, we believe that the Fund has lost its legitimacy and should not be used any more.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. I voted for this deliberation because I want support for European businesses and workers.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. \u2012 Ireland submitted an application for a financial contribution from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) after 108 redundancies at PWA International Ltd (PWAI), established in 1989 in Rathcoole, a joint purchase between United Technologies Corporation and Lufthansa Technik Airmotive, which operated in the repair and installation of machinery equipment. The recent trend towards the relocation of maintenance, repair and general review (MRO) activities, for example for Asia, were factors that seriously affected this sector and Ireland. This application does not meet all the traditional eligibility criteria laid down by the EGF Regulation in terms of the number of redundancies, with a derogation being invoked for exceptional circumstances, as redundancies have serious repercussions on employment and on the local, regional or national economy. Ireland has also decided to provide co-financed by the EGF to 108 young people who do not work, study or train (NEETs). Almost 80% of redundant workers are between 30 and 54 years of age, and all 108 redundant workers are skilled workers operating in the 'repair and installation of machinery and equipment' sector, more specifically in the aviation engine sector. Each new mobilization of the EGF is an accusatory libel to EU policies.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: in writing. – I voted in favour as it will is badly needed by the local community in Ireland. It is small change in comparison to what we have lost as a result of our EU membership.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 Taking into account the Interinstitutional Agreement of 2 December 2013 between the European Parliament, the Council and the European Commission on budgetary discipline and having regard to the Council Regulation, as well as regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council, I support the allocation of a financial contribution of EUR 442 293 for Ireland. This particular application concerns 108 redundancies of PWA International Ltd. The existing difficult situation in the area, together with the cumulative impact of the closure of three major SGO companies in the short term and the fact that no employers remain in this sector in Ireland, could justify an exemption from the threshold of 500 redundancies set out in Article 4(1) of the EGF Regulation.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of mobilising the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for 108 redundancies in the "Repair and installation of machinery and equipment" sector amounting to € 442 293 in Ireland.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The money from the Adjustment Fund should basically be given to the dismissed and not to reintegration or retraining programmes. We do not need skilled unemployed people, and that is why I am voting against this report.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ The application relates to 108 redundancies in PWA International Ltd (PWAI) (Repair and installation of machinery equipment) in Southern and Eastern Ireland. Although the EGAF threshold lies at 500 workers made redundant, this derogation from the threshold of 500 redundancies can be justified by the cumulative effect of three major closures in the maintenance repair and overhaul sector (MRO) within the last years. The redundancies were caused by major structural changes in world trade patterns.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was set up to provide additional support to workers affected by the consequences of major structural changes in world trade. I welcome the fact that, in order to provide rapid support to workers, the Irish authorities have decided to start implementing personalised services as early as 22 May 2015, well before the decision to grant EGF support for the proposed coordinated package. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. I voted in favour of mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund: application EGF/2015/006 IE/PWA International, Ireland. Europe and the world are immersed in a profound process of globalization which, despite being a source of trade and wealth creation, can also carry risks to which we must be very attentive. As a result of this process there are sectors that are more exposed to international competition, so from the EU we must respond to those citizens who lose their jobs as a result of globalisation. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) supports workers who lose their jobs as a result of major structural changes in global trade patterns, caused by globalisation or the global economic and financial crisis.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Writing. I voted today against the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund: Ireland's request – EGF/2015/006 IE/PWA International, as I consider the Globalisation Fund as a whole to be an inappropriate, inefficient instrument.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Writing. Europe has benefited from and will continue to benefit from the ongoing globalisation. We must consistently support citizens who have become unemployed as a a rising part of international competition in reintegrating into the labour market.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the application from Ireland for the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund given that the pre-existing difficult situation in the area, combined with the cumulative effect of three major closures in the MRO sector within a short period, and the fact that no employers in this sector remain in Ireland, may justify a derogation from the threshold of 500 redundancies set out in Article 4(1) of the EGF regulation. The application is for 108 redundancies in the Southern and Eastern Ireland region working repair and installation of machinery equipment for aviation. All redundant workers are expected to participate in the measures.

name: Sylvie GODDYN
text: In writing. PAW International, a machine and equipment installation and repair company, mainly in the aerospace sector, has laid off 108 workers at its Dublin site. Ireland then applied for exceptional assistance of EUR 442,293 to help sacked employees return to work.  The case of PAW International is a typical case of relocation. In the aviation sector, maintenance, repair and overhaul have recently tended to be located or relocated near aviation expansion centres in Asia. The globalization of trade is reflected in increased and unbalanced competition in this sector, which leads to job and know-how losses. I voted for this report, which has the merit of mitigating the social 'break', although I note that Europe seeks above all, by this means, to mitigate its responsibility for relocations.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. This dossier will also be supported favorably. In this case, the Irish companies concerned do not reach the threshold of more than 500 dismissed and it has resorted to seeing these as a new episode that accumulates to previous processes. Conservative groups have complained about this point. Undoubtedly, it is better to have these funds to alleviate consequences, in this case in the sector of mechanical repair and maintenance, than not. We consider that globalisation adaptation funds involve mitigation mechanisms but not a solution, but we consider that, in the absence of alternatives posed by the European model, this is better than nothing.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which presents an application for the use of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in order to assist former employees of PWA International Ltd in Ireland following the redundancy of 500 employees due to major structural changes in world trade patterns. The funds will go towards the reintegration of these persons back into the job market. I believe that workers who end up becoming redundant due to global economic trends, which they have no control over, need at least to be given the help to find alternative employment as soon as possible.

name: Nathan GILL
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this legislative vote to approve the use of funds from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. The Irish government have applied for EUR 442 293 from this EU fund to help 108 workers who have lost their job. UKIP oppose the use of this fund as British taxpayers are being made to pay EU dole money for poor economic decisions in other countries.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ The regulation reflects the agreement reached between Parliament and the Council to reintroduce the crisis mobilisation criterion, to set the Union financial contribution at 60 % of the total estimated cost of proposed measures, to increase efficiency for the treatment of EGF applications in the Commission and by Parliament and the Council by shortening the time for assessment and approval, to widen eligible actions and beneficiaries by the addition of self-employed persons and young people , and to finance incentives for setting up one’s own businesses.

name: András GYÜRK
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) was set up to provide additional support to workers affected by the consequences of major structural changes in world trade. On 6 November, the Commission adopted a proposal for a decision on the use of the EGF for Ireland to support the reintegration into the labour market of workers made redundant from PWA International Ltd and the integration into the labour market of 108 young people not in employment, education or training. This is the 16th request to be examined in the framework of the 2015 budget and a total of EUR 442 293 from the EGF will be directed to Ireland. On the basis of the relevant provisions of the EGF Regulation, the Commission concluded that the conditions for the financial contribution from the EGF were fulfilled for the application. Personalised services for redundant workers include five types of measures: (i) career guidance, career planning and career development, (ii) EGF training support, (iii) training and further education programmes, (iv) higher education programmes and (v) limited-time grants. On the basis of the above, I voted in favour of the adoption of the proposal.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 It is our consistent practice to vote in favour of the amounts released from the globalisation adjustment fund because they are certainly a form of support for laid-off workers. However, we always make it clear that all this is not, in our view, sustainable measures to protect workers. For us, an industrial policy must be long-term, state-supported and ensure that support for workers is not fragmented, as is the case here. The State's strategy should be based on long-term plans for continuing education and retraining of workers in various key areas of state investment.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ I was very pleased to support this application for almost half a million euro of European Globalisation Fund (EGF) assistance for workers made redundant from PWA International (PWAI). The application concerns 108 workers working in the aircraft maintenance, repair and overhaul sector and a related supplier, between mid-2014 and September of this year. In addition to these workers 108 young people not in employment, education or training will also benefit from the fund, bringing the total number of beneficiaries to 216. The total budget for services to assist the redundant workers in upskilling or retraining to return to work is EUR 737 156, with a 60% contribution from the EGF of EUR 442 293. This has been a most beleaguered sector over recent years with the closures of Lufthansa Technik and SR Technics at Dublin Airport but we have seen real positive outcomes from assistance from the EGF programme for SR Technics with 53.45% of beneficiaries back in employment almost a year after the programme finished. The PWAI workers have a similar very specific skill set and I hope will have just as positive an outcome from EGF assistance.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report due to the fact that that the closure of PWAI has had a serious impact on employment and on the local economy based on the pre-existing difficult situation in the area combined with the cumulative effect of three major closures in the aircraft maintenance industry within a short period. Ireland specialised in the Maintenance, Repair and Overhaul (MRO) sector in the 1990s, which served it well at that time, but made it particularly vulnerable to the recent trend to locate MRO activity near centres of global aviation expansion, i.e. Asia, and to the adverse impacts of global trade deals. The variety of training measures to be provided to the beneficiaries will be a great boost to the individuals and the local economy.

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: in writing. ‒ The European Global Adjustment Fund, which helps workers find new jobs and develop new skills when they have lost their jobs as a result of changing global trade patterns, contributes EUR 2.6 million to the Finnish fund and EUR 442 293 to the Irish fund. Though I fully support measures which put in place policies that create growth and jobs, my group and I do not believe that the EGF is the right tool for putting in place such policies, nor that is an efficient tool, which is why I have voted against this proposal. By the way, I believe that the euro must be abolished. It leads to dissension and discord in Europe.

name: György HÖLVÉNYI
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) was set up to provide additional support to workers affected by the consequences of major structural changes in world trade. On 6 November, the Commission adopted a proposal for a decision on the use of the EGF for Ireland to support the reintegration into the labour market of workers made redundant from PWA International Ltd and the integration into the labour market of 108 young people not in employment, education or training. This is the 16th request to be examined in the framework of the 2015 budget and a total of EUR 442 293 from the EGF will be used for Ireland. On the basis of the relevant provisions of the EGF Regulation, the Commission concluded that the conditions for the financial contribution from the EGF were fulfilled for the application. Personalised services for redundant workers include five types of measures: (i) career guidance, career planning and career development, (ii) EGF training support, (iii) training and further education programmes, (iv) higher education programmes and (v) limited-time grants. On the basis of the above, I voted in favour of the adoption of the proposal.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of this report that will provide EUR 442 293 from the European Globalisation Fund to help 108 workers made redundant in the Aeronautical industry. The amount represents 60 % of the total costs of the proposed actions. Actions such as guidance and career planning and development, EGF training grants mechanisms and higher education programmes, are all at the disposal of the redundant workers who represent the main beneficiaries.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a report on the proposal for a decision by the European Parliament and the Council to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in accordance with point 13. Interinstitutional agreement of 2 December 2013 between the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission on budgetary discipline, on cooperation on budgetary issues and on good financial management, tabled by Ireland, after a large number of workers at PWA International Ltd (PWAI) were made redundant and affected by the effects of the global financial and economic crisis.  Union financial assistance should be dynamic and accessible as quickly as possible, so this report, for which I vote, agrees with the Commission that the arguments cited by Ireland can be assessed as 'exceptional circumstances' and that Ireland is entitled to a financial contribution of EUR 442 293 and the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. In my view, this assistance is important in order to allow redundancy workers to be reintested into the labour market and to mitigate the consequences of redundancies.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. – I voted against this legislative vote to approve the use of funds from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. The Irish Government have applied for EUR 442 293 from this EU fund to help 108 workers who have lost their job. UKIP oppose the use of this fund as British taxpayers are being made to pay EU dole money for poor economic decisions in other countries.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Victor Negrescu's report on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund at Ireland's request for the sacked employees of PWA International and a subcontractor. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, established in 2006, helps people who have lost their jobs. This fund will release an envelope of 442,293 euros for 108 sacked employees. This amount will be used to finance training, counselling and support to encourage the recruitment of these laid-off workers.  This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report for the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to support the reintegration into the labour market of workers laid off at PWA International Ltd in Ireland during the financial crisis.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. Ireland's aviation technology is particularly affected by the effects of globalisation and the crisis. It is therefore necessary to vote in favour of mobilising the Fund.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of mobilisation of the fund, as I support giving assistance to reintegrate workers in the labour market made redundant due to major structural changes in world trade patterns due to globalisation and the economic crisis.

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) was set up to provide additional support to workers affected by the consequences of major structural changes in world trade. On 6 November, the Commission adopted a proposal for a decision on the use of the EGF for Ireland to support the reintegration into the labour market of workers made redundant from PWA International Ltd and the integration into the labour market of 108 young people not in employment, education or training. This is the 16th request to be examined in the framework of the 2015 budget and a total of EUR 442 293 from the EGF will be used for Ireland. On the basis of the relevant provisions of the EGF Regulation, the Commission concluded that the conditions for the financial contribution from the EGF were fulfilled for the application. Personalised services for redundant workers include five types of measures: (i) career guidance, career planning and career development, (ii) EGF training support, (iii) training and further education programmes, (iv) higher education programmes and (v) limited-time grants. On the basis of the above, I voted in favour of the adoption of the proposal.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. On 6 November, the Commission adopted a proposal for a decision mobilising the EGF in favour of Ireland, concerning the reintegration into employment of workers made redundant by PWA International Ltd. The request for mobilisation of the EGF, totalling EUR 442 293 for Ireland, concerns 108 workers made redundant at PWA International. I have decided to vote in favour because the eligibility criteria laid down in the EGF Regulation have been met and because I believe in a Europe of solidarity, both horizontally among its members and even more vertically towards its citizens.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. Following the dismissal of 108 workers south of Dublin by PAW International, a company operating in the machinery and equipment repair and installation sector, the Irish authorities have requested assistance from the Globalisation Adjustment Fund.  The application in this case concerns the granting of 442,293 euros to the 108 workers dismissed for reintegration into the labour market, as well as support to 108 young "NEETs" (young people without work, without diploma and without training).  We therefore vote in favour of this text

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I voted for this report because it mobilises 442,293 euros for the reintegration into the labour market of around 100 workers made redundant in Ireland in the repair sector.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: In writing. Following the dismissal of 108 workers south of Dublin by PAW International, a company operating in the machinery and equipment repair and installation sector, the Irish authorities have requested assistance from the Globalisation Adjustment Fund.  This fund, under certain exceptional circumstances, helps workers suffering the consequences of a crisis in a given sector, or by economic changes linked to international competition.  The application in this case relates to the granting of 442,293 euros to the 108 workers dismissed for reintegration into the labour market, as well as support for 108 young "NEETs" (young people without employment, without a diploma and without training).  Layoffs are being affected by structural changes in international trade and increased global competition.  I voted for this text, which indirectly protests against the harmful effects of globalisation on employment.

name: Sander LOONES
text: Written. 'Globalisation is inevitable and goes hand in hand with the opening of new markets, with international competition, with economic growth and with job creation. The flip side of this is job losses in less competitive sectors. The N-VA delegation in the European Parliament understands the objectives of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF), but also pays attention to the taxpayer who pays the bill. Moreover, social policy should be primarily a competence of the Member States. A European transfer union is not a panacea to tackle unemployment. In particular, structural reforms are needed to relaunch economic growth. The MEPs of the N-VA have therefore abstained from voting on this matter.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the adoption of this report by mobilising the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in the amount of EUR 442 293 in relation to redundancies made by PWA International operating in division 33 of NACE Rev. 2 ('Repair and installation of machinery and equipment') in South Dublin, and I agree with that mobilisation.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: in writing. On 6 November, the Irish authorities submitted the application for the EGF financial contribution on 19 June 2015, and on 6 November the Commission adopted a proposal for a decision mobilizing the EGF for Ireland to support the return to the labour market of workers dismissed at PWA International Ltd.  Both Parliament and the Commission agree that all established criteria are met. EGF funding goes to customized services to be offered to laid-off workers: (i) professional guidance and planning and development; (ii) EGF training grants; (iii) training and continuing education programmes; (iv) higher education programmes and (v) limited-term allowances. I would point out that the Irish authorities confirm that the eligible measures are not assisted by other Financial Instruments of the Union and I also stress that the financial contribution of the EGF will comply with the Union's procedural and substance rules on public aid. That is why I voted in favour of this proposal.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. ‒The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund has been created to help people who have lost their jobs as a result of globalisational changes. Ireland applied in June this year to mobilise 442,000 euros from the Fund. The funds will be used for activities to assist laid-off workers in the recruitment process, education and training, and entrepreneurship and self-employment. I supported a report by MPs Negrescu approving the mobilisation of EGF funds to facilitate the recruitment process for 108 workers who are relaxed as a technological surplus in Ireland's PWA International.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was established 9 years ago to help workers who have lost their jobs as a result of the effects of globalisation. The annual budget of the EGF is EUR 150 million. In this case, a vote was held to provide 108 former workers from the Irish company PWA International Ltd, which specialises in overhauling large commercial jet repairs and other repairs. The total financial assistance is EUR 442 293. This step is important not only because it will allow redundant workers to return to the labour market as soon as possible, but also because it will contribute to the maintenance of heavy and highly technical industries within the European Union through the maintenance and diversification of workers' skills and skills. The EGF is one of a number of instruments at the disposal of the European Union that help not only to combat unemployment or to encourage workers to return to the labour market faster, but also provide a positive impetus to the preservation of a number of sectors directly within the eu member states. This is especially important nowadays when several companies transfer production to the rest of the world.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: Writing. \u2012 Ireland submitted a request for a financial contribution from the EFG as a result of the redundancies of 108 employees of PWA International Ltd, included in the repair and installation of machinery, namely aeronautan engineering, which was affected by the global economic crisis. This is the lowest number of redundancies for which the EFG is to be mobilised. The request is based on exceptional circumstances in Ireland, where three major undertakings were closed down and made redundant in the same sector in the short term. I therefore supported the EP resolution to provide support to Ireland for personalised services for the unemployed and to include 108 people in the labour market for a total of EUR 442 293.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, in accordance with point 13 of the Interinstitutional Agreement of 2 December 2013, between the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission on budgetary discipline, cooperation in budgetary matters and sound financial management, because it is comprehensive and documented.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. ‒ I am pleased that as a result of this vote Ireland will get EU aid worth EUR 400 000 for 108 redundant aircraft repair workers to help find new jobs.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I have obviously supported this report on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EMF) for the 108 employees of PWA International Ltd, a maintenance, repair and overhaul company. The WEF is allocating EUR 442,293 to help reintegrate these workers, victims of the Brussels policy and the rules it imposes.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. On 6 November 2012, the Commission adopted a proposal for a Decision mobilising the EGF in favour of Ireland, for financial assistance following 108 redundancies, to facilitate the occupational reintegration of workers, at PWA International Ltd, an economic company classified in the "Repair and installation of machinery and equipment" division. The various training and support measures for entrepreneurship and self-employment, to be given to redundant workers, such as vocational guidance, planning and development, should ensure timely assistance to facilitate the rapid professional reintegration of redundant employees due to the economic and financial crisis.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing. On 6 November 2012, the Commission adopted a proposal for a Decision mobilising the EGF fund for Ireland in order to facilitate the reintegration into employment of workers made redundant by PWA International Ltd, an economic company classified in NACE Revision 2 Division 33 ("Repair and installation of machinery and equipment"), as well as the integration into the labour market of 108 young people who are unemployed and not enrolled in education or training courses. The total amount requested is EUR 442 293.  In view of the role of the EGF Fund, which was set up to provide additional support to workers affected by the consequences of major structural changes in world trade, I am voting in favour of Mr Negrescu's proposal.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the proposal to mobilize the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for Ireland to support the return to the labour market of 108 laid-off workers at PWA International Ltd.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. The situation does not correspond to the intended use of the EGF, but is applied under the procedure of a derogation. That is why I am abstaining from voting.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. The request relates to the mobilization of EUR 442,293 under the Globalization Assistance Fund for the 108 laid-off workers of PWA International, a specialist in the overhaul and repair of jet engines.  The Irish authorities claim that the layoffs at PWA International stem from the company's decision to strengthen its operations in North America and Asia. For more than 10 years, customers based in Asia have accounted for about 50% of PWAI's business and that customers in the United States accounted for 40% of these activities, compared to only 10% for European customers.  The report also makes some timid criticisms of the EU's free trade agreements, particularly with Korea, to explain the company's losses while US companies in the sector strengthen their positions in the Asian market.  I abstain so as not to deprive Irish workers. But in this case as so often it is simply subsidies for relocations.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 That application concerns the dismissal of 108 employees at PWA International. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was set up to provide additional support to workers affected by the effects of major structural changes in world trade patterns. European Union financial assistance to redundant workers should be made available as quickly and efficiently as possible. The Irish application meets the conditions for a financial contribution from the EGF, and the Irish authorities have provided all the necessary guarantees, and I therefore voted in favour of the proposal on mobilising the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, Ireland's application.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) is one of the key tools at the Union’s disposal to provide additional assistance to workers negatively impacted upon by major structural changes in world trade patterns. The Commission approved this specific application as it met the conditions for mobilising EGF to support the local economy. I therefore voted in favour of this report to alleviate the situation of 108 workers in PWA International in Ireland due to the global financial and economic crisis.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report to mobilise EUR 442,292, as part of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, to help 108 sacked employees in two companies operating in the repair and installation of machinery and equipment.  These layoffs are due to the continuation of essential changes in the structure of world trade, as a result of globalization. Ireland, which specialises in maintenance, repair and overhaul (MRO), is being hit hard by the relocation of this type of activity near aviation expansion centres, mainly Asia.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: Writing. \u2012 Ireland applied for a financial contribution from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund when the workers in the service and overhaul sector, which Ireland specialised in at the end of the last century, were made redundant. The reason for the redundancies appears to be a trend of placing service and general repair activities close to the growing global air transport hubs, which are mainly located in North America and Asia. Another reason is the adverse effects of global trade agreements. After examining the application, the Commission declared that the country fulfils all the conditions for a financial contribution. I am therefore voting in favour of mobilising the Fund.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Negrescu (A8-0363/2015) report for the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund: application from Ireland – EGF/2015/006 IE/PWA International. This decision will mobilise the EGF fund in favour of Ireland to support the reintegration in the labour market of workers made redundant in PWA International Ltd, as well as for the integration into the labour market of 108 young people not in employment, education or training (NEETs). I agree with the personalised services which are to be provided to workers made redundant, consisting of five types of measures: (i) Guidance and career planning and development; (ii) EGF Training Grants; (iii) Training and Further Education Programmes; (iv) Higher Education Programmes; and (v) Time Limited Allowances.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund aims to support workers affected by major structural changes in world trade and made redundant as a result of the global financial and economic crisis and to support their reintegration into the labour market. Ireland has submitted an application for a financial contribution from the EGF following 108 redundancies at PWA International Ltd in the 'Repair and commissioning of machinery, equipment, equipment' sector. Ireland enesees five types of measures for the redundant workers covered by the aid: (i) career guidance, career planning and career development, (ii) EGF training support, (iii) training and further education programmes, (iv) higher education programmes and (v) limited-time grants. All redundant workers are expected to participate in the measures.  In its report, the Committee on Budgets notes that the application does not fulfil the traditional eligibility criteria laid down in the EGF Regulation as regards the number of redundancies and has been submitted on the basis of the intervention criterion provided for in Article 4(2) of that Regulation, which, exceptionally, allows for a derogation. The report agrees with the European Commission that the arguments put forward by Ireland justify the application of the criterion of 'exceptional circumstances' and that, accordingly, Ireland is entitled to financial assistance of EUR 442 293 under that Regulation and therefore proposes that Parliament approve the Decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the use of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund at ireland's request. I supported the proposal.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
