text: in writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was set up to provide complementary support to workers affected by the effects of major structural changes in world trade patterns. On 6 November, the Commission adopted a proposal for a Decision on mobilising the EGF in favour of Ireland in order to support the reintegration into the labour market of workers made redundant from PWA International Ltd, which operates in the economic sector classified in NACE Rev. 2 division 33 ('Repair and installation of machinery and equipment'), as well as the integration into the labour market of 108 young people who do not work , do not study and do not follow training (NEET). I am voting in favour of this proposal on mobilising a total amount of EUR 442 293 from the EGF in favour of Ireland. The application concerns the dismissal of 108 employees at PWA International

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. Following the dismissal of 108 workers south of Dublin by PAW International, a company operating in the machinery and equipment repair and installation sector, the Irish authorities have requested assistance from the Globalisation Adjustment Fund.  This request relates to the granting of 442,293 euros in aid to the 108 workers who have been made redundant for their reintegration into the labour market, as well as support for 108 young "NEETs" (young people without employment, without a diploma and without training).  The layoffs are linked to structural changes in international trade and increased global competition, which the European Union is leaving countries totally unarmed. Every euro that sovereign states can take back from this Union that plunges them into misery must be taken back.  That is why I voted for this report.

name: Claude MORAES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report, Labour MEPs have always voted in favour of EGF applications and these applications are no different. It is also worth noting that opportunities for the UK to claim from this fund may arise in the near future and the EGF could help those made redundant and wider communities affected by large shocks to the local economy. In addition, the EGF can do this whilst minimising the cost to the UK Government.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EMF). The aim is to help the 108 sacked employees of PWA International, which specialises in the repair and installation of machinery and equipment in the aeronautical field, to the tune of 442,293 euros.  Ireland successfully specialized in this sector in the 1990s. However, maintenance and repair activities in the aviation sector are now increasingly being established in Asia, where the largest expansions in aviation are located.  Ireland has therefore appealed to the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, which aims to support and support people who have been made redundant as a result of major structural changes in international trade as a result of globalisation (business closures, relocation).

name: Alessandra MUSSOLINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that one of the main tasks of the European Union is to intervene in support of European citizens, where situations of need and poverty arise.  That is why I have decided to support the mobilisation of the EGF for the benefit of 108 workers made redundant at IE/PWA International, an Irish company operating in the repair and installation of machinery and equipment.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted, as rapporteur, for this report that will mobilise the European Globalisation Fund in Ireland where the aeronautical maintenance and repair industry has suffered several losses with the closing in the past years of Lufthansa Technik and SR Technics.

name: Andrey NOVAKOV
text: in writing. \u2012 The app covers 108 people who lost their jobs. The EC's contribution is expected to be EUR 442 000. According to the legislation relating to the European Globalisation Fund (Article 4(1)(a) of the EGF Regulation), it is necessary that the number of job exemptions is at least 500 and the reasons for this are directly related to the economic and financial crisis and globalisation. We see that here we are talking about working-age people (80% of them are between 30-54 years old) who are highly skilled and live near Dublin, the largest economic and industrial hub.  Europe once again proves that it is solidarity and supports business. Thanks for the support for this app. However, I call for the conditions to be respected in order for aid to be valued, necessary and timely.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. I would have abstained on this motion. It is true that all the formal criteria may be met in Ireland's application; nevertheless, the specific case does not seem to me to be sufficiently suitable for making a case for the allocation of funds.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. Ireland wishes to support the reintegration of workers made redundant by PWA International Ltd into the labour market.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: Writing. – I voted in favour of this report. I support the granting of financial support to the Irish company.  It is essential to ensure that redundant workers are provided with dynamic, accessible and effective support to help them find a job as quickly as possible. Active labour market policies must therefore be adequately financed. It should be noted that the closure of PWAI further aggravated the situation in the region, which was still at high unemployment rate, and also had a particularly negative impact not only on the regional economy but also on the national economy.  In this context, it is essential to provide workers with immediate assistance and to make effective use of personalised measures.  It is to be welcomed that this application has been examined very expeditiously and that the Irish authorities have started to grant aid measures much earlier.

name: Margot PARKER
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this legislative vote to approve the use of funds from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. The Irish Government have applied for EUR 442 293 from this EU fund to help 108 workers who have lost their job. UKIP oppose the use of this fund as British taxpayers are being made to pay EU dole money for poor economic decisions in other countries.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 Ireland was the protagonist of a serious economic crisis in 2013, which had negative consequences especially for workers, who now require rapid relocation in the growing economic sector. I am sensitive to employment issues and I am aware of the issues thanks to the work done by my colleagues in the EMPL Committee. For these reasons, I believe it is necessary to respond positively to Ireland's question on the use of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ The Irish aircraft maintenance company has seen a big drop in the number of contracted jobs due to the accelerated development of maintenance technology in Asian countries. This sequence of events is also due to global progress in aircraft production and the development of new materials and safety measures that find flaws more easily and quickly already in the production process.  In addition, due to the concentration of such companies near major transport hubs, Ireland and the EU are exposed to the dislocation of such companies towards global air traffic hubs in countries that have easy access to cheap resources and cheap but well-educated labour. I support this request for disbursement of funds from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, as there are 108 workers and the requested amount is EUR 442 293. A fee of EUR 4 095 per worker can help to adapt in the short term to the new living situation, and in the total amount available to the fund, the total amount represents the minimum part.  In this way we show solidarity towards Ireland, and especially towards its inhabitants. We must show unity in mutual help and perseverance in promoting the spirit of communion. This case is part of the systemic problem of adapting the European economy to new global developments, and it is essential to show unity in efforts to protect EU citizens throughout the process.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. Following the dismissal of 108 workers south of Dublin by PAW International, a company operating in the machinery and equipment repair and installation sector, the Irish authorities have requested assistance from the Globalisation Adjustment Fund. This request relates to the granting of 442,293 euros in aid to the 108 workers who have been made redundant for their reintegration into the labour market, as well as support for 108 young "NEETs" (young people without employment, without a diploma and without training).  The layoffs are linked to structural changes in international trade and increased global competition, which the European Union is leaving countries totally unarmed. Every euro that sovereign states can take back from this Union that plunges them into misery must be taken back. That is why I am voting for this report.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒ Since the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) was set up to support redundancy workers and the self-employed who ceased their activity due to major structural changes in globalisation-in-the-world trade flows, due to the protracted global financial and economic crisis mentioned in Regulation (EC) No 2013/2013; 546/2009(3) or the new global financial and economic crisis and to help them reintegrate into the labour market, I support the decision to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund within the general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2015 in order to provide EUR 442 293 in commitment appropriations and payment appropriations with a view to reintegration into the labour market following the redundancies of 108 PWA International Ltd (PWAI) workers.  Member States should show solidarity with each other when necessary and the Commission must assist them in doing so in order to spend the funds in the most equest and transparent way.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. – PWA International is an Irish company operating in the MRO sector (Maintenance, Repair and Overhaul) and their area of activity is maintenance, repair and overhaul of aircraft. Due to recent changes in global trends, PWAI lost a large part of its clients and was forced to lay off 108 workers from 19 December 2014 to 19 April.  Europe, and Ireland in particular, has been hit hard by new trends where MRL activities are located near global aviation expansion centres. For these reasons, the intervention criteria were met and Ireland acquired the right to use the fund to adapt to globalisation. The fund will implement planned implementing measures such as improving education programmes, helping to guide and plan careers, various trainings and retraining that will reduce unemployment in the sector.  Consequently, I agree with fellow MEP Negrescu's report on the proposal for a decision by the European Parliament and the Council to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund submitted by Ireland.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the proposal to mobilise the EGF in relation to Ireland's application to support the reintegration into the labour market of redundant workers following the closure of PWAI based in Rathcoole, County Dublin. The difficult economic situation that already exists in this area, combined with the closure, in the short space of time, of three large aircraft maintenance, repair and overhaul companies, and the fact that there is no employer left in this sector throughout Ireland, led to the submission of the request for the mobilisation of the fund. The EGF provides personalised services for redundant workers, such as help finding work and helping to start their own businesses. I hope that today's vote will allow employees to be reintegrated into the labour market.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this mobilization of more than 400,000 euros. The process of globalisation has opened Up European markets to international competition, leading to economic and structural changes in our businesses. The EU has set up a European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to mitigate the effects of globalisation on European economies, but especially on workers. Also, it was important to mark European solidarity with this country and this company.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this legislative vote to approve the use of funds from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. The Irish Government have applied for EUR 442 293 from this EU fund to help 108 workers who have lost their job. UKIP oppose the use of this fund as British taxpayers are being made to pay EU dole money for poor economic decisions in other countries.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. Today I voted in favour of Ireland's request for a contribution from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund following the redundancies at PWA International (PWAI) and a supplier in Ireland. I remain convinced that the Globalization Adjustment Fund is a necessary tool of solidarity to help workers affected by the opening of the economy to globalization. I can only hope that the EUR 442,293 will be used to finance measures to help people find a job, train or reorient in work, and create or work on a self-employed job.  Losing one's job remains a difficult test from both a personal and family point of view and Europe must play its part in enabling these people to regain professional stability as quickly as possible.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. \u2012 This report refers to a proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and the Council on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (FEAG) in favour of Ireland, which has submitted an application for this financial instrument to deal with the 108 redundancies at PWA International Ltd (PWAI), which operates in the repair and installation of machinery and equipment.  The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is a financial aid mechanism that aims to support workers affected by the effects of structural changes in world trade patterns in a complementary way, assisting them in their reintegration into work. In view of the arguments put forward by Ireland in this application to the EGf, which are of exceptional character, and in particular the fact that the dismissal of this number of workers has serious repercussions for the local economy, especially in the southern and eastern regions of the country, I am in favour of this application which grants a financial contribution of EUR 442 293 to Ireland , under the EGF Regulation, to provide personalized services geared to the training and reintegration into the labour market of these workers. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. – This dossier will also be supported favorably. In this case, the Irish companies concerned do not reach the threshold of more than 500 dismissed and it has resorted to seeing these as a new episode that accumulates to previous processes. Conservative groups have complained about this point. Undoubtedly, it is better to have these funds to alleviate consequences, in this case in the sector of mechanical repair and maintenance, than not. We consider that globalisation adaptation funds involve mitigation mechanisms but not a solution, but we consider that, in the absence of alternatives posed by the European model, this is better than nothing.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report as it allows the mobilisation of EUR 442 293 following the dismissal of 108 workers at PWA International Ltd., Ireland. This mobilization of funds aims to mitigate the disastrous social consequences of the economic crisis of the capitalist system. While these funds are unable to solve the problems of these Irish workers in view of the high unemployment rates in that country, they at least give the possibility of alleviating a small part of the human drama. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: in writing. ‒ I vote against all of these proposals out of principle, this is because the UK does not receive these kind of payments.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ This mobilisation of the EGF is the 16th time it has been used in 2015. EUR 40 million being mobilised to help those in Ireland who have been made redundant because of the major structural changes in the world’s trade patterns, which led to three major closures and the redundancy of 108 workers in PWA International Limited, who repair and install machinery equipment in Southern and Eastern Ireland. I have always voted in favour of EGF applications, and I cannot agree with the ideologically driven opposition to this much needed funding by the Tories. The UK could benefit massively from the mobilisation of these funds, and it would definitely minimise the costs to the Government when it comes to helping those who have been made redundant.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 The EU has developed legislative and budgetary instruments to provide additional support to workers who are affected by major structural changes in world trade patterns or the global financial and economic crisis, and to assist their reintegration into the labour market. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) serves this purpose. Ireland has submitted an application for a contribution from this Fund of EUR 442 293 to assist 108 redundancies in the company which repaired and installed machinery and equipment. Support should be directed towards career guidance and planning and development, grants and training, training and further education programmes and higher education programmes. As these measures constitute active labour market measures, both the Commission and the EP supported Ireland's request and supported the absorption of €442 293 in financial support from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund by resolution. I supported the motion for a resolution.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: Writing. \u2012 Since the Union has created this legislative and budgetary instrument with the aim of providing additional support to workers in order to help their reintegration, I support ireland's justified request.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. ‒ I supported the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund - Ireland's demand as the Union has put in place legislative and budgetary instruments to provide additional support to workers affected by major structural changes in world trade flows or the consequences of the global financial and economic crisis and to help them reintegrate into the labour market.  The application does not meet the normal eligibility criteria set out in the EGF Regulation with regard to the number of redundant workers, but is submitted on the basis of the intervention criteria referred to in Article 4(2) of that Regulation, which allows exemptions in exceptional circumstances, and I therefore supported the Commission's arguments which can be assessed as 'exceptional circumstances' and that Ireland is therefore entitled to a financial contribution of EUR 442 293 under that Provision.

name: Catherine STIHLER
text: in writing. ‒ 108 aircraft repair workers have been made redundant in Southern and Eastern Ireland. The financial contribution granted through the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, which I supported in plenary today, will aid all affected workers by providing funding for guidance and career planning, training grants, educational programmes and Time Limited Allowances.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. On 19 June 2015, Ireland applied to EGF/2015/006 IE/PWA International Ltd. for a financial contribution from egf following redundancies at PWA International (PWAI) and a supplier in Ireland. The application applies to 108 workers who have been made redundant. The redundancies carried out by companies mainly relate to nuts southern and eastern (IE02) level 2 region. The event that caused the layoffs was the closure of Rathcoole-based PWAI. The EGF should be mobilised to ensure a financial contribution of EUR 442 293. I support this proposal, as I believe that redundancies have a negative impact on employment and the local, regional or national economy. The EGF should therefore be mobilised to assist these workers and provide adequate support to redundant workers.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against the proposal. In fact, by redistributing taxpayers' money, the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund reduces the EU's competitiveness, thereby amplifying the very problem to be solved by the fund.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the use of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund: the role of Ireland - International. I support the granting of a financial contribution to Ireland of EUR 442 293 as a result of the redundancies of 108 redundancies at PWA International as a result of globalisation. The funds will go towards career advice and planning and development, EGF training grants, training and further education programmes, higher education programmes and time-limited allowances.

name: Kay SWINBURNE
text: in writing. ‒ I fully support measures that put in place policies that create growth and jobs. However, I do not believe that the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is the right tool for putting in place such policies, nor do I believe it is an efficient tool that offers value for money for EU taxpayers, therefore I voted against.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 It is our consistent practice to vote in favour of the amounts released from the globalisation adjustment fund because they are undoubtedly a form of support for redundant workers. However, we always make it clear that we do not consider them viable measures to protect workers. For us, an industrial policy must be long-lasting, state-supported and ensure that support for workers is not fragmented, as is the case here. The State's strategy should be based on long-term plans for continuing education and retraining of workers in various key areas of state investment.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The money from the Adjustment Fund should basically be given to the dismissed and not to reintegration or retraining programmes. We don't need skilled unemployed people.

name: József SZÁJER
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) was set up to provide additional support to workers affected by the consequences of major structural changes in world trade. On 6 November, the Commission adopted a proposal for a decision on the use of the EGF for Ireland to support the reintegration into the labour market of workers made redundant from PWA International Ltd and the integration into the labour market of 108 young people not in employment, education or training. This is the 16th request to be examined in the framework of the 2015 budget and a total of EUR 442 293 from the EGF will be used for Ireland. On the basis of the relevant provisions of the EGF Regulation, the Commission concluded that the conditions for the financial contribution from the EGF were fulfilled for the application. Personalised services for redundant workers include five types of measures: (i) career guidance, career planning and career development, (ii) EGF training support, (iii) training and further education programmes, (iv) higher education programmes and (v) limited-time grants.

name: Dario TAMBURRANO
text: in writing. \u2012 We in the M5S usually support and support the EGF's calls for mobilisation, but we voted against it for Ireland. This is because, in our opinion, the Irish Government has unjustified the request by stating that the economic crisis affects not only the air transport sector but also neighbouring companies (already the subject of previous EGF contributions). Furthermore, another factor that has not convinced us is the number of redundancies: only 108 units, well below the 500 units established by the EGF regulation.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. ‒ The current report concerns the mobilisation of the EU Solidarity Fund (EUSF) for a total amount of EUR 442 293 for the 108 workers made redundant in the PWA International Ltd (PWAI) operating in the region of Southern and Eastern Ireland. The EUSF aims to enable a rapid, efficient and flexible response to emergency situations; I therefore welcome the speedy evaluation period for this application, which is less than five months. I also welcome the measures taken by the Irish Government to use this application to provide the redundant workers with guidance and career planning and development, Training and Further Education Programmes, and Time Limited Allowances. I view that as an important step to tackle the decline in the maintenance, repair and overhaul sector, which Ireland has experienced over the past years. The EUSF is an important legislative and budgetary instrument the Union has available to provide additional support to workers across the Union, who are suffering from the consequences of the global financial and economic crisis, and to assist their reintegration into the labour market. For this reason I voted in favour of this current report.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the European Parliament and Council's proposal for a decision on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, in accordance with point 13 of the 2 December 2013 inter-institutional agreement between the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission on budgetary discipline, budgetary cooperation and good financial management.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) in favour of Ireland. The contribution will support the reintegration in the labour market of workers that were made redundant in PWA International Ltd, which was based in County Dublin  and specialised in the overhaul and repair of large commercial jet engine cases. Following the company’s decision to consolidate its operations in North America and Asia in order to locate its activity near the centres of global aviation expansion, the PWAI in Dublin closed down in March 2015 and dismissed 108 workers. The EGF contribution of EUR 442 293 will cover personalised services including measures such as guidance and career development, training grants, further education and time limited allowances.

name: László TŐKÉS
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) was set up to provide additional support to workers affected by the consequences of major structural changes in world trade. On 6 November, the Commission adopted a proposal for a decision on the use of the EGF for Ireland to support the reintegration into the labour market of workers made redundant from PWA International Ltd and the integration into the labour market of 108 young people not in employment, education or training. This is the 16th request to be examined in the framework of the 2015 budget and a total of EUR 442 293 from the EGF will be used for Ireland. On the basis of the relevant provisions of the EGF Regulation, the Commission concluded that the conditions for the financial contribution from the EGF were fulfilled for the application. Personalised services for redundant workers include five types of measures: (i) career guidance, career planning and career development, (ii) EGF training support, (iii) training and further education programmes, (iv) higher education programmes and (v) limited-time grants. On the basis of the above, I voted in favour of the adoption of the proposal.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted against granting Ireland a request to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, which applies to workers made redundant at PWA International Ltd. and one supplier operating in the repair and installation of machinery and equipment.  The company was ultimately closed due to gradual relocation to other overhaul facilities in Arkansas (USA) and Singapore. As more Irish companies have closed in this sector in recent years, it is clear that short-term measures such as EUR 442 293 of assistance from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund cannot help the recovery of this sector in Ireland or the overall Irish economy.  Long-term measures such as cutting red tape and high taxes to return businesses to Ireland and other Member States of the European Union are needed and contribute to a positive downward trend in unemployment, which is a particular problem.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Written in Writing on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the use of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in accordance with point 13 of the Interinstitutional Agreement of 2 May 2006 between the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission on budgetary discipline and information on the budgetary procedure[2] I supported the european union's financial assistance in the event of additional assistance to workers in the event of additional assistance to workers.  This could make a significant contribution to the faster integration of workers back into the labour market, as the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was set up precisely to provide additional assistance to workers in need of assistance in the event of structural changes in world trade. As regards the case of Ireland, I consider that, in the circumstances, it is entitled to a financial contribution of EUR 442 293.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. – This dossier will also be supported favorably. In this case, the Irish companies concerned do not reach the threshold of more than 500 dismissed and it has resorted to seeing these as a new episode that accumulates to previous processes. Conservative groups have complained about this point. Undoubtedly, it is better to have these funds to alleviate consequences, in this case in the sector of mechanical repair and maintenance, than not. We consider that globalisation adaptation funds involve mitigation mechanisms but not a solution, but we consider that, in the absence of alternatives posed by the European model, this is better than nothing.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. ‒ The financial assistance from the Union to workers should be dynamic and available quickly and as efficiently as possible, to assist them in their reintegration into the labour market. Closing PWAI has had a serious impact on employment on the local economy of South Dublin and therefore I support this proposal which professionally will help citizens affected.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. Following the dismissal of 108 workers south of Dublin by PAW International, a company operating in the machinery and equipment repair and installation sector, the Irish authorities have requested assistance from the Globalisation Adjustment Fund.  This fund allows, under certain exceptional circumstances, to help workers suffering the consequences of a crisis in a given sector, or by economic changes linked to international competition and unbridled free trade.  Layoffs are linked to structural changes in international trade and increased global competition.  I voted for it.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was set up to provide additional support to workers affected by the consequences of major structural changes in world trade. On 6 November, the Commission adopted a proposal for a decision on the use of the EGF in favour of Ireland. This is the 16th request to be examined in the framework of the 2015 budget and a total of EUR 442 293 from the EGF will be used for Ireland. I voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. – This dossier will also be supported favorably. In this case, the Irish companies concerned do not reach the threshold of more than 500 dismissed and it has resorted to seeing these as a new episode that accumulates to previous processes. Conservative groups have complained about this point. Undoubtedly, it is better to have these funds to alleviate consequences, in this case in the sector of mechanical repair and maintenance, than not. We consider that globalisation adaptation funds involve mitigation mechanisms but not a solution, but we consider that, in the absence of alternatives posed by the European model, this is better than nothing.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of a resolution because I agree with the decision on the mobilisation of the EGF in favour of Ireland. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was created in order to provide additional assistance to workers suffering from the consequences of major structural changes in world trade patterns and this decision  refers to the mobilisation of a total amount of EUR 442 293 from the EGF to Ireland. It concerns 108 workers made redundant in PWA International. The application was sent to the Commission on 19 June 2015 and supplemented by additional information up to 14 August 2015. The Commission concluded, in accordance with all applicable provisions of the EGF Regulation, that the application meets the conditions for a financial contribution from the EGF, therefore I supported this decision.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. We are talking about a Fund that has been created to provide additional assistance to workers suffering the consequences of major structural changes due to changes in the global market. This is the 16th application that takes place within the 2015 budget and attempts to respond to the situation in Ireland that has faced the closure of several international subsidiaries that have been relocated to other parts of the world such as North America and Asia. Any action to help European citizens in such a situation is welcome, so I consider it necessary to vote in favour of such mobilisation.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. 'I voted to make funds available from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund because we need to support Ireland quickly and efficiently to help the laid-off workers of PWA International Ltd to find another job.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. \u2012 In 1990 Ireland was an expert in the maintenance, repair and general review (MRO) sector. The recent trend to relocate MRO activities to near global aviation expansion centres, for example for Asia, and the harmful effects of global trade, and the closure of SR Technics in 2009 and the closure of Lufthansa Technik Airmotive Ireland in 2014, which resulted in the loss of about 1520 jobs, were factors that seriously affected this sector and Ireland. This application does not meet all the traditional eligibility criteria laid down by the EGF Regulation in terms of the number of redundancies and is submitted under the intervention criteria of Article 4(2) of the Regulation on the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (2014-2020), which allows a derogation in exceptional circumstances, and Ireland is then entitled to a financial contribution of EUR 442 293 under that Regulation.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. The situation does not correspond to the intended use of the EGF, but is applied under the procedure of a derogation. That is why I am abstaining from voting.

name: Theodoros ZAGORAKIS
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the Mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund - Application from Ireland – EGF/2015/006 IE/PWA International because I believe that the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is an important European support tool for workers affected by the effects of globalisation. The countries of the European South, which also face the biggest problem, should make the most of the provisions of this Fund.

name: Marco ZANNI
text: in writing. \u2012 This is Ireland's request to mobilise the EGF (European Globalisation Adjustment Fund) to allocate a contribution of around EUR 450 000 to support 108 workers in the air transport repair and supply sector.  I have always supported the approval of the EGF as the basic rule, although I am aware of the limitations and some critical issues, but in the case of the Irish request there are far too many problems. In fact, the basic mobilisation of the EGF should take place when more than 500 people have been made redundant, while here we are well below, and a derogation from the regulation has been chosen. The Irish Government has tried to explain this by saying that this request is part of a wider crisis in the whole sector, which would also involve other companies, which have already been the subject of previous EGF contributions: this belated justification, which came the day before the vote in the Committee on Budgets, did not convince me anyway, and so I voted against the request to mobilise this Fund for the Irish case.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. Ireland submitted an application for a financial contribution from the EGF after 108 redundancies at PWA International Ltd (PWAI), established in 1989 in Rathcoole, a joint purchase between United Technologies Corporation and Lufthansa Technik Airmotive Ireland, which operated in the repair and installation of machinery equipment in southern and eastern Ireland. In 1990, Ireland was an expert in the maintenance, repair and general review sector. However, the recent trend to relocate these activities to near global aviation expansion centres, for example for Asia, were factors that seriously affected this sector and Ireland. This application does not meet all the traditional eligibility criteria laid down by the EGF Regulation in terms of the number of redundancies and is submitted under the intervention criteria of Article 4 (2) of the Regulation on the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (2014-2020), which allows a derogation in exceptional circumstances, and Ireland is then entitled to a financial contribution of EUR 442 293 under that Regulation , as redundancies have serious repercussions on employment and on the local, regional or national economy. Although these funds only serve as palliatives, not fighting the real causes of the redundancies, we voted in favour.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: in writing. In 2012 The Spanish Socialists have worked hard to get the list of invasive species, voted on 4 December in the Joint Committee on the Environment States-European Commission, to include the species Eichhornia crassipes, commonly referred to as "camalote". The proliferation of this plant is seriously endangering the habitats and biodiversity of the Guadiana Riverbed as it passed through Extremadura, and is already advancing towards Portugal. As set out in Regulation (EU) No 1143/2014 on the prevention and management of the introduction and spread of invasive alien species, the so-called 'list of invasive species' must be approved by means of an Implementing Regulation, as appropriated on 4 December.  The approved list includes the "camalote" and will enter into force within 20 days of its publication in the DOUE. I therefore voted against the rejection of that Implementing Regulation, because I consider it based on procedural and non-legally binding arguments and, in a very specific way, because my main objective in this area is the implementation, as quickly as possible, of measures to eliminate and combat the proliferation of this species and the early recovery of the Guadiana River ecosystem.

name: Tim AKER
text: in writing. – We abstained because the objection, whilst criticising Commission behaviour, recognises and enshrines their power on a topic which should be a choice of Member States.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this objection because I agree with the reasons and arguments given to exercise it. For example, the list of 36 invasive species presented is inconsistent with the provisions of the Invasive Alien Species Regulation, as major harmful or rapidly expanding mammals and plants are not included. In addition, the procedures were not respected, as the European Parliament should have been informed of the elements and methodology of risk analysis, and the species on the list appear to have followed an economic or political criterion. It is therefore important that the criteria in this list be reviewed and the list reworked.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. This objection relates to a list submitted by the Commission on "invasive alien species" such as American lobster, Pacific oyster, African black-tasking goby. The list follows regulation 1143/2014 voted by the European Parliament on 16 April 2014. In this list, pest species are not included in this list, although that should be the case. Other species, on the other hand, are listed without a prior assessment of their harmfulness. I therefore supported this objection.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ For the record, I wish to confirm that I abstained on this vote.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal asking the Commission to withdraw its draft implementing regulation and to submit to the committee a new draft listing the list of invasive alien species of european union concern. The Commission's first proposal does not include many of the most problematic invasive alien species, while it contains some species which cannot have a significant negative impact on biodiversity, ecosystem services, human health or the economy, or which would entail disproportionate costs. Since the reasons for the entry of species on the Union list are based on political rather than scientific criteria, I agree with the need for a new draft regulation.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, which points out in particular that the list of invasive alien species (American lobster, Pacific oyster, black-tasked gobi from Africa, Asian hornet...) proposed by the Commission has been criticized on all sides for omitting major invasive species. The non-binding nature of this objection will not prevent the implementation of the Commission's proposal as it stands, but it was necessary to highlight the lack of seriousness in the preparation of this list.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. I have approved this resolution which rejects the list of invasive alien species proposed by the Commission. The EU draft list fails to address the problem of invasive alien species in a comprehensive way, which would protect biodiversity and reduce and mitigate the impact these species may have on human health or the economy.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. – We voted IN FAVOUR considering that some invasive species have not been included in the list submitted by the Commission even though they should have been and that some of those included do not cause a significant negative impact on biodiversity/ecosystem.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: in writing. The problem of many invasive species included in the Commission's list is more than proven in some european areas, including particularly sensitive ones. The situation also requires immediate action at European level to act in a coordinated manner and prevent the reintroduction of these invasive species from other areas of Europe where no action has been taken. That is why we voted against this report.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. This report concerns an objection to avoid the adoption of the list presented by the Commission concerning "invasive alien species" (American lobster, Pacific oyster, black-tasked gobi from Africa...).  Some pest species should really be included and are not there (assessments would not be completed) while others are there even before the assessment, potentially undermining the economic activities that exploit them. The Commission has therefore presented a list on a heterogeneous basis. I therefore support this objection.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported with my vote the rejection of the list of invasive alien species proposed by the Commission, it not only does not include the most invasive and problematic species, but instead appear species that would not cause damage to the biodiversity of our territories, nor to human health or the economy.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. The Commission has submitted the first list of invasive species of Regulation 114/2014 by means of an implementing act and Parliament, by this objection, opposes it on the account that it should have been a delegated act in the participation of Parliament and not one of one implementing one in which Parliament is not consulted. However, this list includes species that pose a serious threat to our biodiversity, such as water jasmine or chamele, which is currently a huge problem on the Guadiana River and specifically in Extremadura. Therefore, although Parliament should have been consulted when making this list, I voted against the objection and in favour of supporting the approval of the list as soon as possible to alleviate the devastating effects that this plague is having.  I understand the arguments of speed put forward by the Commission in the procedure for adopting the list and I hope that updates to it will be made by delegated acts, with the participation of Parliament.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted for this resolution because it has led Parliament to ask the Commission to withdraw its draft implementing regulation containing a list of invasive alien species of Union concern and to submit a new draft to Parliament. The initial list provided by the Commission does not include species among the most harmful invasive alien species in Europe. However, some species of terrestrial plants and mammals meet the criteria and an in-depth risk assessment is available, but these species are not included in the Union list. The list also does not include mammalian species, which are among the most foreign species in Europe in recent years, and whereas the list also does not include widespread and rapidly spreading plant species with significant and well-documented adverse effects on human health. The commission's original list has been criticised by several competent national authorities, stakeholders and the general public to the extent that these entities are now seriously questioning the effectiveness of the future IAS Regulation, mainly because many of the most problematic invasive alien species are not included in that list, while it includes some species that cannot have a significant negative impact on biodiversity, ecosystem services , human health or the economy, or which would entail disproportionate costs.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. I support this report because I believe that the Commission's draft implementing regulation exceeds the implementing powers provided for in Regulation 1143/2014. The draft Union list does not address the problem of invasive alien species in a comprehensive way that would protect indigenous biodiversity. The proposal does not meet the main requirement to minimise and mitigate the impact these species could have on human health and the economy.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. This objection relates to a list of species deemed invasive by the European Commission, such as American lobster and Pacific oysters. However, it turns out that a number of species are not on this list, while others are noted without having carried out a study beforehand, thus threatening the activity of the economic actors who exploit them. That is why I voted for this objection.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the objection, in accordance with Rule 106 of the Rules of Procedure, to the list of invasive alien species because I believe that there is a need for greater transparency in the choice of species to be part of the list proposed by the European Commission. Their inclusion is not based on a risk assessment and a standardised methodology, but rather on the political will of the Member States. The list proposed by the EC also does not address the problem of invasive alien species in a comprehensive manner so as to protect local biodiversity and ecosystem services, as well as to minimise and mitigate the economic and human health impact that these species could have. In view of the criticism from the competent national authorities, the parties involved and the general public, a point has been reached where the effectiveness of the IAS Regulation is called into question, with many of the most problematic invasive alien species not included in the list, while some species that cannot have a significant negative impact on biodiversity, ecosystem services , human health or the economy were eventually included.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 Vote in favour. The Commission's first list has been criticised by various competent national authorities, stakeholders and the public, so much so that they now seriously doubt the future effectiveness of the regulation on invasive alien species, in particular because many of the most problematic invasive alien species are not on the list while other species not likely to cause significant adverse effects on biodiversity have been included. , ecosystem services, human health or the economy, or for which the measures to be taken would entail disproportionate costs.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the motion for a resolution on the Commission's draft implementing regulation adopting a list of invasive alien species of EU relevance under Regulation (EU) No 1143/2014.  The Commission will adopt, by means of implementing acts, a list of invasive alien species of Eu ropean importance, defined as such because the damage they cause in some Member States is such as to justify the adoption of appropriate measures applicable throughout the Union. This list will be binding in its entirety and directly applicable in all Member States.  However, in compiling this list, the Commission has not ensured that the methodology to be used in risk assessment is applied in the same way in all Member States. Furthermore, the reasons for the inclusion of a species in the Union's draft list are not based on a risk assessment and appear to be based on political rather than scientific criteria.  This resolution therefore called on the Commission to withdraw the draft implementing regulation and to present a new draft. For these reasons, I have chosen to vote in favour of it.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. – I abstained because the objection, whilst criticising Commission behaviour, recognises and enshrines their power on a topic which should be a choice of Member States.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 We support the report, as invasive species pose a serious and rapidly deteriorating threat to natural biodiversity in Europe. Plants and animals entering new, foreign habitats can stifle natural flora or fauna and harm the environment. They also have social and economic effects, for example on human health, fisheries, agriculture and food production.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The motion for a resolution on the objection submitted pursuance to Rule 106 of the Rules of Procedure on the list of invasive alien species is a technical proposal of great importance because it aims to maintain important balances in Europe's natural environment. However, the Commission has not complied with the procedures and the selection of species appears to have been made on the basis of political or economic criteria, since the most important foreign species are absent from this list. That is why I have decided to abstain from this vote.

name: Birgit COLLIN-LANGEN
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the rejection because such a list must be based on relevant risk assessments. It is also a question of human health, where the classification of dangerous invasive species must not be taken lightly.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the objection under Article 106 on the list of invasive alien species, as I believe that the establishment of a list of invasive alien species does not comprehensively address the problem of invasive alien species in order to protect native biodiversity and ecosystem services and minimise the effects on human health or the economy that these species could have.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. – I understand that invasive alien species are numerous and it is therefore important to ensure that priority is given to addressing the subset of invasive alien species considered to be of Union concern on public health. The question is whether this is best to be done at a supranational level or at a national level and whether the proposed solution addresses concretely the problem we are facing. The power to adopt acts in accordance with Article 290 TFEU should be delegated to the Commission. Taking note that Parliament has not been appropriately informed about setting out the common elements for the elaboration of risk assessments, and whereas the transmission of the relevant documents to Parliament was not simultaneous, timely and appropriate; keeping in mind that the draft Union list fails to address the problem of invasive alien species in a comprehensive manner so as to protect native biodiversity and ecosystem services; I agree that the Commission should withdraw its draft implementing regulation and submit a new draft to the Parliament in a proper way which addresses concretely the issue of invasive alien species.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this objection because I agree with the reasons and arguments given to exercise it. For example, the list of 36 invasive species presented is inconsistent with the provisions of the Invasive Alien Species Regulation, as major harmful or rapidly expanding mammals and plants are not included. In addition, the procedures were not respected, as the European Parliament should have been informed of the elements and methodology of risk analysis, and the species on the list appear to have followed an economic or political criterion. It is therefore important that the criteria in this list be reviewed and the list reworked.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ I objected to the draft Commission implementing regulation adopting a list of 36 invasive alien species of Union concern. The initial list ignores species that are amongst the most detrimental IAS in Europe. Some terrestrial plant and mammal species comply with the criteria and a robust risk assessment is available, yet they are not included on the list. Mammal species that are among the most rapidly expanding alien species in Europe in recent years are not listed. The widely spread and rapidly expanding plant species, with considerable and well documented adverse effects on human health, are not listed either. The 2020 biodiversity strategy will fail if we won’t fight the real challenges we are currently facing. The IAS Regulation can deliver real results, but only if rightly implemented and supported by the local authorities.

name: Daniel DALTON
text: in writing. ‒ Invasive species are undoubtedly an increasing problem in our globalised world, threatening biodiversity and costing the EU economy an estimated EUR 12 billion a year. However, I have deep concerns about whether this list of 37 species is going to help EU Member States tackle invasive species in a focused and proportionate way.  The list has some key omissions, including Japanese Knotweed, one of the most destructive and problematic invasive species on the continent, and takes in some harmless plants and animals which could lead to significant costs. Plant sellers and pet keepers across my constituency of the West Midlands have contacted me, concerned about this list and the inclusion of species such as raccoons and water hyacinth, extremely popular with UK pond owners and sold for decades without any problems. Such shortcomings, and a lack of recognition of climate variation within the EU risk undermining the very purpose of the Basic Act on Invasive Species.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This resolution proposes to oppose the European Commission's decision on a proposal for a list of 36 invasive alien species (EEA) of concern to the EU. This list was proposed by the Commission under the new legislative framework to prevent their introduction and manage their spread.  Stressing that some invasive alien species are not included in the proposed list of 36 species of concern to the EU, MEPs propose to object to the Commission's decision. Many of the most problematic species are not included in the draft list, while at the same time some species are being taken up that are not able to cause serious negative consequences.  Considering, moreover, that the Commission's decision lacks scientific support, I supported this objection.

name: Angélique DELAHAYE
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this objection, which opposes the European Commission's decision on a proposal for a list of 36 invasive alien species (EEA) of concern to the EU. This list was proposed by the Commission under the new legislative framework to prevent the introduction of EEAs and manage their spread.  In voting for this objection, I criticise the fact that no expert group has been consulted, especially since there is in fact no expert group in the Commission on this subject. Thus, many of the most problematic species are not included in the draft list, while some species that are not in a way to cause serious negative consequences are included.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that the draft resolution on invasive alien species is a sensible proposal that should be supported. That's why I supported her project. The arguments put forward have their iron and, dare I say, irrefutable logic. Of course, we must protect biodiversity, adopt a complex of measures that do not allow invasive alien species to disturb the balance of ecosystems. Furthermore, extremely strict controls are needed both on the implementation of the measures and on new challenges. The protection of the environment as well as biodiversity cannot be underestimated or derogated from economic, political or any other interest. On the contrary, this should be an irrevocable priority of every representative in Parliament. I would point out that the Commission should do more to do so, not to get away with a half-hearted proposal. Europe's nature and biodiversity must be preserved for generations to come, and there must be strict controls and concrete measures to preserve the balance on the spread of invasive alien species.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 We are voting in favour because the Commission is once again going beyond the limits, jeopardising the balance of European ecosystems.

name: Eleonora EVI
text: in writing. The resolution opposes a draft list of 36 invasive alien species proposed by the Commission with the aim of preventing their introduction and managing their spread within the Union.  The resolution's objection laments the lack of many invasive species on this list which have not yet been included, due to lack of time, by the Commission. The latter, in fact, having the obligation to submit the list by 2015, was forced to propose a list, even if not yet finished. This list will be supplemented by the Commission once the risk assessment for species not yet present has been completed. Since I believe that having a list, although incomplete, is preferable to not having it at all, I voted against this objection.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. I voted for this deliberation because I am opposed to the Commission's text on the subject.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. \u2012 In accordance with the Regulation of Invasive Alien Species, on the prevention and management of the introduction and dissemination of invasive species, the Commission shall submit, by January 2016, a list of these species. The Regulation defines the detailed criteria for the construction of this list. The list presented consists of 36 species. This proposal for objections considers that the list is incompatible with the provisions of the Regulation, as harmful or rapidly disseminated species (animals and vegetables) have not been included. Moreover, the procedures for making this list have not been respected, in particular the European Parliament has not been informed about the elements and methodologies of the impact studies. In short, the decision on the species included in the list seems to take into account criteria of a political or economic nature, without scientific basis, having weighed in their final configuration a set of pressures made by some Member States. Some of these pressures are known. For Portugal, the importance of inclusion in the waterhyine list should be stressed, although Member States with a commercial interest in this species have opposed it. Given that the next revision of this list is planned for six years from now, the shortcomings of this proposal must be corrected at the outset, which is why we voted in favour of the objection.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of the resolution as I believe it makes sense from a biodiversity perspective.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the objection as many of the most problematic invasive alien species are not on the list while other species not likely to cause significant adverse effects on biodiversity, ecosystem services, human health or the economy have been included, or for which the measures to be taken would entail disproportionate costs.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the objection under Rule 106 of the Rules of Procedure on the list of invasive alien species because I believe that the Commission is once again going beyond its powers, jeopardising the balance of European ecosystems.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ Invasive alien species are numerous and it is therefore important to ensure that priority is given to addressing the subset of invasive alien species considered to be of Union concern. The identification of invasive alien species of Union concern shall remain proportionate and focus on species whose inclusion on the Union list would effectively prevent, minimise or mitigate the adverse impact of those species in a cost effective manner. The Commission’s initial list has been criticised by several competent national authorities, stakeholders and the general public, to the extent that they are now seriously doubting the future effectiveness of the IAS Regulation, mainly because many of the most problematic invasive alien species are not listed, while some species incapable of causing a significant negative impact on biodiversity, ecosystem services, human health or the economy. I therefore supported the call on the Commission to withdraw its draft implementing regulation and to submit a new draft to the responsible Committee.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the proposal for a resolution fully aware of the need for a European strategy in the fight against invasive species, which have been installed in various areas of the EU, including Catalonia. We must keep in mind that the Union's draft list does not solve the problem of invasive alien species in a global way, so that indigenous biodiversity and ecosystem services are protected, so we must continue to work towards their eradication.

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: in writing. In 2012 The Spanish Socialists have worked hard to get the list of invasive species, voted on 4 December in the Joint Committee on the Environment States-European Commission, to include the species Eichhornia crassipes, commonly referred to as "camalote". The approved list includes the "camalote" and will enter into force within 20 days of its publication in the DOUE. I therefore voted against the rejection of that Implementing Regulation, because I consider it based on procedural and non-legally binding arguments and, in a very specific way, because my main objective in this area is the implementation, as quickly as possible, of measures to eliminate and combat the proliferation of this species and the early recovery of the Guadiana River ecosystem.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Writing. I voted today in favour of the rejection under Article 106 of the LAND: List of Invasive Alien Species, as I have been working intensively on the list in advance and have discovered, among other things, a lack of logic and insufficient scientific foundations, using the example of the raccoon, among other things. I call on the European Commission to withdraw this implementing provision. Member States should suspend application of the list and respect Parliament's vote. We need a new, better list!

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Objection pursuant to Rule 106 regarding the list of invasive alien species given there are legitimate concerns that the Commission implementing regulation adopting a list of invasive species excludes a significant number of problematic invasive alien species and at the same time includes a number of species that are not detrimental to biodiversity, the ecosystem , human health or the economy in any way.

name: Bruno GOLLNISCH
text: In writing. As it is entitled to do, Parliament is voting today to oppose the Commission's adoption of an enforcement regulation. In this case, it is the list of exotic species, i.e. foreign, animal or plant, considered invasive and potentially dangerous either for native species, or for the environment and biodiversity, or even for human health. Their existence in non-their own countries can also have significant economic repercussions. The most well-known case is that of the Asian hornet, enemy of our bees. These species are estimated to be the second leading cause of biodiversity loss in the world. So it's not an ancillary problem. However, Parliament's resolution is damning: dubious methodology, non-existent or "wet finger" risk assessment, lack of awareness of the opinions of the relevant national authorities or interested parties, etc. Everything contributes to making the list presented by the Brussels Commission a "political" list, sloppy, flawed, useless. It is a pity that the treaties give the Commission quasi-legislative powers and that the procedure for opposing them is so difficult to implement. But if it is to prevent Brussels from harming, I can only agree with this text.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. We voted A FAVOUR on the view that some invasive species have not been included in the list submitted by the Commission even though they should have been and that some of those included do not cause a significant negative impact on biodiversity/ecosystem.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ I objected to the draft Commission implementing regulation adopting a list of 36 invasive alien species of Union concern. text: in writing. ‒ We abstained because the objection, whilst criticising Commission behaviour, recognises and enshrines their power on a topic which should be a choice of Member States.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ My vote was decided by the fact that the regulation is based on an EU list of invasive species of European concern. It is important that this list is comprehensive and based on solid science and risk assessments, as the law requires. The first list which is now being adopted by the Commission should not be blocked, but it should be kept under review and be complemented and improved in the coming years.

name: Sergio GUTIÉRREZ PRIETO
text: in writing. – The Spanish Socialists have worked hard to get the list of invasive species, voted on 4 December in the Joint Committee on the Environment Member States-European Commission, to include the species Eichhornia crassipes, commonly called 'camalote'. I therefore voted against the rejection of that Implementing Regulation, because I consider it based on procedural and non-legally binding arguments and, in a very specific way, because my main objective in this area is the implementation, as quickly as possible, of measures to eliminate and combat the proliferation of this species and the early recovery of the Guadiana River ecosystem.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this motion for resolution objecting to the draft Commission implementing regulation adopting a list of invasive alien species. The regulation deals with the prevention and management of the introduction and spread of invasive alien species. However, I believe, as stated in the resolution, that the draft Union list fails to adequately address the problem of invasive alien species in a comprehensive manner, with many of the most problematic invasive species not listed while others without significant impacts are. In order to protect native biodiversity and ecosystem services and minimise the human health and economic impacts that these invasive species could potentially have, it is crucial that the list ensures those with the most significant adverse impacts are listed. An example from my own constituency of an invasive species which is not listed is the Asian Clam, which is depleting the Irish Pollan, a freshwater whitefish protected under the Habitats Directive.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report as invasive alien species are numerous and it is therefore important to ensure that priority is given to addressing the subset of invasive alien species considered to be of EU concern. It is important to ensure that the identification of invasive alien species of EU concern remains proportionate and focuses on species whose inclusion on the EU list would effectively prevent, minimise or mitigate the adverse impact of those species in a cost effective manner. Many of the most problematic invasive alien species are not listed, while some species incapable of causing a significant negative impact on biodiversity, ecosystem services, human health or the economy, or for which the measures to be taken would result in disproportionate costs, are listed.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of this motion for a resolution that will draft a new document containing the list of invasive alien species of the European Union.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted AGAINST the proposal for a European Parliament resolution on the Commission's draft implementing regulation adopting a list of invasive species of Union importance under Regulation (EU) No 2012/2013; 1143/2014, as such species directly threat European biodiversity, agriculture and fisheries, and therefore I consider it necessary to start implementing the new regulation as soon as possible.  It is important that the list in question is complete and based on scientific data and risk assessment. I believe that the proposal for a list proposed by the Commission should not be rejected, however, it is necessary for the Commission to continue, on the basis of additional assessments, to work on the inclusion of new species on the list.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. – I abstained because the objection, whilst criticising Commission behaviour, recognises and enshrines their power on a topic which should be a choice of Member States.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report of my colleagues Pavel Poc and Renate Sommer on the objection under Article 106 to the list of invasive alien species. I regret that no expert has been consulted by the European Commission to draw up this list, which must be accompanied by scientific evidence. This objection therefore focuses primarily on the procedure that needs to be reviewed. The European Parliament therefore calls on the Commission to amend this list and also to add some dangerous species that are not there.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. I am voting in favour of the resolution. The rapporteur considers that the draft implementing regulation goes beyond the powers of the Commission and has accordingly called on the Commission to withdraw the draft. I am voting in favour of this report because of these considerations.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. I have chosen to vote in favour of the objection under Rule 106. The Commission did not guarantee that the methodology to be used in risk assessment would be applied in the same way in all Member States. Because of this, I believe that it is not possible to guarantee that Member States will use the same type of evidence and apply the same general rules. Finally, I would like to point out that several terrestrial plants and mammalian species have not been included in the list, although a thorough risk assessment has been carried out.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. This objection relates to a list submitted by the Commission concerning "invasive alien species" (American lobster, Pacific oyster, African black-tasked goby, etc.). It follows Regulation 1143/2014, voted by the European Parliament on 16 April 2014. The Commission had to submit a first list by 2 January 2016. Some pest species should really be included and are not there (assessments would not be completed) while others are there even before the assessment, potentially undermining the economic activities that exploit them. The Commission has therefore presented a list on a heterogeneous basis. This objection is raised by the socialist Pavel Poc, who was already rapporteur in the vote in 2014, and the elected National Front had supported his proposal at the time. We voted for it.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution because it has the merit of highlighting the shortcomings of the European list of 'invasive species', even if it has the merit of incorporating the Asian hornet.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I voted against the objection as I support the adoption of the list of invasive alien species as soon as possible to alleviate the devastating effects that this pest is having, since, moreover, opposition to an implementing act has no binding legal validity for the European Commission.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: in writing. In 2012 The Spanish Socialists have worked hard to get the list of invasive species, voted on 4 December in the Joint Committee on the Environment States-European Commission, to include the species Eichhornia crassipes, commonly referred to as "camalote". The proliferation of this plant is seriously endangering the habitats and biodiversity of the Guadiana Riverbed as it passed through Extremadura, and is already advancing towards Portugal. As set out in Regulation (EU) No 1143/2014 on the prevention and management of the introduction and spread of invasive alien species, the so-called 'list of invasive species' must be approved by means of an Implementing Regulation, as appropriated on 4 December.  The approved list includes the "camalote" and will enter into force within 20 days of its publication in the DOUE. I therefore voted against the rejection of that Implementing Regulation, because I consider it based on procedural and non-legally binding arguments and, in a very specific way, because my main objective in this area is the implementation, as quickly as possible, of measures to eliminate and combat the proliferation of this species and the early recovery of the Guadiana River ecosystem.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: Writing. \u2012 There are two primary variants of the expansion of the range of species: the first is natural, and the second is anthropogenic, hence human action. In some cases, the expansion of this range of species did not bring any specific problems, as other native species were not endangered, but in a number of situations the result was completely the opposite. One of the most significant negative examples is the rabbits in Australia and the enormous damage they have done to the local ecosystem over the last few centuries. Drawing up a list of invasive alien species and realising the relevant counter-actions at European Union level is an undeniable step, as there are many such species, such as the same round seagoing minutiae, whose natural range is in the Black, Azov, Marmara and Kaspian Seas, rather than in the Baltic Sea. The biggest problem is that the round seagoing mink eats clams that filter and purify the water. By reducing the amount of bivalve molluscs, it contributes to the flowering of algae and lack of oxygen in the affected waters. As a result, other fish species die in huge quantities, while others, such as cod and perch, are becoming increasingly dangerous for human consumption. Unfortunately, the European Commission failed to put forward a sufficiently high-quality draft regulation in this case. Once its text is edited and in line with the implementing powers for the Commission, it will certainly be adopted to increase the degree of legal standardisation in the fight against invasive alien species at community level. I therefore voted in favour of this motion for a resolution.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of this motion for a resolution because it is complete and documented.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. ‒ Unfortunately invasive alien species are numerous and it is therefore important to ensure that priority is given to addressing the subset of invasive alien species considered to be of Union concern. I do not believe the Commission proposal reaches this objective.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. Dominique Martin supported this objection. The European Commission has submitted a list of "invasive alien species," including American lobster, Pacific oyster or African black-band goby. However, this list is incomplete and arbitrary: some harmful species that should appear do not appear, while others are automatically there even though the assessments are not finished. Being on this list wrongly can undermine the economic activities that exploit them. The Commission seems to have, as often, used arbitrary and heterogeneous criteria to compile its list. That is why we support this objection.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. The rapporteur notes that some land plants and mammal species that meet the criteria and for which a robust risk assessment is available have not been included in the list. If that is the case, then the Commission must present a new report. I therefore agree with this report.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this objection as I am concerned that the seriousness of certain invasive alien species has not been taken into account when establishing this list.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. In April 2014, the European Parliament approved the principle of monitoring invasive alien species to eradicate them when necessary. The Commission has therefore established by acts of enforcement the list of species to be monitored. The resolution before us criticizes this list.
