Indeed, it would appear that "the reasons for the inclusion of a species in the draft EU list are guided by political rather than scientific criteria". This has the effect "that many of the most problematic invasive alien species are not on the list. Thus, widespread and rapidly spreading species of mammals and plant species with significant and well-documented negative consequences on human health are not on the list. Finally, the resolution denounces Parliament's lack of information on this subject since the documents have not been transmitted in a timely and appropriate manner. I'm voting for

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the commission's draft implementing regulation adopting a list of invasive alien species of concern in the Union. This is a topic to which I have always paid a lot of attention. It is extremely important to give priority to identifying all invasive alien species that cause damage in the EU. By combating invasive species we are simultaneously protecting the indigenous biodiversity of each Member State. The Commission's initial list ignores species that are among the most harmful invasive alien species in Europe.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this objection as the draft list does not present a comprehensive list of all problematic alien species or present a strategy for biodiversity for the EU that local authorities, stakeholders and the general public can support. I agreed with the objection that the Commission should redraw its regulation.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. Invasive alien species pose a threat to biodiversity as well as to fishing and agricultural activities. The EU establishes a list of these species in order to better control them by imposing restrictions on their import, sale and use. The establishment of such a list is an essential step in the European biodiversity strategy. Opposing the list, which is expected to be adopted by January 2016 at the latest, would delay the fight against these invasive species and the implementation of the European strategy. With my group, we did not support the objection to this list. The aim was not to block this first list, which will be regularly reviewed and may be completed in the future.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 Under Regulation (EU) No 1143/2014 of the European Parliament and of the Council on invasive alien species, it is for the Commission to adopt, by means of implementing acts, a list of invasive alien species of Union importance. The list in the draft Implementing Regulation D041932/01 adopted by the Commission has been repeatedly criticised by the competent national authorities, stakeholders and the general public. In its report, the Committee on the Environment states that these criticisms are legitimate in many respects: the list does not take into account species that are among the most harmful invasive alien species in Europe. Some terrestrial plant and mammalian species meet the criteria and a well-founded risk assessment is available, but they are not included in the list, as are some of the most rapidly growing alien species in Europe in recent years, as well as large and rapidly spreading plant species with significant and well-documented adverse effects on human health. On the other hand, the list includes species which do not have a significant adverse impact on biodiversity, ecosystem services, human health and the economy, or where the measures to be taken would result in disproportionate costs.  In the opinion of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, the draft Commission Implementing Regulation therefore goes beyond the implementing powers laid down in Regulation (EU) No 1143/2014 and therefore proposes that Parliament, in its resolution, ask the Commission to withdraw its draft implementing regulation and submit a new draft. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. \u2012 The Commission shall adopt a list of invasive alien species causing concern in the Union, under the criteria of Article 4(3) of Regulation (EU) No 1143/2014 of the EP and the Council. In view of the fact that the Commission did not specify the type of acceptable evidence and did not provide a detailed description of the application of Article 5(1)(a) to (h) of the Regulation, including the methodology to be applied in risk assessments, and did not ensure that the methodology and application of risk assessments equally by all Member States when they propose the inclusion of a species in the Union list.  I consider it important that the inclusion of species in the list is based on a risk assessment and a standardised methodology which is not based on the political will of the Member States. It should be noted that the Commission's initial list has been criticised by several national authorities and stakeholders, placing serious doubts as to the effectiveness of the IAS Regulation, mainly because many of the most problematic invasive alien species are not included in the list, while some species that are not likely to cause major harmful impacts on biodiversity, human health or the economy are included.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. This objection relates to a list submitted by the Commission concerning "invasive alien species" (American lobster, Pacific oyster, African black-tasked goby, etc.). It follows Regulation 1143/2014, voted by the European Parliament on 16 April 2014. The Commission had to submit a first list by 2 January 2016.  Some pest species should really be included and are not there (assessments would not be completed) while others are there even before the assessment, potentially undermining the economic activities that exploit them. The Commission has therefore presented a list on a heterogeneous basis.  This objection is entirely well founded, I voted for it.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, which opposes the Commission's decision on a list of 36 invasive alien species deemed to be of concern to the European Union. This list was proposed by the Commission under the new legislative framework to prevent the introduction of EEAs and manage their spread. This text criticises the procedure used by the Commission, including the lack of consultation with experts in the field. The list proposed by the Commission is criticised for not including a large number of problematic species when some species are being taken up that are not able to cause serious damage. It calls for a review of the Commission's decision and the addition of hazardous species to the list.

name: József NAGY
text: Writing. \u2012 It is indisputable that we need a list of invasive alien species of union concern, since the protection of the health of our citizens must be a priority. We must demand the drawing up of a list based not on political but scientific conditions, up-to-date and capable of minimising the damage to human health caused by invasive alien species. The EU list is directly applicable in all Member States and it is therefore important to comply with the abovementioned requirements. In Slovakia, for example, almost half a million people are allergic to ragweed pollen, yet serious efforts have been made to get the law that imposes the obligation to eradicate it.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this motion for a resolution that calls for a submission of a new draft concerning the list of invasive alien species of the Union.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 Not supported. The objection to the EU list of invasive alien species of concern is not justified as the current list has been drawn up on the basis of scientific studies.

name: Margot PARKER
text: in writing. ‒ We abstained because the objection, whilst criticising Commission behaviour, recognises and enshrines their power on a topic which should be a choice of Member States.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ Foreign invasive species are non-native species that do not naturally reside in a particular ecosystem, but have come into it through intentional or unintended introduction, and by their settlement or spread they adversely affect biodiversity, human health or cause economic damage in the area to which they are introduced.  With its implementing decision, the European Commission sought to amend the list of invasive alien species that may cause these harmful effects in the Union. However, in my opinion and in the opinion of most fellow Members, the way of drafting the census proposal was not implemented in a way that would guarantee that the same type of evidence is used in the Member States and that the same standards apply, as pointed out by well-known NGOs of citizens acting in the protection of the environment and nature, and I therefore supported this resolution objecting to the Commission's implementing decision. Unfortunately, some terrestrial plant species and mammals, although they meet the criteria for inclusion on this list and although risk assessments are available indicating their danger, are not included in that list. I therefore call on the Commission to submit a new proposal that will include in the list of alien invasive species the very species considered to be the most endangered invasive alien species in Europe.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. This objection relates to a list submitted by the Commission concerning "invasive alien species" (American lobster, Pacific oyster, African black-tasked goby, etc.). It follows Regulation (EU) 1143/2014, voted by the European Parliament on 16 April 2014. The Commission had to submit a first list by 2 January 2016. Some pest species should really be included and are not there (assessments would not be completed) while others are there even before the assessment, potentially undermining the economic activities that exploit them. The Commission has therefore presented a list on a heterogeneous basis. This objection is well founded, I vote for it.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒ A new draft Commission implementing regulation adopting a list of invasive alien species is needed, as the existing solution is inadequate, flawed and subject to severe criticism from the public and the profession. Implementation should be guaranteed to prioritise the most problematic invasive alien species and align the list with relevant agreements with the World Trade Organisation. Furthermore, it is necessary to take into account the latest scientific knowledge and to include potentially problematic species of these fastest-spreading mammal species, which have not been included in the list until now, which is why I support this objection.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. - I support the motion for a resolution submitted in accordance with Article 106(2) and 3. Rules of procedure on the Commission's draft implementing regulation adopting a list of invasive alien species of Union importance under Regulation (EU) No 2013/2013. 1143/2014 of the European Parliament and the Council (D041932/01 - 2015/3010(RSP)) of colleague Rebecca Sommer and colleague Pavel Poc in front of the Committee on Environment, Public Health and Food Safety. Globally, invasive species in an area, along with the direct destruction of habitats, are considered to pose the greatest danger to its biodiversity. Large migrations of people, trade and transport have always been accompanied by the spread of species beyond the realm of their distribution. The fact is that invasive alien species are numerous, so it is extremely important to ensure an advantage to addressing the problems associated with that subset of invasive alien species considered to be of union importance.  As the Commission has failed to ensure that the methodology to be applied when carrying out risk assessments is carried out in the same way in all Member States and cannot be ensured that the same type of evidence is used in the Member States and the same standards are applied, I agree with the report requesting the Commission to withdraw their draft implementing regulation and submit a new draft to the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety Committee.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 The appearance of exotic species, be they animals, plants, fungi or microorganisms, in new places is not always a cause for concern. However, these species, if they reach a considerable number, can become invasive and we must prevent the serious negative effects that this can have not only on biodiversity but also on society and the economy. That is why it has been decided to create a list of invasive alien species of European importance which will be mandatory in all its elements and directly applicable in each of the Member States. During the preparation of the list, the Commission did not deal comprehensively with all the scientific aspects, leaving aside very important aspects. That is why I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution calling on the Commission to withdraw the draft implementing regulation and to submit a new draft to the committee responsible.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. I voted for the resolution on the list of invasive alien species. My aim is not to reject outright the European Commission's proposal which is good. On the contrary, to ask the Commission to better list invasive alien species. Many of the most problematic species are not included in the draft list, while at the same time some species are included in the 36 species that are not able to have serious negative consequences. I want the most comprehensive list, even if an update was planned. I therefore voted for the Commission to make a better list that is possible quickly and supported by all thanks to its effectiveness. It is therefore a political signal from the European Parliament to the Commission.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ We abstained because the objection, whilst criticising Commission behaviour, recognises and enshrines their power on a topic which should be a choice of Member States.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. I have voted in favour of this motion for a resolution to object to the Commission's draft implementing regulation, which adopts a list of invasive alien species of concern in the Union, as I believe that this Regulation exceeds the implementing powers laid down in Regulation (EU) No 1143/2014, as stated in paragraph 1 of the report. The Commission is therefore asked to submit a new draft, in line with the regulatory provisions and to include in one document the identification of the group of invasive alien species which raise legitimate concerns in many Member States of the European Union. In this way, we will be able to take specific uniform measures to minimise the adverse effects that these species may have on the preservation of European biodiversity and related ecosystem systems, as well as on the economy and human health.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. I supported this text which opposes the Commission's decision on a proposal for a list of 36 invasive alien species (EEA) of concern to the European Union. This list was proposed by the Commission under the new legislative framework to prevent the introduction of EEAs and manage their spread. Indeed, the procedure followed by the Commission is problematic and no group of experts has been consulted; as a result, it appears that in the end, many of the most problematic species are not included in the draft list, while at the same time some species are being taken up that are not able to cause serious negative consequences. The text aims to ensure the safety of citizens by therefore calling on the Commission to review its decision and to add dangerous species to the list.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. – We voted IN FAVOUR considering that some invasive species have not been included in the list submitted by the Commission even though they should have been and that some of those included do not cause a significant negative impact on biodiversity/ecosystem.

name: Daciana Octavia SÂRBU
text: in writing. ‒ Alien invasive species are not new, but they are expected to increase in number and severity because of the trends in global trade and climate change. We do need legislation to help minimize negative environmental impacts, and this includes an authoritative list of species which could pose a threat. I cannot see why the Commission has chosen to adopt the list of species before adopting the criteria by which that list is created. This is completely illogical. And not surprisingly, the absence of agreed criteria has resulted in a list which is highly disputed. I expect the Commission to come forward with the necessary criteria and a revised list. This will help Member States implement the legislation and protect against the damaging environmental effects of alien invasive species.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this objection because I agree with the reasons and arguments given to exercise it. For example, the list of 36 invasive species presented is inconsistent with the provisions of the Invasive Alien Species Regulation, as major harmful or rapidly expanding mammals and plants are not included. In addition, the procedures were not respected, as the European Parliament should have been informed of the elements and methodology of risk analysis, and the species on the list appear to have followed an economic or political criterion. It is therefore important that the criteria in this list be reviewed and the list reworked.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this vote as I believe this will have unnecessary consequences. If I voted in favour or against this proposal it could lead to more EU legislation.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution because I agree that the Commission implementing regulation adopting a list of invasive species needs to be reconsidered. Many of the most problematic invasive alien species are not listed, while some species are incapable of causing a significant negative impact on biodiversity, the ecosystem, human health or the economy. For example, as one constituent has pointed out to me, the water hyacinth would not be able to survive in the climate of the West Midlands and as such I would need further convincing as to why it may be included in the invasive species list. Hence, I join this call on the Commission to withdraw this draft implementing regulation and consult again stakeholders and the general public.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 The Commission has come up with a proposal for an implementing regulation which should adopt a list of invasive alien species of Union concern. This concerns plant species and mammals that were not originally present in Europe and now pose a risk due to their adverse impact on biodiversity, ecosystem services, but also on human health and the economy.  Since the list presented by the Commission is motivated mainly by the political will of the Member States and does not take into account scientific criteria, I agree with Parliament's resolution calling for this proposal to be withdrawn. Moreover, the EP has not been sufficiently informed on how the risks will be considered. According to the information available, many of the most problematic invasive non-originating species are not included in the list and, conversely, there are species on the list that have a demonstrably negative impact on biodiversity or human health. For these reasons, the Commission should withdraw its proposal and, after a thorough examination, present its new, recast form.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. ‒ I supported the proposal for a resolution on the Commission's draft implementing decision on the adoption of a list of invasive alien species of Union importance in accordance with Regulation (EU) No 2013/2013; 1143/2014 of the European Parliament and the Council, and in line with the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal as I agree with the objection regarding the inadequacy of the list presented.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the draft Commission implementing regulation adopting a list of invasive alien species of Union concern. I believe that we need greater transparency as regards the choice of species that should be included in the list proposed by the European Commission. Their inclusion is not based on a standardised risk assessment and methodology, but on the political will of the Member States. This action will also ensure better human health and the environment.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The Commission is once again going beyond its limits, jeopardising the balance of European ecosystems.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 In its motion for a resolution, the European Parliament objected to the list of invasive alien species of union importance, and I voted in favour of this objection. This EU list is fully binding and directly applicable in all Member States, so I think it is of the utmost importance that it is properly designed. The motion invites the Commission to withdraw the draft implementing regulation and to submit a new draft, as the draft exceeds the implementing powers laid down in the related Regulation. The process does not ensure that the methodology to be used in the risk assessment is applied uniformly by all Member States, thus ensuring that Member States apply the same type of evidence and the same general standards. For example, the reasons for listing species in the EU may be based on political rather than scientific conditions.  As we know, there are many invasive alien species in Europe, so I agree that priority should be given to regulating invasive alien species that are considered dangerous for the Union. The motion states that an invasive species is considered to be dangerous to the Union if the significance of the damage caused by it in the Member States concerned justifies the adoption of targeted measures applicable throughout the Union, including those which are not yet affected, even if they are unlikely to be affected.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The European Commission has adopted by means of an implementing act a list of invasive alien species posing a threat to the Union. This list will be binding in its entirety and directly applicable in all Member States, so it is so important that both the development process and the list itself are considered, comprehensive and include those species that actually pose a danger to the ecosystem and the people of Europe. It is also important that dangerous species are placed on the list after a sound risk assessment, and not arbitrarily or sometimes even accidentally.  Unfortunately, the European Commission has not fully complied with all of the above-mentioned guidelines. I therefore supported the EP's position that the European Commission has exceeded its implementing powers and should withdraw its proposal and submit a new draft implementing regulation.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. I again voted positively on the motion for a resolution on the Commission's draft implementation regulation adopting a list of invasive alien species of concern to the Union, in line with Regulation (EU) 1143/2014 of the European Parliament and the Council, which was adopted in the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this resolution which calls on the Commission to withdraw its draft implementing regulation on adopting a list of invasive alien species of Union concern pursuant to Regulation (EU) No 1143/2014 (‘the IAS Regulation’).

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I supported the objection to the list of invasive alien species relevant to the European Union, and I believe that the rapporteurs correctly recognised the discrepancy of the original list with the provisions of the resolution, which aims to prevent and manage the introduction and spread of these species.  Indeed, these species whose settlement or spread threatens biodiversity, human health or causes economic damage cost the European Union around €12 billion a year. Although the Commission has proposed a list of species against which measures should be taken set out in that resolution, no standardised procedure has been used and the proposed list does not contain all problematic invasive species having a significant negative impact on biodiversity and ecosystem services, while other species against which action would result in cost disproportion are included in that list.   In my view, it is of utmost importance that the Commission drafts a new draft before the census is adopted, so that Member States can take steps to monitor, eradicate and manage invasive alien species when they appear on their territory in accordance with the resolution, with a view to protecting indigenous biodiversity.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. \ I supported the motion for a resolution – on the objection – in accordance with Rule 106 of the Rules of Procedure on the list of invasive alien species, because I believe that measures must be taken in all Member States to prevent damage caused by invasive alien species. These measures could also reduce their adverse environmental impacts, as invasive alien species cause major changes in the ecosystem.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. – We voted IN FAVOUR considering that some invasive species have not been included in the list submitted by the Commission even though they should have been and that some of those included do not cause a significant negative impact on biodiversity/ecosystem.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. ‒ The problem of invasive alien species is serious and must be tackled firmly from the European institutions, this is not an internal problem of a Member State.  It seems that the initial list of the Commission has been criticised by various national authorities because it ignores invasive alien species that are among the most harmful of Europe, and plant species spread widely and rapidly expanding with adverse effects.  I support this motion so that this proposed Regulation will be withdrawn and I encourage the Commission to submit a new one.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. This objection relates to a list submitted by the Commission concerning "invasive alien species" (American lobster, Pacific oyster, black-tasking goby).  Some pest species should really be included and are not there (assessments would not be completed) while others are automatically there even before the assessment, potentially harming certain economic sectors.  Unfortunately, the non-binding nature of this objection will not prevent the implementation of the list, which nevertheless has the merit of integrating the Asian hornet. I voted for it.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. \u2012 It is for the Commission to adopt, by means of implementing acts, a list of invasive alien species of Union importance. As there are many invasive alien species, priority should be given to regulating invasive alien species which are considered to be dangerous to the Union. I voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. – We voted IN FAVOUR considering that some invasive species have not been included in the list submitted by the Commission even though they should have been and that some of those included do not cause a significant negative impact on biodiversity/ecosystem.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this objection because I believe this topic should be addressed with more caution and there is a need to ensure that the identification of invasive alien species of EU concern remains proportionate and focuses on species whose inclusion on the Union list would effectively prevent, minimise or mitigate the adverse impact of those species in a cost effective manner. I also wanted to stress out that Commission failed to ensure that the methodology to be applied in the risk assessments is carried out in the same way by all Member States when proposing the inclusion of a species on the Union list, and whereas it cannot be ensured that Member States use the same type of evidence and apply the same overall standards , we called on the Commission to withdraw its draft implementing regulation and to submit a new draft to the committee.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. U2012 Taking into account that Parliament has not been adequately informed of the establishment of common elements for the development of risk analyses, that the Commission did not respect the provisions of Article 4(3) of the Invasive Alien Species Regulation and that the draft Union list and the Commission's initial list have been criticised by a number of competent national authorities , stakeholders and the general public by ignoring invasive alien species that are among the most harmful in Europe, the decision calls on the Commission to withdraw its draft Implementing Regulation and submit a new draft. We are talking about a serious and sensitive issue that affects many sectors. It is therefore necessary to submit a proposal that gives greater guarantees. That is why I consider it necessary to vote in favour of such an objection

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. 'I voted against the objection because I do not think that the European Commission should be blocked in this dossier. The relevant list is based on scientific research. However, this list must be revised and supplemented at regular intervals in the coming years.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. \u2012 According to Regulation (EU) No 1143/2014 on the prevention and management of the introduction and dissemination of invasive species, the European Commission has until January 2016 to submit a list of these species based on criteria defined in the Regulation. Although it is a very complete legislative document, there is a lack of an important element, namely which species should be targeted and controlled, and therefore Articles 3 and 4 define detailed criteria for the construction of that list.  The list submitted by the Commission consists of 36 species, which, according to the rapporteur of the objection, is incompatible with the provisions of the Regulation, as the most harmful species or the fastest dissemination of plants and animals have not been included. Moreover, the procedures for making this list have not been respected, in particular the European Parliament has not been informed about the elements and methodologies of the impact studies, and the decision on the species included in the list appears to be political or economic and not on a scientific basis.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. The rapporteur notes that some land plants and mammal species that meet the criteria and for which a robust risk assessment is available have not been included in the list. If that is the case, then the Commission must present a new report. I therefore agree with this report.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the commission's draft implementing regulation adopting a list of invasive alien species of concern in the Union in accordance with Regulation (EU) No 1143/2014 of the European Parliament and the Council (D0419 32/01 – 2015/3010(RSP)), primarily because it agrees that the draft list proposed by the EC does not comprehensively treat the problem of invasive alien species, nor does it take care to protect indigenous biodiversity and ecosystem services, minimize and mitigate the impacts these species can have on human health or the economy. It also weighed on my decision to vote that the text calls for the withdrawal of this draft implementing regulation and the presentation of a new one. The Commission's new project should include, among others, the water hyacinth, an invasive species that is creating serious threats to the Alqueva river basin.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. \u2012 According to the Regulation of Invasive Alien Species, on the prevention and management of the introduction and dissemination of invasive species, the European Commission must submit by January 2016 a list of these species. The Regulation defines the detailed criteria for the construction of this list. The decision on the species included in the list seems to take into account criteria of a political or economic nature, without scientific basis, and a set of pressures made by some Member States has weighed on their final configuration. Some of these pressures are known. For Portugal, the importance of inclusion in the waterhyine list should be stressed, although Member States with a commercial interest in this species have opposed it. Given that the next revision of this list is planned for six years from now, the shortcomings of this proposal must be corrected at the outset, which is why we voted in favour of the objection.

name: Daniel DALTON
text: – Madam President, I strongly oppose this objection which ignores scientific facts and evidence and seeks to prevent not only this authorisation, but all GM food and feed product authorisations, including those that have already passed safety assessments. This is madness. It will only penalise our farmers who rely on GM feed.  In this case, EFSA said that GM maize NK 603 was safe. Now, we should be led by the science on this, not by dogma. If a product is deemed safe by EFSA, there is no justification to deny it being placed on the market. What is the point of EFSA if we ignore their advice and base our opinion on personal dogma? The rest of the world is embracing GM. It has huge potential; it can be more environmentally friendly than conventional farming; it offers hope in drought-hit regions, and it is safe. Europe is being left behind with its medieval attitude to this new technology. We should embrace it, not reject it.

name: Peter JAHR
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I would like to call on all the Members who say that the risk assessment is not yet comprehensive and not yet certain that we should once again agree together to allow research on genetic engineering again in the European Union, which will once again enable a proper risk assessment. I very much regret the tendency that, by strictly 'no' to genetic engineering, we are of course also displacing research from the European Union. It would be necessary for us to continue here in the spirit of basic research, because the alternative is for other regions in this world to take over the research, so that the other regions in the world then also take over the risk assessment. I would very much like to take part in this dispute. I repeat myself: this also requires research in the European Union on this issue.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – European legislation on genetically modified products is currently, unfortunately, rather ineffective. This concerns, first of all, the exercise of controls at Community level. For example, as can be understood from now well-known facts, genetically modified maize has been allowed to be imported into the Union territory in recent years, in the case of which the full necessary testing was not carried out. Colleagues! It is quite understandable that there is already a huge list of different products in the world that have been modified , either through breeding procedures or genetically. It is therefore also understandable that many of them affect our citizens in one way or another. In any case, the most important consideration that we must take into account is the health of Europeans and the absence of any possible threat. Support!

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Madam President, in my opinion, this issue is very technical and was an objection under Rule 106 of the Rules of Procedure. It is a fact that on March 20 this year, the international agency in charge of cancer research identified just one part of the substance as harmful to health, even causing cancer. On the other hand, there are other studies and, in my opinion, such strictly scientific material should not be subject to purely political scrutiny. I expected the proposed resolution to be more accommodating on this issue. For this reason, I could not support it, although, of course, I do not support GM food, but this does not even concern the issue of basic research, as my colleague Jahr has said here. For this reason, I did not support this motion for a resolution.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: in writing. I voted against this Resolution because the European Commission, when it adopted Implementing Decision (EU) 2015/2279 on 4 December, acted in accordance with law, that is to say, as laid down in Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003 on genetically modified food and feed. As long as new legislation is not adopted that derogues and improves the current authorisation and marketing procedure, the Commission must and must authorise all those that comply with our current European standard. It should be recalled that, on 28 October 2015, the European Parliament rejected the Commission's legislative proposal because, inter alia, it was a direct attack on the proper functioning of the internal market. While it arrives and is being processed, we will have to refer to Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003.

name: Tim AKER
text: in writing. – We abstained because the objection, whilst criticising Commission behaviour, recognises and enshrines their power on a topic which should be a choice of Member States.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this objection urging the European Commission to repeal its Implementing Decision (EU) 2015/2279 by which it authorized the marketing of products that NK603 × T25 (MON-6-3-6 × ACS-ZM-3-2), contain or have been produced from it. The current procedure for the authorisation of genetically modified food and feed is not working well and, as long as it is not improved, any authorisation of such products should be suspended. In addition, the Commission had an obligation to submit a draft to Parliament to know its opinion before approving the marketing of this type of maize, but, despite having the opposite position of Parliament's Committee on the Environment since 1 December, it did not expect to hear Parliament's opinion. Not only am I in favour of this objection, but I also support any future objections to the authorisation of GMOs, and the Commission must make a legislative proposal that respects the right of Member States not to authorise GMOs for human and animal feed in their territory.

name: Louis ALIOT
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the objection to the marketing authorization of products containing or based on genetically modified maize.  The report looks back at EFSA's (European Food Safety Authority) assessments, which were found to be unsatisfactory, and the fact that European Commission President Jean-Claude Junker had promised that there would be "no new GMOs without consensus". Moreover, the GMO in question is a threat to public health as well as to the food sovereignty of the European peoples and the countries that could cultivate them. Deeply opposed to the marketing of Monsanto's GMO, I therefore support this objection. However, I regret that the first objection identical to this one filed by Sylvie Goddyn (ENL MP) was rejected, as the other Members refused to make a joint objection with the ENL group.

name: Lynn BOYLAN
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this resolution to reject the authorisation of GMO maize NK 603 x T25. President Juncker’s pre-election promise to democratise the EU GMO authorisation procedure has been fudged and the Commission itself acknowledges the irregularity of the current system in its preamble to the proposal on GM food and feed. It is therefore unacceptable that the Commission has chosen to continue to authorise GM products in a system it has admitted itself is flawed. The authorisation is also controversial as the given GMO is engineered to be glyphosate intolerant. The use of this chemical as a herbicide has been found to be ‘probably carcinogenic’ by the WHO who used only published peer-reviewed studies to evaluate the toxicity of the chemical. On the other hand, EFSA, who found that it was ‘unlikely’ to cause cancer, expanded their studies to include non-peer-reviewed industry studies and did not examine, as the WHO did, the combination effects of the formulated products. I am therefore very pleased that this objection passed and sent a strong signal to the Commission.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: Writing. By its implementing decision of 4 December 2015, the European Commission wanted to authorise the placing on the market of genetically modified and glyphosate-tolerant maize NK603xT25. In view of the fact that, according to the World Health Organisation, the weedkiller glyphosate is 'probably carcinogenic to humans', I welcome this motion for a resolution calling for the measure to be repealed. In addition to my critical attitude towards herbicides and GMOs that are harmful to humans and the environment, I also regret that the Commission has ignored the rejection of the act adopted in the ENVI Committee. Although the decision was taken in accordance with the current legal situation, the GMO authorisation procedure requires urgent reform.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. This objection to the marketing authorization of products containing or base of genetically modified maize NK603xT25 is supported by a Greens/S-D/EFDD/GUE coalition. My colleague from the National Front, Sylvie Goddyn, had made the same objection but had not been accepted, although it is customary in these cases to make a common objection. The rationale for this objection is twofold: on the one hand EFSA's assessments are unsatisfactory and, on the other hand, Commission President Juncker promised "no new GMOs without consensus". In essence, tolerant to glyphosate and its derivatives, the GMO in question is a threat to the public health and food sovereignty of Europeans. Being hostile to Monsanto's GMOs, I supported this objection.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ Whilst this resolution criticises the Commission’s behaviour, it also enshrines EU competence.  I opposed certain amendments relating to glyphosate.  It has been brought to my attention that, whilst glyphosate is indeed used with relation to GM crops, it is also used for non-GM crops without causing any problems. I understand the anti-GM case, and to an extent I have some sympathy with it, but these amendments do not relate to GM.  Furthermore, some of the language used (like the word ‘enslaving’), is inappropriate and distasteful.

name: Guillaume BALAS
text: In writing. I and three other MPs from 3 different political groups objected to the introduction of Monsanto NK603 X T25 GM maize. It is not only a question of refusing this GMO resistant to Roundup, as we now do for every GMO because they also increase the dependence of our farmers on the firms that submit them by crossing their seeds. But it is also a question of defending the prerogatives of the European Parliament in the face of a European Commission which continues to decide on its own, without hearing the majorities expressed in our House. There is an obvious denial of democracy in the process of authorizing GMOs.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to repeal the On 17 May 2010 Monsanto Europe S.A. submitted an application for the placing on the market of products containing genetically modified maize NK60 ×3xT25. According to the request, genetically modified maize contains substances having a carcinogenic effect on humans. I support the request for the Commission to withdraw on 4 December 2015. Commission Implementing Decision (EU) 2015/2279 authorising the placing on the market of products containing genetically modified maize.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. The objection is brought by a Green/S-D/EFDD/GUE coalition. An identical objection was presented by Sylvie Goddyn. Contrary to the practices that have previously presided over (and which are the recommendations of the committee secretariat), the other MEPs refused to make a common objection with the ENL group. Both objections were therefore presented in committee, only the "adverse" objection was accepted. Considering that EFSA's assessments are unsatisfactory and especially that President Juncker promised "no new GMOs without consensus", the elected representatives of the ENVI Committee chose to table this objection, although it cannot be binding on the Commission. Tolerant of glyphosate and its derivatives, the GMO in question is a threat to the public health and food sovereignty of Europeans and the countries that will cultivate them. The basis for the objection to the plenary vote is essentially political, regretting that Juncker is not keeping his promises. That is why my group has tabled three plenary amendments recalling the danger posed by glyphosate and the adoption of GMOs, the multiple flaws in EFSA's opinion, but also the risk to the sovereignty of peoples and farmers.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. I approved this resolution which rejects the Commission's decision to authorise the marketing of a type of genetically modified maize and recalls that the European Parliament rejected the legislative proposal of 22 April 2015 amending Regulation 1829/2003 because, if their cultivation necessarily takes place on the territory of a Member State, the trade in GMOs ignores borders, which means that a national right of "refusal" of use and sale, as proposed by the Commission, would have been impossible to exercise without reintroducing border controls on imports. The resolution therefore calls on the Commission to establish a new legislative initiative on the authorisation of GMOs.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. – We voted A FAVOR considering that NK603 x T25 maize tolerates different types of herbicides, including glyphosate, and the latter was classified as a possible carcinogen for humans by the International Agency for Research on Cancer on 15 March this year. We claim that the draft act implemented is not compatible with Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003 on GMO food and feed, nor with Regulation (EC) No 396/2005 on pesticide residues in food and feed, since it does not ensure a high level of protection for human life and health, animal welfare, environmental and consumer interests in relation to genetically modified food and feed.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report which considers that the Commission Implementation Decision on genetically modified diseases exceeds the implementing powers provided for in Regulation 1829/2005. Any implementing decision authorising the marketing of products consisting of genetically modified maize, contained or produced from it under Regulation 1829/2003 in its current version of malfunction should be suspended until the adoption of the new Regulation on the basis of the EU Operating Treaty.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. This report relates to an objection (similar to that submitted by ENL) to signal opposition to maize NK603xT25. Indeed, EFSA's assessments are unsatisfactory and above all that President Juncker promised "no new GMOs without consensus". The GMO in question is a threat to the public health and food sovereignty of Europeans and the countries that will cultivate them and it remains clear that we must show our hostility to Monsanto's GMOs. Three amendments have been tabled by our group and I have decided to vote for this report even though it is not binding on the Commission.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I support with my vote this resolution in favour of rejecting the authorisation of genetically modified maize NK603xT25, owned by Monsanto. I am opposed to the use of GMOs in our crops, I am convinced that we must continue to protect the market and citizens from the invasion of these modified varieties produced by multinationals and continue to support the genuineness of our local production.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the objection to this implementing act by which the European Commission authorises Monsanto to introduce the NK603xT25 genetically modified maize variety in the Netherlands. With this objection, we call on the Commission to refrain from authorising the importation of any GMOs until a new regulation is introduced, as requested by this Parliament.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted for this resolution because it decided by Parliament not to approve the draft Commission implementing decision authorising the placing on the market of products containing genetically modified maize NK603 × T25 and requested the submission to Parliament of a new draft decision. On 17 May 2010, Monsanto Europe S.A. submitted to the competent authority of the Netherlands an application for placing on the market of foods, food ingredients and feed containing, consisting of, or produced from NK603 maize × T25 in accordance with Articles 5 and 17 of Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003. The request states that genetically modified maize contains such proteins as ammonium glufosinate and the International Agency for Research on Cancer, the World Health Organisation's specialised agency on cancer, classified glyphosate as probably carcinogenic to humans on 20 March 2015.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: Writing. On the issue of GMOs, the profession also does not have a single opinion, so it is expected that Members and the rest of the public are not united on these issues.  I myself am in a supporter of the precautionary principle in GMOs, so I find it completely unnecessary that the procedure on such a sensitive issue as the registration of genetically modified maize should be carried out with such a ihto. Blaming institutions and postponing responsibility from one to the other is also counterproductive. We are at a sensitive moment when the institutions should have more mutual respect, and above all we must respect the will of the people who are majority against the use of GMOs in Europe. I, too, often ask myself whether we really need genetically modified maize seeds that will be resistant to glyphosate and glyphosate.  I understand that we are not able to produce enough soy in the EU for various reasons and that we need to import soy from countries where they mostly use GMOs. But I can't understand why we need genetically modified corn seed. I firmly believe that we can grow enough corn without such a seed. I therefore supported the proposed objection of a peaceful conscience.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. ‒I voted for this complaint because I believe that the current GMO food authorisation system in the EU needs to be changed. At issue is a political message to the Commission, which gave sales and import authorisation under the GMO food directive, which Parliament considers undemocratic.  Monsanto applied for authorisation in 2010 and Member States were unable to agree on granting or refusing a licence for five years. In such a situation, the Commission has the right under the existing rules to act as it deems necessary. While the decision is legal, it is not democratic. The problem the European Union has with GMO will not be solved on its own nor is the status quo sustainable. It should be accepted that most Member States are against GMO, but some countries want it.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. This non-binding objection is intended to signal Parliament's disagreement with the European Commission over the marketing authorization of products containing genetically modified maize. Jean-Claude Juncker, however, had made it clear that there would be no introduction of a new GMO without prior consensus. It turns out that once again the Commission is freeing itself from any democratic process to meet the expectations of American multinationals, in this case Monsanto.  In view of the assessments of the European Food Safety Authority, the GMO in question poses a real threat to public health but is above all a danger to our farmers and to the food sovereignty of Europeans. Nevertheless, we deeply regret the sectarianism of the other parliamentary groups which did not wish to reach a common objection with the ENL group. As a reminder, Sylvie Goddyn had also objected to the marketing of this GMO. So I voted for that objection.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 I abstained in the vote on the resolution referring to 'Objection in accordance with Rule 106 of the Rules of Procedure: authorisation of genetically modified maize NK603xT25', because, at Commission level, there had to be serious concerns about the questions relating to the use of glyphphosphate, which is likely to promote the development of cancer, in maize cultivation.  As can be seen, maize as such, genetically modified, is not classified as dangerous to health, but the substances with which it is treated. The Commission must find mechanisms to ensure that human health is not affected by chemicals used in various agricultural crops, regardless of whether we are talking about genetically modified crops or organic crops. The Commission must ensure that all food or feed containing genetically modified organisms is properly labelled so that the consumer can make an informed decision as to whether or not to consume a genetically modified product.  It is inadmissible to reject the de facto cultivation of genetically modified cereals as long as the countries of the European Union import such products massively from other countries such as Argentina. This creates inequities between farmers in the European Union and those in other countries.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 Vote in favour of the objection against the authorisation of this Monsanto GMO mast. We are opposed in principle to any new authorisation of GMOs, all the more so in the current legal context. In fact, the Commission is using the pretext of approving the possibility for Member States to ban the cultivation of a GMO on their territory - which is entirely theoretical, as we saw at the time, by voting against the measure - to unblock authorisations for new GMOs, despite the fact that the committee responsible still has the usual impasse in the cross-vetoes of the Member States for and against GMOs.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the motion for a resolution on the Commission's Implementing Decision (EU) 2015/2279, of 4 December 2015 authorising the placing on the market of products containing, consisting of or obtained from genetically modified maize NK603 × T25 (MON-ØØ6Ø3-6 × ACS-ZMØØ3-2) in accordance with Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003 of the European Parliament and of the Council. In this resolution, the European Parliament has opposed the placing on the market of these products. The maize we are talking about expresses the CP4 EPSPS protein, which gives tolerance to the herbicide glyphosate, included by the World Health Organization specialized in the oncology field in the list of probable carcinogens for humans. Furthermore, with this vote, Parliament has stressed that any implementing decision authorising the placing on the market of products containing, consisting of or obtained from genetically modified organisms under Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003 in its current non-functioning form should be suspended until the Commission has presented a new legislative proposal that takes account of the concerns repeatedly expressed at national level and by this Parliament. For all these reasons, I have chosen to vote in favour of the resolution.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. – I abstained because the objection, whilst criticising Commission behaviour, recognises and enshrines their power on a topic which should be a choice of Member States.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the parliamentary motion objecting to the authorisation of genetically modified maize as I am concerned that it contains stacked (multiple) genes, on which there is still no agreement amongst experts on possible synergistic effects even if the individual genes have already been authorised separately.

name: Jean-Marie CAVADA
text: In writing. I welcome the adoption of the resolution on the objection to the authorisation of genetically modified maize NK603xT25. The text seeks to seek the withdrawal of the authorisation of a GMO maize developed by the multinational Monsanto, and tolerant to a glyphosate herbicide classified as a "probable carcinogen" by WHO.  Despite who's alarming findings, the Commission decided to allow maize NK603xT25 and MON87427 for food and feed, based on a favourable opinion from the European Food Safety Authority. Such a discrepancy in analysis, on a subject as crucial as the health of European citizens, at a time when WHO studies are renowned for their integrity and scientific solidity, suggests that it is necessary to review European GMO assessment procedures. The current framework seems to me to be far too lax and unfit to guarantee the non-danger to human health of GMOs circulating in the Union.  Following the adoption of this resolution, I expect the Commission to submit a credible proposal to set a new European framework for the authorisation of GMOs.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 We disagree and vote against the report which states that any implementing decision approving the placing on the market of products containing, consisting of or produced from genetically modified organisms in accordance with Regulation (EC) No 1782/2003 should be amended accordingly. In its current non-operational form, it should be suspended pending the adoption of a new Regulation on the basis of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The objection under Article 106 to the authorisation of genetically modified maize NK603xT25 is a positive effort as it forms part of initiatives opposing the use of genetically modified organisms. As I have already expressed my opposition to any use of this type of organisation, I have decided to vote in favour of this motion for a resolution.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. – In my view the adoption of GMO cultivation is irreversible and leads to the enslavement of farmers to multinational companies; the import of GMOs is indirectly responsible for this enslavement, which does not meet with the approval of European citizens.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this objection urging the European Commission to repeal its Implementing Decision (EU) 2015/2279 by which it authorized the marketing of products that NK603 × T25 (MON-6-3-6 × ACS-ZM-3-2), contain or have been produced from it. The current procedure for the authorisation of genetically modified food and feed is not working well and, as long as it is not improved, any authorisation of such products should be suspended. In addition, the Commission had an obligation to submit a draft to Parliament to know its opinion before approving the marketing of this type of maize, but, despite having the opposite position of Parliament's Committee on the Environment since 1 December, it did not expect to hear Parliament's opinion. Not only am I in favour of this objection, but I also support any future objections to the authorisation of GMOs, and the Commission must make a legislative proposal that respects the right of Member States not to authorise GMOs for human and animal feed in their territory.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution. I agree with objecting to the draft Commission Implementing Decisions which authorises the placing on the market of genetically modified maize since it contains stacked genes. In the case of stacked (multiple) genes there is still a debate going on, on possible synergistic effects even if the individual genes have already been authorised singly. For these reasons, I could not support the draft Commission Implementing Decision.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This resolution proposes to oppose the European Commission's decision on the authorisation of genetically modified maize NK 603 x T25. First of all, this authorisation decision derives directly from the mandate granted by the European Parliament and the Council to the Commission in the context of a legislative text on labelling and traceability requirements passed in 2003 (Regulation (EC) No. 1829/2003). This proposal of objection, mainly motivated by ideological considerations, however, is based on strong, criticallyable arguments. First, the European Commission has complied with the procedure in place for authorising GMOs. In addition, the European Food Safety Authority (EEA) conducted a study and concluded that the plant in question did not pose a risk to human health or the environment. I would add that the authorisation to market GMOs is ultimately within the competence of the Member States and that France has not opposed it. For these reasons, I voted against the objection.

name: Angélique DELAHAYE
text: In writing. I voted against this objection filed by the groups S and D, Greens, GUE and EFDD and supported by the ENF. They base their objection on the fact that the European Commission has exceeded its powers by authorising the marketing of products containing genetically modified maize. On the contrary, the Commission has complied with the procedure in place for authorising GMOs, including an analysis by the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) on the safety of the plant for human and animal health, and for the environment before issuing a proposal for authorisation. Whether or not to market is the responsibility of the Member States who have spoken in the Council (France abstained). I also deplore the commission's lack of respect for the European Parliament, which published the marketing act before the vote on the objection in plenary.

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: Written. 'This resolution not only protests against the authorisation of a specific GMO on the European market, but also calls for the introduction of a de facto moratorium on the approval of all GMOs until a new approval procedure is adopted.  The N-VA cannot support this resolution for the following reasons: The European approval procedure for GMOs is particularly strict and rigorous. A robust and independent risk assessment by the European Food Safety Agency EFSA plays a crucial role in this. The N-VA strongly believes in scientifically based and "evidence-based" policies. Adopting the text before is at odds with this and would undermine EFSA's credibility.  Moreover, the European Commission has not exceeded its mandate in this executive action. The legislation is clear: if Member States do not achieve a qualified majority (neither for nor against the approval of a GMO), the European Commission is authorised to approve GMOs on the basis of a positive opinion from EFSA.  With regard to glyphosate, it is noted that there is no scientific consensus. The discussion on this controversial substance must be further and fundamentally pursued.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report because I am opposed to the European Commission's decision to allow the importation of GMO maize NK603 x T25 into Europe. This GMO, developed by the multinational Monsanto and intended for livestock, is tolerant to the pesticide Round-up, another Monsanto product whose active ingredient, glyphosate, has been classified as a probable carcinogen by who. Under these conditions and under the precautionary principle, it seems to me unthinkable to allow the commercialization of NK603. I also consider that the current procedures for authorising GMOs in the Union do not make it possible to be sure that the GMO in question is not dangerous to human health. The European authorities (EFSA) rely mainly on industrial studies to authorise or not GMO. This sometimes yields worrying results. European GMO assessment procedures should be reviewed to become completely independent of industry.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. The purpose of this report was to introduce a new genetically modified organism to the market. While President Jean-Claude Juncker promised that no GMOs would be allowed without consensus, I wanted to oppose this new introduction. Tolerant to glyphosate and its derivatives, this GMO will pose a real food health problem. I categorically rejected the introduction of GMOs into our market and voted against this report.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported the motion for a resolution as I believe such are my political beliefs and this I have made as a commitment to my constituents that European countries should not allow GMO-containing food and feed into their markets. It is clear to me that MTK, including Monsanto, are putting intense pressure on us to open our doors to GMO products widely. But we should not succumb to ios under this pressure because there are no guarantees about the effects of these GMOs on the environment, health and life of humans. Recent investigations and studies in this area clearly prove it.  I understand that the tolerance procedure itself, which is carried out by the Commission, suffers from a number of weaknesses. We can't play God with people's lives and health. We can't, for someone's economic interests, open Pandora's box. I have therefore supported the resolution requiring a suspension of the implementation of an already taken tolerance decision and demanding the suspension of all admission proceedings until the procedure is amended.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 We are voting in favour because the Commission acts as a pimp and at the same time as a sub-operator of multinational food companies, and no one can estimate how many lives have been lost or will be lost as a result of its actions.

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: Writing. \u2012 The EU GMO authorisation system is based on the precautionary principle. Accordingly, the safety of gm products should be ascertained before authorisation.  A wide range of experts objected to the aequisience of studies on the health safety of NK 603xT25 maize. The following deficiencies are identified in the risk assessment carried out: the safety of the NK603xT25 double modified maize line has been determined on the basis of data from single modifications. However, when examining agronomic and phenotypic characteristics, this genetically modified maize was different from its traditional pair.  Inexplicably, EFSA did not considered any of the significant differences to be such as to require further investigation. This and the disregard for the difference in the composition of seeds and feed were confirmed by the EFSA GMO Panel. It should also be criticised that longer-term animal feeding trials should have been carried out in order to determine that this product does not indeed pose a risk to human or animal health. In addition, the GM maize in question is resistant to herbicides with the active substance glyphosate. In the course of its cultivation, therefore, increased use of these plant protection products may occur, which will later increase the level of residues in the crop. It is also important to note here that in 2015 the herbicide glyphosate was classified as a "likely human carcinogen" by the WHO.  Against this view, I voted in favour of parliament's objection to the authorisation of GM maize NK 603xT25.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. I voted for this report because I am opposed to GM maize.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. This objection seeks to reject any authorisation for the placing on the market, both for trade or for animal feed, of genetically modified organisms (GMOs), as the procedures are being reviewed and there is a clear inadequacy and inadequacy of current EU legislation. In the present case, the authorisation for the use of genetically modified nk603xT25, which is resistant to Glyphosate, requested by the multinational Monsanto, is rejected. This herbicide (along with another, ammonium gulosin-to), has been classified as probably carcinogenic to humans by the World Health Organization's cancer agency.  Despite this, the European Food Safety Authority stated that the herbicide was unlikely to pose a danger. Symptomatic of the lack of credibility of this entity, whose promiscuous links to industry have been pointed out several times. Since the current GMO authorisation process came into force, authorisation decisions have been adopted by the European Commission without the support of a qualified majority of Member States. The European Commission is asked to present, as has already been promised by its president but has not yet been fulfilled, a new legislative proposal amending the current legislative framework on GMOs, which is considered not to properly address concerns about food safety, public health and the environment. We voted in favour.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of the resolution as it aims to prevent the proliferation of GM food.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 Vote in favour of the objection against the authorisation of this Monsanto GMO mast. The European Commission is proving to be a long way from the people and workers of Europe on a daily basis, also putting health at risk, as well as the economy, history and traditions, and at the same time it is always in favour of the large multinationals.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the objection under Article 106 concerning the authorisation of the genetically modified maize NK603xT25, because the Commission acts as a pimp and at the same time as a sub-operator of multinational food companies, and no one can estimate how many lives have been lost or will be lost as a result of its actions.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ Considering the fact that there are still doubts on the effects of products containing genetically modified organisms, I believe that any implementing decision authorising the placing on the market of products containing genetically modified organisms should be suspended until a new regulation is adopted. GMO trade crosses borders, which means that a national ‘sales and use’ ban proposed by the Commission could be impossible to enforce without reintroducing border checks on imports. In order to ensure a high level of protection of human life and health, animal health and welfare, environment and consumer interests in relation to genetically modified food and feed, whilst ensuring the effective functioning of the internal market, I support the objection to the implementing act of the Commission.

text: in writing. I voted against the objection considering that a new Regulation is necessary on the basis of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. name: Enrico GASBARRA
text: in writing. I think it is very important that my colleagues in the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Consumer Policy should repeal the implementing decision on the placing on the market of six types of genetically modified maize. Parliament's scrutiny is decisive in these cases of procedural and substantive control over the Commission's implementing acts, and it is rightly stressed that any implementing decision authorizing the placing on the market of products containing, consoding or obtained from genetically modified organisms should be suspended until a new regulation on the sensitive issue of GMOs is adopted. , which this House rejected only a month ago.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Writing. I voted today in favour of the rejection under Article 106 of the CRP: Authorisation of the genetically modified maize variety NK603xT25, as I consider the cultivation of genetically modified organisms and the excessive market power of individual groups to be politically and morally unacceptable.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the  Objection pursuant to Rule 106 concerning the authorisation of genetically modified maize given the Commission should establish a new legislative initiative on the authorisation of GMOs.

name: Sylvie GODDYN
text: In writing. I supported the objection to Monsanto's approval of Monsanto's GMO maize NK603xT25. I myself had lodged an objection against this new GMO in the Committee on Environment, Public Health and Food Safety. These GMOs increase the use of the herbicide glyphosate (also from Monsanto), a carcinogen according to the WHO. In addition, these genetically modified organisms remove all food sovereignty from producing countries and freedom of choice from the farmers who exploit them. In addition, EFSA's assessment concluded that it was in a favourable opinion that ignored the comments of the national agencies. Finally, glyphosate has been patented as an antibiotic. At a time when antibiotic resistance is a serious global health threat, exposing wildlife and the food chain to an antibiotic uncontrolled is irresponsible. This objection therefore had all legitimacy and allowed Parliament to signal its opposition to the Commission. However, the latter saw fit to issue the final authorisation of this GMO during the procedure of studying the objection, showing its disdain for democracy and the elected representatives.

name: Bruno GOLLNISCH
text: In writing. This is definitely not the day of the Commission: Parliament will again oppose one of its acts of execution, without it being binding on it. The act before us is to authorize the marketing of genetically modified maize. In defiance of the most basic precautionary principle and above all in defiance of the very clear positions that this Parliament took a few months ago on GMOs. But how can we be surprised: autistic in the face of the will of the people, how could the Commission not be so to the opposition of its representatives? I voted in favour of this text. However, I would like to denounce the stupid attitude, excuse me for the term, which led our colleagues to refuse to take into account the ENL Group's opposition proposal in the Committee on the Environment, and its amendments in plenary. For purely political and partisan reasons, and even though, pursuing the same goals, these proposals would have only strengthened the text. If a group you don't like put down a resolution saying the sky is blue when the weather is nice, would you also vote against it?

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. We voted A FAVOR considering that NK603 x T25 maize tolerates different types of herbicides, including glyphosate, and the latter was classified as a possible carcinogen for humans by the International Agency for Research on Cancer on 15 March this year. We claim that the draft act implemented is not compatible with Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003 on GMO food and feed, nor with Regulation (EC) No 396/2005 on pesticide residues in food and feed, since it does not ensure a high level of protection for human life and health, animal welfare, environmental and consumer interests in relation to genetically modified food and feed.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this motion because I agree that the current approval system for GM food and feed is not functioning as well as it could be. I also voted in favour of Amendment 6 because the Commission’s decision to authorise genetically-modified maize breaches Article 13(2) of the Treaty, similarly Amendment 1 also points out that authorisation of GM maize disrespects the principle of sincere cooperation.

name: Nathan GILL
text: in writing. ‒ We abstained because the objection, whilst criticising Commission behaviour, recognises and enshrines their power on a topic which should be a choice of Member States. Do we really need the EU telling us what we can and cannot do in every aspect of our lives?  At what point are we going to say, enough is enough? Roll on the Brexit.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ The GM maize NK603 × T25 is a crop made tolerant to both glyphosate and glufosinate-ammonium-based herbicides. It was produced through the crossing of two previously authorised GM maize varieties and developed by Monsanto Europe S.A.  The Commission’s draft implementing act approves the placing on the market of food, food ingredients and feed containing, consisting of, or produced from this maize while the cultivation remains prohibited in the EU. That is why I have voted against.

name: Sergio GUTIÉRREZ PRIETO
text: in writing. – I voted against this resolution because the European Commission, when it adopted Implementing Decision (EU) 2015/2279 on 4 December, acted in accordance with law, that is to say, in accordance with Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003 on genetically modified food and feed. Until a new rule dereaching that regulation is adopted, I understand that it is not reprehensible for the institutions to apply the legislation in force. While it is true that we are awaiting a legislative proposal amending the 2003 Regulation and improved the current authorisation and marketing procedure, it should be recalled that, on 28 October 2015, the European Parliament rejected the Commission's legislative proposal because, inter alia, it was a direct attack on the proper functioning of the internal market. In addition to this rejection, Parliament requested the Commission to submit a new proposal. We are now waiting to be able to consider a new legislative proposal. While it arrives and is being processed, we will have to refer to Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003.

In addition, it is the Member States that will or will not allow the introduction of this GMO on their territories. There was therefore no need to make such a resolution.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. Monsanto Europe requires the placing on the market of food and feed containing a genetically modified maize variety. Allowing such an authority to be authorised is in no way justified and Parliament must be more closely involved. I am therefore voting against this report.

text: Writing. \u2012 At the European Parliament plenary session in Strasbourg, I voted in favour of a European Parliament resolution calling for the withdrawal of Commission Implementing Decision (EU) 2015/2279 of 4 December 2015 allowing the placing on the market of products containing, consisting of, or produced from genetically modified maize pursuant to Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003 of the European Parliament and of the Council. The impact of these products on human health and the environment is still unclear and investigated.
