text: Writing. I voted in favour of the opposition to the authorisation of the maize variety NK603×T25: the ban on the cultivation of GMO crops in Austria guarantees the necessary protection in the sense of citizens who reject genetically modified organisms by a majority. The opposition is an important signal for a GMO-free European Union. In the spirit of the principle of subsidiarity and the national right of self-determination, I am clearly in favour of the freedom of genetically modified organisms on Austrian soil. The level of protection in Austria must remain high in order to safeguard the interests of consumers in the area of food safety.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. The objection is brought by a Green/S-D/EFDD/GUE coalition. An identical objection was presented by Sylvie Goddyn.  Considering that EFSA's assessments are unsatisfactory and especially that President Juncker promised "no new GMOs without consensus", the elected representatives of the ENVI committee want to signal their opposition. But the full validation of this objection will not be binding on the Commission. We voted for that objection.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution because it has the merit of reminding the Commission of the order, which is far too favourable to GMOs and does not take enough account of the warnings of the European Parliament.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Resolution because it objects that the Commission implementing act to which it refers does not legally bind the Commission, and requests that it refrain from authorising the importation of any GMOs until a new regulation is introduced, as requested by Parliament on other occasions.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the motion for a resolution on Commission Implementing Decision (EU) 2015/2279 of 4 December 2015 approving the placing on the market of products containing, consisting of or produced from genetically modified maize NK603 T25, in accordance with Regulation (EC) No 1782/2003. In my speech of 14/12/2015 to the plenary of the European Parliament, it is fully and well documented.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted to tell the EU Commission to withdraw its authorisation of the use of glyphosate-tolerant GM maize NK603xT25 in food and feed. Glyphosate, a herbicide, is classified as ‘probably carcinogenic’ by the WHO. I urge the Commission to suspend any authorisations for GM food and feed as long as the authorisation procedure, currently under review, has not been improved.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this objection. We strongly oppose the use of this GMO, which is a threat to the public health and food sovereignty of states.  It is also a matter of principle: Commission President Juncker promised "no new GMOs without consensus". Seeing him go back on his word will not surprise anyone, but we cannot allow the President of the Commission to allow himself to lie to the citizens and get away with it.

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 I wish to vote in favour of the resolution on the suspension and repeal of Commission Implementing Decision 2015/2279, approving the placing on the market of products containing, consisting of or produced from genetically modified maize NK603 × T25 (MON-ØØ6Ø3-6 × ACS-ZMØØ3-2), since I consider that this decision is contrary to the powers conferred by Regulation (EC) No 1782/2003. In accordance with Council Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003 of 18 December 2003 laying down detailed rules for the application of Council Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003 as regards the application of Council Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003 as regards the application of The aim of the system for the authorisation of genetically modified food and feed is to 'ensure a high level of protection of human life and health, animal health and welfare, the environment and the interests of consumers'.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. Although 19 Member States have banned the cultivation of genetically modified maize on their territory, the Commission is pressing ahead with a further attempt at authorisation. This is not in line with the will of the European Member States, and the Commission is also exceeding its implementing powers.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: in writing. ‒ I rejected this objection as I support the EFSA and the Commission scientific GMO authorisation procedure.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. In 2010 Monsanto submitted a request to the Netherlands for the marketing of foodstuffs containing genetically modified maize NK603 x T25. The European Food Safety Agency (EFSA) issued a favourable opinion in 2015. We now know his incompetence in GMO.  As a result, the Commission plans to allow the use of this maize for human and animal feed for 10 years. Note that this corn is resistant to herbicides containing glyphosate. However, on March 20, 2015, the International Agency for Research on Cancer, the World Health Organization's agency specializing in the study of cancer, classified glyphosate as a probable carcinogen for the human species.  The resolution denounces this abject decision which encourages the cancer epidemic in Europe and calls on the Commission to repeal its decision on implementation. I'm voting for.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 I have some reservations about the text presented in this resolution, in particular as regards the scientific assessment of risks and possible impacts on humans. I believe that a more in-depth debate on the matter in question should be taken, which is why I have decided to vote against the motion for a resolution authorising the placing on the market of products containing, consisting of, or produced from, genetically modified maize NK603 x T25.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I chose to support this objection to the authorisation of genetically modified maize NK603xT25 as the substance was classified as a probable carcinogen by the WHO. I also supported this objection as every authorisation decision taken by the Commission concerning genetically modified organisms was done so without the necessary support of Member States.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Motion for a Resolution objecting to the draft Commission Implementing Decision authorising the placing on the market of genetically modified maize NK 603 x T25 pursuant to Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003, since it seems that the genetically modified organism in question, maize NK 603 x T25 contains stacked genes.  In the case of stacked (multiple) genes there is still some debate on possible synergistic effects even if the individual genes have already been authorised singly, therefore I could not support the Commission proposal.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 Monsanto Europe S.A. submitted an application to the competent authority of the Netherlands on 17 May 2010 for the placing on the market of foodstuffs, food ingredients and feedingstuffs containing, consisting of or produced from maize NK603 × T25. On 4 December 2015, the Commission granted the authorisation by Commission Implementing Decision (EU) 2015/2279, even though this maize contains CP4EPSPS protein, as described in the application, which provides resistance to herbicides containing glyphosate and contains PAT protein, which provides resistance to herbicides containing glufosizinate ammonium. However, on 20 March 2015, the International Agency for Research on Cancer classified glyphosate as a substance 'likely to be carcinogenic to humans'. In its report, the Committee on the Environment recommends that Parliament state that all implementing decisions authorising the placing on the market of products containing GMOs adopted in accordance with the current poorly functioning Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003 should be suspended until a new regulation is adopted under the TMS. At the same time, ask the Commission to submit a new legislative proposal amending Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003, taking into account the frequently voiced concerns expressed by Member States that are not only related to the risks posed by GMOs to health or the environment. I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. \u2012 I advocate reducing divergences in the trade mark system in Europe and that the European Union trade mark system and national trade mark systems coexist in a complementary relationship.  I believe it is essential to ensure that trademarks enjoy the same protection in accordance with the legal systems of all Member States. In line with the broad protection conferred on EU trade marks which enjoy prestige in the Union, broad protection should also be granted at national level to all trade marks enjoying prestige in the Member State concerned. I would stress that trade mark systems in the Union will need to be modernised in order to meet the increased demands of those concerned for faster, better quality and more rational trade mark registration systems. By making brand systems more efficient, we will be reducing costs, bureaucracy and complexity for businesses, which could mean increased innovation and economic growth.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. Considering that EFSA's assessments are unsatisfactory and above all that President Juncker promised "no new GMOs without consensus", the elected representatives of the ENVI committee want to signal their legitimate opposition.  Indeed, tolerant to glyphosate and its derivatives, the GMO in question is a threat to the public health and food sovereignty of Europeans and the countries that will cultivate it.  I voted in favour of that objection.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted against this objection to the authorisation of genetically modified maize filed by the Groups of S and D, Greens, GUE and EFDD and supported by the ENF.  According to this text, the European Commission has exceeded its powers by authorising the marketing of products containing genetically modified maize. However, the Commission has complied with the procedure for authorising these products, based in particular on an analysis by the European Food Safety Authority (EEA) which has established the safety of this plant for human and animal health, as well as for the environment.  The Commission's proposal for authorisation was forwarded to the Council, which did not reject it, as France abstained. Currently, marketing approvals for GMO products are the responsibility of Member States.

name: József NAGY
text: Writing. \u2012 The regulation of genetically modified plants and their food is a very complex issue. On this subject, I have taken the view that, in addition to the security of long-term food supply and the EU's strategic objectives, we must also take into account the views of the public and domestic producers on GM food. Because it is a very important fact that 60% of the citizens of the Union and the majority of Member States remain opposed to GM products. The European Commission must act in accordance with our decision in the authorisation process.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this report that underlines the importance of risk evaluation to human health and biodiversity, prior to the authorisation of genetically modified organisms (GMOs) such as maize.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. I would have strongly agreed with the request to reject the authorisation of this genetically modified maize variety. Any vote to the contrary would be incompatible with my democratic mandate.

name: Margot PARKER
text: in writing. ‒ We abstained because the objection, whilst criticising Commission behaviour, recognises and enshrines their power on a topic which should be a choice of Member States.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ I support Parliament's request asking the Commission to withdraw its Implementing Decision (EU) 2015/2279. Genetically modified maize MON-ØØ6Ø3-6 × ACS-ZMØØ3-2 expresses the CP4 EPSPS protein that causes tolerance to herbicide glyphosate, and the PAT protein that causes tolerance to herbicides containing gluphosinat-amonia. In this way, the use of this GM maize takes precedence over other commercial varieties if used in combination with a herbicide containing the active substance glufosinate-amonia, but in combination with a herbicide containing the active substance glyphosate.  Glufosinat-amonia is known for its teratogenicity, and glyphosate was classified by the International Agency for Research on Cancer (a specialized cancer agency of the World Health Organization) on March 20, 2015 as likely carcinogenic to humans. I consider the use of a potentially carcinogenic or known teratogenic substance in the environment to be a risk that is not justified. I consider the current authorisation system for GM food and feed to be unlasted, as no announced review of this procedure has yet been carried out.  Similarly, I consider that by rejecting the proposal to amend Regulation (EC) No 2020/2013, 1829/2003 a situation arose in which, until the adoption of the new proposal, the right of Member States to independently decide on the use of GMO food and feed on their territory is not guaranteed, which is contrary to the principle of subsidiarity.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. Considering that EFSA's assessments are unsatisfactory and above all that President Juncker promised "no new GMOs without consensus", the elected representatives of the ENVI committee want to signal their opposition, which is more than legitimate.  Indeed, tolerant to glyphosate and its derivatives, the GMO in question is a threat to the public health and food sovereignty of Europeans and the countries that will cultivate it. I voted in favour of that objection.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. \u2012 Genetically modified maize MON-ØØ6Ø3-6 × ACS-ZMØØ3-2 emits CP4 EPSPS protein that creates resistance to herbicide glyphosate and PAT protein that creates resistance to ammonium gluphosin herbicide. The International Agency for Research on Cancer has classified glyphosate as likely carcinogenic to humans. Taking into account these recommendations and the likely consequences of consuming this type of GM maize, I fully support the objection in accordance with Article 106. Rules of procedure for approving its use.  Parliament earlier this year already rejected a legislative proposal of 22 April 2015 amending Regulation (EC) No 22/2016. 1829/2003(6) because, despite the fact that farming necessarily takes place on the territory of one Member State, trade in GM organisms takes place outside national borders, meaning that the national prohibition on 'sale and use' proposed by the Commission could be unenforceable without the reintroduction of border controls on imports.  The Commission's implementing decision is incompatible with Union law as it is incompatible with Regulation (EC) No 2013/2013. 1829/2003 and Regulation (EC) No 396/2005(8) to provide a basis for providing a high level of protection for human life and health, animal health and welfare, the environment and consumer interests in relation to GM food and feed, while ensuring the effective functioning of the internal market, which is why I ask for its withdrawal.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 On 17 May 2010, Monsanto Europe S.A. submitted to the competent authority of the Netherlands, in accordance with Articles 5 and 17 of Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003, an application for marketing relating to food, food ingredients and feed, consisting of or obtained from genetically modified maize NK603 × T25. Commission Implementing Decision (EU) 2015/2279 of 4 December 2015 authorises the placing on the market of these products pursuant to Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003 of the European Parliament and of the Council. I voted in favour of the objection because I believe that the Commission's Implementing Decision (EU) 2015/2279 does not comply with EU law, as it is not compatible with the purpose of Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003 and Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003. Regulation (EC) No 396/2005(8), which consists, on the basis of the general principles laid down in Regulation (EC) No 178/2002, of providing the basis for ensuring a high level of protection of human life and health, animal welfare, the environment and consumer interests in relation to genetically modified food and feed, while ensuring the effective functioning of the internal market.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: Writing. \u2012 Due to my sceptical view of GMOs, I have decided to support the objection submitted.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. I rejected this objection for a simple reason. What is present in this resolution is simply wrong. We can and must be very vigilant about GMOs, but here the objection is based on the fact that the European Commission would have exceeded its powers by allowing the marketing of products containing genetically modified maize, consisting of this genetically modified maize or produced from it.  However, the Commission has complied with the procedure in place for authorising GMOs, including an analysis by the European Food Safety Authority (EESA or EFSA) on the safety of the plant for human and animal health, and for the environment before issuing a proposal for authorisation.  This proposal for authorisation was then forwarded to the Council, which did not reject it, France abstained. Currently, the authorisation to market is the responsibility of the Member States. I wonder about this process, particularly from the Socialists who criticise the European Commission, while the ruling left has not said anything to the Council in the face of this AMM proposal. It's called a sleight of hand and I don't support it.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ We abstained because the objection, whilst criticising Commission behaviour, recognises and enshrines their power on a topic which should be a choice of Member States.

name: Frédérique RIES
text: In writing. I voted this lunchtime with 402 other MEPs in favour of the objection against the authorisation of genetically modified maize NK603 x T25 for use in animal feed. As I did in the Committee on the Environment a fortnight ago.  While this maize has passed the railings of EFSA's control, as will always be observed by savvy observers, its specific nature - it is designed to tolerate glyphosate, a widespread chemical whose safety has not been proven - warrants the utmost caution. Other arguments have, of course, argued for this objection to be adopted, even though the EP cannot formally oppose it. It is legitimate to question the haste of the authorisation taken by the Commission on Friday 4 December without waiting for the plenary to decide on its admissibility.  It is a provocation that undermines fair cooperation between institutions on the monitoring of legislative acts. What can we say about Jean-Claude Juncker's outright denial of his promise made in July 2014 in the Chamber to change the current system of authorisation of GMOs, both for import and culture, because it is not democratic. Fortunately, it's not too late to reverse the trend!

name: Robert ROCHEFORT
text: In writing. I supported the objection to the marketing of food for human and animal purposes and ingredients containing or produced from genetically modified maize "NK603 x T25" produced by Monsanto.  Firstly, because it seems to me that the current procedure for authorising GMO to market is neither satisfactory nor democratic, as each authorisation decision has been adopted by the Commission without the support of a qualified majority of The Member States. Secondly, because certain arguments "against" are very challenging: negative public opinion, risk assessment deemed insufficient, lack of toxicity study over 90 days and precautionary principle. Finally, because this issue arises with glyphosate in the background: the maize in question is indeed tolerant to herbicides containing glyphosate, a substance being evaluated that could be harmful to health. This is not the time to move forward without precaution: WHO, through the International Cancer Centre in Lyon, classified glyphosate as a "probable human carcinogen" in March 2015, while EFSA said last November that it was "unlikely" that it posed a risk of cancer to humans.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. I voted today in favour of this objection, in accordance with the opinion of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, which opposed this proposed implementation on 1 December 2015 to authorise the marketing of products containing genetically modified maize NK603xT25.  I have also supported amendments which consider that the decision of the EUROPEAN executive to proceed with its decision to implement when the draft was rejected by the relevant parliamentary committee before the plenary vote violates Article 13, paragraph 2 of the Treaty on european Union with regard to fair cooperation between the institutions.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. \u2012 This motion for a resolution concerns the objection to the placing on the market of products containing, consisting of or produced from genetically modified maize NK603 x T25, on the foot of the view that the Commission's Implementing Decision in this respect exceeds its implementing powers laid down in Regulation (EC) No 1829/2005 and is not in line with EU law. I therefore believe that there should be a re-examination of the situation in order to ascertain whether or not the Commission's implementing decision should be suspended until a new regulation is adopted in order for it to comply with the provisions of the communautaire acquis. Because it is a question of the need to provide a high level of protection to human life and health, animal health and welfare, environmental preservation itself and the need for consumers to be properly informed, and because doubts remain about safeguarding these rights, I have decided to abstain.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. – We voted A FAVOR considering that NK603 x T25 maize tolerates different types of herbicides, including glyphosate, and the latter was classified as a possible carcinogen for humans by the International Agency for Research on Cancer on 15 March this year. We claim that the draft act implemented is not compatible with Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003 on GMO food and feed, nor with Regulation (EC) No 396/2005 on pesticide residues in food and feed, since it does not ensure a high level of protection for human life and health, animal welfare, environmental and consumer interests in relation to genetically modified food and feed.

name: Daciana Octavia SÂRBU
text: in writing. ‒ The continued political stalemate between the Member States on GMOs has already forced the Commission to propose the part-renationalisation of GMO policy. Yet widespread dissatisfaction with the GMO authorisation process remains. The whole procedure needs to be reviewed, as President Juncker promised. Until this is done, the lack of confidence in the system will only cause further controversy.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this objection urging the European Commission to repeal its Implementing Decision (EU) 2015/2279 by which it authorized the marketing of products that NK603 × T25 (MON-6-3-6 × ACS-ZM-3-2), contain or have been produced from it. The current procedure for the authorisation of genetically modified food and feed is not working well and, as long as it is not improved, any authorisation of such products should be suspended. In addition, the Commission had an obligation to submit a draft to Parliament to know its opinion before approving the marketing of this type of maize, but, despite having the opposite position of Parliament's Committee on the Environment since 1 December, it did not expect to hear Parliament's opinion. Not only am I in favour of this objection, but I also support any future objections to the authorisation of GMOs, and the Commission must make a legislative proposal that respects the right of Member States not to authorise GMOs for human and animal feed in their territory.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this report as it recognises and enshrines EU competence (power) over areas I do not wish to see the EU have power over.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this motion because I agree that the current approval system for GM food and feed is not functioning as well as it could be. I also voted in favour of Amendment 6 because the Commission’s decision to authorise genetically-modified maize breaches Article 13(2) of the Treaty, similarly Amendment 1 also points out that authorisation of GM maize disrespects the principle of sincere cooperation.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I agree with the EP's position that the Commission implementing decision authorising the placing on the market of products containing a specific type of GM maize should be repealed. By this Decision, the Commission would authorise the cultivation of genetically modified maize, which displaces certain types of proteins which, although they lend it resistance to herbicides but are also considered carcinogenic substances.  The rules on the cultivation of GMOs are still not resolved at EU level. Parliament rejected the last legislative proposal because the Commission did not take into account a number of facts in it. We must be aware that the cultivation of GMOs takes place on the territory of a Member State, but trade in GMOs is of a cross-border nature. This means that even if there were a national ban on the sale and use of GMOs, the spread of these products could not be prevented other than by introducing border controls on imported goods. For example, Monsanto has applied for the registration of this maize in the Netherlands. Should this application be approved, products of this crop may be sold freely in other countries. We are therefore asking the Commission to annul its decision on this type of maize. At the same time, it needs to come forward with a new proposal for legislation on the authorisation of genetically modified food and feed.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I did not vote against the authorisation of products containing genetically modified maize NK603 × T25 for several reasons. By authorising these products, the Commission has in no way gone beyond the scope of the empowering Regulation and its decision is based on scientific advice, namely the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA). In such a situation, there is no reason to raise a comitological objection. Moreover, the authorisation of products containing NK603 × T25 is fully in line with the recommendations of the Ministry of Agriculture of the Czech Republic and other responsible authorities of the Czech Republic.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. ‒I support this proposal because I consider that genetically modified maize MON-ØØ6Ø3-6 × ACS-ZMØØ3-2, as specified in the application, it emits CP4 EPSPS protein that creates resistance to the herbicide glyphosate and PAT protein that creates resistance to the herbicide ammonium glufosinate, and since the International Agency for Research on Cancer (a specialized cancer agency of the World Health Organization) on 20 March 2015 classified glyphosate as likely carcinogenic to humans.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: Writing. \u2012 I did not support the proposal because I do not agree with the arguments for banning the GMO in question and consider the arguments presented to be misleading to untrue. In particular, if these arguments are also to be used for the purpose of a blanket ban on the authorisation of new GMOs.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the objection in accordance with Rule 106 of the Rules of Procedure: Authorisation of Genetically Modified Maize NK603xT25. Monsanto Europe S.A. has submitted an application for the placing on the market of foods, food ingredients and feed containing NK603 x T25 maize, which provides resistance to the herbicide glyphosate, which has been classified as a substance likely to be carcinogenic to humans by the International Agency for Research on Cancer. I support the report, which considers that the implementing decision in the current non-functioning version, which allows products containing, consisting of or produced from genetically modified organisms to be put on the market, should be suspended until a new regulation is adopted on the basis of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The Commission acts as a pimp and at the same time as a sub-operator of multinational food companies, and no one can estimate how many lives have been lost or will be lost as a result of its actions.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. – I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution rejecting the placing on the market of products containing, consisting of or produced from genetically modified maize for two reasons. On the one hand, I supported it because I believe that the implementing decision in question (and its design) does not comply with EU law. On the other hand, it is a genetically modified plant which, according to the International Agency for Research on Cancer , the WHO Agency for Cancer, is also resistant to glyphosate, which is believed to be carcinogenic. This is dangerous for human and animal health because it encourages the use of herbicides containing glyphosate, which may be stored in the plant in case of misuse. I also think it is important to note that this case shows a systemic error, as the European Parliament has repeatedly taken a position on genetically modified food and feed in order to protect the health of the electorate and their environment. I believe that it is right for the Commission to take these resolutions into account. The current approval system for genetically modified food and feed is not working properly and correction is essential.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. I am in perfect agreement with the refusal of GMOs whose safety is not guaranteed. The industry continues to make fun of the consumer. No impact analysis is reliable; we have studies that say everything and its opposite. The precautionary principle must be the rule in order to preserve the health of European citizens.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this resolution which seeks to repeal Commission Implementing Decision (EU) 2015/2279 authorising the placing on the market of products containing, consisting of, or produced from genetically modified maize NK603 × T25. The GM maize NK603 × T25 is a crop made tolerant to both glyphosate and glufosinate-ammonium-based herbicides. It was produced through the crossing of two previously authorised GM maize varieties and developed by Monsanto Europe S.A.  The Commission’s draft implementing act approves the placing on the market of food, food ingredients and feed containing, consisting of, or produced from this maize while the cultivation remains prohibited in the EU. EFSA delivered a positive opinion on the GMO stating that the maize is as safe as its non-GM comparator and non-GM conventional maize varieties with respect to potential effects on human and animal health and the environment in the context of its scope.

name: Valdemar TOMAŠEVSKI
text: Writing. I fully supported the opposition to the authorisation of genetically modified maize by voting. This is important for European agriculture and for the security of food that reaches consumers. According to the report, genetically modified maize contains a protein that provides resistance to glyphosate herbicides and ammonium glufosinonate, which has been classified by the International Agency for Research on Cancer as having carcinogenic effects on humans. A objection to this issue is therefore necessary and any decision should be suspended until a new regulation is adopted.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒I voted to object to the Commission's implementing decision to authorize the marketing of products containing GENETICALLY modified NK603 maize, consist of or manufactured, as I consider that the Members who lodged that complaint recognised the problems that those products would cause. Since the European Parliament, as a representative body of EU citizens, has never given authorisation to market GM products and some Member States explicitly oppose such products, I believe that the Commission should withdraw its decision and thus protect the health of EU citizens. I believe that, in its decisions, the Commission should, in particular, be guided by the objective of providing high protection of human life and health, animal health and welfare, the environment and consumer interests in relation to genetically modified food and feed.  Therefore, I believe that each Member State has the right to decide whether and to what extent it wants to introduce GMO products on its market or not.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. I supported the objection under Rule 106 of the Rules of Procedure on the authorisation of genetically modified maize NK603xT25, as genetically modified maize NK603xT25 is resistant to the herbicide glyphosate, which has been proven to cause cancer in humans. By objecting, we will indirectly contribute to human and animal health, affect the interests of the environment and consumers, and also ensure the effective functioning of the internal market.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. – We voted A FAVOR considering that NK603 x T25 maize tolerates different types of herbicides, including glyphosate, and the latter was classified as a possible carcinogen for humans by the International Agency for Research on Cancer on 15 March this year. We claim that the draft act implemented is not compatible with Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003 on GMO food and feed, nor with Regulation (EC) No 396/2005 on pesticide residues in food and feed, since it does not ensure a high level of protection for human life and health, animal welfare, environmental and consumer interests in relation to genetically modified food and feed.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. The objection relates to the tolerance of glyphosate and its derivatives of the GMO in question, which is a threat to the public health and food sovereignty of Europeans and the countries that will cultivate it. The basis for the objection to the plenary vote is essentially political, regretting that Juncker is not keeping his promises. It remains clear that I wish to express my hostility to Monsanto's GMOs and that is why I support this objection. I voted for it.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. \u2012 All implementing decisions authorising the placing on the market of products containing, consisting of or produced from genetically modified organisms, adopted in accordance with the current, dysfunctional Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003, shall be suspended until a new Regulation is adopted under the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. I supported the report.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. – We voted A FAVOR considering that NK603 x T25 maize tolerates different types of herbicides, including glyphosate, and the latter was classified as a possible carcinogen for humans by the International Agency for Research on Cancer on 15 March this year. We claim that the draft act implemented is not compatible with Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003 on GMO food and feed, nor with Regulation (EC) No 396/2005 on pesticide residues in food and feed, since it does not ensure a high level of protection for human life and health, animal welfare, environmental and consumer interests in relation to genetically modified food and feed.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this objection because although I believe the safety of our food is necessary and we need to put in place more cautious measures, in this particular case of genetically modified maize all the scientific research available indicates that there are no reasons of concern that would justify its production and sale not to be authorised.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: In writing. The European Parliament has rejected the Commission's authorisation to import two GMOs (NK603 and T25) for human feed, using its right to oppose the Commission's regulatory measures. This shows how little the European Parliament's positioning committee is doing on GMOs. The Commission has always authorised applications, and EFSA has always given positive opinions to applications for authorisation. The Commission's decision, taken on 4 December, is contrary to the proposal for a legislative revision made in April 2015 allowing national bans, even though it was rejected by the European Parliament last October because it did not satisfy neither supporters nor opponents of GMOs. In addition, the Commission has still not followed through on Juncker's promise to overhaul the application assessment procedure and for the authorisation/ban of GMOs in the EU. I voted to reject these two authorizations. This vote is a new political signal from the European Parliament for the Commission to finally review THE European GMO legislation and finally hear the voice of European citizens.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. \u2012 A few days after the European Parliament's Committee on the Environment objected to the authorisation of Monsanto's genetically modified NK603xT25 maize, the European Commission, in the absence of consensus between Member States, decides to authorise the market introduction of monsanto's nkgenic maize. This is an undemocratic decision. In addition, its concrete content takes on the greatest gravity. This is a genetically modified corn to tolerate two herbicides – glyphosinate and glyphosate. The first is classified by the European Union itself as toxic to reproduction. The second is classified by the World Health Organization as potentially carcinogenic. The full discredit of the current GMO authorisation mechanism requires the immediate suspension of the issue of authorisations until the President of the European Commission delivers on his promise and proposes a new mechanism.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. Although 19 Member States have banned the cultivation of genetically modified maize on their territory, the Commission is pressing ahead with a further attempt at authorisation. This is not in line with the will of the European Member States, and the Commission is also exceeding its implementing powers.

name: Damiano ZOFFOLI
text: Zoffoli (S&D), in writing. \u2012 I welcome today's vote by the European Parliament to pass a resolution calling on the Commission to withdraw its authorisation for the use of NK603xT25 tolerant glysophate mast in food and feed. In the resolution we wanted to highlight that glysophate, a herbicide, is classified by the WHO as 'probably carcinogenic' and to call on the Commission to suspend all authorisations for GMO food and feed until the authorisation procedure, which is currently under review, has been improved. Finally, it is important to emphasise that the EP recently rejected the European Commission's proposal that would allow each Member State to restrict or prohibit on its territory the sale and use of EU-approved GMO food or feed. And the authorisation we are debating today is an attempt by the Commission to circumvent this decision in order to allow the introduction of new GMO foods without waiting for new legislation that will finally clarify this sensitive issue.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution tabled pursuant to Article 106 on the Commission's Implementing Decision (EU) No 2015/2279 of 4 December 2015, authorising the placing on the market of products containing, consisting of, or produced from, genetically modified maize, on the same way that any implementing decision authorising the placing on the market of products containing, consisting of, or produced from, genetically modified organisms (GMOs), in accordance with Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003, should be suspended until the adoption of a new Regulation.  The current version of the Regulation lacks functionality and an effective system for the approval of genetically modified food and feed. Furthermore, the final decision by the Commission on this type of authorisation, which has become the norm, should be an exception only in the context of the whole procedure. I therefore believe that the Commission's Implementing Decision is not compatible with the purpose of the Regulation guaranteeing a high level of protection of human life and health, animal health and welfare, the environment and consumer interests.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. \u2012 This objection seeks to reject any authorisation for the placing on the market, both for trade and for animal feed, of genetically modified organisms (GMOs), as the procedures are being reviewed and there is a clear inadequacy and inadequacy of current EU legislation. In the present case, the authorisation for the use of genetically modified maize NK603xT25, which is resistant to glyphosate, requested by the multinational Monsanto is rejected. This herbicide (along with another, ammonium glufosinate) has been classified as probably carcinogenic to humans by the World Health Organization's cancer agency. Despite this, the European Food Safety Authority stated that the herbicide was unlikely to pose a danger. Symptomatic of the lack of credibility of this entity, whose promiscuous links to industry have been repeatedly pointed out. The European Commission is asked to present, as has already been promised by its president but has not yet been fulfilled, a new legislative proposal amending the current legislative framework on GMOs, which is considered not to properly address concerns about food safety, public health and the environment. We voted in favour.

name: Marco ZULLO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution strongly calling on the European Commission not to authorise the use of Roundup Ready Liberty Link genetically modified maize, monsanto feed designed to tolerate glyphosate spraying. Glyphosate and GMO maize are clearly a single trade package, which Monsanto has managed to get authorised by the European executive, in defiance of the wishes of Parliament, which has expressed its negative opinion twice. I find it scandalous that the only body democratically elected by the citizens cannot give binding opinions on this matter and that the resolution is only an act of political direction. An act which, against all institutional practices, the Commission itself did not even deign to wait by approving the use of NK603 x T25 maly at the beginning of the month, even before the Plenary could give its opinion. Since the beginning of my term of office, I have fought to make Europe a GMO-free territory, and with this vote I reiterate a dry no to the entry of gm food and feed into European territory.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – A Uachtaráin, cé go bhfuil a lán moltaí maithe sa tuarascáil seo, ag deireadh na dála staon mise agus mo chomhghleacaithe i bhFine Gael air an vóta deiridh. Bhí ár ngrúpa i bhfabhar.  An chúis gur staonamar na arís feicimid go bhfuil an tAontas ag iarraidh a maidí rámha a chur isteach i gcumhachtaí na mBallstát. Is is dualgas agus cumhacht na mBallstát cáin a shocrú dá gcorparáidí, dá lucht gnó agus do dhaoine príobháideacha. Ach arís agus arís eile, feicimid go bhfuilimid ag iarraidh gach rud a shocrú agus a leagadh síos ó thaobh na hEorpa de. Nílimid sasta laws sin.  Cinnte caithfidh gach corparáid a gcuid cheart de cháin a íoc ach caithfear é sin a fheiceáil trasna na hEorpa, agus is amhlaidh mar atá in Éirinn. Ach is scéal eile is a bheith ag cur isteach ar chumhachtaí na mBallstát.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – During the first plenary session in December this year, brussels already had a vote on the establishment of the so-called TAXE Committee and the appointment of its members. The committee's primary task will be to continue to work in fact the same directions as the committee of the previous legislature, the installation of which was heavily influenced by the LuxLeaks scandal. Thus, promoting a more transparent, efficient, fairly fair tax system at Community level through monitoring of tax processes. The role of the Member States in the field of taxation is not called into question, it is clear. However, given the already existing degree of economic integration, a number of legislative aspects relating to business and the increasing need to combat tax evasion more effectively or to provide unfair financial assistance, the role of this report is very high.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: – Madam President, unfortunately I was not able to support  this report on corporate tax policies either. It has a number of excellent suggestions that I agree with, for example, the issue of public country—by—country reporting for all multinational companies in all sectors. I also support the idea of stricter rules governing firms which give tax advice in order to avoid conflicts of interest. However, I could not support the recommendation for a new approach to international tax arrangements. This recommendation says that the Commission should be mandated to negotiate tax agreements with third countries on behalf of the Union, instead of the current practice under which bilateral negotiations are conducted which produce sub—optimal results, especially for developing countries. I just cannot support that proposal and it goes further than that because I believe that is beyond the competence of the EU. I also believe it would be unacceptable to a majority of our citizens to see the EU Commission negotiate tax agreements with third countries. It is a real pity. This is a good report, but it has gone too far.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Madam President, I consider the draft report tabled by our colleagues to be one of the best I have read here, despite the fact that I do not agree with it on some points. Finally, I decided to support the report as a whole, because it is primarily aimed at the fundamental main objective, and that is the inadmissibility of unfair tax competition, which has simply been operated by some states, as the Luxleaks case has indeed shown. But with all due respect, it is not just that such agreements distort the business market, they are unequal, in fact they go against all the values on which Europe stands. I regret that some of the leaders, important representatives of the European Union today, have also been involved. But the moment we go into direct tax unification, into a consolidated tax base, in this case, I'm going to say I'm against it.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. \u2012 The Luxleaks investigation revealed a number of irregularities carried out by the Luxembourg Government in the secret granting of tax concessions to large multinationals. In view of this, in December 2014, the European Parliament authorised the drafting of a report on improving the rules on transparency, coordination and convergence of corporate tax policies. Many of the aspects and proposals presented in the report have already been analysed when the TAXE report was adopted, such as: improving the exchange of information, a clear definition of the concept of a tax haven, and the preparation of measures to combat this practice of evasion. As stated in the TAXE report, while it is true that some of the proposed measures are sustainable and adapted to the requirements of transparency, it is also true that no form of responsibility has been foreseen towards individuals and states individually involved. That is why I have chosen to abstain.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: in writing. We welcome the adoption of this own-initiative report which has run in parallel with the TAXE Commission, although more focused on recommendations than fact-based research. We welcome the fact that some purely socialist achievements have been incorporated into the report, such as the inclusion of the obligation to carry out country-by-country reports, the harmonisation of the corporate tax base (BICCIS), protection for whistleblowers, the establishment of a common definition of tax haven, or the automatic exchange of tax rulings. However, we must regret that, because of the opposition of the PPE, ALDE and ECR Groups, we have not been able to move forward in plenary with the creation of a European fund to assist whistleblowers, as well as more regulation for tax consulting firms. On the other hand, although it has not been incorporated into this report, we do not in the future renounce the creation of a European tax agency to manage the repertoire of tax rulings and the list of cross-border evadors.

name: Tim AKER
text: in writing. – The title of this recommendation to the Commission highlights not just transparency but also coordination and convergence of corporate tax policies – in other words the ground is being prepared for harmonisation of corporate taxes across the EU, which will end the healthy tax competition between jurisdictions that is the only brake on ever-growing public expenditure.  UKIP accordingly voted against tax harmonisation.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. U2012 The internationalization of production requires fiscal harmonization and a clear accounting definition of taxes, in order to avoid the usual tax avoidance practices among large companies. It is also necessary to improve the transparency of the tax provisions of the Member States, in order to avoid a repeat of scandals such as that of LuxLeaks. These aspects are reflected in the report, although still insufficient. Nevertheless, I believe that the proposals allow the Commission and the Council to be pressured to fully reformulate the taxation policies of today's companies, so I voted in favour.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: Writing. Taxes should be paid where economic activities are carried out, where the winners are generated and where public services and infrastructure are used. The review of the Luxleaks affair has clearly shown that aggressive tax planning and the transfer of profits by multinationals, which are encouraged and exploited by the excessive complexity and differences between national tax systems, lead to tax losses and unfair conditions of competition. The latter is also due to the fact that SMEs, family businesses and the self-employed in particular are rarely able to shift their profits from high-tax countries to low-tax countries and to pursue an aggressive tax arrangement, thereby reducing their overall tax base. In addition to an international approach, there is also a need for a Union-wide approach. That is why I support this legislative resolution, which obliges the European Commission to put forward concrete proposals, inter alia, on greater transparency and on bringing Member States closer together on corporate tax, exchange of information and a legal framework for the protection of whistleblowers.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. This report was written in the wake of the LuxLeaks scandal and is in many ways similar to that of the TAXE commission. The conclusions of the two reports converge on many points. Indeed, the themes are the same, namely to combat aggressive tax competition at european union level and optimization schemes. As a reminder, the damage to the EU Member States has been set at almost 50 to 70 billion euros per year. And this only applies to the relocation of profits. The damage is between 160 and 190 billion euros if we include special tax regimes and agreements as well as fraud. I again regret the idea of the abolition of bilateral conventions by multilateral agreements under the aegis of the European Union, instead of States.  Considering that this report is redundant with that of the TAXE Committee and that it contains demands that are not acceptable in favour of tax integration while presenting recommendations that we support, I abstained.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ I do not believe in harmonisation of taxation policies, which should in my view be the sole responsibility of the Member States. This report, inter alia, calls for the Commission to introduce EU tax information numbers, enter tax agreements with third countries, and interfere with domestic laws concerning tax havens and tax abuse.  Finally, the call for a common consolidated corporate tax base is an anathema to what UKIP stands for.

name: Guillaume BALAS
text: In writing. I have decided to vote in favour of the initiative report prepared by Anneliese Dodds (S-D, UK) and Ludek Niedermayer (EPP, CZ) of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs for several reasons. It not only makes a number of recommendations to improve corporate tax transparency, but it also allows for the coordination and convergence of tax policies at European level.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to better coordinate and increase the transparency of corporate tax policies. I support the recommendations on new rules that will increase the convergence, transparency and coordination of eu countries' corporate tax policies. In November 2014, the International Consortium of Investigative Journalism adopted a report on the use of the International Consortium of Investigative Journalists. The publication of tax rulings and other harmful practices in Luxembourg (LuxLeaks) revealed that almost 340 multinational companies had reached collusion with Luxembourg, which enabled many of these companies to minimise their total tax costs by undermining the Union's public interests.  I agree with the need to significantly increase the transparency of corporate tax policy in the EU. Greater transparency in corporate taxation can improve tax collection, increase the efficiency of the work of tax administrations and be crucial to ensuring public confidence in tax systems and governments.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. I abstained on this report, which duplicates the proposals of the TAXE Committee and contains some unacceptable demands as they stand, notably in favour of 'tax integration'.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. – We voted in favour of this report, with which the European Parliament calls on the Commission to resume its work in order to establish a consolidation of the tax base of multinationals, which would help combat tax evasion and tax competition on the ground between countries. The document also contains other very interesting elements such as whistleblower protection and greater control of 'tax advisory' companies, which in many cases are complicit in evasion.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: in writing. We share the need to add transparency, escalation and justice to corporation tax policy across Europe to prevent competition between national tax systems on the basis of circumvention and what has been called 'fiscal creativity'. We share recommendations to prevent circumvention and recourse to tax havens and agree to protect people who with their testimonies help identify and punish elusive behavior or fraud. This protection should include the creation of a fund financed with money recovered from fraud or circumvention so that the perpetrators of these testimonies can overcome the problems caused by their cooperation with the tax authorities. We are fine with the control measures of international companies, and especially urgently the shared definition of 'tax haven'.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. I abstained on this report which, while it has the laudable intention of combating aggressive tax competition at EU level, is once again taking the opportunity to grab a little more sovereignty over the Member States.  Indeed, I regret that the parliamentarians of the TAXE Committee saw fit to replace bilateral agreements with multilateral agreements negotiated under the aegis of the Union, resulting in a de facto loss of control over these agreements for the Member States. Having said that, I recognise the usefulness of some of the proposed measures, such as the regulation of free ports or retaliatory measures for companies using tax havens. A failed act, then.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 The text aims to promote transparency and avoid future scandals such as the "Luxleaks" one involving the Luxembourg Government and President Juncker himself. Unfortunately, the fact remains that there is no reference to the obvious political responsibilities of what happened and that a chapter is being introduced on convergence in the field of taxation between the various Member States, which I do not agree with, for these reasons I abstained.

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: Written. I've abstained. The report has many positive proposals, such as mandatory public country-by-country reporting of profits and taxes, legal protection for whistleblowers and increased coordination and exchange of information between Member States to combat tax evasion and aggressive tax planning. However, the proposal also contains proposals aimed at giving the EU power over tax policy and, in the long term, tax law. I am opposed to this, as these are important elements of a strategy for a federal EU state. That's why I'm abstaining.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. We welcome the adoption of this own-initiative report which has run in parallel with the TAXE Commission, although more focused on recommendations than fact-based research. We welcome the fact that some purely socialist achievements have been incorporated into the report, such as the inclusion of the obligation to carry out country-by-country reports, the harmonisation of the corporate tax base (BICCIS), protection for whistleblowers, the establishment of a common definition of tax haven, or the automatic exchange of tax rulings. However, we must regret that, because of the opposition of the PPE, ALDE and ECR Groups, we have not been able to move forward in plenary with the creation of a European fund to assist whistleblowers, as well as more regulation for tax consulting firms. On the other hand, although it has not been incorporated into this report, we do not in the future renounce the creation of a European tax agency to manage the repertoire of tax rulings and the list of cross-border evadors.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because it calls on the Commission to propose legislative measures at EU level, while respecting the sovereignty of the Member States in the field of tax policy, in order to increase the transparency, coordination and convergence of corporate tax policies in the Union. Parliament adopted in December 2014 a proposal for a directive on the protection of the environment and the environment. decided to authorise the preparation of an own-initiative legislative report on the transparency, coordination and convergence of corporate tax policies in the European Union. This decision was a reaction to luxleaks information published by the Consortium of Journalists in 2014, which revealed that many multinational companies had entered into collusion with the Luxembourg authorities, which allowed companies to reduce their tax obligations, with little or no economic activity in that country. Subsequent public debates have shown that such so-called aggressive tax planning practices are in no way limited to Luxembourg and are indeed a very common phenomenon throughout the EU. Such practices should always be unacceptable. Parliament considers it essential that the contribution of all economic actors be fair in difficult economic conditions, such as where Europe is currently located. If certain multinational companies do not pay tax contributions, this creates unequal operating conditions where smaller, national businesses find it difficult to compete, which is completely contrary to the principle of the single market.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: Writing. \u2012 The proposals in the report indicate both the Determination of the European Parliament and europeans to make legislative changes to prevent companies from jumping from country to country to reduce their tax obligations to almost zero. The Luxleaks scandal revealed exactly how much tax companies were getting rid of, avoiding paying money that could have been used to build schools, hospitals or reduce public debt. Corporate tax avoidance means billions of dollars in lost revenue to national budgets each year, leads to unequal competition between companies and undermines Europeans' faith in the state and government.  I believe that the rapid introduction of the measures proposed by Parliament and the OECD would not only make collecting national taxes more efficient, but would also increase competition in the market and reduce the cost to companies of complying with the law. I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: Writing. We have voted positively on another European Parliament resolution, which represents a response to the Luxleaks tax affair and all the unfair tax practices of the past that have been exposed to it. Transparency, transparency and information exchange will be essential in the future. Of course, we are not interfering with fiscal sovereignty in any way, but it is right that, through mandatory public reporting, it is very clear how much tax companies have paid in which country. This will also give less interest in the spillover of profits, while tax policy makers will have an insight into the reality and will be able to adapt to the situation accordingly. In any case, a set of uniform rules will have to be developed for larger companies present in many markets within the EU, at least as far as the common consolidated basis for taxation is concerned.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. This report aims to combat evasion, optimisation and tax dumping within the European Union itself, which create a loss of between 160 and 190 billion euros for Member States. The rapporteur's recommendations are relatively similar to those made in the TAXE report. They therefore call for consensus on a common definition of tax haven, full country reporting by the end of the first quarter of 2016, increased transfer pricing controls between subsidiaries of the same company, speeding up automatic process exchanges between Member States and strengthening retaliatory measures against companies engaged in such activities.  Nevertheless, we regret the presence in this report of questionable proposals which will prove ineffective, such as the labelling of companies using transparent tax practices. Finally, we challenge the abolition of bilateral conventions, which weakens the ability of Member States to control these agreements. I therefore abstained on this text.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 The european Union-wide revenue losses due to corporate tax avoidance practices could amount to around EUR 50-70 billion annually, which is the amount lost through the transfer of profits. These losses could amount to EUR 160-190 million if special tax regimes, collection inefficiencies and other such activities are taken into account. Losses related to the erosion of the taxable base and the transfer of profits constitute a danger to the proper functioning of the internal market and to the credibility, efficiency and fairness of corporate tax systems within the Union.  It is necessary to adopt a coordinated and differentiated approach at national, Union and international level. In the absence of joint action, many Member States will adopt unilateral national measures, which have often proved to be ineffective and insufficient. I was in favour of this report, because there is a need for greater attention and focus on this sector from the relevant institutions to combat tax avoidance and only by applying the principles of transparency, coordination and convergence can we achieve this objective.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 The Dodds-Niedermayer report contains recommendations to the European Commission on a very important issue, linked to the work of the TAXE Special Committee, namely closely linked to the Luxleaks affair.  The issue of convergence in corporate tax policies in the EU may pose some questions for those who, like us, view this from a Euro-critical point of view. The Luxleaks case has brought out a system that has had a major impact on making corporate tax levies extremely opaque, especially in the case of multinationals. In this respect, therefore, we can more than positively accept the calls for transparency and greater coordination between the Member States.  On the contrary, we are not very convinced by the chapter on convergence in taxation between the various Member States. Furthermore, as with other similar texts, we can only remember how these lists of good intentions are, in fact, late and will take many years for them to be put into practice and bring concrete results and fairness and transparency within the Union. Our group has tabled a number of amendments aimed, among other things, at highlighting the specific direct responsibilities of Juncker-led governments that have followed one another over the years. I abstained. In fact, there is almost no reference to obvious political responsibilities.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. This report is a recommendation to the European Commission to promote transparency, coordination and convergence of corporate tax policies in the European Union. It reiterates the importance of implementing certain measures such as a country-by-country business report to improve tax transparency, a consolidated common corporate tax base gradually being put in place, and safeguards for whistleblowers.  We must draw lessons from the Luxleaks scandal, which has highlighted the unbridled and unfair competition that Member States are engaged in in the tax field. There is a need to improve transparency in the tax field within the Union by enabling greater information exchange between Member States.  Tax convergence and, ultimately, tax harmonisation is the solution to the problem of unfair tax competition.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 After careful consideration and discussion in this House, I voted in favour of the report with recommendations to the Commission on how to bring transparency, coordination and convergence to the Union's policies on corporate taxation. I believe that, in a European context characterised by a lack of investment and growth, a truly protective System of Community rules is also concerned with sectors of which there is little perception, namely that of the 'economic and financial health' of the Union. Moreover, it is only by means of a structured system of rules that transparency, coordination and convergence in company tax policies can be imposed. It is well known that with tax rulings many companies have benefited from tax rates of less than 1% on profits then transferred to Luxembourg and that tax avoidance could result in revenue losses for the Union of up to around EUR 160-190 billion per year, with significant administrative costs and burdens for citizens, businesses and SMEs. I agree with the report and with the proposed recommendations, in particular those on mandatory notification of new tax measures and the extension of the automatic exchange of information to all rulings. There is also an absolute need for a common definition of 'tax havens' as well as 'permanent organisation' of companies.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. – I was shadow rapporteur of this report and I was proactively involved in seeking to improve the text. I tabled over 30 amendments in order to improve the content of the report and to protect the interests of the Irish people.  However, whilst I recognise that there were a number of positive aspects of this report, specifically the focus on tax transparency and the need to address tax avoidance tools such as ‘Patent Boxes’, I am fundamentally concerned that the intention behind this report is to introduce tax harmonisation across Europe.  It is absolutely and fundamentally the right of the government of each Member State to legislate in the best interests of their citizens, particularly in the matter of direct taxation.  The intention behind this report has always been to introduce a single legislative proposal for a mandatory Common Consolidated Corporate Tax Base (CCCTB). My mandate on the Economic and Monetary Affairs Committee is to put the interests of Irish citizens first and foremost and that it does not serve their interests to have our sovereignty relinquished through any attempted tax harmonisation.  Therefore, I voted against this report and will do on any similar assaults on our economic sovereignty.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. – The title of this recommendation to the Commission highlights not just transparency but also coordination and convergence of corporate tax policies – in other words the ground is being prepared for harmonisation of corporate taxes across the EU, which will end the healthy tax competition between jurisdictions that is the only brake on ever-growing public expenditure. UKIP accordingly voted against tax harmonisation.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I am in favour of tax transparency and against tax fraud. However, I believe that fighting tax fraud does not mean that the EU should legally oblige Malta to introduce a Common Consolidated Corporate Tax Base (CCCTB). Tax related issues are and will remain national competences. I am convinced that a one-size-fits all approach is not the right way forward for Europe as the EU is not a homogenous area and not all regions in the EU face the same economic realities, be it for their domestic market size, geographical realities or resources. Inevitably it would be the EU’s smaller economies, such as Malta, that would bear the disproportionate brunt of such policies. For these reasons I voted against this report.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 Following the events surrounding the LuxLeaks scandal, the European Parliament decided in December 2014 to authorise the drafting of a legislative own-initiative report, which was aimed precisely at improving transparency, coordination and convergence in corporate tax policies in the Union. Many of the recommendations contained in the text were already present in a previous report, including public Country-By-Country reporting, automatic notification of certain tax measures, improved exchange of information, the introduction of the common consolidated corporate tax base, as well as measures to ensure legality – such as increased protections for whistleblowers, a clear definition of what falls under the category of tax havens and the measures needed to combat the fraudulent use of whistleblowers. Same. Despite some obvious points, the report is not satisfactory on others; An example of this is the absence of any reference to the political responsibilities of individuals and Member States, which in fact have facilitated the spread of these harmful practices for years. I have therefore chosen to abstain.

name: Jean-Marie CAVADA
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report and welcome its adoption. The fight against tax evasion and evasion must be a priority in all Member States, in order to preserve fair competition between economic actors, and to enforce tax justice. In my view, many of the measures in this report will address this challenge. In particular, I take the proposal for country-by-country reports on profits, taxes and subsidies for large companies, although I regret that the amendment to exempt SMEs from such a mechanism has been rejected. Similarly, I fully support the idea of a European definition of 'tax haven' and counter-measures for those who use it.  I believe that the establishment of a virtuous European corporate tax regime necessarily requires greater protection for whistleblowers, as the LuxLeaks scandal has taught us recently. With this in mind, I very much welcome the idea of legal protection for whistleblowers, which is essential for greater transparency of tax systems in Europe.

name: Nessa CHILDERS
text: in writing. ‒ Parliament is rightly signalling a strong message, after the Council watered down what were already very minimal proposals by the Commission on tax rulings. A truly single market can only function effectively within a more transparent and cooperative corporate taxation framework. Country-by-country reporting would represent an important step in the fight against tax evasion and avoidance, through a more transparent tax framework in Europe. The European Union should ensure that multinationals pay their taxes where they make their profits.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 We are opposed to this report because it wrongly targets a common single corporate tax for all EU member countries. We agree with the fight against tax evasion and fraud, but this is not linked and has nothing to do with the ability of countries to freely define their tax policy. In the name of the so-called fight against tax havens, you are wrongly trying to harm business and freedom to pursue tax policy by each country, by affecting the tax regime of the Member States. All you do is serve tax havens and direct foreign companies outside the EU to those very tax havens. It is inconceivable to call for a mandatory common corporate tax regime on the EU's free economies, when the EU has different rates of tax and VAT and when the EU is against the centralised economy. Moreover, the exercise of an independent tax policy by each Member State is a key component of the free economy and is an important tool for economic and social policy. You cannot and are not entitled to impose a common corporate tax on the Member States because this goes against the very principles of the open economy and the EU.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The report on achieving transparency, coordination and convergence in corporate tax policies in the Union concerns the Union as a whole. Despite the individual details and dysfunctions of the proposal, I finally decided to vote in favour of the report because it seeks to correct the dysfunctions of the Eurozone and achieve greater transparency.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this vote. Member States’ tax measures, particularly those that do not concern corporate tax, are sovereign decisions which should not be subject to scrutiny by other Member States.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 I agree with the legislative own-initiative report by Mr Dodds and Mrs Niedermayer on promoting transparency, coordination and convergence in corporate tax policies in the European Union, which, due to corporate tax avoidance, special tax arrangements and inefficiencies in collection, is found to lose hundreds of billions of euros a year. I believe that these practices should not be considered acceptable, all the more so in the difficult economic circumstances in which Europe finds itself at this historic moment, where it is essential that all economic actors contribute more than fairly. The failure of some multinational companies to contribute creates a situation of iniquity, in which smaller national companies struggle to compete, contrary to the principle of the single market. In addition, national governments are also affected by this behaviour because, in the face of a decrease in the tax base, they are forced to take into account the reduction of public services or the increase in taxes for citizens, thus causing obvious inconvenience to the population.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. – I reaffirm my position against an EU corporate tax policy while at the same time I underscore my firm belief in tax transparency and the fight against tax fraud. But to implement the latter there is no need for a mandatory introduction of a Common Consolidated Corporate Tax Base because the EU is not a homogenous area and not all regions in the EU face the same economic realities, be it for their domestic market size, geographical realities or resources. A one-size-fits all approach is not the right way forward for Europe as inevitably it would be the EU’s smaller economies, such as Malta, that would bear the disproportionate brunt of such policies.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. \u2012 Following the LuxLeaks scandal, the ECON Committee has drawn up a series of recommendations with the aim of improving transparency, coordination and convergence in corporate tax policies in the Union. The latter are present in the text that emerged from the TAXE report, among which we find a country-by-country public reporting, an automatic notification of certain tax measures, an improvement in the automatic exchange of information, the introduction (in two stages) of the common consolidated corporate tax base (CCCTB), greater protections for whistleblowers, a clear definition of what falls into the category of tax havens and the measures necessary to combat the use of this harmful practice as well. As with the TAXE report, here too there has been a clear desire to omit the political responsibilities of important individuals and particular Member States, which in fact have facilitated the spread of these harmful practices for years, which is unacceptable to us. Our amendments underline the political responsibility of Juncker and the Benelux countries, and propose the withdrawal of the licence to those companies (banks in particular) that operate through tax havens. For the above reasons, I have chosen to abstain.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. U2012 The internationalization of production requires fiscal harmonization and a clear accounting definition of taxes, in order to avoid the usual tax avoidance practices among large companies. It is also necessary to improve the transparency of the tax provisions of the Member States, in order to avoid a repeat of scandals such as that of LuxLeaks. These aspects are reflected in the report, although still insufficient. Nevertheless, I believe that the proposals allow the Commission and the Council to be pressured to fully reformulate the taxation policies of today's companies, so I voted in favour.

name: Andrea COZZOLINO
text: in writing. \u2012 Although the European Union has taken important steps towards economic integration, such as economic and monetary union and the Banking Union, further efforts are needed with regard to greater coordination of fiscal policies at Union level, within the limits set by the European Treaties. The coordination of company taxation policies is an indispensable factor in the integration process. I voted in favour of the European Parliament resolution because I believe that it makes some very important recommendations to the Commission to combat aggressive tax planning and evasion, such as: the creation of a country-by-country tax data collection system; greater transparency on tax rulings, protection of whistleblowers and coordination on corporate tax policies; creation of a common consolidated tax base as a system for simplifying and harmonising the definition of tax assets; the creation of a common European tax code and a firm policy on tax havens.

name: Miriam DALLI
