text: in writing. – When dealing with taxation I am always in favour of having proper tax transparency rules and boosting our fight against tax fraud and abuse. But this should not mean the implicit or explicit mandatory introduction of tax harmonisation or convergence, including also the mandatory introduction of a Common Consolidated Corporate Tax Base (CCCTB). Not all Member States in the EU have the same economic realities and small economies do face different economic and geographical realities, market size and resources which are different from larger economies. Small economies require flexibility to help them counterbalance the disadvantages which they otherwise would face. Tax matters should remain an issue of national competence which can help reflect these different realities. Otherwise, small economies like Malta would end up carrying the greatest burden. For these reasons I could not support this report.

name: Daniel DALTON
text: in writing. ‒ Whilst I am strongly in favour of tackling tax fraud, I cannot support this report, calling as it does for a common consolidated corporate tax base and infringing on Member State sovereignty over tax policy. I am fundamentally opposed to harmonisation of corporate tax rates in the EU; nation states should be able to decide their own tax rates as best suited to their national economies. The fight against tax fraud needs to be focused through the OECD and the G20; the EU should be rigorously following their work in exchanging information to detect fraud. For these reasons I cannot support this report.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This non-legislative initiative report makes recommendations to improve corporate tax transparency, coordination and convergence of corporate tax policies. This report is based on the work of Parliament's Special Committee on Tax Rulings (TAXE) chaired by my colleague Alain Lamassoure. The latter was created in the wake of the "LuxLeaks" revelations and its recommendations were approved in plenary session on 26 November.  In particular, the rapporteurs propose the introduction in stages by 2017 of a common corporate tax regime, a common definition on tax havens, and a series of legislative proposals aimed at improving the exchange of information between national administrations on tax rules, for example. Supporting the objectives of this report, I voted in favour of it.

name: Angélique DELAHAYE
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the Dodds and Niedermayer Report, which follows on from the analysis of the TAXE Commission (special commission on tax rulings in member states, set up in February 2015 following the "LuxLeaks" revelations) and formulates concrete proposals for the taxation of multinational companies in Europe.  This text greatly promotes transparency through country-by-country information and on all sectors that multinationals will be required to publish, the establishment of a new fair taxpayer label for companies complying with good tax practices and the mandatory disclosure of new tax measures by the European Commission. Through this vote, I wish to make public the mechanism for reporting activity and taxation country by country. Finally, the report stresses the need for a European legal regime to protect whistleblowers.

name: Andor DELI
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, because the proposals made there in it indicate both the Determination of the European Parliament and the Europeans to make legislative changes to prevent companies from jumping from country to country to reduce their tax obligations to almost zero. The Luxleaks scandal revealed exactly how much tax companies were getting rid of, avoiding paying money that could have been used to build schools, hospitals or reduce public debt. Corporate tax avoidance means billions of dollars in lost revenue to national budgets each year, leads to unequal competition between companies and undermines Europeans' faith in the state and government.  I believe that the rapid introduction of the measures proposed by Parliament and the OECD would not only make collecting national taxes more efficient, but would also make competition on the market fair and would cost companies less to comply with the law.

name: Jean-Paul DENANOT
text: In writing. Multinationals must pay their taxes where they make their profits! The report gives a definition of "aggressive tax optimisation" and recalls a number of recommendations from the TAXE commission, set up in the wake of the LuxLeaks scandal. These include country-by-country accounting reporting, reaffirming its public character; harmonizing the corporate tax base; Protecting whistleblowers The list of tax havens; Automatic exchange of tax ruling information; notification of new tax measures and the creation of property registers to combat money laundering.  I also supported two amendments rejected by the right advocating the creation of a fund dedicated to whistleblowers and strict regulation of the tax optimization industry making this type of assembly impossible. To want to play on all fronts - with states and multinationals - large audit firms too often flirt with conflict of interest.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. The aim of this report was to combat aggressive tax competition with the euro area, as well as to limit the possibility of fraud. While nearly 190 billion euros are lost each year in this area, reform was widely expected. Although the establishment of a whistleblower protection system, retaliatory measures against companies using tax havens and the overhaul of the code of conduct are certain advances, states are losing their sovereignty here. Indeed, while bilateral conventions allowed states to control the specificity of their tax systems, this report calls for a comprehensive framework. Attached to good tax conduct but also to the sovereignty of Member States in this area, I abstained.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 The idea of this document is good, but the implementation does not allow me to support it. The fight against tax evasion in the EU must be fought, on the one hand, by all Member States and, on the other hand, must be coordinated, because if this does not happen, what we are witnessing now will be monitored.  Multinationals will shift their accounting profits from some countries with high rates to those with lower rates, which will be a major contribution to the local budget and, on the other hand, to the Community budget. It can get even more unpleasant if we step up measures against base base reduction and profit shifting.  Do not turn out that all these revenues are transferred to offshore areas and/or to non-EU countries. We still have a lot of work to do to combat these abuses.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 It is proposed to vote in favour of the report, as it seeks to combat tax evasion and tax fraud by filling regulatory gaps with international tax matches.

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, because the proposals made there in it indicate both the Determination of the European Parliament and the Europeans to make legislative changes to prevent companies from jumping from country to country to reduce their tax obligations to almost zero. The Luxleaks scandal revealed exactly how much tax companies were getting rid of, avoiding paying money that could have been used to build schools, hospitals or reduce public debt. Corporate tax avoidance means billions of dollars in lost revenue to national budgets each year, leads to unequal competition between companies and undermines Europeans' faith in the state and government.  I believe that the rapid introduction of the measures proposed by Parliament and the OECD would not only make collecting national taxes more efficient, but would also make competition on the market fair and would cost companies less to comply with the law.

name: Eleonora EVI
text: in writing. In December 2014, the European Parliament decided to authorise this legislative own-initiative report in order to promote transparency, coordination and convergence of corporate taxation policies in the European Union. This decision was the direct reaction to the Luxleaks scandal. Every year, the EU loses around EUR 50-70 billion due to corporate tax avoidance through profit transfer alone. Such practices should never be considered acceptable, especially in difficult economic circumstances such as those facing Europe at this time, when Parliament considers it all the more essential that all economic actors contribute fairly. The lack of contribution from some multinational companies creates an iniquity environment, in which smaller national companies struggle to compete, and this is totally at odds with the principle of the single market. It is precisely from the point of view of fairness that the recommendation clearly shows a desire to completely omit the political responsibilities of important individuals and particular Member States, which in fact have facilitated, for years, the spread of these harmful practices. For this reason, although some of the proposed measures are acceptable, I have chosen to abstain.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. I abstained on this resolution because I am in favour of a policy of bilateral agreements on tax matters.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. The LUXLEAKS scandal and other investigations that followed showed that tax fraud and tax evasion are widespread practices in most Member States, with the knowledge of their governments.  This report aims to address ways of "ensuring transparency, coordination and convergence of corporate tax policies in the EU". The report contains positive recommendations, such as: - The submission of mandatory and public reports by country by multinational companies for all sectors; - Countermeasures in relation to companies that use tax havens; - adapting the definition of a permanent establishment so that undertakings cannot artificially avoid having a taxable presence in The Member States where they have an economic activity; - Improving the transfer pricing framework in the EU. The proposal to introduce a common consolidated corporate tax base can help combat the transfer of profits. But the application of this measure will not solve the problem on its very two. The report leaves the door to fiscal harmonisation ajar, through proposals which, in the name of combating tax avoidance and profit-making, aim to set the tone for the loss of yet another economic policy mechanism, this time fiscal policy. We abstained.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: in writing. – I voted against as I believe that the EU should have no say in Ireland’s tax affairs.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 In December 2014, the European Parliament decided to authorise the preparation of a legislative own-initiative report on transparency, coordination and convergence of corporate taxation policies in the European Union. The decision was a direct follow-up to the November 2014 LuxLeaks revelation by a consortium of journalists, which found that many multinationals had entered into secret contracts with the Luxembourg authorities that allowed them to reduce their tax liability, in some cases to nearly 1 percent, while creating little or no economic activity in the country. Recent experience has shown that Member States cannot act alone in the fight against aggressive tax planning. The very fact that we should have a single market within the European Union requires coordinated action. While maintaining the principle of sovereignty of Member States in relation to tax policy, there is a need for European Union legislative measures to improve transparency, coordination and convergence in tax policies in the European Union.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 Despite some considerations that I support, my vote will abstain as there is no sign of a clear denunciation of the Luxleaxs case and of the clear correlation with the political responsibilities of the Luxembourg Government.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report with recommendations to the Commission on achieving transparency, coordination and convergence in corporate tax policies in the Union because it seeks to combat tax evasion and tax fraud by filling regulatory gaps with international tax matches.

name: Ashley FOX
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report as tax is firmly a member state competency. Whilst I support the fight against tax fraud and tax evasion this is not the right forum. The OECD has made excellent progress in this arena and we do not need to duplicate it. This knee jerk reaction against the ‘LuxLeaks’ is neither necessary nor appropriate, rather it is a power grab by the EU.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ The European Parliament decided in December 2014 to authorise the drafting of a legislative own initiative report ‘Bringing transparency, coordination and convergence to Corporate Tax policies in the European Union’. This decision was a direct follow-up to the LuxLeaks revelations by a consortium of journalists in November 2014, which revealed that many multi-national companies concluded secret deals with the authorities of Luxembourg that allowed them to reduce their tax liability, in some cases to almost 1%, while creating little or no economic activity in that country. I supported the recommendation that will provide a new agenda for tax justice. More transparency, coordination and convergence are needed to fight tax fraud, tax avoidance and aggressive tax planning.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, because the proposals made there in it indicate both the Determination of the European Parliament and the Europeans to make legislative changes to prevent companies from jumping from country to country to reduce their tax obligations to almost zero. The Luxleaks scandal revealed exactly how much tax companies were getting rid of, avoiding paying money that could have been used to build schools, hospitals or reduce public debt. Corporate tax avoidance means billions of dollars in lost revenue to national budgets each year, leads to unequal competition between companies and undermines Europeans' faith in the state and government.  I believe that the rapid introduction of the measures proposed by Parliament and the OECD would not only make collecting national taxes more efficient, but would also make competition on the market fair and would cost companies less to comply with the law.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. I voted on the finding that we must increase transparency, coordination and convergence in corporate taxation policies in the Union. We cannot agree that, as a study commissioned by the European Parliament details, the EU will lose around EUR 50 000 to EUR 70 billion per year due to circumvention of corporation tax only by relocating profits. These practices are not acceptable under any circumstances.

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: in writing. We welcome the adoption of this own-initiative report which has run in parallel with the TAXE Commission, although more focused on recommendations than fact-based research. We welcome the fact that some purely socialist achievements have been incorporated into the report, such as the inclusion of the obligation to carry out country-by-country reports, the harmonisation of the corporate tax base (BICCIS), protection for whistleblowers, the establishment of a common definition of tax haven, or the automatic exchange of tax rulings. However, we must regret that, because of the opposition of the PPE, ALDE and ECR Groups, we have not been able to move forward in plenary with the creation of a European fund to assist whistleblowers, as well as more regulation for tax consulting firms. On the other hand, although it has not been incorporated into this report, we do not in the future renounce the creation of a European tax agency to manage the repertoire of tax rulings and the list of cross-border evadors.

name: Elisabetta GARDINI
text: in writing. \u2012 Even today, companies are all too often faced with unjustifiable tax differences. Much remains to be done to make the market truly fair and fully competitive. In this respect, transparency, coordination and convergence of policies are the right way forward. This report contains a number of measures along these lines, which is why I voted in favour of the report.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the EP own-initiative report on transparency, coordination and convergence in THE UNION's corporate taxation policies, because I believe it is essential to make progress on corporate taxation in Europe, so that it is fair, and especially companies, particularly multinational companies, pay taxes in the countries where income is actually produced and thus fight the phenomenon of aggressive tax planning at its root. In this parliamentary term, the EP has vigorously placed taxation issues, which are the responsibility of the Member States, at the centre of its debate. To this end, it has renewed its mandate to the TAXE Committee of Inquiry into tax rulings, it is focusing on the introduction of a common tax base which should be the focus of common corporate taxation (CCCTB), in order to promote, with this and other actions of coordination and convergence in the tax field, sustainable development and the strengthening of the competitiveness of SMEs. In its recommendations to the Commission, the EP calls for country-by-country reporting for all multinationals, mandatory notification of tax measures, greater transparency of free ports, protection of whistleblowers and an exhaustive list of countries to be considered tax havens.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Writing. I voted today in favour of the report 'Transparent design, coordination and approximation of corporate tax policy', as I support any measure in Europe that ensures greater tax justice and makes international corporations accountable, as every citizen or medium-sized company knows it.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Writing. Together with my colleagues in the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats, I have once again advocated effective and fair tax systems. A transparent corporate tax rate ensures that existing tax rules continue to be respected. However, the real problem is not the tax models of individual states. The lack of cooperation between Member States is the reason for the emergence of ever-new tax loopholes.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on corporate tax avoidance, because it is clear that something needs to be done about the billions and billions of pounds lost every year to tax evasion and aggressive tax avoidance.  People across the UK, and the EU, are rightly furious that they face higher taxes or cuts to public services as a result of multinational companies with clever advisers reducing their own tax bill to almost nothing.  This report sets out a clear plan for action at EU level that will stop these kinds of practices once and for all.  The Tories should be ashamed of voting against it, and David Cameron should listen to the voice of British and European people and act on these recommendations as soon as possible.

name: Bruno GOLLNISCH
text: In writing. The Dodds-Niedermayer report on corporate tax that we are voting on today is the logical counterpart of the Committee on Tax Rulings adopted last month. It has the same theme: the fight against aggressive tax competition and the double non-taxation of companies, especially multinationals that champion tax optimisation. I abstained on the final vote of this report: I support most of its proposals, which are the result of the OECD recommendations, with the exception of those which would give Brussels some power to harmonize direct taxes. I do not trust the Commission more in this area than in the others. But the road is going to be difficult to put some morality and justice back in the race for at least possible taxes, whose main victims are national budgets and captive taxpayers, SMEs and ordinary citizens.  In France, the National Assembly has just rejected "country reporting", which would have forced large transnational companies to publish their turnover, staff, taxes paid, etc. country by country. Of course, this amendment was probably perfectable, but its rejection, at the request of the Secretary of State for the Budget, is still symbolic.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. In 2012 We voted in favour of this report, with which the European Parliament is calling on the Commission to resume its work in order to establish a consolidation of the tax base of multinationals, which would help combat tax evasion and down-country tax competition. The document also contains other very interesting elements such as whistleblower protection and greater control of 'tax advisory' companies, which in many cases are complicit in evasion.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as it is clear that something needs to be done about the billions and billions of pounds lost every year to tax evasion and aggressive tax avoidance. This report, co-drafted by Labour MEP Anneliese Dodds, marks a major step forward. People across the UK, and the EU, are rightly furious that they face higher taxes or cuts to public services as a result of multinational companies with clever advisers reducing their own tax bills to almost nothing. This report sets out a clear plan for action at EU level that will stop these kinds of practices once and for all. The Tories should be deeply ashamed of voting against it. David Cameron should listen to the voice of British and European people and act on these recommendations as soon as possible.

name: Nathan GILL
text: in writing. ‒ The title of this recommendation to the Commission highlights not just transparency but also coordination and convergence of corporate tax policies – in other words the ground is being prepared for harmonisation of corporate taxes across the EU, which will end the healthy tax competition between jurisdictions that is the only brake on ever-growing public expenditure.  UKIP accordingly voted against tax harmonisation.

name: Enrique GUERRERO SALOM
text: written. - We value positively the approval of this own initiative report that has run in parallel with the TAXE Commission, although more focused on the recommendations than on the investigation of the facts. We are pleased that some purely socialist achievements have been incorporated into the report, such as the inclusion of the obligation to carry out country-by-country reports, the harmonization of the corporate tax base (CCCTB), the protection for whistleblowers, the establishment of a common definition of tax haven, or the automatic exchange of tax resolutions. However, we must regret that, due to the opposition of the PPE, ALDE and ECR Groups, we have not been able to carry out in plenary the creation of a European fund to assist complainants, as well as more regulation for tax consulting companies. On the other hand, and although it has not been included in this report, we will not renounce the creation of of a European tax agency that administers the repertoire of tax rulings and the list of cross-border evaders.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: in writing. - With the revelations of the LuxLeaks affair, the fight against tax evasion by large multinationals has become obvious. It is in this context that I supported the report by my colleague Dodds aimed at introducing rules at European level to prevent certain unscrupulous companies from using loopholes to dodge a tax that could have been used to build schools. and hospitals or pay down the national debt. By offering greater protection to whistleblowers and forcing companies to disclose the exact amount of their profits, tax justice will no longer be just empty words. Of course, we would have liked to go even further with the strengthened supervision of the "Big 4" (main listeners), but this text is already making good progress. Among these, I note the introduction of a mandatory and public report, country by country, the creation of a common consolidated tax base. (CCCTB), that is to say a single set of rules for cross-border companies making it possible to calculate taxable profits within the EU, the establishment of a common and convincing definition of tax havens, or even the automatic exchange of information on tax rulings and mandatory notification of new tax measures.

name: Jytte GUTELAND
text: written. - We Swedish Social Democrats voted in favor of the report as a whole. We welcome the fact that Parliament is pursuing an offensive and partly visionary line when it comes to combating tax evasion and aggressive tax planning. This is an area where further efforts are required and where an active development process is important to identify measures that work. All the recommendations in the report may or may not be realized in the near future, but it is still useful to establish a kind of agenda in this way. At the same time, it is important to emphasize that the setting of tax rates must essentially continue to be a national matter. It must be up to the Member States themselves to decide what tax levels are needed to secure sufficient revenue in the public budgets.

name: Sergio GUTIÉRREZ PRIETO
text: written. - We value positively the approval of this own initiative report that has run in parallel with the TAXE Commission, although more focused on the recommendations than on the investigation of the facts. We are pleased that some purely socialist achievements have been incorporated into the report, such as the inclusion of the obligation to carry out country-by-country reports, the harmonization of the corporate tax base (CCCTB), the protection for whistleblowers, the establishment of a common definition of tax haven, or the automatic exchange of tax resolutions. On the other hand, and although it has not been included in this report, we will not renounce the creation of of a European tax agency that administers the repertoire of tax rulings and the list of cross-border evaders.

name: András GYÜRK
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the Doods-Niedermayer report, which signals the determination of the European Parliament and Europeans to prevent legislative changes from reducing companies' tax obligations to almost zero. The Luxleaks scandal revealed exactly how much tax companies were exempt from, avoiding paying money from which schools, hospitals could have been built, or with which public debt could have been reduced. Corporate tax evasion results in billions in revenue losses for national budgets every year, creates unequal competition between companies and undermines Europeans ’faith in the state and government. I believe that the rapid introduction of the measures proposed by Parliament and the OECD would not only make the collection of national taxes more efficient, but would also make competition in the market fairer and reduce compliance for companies.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: GUE / NGL), in writing. - The report does not propose anything specific on the common corporate tax or anything new, but only focuses on the further exchange of tax information between Member States, which will, however, be coordinated by Brussels. Our firm position was against a common corporate tax because we believe that each Member State should retain the sovereign right to design and implement its tax policies. That is why we voted against the report.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I chose to abstain on this report due to the fact it contains a number of worrying elements such as calling for a full, mandatory CCCTB, calling for Member States to inform each other and the Commission of any new allowance, relief or incentive which could have a material impact on their effective tax rate, calling for mandatory, public country-by-country reporting for all multinationals and making claims that the ongoing state aid investigations have revealed a lack of transparency in the way state aid rules are applied.

name: György HÖLVÉNYI
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of this report. The proposals in the report express the will of the European Parliament and European citizens to finally put an end to changes in legislation that will reduce companies' tax liabilities to almost zero by making legislative changes. The Luxleaks scandal revealed exactly how much tax companies were exempt from, avoiding paying money from which schools, hospitals could have been built, or with which public debt would have been reduced. Corporate tax evasion results in billions in revenue losses for national budgets every year, creates unequal competition between companies and undermines Europeans ’faith in the state and government. I believe that the rapid introduction of the measures proposed by Parliament and the OECD would not only make the collection of national taxes more efficient and fairer in one fell swoop, but would also cost companies less. compliance with legislation. For the above reasons, I voted in favor of the report.

name: Mary HONEYBALL
text: in writing. ‒ It is clear that something needs to be done about the billions and billions of pounds lost every year to tax evasion and aggressive tax avoidance. This report, co-drafted by Labour MEP Anneliese Dodds, marks a major step forward. People across the UK, and the EU, are rightly furious that they face higher taxes or cuts to public services as a result of multinational companies with clever advisers reducing their own tax bills to almost nothing.  This report sets out a clear plan for action at EU level that will stop these kinds of practices once and for all.  The Tories should be deeply ashamed of voting against it. David Cameron should listen to the voice of British and European people and act on these recommendations as soon as possible.

name: Ian HUDGHTON
text: in writing. ‒ I do not support all the calls in this report and in particular oppose calls for a common consolidated corporate tax base.  Tax raising powers are and should remain a Member State competence.  Nevertheless, the EU does have a role to play in promoting transparency and eliminating tax evasion. This report makes a number of useful recommendations in this regard and on balance I was able to give it my qualified support.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of this report that will set out a list of measures that the Commission might propose as legislative acts with regard to transparency, convergence and coordination.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: written. - I voted in favor of the report with recommendations to the Commission on the introduction of transparency, coordination and convergence in corporate tax policies in the Union, because I believe that greater transparency in the field of corporate taxation can improve tax collection and efficiency of tax authorities, and that it is key to greater public confidence in tax systems and governments and that this should be a key priority. Furthermore, better coordination of national tax policies is certainly needed, as this is the only viable way to address BEPS and aggressive tax planning, where convergence is also needed, as the fact is that different rules on corporate taxation apply in different Member States. Therefore, I am voting in favor of this report, which asks the Commission to submit one or more legislative proposals by June 2016, in line with detailed recommendations.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. – The title of this recommendation to the Commission highlights not just transparency but also coordination and convergence of corporate tax policies – in other words the ground is being prepared for harmonisation of corporate taxes across the EU, which will end the healthy tax competition between jurisdictions that is the only brake on ever-growing public expenditure.  My colleagues and I accordingly voted against tax harmonisation.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the report by my colleagues Anneliese Dodds and Luděk Niedermayer to promote transparency, coordination and convergence of corporate tax policies. This report proposes concrete measures on the taxation of multinational companies in Europe. The aim is to do away with unfair tax practices that benefit certain large companies. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of this text because it formulates concrete proposals for the taxation of multinational companies in Europe, in particular concerning the transparency of each country on its tax system, the coordination of the tax base or the common definition of tax havens.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: written. - This report, on which I also participated as shadow rapporteur, is very balanced. Although some suggestions for expanding competencies should be treated with caution, it is generally necessary to carry out certain adjustments in order to avoid tax avoidance and tax evasion.

name: Krišjānis KARIŅŠ
text: in writing. - Unfortunately, there are 'gaps' in existing tax laws in EU Member States that are often exploited. The Member States of the European Union are losing and have lost huge sums of money due to corporate tax evasion in full and the deliberate aggressive tax policies of some Member States. This has seriously distorted fair competition in the European Union's single market. The report included recommendations for a fairer and more transparent corporate tax policy, including the recommendation that large multinational corporations should pay taxes in the Member State in which they do business and make a profit, rather than legally channeling those profits to other Member States that grant them tax credits. I believe that there is a need for greater coordination and transparency between Member States. National rights to compete in the field of taxation must be preserved, but competition between companies must be fair. I abstained in the vote on the resolution because, unfortunately, it also consists of proposals which would undermine the sovereignty of the Member States in the field of taxation. Each Member State now has the right to shape its own tax policy, and Latvia must be able to set taxes in a way that promotes entrepreneurship and attracts investment. The business and investment environment varies greatly from one Member State to another. I believe that certain points in this report threaten the sovereignty of the Member States with regard to tax matters.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report as it is clear that something needs to be done about the billions and billions of pounds lost every year to tax evasion and aggressive tax avoidance. People across the UK, and the EU, are rightly furious that they face higher taxes or cuts to public services as a result of multinational companies with clever advisers reducing their own tax bill to almost nothing. This report sets out a clear plan for action at EU level that will stop these kinds of practices once and for all. The Tories should be ashamed of voting against it, and David Cameron should listen to the voice of British and European people and act on these recommendations as soon as possible.

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of this report, as its proposals signal the determination of both the European Parliament and Europeans to finally implement legislative changes to reduce companies' tax obligations by bouncing from country to country to almost zero. The Luxleaks scandal revealed exactly how much tax companies were exempt from, avoiding paying money from which schools, hospitals could have been built, or with which public debt would have been reduced. Corporate tax evasion results in billions in revenue losses for national budgets every year, creates unequal competition between companies and undermines Europeans ’faith in the state and government. I believe that the rapid introduction of the measures proposed by Parliament and the OECD would not only make the collection of national taxes more efficient in one fell swoop, but would also make market competition fairer and cost companies less. COMPLIANCE WITH LAWS

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. - The Luxleaks scandal highlighted the fact that many multinational companies have implemented non-transparent practices in order to reduce the tax debt to almost 1%. Unfortunately, such aggressive tax planning practices are widespread across the EU. I believe it is of vital importance to coordinate national tax policies as much as possible, as we know that legislation in this area is the prerogative of the Member States. I have decided to vote in favor of this proposal as the measures listed could lead to greater transparency, coordination and convergence in Union policies on corporate taxation.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: in writing. - The Dodds Niedermayer own-initiative report follows the LuxLeaks scandal, but was launched in December 2014, three months before the establishment of the special committee. The theme is exactly the same: fighting aggressive tax competition at Union level and optimization schemes. The damage at the European level is evaluated as ranging from 50 to 70 billion euros per year for the relocation of profits alone, and from 160 to 190 billion euros if one includes special tax regimes and agreements and fraud. Once again, we regret the idea of abolishing bilateral conventions by multilateral agreements under the aegis of the Union, which would speak with one voice, insofar as the States thus lose control of these agreements. We abstain because there are positive points and negative points.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: in writing. - I abstained on this report because it is in favor of the fiscal integration to which I am opposed. It is a shame because its other recommendations, for example on the protection of whistleblowers or even on "reporting" by country for multinationals, are relevant.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: written. - This is a parallel report to that of Ferreira and Theurer as a result of the LuxLeaks scandal, although more focused on the recommendations than on the investigation of the facts. The report includes the obligation to carry out country-by-country reports, the harmonization of the corporate tax base (CCCTB), the protection for whistleblowers, the establishment of a common definition of tax haven, and the automatic exchange of resolutions. tributary. For these reasons, I have considered voting for it.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: written. - Due to the conclusion of agreements by various multinationals with Luxembourg authorities to reduce their tax obligations when the economic activity carried out in that country was practically non-existent, the European Parliament considers it necessary to increase transparency in the area of corporate taxation. These 'aggressive tax planning' practices are not only carried out in Luxembourg, but are spread throughout the EU. Obviously, these activities should not be tolerated under any circumstances, but even less so when we find ourselves in delicate economic circumstances. In the event that multinational companies do not contribute to applying these measures, it would generate a contradiction with respect to the principle of the single market, since the smaller national companies would not be able to compete in these unequal circumstances. This fact, in addition, would generate a great impact on national governments, which, faced with the reduction of income from fiscal taxation, they would be forced to consider cuts in the services provided by the State. In short, I believe that this report should be approved so that the EU can carry out coordination and transparency measures in the field of Union corporate tax and thus achieve favoring the conditions of the companies that are part of the European single market.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: written. - To enable the transfer of profits, in order to avoid paying taxes in the Member State where the added value is created, the European Union loses between 50 and 70 billion euros a year. With the loss of these funds, Member States are unable to stimulate growth factors, while burdening labor and production, thus stifling economic recovery, development and job creation. I supported the report because it proposes measures to help achieve transparency, coordination and convergence between Member States in order to avoid unfair tax practices and to enable fair taxation and tax competition. Achieving these goals would enable tax relief for those entities, small and medium-sized enterprises, which truly contribute to economic growth, development and job creation.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: in writing. - In addition to the major negative economic and economic effects on the Union and the Member States, tax evasion also has other effects in the form of distrust of people and businesses who comply with their tax obligations. The frauds detected, the scandals and the laxity of their solutions and sanctions demonstrate that the Union must take effective legislative action to improve transparency, coordination and convergence in corporate taxation policies in the Union, including sanctions and sanctions for those who do not respect and infringe the rules. Failure to address and delay the adoption of fundamental measures in this area will increase not only distrust in the fairness of the Union's legal system, but also the likelihood of further infringements and the emergence of new financial fraud.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. - I vote in favor of the report with the recommendations to the Commission on achieving transparency, coordination and convergence in corporate taxation policies in the Union, because it is complete and substantiated.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report on the legal steps needed to improve corporate tax transparency.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: in writing. - I abstained on this report which, although it has the laudable intention of fighting aggressive tax competition at Union level, once again takes the opportunity to steal a little more sovereignty from the Member States. Indeed, I regret that the parliamentarians of the TAXE committee have seen fit to abolish bilateral agreements through multilateral agreements negotiated under the aegis of the Union, causing de facto a loss of control of these agreements for the Member States, in favor of Brussels. Even if I recognize the usefulness of certain proposed measures, such as the regulation of free ports or even retaliatory measures for companies using tax havens, I cannot however speak in favor of them.

name: Jiří MAŠTÁLKA
text: in writing. - Today, we voted on a report with a very pleasing title, but which essentially seeks to introduce full harmonization in the area of tax policy in the case of corporate taxation in the EU. Of course, there are elements in the report that I support, such as the need to combat tax evasion, aggressive tax planning, tax havens or non-transparency and tax fraud. However, I remain convinced that tax policy should remain fully within the competence of individual Member States and that the EU is not prepared for any harmonization of tax rates in this area due to differences between Member States. Therefore, I could not support the report and I voted against.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing. - This report calls for the creation of methods for introducing greater transparency and convergence of Union policies in the field of corporate taxation. A report that I fully agree with and with respect to which, therefore, I can only vote in favor. In fact, a study commissioned by the European Parliament shows how the EU loses about 50-70 billion euros a year due to the tax avoidance of companies carried out solely through the transfer of profits, a figure that then rises to about 160- 190 billion euros, if we take into consideration the particular tax agreements and the inefficiencies in collection.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: written. - My support for the report with the recommendations that the European Parliament makes to the Commission on increasing transparency, coordination and convergence in tax policies for companies in the Union. We cannot continue to allow ourselves to lose billions of euros every year due to corporate tax avoidance solely through the offshoring of profits. These practices should not be acceptable under any circumstances, but in difficult economic circumstances, such as those facing Europe today, MEPs consider it essential that all economic players contribute equitably.

name: Emmanuel MAUREL
text: in writing. - The Dodds-Niedermayer resolution ends a year of fiscal awakening in Europe, initiated by the European Parliament. The automatic and obligatory exchange with regard to tax “rulings”, the hearing and research work of the special TAX committee, its progressive report and the decision to renew the committee's mandate, these advances are confirmed. But the resolution, an initiative of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, carried by two co-rapporteurs from opposing political families, deepens the positions of the European Parliament and details new recommendations. The text also provides a more precise observation of optimization practices and the state of corporate taxation in the European Union. In addition, he is in favor of a rigorous and objective method for establishing a European list of tax havens, associated with very comprehensive sanctions for all those who resort to it. In In addition, it supports greater transparency by proposing that any new tax measure (abatement, credit, special rate) be communicated to the other Member States and added to a centralized register. Because it crowns, on these aspects as on many other essentials, the protection of whistleblowers, the harmonization of the corporate tax base, I voted in favor of this text.

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: S&D), in writing. - There are positive elements in the report, such as those about greater transparency and others, but in my opinion they are not enough to vote in favor of the report. My objection focuses mainly on the fact that the report contains terms and descriptive references that may be politically acceptable but of dubious legal content, such as those on an aggressive tax rate. The report makes a correlation between legal low tax systems, which are described as aggressive tax planning systems and which "often lead to the use of a combination of international tax inconsistencies, very favorable specific national tax rules and tax havens". But a similar correlation without being put corporate tax base, which inevitably aims to converge the corporate tax rate of the Member States. This, however, works against the ability of Member States to set their own taxation in the context of free competition and also undermines the competitive advantage of small island and remote Member States in particular, which have built a balanced system for decades using their available resources. focus on their human resources.

name: Georg MAYER
text: written. - A very balanced report in and of itself. However, there are some suggestions for expanding competencies: European definition of standards for the withdrawal of commercial licenses from companies that have participated in tax avoidance, European control and auditing of tax advisors, CCCTB, etc. I do not consider such centralization to be welcome. Therefore I abstain from voting.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained overall on this report as a number of aspects are of a sensitive nature for Ireland.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: in writing. - Following the LuxLeaks affair, ie the practice of advantageous tax agreements between Luxembourg and a number of multinationals, this report proposes “better tax coordination” within the EU. If the report contains good proposals such as the obligation for multinationals to publish their turnover by sector and country or the legal protection of whistleblowers, it also proposes clearly anecdotal measures such as the creation of a “loyal taxpayer” label for companies that pay their taxes. How about a medal? In fact this is very revealing of the spirit of this text which claims to fight against tax fraud without really wanting to attack those who practice it. In this context, I am abstaining so as not to discourage good intentions without condoning the weakness of the measures proposed.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the report on ensuring the transparency, coordination and convergence of corporate tax policies in the Union. In the debates held by the European Parliament's TAXE Committee, it became clear that aggressive tax planning practices are not limited to just Luxembourg, but they are quite widespread across the EU. According to a study requested by the European Parliament, the EU loses around 50 to 70 million euros a year through corporate tax avoidance and the transfer of profits. It is extremely important that legislative measures are taken at EU level in order to improve the transparency, coordination and convergence of corporate taxation policies in the Union.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ Even though I support the Union’s efforts to tackle illicit financial flows and promote transparency, I could not support this report as it contained references to the creation of a common consolidated corporate tax base which infringes on Member States’ national competences.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: in writing. - The revelations of the LuxLeaks scandal have highlighted the importance of promoting transparency, coordination and convergence of corporate tax policies within the Union. The European Parliament has adopted a series of recommendations in this sense which I would like to welcome. Strengthening transparency in the field of corporate taxation must be a priority for the European Union. In particular, it will improve tax collection and more broadly strengthen citizens' confidence in tax systems. This report sets out a series of proposals which the Commission and the Member States should absolutely take into account. It is time for the Union to adopt effective legislation that will have the task of preventing base erosion and profit shifting. When it comes to international tax regimes, the Union's unique representation on the international scene is also essential. a priority that the European Union must tackle.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I have stated previously that as far as taxation at EU level is concerned, I have always been in favour of transparency, coordination and exchange of information. I support measures targeting abuse, enhancing transparency and addressing instances of harmful tax competition in the area of corporate taxation as promulgated by international standards. However, the Dodds report goes beyond those objectives and calls for measures to bring forward, as soon as possible, a legislative proposal for the introduction of a common consolidated corporate tax base and various actions towards the introduction of tax harmonisation at European level. In my opinion a move towards an EU-wide basis to introduce tax convergence and harmonisation in direct tax matters, forcing a one-size-fits all approach, can put small countries such as Malta into a disadvantaged position. Therefore I voted against the Dodds report.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: in writing. - The report of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs partly concludes from the draft report of the Special Committee on Conditional Tax Determinations and Other Measures Similar in Nature or Effect, and partly concludes that aggressive tax planning practices are Member States' corporate tax policies need to be harmonized, harmonized and approximated. He therefore proposes that Parliament ask the Commission to submit one or more legislative proposals to Parliament by the end of June 2016. The annex to the report provides detailed recommendations on the content of these legislative proposals. I supported the report.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: in writing. - This own-initiative report paints a worrying picture of the aggressive tax optimization practices of multinationals, quantifying the damage to the public finances of Member States at an amount of between 60 and 170 billion euros per year. The recommendations that are made are for the most part laudable, in line with the main lines of the OECD plan (reporting by country, ACIS, control of transfer prices, etc.). On the other hand, he recommends substituting the EU for states in international tax conventions, and eradicating bilateral conventions. It would also have benefited from going further in terms of sanctions against consulting firms participating in aggressive optimization schemes, in particular by strictly separating advisory activities to governments and companies. In the end, the report obliges the Commission more directly to embark on the path of these reforms, but the largely redundant nature of the conclusions with those of the special TAX committee encourages abstaining from the final vote.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: in writing. - The Dodds Niedermayer own-initiative report largely duplicates the report of the special TAX committee. It also follows the LuxLeaks scandal, but was launched in December 2014, three months before the establishment of the special commission, hence this redundancy. The theme is exactly the same: fighting aggressive tax competition at Union level and optimization schemes. The damage at European level is assessed at an amount between 50 and 70 billion euros per year for the relocation of profits alone, and 160 to 190 billion euros if we include special tax regimes and agreements and frauds. The conclusions are broadly convergent, but we can regret the idea of abolishing bilateral conventions in favor of multilateral agreements under the aegis of the Union, which would speak with one voice, since the States would thus lose control. of these agreements. We note some different proposals, such as the regulation of free ports, for more transparency. The proposal to strictly regulate conflicts of interest in consulting companies was unfortunately rejected in committee. In view of these shortcomings, I am abstaining from this report.

name: Claude MORAES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on corporate tax avoidance, because it is clear that something needs to be done about the billions and billions of pounds lost every year to tax evasion and aggressive tax avoidance.  People across the UK, and the EU, are rightly furious that they face higher taxes or cuts to public services as a result of multinational companies with clever advisers reducing their own tax bill to almost nothing.  This report sets out a clear plan for action at EU level that will stop these kinds of practices once and for all.  The Tories should be ashamed of voting against it, and David Cameron should listen to the voice of British and European people and act on these recommendations as soon as possible.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of this report, which calls for promoting transparency, coordination and convergence of corporate tax policies. This text recalls in particular that measures allowing aggressive tax optimization are incompatible with the principle of loyal cooperation between the Member States. Stemming from the work of the TAXE committee, this report aims to combat tax evasion, which leads to distortions of competition detrimental to growth and to EU businesses, especially SMEs.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. - We strongly support this measure, which became essential following the revelations, known as "LuxLeaks" by a group of journalists in November 2014, which revealed that many multinational companies have concluded secret agreements with the Luxembourg authorities which have allowed them to reduce their tax obligations, in some cases, to nearly 1 percent, in the face of creating little or no economic activity in that country. This report makes us proud as it creates a new agenda for tax justice, as it introduces more transparency and coordination and convergence mechanisms, which are needed to combat tax fraud, tax evasion and aggressive tax planning.

name: Alessandra MUSSOLINI
text: in writing. - It is necessary that all economic actors fulfill the envisaged tax obligations in a responsible and fair manner. The need to stick to this assumption is now more pressing than ever, in light of the economic difficulties that the European Union is forced to face. On the basis of what has been said, I have decided to support favorably the report signed by colleagues Dodds and Niedermayer, which proposes forward-looking measures in the field of corporate taxation, the aim of which is to restore a balanced and transparent system.

name: József NAGY
text: in writing. - I welcome the report on transparency, coordination and convergence of corporate tax policies in the European Union. The importance and timeliness of the report is underpinned, inter alia, by the 'aggressive tax planning' carried out by multinational companies linked to Luxembourg, which has resulted in a reduction in the tax liability of the companies concerned to a minimum. Cases like this and such things are a great loss of money for the European Union. In order to prevent the differences between the laws of the Member States from being exploited for unjustified tax reductions, we must act in unison and set up a comprehensible, easy-to-understand system that prevents the so-called use of loopholes.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒  I have voted for this report that will create clear guidelines for country-by-country reporting, with the purpose of increasing transparency while maintaining data protection and competitive advantage for EU firms.

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: in writing. - I am pleased that the EP, even with my voice, has supported the report of which I was co-rapporteur, which calls on the Commission to come forward with legislative and non-legislative measures to combat unfair tax practices in countries and aggressive corporate tax planning. Differences in tax rules, different regimes vis-à-vis third countries or the specific unfair tax policies used by some countries allow large multinational companies in particular to legally reduce their tax payments in the EU. Smaller companies that do not have such options pay for it. Estimates say that European state budgets lose around € 50-150 billion in corporate income taxes each year. The efficiency of corporate tax collection in Europe will increase as EU Member States better coordinate their tax policies, repeal unfair provisions in their regulations and work together with third countries. Today's vote has taken an important step towards such changes.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: written. - It is true that the title of this report promises to be closer to the citizen and more transparency, but I consider the individual measures to be unsuitable for achieving these goals. In the end, another report that aims at more Brussels influence at the expense of the nation states and dresses this in fine words. Therefore I would have abstained from voting.

name: Urmas PAET
text: in writing. - I supported. Tax fraud and tax evasion cause great damage to the EU and its Member States and also create inequalities between companies. Coordinated action and some common action within the EU are needed to stop it.

name: Margot PARKER
text: in writing. ‒ The title of this recommendation to the Commission highlights not just transparency but also coordination and convergence of corporate tax policies – in other words the ground is being prepared for harmonisation of corporate taxes across the EU, which will end the healthy tax competition between jurisdictions that is the only brake on ever-growing public expenditure.  UKIP accordingly voted against tax harmonisation.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: in writing. – The extent of the cost of aggressive tax planning in the EU is estimated of annual revenue losses ranging from EUR 50-70 to EUR 160-190 billion.  Fighting tax evasion and tax fraud, and the related opacity and secrecy, requires actions at EU and international level. Tackling aggressive tax planning is a major aim of cooperation at EU level, in particular in corporate taxation, where the objective is to reduce the number of loopholes stemming from the complex array of rules, assessment bases and rates which may apply to a single firm. I support the report that urges for bringing transparency, coordination and convergence to corporate tax policies in the Union.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: written. - The report with recommendations to the Commission on the introduction of transparency, coordination and convergence of corporate tax policy in the Union is a consequence of the Luxleaks scandal. Although its creation was prompted by discoveries that fundamentally shook Member States' tax policies and called into question the work of their tax administrations, the good thing is that it has accelerated the decision-making process on changes in tax policies, in this case with particular emphasis on corporate tax . Corporate and individual taxation certainly needs to be further regulated and this can be achieved precisely by increasing and improving the transparency, coordination and convergence of national tax policies. Aggressive tax planning, tax base erosion, profit shifting, tax evasion and other tax fraud lead to a tax gap that significantly affects government revenues and the introduction of unpopular measures, such as rising VAT rates, the introduction of new taxes (e.g. real estate taxes is just being run wide debate here in Croatia) or an increase in national indebtedness. We must prevent such occurrences, and this is what this report says, and I fully agree with that. I also supported this report because I believe that the recommendations given are sufficiently detailed and hit the point. I particularly welcome measures such as mandatory public reporting by Member State for all multinational companies in all sectors.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: in writing. - The Dodds Niedermayer own-initiative report largely duplicates that of the special TAX committee. It also follows the LuxLeaks scandal, but was launched in December 2014, three months before the establishment of the special commission, hence this redundancy. The theme is exactly the same: fighting aggressive tax competition at Union level and optimization schemes. The damage at European level is evaluated at an amount between 50 and 70 billion euros per year for the relocation of profits alone, and between 160 and 190 billion if we include special tax regimes and agreements and fraud. The conclusions are broadly convergent, but we can regret the idea of abolishing bilateral conventions in favor of multilateral agreements under the aegis of the Union, which would speak with one voice, since the States would thus lose control. of these agreements. We note some different proposals, such as the regulation of free ports, for more transparency. The proposal to strictly regulate conflicts of interest in consulting companies was unfortunately rejected in committee. In view of these shortcomings, I am abstaining from this report.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: written. - I support the proposed recommendations on legislation to improve the transparency, coordination and convergence of corporate tax policy in the Union. The proposed measures, prepared by the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs and colleagues Anneliese Dodds and Luděk Niedermayer, are based on the work of the EP's Special Committee on Tax Decisions and its recommendations approved earlier last month. The Lux Leaks case, when a consortium of journalists investigating tax decisions and other harmful practices in Luxembourg, announced that almost 340 multinational companies had entered into secret agreements with Luxembourg, which best indicates the urgency of adopting and implementing the proposed measures. We need comprehensive and public reporting by country for all multinational companies in all sectors and an amendment to Directive 2011/16 / EU, which includes proposals for the automatic exchange of information on tax decisions. It is unacceptable that the EU loses around 50 to 70 billion euros every year due to avoidance payment of tax earned through its transfer. That figure rises to about 160 to 190 billion euros, if we take into account special tax arrangements and inefficiencies in tax collection. These are significant resources that we need to control and use more efficiently.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: written. - I agree with the report with recommendations to the Commission on the introduction of transparency, coordination and convergence in corporate tax policies in the Union, by Dodds and Niedermayer. In November 2014, an international consortium of investigative journalists published information that almost 340 multinational companies had entered into secret agreements with Luxembourg with the aim of minimizing their global taxes to the detriment of the Union's public interest. It was also revealed that between 2002 and 2010, some tax advisers targeted multinational companies to obtain at least 548 tax decisions in Luxembourg. Due to the aforementioned affair in Luxembourg, I call on the Commission to take all necessary steps to introduce country-by-country public reporting for all multinational companies in all sectors by early 2016. I believe that greater transparency in the area of corporate taxation can improve tax collection and the efficiency of tax authorities, and that it is crucial for ensuring greater public confidence in tax systems and governments and that this should be an important priority. I firmly believe that progress in the fight against tax evasion, tax avoidance and aggressive tax planning can only be monitored through a harmonized methodology that can assess the size of direct and indirect tax gaps in all Member States and in the Union as a whole.

name: Pavel POC
text: in writing. - As in the past, I have now supported the report on the introduction of transparency, coordination and convergence in the field of corporate tax collection. I consider it very important for multinational companies to report publicly whether they pay taxes where they are economically active. I no longer want to tolerate the fact that states rob each other or, better said, allow their own citizens to be robbed. I therefore supported the protection of whistleblowers, without whom dishonesty, breaches of regulations, fraud or illegal activities of large corporations would very rarely be detected. This relevant information needs to be disclosed to either national or European authorities, which will then take the relevant measures. I also voted in favor of calling for a strict definition and updating of the list of tax havens, because they are the ones that allow businesses to harm the public interest in another state. I supported the mandatory notification of new tax measures, which should be become part of the annual European Semester process, and the introduction of sanctions if Member States refuse to cooperate. It is no longer possible to conceal unfair practices, which put SME positions at a great disadvantage and cost ordinary taxpayers billions of euros. As MEPs are directly accountable to their constituents, it is essential that the European Parliament be involved as much as possible in the information and scrutiny process.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. - According to a study commissioned by the European Parliament, the EU loses around € 50-70 billion annually due to corporate tax avoidance achieved through profit shifting alone. This figure rises to around € 160-190 billion, also taking into consideration the special tax arrangements, inefficiencies in collection and other elements. Such practices should never be considered acceptable, however, in difficult economic circumstances such as those facing Europe in this period, the report considers it even more essential that all economic actors contribute equitably. In November, Parliament adopted the Commission's Special Report on Tax Agreements, calling for mandatory reporting of multinational profits and taxes in each country. Today the Commission is asked to invite Member States to share tax information, to declare tax rates negotiate with companies and protect whistleblowers who have made it possible to uncover scandals such as Luxleaks. For all of this, I voted in favor of this report.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: in writing. - I very much support the fight against tax evasion and tax evasion. On the other hand, however, I cannot support attempts to harmonize direct taxes, because that corresponds not only to my belief that there should be full tax competition in the EU, but also to the election program for which I was elected to this House by Czech voters. Therefore, I could not support the report as a whole.

name: Franck PROUST
text: in writing. - I voted for the Dodds / Niedermayer report promoting transparency, coordination and convergence of corporate tax policies within the Union. This is a major subject which follows the excellent analytical work of the TAXE commission chaired by Alain Lamassoure and which formulates concrete proposals for the taxation of multinational companies in Europe. Our companies face major challenges, but do not always have the financial means for their ambitions. Tax is due for the good of the community. If some people bypass and avoid this type of levy as much as possible, we must be able to recover these sums for the community without of course hindering the investment of our companies so that they remain efficient and competitive.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ The title of this recommendation to the Commission highlights not just transparency but also coordination and convergence of corporate tax policies – in other words the ground is being prepared for harmonisation of corporate taxes across the EU, which will end the healthy tax competition between jurisdictions that is the only brake on ever-growing public expenditure.  UKIP accordingly voted against tax harmonisation.

name: Dominique RIQUET
text: in writing. - The revelations of the LuxLeaks scandal (tax avoidance and dumping) have once again demonstrated the need to continue cooperation and fiscal convergence between the Member States. This is why I voted in favor of the report containing recommendations to the European Commission to promote transparency, coordination and convergence of corporate tax policies within of the Union. In this perspective, the report proposes the establishment of a number of incentive and regulatory measures. From a regulatory point of view, it calls for strengthening the transparency of multinational firms which, for years, have resorted to aggressive tax optimization practices, taking advantage of the disparities in taxation within the Union. In addition, the report recommends the obligation to inform the other States of the Union of the new fiscal measures which they plan to adopt. Through elsewhere, the European Parliament invites the Commission to set up a “loyal taxpayer” label in order to promote the good practices of companies which submit to the fair payment of taxes in the countries where they generate their profits.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: in writing. - "Aggressive tax planning" practices are widespread across the EU. This phenomenon consists of taking advantage of the technical aspects of a tax system in order to reduce tax obligations. Although it is not the same as tax evasion and fraud, which are illegal activities, in essence the three practices reduce the tax base, undermining confidence in governments and companies. The EU loses around EUR 70 billion a year due to corporate tax avoidance, simply through the transfer of profits. Such practices are never acceptable, even more so in difficult economic circumstances, such as those facing Europe today. If some multinational companies do not contribute, then a level playing field ceases to exist and smaller national companies find it difficult to compete, which is completely opposite to the principle of the single market. Recent experience shows that Member States cannot act individually in the fight against aggressive tax planning. Respecting the sovereignty of the Member States in matters of tax policy, it is necessary to adopt legislative measures at EU level in order to improve the transparency, coordination and convergence of corporate tax policies in the Union.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: in writing. - Today the European Parliament was called upon to vote on an important report in order to promote transparency, coordination and convergence of corporate tax policies. An important report which follows in particular the "LuxLeaks" cases and whose recommendations should prevent companies from crossing borders in Europe with the sole aim of reducing their tax bills. I voted in favor of this report in order to demand a rapid reaction from the Commission in the face of aggressive tax optimization orchestrated in particular by multinationals. We cannot accept these practices as the repercussions for citizens and society as a whole are major. For example, in my view, it is urgent for the Commission to present a proposal for companies' annual reports to include country by country their profits, taxes and subsidies and for this information to be public. Just as it is urgent that the Commission make a proposal for a common base for corporate tax. Finally, I also voted in favor of strengthening the protection of whistleblowers, which in my view is currently insufficient.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. - The aggressive tax practices carried out in some Member States of the European Union have caused a great deal of controversy and controversy, being even more publicly known since the propagated "Lux Leaks" case (11/2014). In February of this year, the European Parliament created a special commission on aggressive tax practices which was intended to "investigate practices with respect to the application of tax law and EU state aid legislation in relation to tax decisions. and other measures of the same nature or effect taken by the Member States, if those practices constitute an act of a Member State or the Commission ", as could be read in the text of the decision that created it. The Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs has also decided to produce its own own initiative report proposing legislative actions on this matter, which was voted in favor of me. Of the proposals contained in this report, which are divided into four areas, namely transparency, coordination, convergence and other measures, I would just like to highlight public reports describing the situation in each of the Member States, the creation of a common and convincing definition for 'tax havens 'and improving the exchange of information between tax administrations.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the report "Bringing transparency, coordination and convergence into European Union policies on corporate taxation" as I believe that European businesses need a fairer, more transparent, more efficient and possibly stable. To do this, greater convergence and cooperation between EU Member States in tax matters is needed. The differences between the various national tax systems make the controls on tax evasion and tax avoidance difficult which entail: lost earnings in the coffers of states already deeply affected by the crisis, an unbalanced distribution of costs among taxpayers and unfair competition between large multinationals towards small and medium enterprises and self-employed workers.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: written. - We have voted in favor of this report, with which the European Parliament asks the Commission to resume its work with a view to establishing a consolidation of the tax base of multinationals, which would help combat tax evasion and tax competition to the low between countries. The document also contains other very interesting elements such as the protection of whistleblowers and greater control of "tax advisory" companies, which in many cases are complicit in tax evasion.

name: Alfred SANT
text: in writing. ‒ I agree with all proposals in this report which make recommendations regarding an improvement in transparency related to the taxation measures applying in EU Member States. I fully support measures uniquely designed to promote full transparency in national tax treatments. However the report basically proposes measures that implicitly or explicitly promote moves that on an EU-wide basis would introduce tax convergence and harmonisation. This goes against the interests of smaller economies of the Union, which lack the endowments of the larger economies. Their flexibility in policy making is already constrained among others, by the convergence in VAT rates, state aid rules, the single currency, the six pack/two  pack rules applied to their budgets. As a result, structural divergences between parts of the Union have grown, not diminished. Reducing the tax flexibility of such economies would further increase these disparities, which is unfair, dysfunctional and unacceptable. Tax competition should remain part of the limited array of decision tools available to national economies.  For these reasons, I have voted against the Report.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: written. - The internationalization of production requires tax harmonization and a clear accounting definition of taxes, in order to avoid the usual tax avoidance practices among large companies. It is also necessary to improve the transparency of the tax provisions of the Member States, in order to avoid the repetition of scandals such as that of LuxLeaks. These aspects are reflected in the report, although in a still insufficient way. Despite this, I believe that the proposals make it possible to put pressure on the Commission and the Council to comprehensively reformulate the tax policies of current companies, which is why I voted in favor.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this resolution because it calls on the Commission to introduce EU Tax Information Numbers. This could allow the EU to enter into tax agreements with third party countries; instead I believe this should be done on a bilateral basis.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ It is quite clear that something needs to be done about the billions of pounds lost every year to tax evasion as well as aggressive tax avoidance. This is why I voted in favour of this report that sets out a clear plan of action for action at EU level that will stop these kinds of practices once and for all. People across the West Midlands – as well as the rest of the EU – are rightly annoyed that they face higher taxes and cuts to public services because of multinationals reducing their own tax contribution to the society from which they have been able to grow their businesses and profits. The Tories should be ashamed that they voted against this report. David Cameron and his Party should listen to the voices of the British and European people and act on these recommendations as soon as possible.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
