text: in writing. - According to a study commissioned by the EP, the EU loses € 50-70 billion a year due to corporate tax avoidance through profit shifting. This figure increases to € 16-190 billion, taking into account special tax regimes, tax shortcomings and other elements. Such practices are unacceptable because, in complex economic crises, all those involved in the economy must contribute on an equitable basis. If some multinational companies do not contribute, unequal conditions arise under which, in particular, small and medium-sized enterprises cannot compete and are forced to lay off workers, respectively. restrict the production and provision of services. This results in a reduction in tax bases as well as less funding for national governments and a reduction in public services. In combating aggressive tax planning, Member States must act in a coordinated manner, while maintaining the principle of Member State sovereignty. For this reason, they must be within the EU legislative measures to improve transparency, coordination and convergence in tax policies in the Union. That is why I also supported the motion for a resolution.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: in writing. - Aggressive tax planning has serious consequences for Member States' tax revenues. As a result, they are forced to raise taxes, reduce public services or take on additional debt. National tax laws are the sole responsibility of the Member States. They take unilateral measures to combat unfair practices, which are often ineffective. Most of the problems are cross-border in nature. The highest price is paid by small and medium-sized enterprises, which by their nature operate in one country, while multinationals take advantage of differences in tax systems and gain an unjustified competitive advantage through manipulation. The report in question contains a series of recommendations to the Commission to submit legislative proposals aimed at harmonizing corporate tax policy. This would reduce the extent of harmful tax competition in the EU and begin implementing the Organization for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) guidelines into EU law. The report also calls on the Commission to decisive and swift action, including a proposal for Member States' public and mandatory reporting, the protection of whistleblowers and a more comprehensive definition of tax havens, providing for countermeasures for companies that also create these tax havens. I believe that the report contains proposals for the most appropriate measures that will be key to better coordinating the tax policies of the Member States, which is why I supported the report.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: in writing. - This proposal contributes to stepping up the fight against tax fraud, tax evasion and avoidance through the promotion of clearer, more transparent and fair rules between Member States.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: written. - I support this bill on the introduction of transparency, coordination and convergence in corporate tax policies in the Union, because the European Union has made great strides towards economic integration, such as economic and monetary union and banking union, and the harmonization of tax policies at Union level within the limits set by the Treaty, an integral part of the integration process. Tax decision-making practices can be a legitimate way to provide the necessary legal certainty to companies and reduce financial risk for honest companies, but are nonetheless vulnerable to potential abuse and tax evasion, and in the case of providing legal certainty only to selected actors between undertakings to which decisions have been assigned and undertakings which do not benefit from such decisions. The most appropriate response to aggressive tax planning is good legislation, its proper implementation and international coordination of how the desired outcomes would be achieved.

name: Catherine STIHLER
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on corporate tax avoidance, because it is clear something needs to be done about the billions and billions of pounds lost every year to tax evasion and aggressive tax avoidance. People across the UK, and the EU, are rightly furious that they face higher taxes or cuts to public services as a result of multinational companies with clever advisers reducing their own tax bill to almost nothing. This report sets out a clear plan for action at EU level which will stop these kinds of practices once and for all. The Tories should be ashamed of voting against it, and David Cameron should listen to the voice of British and European people and act on these recommendations as soon as possible.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: written. - An international consortium of investigative journalists, investigating tax decisions and other harmful practices in Luxembourg (LuxLeaks), announced in November 2014 that almost 340 multinational companies had entered into secret agreements with Luxembourg. Many of them have been allowed to minimize their global taxes to the detriment of the Union's public interest, with little or no economic activity in Luxembourg. National political leaders, with a few laudable exceptions, have not shown sufficient willingness to address the problem of tax evasion when it comes to income taxation. The total loss of government revenue as a result of tax evasion is most often offset by an increase in the overall level of taxation, cuts in public services, or an increase in national borrowing, damaging other tax bonds as well as the economy as a whole. I accept the Council's position at first reading because I consider how the Union and the Member States should take equally decisive measures to tackle tax evasion and tax fraud in the taxation of undertakings and natural persons.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: in writing. - I did not support the proposal, as the present proposal focuses mainly on the harmonization of taxation within the EU, which I fundamentally reject.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the report on promoting transparency, coordination and convergence in corporate tax policies. I support transparency in the field of corporate tax and the coordinated action of the Member States in this area. A study commissioned by the European Parliament shows that the EU loses around € 50-70 billion each year by shifting profits from corporate tax evasion alone, which is a very worrying figure.

name: Kay SWINBURNE
text: in writing. ‒ While the issues of tax fraud and tax avoidance by companies are extremely important, I do not believe that the correct level to deal with them is within the EU. This report calls for common taxation at an EU level, a proposal that I fundamentally disagree with. Taxation is a sovereign issue that should be up to national governments to decide what suits their citizens and their economies best. The UK Government has been at the lead of OECD negotiations on a global agreement around taxation and new BEPS proposals. Each Member State of the EU should be working at a global level to ensure a consistent approach to taxation which will limit the opportunity for avoidance.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: GUE / NGL), in writing. - The report does not propose anything specific on the common corporate tax or anything new, but focuses mainly on the proposal for further exchange of tax information between Member States, which will, however, be coordinated by Brussels. Our firm position is against a common corporate tax, because we believe that each Member State should retain its sovereign right to design and implement its fiscal policies. That is why we voted against the report.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI), in writing. - The report seeks to combat tax evasion and tax fraud by filling regulatory gaps with international tax correlations.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the report on transparency, coordination and convergence of corporate tax policies in the European Union. The rapporteurs have rightly pointed out that the tax assessment system, in addition to being legally used, is open to abuse and distortion of competition. I agreed with the statement that legislative action is needed at EU level to improve the transparency, coherence and convergence of corporate tax policies. Recommendations to achieve these, such as public country-by-country reporting by multinational companies, the development of a “fair taxpayer” label for companies with good tax practices, the mandatory notification of new tax measures, the automatic exchange of information on tax assessments or the introduction of common consolidated corporate tax fund introduction would all provide an effective solution to the established to improve the unsustainable situation.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: in writing. - 50-150 billion euros a year are lost by Member States due to aggressive tax practices by some companies. Differences in tax regulations, different practices applied in relations with third countries, or other activities benefiting only a few or a dozen international corporations are important issues from the point of view of the need for Member States to ensure adequate budget revenues. It should be emphasized that tax evasion distorts competition and creates an unfair legal environment for taxpayers. The European Parliament therefore called for action to stop tax fraud in the EU. However, it should be emphasized that any possible changes must be properly balanced and in no case may be contrary to the fundamental principle of the sovereignty of each Member State in shaping its own tax policy.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: signed up. - Inconsistencies between several tax systems pave the way for companies, especially multinationals, to avoid paying their taxes. If we take into account collection inefficiency or special tax regimes, along with the profit transfer system, the losses calculated in the budget can reach between 160 and 190 billion euros annually. Simply put, we lose 110% of the EU budget every year due to tax evasion practices. I appreciate the solution to this problem through the principles of transparency, convergence and transnational coordination. I participated in this vote with the intention of giving the Commission the necessary tools to limit, as far as possible, the losses to national budgets caused by the avoidance of tax payments by large companies operating in the EU. I also appreciate the work of the TAXES Commission, which has succeeded in substantiating some clear principles, including the introduction of a common corporate tax rules. I absolutely agree that this base must be operational by the end of 2017 at the latest. It is irrational to react to the limitation of public funds for investments and operation of national and European devices, but at the same time not to progress in increasing the quality of collection in budgets. supporting these investments and institutions.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the text. The European Parliament called on the European Commission to present, as soon as possible, a proposal for a new mechanism obliging each Member State to inform, without delay, the other Member States and the Commission of its intention to adopt any new measures. tax abatement, relief, exemption or benefit, likely to have a significant impact on the effective tax rate in that Member State or on the tax base of another Member State

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this initiative report which is the response of the ECON Committee to the  LuxLeaks scandal. This report comes just before the Commission is, in principle, expected to present on 27 January next, an anti-BEPS directive (Action Plan on Base Erosion and Profit Shifting) drawn up by the OECD in this field. The different recommendations of the report are built on the work of TAXE Committee. This report, together with the one from the TAXE Committee, constitutes a clear and strong message from the European Parliament on the LuxLeaks scandal.

name: Isabelle THOMAS
text: in writing. - Following the revelations of the Luxleaks scandal, Europeans realized that it was urgent to fight against tax dumping. After the conclusions of the special committee of the European Parliament, we propose in this report the compulsory exchange of information on all the tax rulings granted by each State and an accounting reporting country by country. We propose the creation of property registers to combat money laundering and the development of a European list of tax havens. We are in favor of the harmonization of the corporate tax base, the notification of any new tax measures by the Member States and the protection of whistleblowers. I also voted for the creation of a fund for these whistleblowers and increased control of "optimization" consulting companies, but these socialist proposals were blocked by the right. Nevertheless all the proposed measures in this report are all tools to put an end to the race to the lowest tax bid in Europe. Once again, Parliament reaffirms its desire to end dumping and urges the European Commission. We expect an ambitious legislative proposal as soon as possible.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: written. - In parallel with the Commission's request that a special Committee on Tax Decisions and other measures of a similar nature or effect examine tax rules in individual Member States of the Union, the Committee on Economic and Monetary Policy was mandated to create an own-initiative report on corporate taxation. the aim is precisely to build on the report of the TAXE special committee, which should lead to a future proposal for a concrete legislative resolution of the Commission. The report contains 15 recommendations calling on the Commission to make a legislative proposal that should increase the transparency, coordination and convergence of corporate taxes in the European Union. Although I support in principle some of the views expressed in the report on better coordination between Member States, I cannot agree with the proposals, which unfortunately make up the majority of the reports, which call for direct taxation by the Union, which is a gross violation of the principle of subsidiarity. yes they are Member States and which have exclusive regulatory competences in this segment. Examples include calls for the creation of a mandatory common consolidated corporate tax and the requirement that in future international agreements in the field of taxation policy, the Commission take over competence instead of the existing system of bilateral agreements. I am extremely opposed to such proposals, so I voted against.

name: Romana TOMC
text: in writing. - I supported the report with recommendations to the Commission on promoting transparency, coordination and convergence in corporate tax policies in the Union, as I believe that a more transparent corporate tax policy is needed, as profit diversion is avoided due to circumvention. the payment of corporate income tax loses a huge amount each year, around € 50-70 billion. Member States should also act in a more coordinated manner to combat aggressive tax planning and improve transparency, coherence and convergence in corporate tax policies in the European Union.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: written. - We have voted in favor of this report, with which the European Parliament asks the Commission to resume its work with a view to establishing a consolidation of the tax base of multinationals, which would help combat tax evasion and tax competition to the low between countries. The document also contains other very interesting elements such as the protection of whistleblowers and greater control of "tax advisory" companies, which in many cases are complicit in tax evasion.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: in writing. - The Dodds Niedermayer own-initiative report largely duplicates the report of the special TAX committee. It also follows the LuxLeaks scandal, but was launched in December 2014, three months before the establishment of the special commission, hence this redundancy. The theme is exactly the same: fighting aggressive tax competition at Union level and optimization schemes. The damage at European level is assessed at an amount between 50 and 70 billion euros per year for the relocation of profits alone, and between 160 to 190 billion euros if we include special tax regimes and agreements and frauds. We regret once again the idea of abolishing bilateral conventions in favor of multilateral agreements under the aegis of the Union, which would speak with one voice, to the extent that the States thus lose control of these agreements. . I therefore chose to abstain.

name: István UJHELYI
text: in writing. - Recent experience shows that Member States cannot act on their own against aggressive tax planning. The fact that we theoretically have a single market within the European Union requires concerted action. Respecting the sovereignty of Member States in the field of tax policy, the rapporteurs consider that EU legislative measures are needed to ensure the transparency, coordination and convergence of EU corporate tax policies. I voted in favor of the report.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: written. - We have voted in favor of this report, with which the European Parliament asks the Commission to resume its work with a view to establishing a consolidation of the tax base of multinationals, which would help combat tax evasion and tax competition to the low between countries. The document also contains other very interesting elements such as the protection of whistleblowers and greater control of "tax advisory" companies, which in many cases are complicit in tax evasion.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this text because it is necessary to ensure greater transparency, especially when it comes to tax regulations. The EU loses around EUR 50-70 billion every year because of corporate tax avoidance achieved via profit shifting alone. I agree that we need to address the topic of ‘aggressive tax planning’ where practices are by no means limited to Luxembourg, and in fact are rife throughout the EU. The phenomenon of ‘aggressive tax planning’ consists of taking advantage of the technicalities of a tax system, or of mismatches between two or more tax systems, for the purpose of reducing tax liability. While this differs from tax fraud and tax evasion, which constitute illegal activities of evading tax liabilities, in essence all three practices serve to reduce the tax base, undermining faith in governments and businesses alike. Since I agree that such practices should not be acceptable at any time, I voted in favour.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: written. - This report addresses a matter of great importance for Europe, such as tax policy. Through reports of this type, the aim is to advance towards greater cooperation between the Member States in this matter, as well as to increase transparency, coordination and convergence in this area, a key issue for Europe. I therefore consider it necessary to vote in favor of this report.

name: Marco VALLI
text: in writing. - The report covers recommendations to the Commission on transparency, coordination and convergence in corporate tax policies in the Union. The report intends, in fact, to stem the use of tax evasive practices for businesses, which each year harms more and more the coffers of the Member States. Although it is necessary to activate as soon as possible some of the proposals contained in the report (such as a common European tax identification code, legal protection of whistleblowers, measures to ensure that all profits are taxed where they were generated) I considered it appropriate to abstain due to some gaps present. In fact, there is no reference to the responsibilities of governments, banks and corporate tax consultants that emerged from the Luxleaks case. In addition, downward compromises have been reached in several cases, for example by introducing the common consolidated tax base for income tax. company (CCCTB) in two stages, while it should be introduced without intermediate stages. For these reasons, I did not support the report and preferred to abstain.

name: Derek VAUGHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which proposes mandatory reporting of tax arrangements, meaning all companies that operate across borders must publicly report on where they make their profits and where they pay their taxes. By introducing laws at EU level, we can prevent companies jumping across borders to reduce their tax bills to almost zero. This report is an important step in setting the tax agenda for the European Union and closing loopholes that multinational companies have been able to exploit by playing one country against another. We need a fairer taxation system that means citizens no longer foot the bill for the corporate sector.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: written.- The fight against tax evasion and fraud requires more action at European level.I voted in favor of this report because I believe there should be more transparency and coordination of Member States' tax policies in the European Union.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. - This issue was accentuated following the LuxLeaks revelations by a consortium of journalists in November 2014, which revealed that many multinational companies had entered into secret agreements with the Luxembourg authorities, allowing them to reduce their tax obligations, in some cases to almost 1%, creating very little or no economic activity in the country. These "aggressive tax planning" practices are not limited to Luxembourg at all, but in reality they are quite widespread across the EU. According to available studies, the EU loses around 50-70 billion euros a year due to corporate tax avoidance, simply through the transfer of profits. This amount amounts to approximately EUR 160-190 billion if special tax arrangements, collection inefficiencies and other similar elements are taken into account. Such practices are never acceptable, much less in difficult economic circumstances, such as those facing Europe today. This scandal deeply affects the credibility of the European institutions, taking into account that they directly involve the presidents of the European Commission and the Eurogroup. It demonstrates who this EU serves with its model of neoliberal integration based on the free movement of capital and the sacredness of financial markets.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: written.- A very balanced report in and of itself.However, there are some suggestions for expanding competencies: European definition of standards for the withdrawal of commercial licenses from companies that have participated in tax avoidance, European control and auditing of tax advisors, CCCTB, etc. I do not consider such centralization to be welcome.Therefore I am abstaining from my vote.

name: Julie WARD
text: in writing. ‒ Tax injustice, tax avoidance, and tax evasion, are key drivers of the rampant inequality in our world today. Trillions upon trillions of euros are stashed away, where they should be used for health, education, transport, social care, and all the other public services and investment we urgently need. Only by working together within the EU can Member States take the necessary  action to tackle this issue. We demand new legislation to crack down on this tax avoidance and evasion. Mandatory, public country-by-country reporting of tax arrangements, the new ‘fair taxpayer label’ for companies who engage in good tax practices, better protection for whistle-blowers, a common consolidated corporate tax base, a common definition of tax havens, and sanctions for firms making use of tax havens; all these are important tools in our arsenal in the fight against avoidance and evasion. I urge the Commission and Member States to implement these measures swiftly and effectively.

name: Dame Glenis WILLMOTT
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on corporate tax avoidance, because it is clear that something needs to be done about the estimated EUR 1 trillion of tax revenue lost every year to tax evasion and aggressive tax avoidance in the EU. People across the UK, and the EU, are rightly furious that they face higher taxes or cuts to public services as a result of multinational companies with clever advisers reducing their own tax bill to almost nothing.  This report sets out a clear plan for action at EU level that will stop these kinds of practices once and for all.  The Tories should be ashamed for voting against it, and David Cameron should listen to the voice of British and European people and act on these recommendations as soon as possible.

name: Marco ZANNI
text: in writing. - The approved report contains a number of recommendations to the Commission on how to promote transparency, coordination and convergence in corporate tax policies in the Union. Together with the final report of the TAXE committee and the amendment to the directive on the automatic exchange of information on tax rulings, it indicates the willingness of the European Parliament to combat aggressive tax planning and business avoidance, a plague that causes huge losses to Member States every year and creates a kind of fiscal dumping, benefiting multinationals at the expense of SMEs. I therefore believe that some of the proposed measures should be implemented and implemented as soon as possible: the proposal for a common European tax identification code; the proposal for a legal protection of whistleblowers; ensuring that profits are taxed where value is created. However, in the approved text there are some critical issues and gaps that prompted me to abstain: country-by-country reporting should be public and easily accessible, while the common consolidated tax base CCCTB should be introduced without intermediate stages. Furthermore, there is no explicit reference to political responsibilities in the Luxleaks case and to the role of banks and tax advisors in facilitating tax avoidance practices.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. - The LUXLEAKS scandal and other investigations that followed showed that tax fraud and evasion are widespread in most Member States with their governments' knowledge for decades. In view of the facts discovered, the EP authorized, in December 2014, the drawing up of a legislative initiative report on ways to "ensure the transparency, coordination and convergence of corporate taxation policies in the European Union". The report presents some recommendations that seem to be very positive, namely the presentation of mandatory and public reports by country by multinational companies for all sectors, the creation of a common and rigorous definition of tax haven or countermeasures in relation to companies that use havens tax. In the report, the door to fiscal harmonization is left ajar, through proposals that, in the name of combating tax avoidance and the transfer of profits, aim to set the tone for the loss of sovereignty in terms of fiscal policy. We abstained.

name: Daniel DALTON
text: – Madam President, I very much welcome my colleague Mr Belder’s report and its emphasis on stronger relations and constructive dialogue to achieve further improvements in human rights and democracy in China. The UK is China’s number one investment destination in Europe and our economic ties are growing. In the West Midlands, my constituency, this is especially true. This is the manufacturing heartland of the UK and we have an export surplus of nearly GBP 3 billion a year with China and we now have direct flights from Birmingham to Beijing as well. That said, we must be mindful of the problems of human rights and democracy that continue in China. But we will never achieve reforms by lecturing the Chinese Government. We will achieve them by interacting and trading with China so that we can demonstrate the many benefits, including economic, of greater respect for human rights and democracy. Trade brings people together, it makes everyone richer and, ultimately, it will break down barriers and achieve a better outcome, both for Europeans and for people in China.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: - Madam President, I supported this report, mainly because it contains a passage on the human rights situation in China. The report makes it clear that the human rights situation is a serious concern and that China really needs to do something about human rights today if it is to become a developed and perhaps democratic country in the future. I am very pleased that the report points to, for example, the law on the management of foreign NGOs, which, if effective in the future, will significantly reduce civil society in China and lead to international humanitarian organizations not being able to support Chinese dissidents in the future. to support humanitarian goals in China. So yes, trading with China is necessary, it is, of course, economically advantageous, but without referring to human rights, I think it is bad. Therefore, as I said, it is good that, in addition to economic benefits, we are talking about human rights.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – A Uachtaráin, molaim an tuarascáil seo agus vótáil mé ina fabhar; agus le mo ghrúpa i ngach uile vóta. Gan dabht ar bith is maith an rud é go mbeadh gaol dearfach, láidir againn leis an tSín agus aitheantas a thabhairt di as ucht an dul chun cinn iontach atá á dhéanamh aici maidir lena geilleagar.  Freisin, bhí sé de phribhléid agamsa a bheith i bPáras an tseachtain seo caite. Le Feisirí eile ón bParlaimint, bhuaileamar le toscairí ón tSín. Caithfear creidiúint a thabhairt dóibh as ucht an méid atá á dhéanamh acu chun troid i gcoinne athrú aeráide; agus chabhraigh siad go mór chun an comhréiteach a bhí againn ag an deireadh a bheith againn.  Rud amháin eile nach bhfuil mé róshásta faoi ná imeachtaí atá ar siúl ag an tSín i Muir na Síne Theas: caithfidh siad glacaint le dlíthe idirnáisiúnta maidir leis sin.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: – Madam President, it is not an easy task for the EU to sort out the dilemma of how to best deal with China, the second largest economy in the world and its second largest trading partner. But China is also an authoritarian state responsible for serious breaches of fundamental rights, including the freedom of expression, association, assembly and religion.  Europe needs an approach in which the pursuit of its trade and investment interests does not go against the principles it claims to stand for. It should not ignore issues such as the persecution of Buddhist monks and nuns, the ever-increasing number of self-immolations, the forceful resettlement of over 2 million Tibetan nomads, the mistreatment of the Uighur population, the demolition of Christian churches or removal of their crosses, the forced disappearance of hundreds of human rights lawyers and so on. Only by dealing with such matters can we build a credible and strong relationship with China; one that is in the interest of both the EU and the population of China.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: - I abstained and I will explain why.Because it is clear that relations with the People's Republic of China play a very important, if not the most important, role in EU foreign policy.And this - one way or another, this relationship covers all the policies pursued in our community: from trade and investment to culture and human rights.And while we compete in several sectors or our positions differ, there is a strong need for closer cooperation with the PRC.Overall, the report was well constructed, but, ladies and gentlemen, I do not see a single voice here, which is vitally necessary for us.Because, when it comes to China's domestic policy or human rights, China's standards are very far from the human rights standards that exist in our community, the European Union.As I did not see this single voice, I abstained.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. - EU-China relations are regulated for the first time thanks to the approval of the Belder report in 2006. The report presented on the report highlights how it deals with fundamental issues such as strategic partnership, internal situation, human rights and cross-border relations. While China's undisputed role as an economic power is certainly recognized, on the other hand, a series of problems are underlined linked, first of all, to the discrepancy between the formal commitments made in terms of human rights and their effective respect; it is also concerned about climate change and the initiatives promised by China. From reading the report, however, the clear intention emerges to establish relations with China on the basis of a concerted line with the USA, without therefore highlighting a clear and clear-cut European strategy in this regard. I therefore decided to abstain, hoping for the development of a European plan that promotes respect for the EU's main interests and objectives.

name: Tim AKER
text: in writing. – UKIP does not support the principle of the EU having any sort of foreign policy. This report gives an overall look at relations between the EU and China, supporting current agreements and calls for more EU action in several areas. This is therefore an endorsement of EU foreign policy. However it also raises several legitimate concerns, in particular with the attempted interference by the Chinese government in democratic processes within Hong Kong. In light of this balance UKIP abstained.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: written.- I voted against this report, because it has a strong focus on the so-called "indispensable" role of the US, and calls for a common approach to be developed with the US on China, holdingthat this will help promote the interests of the EU, something with which I do not agree.In addition, it delves into issues that are not the competence of the EU or of this report, such as denouncing that China is allying with Russia to block the action of the United Nations with respect to Syria.For this reason, and although I have found interesting elements for which I have voted in favor, I have had to vote against the adoption of this report as a whole.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: in writing.- The facts reported in this report are for the most part correct.Nevertheless, we at the National Front consider that foreign policy is a competence which belongs to the States and not to the European Union.Above all, we believe that European institutions, like states, should not interfere in China's internal political affairs.That is why I opposed this report.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this report, which has some good points to it but fundamentally seeks to politicise trade and other agreements with China.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this report, on which the EP is expressing its views on the future of EU-China relations.The EU-China Strategic Partnership is crucial for EU-China relations.There is a need to pursue common interests and jointly address many global challenges, such as global and regional security, the fight against terrorism and organized crime, cyber security, weapons of mass destruction and non-proliferation, energy security, global financial and market regulation, climate change and sustainable development.development.I support the calls for the EEAS to ensure that human rights are high on the agenda in its relations and dialogues with China.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: in writing.- I voted against this text of rare arrogance, while the European Union is increasingly badly placed to give lessons.Could this be a way of blaming China for its rapprochement with Russia?

name: Hugues BAYET
text: in writing.- I approved this own-initiative report which underlines the growing role of China on the global geopolitical scene as well as in economic and financial relations, but which notes the very worrying deterioration in recent years in the human rights situation.man in the country.The report notes that the freedom of the country's human rights activists, lawyers, journalists, bloggers, academics and various representatives of civil society has, for years, never been so high.muzzled!

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. - Despite the recent financial difficulties that seem to reduce expectations on economic performance, the PRC continues to represent, forty years after the start of EU-China diplomatic relations, one of the Union's main trading partners. The role of investor in strategic sectors of the economy in large areas of the globe is increasingly associated with that of a protagonist on the international scene. A key presence in recent dialogues on the environment, security and the fight against terrorism, China continues to present numerous unknowns on issues such as respect for human rights, protection of minorities and freedom of expression, My vote in favor of the Belder report on relations EU-China was born from the deep conviction that only a common commitment and a proactive approach can guarantee a profitable development of the global strategic partnership in the coming years. Supporting relations between Europe and China must have as main objectives not only the crucial ones linked to the development of infrastructural networks, protection of the fair treatment of businesses and development of investments but also those related to the regulation of global markets, the non-proliferation of arms and sustainable development programs.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: written.- We have REFRAINED on this report.The report has two lines that make us unable to vote in favor: first, it calls for the signing of trade agreements with China and to take advantage of the commercial opportunities of China's rise.Second, it calls on China to "follow" the EU and the US in international politics.On the other hand, the points where repression and the lack of freedom are criticized are well developed.In addition, section 62 and the second part of section 51 have been approved, which were key for us.In this second part, the mandatory nature of a human rights clause in any bilateral treaty with China is mentioned and, in paragraph 62, obligations regarding labor regulations are imposed on European companies regardless of whether they are contemplated by Chinese law orno.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: written.- I have supported this report because it contains some very necessary warnings to the Chinese regime for its repeated violations of fundamental rights, also relating specific cases as striking as the arrest of two hundred lawyers of opponents.I also share the calls to collaborate with the international stabilization and peace operations in Ukraine or Syria, and I find the call to avoid military threats against Taiwan in case of possible secession especially interesting.Aiming a battery of 1,500 missiles at another territory is never a solution, such as placing the armed forces (a case that occurs in the constitution of a member state) as guarantors of national unity.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: in writing. - I firmly rejected this report, symbolic of the way in which the European Union intends to arrogate to itself the privilege of maintaining diplomatic relations with third States while carrying out a real policy of interference disrespectful of the sovereignty of nations sovereigns. The purpose of the report is in particular to weaken relations between China and Russia, the European Union continuing to consider the latter country as having divergent strategic interests, and this, despite the geopolitical reality which would like the Russian Federation to be an ally of choice, especially in the fight against Islamist terrorism. Obviously, the report cannot help highlighting the human rights violations committed in China, while continuing to carry out its seduction operation aimed at Chinese capital. A "double standard" typical of Brussels institutions which like to teach lessons while continuing to take advantage of what they can. Once again, the European Union has it all wrong on foreign policy, as, alas, on so many other subjects.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing.- This less courageous text does not clearly address the issue of the ESM and the granting of market economy status to China.For this reason I have expressed myself with an abstention.

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: written.- I have abstained.I believe that the report on relations with China highlights important issues, not least with regard to human rights violations in China.But the report is characterized by a market-liberal line where the homage to free trade, and opposition to the public sector, dominates.In a world where the biggest threat is the growing climate crisis, the issues of trade and the economy must be problematized more than what is happening in this report.That's why I abstain.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: written. - Diplomatic relations between the EU and China are 40 years old. This report, which I voted favorably, salutes the recent reforms undertaken by President Xi Jinping, highlighting the New Silk Road initiative and the launch of the Asian Investment Bank. The EU and China must cooperate closely on issues such as the fight against terrorism and crime, nuclear non-proliferation, control over weapons of mass destruction, cybersecurity, regulation of financial markets or climate change. However, the lack of transparency, information and statistics on government intervention in the Chinese economy, as well as dumping practices, state subsidies and lack of respect for intellectual property rights is worrying. As of today, China does not meet the requirements to be considered a market economy, so the EU should not grant such status in the coming months. With regard to respect for human rights, I condemn the restrictions on freedom of expression, freedom of association and assembly, religious freedom, the persecution of human rights defenders, bloggers and ethnic minorities, as well as the application of the death penalty, which must be abolished.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of this report because it expressed Parliament's position on the prospects for EU-China relations. In the report, Parliament welcomes the 40th anniversary of EU-China diplomatic relations, which should lead to the stronger strategic partnership that is so necessary in a multipolar and globalized world and speed up the ongoing negotiations on a new partnership and cooperation agreement based on trust, transparency and respect for human rights. Parliament emphasized that China was a major international power and one of the EU's most important partners, and that both sides were committed to promoting a comprehensive strategic partnership between the EU and China over the next decade, to the benefit of both the EU and China. In Parliament's view, China should play a greater role in multilateral financial institutions, which better reflects the size of its economy. However, Parliament is concerned about the lack of dumping and transparency with regard to the Chinese Government's policies and subsidies through tax credits, land subsidies, cheap credits, subsidized raw materials and other measures. Barriers faced by European companies in the Chinese market, such as forced technology transfer, insufficient protection of intellectual property rights and discrimination, are also a concern.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: in writing. - Cooperation between the European Union and China dates back forty years. They established their strategic relationship in 1975, signed a Trade and Cooperation Agreement in 1985, and have since continued to support China’s sustainable development by strengthening the partnership for political, economic and social reform. I voted in favor of the report as it reflects the paramount importance of bilateral strategic relations in addressing global issues such as global and regional security, tackling the economic crisis, energy security, non-proliferation and non-proliferation, climate change, democracy and the rule of law. the promotion of human rights and the fight against organized crime and terrorism. At the same time, I consider it important that the decision calls on the Chinese authorities to abide by their international commitments on the rule of law and human rights.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: in writing. - Mr Belder's report is a correct assessment of EU-China relations and publicly highlights both positive and negative issues in relations between the countries. That’s right, in any case, we need to talk and try to find common ground while pointing out mistakes. Thus, human rights will remain high on the agenda of the talks, as will the unfair trade practices coming from them. At the same time, we want better coordination in areas of strategic importance, such as security and defense, the fight against terrorism, illegal migration, international crime, nuclear non-proliferation, global and regional security, energy security, global governance and regulation of finance and markets, climate change. , as well as urbanization, development and assistance programs and sustainable development, etc. The fact is that we can also learn a lot from the Chinese, as they are technologically very competitive in some areas, and their concepts of learning and staffing new capable staff are also interesting. The report is so critical where it needs to be, but it leaves the door open for dialogue, which is why I was also happy to support it.

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: in writing. - On the occasion of the 40th anniversary of EU-China diplomatic relations, I welcome a report that aims to deepen and clarify the European Parliament's view on our relations with this international partner, which is increasingly important and active on the political and economic scene global. I would also like to highlight the contribution made by the S & amp; D group to this report, which aimed to underline our goals and positions with respect to some vital issues. In light of this, it is necessary to support the strengthening of the strategic partnership with China, which is fundamental for addressing today's global challenges in a perspective of cooperation and greater coordination, and it is also important to collaborate with China on projects such as the Juncker Plan on European side and the EU-China bilateral investment agreement. Nonetheless, in deepening our relationship we must always remember to defend our fundamental interests and values, with a view to a dialogue based on transparency and reciprocity, remembering that China still needs to make many steps forward as regards respect for rights. human rights, the protection of workers and the environment and, in general, the complete transition to a market economy and the rule of law.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: written.- I support this report, which covers the general relationship between the EU and China, from a political, economic, environmental, social and human rights perspective.The aim is to create, in a constructive approach, a document that helps to define cooperation between the EU and China, one of the largest "players" globally.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. - The People's Republic of China can be an important trade and political partner for the European Union. Its now established role as a leading player in the global geopolitical chessboard must encourage us to weigh up relations with China and encourage it to play its part in maintaining world stability. Our political will to maintain good bilateral relations and the common interest in economic development and in the continuation of trade and economic-entrepreneurial collaboration cannot, however, stop us from calling the Chinese government to respect human rights, to introduce reforms that promote freedom of thought and speech, the protection of ethnic and religious minorities, the right of people to self-determine the choices of their own life. China today is still far from being a free and democratic country: we believe that it can become one and that collaboration with the European Union can also help the Chinese people for civil and political progress.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: signed up. - This year marks the 40th anniversary of the beginning of EU-China diplomatic relations, which are extremely important for both sides, in order to find common answers to a number of global issues, such as global security, counter-terrorism, cyber security, as well as climate change. We need to see China as a major trading partner for the Union, with a huge, booming market, but we need to react to the slippage in this country. Although the Chinese government recognizes the importance and universality of human rights, it is unable to demonstrate concrete results in improving the human rights situation. It is unacceptable that, in the Chinese view, socio-economic rights take precedence over individual civil and political rights. It is also worrying that China is currently the country that executes the most people and continues to secretly impose the death penalty on thousands of people annually, regardless of minimum international standards for the use of the death penalty. I spoke in favor of this report with the conviction that the involvement of the EU through the Council and the Commission can have positive results, achieving, through a constructive dialogue, the transition of this country to the rule of law and respect for human rights.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. - Voting of abstention. The report calls for greater cooperation between the EU and China in addressing global challenges and threats, such as the fight against terrorism, illegal immigration, global and regional security, climate change or financial governance and global market. The strengthening of the EU-China strategic partnership is necessary in a multipolar and globalized world: we ask to speed up negotiations on a new partnership and cooperation agreement "based on trust, transparency and respect for human rights." It is emphasized that the 17th EU-China Summit on 29 June 2015 gave a signal for "closer political cooperation that goes beyond simple trade relations and towards a coordinated strategic approach to address global challenges and common threats" . While concern over the current financial crisis affecting China was noted, it was stated that EU Member States should take advantage of the opportunities offered by the growth of the Chinese economy. Furthermore, the importance of the bilateral investment agreement currently under negotiation is stressed as it can pave the way for equal treatment of companies, both in Europe and in China.

name: Alain CADEC
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the report on relations between the European Union and China.This report reiterates the importance of strengthening the strategic partnership with China so that it is beneficial for both parties.China is an essential economic partner.In this perspective, the European Union must cooperate with this country.The report also highlights the gaps in respect for human rights and democracy which are proving to be very problematic.We must cautiously develop relations between the European Union and China.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. - Today I voted in favor of this report to promote the EU-China strategic partnership. China is a major international power and a major partner of the EU. The global strategic partnership that the two parties have decided to promote for the next decade is therefore good. Relations between the EU and China have recently reached a new and closer level of cooperation, which goes beyond simple trade relations, to address common challenges such as climate change and threats to international peace and security. On the economic relations front, however, much still needs to be done due to the difficulties that European companies encounter in the Chinese market, for example, in the area of ​​technology transfer and intellectual property protection. Finally, I think that the time has come for the Member States to speak with one voice to the Chinese government, especially on issues of international cooperation and dialogue on human rights. Unfortunately, too often, European states prefer to focus on bilateral relations, helping to undermine Europe's credibility and make international cooperation actions less effective.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. – UKIP does not support the principle of the EU having any sort of foreign policy. This report gives an overall look at relations between the EU and China, supporting current agreements and calls for more EU action in several areas. This is therefore an endorsement of EU foreign policy. However it also raises several legitimate concerns, in particular with the attempted interference by the Chinese government in democratic processes within Hong Kong. In light of this balance UKIP abstained.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ This report welcomes the 40 years since the first diplomatic relations between the EU and China started. It underscores the commitment of both sides to the EU-China Comprehensive Strategic Partnership, which will be mutually beneficial. The Chinese government is also called upon to renter into a dialogue with Tibetan representatives and a speedy solution to the tension in the areas of the South and East China Seas. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. - The Belder report is very severe on the issue of human rights, elevating conditionality to the top of criteria in EU-China relations, but it seems to do so, more than for European interests, in function of a Chinese containment wanted by Washington. This seems evident when the HR / VP is invited to conduct EU-China relations along a concerted line with the US. So I wonder when we will have European strategic autonomy. The report also places on all international issues unacceptable assumptions for Beijing: from the resolution of the disputes in the South China Sea in the UNCLOS framework to the distancing from Assad and the Russian-Iranian front, which Beijing has been approaching in recent years. . And it does so by calling on China to cooperate in European instruments, but also in American initiatives, such as the New Silk Road or the IMF. Contradictions and limitations of the institutional systems close to the USA, always and in any case considered positive, never come to light. In short, while maintaining an excellent line with regard to human rights, I believe that this report perhaps lacks an original perspective that could make the EU an entity separate from its transatlantic ally and with strategic autonomy and interests of its own. For these reasons I preferred to abstain.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: in writing. ‒ Relations with China are one of the key areas of the EU external activities. I welcome this report marking the 40th anniversary of EU-China diplomatic relations. The report is well balanced and reflects realistically the current position of China in international relations. I find very important that the report mentions the need for a bilateral investment agreement between the EU and China and for an enhanced cooperation improving market access for companies, mainly SMEs.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: PPE), in writing. - We support this report and note the priority given by President Xi's presidency to the United States, given his proposal for a "new type of relationship" between China, the United States and other regional powers. However, we believe that a more constructive approach is needed for a new world order to which China should contribute and integrate, one that is based on the universal values ​​of human rights, democracy and human security. We also call on the EU to become more active in Asia and to work with China, the US and other regional powers to increase stability in the region. We note that the recent White Paper on China's military strategy reveals Beijing's intentions to further strengthen the Chinese Navy, as well as to expand the scope of its operations, moving from a "coastal defense" approach to "coastal protection". of the high seas ".

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ In this report, Parliament welcomes the 40th anniversary of diplomatic relations between the EU and China as a source of inspiration to strengthen the Strategic Partnership. It is stressed that the two sides are committed to promoting over the next decade the EU-China Comprehensive Strategic Partnership, which will be mutually beneficial to both the EU and China.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing.- I am in favor of the report presented by my colleague Belder on relations between the European Union and China.I argue that the 17th EU-China Summit was important in strengthening the strategic partnership between these two countries.Furthermore, I believe that this latest summit has helped to speed up the ongoing negotiations on a new partnership and cooperation agreement based on trust, transparency and respect for human rights.The commitment to promote this partnership will bring benefits to both sides, allowing the further implementation of bilateral relations and sending a signal of political cooperation useful for addressing common global challenges and threats.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. – Although the report reaffirms that forced abortions are strictly illegal in China, family-planning officials repeatedly coerce women into inhumane practices such as forced abortions or sterilisation. China needs to do more to show mutual concordance with the EU on the condemnation of the so-called ‘social maintenance fee’, an often-exorbitant fine that parents have to pay in the event of extra births. Having said that I agree that the strategic partnership needs to be nurtured further through strong commitment in sincere cooperation between the EU and China,  most notably with respect to mutual responsibility and a good level of confidence between the two parties based on universal value of upholding the fundamental principles of human rights.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. - The Belder report addresses several issues. It can be enclosed in 5 large macro-areas. Overall it is very good, rigid on the issue of human rights, underlines the contradiction between the Chinese statements and the effective protection of human rights by Beijing. It calls on China to cooperate in European instruments, but also in American initiatives, such as the New Silk Road or the IMF. The report never highlights contradictions and limitations of institutional systems close to the USA, which are always and in any case considered positive. While he warns, for example, the EU states that will join the AIIB on the need for it to comply with the social responsibility criteria of the credit due, it never questions that these same criteria are respected by the IMF. While maintaining an excellent line with regard to human rights, the report turns out to be an example of "asymmetrical" conditionality: getting tough with China, but above all because the United States asks for it (at least this seems to be leaking between of the report); perhaps there is no original perspective that could make the EU a separate entity from its transatlantic ally and with strategic autonomy and interests of its own. For these reasons I have decided to abstain.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: written.- I voted against this report, because it has a strong focus on the so-called 'indispensable' role of the US, and urges the Vice President / High Representative to develop a common approach with the US inas for China, arguing that this will contribute to promoting the interests of the EU, something with which I do not agree.In addition, she delves into issues that are not the competence of the EU or this report, such as denouncing that China is allying with Russia to block the action of the United Nations with respect to Syria.For this reason, and although I have found interesting elements for which I have voted in favor, I have had to vote against the adoption of this report as a whole.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ The report covers generically the relations between EU and China, dealing with political, economic, environmental, social and human rights aspects. The report has a constructive approach, by not just focusing on a critical attitude against China, but yet still being just in the areas where deficiencies are identified. Noting that such a balance is healthy and strategically balanced in arriving at the desired outcomes in China, including the developments of certain individual freedoms, I have voted in favour of this report.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: signed up.- I welcome the 40th anniversary of the diplomatic relations between the European Union and China, as a source of inspiration for strengthening the strategic partnership so necessary in a multipolar and globalized world, and I believe that China is an important international power and aone of the EU's most important partners.That is why I believe that the two sides must promote the comprehensive strategic partnership between the EU and China in the next decade, which will be beneficial for both the EU and China.

name: Nicola DANTI
text: in writing. - The fortieth anniversary of the opening of diplomatic relations between China and the European Union was celebrated this year. Today, the partnership with Beijing is certainly essential to address the great challenges of global governance and the main issues on the international agenda. The resolution voted by a large majority by the European Parliament outlines a general and sectoral picture of the state of relations and its possible future developments. In particular, the resolution stresses that the Union and its Member States must be able to exploit the opportunities offered by increased trade and economic cooperation between the two parties. In my opinion, however, this must be based and founded on respect for shared and fair rules, based on the principle of reciprocity. In this sense, we must be clear: a mature bilateral trade cooperation cannot for now foresee the granting of market economy status to China. Indeed, the country is still very far from respecting the standards set by the World Trade Organization for obtaining this status. Only with a different acceptance of responsibility on the part of China and through sincere cooperation will we be able to profitably advance the quality of our partnership.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: in writing. - This own-initiative report presents the European Parliament's position on the EU-China partnership, on the occasion of the 40th anniversary of diplomatic relations between the EU and China. Welcoming the rapid economic development in China, the report reiterates the importance for the Union of ensuring a win-win partnership and deepening ties between citizens. It calls on Member States to take greater advantage of the development opportunities offered by these relations. The report also expresses a series of criticisms vis-à-vis the power in place and the situation of human rights, democracy and freedoms in certain regions of China (Tibet, Hong-Kong, Taiwan) or with regard to certain groups (Tibetans). Failure to respect international law, in particular the law of the sea, is finally singled out in this report, since China is pursuing an expansive policy in the South China Sea. Supporting the conclusions of this report, I voted in favor of it.

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: in writing.- The fortieth anniversary of diplomatic relations between the European Union and China should be an opportunity to take stock of cooperation between the two entities, but also to consider coordinated responses to global challenges such as terrorism,immigration, climate change or even financial governance.The EU and China must move towards adopting a coordinated strategic approach both economically and politically.But strengthening the partnership between the European Union and China can only be done on the basis of mutual trust and transparency.This requires an improvement in respect for human rights, freedom of expression and commitments in favor of the defense of the environment by the Chinese political authorities.

name: Andor DELI
text: in writing. - Cooperation between the EU and China dates back forty years. Their strategic relationship was established in 1975, a Trade and Cooperation Agreement was signed in 1985, and since then the EU has consistently supported China’s sustainable development by strengthening its partnership for political, economic and social reform. I voted in favor of the Belder report, as it reflects the paramount importance of bilateral strategic relations in addressing global issues such as global and regional security, economic crisis management, energy security, non-proliferation and climate change, climate change, democracy and the rule of law. the promotion of human rights and the fight against organized crime and terrorism. At the same time, I consider it important that the decision calls on the Chinese authorities to abide by their international commitments on the rule of law and human rights, in particular freedom of religion, freedom of expression and freedom of the media, as real strategic cooperation cannot be without these values. As demonstrated at the Paris Climate Summit, the two sides are able to work together. The same can rightly be expected of the fundamental principles governing the EU's foreign policy.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: in writing. - I supported this report because it covers all aspects of EU-China relations and calls for both to work more closely together to address global challenges and threats , such as terrorism, illegal immigration, security, climate change and global financial and market governance. I support the call for the strengthening of talks on a new partnership and cooperation agreement based on trust, transparency and respect for human rights. To keep a clear vision of the rapid development of our mutual relations, I support the call on the Commission to produce an annual report on the development of EU-China relations and to ensure that human rights are brought to the forefront. priority. I also support the demand to ask the Commission to complain forcefully to the Chinese authorities about the adoption of repressive regulations, such as the draft law on the management of foreign NGOs and the new draft law on cybersecurity.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: In written form. - I supported Mr Belder's report on EU-China relations because I find it extremely good and comprehensive. The report pays special attention to five areas - the strategic partnership and cooperation between the EU and China, the country's internal affairs, its foreign policy, the human rights situation, and relations with Taiwan and Tibet. The recommendations made in the report are extremely important, the most important of which is that the reform of the human rights protection system should not be neglected at the expense of the country's economic growth. Economic reforms and those in the field of democracy and human rights go hand in hand with the aim of improving the overall prosperity and quality of life in the country.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), in writing.- This is negative in its entirety because, in my view, the EU should first create an independent foreign policy, harnessing its power and then intervening internally in other countries, especially powers such as China.I point out the paragraphs in which China is urged to intervene and condemn al-Assad and Russia on the issue of Ukraine.

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: in writing. - Cooperation between the EU and China dates back forty years. Their strategic relationship was established in 1975, a Trade and Cooperation Agreement was signed in 1985, and since then the EU has consistently supported China’s sustainable development by strengthening its partnership for political, economic and social reform. I voted in favor of the Belder report, as it reflects the paramount importance of bilateral strategic relations in addressing global issues such as global and regional security, economic crisis management, energy security, non-proliferation and climate change, climate change, democracy and the rule of law. the promotion of human rights and the fight against organized crime and terrorism. At the same time, I consider it important that the decision calls on the Chinese authorities to abide by their international commitments on the rule of law and human rights, in particular freedom of religion, freedom of expression and freedom of the media, as real strategic cooperation cannot be without these values. As demonstrated at the Paris Climate Summit, the two sides are able to work together. The same can rightly be expected of the fundamental principles governing the EU's foreign policy.

name: Eleonora EVI
text: in writing. - The Belder report covers all the most relevant aspects of relations between the EU and China. The second largest global economy, which continues to grow at an accelerated rate - 7.7% in 2013 - is likely to become the first economy in the world within ten years. Trade with the EU exceeds one billion per day and, following access to the WTO in 2001 and the probable recognition of the market economy status that China will receive, Chinese competition will be even more felt, putting itself under serious pressure some Italian industrial sectors. On a positive note, the Belder report is very strict on the issue of human rights but, on careful reading, it seems more so with intentions aimed at Chinese containment, which is but a reflection of US policy towards Beijing. It is a pity that the report fails to convince genuinely, if not ambiguously, European interests in terms of politics and positions protecting European interests. Although some elements of the report were positive, I decided to abstain.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. - This report is marked, on the one hand, by the EU's manifest interest in investment and trade issues with China and in its determination to access larger slices of the Chinese domestic market and, on the other hand, by its insistence on interference across the board. in China's internal affairs, assuming the right to parameterize a wide range of Chinese policies (from economics to religious politics, from diplomacy to defense, through human rights and civil society). The report never affirms the principles of respect for sovereignty and non-interference, mutual interest, equal conditions, progress and social welfare. The issue of human rights is ubiquitous throughout the document, although it also deserves a specific chapter, always from an inquisitive perspective and of superiority in the matter by the EU. Whether here, whether on issues of security and terrorism, the rights of national minorities, etc., the text strives for supreme hypocrisy, which could well be summed up in one: "don't look at what I do, do what I preach" . Full of pressures, prescriptions and observations that incur a flagrant and gross offense of interference and interference - expressing the EU's vision and interests - this report can only be rejected.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: in writing. – I voted against as I believe the EU does not have a role in foreign affairs. Ireland has its own Foreign Affairs Department to do that.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing.- This report covers the general relations between the European Union and China and deals in detail with the political, economic, environmental, social and, last but not least, human rights aspects.The original draft report, which was submitted 4 months ago, was not well received by all groups and expressed dissatisfaction with it.However, I do not think that it would be a happy decision to support the negotiation of a bilateral investment agreement between the European Union and Taiwan.The aim of the recast text is therefore to change the text previously presented and to prepare a document that will be useful in relations between the European Union and China.China is one of the most important players in the global field and the European Union must maintain fair relations with it.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing.- The report calls for greater cooperation between the EU and China and I agree on many issues.However, there are still too many fields left intentionally empty, not mentioned and not addressed with the right incisiveness, I am thinking of the recognition of the ESM or the environmental and exploitation of workers and much more.That's why I can't support the relationship.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing.- I am voting against the report on EU-China relations, because I believe that the EU must first create an independent foreign policy, harnessing its power and then intervening internally in other countries and especially powers such as China.I point out the paragraphs in which China is urged to intervene and condemn al-Assad and Russia on the issue of Ukraine.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ China is a major trading partner of the EU, with a huge and expanding market; the ongoing investment agreement negotiations represent one of the most important issues in EU-China bilateral economic and trade relations. I welcome the 40th anniversary of diplomatic relations between the EU and China as a source of inspiration to strengthen the Strategic Partnership, which is so necessary in a multipolar and globalised world, and to speed up the ongoing negotiations for a new Partnership and Cooperation Agreement based on trust, transparency and respect for human rights. I strongly support the call for finding mutual answers to a range of global concerns and identifying common interests, such as global and regional security, counter-terrorism, the fight against organised crime, cybersecurity, weapons of mass destruction and nuclear non-proliferation, energy security, global financial and market regulation, climate change and sustainable development. I am especially worried about environmental degradation in China, which has taken on dramatic proportions and I believe that more urgent, strong and targeted government action is needed.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: in writing. - Cooperation between the EU and China dates back forty years. They established their strategic relationship in 1975, signed a Trade and Cooperation Agreement in 1985, and have since continued to support China’s sustainable development by strengthening the partnership for political, economic and social reform. I voted in favor of the Belder report, as it reflects the paramount importance of bilateral strategic relations in addressing global issues such as global and regional security, tackling the economic crisis, energy security, non-proliferation, climate change, democracy and the promotion of human rights and the fight against organized crime and terrorism. At the same time, I consider it important that the decision calls on the Chinese authorities to abide by their international commitments on the rule of law and human rights, in particular freedom of religion, freedom of expression and media, and respect for Tibetans' human and religious rights, as a genuine strategic cooperation you cannot do without these values ​​either. As demonstrated at the Paris Climate Summit, the two sides are able to work together. The same can rightly be expected of the fundamental principles governing the EU's foreign policy.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: in writing. - In Asia and the Pacific, China and Taiwan are also important economic partners for the EU, and I therefore welcome the significant improvement in Sino-Taiwan relations and an EU-Taiwan Bilateral Investment Agreement, given that Taiwan joins China at regional level. leading best gateway and springboard for EU businesses, and many states, including the People’s Republic of China, have already concluded such (de facto) agreements with Taiwan. I am also pleased that China has accepted Taiwan's participation in certain UN organizations (WHO, ICAO), and is concerned that the Chinese Government has reaffirmed the 2005 anti-secession law, which allows for the use of military means if Taiwan's independence is declared. Disputes concerning China-Taiwan relations must be settled by peaceful means in accordance with international law. The meeting between senior officials from both sides of the Taiwan Strait on Kinmen Island on 23 May 2015 was a hopeful move, the third official meeting between Chinese and Taiwanese leaders responsible for China-Taiwan relations; supports initiatives that peacefully develop relations between China and Taiwan. I voted in favor of the report.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: written.- I voted in favor convinced that good relations and close cooperation between the EU and China can be of great benefit to both parties, which is why the EU-China Strategic Partnership is of vital importance.We must also bear in mind that China is an important trading partner of the EU, with a huge and expanding market.However, from the EU we must be vigilant in defending human rights and basic freedoms in China.

name: Enrico GASBARRA
text: in writing.- The strategic partnership with China offers important opportunities for European economic development and useful support to be able to respond to the main global emergencies, as well as to pursue shared interests and choices that are crucial for growth and security.Chinese interest in the European market could represent a crucial link for the Union for the success of the Junker plan: the leverage effect of China could in fact be the multiplier element for new investments in Europe.An opportunity that the Union cannot miss, which is why I vote in favor of the Belder report, remaining firmly convinced that in order to obtain the maximum economic effects, the first need is to ensure fairness, transparency and compliance with anti-dumping measures to protectEuropean regulations for business and employment.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the EP non-legislative resolution on EU-China relations because I believe that this strategic partnership is of fundamental importance to both sides and represents the right way to find common solutions to major global challenges. I find the political agreement for the improvement of strategic infrastructure links between the EU and China very interesting and I note the need to cooperate with the Asian giant in ambitious projects such as the One Belt, one Road, the initiative designed to build great connections in the energy and communications in Asia, which undoubtedly represents a channel of global geostrategic importance. I would also like to underline the urgency of the environmental issue, especially in the aftermath of the COP21 summit and the red alert in Beijing for the worrying levels of smog in the city. In this regard, I believe that greater cooperation between the EU and China is needed to address the main environmental challenges and the fight against climate change. Therefore, I express my doubts about the condition of human rights in China and the numerous and severe restrictions on freedom of expression, association and religion, especially towards the Tibetan people, and I remind you that in no case should economic rights prevail over civilian ones.

name: Arne GERICKE
