text: written.- I voted for the report on EU-China relations today, as I support Mr Belder's critical approach.At the same time, I urge the human rights violations in China - for example against members of Falun Gong or in the case of the illegally forced organ trafficking - and call on the EU to name them unreservedly.Human rights always take precedence over economic policy!

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: written.- Forty years of diplomatic relations between the EU and China are a success for both countries.Expanding this relationship offers many opportunities for both sides.However, in addition to economic advantages, it is also important to express social and political problems.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Belder report given it is important we start drawing the map for EU and China relations in the years ahead on crucial issues like global governance, human rights, and cooperation on investment and trade. The recent impact of China’s Black Monday on the stock market and the impact on our industry of Chinese dumping, not least in the UK steel and ceramics sectors, including in my region of the West Midlands, show that its financial and economic policies should also be firmly on our radar. Acting as a block, the EU can help ensure that the interests of these key sectors in member states are promoted and protected.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: written.- We have REFRAINED on this report.The report has two lines that make us unable to vote in favor: first, it calls for the signing of trade agreements with China and to take advantage of the commercial opportunities of China's rise.Second, it calls on China to "follow" the EU and the US in international politics.On the other hand, the points where repression and the lack of freedom are criticized are well developed.In addition, section 62 and the second part of section 51 have been approved, which were key for us.In this second part, the mandatory nature of a human rights clause in any bilateral treaty with China is mentioned and, in paragraph 62, obligations regarding labor regulations are imposed on European companies regardless of whether they are contemplated by Chinese law orno.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report which says the EU and China must work more closely together to tackle global challenges and threats, such as terrorism, illegal migration, security, climate change and global financial and market governance.

name: Nathan GILL
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP does not support the principle of the EU having any sort of foreign policy. This report gives an overall look at relations between the EU and China, supporting current agreements and calls for more EU action in several areas. This is therefore an endorsement of EU foreign policy. However it also raises several legitimate concerns, in particular with the attempted interference by the Chinese government in democratic processes within Hong Kong. In light of this balance UKIP abstained.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for the report on EU-China relations. Acknowledging the progress made over the last decades, there are still several areas of moderate or deep concern from the point of view of the European Parliament vis-à-vis the People’s Republic of China (PRC). With this report, amendments and compromises were adopted on human rights, the state of play in Tibet and Taiwan, freedom of expression, religious liberty, minorities protection or environmental threats.

name: András GYÜRK
text: in writing. - Cooperation between the EU and China dates back forty years. They established their strategic relationship in 1975, signed a Trade and Cooperation Agreement in 1985, and have since continued to support China’s sustainable development by strengthening the partnership for political, economic and social reform. I voted in favor of the Belder report, as it reflects the paramount importance of bilateral strategic relations in addressing issues such as global and regional security, economic crisis management, energy security, non-proliferation and non-proliferation, climate change, democracy and the rule of law. the promotion of human rights and the fight against organized crime and terrorism. At the same time, I consider it important that the decision calls on the Chinese authorities to abide by their international commitments on the rule of law and human rights, in particular freedom of religion, freedom of expression and freedom of the media, as real strategic cooperation cannot be without these values. As demonstrated at the Paris Climate Summit, the two sides are able to work together. The same can therefore rightly be expected of the fundamental principles governing the EU's foreign policy.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: GUE / NGL), in writing. - Unfortunately, the report is not balanced. He blames China and is clearly in favor of other countries in the region with which the EU has closer and better relations. Under the pretext of human rights, an attempt is being made to intervene in the interior of the country and in the path chosen by its own people. Certainly China has a long way to go on a number of human rights issues. The report has no legal force and does not take a position on whether or not we support EU-China relations, but describes the relations and aspirations. We are in favor of a close EU-China relationship with mutual understanding and a willingness to work together, but we believe that the report seeks to serve other interests.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ As this year marks the 40th anniversary of diplomatic relations between the EU and China, this own initiative report, which I voted in favour of, was produced to acknowledge the progress made over the last four decades and to highlight several areas of moderate and deep concern. In particular it reinforced several concerns on human rights, freedom of expression and environmental issues.  Furthermore, I was happy to see the introduction of several other important issues in the report, including the need to build a greater and consequent cooperation on trade focused on SMEs between both blocks, the legitimate concern on the unilateral establishment of an air-defence identification zone and the consequent claim over navigational air control within areas claimed by Japan and South Korea.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I chose to support this report due to the fact that 2015 marks the 40th anniversary of diplomatic relations between the EU and China. The EU-China Strategic Partnership is of key importance to relations between the EU and the People’s Republic of China (PRC) and to finding mutual answers to a range of global concerns and identifying common interests, such as global and regional security, counter-terrorism, the fight against organised crime, cybersecurity, weapons of mass destruction and nuclear non-proliferation, energy security, global financial and market regulation, climate change and sustainable development, It is also critical in creating a framework to address bilateral concerns between the EU and China.

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: written.- The report advocates close cooperation with China on global challenges such as climate change and China's strong involvement in international business organizations.Compliance with human rights in China remains a serious problem.The report extensively addresses the situation in Tibet and the restriction of individual freedoms.However, the report supports a constructive approach in dealing with China.I voted in favor of this report because it is balanced and takes into account the different aspects of EU-China relations.I also believe that the single euro must be abolished.It leads to discord and dissension in Europe.

name: György HÖLVÉNYI
text: in writing. - Cooperation between the EU and China dates back forty years. Their strategic relationship was established in 1975, and in 1985 they signed a Trade and Cooperation Agreement. Since then, the EU has continued to support China's sustainable development by strengthening its partnership for political, economic and social reform. I voted in favor of the Belder report, as it reflects the paramount importance of bilateral strategic relations. It addresses global issues such as global and regional security, tackling the economic crisis, energy security, non-proliferation and non-proliferation, the promotion of climate change, democracy and human rights, and the fight against organized crime and terrorism. fight. At the same time, I consider it important that the decision calls on the Chinese authorities to abide by their international commitments in the field of the rule of law and human rights, in particular freedom of religion, freedom of expression and freedom of the media. A true strategic partnership cannot do without these values ​​either. As demonstrated at the Paris Climate Summit, the two sides are able to work together. The same can rightly be expected of the fundamental principles governing the EU's foreign policy.

name: Ian HUDGHTON
text: in writing. ‒ China is an increasingly important partner to the EU and it is essential that relations continue to develop for our mutual benefit. Nonetheless we must continue to uphold human rights, democracy and the rule of law.  I consider that this report struck the correct balance and was able to vote in favour.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of this report that will establish a new connectivity platform with the aim of creating a favourable environment for sustainable and interoperable cross-border infrastructure networks between EU countries and China.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: written.- I voted in favor of the report on EU-China relations because the strategic partnership between the EU and China is crucial for finding common answers to a number of global issues and identifying common interests.China, as the EU's main trading partner with a huge and growing market, is certainly the desired strategic partner with which the EU began in 2013 to strengthen its bilateral cooperation and improve the global dimension of its strategic partnership.I certainly believe that successful EU-China cooperation needs to be further expanded and deepened in many areas, and that EU Member States need to make further use of the benefits offered by Chinese economic development.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. – UKIP does not support the principle of the EU having any sort of foreign policy. This report gives an overall look at relations between the EU and China, supporting current agreements and calls for more EU action in several areas. This is therefore an endorsement of EU foreign policy. However it also raises several legitimate concerns, in particular with the attempted interference by the Chinese government in democratic processes within Hong Kong. In light of this balance I abstained.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the report by my colleague Bas Belder on relations between the European Union and the People's Republic of China.On the occasion of 40 years of diplomatic relations between the two entities, the European Parliament underlines the beneficial role for both parties of the strategic partnership between China and the EU.Personal exchanges must nevertheless be encouraged and strengthened to accelerate exchanges.The report also underlines the need for the Chinese economy to diversify and recalls that the challenges of protecting human rights in China remain crucial.This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this report which welcomes the 40th anniversary of EU / China relations as a source of inspiration to strengthen our strategic partnership with this country.While welcoming the progress made in terms of partnerships, this report remains lucid vis-à-vis China and invites the Beijing authorities to greater respect for human rights (death penalty, Tibet, freedom ofexpression) as well as a de-escalation of tensions in the South China Sea.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: written.- The report creates a very realistic picture of the EU's relations with the People's Republic of China.The proposed approaches are quite sensible, but he shifts a lot of responsibility to the USA and hardly sets independent EU initiatives.Therefore I am abstaining from my vote.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report as it helps in defining the cooperation line for the EU with one of the most important players at global level.

name: Bernd KÖLMEL
text: written.- The report advocates close cooperation with China on global challenges such as climate change and China's strong involvement in international business organizations.Compliance with human rights in China remains a serious problem.The report extensively addresses the situation in Tibet and the restriction of individual freedoms.The report also supports a constructive approach in dealing with China.I voted in favor of this report because it is balanced and takes into account the different aspects of EU-China relations.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: In written form. - I supported the report because the strategic partnership between the EU and China is essential for finding common answers to a number of global problems for both countries, as well as for identifying common interests, such as global and regional security. The country is a major international power and one of the EU's most important partners. 2015 marks the 40th anniversary of EU-China diplomatic relations, but global challenges oblige us to seek to deepen our relations in the long term. China is a major trading partner for the EU and concluding an investment agreement can have a strong effect on our economies. Of course, the EU must build its partnerships on the democratic principles and high standards it upholds. It is necessary, above all, to seek a constructive dialogue with the authorities to improve the human rights situation in the country, as well as to deal with the deterioration of the environment.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: in writing.- I voted against this text because the EU is interfering in Chinese internal policy.However, I believe that every state - including China - has the right to exercise sovereignty over its territory.As for Chinese foreign policy, if it poses a problem, it is up to European states to protest, and not to the European Union.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: written. - I voted in favor, as it is a comprehensive report on EU-China relations on the occasion of the 40th anniversary of diplomatic relations between the two powers, which addresses political, economic, environmental, social and human rights issues. On the political level, the report praises the reforms undertaken by President Xi Jinping. On the economic front, the report points out the importance of the negotiations for the conclusion of an EU-China investment agreement that began in 2013, and expresses its concern about the slowdown in the Chinese economy and the consequences for the global market. Regarding the internal situation in China, concern about the degradation of environmental conditions in some cities of the country is highlighted. The human rights chapter is quite complete. It condemns the restrictions on freedom of expression, freedom of association and assembly, and religious freedom, as well as the persecution of human rights defenders, bloggers and ethnic minorities; the application of the death penalty is also condemned. Regarding the external situation and relations with Taiwan, the report calls for curbing the escalation of tension in the South China Sea.

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: written.- The report advocates close cooperation with China on global challenges such as climate change and China's strong involvement in international business organizations.Compliance with human rights in China remains a serious problem.The report extensively addresses the situation in Tibet and the restriction of individual freedoms.However, the report supports a constructive approach in dealing with China.I voted in favor of this report because it is balanced and takes into account the different aspects of EU-China relations.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: written.- I supported the report of MP Baso Belder on the occasion of the 40th anniversary of diplomatic relations between the EU and China - which is a key strategic partner in a number of global issues.I welcome the conclusions of the meeting held on 29 June, at which relations and cooperation were brought to a new level, and all the positive changes that have taken place under the leadership of President Xi.China is the EU's main trading partner, and the report calls for even better coordination in all areas, such as security, financial system, urbanization and development, and emphasizes the importance of co-operation on climate change and regional development.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: in writing.- In order to develop positive EU-China relations, it is necessary that they respect each other as strategic partners and not rivals.The EU is China's largest trading partner, while China is the EU's second largest trading partner.Through economic and political dialogue and in compliance with applicable regulations and international agreements, it is necessary to develop mutually beneficial trade relations, promote the development of investment, tourism, address environmental issues, cyber and computer security, as well as global and regional security issues.At the same time, it is a way of intensifying the promotion, respect and observance of human rights and the rule of law in China.EU Member States need to focus more on China's rapid economic development and seize its opportunities.

name: Ernest MARAGALL
text: in writing. – China is a key international power and one of the EU’s most important partners. The year 2015 marks the 40th anniversary between the EU and China, and it is significant to enhance the EU-China Strategic Partnership, which plays a key role in the relations between the EU and the People’s Republic of China in terms of finding key answers to a range of global concerns (environmental protection in particular) and identifying common interests. It is also important that the EU maintains a constructive dialogue with China to encourage China’s transition to the rule of law and respect for human rights. These are the main reasons why I have voted in favour of this report.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing.- I am voting against the report on EU-China relations because it is neither complete nor documented.I also vote against the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the Plenary Session of the European Parliament on 15/12/2015.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report which says the EU and China must work more closely together to tackle global challenges and threats, such as terrorism, illegal migration, security, climate change and global financial and market governance.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: in writing.- I strongly opposed this report.As always, the European Union allows itself, under the guise of "diplomatic relations" with third countries, to interfere in a scandalous way in the sovereignty of sovereign nations.The clear aim of the report is to weaken relations between China and Russia, the latter country still considered by the European Union to be unreliable and as having divergent strategic interests.The EU forgets, perhaps voluntarily, that the Russian Federation could be an ally of choice, in particular in the fight against Islamist terrorism.Obviously, the report cannot help but point out that China is guilty of human rights abuses, while continuing to attract as much Chinese capital to Europe as possible: the EU once again proves its contempt forThe other countries.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing.- China and the European Union have long been trading partners.Europe buys 20% of Chinese exports and China 10% of European exports and this is not just about trade issues but also about investments.The relationship between the European Union and China is also of particular importance in finding common responses to a number of global problems, such as the fight against terrorism and organized crime, energy security, climate change and sustainable development.Precisely because China appears to be a major international power and one of the main partners of the European Union, greater coordination is needed between the two in sectors of strategic importance.The European Union and China must act and cooperate on defense and security matters and commit themselves to the protection and promotion of human rights dialogue.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing.- I agree with the positions expressed in this report.With it, in fact, an attempt is made to underline the importance of exchanges between Chinese and European citizens, with the hope that the Chinese authorities intend to face the transition phase taking into account the necessary achievement of a sustainable economy.Parliament also notes that human rights in China remain a matter of concern.Democratic reforms are called for for the benefit of the people of Hong Kong.However, the alarms remain alive for the growing tension between the parties in the South China Sea and, therefore, a peaceful resolution of disputes, based on international law, is called for.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: written.- It is necessary for the EU and China to intensify their economic and political relations.I support the report of my colleague Antonio López-Istúriz, in which we ask to promote a comprehensive Strategic Association during the next decade, something that would be very beneficial for both parties from an economic, commercial and political point of view.

name: Georg MAYER
text: written.- The report contains some sensible approaches.However, it appears that the rapporteur believes that the EU would be powerless in foreign policy without the involvement of the US.The report also contains anti-Russian views.I therefore abstain from voting.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as an important milestone in the 40 years of diplomatic relations between the EU and China.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: in writing. - In this report, the EU is primarily driven by short-term mercantile and productivist concerns in Asian markets. This is the narrow meaning of the partnership and cooperation agreement defended by this report. There follows therefore an ode to neoliberalism against the Chinese economic model and its protectionism which would mistreat European companies (which nevertheless practice social dumping in this way on our soil). Since many Member States have bilateral agreements with China, MEPs have deemed it fashionable to associate all their criticism with it, sinking into the most intolerable interference. Everything goes there: from Tibet, through Ukraine and Syria. At no time is the role of the United States of America in the region or the settlement of conflicts in the China Sea mentioned. On the contrary, we should develop a global “common approach”, and not just mercantile, with the latter. I vote against this lost opportunity, this neo-colonial style of relating to China and the Atlanticist hysteria that points to every line.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the motion for a resolution on relations between the EU and China.There are several sectoral dialogues between China and the EU, namely on the environment, regional policy, employment and social affairs and civil society.The identification of common interests such as global and regional security, the fight against terrorism, the fight against organized crime, cybersecurity, weapons of mass destruction and nuclear non-proliferation, energy security, financial and market regulation at the levelclimate change and sustainable development, give this strategic partnership enormous value.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ This report applauds the 40 years of diplomatic relations between the EU and China and utilises it as a way to strengthen the Strategic Partnership. I chose to support this report as it is clear that the partnership between the EU and China is of mutual benefit.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: written. - The 40th anniversary of the start of diplomatic relations between the EU and China is the reason for this report. While we recognize that China has made progress in many areas over the past decades, we must remain alert to a number of evolutions that could adversely affect bilateral relations. In the last 20 years, China has developed into an economic superpower. Thanks to this economic "boost", more than 600 million Chinese have achieved a better socio-economic status. The downside is that Europe is not taking full advantage of China's giant economic leap and more often needs to express concern about the obstacles faced by European companies, such as lack of access to the Chinese market and lack of protection of intellectual property rights. The geostrategic effects of China's global investment policy and its investment activities in the EU and its neighborhood are still not sufficiently considered. Tangible improvements regarding the rule of law and respect for human rights remain insufficient, despite the commitment in March 2014 to deepen contacts between the EU and China in this area. I also supported the report because it also makes a case for enhanced cooperation in the fight against international terrorism.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: in writing. - Respecting China's fact that it has become a key power and one of the EU's most important partners, I consider it necessary, in the context of the EU-China Relations Report, not to turn a blind eye to human rights violations in that country. On the contrary, they must come first in mutual dialogue. Chinese human rights activists say their freedom is being restricted right now than it has been for decades. One of the reasons is the forthcoming adoption of a draft law on the treatment of foreign NGOs, which will further curtail the space for Chinese civil society and significantly restrict freedom of association and expression in the country, including a ban on "overseas NGOs" that are not registered with the Chinese Ministry of Public Security and the provincial security services, provided funding to Chinese individuals or organizations, as well as a ban on domestic workers working on their behalf. It is important to insist in negotiations with Chinese officials to bring their laws into line with international human rights standards and not to be silenced by China's current "check diplomacy". Even China's investment aid to the EU cannot overshadow a clear position on respect for human rights.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ China has emerged as an important player on the world scene and is a key trade and investment partner of the EU and for any Member State including Malta. It is in the interest of European business that the EU strives for a sound and balanced economic relationship with China. Therefore, I backed the resolution to strengthen the strategic partnership between the EU and China, but on the condition that the international trade between both sides is based on a fair global trade system and a level playing field among all players. We should have a constructive approach towards China, while being just in the areas where deficiencies are identified.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: in writing.- The report of the Committee on Foreign Affairs reviews the state of bilateral relations in the context of 40 years of diplomatic relations between the European Union and China, analyzes strategic issues, assesses areas where progress has been made and faces problems that have so far proved unsolvable.It takes a look at the issues of the Strategic Partnership, China's internal situation and problems, its foreign and military policy aspirations, the situation of human rights, and, as a special issue, China-Taiwan relations.The report proposes that the European Parliament take a position on these issues, thus guiding the future of EU-China relations.I supported the report.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. - The Union assumes a clear foreign policy vis-à-vis the BRIC and other emerging powers. This report appears in the development of a Strategic Partnership and in the celebrations of 40 years of Diplomatic relations between China and the Union. The meetings that have taken place between both parties, at the most diverse levels - commercial, scientific, cultural - are the example of commitment to move towards a strategic relationship. However, I would like to emphasize that there are issues that still concern us, in particular the issue of human rights, namely the demonstrations in Hong Kong calling for changes to the political system and behavior towards Tibet. At the same time, the growing escalation of tension with neighboring countries in the South China Sea region is also worrying. On the other hand, I welcome the progress in the dialogue between China and Taiwan. As I believe in the importance of dialogue for external relations and in the importance of this strengthening of relations, I am in favor of this report.

name: Claude MORAES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report which covers the relations between EU and China, divided into four parts covering EU-China Strategic Partnership and Cooperation, the internal situation, human rights and cross-Strait relations. It is important because it draws the map for EU and China relations in the years ahead.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this resolution on relations between the European Union and China.On the occasion of the 40th anniversary of the establishment of diplomatic relations between the Union and China, this text recalls that the strategic partnership concluded between the two parties is a fundamental instrument in the search for common responses to a set of challenges.planets, such as global and regional security, the fight against terrorism and organized crime, energy security, global financial regulation and the regulation of global markets, climate change and sustainable development.

name: Luigi MORGANO
text: in writing. - It is essential for Europe to maintain good relations with China, undoubtedly a global player of increasing importance. However, these relationships must be based on a relationship of trust and between equals. In the negotiations on investments and geographical indications, the EU and China are striving for a swift and ambitious agreement. The "stone guest" in bilateral relations, however, is the granting of market economy status at the World Trade Organization. The Chinese interpretation is that there must be an automatism in this sense; Conversely, the EU has long ago made it clear that a number of criteria must be met for recognition. China currently meets only one of them (absence of distortions by the state in business decisions). On the other hand, there is still a lack of transparency in tax legislation and in the granting of public procurement, where foreign companies are clearly discriminated against and whose appeal procedures are completely unsatisfactory. Furthermore, there are countless serious violations of intellectual property rights and the persistence of subsidies that create Chinese overcapacity in strategic sectors. I voted in favor of the report because EU-China relations are evolving. But China must put certain and adequate remedies to the unresolved distortions.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒  I have voted for this report that reiterates the key importance of a strategic partnership between EU and China in order to find mutual answers to global security, financial and market regulation, energy security and climate change, as well as sustainable development of a framework that can respond to bilateral concerns.

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: in writing.- I supported the report, which recognizes the importance of cooperation with China in specific areas, but is not discouraging and also raises the issue of human rights.China is a partner in areas such as the fight against terrorism, illegal migration, transnational crime, nuclear non-proliferation, cyber security, weapons of mass destruction, energy security, global financial and market regulation and climate change, but that does not mean that the EU will notraise your voice in cases where the freedoms of civil rights defenders, lawyers, journalists, bloggers, academics and other civil society representatives are being persecuted and restricted in China.The EU must not be deaf to ubiquitous censorship, which should be further strengthened by the draft law on cyber security.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: written.- I would have abstained because the report does not address current problems in the area of human rights.

name: Urmas PAET
text: in writing.- I supported.EU-China relations and their promotion, as well as finding a common language on various topics, are very important.China has an important role to play in promoting the world economy and in the fields of energy and climate, but also in foreign and security policy.China could be more involved in the fight against Daeshi, as well as avoiding tensions in the South China Sea and helping to resolve what is happening in North Korea.

name: Margot PARKER
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP does not support the principle of the EU having any sort of foreign policy. This report gives an overall look at relations between the EU and China, supporting current agreements and calls for more EU action in several areas. This is therefore an endorsement of EU foreign policy. However it also raises several legitimate concerns, in particular with the attempted interference by the Chinese government in democratic processes within Hong Kong. In light of this balance UKIP abstained.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: in writing. – As a member of the European Parliament’s Delegation for Relations with China, I am following closely the relationship between the European Union and China. The EU is China’s largest trade partner and China is the EU’s second largest partner. The Chinese economy has been growing vigorously in the last twenty years and EU Member States should take greater advantage of the opportunities offered by this economic development. That is why I am fully supporting the report on EU-China relations.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: written. - I support the report on EU-China relations. The report rightly notes the importance of China for the European Union in terms of cooperation in a number of fields, the key ones being the economy and the fight against asymmetric security threats. Nevertheless, despite the improvement of the general situation in China in combating poverty, overall progress and raising living standards, it is important to point out three items that must not be ignored. First, it is the protection of the environment and compliance with international agreements which regulate the goals of all states in combating activities and preventing actions that may adversely affect environmental pollution. China needs to make a clear departure from the current model of production that causes significant pollution. Second, the area in which China must work is the protection of human rights in their entirety and the consistent implementation of the rule of law. Family planning policies are the third problematic area. It is important to give China a clear signal that family planning policy must not be limited at the state level despite demographic policy goals. In this way, women are placed in an extremely unfavorable position, abortion and abandonment of children is encouraged. China must devise other mechanisms to control population growth in accordance with the needs of society, without violating the right to life.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: written. - Ahead of the 40th anniversary of diplomatic relations between the European Union and China, I welcome the constructive efforts of the report on the relationship between these two political and economic giants in a spirit of transparency and trust. I agree with the stated need for the members of the Union to coordinate their approach to China in view of the dynamic and active operation of Chinese diplomacy and the expected cooperation of the Union with the Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank. Furthermore, I believe that China should play a more important role in international financial institutions, but at the same time take more serious commitments in the areas of good governance, social responsibility and environmental protection. Also, enhanced coordination between China and the European Union in strategic areas such as counter-terrorism, nuclear non-proliferation, regulation of global financial and market flows, etc. would allow the Union to operate more effectively on the international stage and increase the level of trust in their relations. Finally, I believe that the Union must continue to highlight the problems and bad practices in China's domestic policy, especially with regard to human rights, media freedoms, the functioning of civil society, and so on.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: written. - I support the motion for a resolution by Mr Bastian Belder on EU-China relations. As diplomatic relations between the EU and China began in 1975, and this year marks the fortieth anniversary of the establishment of diplomatic relations, during which China is growing steadily as a global power, it is important to review European strategic priorities in relations with China. The partnership between the EU and China is essential for the identification of common interests, in order for bilateral cooperation to address common issues of interest. Some important global and common issues are global and regional security, the fight against terrorism and organized crime, cyber security, weapons of mass destruction and non-proliferation, energy security, global financial and market regulation, climate change and sustainable development. The fact that China is the EU's main trading partner should be taken into account and its tendency to expand the market should be borne in mind. I welcome the fact that China has made progress in a number of segments, such as the issue of the human rights situation, the fight against corruption and the reduction of the number of poor. On the other hand, it should be borne in mind that there is still a lot of room for improvement, especially in terms of ecology and climate change.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing.- China and the European Union have been trading partners for a long time.Europe buys 20% of Chinese exports and China 10% of European exports and it is not just about trade issues, but also about investments, which are developing rapidly on both fronts.Chinese investments in Europe have grown particularly fast in the years following the financial crisis, and in the last year the euro has depreciated against the Chinese currency by 25%.But beyond purely commercial exchange, cooperation on security and defense must be strengthened, the negotiations underway for a new partnership and cooperation agreement based on trust, transparency and respect for human rights must be accelerated and the great challenge of change tackled.climatic.For all these reasons, I have voted in favor of this report.

name: Franck PROUST
text: in writing.- I voted for the report on relations between the European Union and China.This year 2015 was marked by 40 years of our diplomatic relations with China.There have been changes in 40 years!But we must change our software vis-à-vis our partners such as China.It is no longer necessary to have a benevolent gaze on them, but to know how to be respected, effectively and in all diplomacy.We have conceded too much our know-how, some of our technologies to a country which will be ready in 2016 to wage a trade war against Europe if it does not obtain, by December, the status of market economy.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP does not support the principle of the EU having any sort of foreign policy. This report gives an overall look at relations between the EU and China, supporting current agreements and calls for more EU action in several areas. This is therefore an endorsement of EU foreign policy. However it also raises several legitimate concerns, in particular with the attempted interference by the Chinese government in democratic processes within Hong Kong. In light of this balance UKIP abstained.

name: Dominique RIQUET
text: in writing. - Over the past forty years, the European Union (EU) has forged a set of privileged links with China, in the economic, diplomatic and commercial fields, like the trade and cooperation agreement of 1985. In an unstable global economic and geopolitical context, it is necessary to preserve and strengthen strategic relations with this country, which represents a considerable market for our industries and services. China is indeed one of the Union's leading trading partners in terms of both our imports and our exports. Chinese investments also constitute a considerable opportunity to expand the European Fund for Strategic Investments as well as closer cooperation with the Asian Investment Bank for infrastructure. A successful rapprochement between the EU and China would be an opportunity to assert our concerns for fundamental freedoms, such as freedom of the press and of expression. For all these reasons, I supported the report on EU-China relations.

name: Robert ROCHEFORT
text: in writing. - I voted for the resolution on EU-China relations. The year 2015 marks the 40th anniversary of diplomatic relations between China and the European Union, an opportunity to discuss the negotiations for a new partnership and cooperation agreement, based on trust, transparency and respect for rights. of man. This type of closer cooperation could help tackle common global challenges and threats such as illegal immigration, terrorism, climate change and global financial and market governance. The Bilateral Investment Agreement (BIA), currently under negotiation, could be an important tool to ensure fair treatment of businesses in Europe and China. Let us recall here that a chapter on sustainable development should absolutely be found there, economic growth having led to significant environmental problems and great inequalities in China. Finally, we must stress that the human rights situation in China remains worrying, especially the unacceptable policies towards the Tibetan people. I hope that the Chinese leaders reconsider their position and respect the universality of human rights. We must also continue to strongly oppose repressive bills or those aimed at unfairly weakening foreign NGOs.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: in writing. - If I voted in favor of this report, it is because I believe that closer cooperation between the European Union and China is desirable in order to face global challenges. These challenges include terrorism, illegal immigration, security, climate change, and global financial and market governance. To do this, we must move forward towards a new partnership and cooperation agreement based in particular on respect for human rights. Because if China's economy is growing steadily, we cannot say the same about respect for human rights. By voting for this report, I urge the European Union to speak out with force and conviction against the government measures taken in this country to restrict freedom of association and expression. If China remains an important economic partner, we cannot hide its shortcomings in social as well as environmental matters. Let us ensure that the Chinese authorities provide solutions to these problems as quickly as possible. It should be noted that this report does not address the question of the possible recognition of the status of market economy for China by the European Union, a point on which I will remain uncompromising.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. - This report on relations between the EU and China, which I voted in favor of, follows on from the celebration of the 40th anniversary of our diplomatic relations, stating that this anniversary should serve as “a source of inspiration to strengthen the strategic partnership, so necessary in a multipolar and globalized world, and to accelerate ongoing negotiations on a new partnership and cooperation agreement, based on trust, transparency and respect for human rights. The high-level strategic dialogue and, more specifically, its practical implementation in strengthening the rapprochement between the two economies, has contributed to the fact that, in the last 20 years, there has been vigorous growth in China and an increase in its strategic importance as European partner in Asia. The strengthening of the joint dialogue should also prioritize the protection of human rights, particularly in Tibet, and the situation of (almost) permanent tension in the South China Sea. In view of the opportunities offered by this strengthening of cooperation and dialogue - for example in the context of sustainable development and the circular economy - European and Chinese citizens and businesses now have new possibilities for approximation that should not be missed.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this report, which takes stock of relations between the European Union and China and encourages the strengthening of their cooperation in various fields.These include the fight against terrorism, illegal immigration, security, climate change and global financial and market governance.Diplomatic relations between the EU and China are celebrating their 40th anniversary and the conclusions of the EU-China summit on June 19, 2015 must be continued.It is also about strengthening EU-China relations in order to make progress in the defense of human rights and fundamental freedoms.Finally, it is important to continue to work together to improve the situation of environmental protection and encourage China to take more actions in this direction.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: written.- We have REFRAINED on this report.The report has two lines that make us unable to vote in favor: first, it calls for the signing of trade agreements with China and to take advantage of the commercial opportunities of China's rise.Second, it calls on China to "follow" the EU and the US in international politics.On the other hand, the points where repression and the lack of freedom are criticized are well developed.In addition, section 62 and the second part of section 51 have been approved, which were key for us.In this second part, the mandatory nature of a human rights clause in any bilateral treaty with China is mentioned and, in paragraph 62, obligations regarding labor regulations are imposed on European companies regardless of whether they are contemplated by Chinese law orno.

name: Sven SCHULZE
text: written.- Good relations with the People's Republic of China are of the greatest importance to us Europeans economically, culturally and in terms of security.China will soon be the largest economy in the world and Europe's most important trading partner.It is therefore important that we have dialogues with the Chinese at all levels.The human rights situation, which is still difficult, must not be ignored.The same goes for the situation in Tibet, Hong Kong and Taiwan, where many people are suffering from Beijing's policies.The report rightly states that the EU must repeatedly call for dialogue and a willingness to talk and identify the problems.Overall, a good compromise was found that reflects our values and policies towards China.I therefore agreed today.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: written.- I voted against this report, because it has a strong focus on the so-called "indispensable" role of the US, and calls for a common approach to be developed with the US on China, holdingthat this will help promote the interests of the EU, something with which I do not agree.In addition, it delves into issues that are not the competence of the EU or of this report, such as denouncing that China is allying with Russia to block the action of the United Nations with respect to Syria.For this reason, and although I have found interesting elements for which I have voted in favor, I have had to vote against the adoption of this report as a whole.

name: Remo SERNAGIOTTO
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the report as it provides a balanced assessment of the growing ties between the European Union and China, making a number of recommendations to improve and strengthen the cooperation and strategic partnership between the two sides, while clarifying some issues in this regard the situation of human rights and democracy in the Asian country. Although China is an important trading partner of the EU, I would however like to remind you that it cannot be considered a market economy country as it does not meet the five criteria required by European legislation to obtain such recognition. A contrary decision to this effect would risk exposing many European industrial sectors to unfair Chinese competition with serious consequences and job losses. Finally, I hope that the European Union and China can adopt a coordinated strategic approach to address common global challenges such as the fight against corruption, economic and social progress inspired by the principle of sustainable development, disarmament and weapons of mass destruction, the fight against terrorism and climate change.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this report as I believe individual nation states should deal with each other directly, rather than through the mechanisms of the EU.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ The report makes a general overview of the EU’s relationship with China and vice versa. It addresses the political, economic and environmental aspects of our relationship as well as the sore topic of social and human rights.  It was important that this document be voted through the European Parliament, as it aids in defining the cooperation line for the EU with one of today’s most important global players.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: in writing. - The EU-China Strategic Partnership is of great importance for bilateral cooperation and for finding common answers to many global challenges, as well as creating a framework for addressing bilateral issues between the EU and China. I supported the resolution because I consider the relations and cooperation between the two partners to be extremely important and also because both sides contribute equally to global stability. However, I see priority cooperation in the economic field, in which the EU is China's most important trading partner and China is the world's largest exporter and the EU's second most important partner (after the United States). However, I regret that significant changes in the level of EU-China relations cannot be expected in the area of ​​human and civil rights, as evidenced by the many cases of disappearances or ill-treatment of Chinese human rights defenders. I also see deteriorating relations between the partners due to the strengthening of China's position on the international stage due to economic growth, but also due to a number of reforms, for example in the military sector. I believe that, despite these unfavorable facts, the partnership between the EU and China will continue and focus on areas that are mutually beneficial, which do not constitute a conflict of interest or a conflict of views.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: in writing.- I supported the resolution on EU-China relations.Relations between China and the European Union are intensifying, both at the level of individual states (including the Czech Republic) and the Union and its institutions.This year we commemorated the 1940s since the establishment of relations between the People's Republic of China and the European Communities.However, in rapprochement with China, we must not forget Taiwan, with which we do not have diplomatic relations, but we have common political and economic interests and the fact that Taiwan is the only functioning democracy in the Chinese context.I also supported the resolution because, in addition to positive assessments of and relations with China, it does not forget the many problematic issues, such as human rights, the rule of law and intellectual property, or the situation in Tibet and Xinjiang in Uighur.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: in writing. - 2015 marks 40 years since the establishment of diplomatic relations between the EU and China, which are essential for finding reciprocal answers to a range of global issues and for identifying common interests. China is an important trading partner of the EU, which led to the start of negotiations on a bilateral investment agreement in 2013. On 29 June 2015, the EU-China Summit took place in Brussels, at which both sides reiterated their commitment to deepening the partnership. At this summit, bilateral relations were raised to a new level, and a signal was given for closer political cooperation, which would go beyond just trade relations and focus on a coordinated strategic approach. The report highlights, among other things, the strong economic growth of the Chinese economy over the last twenty years and emphasizes that Member States should make better use of the opportunities offered by this economic development. I agree that China should play a greater role in multilateral financial institutions, which would better reflect the size of its economy. I also believe that increased coordination between the EU and China is needed in areas of strategic importance. The report reflects the current picture of EU-China relations and highlights critical points that need to be addressed in order to improve cooperation. Because of what has been described, I supported the report in plenary.

name: Joachim STARBATTY
text: written.- The report advocates close cooperation with China on global challenges such as climate change and China's strong involvement in international business organizations.Compliance with human rights in China remains a serious problem.The report extensively addresses the situation in Tibet and the restriction of individual freedoms.However, the report supports a constructive approach in dealing with China.I voted in favor of this report because it is balanced and takes into account the different aspects of EU-China relations.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: in writing.- China is the EU's strategic trading partner, and I therefore welcome any intensification of trade relations.Of course, the issues of IPR infringements and the issue of climate change also need to be discussed in the next negotiations.The issue of Chinese steel dumping remains an open question for resolution.

name: Jaromír ŠTĚTINA
text: in writing. - I supported the report on EU-China relations because it not only commemorates the anniversary of the establishment of diplomatic relations and the importance of our strategic trade partnership, but also reminds China of the importance of de facto compliance with international commitments on human rights and fundamental freedoms. The values ​​of human rights, the rule of law and peace cannot only be formally recognized by China, they must be reflected in its daily lives. The widespread censorship of the Internet, religious repression against Tibetans and Uighurs, and the marginalization of minority cultural rights in China cannot simply be closed. The report's efforts to commemorate China's role in international relations and as a permanent member of the UN Security Council can also be commended. Instead of provoking provocations in the South China Sea and constantly blocking UN activities in the Syrian conflict, China should contribute more to peace and global security. I am glad that the report emphasizes these issues. Given my long commitment to the Ukrainian issue, I also supported China's call for support for US and EU initiatives to end international law violations in the conflict in Ukraine.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: written. - I supported the European Parliament's motion for a resolution on EU-China relations, given that the structured political dialogue between the EU and China officially began in 1994, and that a high-level strategic dialogue on strategic and foreign policy issues was launched in 2010, and in particular the 5th High Level Strategic Dialogue between the EU and China held on 6 May 2015 in Beijing. I therefore call for better coordination between the EU and China in areas of strategic importance such as the G20, security and defense, the fight against terrorism, illegal migration, transnational crime, nuclear non-proliferation, global and regional security, cyber security, weapons of mass destruction, energy security, global governance of financial systems and markets and their regulation, climate change and urbanization, development and assistance programs and sustainable development. I would stress the importance of the EU-China bilateral trade agreement on investment, which is currently being negotiated, and call for a full chapter on sustainable development to be included in the bilateral investment agreement, which provides binding commitments to the ILO's core labor standards. and key multilateral environmental agreements, and further measures and active monitoring to ensure more balanced trade relations for European companies after the removal of barriers to trade and investment.

name: Catherine STIHLER
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome this report on EU-China relations which draws the map for EU and China relations in the years ahead.  The report addresses important issues such as the EU and China Strategic Partnership and cooperation, the internal situation, human rights and cross-Strait relations.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: written. - The 40th anniversary of the establishment of diplomatic relations between the EU and China is being marked. A strategic partnership has been created, which is urgently needed in a multipolar and globalized world, and to speed up the ongoing negotiations on a new partnership and cooperation agreement based on trust, transparency and respect for human rights. China should play a stronger role in multilateral financial institutions. There are 60 sectoral dialogues between the EU and China on a wide range of different issues. The parties involved should avoid unilateral provocative moves in the South China Sea. Disputes need to be settled peacefully in accordance with international law and through mechanisms for impartial international mediation such as the UN Convention on the Law of the Sea (UNCLOS). China and Taiwan are important EU economic partners in Asia, and the conflict needs to be resolved as peacefully as possible. I support this proposal because I believe that EU-China relations must offer an effective platform for a mature, meaningful and open human rights dialogue, and the 40th anniversary of EU-China relations in 2015 provides a real opportunity to make progress in this area. China is a key international power and one of the EU's most important partners.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the report because I welcome the enormous and mutual benefits of EU-China relations, but I am also concerned about the continuing lack of respect for human rights and democracy in China.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: in writing.- I supported the report on relations between the European Union and China.The report makes it clear that the human rights situation in China is a matter of serious concern and that China needs to make great progress in respecting human rights and fundamental freedoms if it is to become a developed country and possibly a democracy in the future.I welcome the report's deep concern at the forthcoming adoption of China's draft NGO governance law, as this law could lead to further shrinking space for Chinese civil society and severely restrict freedom of association and expression in the country.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: GUE / NGL), in writing. - We voted against the report on EU-China relations because it neither puts the development of EU-China relations on the right footing, nor does it exercise constructive criticism. On the contrary, the report is hypocritical and fully identical with the foreign policy and interests of the EU's ruling circles. at the same time the need to expand trade agreements and economic ties between the EU and China. That is why we decided to vote against the report.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI), in writing.- The EU must first create an independent foreign policy, harnessing its power and then intervening internally in other countries and especially powers such as China.I focus especially on the paragraphs where China is urged to intervene and condemn Assad and Russia on the issue of Ukraine.

name: József SZÁJER
text: in writing. - Cooperation between the EU and China dates back forty years. They established their strategic relationship in 1975, signed a Trade and Cooperation Agreement in 1985, and have since continued to support China’s sustainable development by strengthening the partnership for political, economic and social reform. The Belder report, as it reflects the paramount importance of bilateral strategic relations in addressing global issues such as global and regional security, economic crisis management, energy security, non-proliferation and non-proliferation, climate change, democracy and human rights; the promotion of human rights and the fight against organized crime and terrorism. At the same time, I consider it important that the decision calls on the Chinese authorities to abide by their international commitments on the rule of law and human rights, in particular freedom of religion, freedom of expression and freedom of the media, as real strategic cooperation cannot be without these values. As demonstrated at the Paris Climate Summit, the two sides are able to work together. The same can rightly be expected of the fundamental principles governing the EU's foreign policy.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: in writing. - This year is the 40th anniversary of establishing diplomatic relations between the European Union and China. Our relationships have never been so dynamic; they take place on all levels: political, economic, social and scientific. This strategic partnership is now taking it to the next higher level. Firstly - by starting negotiations on a bilateral investment agreement in 2013, and secondly - by jointly fighting terrorism, organized crime and climate change in international fora. The report of the European Parliament emphasized the importance of China for the European Union, and properly indicated the consequences of the current internal and external changes in the Middle Kingdom, such as the economic slowdown, the stock market crash in 2015, the country's liberalization or a dynamic arms policy . In addition, the report stresses the importance of better coordination of the actions of EU Member States in relations with China, as well as better coordination between the EU and China in areas of strategic global importance. Therefore, I have chosen to vote in favor of the EP report.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. ‒ This report covers the relations between EU and China, which began 40 years ago, covering political, economic, environmental, social and human rights aspects. The report follows a constructive approach that highlights both China’s vigorous economic growth and international importance, and the deficiencies it has yet to overcome. Initially, the report calls for enhanced coordination and cooperation between the EU and China in areas of strategic significance, such as security, climate change, sustainable development, market governance and regulation. The report also states the EU’s support for an open human rights dialogue between the EU and China based on mutual respect. The report also takes account of the tensions in the South China Sea by asking all parties to avoid provocative actions that lead to escalations, and instead to favour peaceful settlements of disputes according to international laws and arbitration. China is a significant partner for the EU, and I believe the current report represents the importance of open and constructive relationships between the sides. I also believe that the current document can help defining the cooperation line for the EU with China; for this reason I voted in favour of the report.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: in writing.- I also stress, as my colleagues have done, that China is an important partner, that it is making efforts and that we must work with it.I nevertheless call on the EEAS to ensure that human rights are high on the agenda for relations and dialogues with China.On the other hand, trade agreements should not be an excuse for the establishment of an ISDS, even light!

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report on the relations between the EU and the People’s Republic of China. Indeed, this country is an important partner for some countries of the European Union, but the relations are extremely unequal and more could be done to reinforce the link between the EU and China. In this respect the report addresses various different issues, such as the bilateral investment agreement currently being negotiated, the multiple meetings taking place between the two parties, respect for human rights, as well as China’s domestic and external policy.

name: László TŐKÉS
text: in writing. - Cooperation between the EU and China dates back forty years. Their strategic relationship was established in 1975, a Trade and Cooperation Agreement was signed in 1985, and since then the EU has consistently supported China’s sustainable development by strengthening its partnership for political, economic and social reform. I voted in favor of the Belder report, as it reflects the paramount importance of bilateral strategic relations in addressing global issues such as global and regional security, economic crisis management, energy security, non-proliferation and climate change, climate change, democracy. and the promotion of human rights and the fight against organized crime and terrorism. At the same time, I consider it important that the decision calls on the Chinese authorities to abide by their international commitments on the rule of law and human rights, in particular freedom of religion, freedom of expression and freedom of the media, as real strategic cooperation cannot be without these values. As demonstrated at the Paris Climate Summit, the two sides are able to work together. The same can rightly be expected of the fundamental principles governing the EU's foreign policy.

name: Valdemar TOMAŠEVSKI
text: in writing.- I supported the resolution on EU-China relations, as the 40th anniversary of EU-China diplomatic relations requires an appropriate response from Parliament in order to strengthen the strategic partnership and speed up the ongoing negotiations on a new Partnership and Cooperation Agreement.This is important for every EU Member State.China is a major international power and one of the EU's most important partners, and the Member States must speak with one voice in their dealings with the Chinese Government.Only in this way will the negotiations be successful and benefit Europe as a whole.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: written.- I supported the report on EU-China relations, which explains the situation in five key areas, namely: strategic partnership and cooperation between the European Union and China, the internal situation in China, external relations, the human rights situation and cross-relations.I believe that the report rightly highlights key areas where further reforms and improvements are needed, in particular the human rights situation.Namely, although Chinese strategic investments in Europe are very welcome, there are major internal problems that China should solve, primarily the fight against corruption, regional tensions and violence, and relations with Taiwan.While it is clear that a growing regional and global economic player is important, I believe that China needs to implement significant reforms in line with its economic growth to ensure that social, civil and political rights are respected, as highlighted in the report.

name: Romana TOMC
text: in writing.- I supported the report on EU-China relations, as I believe that the EU-China partnership is of strategic importance.China is one of the EU's most important partners.China is a central international power and thus makes an important contribution to global security, the fight against terrorism, global financial and market regulation, and sustainable development.It is also very important for the EU and China to work together on investment, as China has a large and growing market and is an important trading partner of the EU.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: written.- We have REFRAINED on this report.The report has two lines that make us unable to vote in favor: first, it calls for the signing of trade agreements with China and to take advantage of the commercial opportunities of China's rise.Second, it calls on China to "follow" the EU and the US in international politics.On the other hand, the points where repression and the lack of freedom are criticized are well developed.In addition, section 62 and the second part of section 51 have been approved, which were key for us.In this second part, the mandatory nature of a human rights clause in any bilateral treaty with China is mentioned and, in paragraph 62, obligations regarding labor regulations are imposed on European companies regardless of whether they are contemplated by Chinese law orno.

name: Ulrike TREBESIUS
text: written.- The report advocates close cooperation with China on global challenges such as climate change and China's strong involvement in international business organizations.Compliance with human rights in China remains a serious problem.The report extensively addresses the situation in Tibet and the restriction of individual freedoms.However, the report supports a constructive approach in dealing with China.I voted in favor of this report because it is balanced and takes into account the different aspects of EU-China relations.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. ‒ I am still worried about certain fundamental freedoms and human rights not being respected in China. Moreover internet freedom is not guaranteed. I note that a strong contradiction exists between the official Chinese aspiration to the universality of human rights and the worsening human rights situation. Recently there has been a worsening of the situation of human rights and freedoms in China that started in 2013 and has intensified an already existing crackdown on the population, limiting the space for expression and peaceful advocacy for civil society even further. The Tibetan people but also the Uighur population remain discriminated against and their freedom and fundamental rights are being violated. Let me remind you once again that his Holiness the Dalai Lama is not asking for independence of Tibet but through the memorandum he proposed more autonomy for Tibet. China should grasp this opportunity. Freedom for Tibet means freedom for China.

name: István UJHELYI
text: in writing.- I see that the EU as a whole and the Member States individually, everyone wants to work with China, to conclude economic agreements.Unfortunately, this intention to cooperate is not sufficiently reflected in the report, we are educating China in many places, we are in the wrong style for the issue.Unfortunately, that is why I was not able to vote in favor of the report.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: written.- We have REFRAINED on this report.The report has two lines that make us unable to vote in favor: first, it calls for the signing of trade agreements with China and to take advantage of the commercial opportunities of China's rise.Second, it calls on China to "follow" the EU and the US in international politics.On the other hand, the points where repression and the lack of freedom are criticized are well developed.In addition, section 62 and the second part of section 51 have been approved, which were key for us.In this second part, the mandatory nature of a human rights clause in any bilateral treaty with China is mentioned and, in paragraph 62, obligations regarding labor regulations are imposed on European companies regardless of whether they are contemplated by Chinese law orno.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour in this matter because I recognise China as a relevant stakeholder in a worldwide political and economic sense and also as a relevant partner of European Union in many fields. 2015 marks the 40th anniversary of diplomatic relations between the EU and China, whereas the EU-China Strategic Partnership is of key importance to relations between the EU and the People’s Republic of China (PRC) and to finding mutual answers to a range of global concerns and identifying common interests, such as global and regional security, counter-terrorism, the fight against organised crime, cyber security, weapons of mass destruction and nuclear non-proliferation, energy security, global financial and market regulation, climate change and sustainable development, as well as in creating a framework to address bilateral concerns between the EU and China.  In this resolution we address the topics of the EU-China Strategic Partnership and cooperation, the internal and external situation, the human rights situation, and cross-Strait relations, and I believe it shows a comprehensive approach that can be a significant step in increasing cooperation with China.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: written.- This report aims to recognize the weight and importance of China as a trade partner of the EU and, at the same time, highlight some issues that concern the EU, such as those related to the transition of the Chinese economy towards a more sustainable model,the concern related to human rights in the Asian giant or the problems with Hong Kong and Tibet.We are talking, therefore, of a report that not only includes the need to continue maintaining relations with the Asian giant, but also points out important points that must be worked on.I therefore consider it necessary to vote in favor of this report.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: written.- I voted for this report, which concerns many aspects of the relationship between the European Union and China.If we want to tackle global challenges, we will have to work better with China.That is why I support this report which advocates new cooperation agreements based on trust, transparency and respect for human rights.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: in writing. - This report is part of the current negotiations of the EU-China partnership and cooperation agreement. This agreement should cover the fields of industry, agriculture, technology, energy, environmental protection ... This report recognizes the need to respond to the challenges facing the EU jointly and China, particularly with regard to the environment. He recalls the need for European companies to respect international labor standards. Finally, it addresses the issue of human rights (NGOs, minorities, freedom of expression or the death penalty). It also shows the will to impose an economic model definitively converted to free trade and there are many parallels with the TTIP. The public subsidies of the Chinese state to its companies are also condemned and a greater involvement of China in the WTO and the IMF is called for there. Finally, he incongruously urges China to intervene in the Ukrainian issue. Negotiating this type of agreement once again demonstrates the priority given to economic issues: China is a "big market" of 1.7 billion people. China is a major global player and the negotiation of this agreement, if it succeeds, will be interesting to follow. In the meantime, I have chosen to abstain.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. - 2015 marks the 40th anniversary of the establishment of diplomatic relations between the EU and China. The EU – China strategic partnership is of great importance, both for relations between the EU and the People's Republic of China (PRC), and for the development of common solutions in relation to various global concerns, the identification of common interests. In 2013, China and the EU started negotiations for a bilateral investment treaty. In other words, we consider the deepening of relations between the EU and the People's Republic of China to be positive, provided that this deepening is based on respect for the sovereignty and independence of the parties and, in particular, on the right to choose their economic and social development strategy. What we do not recognize is neither the legitimacy and, much less, the moral authority of the EU in giving lessons in democracy when we know that here, as it is easy to witness, lives in a true financial dictatorship of big business.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: written.- The report contains some sensible approaches.However, it appears that the rapporteur believes that the EU would be powerless in foreign policy without the involvement of the US.The report also contains anti-Russian views.I therefore abstain from voting.

name: Theodoros ZAGORAKIS
text: PPE), in writing.- I voted in favor of the report on EU-China relations, as it presents a realistic framework for cooperation.The EU-China Strategic Partnership is indeed very important.China is a major international power and one of the EU's most important partners. However, we should not overlook the problems and differences that we will be called upon to resolve together in the coming years.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: in writing.- I supported Mr Belder's third report on relations between the European Union and China.The report on the occasion of the 40th anniversary of formal relations assesses the European Union's ties with the country well and realistically.I appreciate that, in addition to the sections addressing the challenges of maintaining and strengthening cooperation, the report also looks at a realistic assessment of the current situation in China, especially with regard to human rights issues, the death penalty, of which China is the world's largestimplementers, but also environmental problems.I hope that the parliamentary calls formulated in this way will also help to ensure that the great growth of the Chinese economy is accompanied evenly by positive changes in human rights and the environment.

name: Kosma ZŁOTOWSKI
text: in writing. - Cooperation between the European Union and the PRC is undoubtedly one of the strategic areas of our common external policy. Both the economic partnership and political relations with Beijing are very important to us. However, our perception of these relations cannot be one-dimensional and must take into account, apart from the huge economic opportunities, also existing problems, including human rights issues. The resolution adopted today balances these issues well and highlights the most important opportunities and challenges facing us and our Chinese partners in the coming years, which is why I voted in favor of it. Particular enthusiasm is aroused by the possibilities of cooperation in the field of infrastructure building and the creation of the New Silk Road.
