text: written. - Socialists have managed to consolidate a progressive position for the next World Humanitarian Summit (Istanbul, May 2016), we emphasize the key elements to reform the current humanitarian aid system, such as: guaranteeing the defense of humanitarian principles and the impartiality of aid from a political point of view and put mechanisms in place to ensure that governments are accountable for their roles and responsibilities in the area of ​​protecting the most vulnerable. As key measures it is proposed: a global consensus for humanitarian action, greater transparency and accountability regarding the use of aid, a code of conduct for donors and a global fund that ensures and facilitates sufficient means to tackle crises such as Ebola or that of Syrian refugees. We regret that the extremist groups (left and right) of the European Parliament have not supported this report or have abstained, without betting on the protection of the most vulnerable, human dignity and respect for human rights. They have neglected the empowerment of women, the education of children and the protection of migrants and refugees in emergencies.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: written. - This report assesses the weaknesses and threats that the world we live in is facing and that are growing due to natural disasters, rapid population growth or scarcity of resources, among other things. What is expected of the World Humanitarian Summit, convened by the United Nations and to be held in Turkey, is listed below. Among other objectives, Parliament urges the Member States to adopt specific commitments and priority areas of action, and the EU itself, as the world's largest humanitarian aid donor, to show leadership at the Summit. Furthermore, among other things, it calls for the right to education to be guaranteed more effectively in situations of protracted humanitarian crises and that special emphasis be placed on the issue of climate change and humanitarian action. For the reasons set out here and for others, for which there is no space but are equally crucial, I voted in favor of this report.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: in writing. - The European Union is the largest donor and supporter of humanitarian action. Humanitarian aid is also based on four principles enshrined in the Lisbon Treaty - humanity, neutrality, impartiality and independence. It should therefore be provided to people who really need it, regardless of any external or internal factors of the country in which they live. The number of people reliant on humanitarian aid has multiplied in recent years, due to the countries' internal and regional conflicts, but also to natural disasters. The situation is all the more complicated because some countries do not respect international humanitarian law, making it impossible to provide aid. The Humanitarian Aid Regulation was adopted in 1996, and it is logical that, in its twenty years of existence, it will no longer respond to the changing situation in the world. It is therefore necessary to revise it and adapt it to the new conditions so that the delivery of aid is coordinated and effective in the interests of those who need and depend on humanitarian aid.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing.- I vote in favor of the report entitled "Preparing for the World Humanitarian Summit: Challenges and Opportunities for Humanitarian Aid" and refer to the reasons I gave in detail in my speech to the European Parliament on 15/12/2015.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this resolution which ‘Stresses that today’s enormous humanitarian challenges require a more inclusive, diverse and truly global humanitarian system, to be strengthened at the WHS, that, at the same time, recognises the diversity in today’s humanitarian response system and the complementary roles of all actors; calls on the EU to promote a “Global Consensus on Humanitarian Action” that reaffirms the principles of humanitarian aid and the obligations and entitlements under international humanitarian law (IHL), while ensuring people-centred and human rights-based protection responses, and holds governments accountable for their roles and responsibilities in protecting people; raises awareness of the negative impacts of the politicisation of humanitarian assistance, and recalls that the upholding of, and continued commitment to, core humanitarian principles is critical to ensure a humanitarian space in areas of conflict and natural disasters’.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: in writing.- I abstained on this text.This report prepares the major texts that will be discussed at the World Humanitarian Summit to be held on March 23 and 24, 2016 in Istanbul.This summit is being held for the first time, following recent conflicts and the large numbers of displaced people.This report calls on Member States to increase their funding for humanitarian aid in order to ensure a high level of aid for all people.This promising text opens up new perspectives on humanitarian aid by emphasizing in particular prevention rather than ad hoc management.But it is unfortunately polluted by claims which have no connection with the subject.We thus end up with a text reoriented towards sex education and "education for relational life", polluted by LGBT claims, and of course, directed to the great benefit of migrants.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing.- I welcome the report on preparation for the World Humanitarian Summit.The enormous challenges for the World Humanitarian Summit require the elaboration of a new humanitarian system aimed at strengthening and promoting the protection of the principles of humanitarian aid, guaranteeing protection responses, centered on people and based on human rights, capable ofto hold governments, local authorities, and international organizations accountable, to promote the adoption of actions aimed at ensuring access to assistance for affected communities, in particular women, children and the most vulnerable groups, and theirparticipation in related decision-making processes.

name: Jiří MAŠTÁLKA
text: in writing. - Today, we voted on a report on preparations for the World Humanitarian Summit. Humanitarian aid is a very important topic, so I am glad that we had the opportunity to discuss this topic. The report contains alarming facts that the number of people in need has more than doubled since 2004 and exceeded 100 million in 2015; the humanitarian crisis is affecting 250 million people; and the number of forcibly displaced persons is the highest since World War II, reaching almost 60 million. We must also realize that children, women and other particularly vulnerable groups are most affected by these consequences. I fully agree that poverty and crisis vulnerability are inextricably linked, which emphasizes the need to address the root causes of crises and to meet the long-term needs of the population affected by crises. I am also well aware that the consequences of humanitarian crises will be even more serious if their real causes are not addressed and humanitarian aid is not better linked to development cooperation. However, as the report emphasizes in particular the importance of the private sector, including trade objectives, which I personally think is not entirely one of the priorities in humanitarian aid, I abstained in the final vote.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing.- The report by my colleague Salomi aims to address the growing challenges in the area of aid and humanitarian assistance.The EU could consider sponsoring a "Comprehensive Consensus on Humanitarian Action", recognizing the diversity of the current humanitarian response system and exploiting all complementary roles.I support by voting in favor.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: written.- The EU has to take the lead and play a central role in the process of the World Humanitarian Summit, which is to be held in Turkey in May 2016. We in the European Parliament hope that this opportunity will be fully exploited to achieve positions andcommon objectives, because working together is the only way to face a situation that is more complicated every day in humanitarian matters.I support the report in which, from the European Parliament, we made it clear that the EU has to take a strong role in this Summit to respond to the needs of people in conflict situations, improve humanitarian effectiveness, ensure the financing ofmeasures, reduce vulnerability and improve risk management and introduce a culture of innovation.

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: S & amp; D), in writing. Today's globalized society is facing humanitarian crises of various magnitudes that end in a huge and endless humanitarian crisis with many different aspects and consequences, such as population displacement and unprecedented refugee flows. The causes of this crisis are war and natural disasters caused by climate change - all products of human intolerance and greed. As eyewitnesses to this dramatic increase in the number of people in urgent need of help, we cannot really close our eyes. The urgency of the problem and the under-functioning of the current approach are evidenced by the convening of the first World Summit in Istanbul next May. The emergency relief measures taken to date have proved insufficient to address and reduce the scope and complexity of the problem and have failed to provide real protection to our fellow human beings. So, by voting in favor of the report, I want to emphasize the urgent need to adopt a long-term common global policy that can anticipate and prevent events before they happen. The EU, a pioneer in humanitarian aid, must continue to play a key role in this effort with the ultimate goal of creating a "global consensus on humanitarian aid".

name: Georg MAYER
text: written.- Due to the fact that climate refugees, LGBTI people and particularly HIV-infected people are also defined as “in need of protection” and that the aim is to intervene in humanitarian aid and the administrative sector of various Member States by integrating private funds, I reject this reportfrom.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: in writing. ‒ I support this report except in such instances whereby national governments were obliged to make compulsory financial payments, as this is an issue of national competence.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: in writing. - This report full of good intentions supports the initiatives of the United Nations, in particular as regards the assistance and reception of migrants. But it largely ignores the geopolitical causes of current humanitarian disasters, starting with the responsibility of EU governments in conflicts and population displacement. He also ignores the hypocritical play of the EU with Turkey, host of this Summit. The EU is indeed offering 3 billion to this country while turning a blind eye to the support given by its government to jihadist groups which are destabilizing Syria and worsening the humanitarian crisis. And without saying a word about the serious violations of democratic rights in this country. The report calls for an increase in humanitarian aid on the ground without denouncing regular violations of international humanitarian law such as the bombing of the MSF hospital by the United States of America in Afghanistan. In addition, the report advocates a growing privatization of the global humanitarian aid funding and decision-making system. I am abstaining so as not to discourage humanitarian aid, but I refuse to endorse the growing European hypocrisy on this matter.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the resolution on preparing for the World Humanitarian Summit: challenges and opportunities for humanitarian aid. The world is currently facing unprecedented humanitarian crises, both in number and scale and persistence. Recurrent natural disasters, level 3 emergency situations in Syria, Iraq, Yemen, South Sudan and the Central African Republic and the Ebola outbreak in West Africa have exponentially increased the number of people in need of humanitarian aid . The World Humanitarian Summit, which will take place in Istanbul in May 2016, must try to reshape the humanitarian system and adapt it to new scenarios, such as the current refugee crisis. Only in this way can we hope to make humanitarian action more efficient and prepared for the future. The EU has the responsibility and the necessary capabilities to take a leading role in the search for more efficient and effective ways of meeting the needs of victims of conflicts and disasters.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ While this report contained amendments aimed at providing humanitarian assistance which I was happy to support, the final version of the report regrettably contained references to the right to abortion and therefore I could not support the final version of the text.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: in writing. - The world is strongly threatened by repeated humanitarian crises. The complexity of conflicts, the content of natural disasters, the increase in famines, the effects of climate change, the Ebola crisis, the migration crisis, etc. drive our humanitarian system to its limits. The migration crisis and the reception of refugees reminded us of our interdependence, our duty of humanity and the importance of acting in the field of development to address the root causes of crises. I welcome the adoption of the report on the World Humanitarian Summit which will take place in Istanbul in 2016. This report lays the foundations which will allow the European Union to refine the position and the strategy it will defend within the framework of this important summit. This summit represents a unique opportunity to strengthen humanitarian aid, seek innovative solutions and put in place instruments to meet the lasting challenges we face.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: in writing. - In the context of the report in preparation for the World Humanitarian Summit: Challenges and opportunities in the field of humanitarian aid, I think it is important to emphasize the paradox of the European Union's increase by unborn children, calling for easier access to abortions. Instead of receiving the necessary funding for facilities and institutions that save lives, the Union wants to support the millions of organizations that carry out and promote abortion in developing countries, and thus the lives of women, although this is against the needs declared by women themselves in those countries. . Recently, right on the floor of the European Parliament, for example, the Zambian ambassador to Belgium expressed the wish that development aid should really go to help mothers and children. Indeed, in several third world countries, maternal deaths are falling due to improving health care and overall living conditions. However, pro-abortion organizations want to artificially attribute this fact to the spread of abortion in the world.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on preparing for the World Humanitarian Summit (WHS) by rapporteur Enrique Guerrero Salom, because there are various elements of the report which I fully support, especially in view of the changing nature of humanitarian challenges that the world is facing at the moment.  The summit presents a unique opportunity to work together to ensure a principled and effective humanitarian action. Having said that however, I voted against the provisions in this report calling for the termination of pregnancy through induced abortion. The use of abortion is not the right way forward to resolve health or social problems and I am against it.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: in writing. - The report of the Committee on Development draws attention to the fact that humanitarian crises of unprecedented magnitude, severity and length have led to a sharp increase in the number of people in need of humanitarian aid. To address all these concerns and find solutions, the UN Secretary-General convened the first humanitarian summit in May 2016. The event aims to transform and adapt the humanitarian system to the rapidly changing arena of emergencies, making humanitarian action more efficient, effective and timely. There is a clear need to strengthen the relationship between the humanitarian and development communities and to shift the focus from response to prevention and anticipation. The report points out that, due to unprecedented needs and limited resources, the global humanitarian aid system has reached its limits, but at the same time the fundamental values ​​of fairness, dignity, humanity and solidarity are at stake. The Committee on Development recommends that Parliament take a stand in favor of the Union taking the lead and playing a key role in the process leading to the Humanitarian Summit, in order to achieve a decisive outcome guided by humanitarian principles and the needs of the beneficiaries. To this end, the Union must present itself in Istanbul with a strong common position and united action. The report proposes details of such a position. I supported the motion.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. - Humanitarian crises have grown in recent years in terms of scale and frequency. The number of people forced to move has reached its highest level since World War II. We are talking about more than 60 million people, of which 40 million are displaced within their countries, and more than half of the refugees worldwide are children. This document is intended to be a contribution to the first World Humanitarian Summit to be held in May next year in Istanbul. I agree, with the inclusion of an action plan, with a duration of 5 years, to operationalize the actions and political commitments assumed, as well as with the necessary complementarity between humanitarian aid and development aid, to face the countless obstacles and the lack of coordination between these two policies. I am also in favor of the need to analyze the Geneva Convention for Refugees and the Kampala Convention, in order to adapt it to the problems of our current world. I also subscribe to the need to analyze the issue of climate refugees, which is today a reason for the internal displacement of thousands of people. Because I believe that we can and should do more for the most vulnerable groups, I vote in favor of this report.

name: Claude MORAES
text: in writing. ‒ Given recent humanitarian crises and particularly in the case of Syria, where the UK government has rightly provided aid to affected regions, Labour MEPs should welcome this report and put particular pressure on the UK government to lead as a key global player in humanitarian action. Access to education must be a priority in humanitarian emergencies, and Labour MEPs should join calls for this to be a key point on the agenda of the World Humanitarian Summit next year in Istanbul.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this text, which covers the challenges and prospects for humanitarian assistance in view of the world humanitarian summit to be held in early 2016 in Turkey.This text recalls that the prevalence and increased intensity of natural disasters, the numerous conflicts and displacement linked to these disasters have resulted in an increased need for humanitarian aid in the world.In particular, it calls on the Member States of the Union and other donors to increase their funding for the benefit of local humanitarian aid actors, who have the capacity, skills and means necessary to intervene in the field.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. - We express our strong support for this resolution, which became necessary after the UN Secretary-General convened the first World Humanitarian Summit, which will take place in May 2016 in Istanbul. Indeed, the world is facing unprecedented humanitarian crises in number, size and persistence. Funding has actually grown, but needs have done so faster. Furthermore, security threats can increase through the perception that humanitarian aid is being used for political or economic reasons. We particularly welcome the rapporteur's work because it is based on the idea that the European Union, as a major donor and a key global player in humanitarian action, has the responsibilities but also the strength to take a leadership role in research. more efficient and effective ways to meet the needs of people affected by conflicts and disasters.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒  I have voted for this report that will instate an operational framework for the key stakeholders, the NGOs and development communities, with the purpose of creating convergence between humanitarian aid and development policy, in order to reduce and manage future humanitarian risks.

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: in writing.- I supported the report, which also contains some contentious issues on cultural and ethical issues, because I believe that a positive signal needs to be sent in order to make the forthcoming World Humanitarian Summit a success based on impartial assistance and general agreement on the implementation of humanitarian aid.principles of humanity, neutrality, impartiality and independence, as well as compliance with obligations under international humanitarian law.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: written.- I would have abstained from voting because I initially see the nation states as responsible for the issue of humanitarian aid.If you want to go so far as to justify Brussels' competence in this area, then the measures are not going far enough for me or in the wrong direction.

name: Urmas PAET
text: in writing.- I supported.The humanitarian environment has changed significantly, in particular in terms of the number, scale and duration of humanitarian emergencies, resulting from both military conflicts and natural disasters, and exacerbated by global trends such as climate change.As a leading donor, the EU has embarked on good practice in humanitarian aid, but needs to keep pace with the times and change its strategies accordingly.The speed of humanitarian aid is crucial.It is also important that the promised financial contributions are actually made by the Member States.

name: Margot PARKER
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP abstained on this non-legislative and non-binding report. UKIP does not recognise the legitimacy of or support the EU acting on behalf of the UK in any international capacity. The report calls for a new fund to be created to which financial contributions would be compulsory. It called for a European action plan and that the private sector align with EU development objectives. However we fully support the calls to end sexual based violence and stop discrimination of the LGBTI community, and that more needs to be done to end human rights abuses. While we cannot support the EU acting in the world, we cannot oppose calls to end abuses around the world – so we have to abstain on this report.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: written.- I am against this report because it incorrectly addresses most of the modern problems of human rights protection and the provision of humanitarian aid.In crises caused by natural factors, there is an already elaborated model of action of levels of government and international institutions.I am also against myself because there is no model of committing funding to humanitarian protection programs that would be fair to everyone.It is wrong to insist that regional organizations or the private sector bear the financial costs of humanitarian crises and it is questionable how to establish a system that would correctly and fairly determine the benefits that a particular state, regional organization or private sector must allocate.A consistent foreign policy needs to be developed that fully upholds the European Union's main priorities with regard to the protection of human rights, democracy, the prevention of violent armed conflict or threats to human security.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: written.- Ahead of the first World Humanitarian Summit, it is necessary to support innovative ways of thinking and acting in the field of humanitarian aid, given the continuity of human-caused conflicts and natural disasters.Given the refugee and migrant crisis and climate change, the humanitarian aid system is overloaded and requires new mechanisms, financial instruments and forms of international cooperation.In particular, the Union's efforts to lead by example in terms of a greater focus on causes, ie disaster prevention and prediction, than on consequences, ie remediation, are to be commended.Also, only with the flexible and timely provision of funding, with a focus on those most at risk such as women and children, is it possible to ensure the effectiveness and efficiency of humanitarian aid.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: written. - "Report on the preparations for the World Humanitarian Summit: Challenges and Opportunities for Humanitarian Aid" was submitted by Enrique Guerrero Salom. Given that humanitarian challenges that are taking place simultaneously and affecting entire regions and causing resource scarcity, poverty, inequality, migration, displacement and instability are becoming more severe, I support this report which points to the need to accelerate the World Humanitarian Summit. redesigning the humanitarian aid system to better serve those in need. We must protect the humanitarian principles of humanity, neutrality, impartiality and independence, and the fundamental rules of international humanitarian law and human rights set out in the Geneva Conventions and their Additional Protocols. It is extremely important to encourage the world community to gather at the World Humanitarian Meeting for the protection of human rights, respect for the principles of humanity, impartiality and condemn abuses of neutrality or disrespect for major humanitarian principles for political, military or non-humanitarian purposes.

name: Miroslav POCHE
text: in writing.- The current complex international situation brings an unprecedented number of humanitarian challenges that require clear responses and a truly global and functioning humanitarian aid system.As a Social Democrat, I am convinced of the need to strengthen the system of protection for the most vulnerable, based on solidarity and shared responsibility.We need humanitarian aid to be more effective, efficient and more prevention-oriented.At the World Humanitarian Summit to be held in Istanbul, Turkey, in May, the current system should be largely reshaped and strengthened accordingly.The European Union is the largest donor in the field of humanitarian aid, demonstrating, among other things, the strength of its values and its commitment to true global responsibility.I therefore hope that the World Humanitarian Summit will bring clear answers and an improvement on the current situation.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. - Unprecedented humanitarian crises are ongoing in the world in terms of both scale and duration. Constant and prolonged conflicts at the hands of man and recurring natural disasters have fueled a sharp increase in the number of people in need of humanitarian aid. This has pushed the humanitarian response system to its limits. In a context in which the gap between humanitarian needs and the operational and financial resources available to respond to them risks widening further, the UN Secretary General Ban Ki-Moon, has convened an unprecedented first World Humanitarian Summit (VUM). Efforts will be made to restructure and adapt the humanitarian system to a rapidly evolving emergency scenario in order to make humanitarian action more efficient, effective and adapted to future needs. Humanitarian funding, risk management, a culture of innovation in humanitarian aid and the essential role of NGOs will be discussed. I am voting in favor that, less than a year after the summit, we can start doing something concrete in order to reduce and manage future humanitarian risks.

name: Franck PROUST
text: in writing.- I voted for the resolution in view of the preparation of the world humanitarian summit.The portrait of the global humanitarian situation is still terrifying.Conflicts, crises, wars affect an entire section of Humanity.Even though every situation is different, we can put in place effective action plans for people in times of war, but also with the reconstruction and aftermath of those conflicts in mind.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP abstained on this non-legislative and non-binding report. UKIP does not recognise the legitimacy of or support the EU acting on behalf of the UK in any international capacity. The report calls for a new fund to be created to which financial contributions would be compulsory. It called for a European action plan and that the private sector align with EU development objectives. However we fully support the calls to end sexual based violence and stop discrimination of the LGBTI community, and that more needs to be done to end human rights abuses. While we cannot support the EU acting in the world, we cannot oppose calls to end abuses around the world – so we have to abstain on this report.

name: Robert ROCHEFORT
text: in writing. - I voted for the resolution on the preparation of the world humanitarian summit. The number of people in need has more than doubled since 2004 and an estimated 250 million people are affected by humanitarian crises around the world. We therefore call on Member States to support the World Humanitarian Summit, which should include a five-year roadmap including concrete political commitments. The European Union should in particular, as the main donor of humanitarian aid, commit to more flexible methods of delivering aid and act to ensure better prevention of humanitarian crises. The summit should work to create a global humanitarian fund, more systematically link humanitarian aid, development cooperation and resilience, work on disaster risk management and reduction, or use new technologies to improve performance. aid effectiveness. Finally, it is important that the funding of humanitarian aid from the Union budget is predictable and available in good time.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: in writing.- This is a real call to Member States to support the World Humanitarian Summit and to adopt solid conclusions at Council level, with specific commitments and priority areas of intervention, guaranteeing operational efficiency, common quality standards, better coordination and partnerships withemerging donors, based on politically non-biased aid, as well as a common understanding and application of the principles of humanity, neutrality, impartiality and independence and in compliance with their obligations under international humanitarian law.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: in writing. - 250 million is the number of people who today are affected by humanitarian crises. Among them, there are some 100 million people currently in need due to natural disasters but also to increasing numbers of armed conflicts. But humanitarian crises can only be summed up in a few figures. These people, who live in often inhuman conditions, have no choice but to flee their country and find refuge in another part of the world. And the worst is to be feared since, beyond the numerous armed conflicts, it is estimated that one billion human beings could be displaced by climate change by 2050, in particular due to a shortage of 'water. We must put people back at the center of political decisions as quickly as possible. And I really hope that the 2016 World Humanitarian Summit to be held in Istanbul will rise to the challenges of the day. We must also integrate that if humanitarian aid is necessary, it must only constitute one part of a more global action plan which must target economic and social development (or redevelopment) in these regions of the world in difficulty.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. - The EU has proactively participated in resolving / minimizing the effects of an increasing number of humanitarian crises which are increasing in scale, seriousness and persistence and which require a coordinated, firm and adequate response on a global scale. In May 2016, the first World Humanitarian Summit will take place and, as such, the EU should draw up a concrete development and operational plan in view of the political commitments that it will assume and in view of the humanitarian catastrophes that have emerged. I also believe it is essential to increase the financial amounts allocated to humanitarian aid through global solutions assumed multilaterally and on a global scale. The main challenges we face today require innovative solutions, linking thematic areas such as humanitarian effectiveness, the reduction of vulnerability, or even risk management. I therefore vote in favor of this report, which suggests a set of preparatory measures with a view to this Summit, where urgent and effective measures must be adopted to minimize or eliminate the humanitarian calamities that have occurred in recent years and which demand an immediate and definitive response. .

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of this report, which provides the European Parliament's contribution to the first world humanitarian summit, which will take place in Istanbul on 23 and 24 May 2016. We are currently facing humanitarian crises without precedent in their number and their magnitude. In 2015, 250 million people were affected by humanitarian crises and there are nearly 60 million displaced people, more than half of whom are children. These numbers are alarming and have reached their highest level since World War II. This is why I supported this resolution, which calls for including in the summit's final document a five-year roadmap for the development and implementation of the concrete political commitments that have been made. It is necessary to make development aid and humanitarian aid more complementary in order to compensate for the lack of funding in the humanitarian field. Finally, this report covers the key issues of humanitarian crises and provides innovative solutions such as vulnerability reduction, risk management and humanitarian effectiveness.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: written. - We have ABSTAINED in voting on the report on the World Humanitarian Summit because, despite including positive references, such as gender and migrant rights, in line with the current trend in the privatization cooperation / aid system , the report calls for a strong push for the inclusion of the private sector in humanitarian action. Thus, the report calls for aligning action strategies with business objectives. The report also calls for an increase in public-private partnerships in humanitarian action; partnerships that have proven to be ineffective and that often result in privatization of benefits and socialization of risks and losses. We consider that the policy of humanitarian action has to be a purely public policy and not be at the service of private interests; Only in this way can we equip ourselves with a robust humanitarian policy capable of meeting the challenges we face.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: written. - Although this report can be seen as a call to strengthen and improve humanitarian aid through the support of the World Humanitarian Summit, making positive reference to the need for the EU to be guided by principles of solidarity, responsibility and accountability, these wishes remain in dead paper as long as the EU and its Member States maintain the current trade and foreign policy, which is the cause of many of the conflicts and impoverishment of third countries. This report contains positive aspects such as the need to make a greater effort to guarantee the right to education in humanitarian emergencies, the inclusion of a gender approach in the entire cycle of humanitarian aid and even the recognition of the need minimum humanitarian standards to promote essential public services. But, once again, it once again associates public services with the private sector in a veiled defense of public-private partnerships, thus making it possible for European transnational companies to do business and profit from the vulnerable situation of people in emergency situations. humanitarian. For all this I have voted against.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this report because even though I agree with many things that have been said in this report, it is my belief that many of the things that this report discusses should be discussed by individual nation states at the World Humanitarian Summit.

name: Pedro SILVA PEREIRA
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the report on the 1st World Humanitarian Summit, which will take place in Istanbul in May 2016, because the EP makes very important recommendations for the redefinition of the global humanitarian system, which has a growing deficit between needs and available resources. The report recommends a global partnership for principled humanitarian action, a leadership role for the EU as the main donor of humanitarian aid worldwide, as well as greater complementarity between humanitarian aid and development aid. The report also defends three other important ideas: a five-year roadmap for operationalizing the political commitments made at the summit; the creation of a global fund for humanitarian assistance, favoring the effectiveness of humanitarian financing; and increased funding for the education of children in humanitarian emergencies, with 4% of the EU humanitarian aid budget allocated to this objective. I therefore supported this report because it contains concrete suggestions for making the humanitarian system more inclusive, effective, transparent and truly global.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report as it encourages the EU to assume leadership and play an important role in the World Humanitarian Summit (WHS) process. I would also encourage the UK Government to join the EU in taking a lead in humanitarian action and consider building partnerships and find common ground on humanitarian principles and international standards, through the opportunities presented through the WHS.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: in writing. - The number of people in need has more than doubled since 2004 to more than 100 million in 2015. As many as 250 million people are affected by humanitarian crises and there are now more refugees and internally displaced people as a result of forced displacement than after World War II. . These are just a few of the figures in the report that have also made me think more seriously about this issue. I am concerned that all events, such as natural disasters, the effects of climate change, military conflicts, epidemics or population migration, most often affect the poor and marginalized people, not excluding children. I supported the resolution because I believe that new solutions need to be sought and measures taken to make global humanitarian action more effective, which has been severely tested in recent years not only by various natural disasters, but also by ongoing military conflicts and their consequences. In the context of humanitarian aid, I would like to highlight the work of humanitarian workers who, despite repeated attacks on their people in critical situations, provide basic care to the people affected and the regions concerned.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: in writing.- I spoke in plenary on this report and appreciated the many important information and recommendations it contains.Unfortunately, it also contains a number of problematic points.Among other things, he addresses issues such as abortion and reproductive and sexual health and rights, mentioning, for example, guaranteeing access to the "abortion service in situations of humanitarian crises", which I personally see as a very controversial issue.My group's attempt to delete these points failed, so in the end, like most of my PPE colleagues, I abstained in the final vote.In the end, the news passed only very narrowly.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: in writing. - We are currently facing one of the biggest humanitarian crises in history. Urbanization, rapid population growth, demographic change, more frequent and growing natural disasters, environmental degradation, climate change and resource scarcity leave behind poverty, inequality, migration, displacement and fragility. All of the above has dramatically increased the need for humanitarian action around the world. To this end, the first World Humanitarian Summit will be held in Istanbul on 23 and 24 May 2016. The report on the preparations for the World Humanitarian Summit contains an analysis of the current humanitarian crisis and makes a number of concrete proposals for improving the situation. The report emphasizes, among other things, that the final document of the World Humanitarian Summit should contain a five-year plan for the development and operationalization of the concrete political commitments made. These should include an intergovernmental monitoring and accountability framework, an assessment of aid organizations' practices and an impact assessment involving the involvement of relevant stakeholders. I agree that the humanitarian principles of humanity, impartiality, neutrality and independence, as well as the basic rules of international humanitarian law and human rights in the Geneva Conventions and their protocols, must be at the heart of all humanitarian action. The report reflects the need to adequately address the current humanitarian crisis, which is why I supported it in plenary and voted in favor of its adoption.

name: Joachim STARBATTY
text: written.- The report discusses the objectives of the European Union with regard to the first World Summit on Humanitarian Aid, which will take place on 23/24May 2016 in Istanbul.The report contains a number of good recommendations.A five-year action plan is to be adopted, a link to the international development agenda established and humanitarian aid, especially in refugee camps, to be noticeably improved.On the other hand, there are also problematic parts.Among other things, mandatory funding is required from the donor countries, without specifying how these mandatory payments are controlled, who is responsible for them and how high the respective amount will be for the donor country in question.Against this background, I have abstained from voting.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: in writing.- Growing challenges, such as climate change and related natural disasters, urbanization and demographic change, require adequate responses.I appreciate the decision to organize a World Humanitarian Summit, which will give all stakeholders the opportunity to discuss these important issues and find tools for common solutions.

name: Jaromír ŠTĚTINA
text: in writing. - The continuing increase in the number of humanitarian disasters in the world cannot be underestimated and there is a need for gradual coordination of Member States' policies in addressing the causes and consequences of such crises. In particular, I appreciate the report's call for the strengthening of public-private partnerships in developing strategies for preventing emergencies and emergencies and in repairing possible damage. Technology start-ups and insurance companies undoubtedly play an important role in developing tools and national emergency preparedness and response plans and in reducing disaster risk. The emphasis on the key role of NGOs working in the field during humanitarian disasters and the need for them to be consulted by national authorities can also be welcomed. However, I allowed myself to disagree with the unconditional financial assistance and mandatory financial payments of governments, the private sector and regional organizations in replenishing the planned global humanitarian aid fund. I believe that the entities concerned should not be deprived of the opportunity to decide on the addition of funds to the fund voluntarily after a proper evaluation of their own financial possibilities. References to the issue of abortion in the context of humanitarian crises also seem superfluous in the whole context of the report. In view of the above, I have therefore finally decided to abstain.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: written.- In a very unstable world, we are facing increasing diversity, frequency and strength of natural disasters and scarcity, and an unprecedented escalation in the number of complicated conflicts.The number of people in need has more than doubled since 2004 and in 2015 to more than 100 million.Humanitarian crises have affected 250 million people, and the number of IDPs has reached its highest point since World War II at almost 60 million, including nearly 40 million displaced people within their countries.Half of the world's refugees are children, and that is why I support the Commission's recommendations for drawing up a comprehensive list of performance indicators.I therefore call for a new agreement to be reached at the World Humanitarian Summit on intervening in fragile states and long-term crises, through sustainable programs, implementation plans and projected financing for development.

name: Catherine STIHLER
text: in writing. ‒ As a leading donor and key global player in humanitarian action, the EU should take a leading role in the first-ever World Humanitarian Summit (WHS). I therefore welcome this report outlining the key challenges and opportunities for humanitarian assistance. The humanitarian crises pose many challenges and the WHS presents an opportunity for the EU to build partnership and find common ground on humanitarian principles and international standards, enhance cooperation and coordination of assistance. Together, we must ensure children, women and people with disabilities are protected, improve and increase the cooperation between humanitarian and development policies, and also ensure access to education is a priority in humanitarian emergencies.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: in writing.- I did not support the proposal for two reasons.The first reason is that the European Union is trying to solve problems around the world, and it cannot solve its own.The second reason is that I have doubts as to whether the proposal presented will increase the effectiveness of humanitarian aid at all.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: in writing.- In the vote on the report on the preparations for the World Humanitarian Summit: Challenges and Opportunities for Humanitarian Aid, I abstained.The need for humanitarian action has increased worldwide due to a number of challenges, such as urbanization, rapid population growth, demographic change, more frequent and increasingly severe natural disasters.I agree with the calls in the report on the global humanitarian system, which should be strengthened at the World Humanitarian Summit and which should at the same time recognize the diversity of today's humanitarian response system and the complementary role of all actors.However, the report contains several points that I cannot support.The report also talks about abortion and access to all sexual and reproductive health services, which I cannot support.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: GUE / NGL), in writing. - Humanitarian aid is a key part of our ideological and political stance towards the exploitation of societies in developing countries because of capitalist interests. However, in this report, there are reports of support for private organizations providing humanitarian aid, which is of particular concern to us as the main goal of these organizations is to maintain their profitability. These organizations base their profitability on maintaining the status quo, which is why incidents and evidence of their involvement in the processes of civil strife and war so often come to the surface. We have abstained, as the relevant negative references and the shortcomings that characterize our text raise particular concerns.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI), in writing. - The humanitarian crisis is created and aggravated, basically, by the policies of the great powers, which aim mainly at strengthening them on the world chessboard. Economic interests, the pursuit of wealth and the strengthening of their geopolitical and geostrategic position are the main cause of conflicts, crises and wars but also the deterioration of the environment. Properly structured, coordinated and effective humanitarian assistance from all countries and from international bodies and organizations is essential. However, any approach in order to provide humanitarian assistance must be done with special attention to the specifics of each region and with respect for the cultural values ​​and culture of the respective population groups. The involvement of the private sector in humanitarian aid and in the management of the humanitarian crisis must be ancillary and not guided by the profit of the respective companies, so as not to be detrimental to the objectives pursued.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of this report, which outlines the role of the European Union and its Member States in preparing for next historic global humanitarian summit in May. I have borne in mind that the EU, as the world's leading donor and a leader in the international political implementation of humanities, has a special responsibility in this challenging period. EU Member States are now facing the effects of the proportion of masses displaced by regional conflicts, especially in the Middle East, and the resulting wave of migration, not only as members of the international community but also at their own borders. I agree that the answer to this can only be effective through concerted EU action, including in the framework of the Humanitarian Action Plan. The report details potential areas for improving EU humanitarian cooperation, such as international trade, development policy, enlargement and neighborhood policy, asylum and migration policy, which I consider to be a priority. I also welcome the report's emphasis on addressing the growing humanitarian crisis for particularly vulnerable groups, such as children, women and the elderly; In my own political and parliamentary work, I myself have been trying for a long time to draw the EU's political attention to the importance of addressing their specific problems and vulnerabilities.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: in writing. - We live in very challenging times today - rapid population growth, demographic changes, natural disasters, migration, regional conflicts and climate change have dramatically increased the need for humanitarian aid around the world. The first World Humanitarian Summit to be held in Istanbul next year will be an excellent opportunity for the international community to look at the existing problems and find the most effective solutions. Unfortunately, each year the funds allocated to humanitarian purposes are decreasing, and many countries, despite their improving economic situation, do not decide to support other countries or people in need. It therefore seems appropriate that the European Parliament's call for greater coordination and integration in the global humanitarian system should be taken into account at this summit. The report also rightly points to the need to continue the dialogue on the complementary roles and mandates of different humanitarian organizations or even individual states. Unfortunately, the document contains many provisions of a very ideological nature that may hinder the implementation of the provisions of the European Parliament. Moreover, due to the extremely wide range of issues covered in the report, it is difficult to find clear priorities. As a result, I decided to vote against it.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: signed up. - The world we live in shows us that humanitarian challenges do not cease to arise. Categories forced to reach a situation of risk or vulnerability due to conflict, epidemic, lack of food or natural disasters are multiplying. Cooperation with the United Nations for the efficiency of humanitarian aid is all the more valuable in this context. A global alliance of innovation for humanitarian purposes is a must for the next period and the EU can be at the forefront of supporters of such action. The EU continues to be a major donor to the UN, and as such, which I have mentioned several times, it must play a key role in the UN's humanitarian and public policies. This also translates into the formulation of a common and united position of the Member States with regard to the presence at the UN. We must assume that this report deals not only tangentially with the refugee crisis. The way in which the EU treats this vulnerable category of displaced people also defines our real attitude towards the phenomenon of humanitarian aid. I support this motion for a resolution and I hope that this act will also be doubled by firm EU action in the field of humanitarian aid restructuring.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the text.Let us stress that the humanitarian problems of a considerable magnitude which are currently posed require a humanitarian system - which the World Humanitarian Summit will have to help strengthen - which is more open, multifaceted and truly global in scope and which, at the same time, recognizesthe diversity of the current humanitarian intervention system and the complementarity of the different actors.Parliament calls on the EU to promote a global consensus on humanitarian action which reaffirms the principles of humanitarian aid as well as the rights and obligations under international humanitarian law, which ensures that protection measures are people-centered andbased on human rights, and which establishes the responsibility of governments with regard to their role and duties in the protection of persons.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I endorsed adoption of this report in view of the World Humanitarian Summit (WHS), which will be held in Istanbul in May 2016 with the aim to adapt the humanitarian system to an unprecedented number of emergencies and to make humanitarian action more efficient and effective. The report notes that 250 million people are affected by humanitarian crises. It underlines that the WHS outcome document should include a five-year roadmap for concrete political commitments undertaken, linking the post-2015 development agenda, the Sendai Framework for Disaster Risk Reduction and the 2015 United Nations Climate Change Conference (COP 21). It suggests that one of the Summit’s objectives should be to reflect on the need for UN reform towards a transparent and effective coordination system. The EU, as the world’s largest humanitarian aid donor, should show leadership in the WHS and urge prevention, as well as a stronger commitment to a human-rights-based approach in humanitarian action.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: written. - Although the aim of this report is to transform humanitarian aid to make it more efficient, transparent and truly global, I abstained. I support certain parts of this report and believe that the European Union should really respond to doubling the number of people affected by the humanitarian crisis and people in need since 2004. I believe that it is extremely important, in accordance with international law, to facilitate the delivery of humanitarian aid to the most vulnerable groups and to improve hygienic conditions and sanitary infrastructure for emergencies in order to provide adequate assistance and health care to those at risk. However, I can in no way agree with the individual proposals of this report. Namely, I do not support the proposal of mandatory payments to the Global Fund for Humanitarian Aid, and I oppose the attempt to classify abortion access as a range of common health services in the field of sexual and reproductive health. I believe that the imposition of such obligations and provisions is inappropriate for a report that should facilitate access to assistance for those at risk.

name: Romana TOMC
text: in writing.- In the vote on the Report on the preparations for the World Humanitarian Summit: Challenges and Opportunities for Humanitarian Aid, I abstained because the report adopted amendments that I myself could not support and do not advocate.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: written. - We have ABSTAINED in voting on the report on the World Humanitarian Summit because, despite including positive references, such as gender and migrant rights, in line with the current trend in the privatization cooperation / aid system , the report calls for a strong push for the inclusion of the private sector in humanitarian action. Thus, the report calls for aligning action strategies with business objectives. The report also calls for an increase in public-private partnerships in humanitarian action; partnerships that have proven to be ineffective and that often result in privatization of benefits and socialization of risks and losses. We consider that the policy of humanitarian action has to be a purely public policy and not be at the service of private interests; Only in this way can we equip ourselves with a robust humanitarian policy capable of meeting the challenges we face.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. ‒ I fully support this resolution. Whereas growing challenges, such as urbanisation, rapid population growth, demographic changes, the prevalence and increased strength of natural disasters, environmental degradation, desertification, climate change, numerous long-lasting and simultaneous conflicts with regional impact and resource scarcity, added to the consequences of poverty, inequality, migration, displacement and fragility, have consequently dramatically increased the need for humanitarian response throughout the globe. Whereas the number of people in need has more than doubled since 2004 to over 100 million in 2015; whereas 250 million people are affected by humanitarian crises; whereas the number of forcibly displaced persons has reached its highest point since World War II at nearly 60 million, including almost 40 million displaced inside their own countries; whereas over half of the world’s refugees are children. I call on the EU and its Member States, as the largest donors and key operational actors, to lead by active example, and I emphasise that all EU humanitarian actions should be guided by the principles of solidarity, responsibility and accountability, and should be designed to ensure that vulnerable people are protected, both physically and psychologically.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: in writing. - Despite a rather promising approach to the new perspectives of humanitarian aid, emphasizing in particular prevention rather than ad hoc management which is often costly and does not help the empowerment of the affected countries, this report is in fact polluted. through claims that have no direct link with our subject, in particular through two opinions from the FEMM and AFET committees. The FEMM commission has thus issued a particularly oriented opinion on sex education and "education for relational life". LGBT claims also find a place in the report. Finally, if the summit is to concern all populations affected by a crisis, migrants and the desire to offer them special protection are predominant in the text. One of the main features of this text is the injunction to Member States to increase their funding but also to implement without delay the measures that will be taken at the summit, in particular with a "comprehensive refugee reception plan". The appeal for the contribution of the private sector within the framework of the financing of humanitarian aid is also one of the key elements of the report. I choose ABSTENTION on this text.

name: István UJHELYI
text: in writing.- Record needs and limited resources have led the global humanitarian aid system to reach its limits.At the same time, the fundamental values of fairness, dignity, humanity and solidarity are at stake.The Union is expected and able to take the lead and play a key role in the process leading to the Humanitarian Summit, in order to achieve a decisive outcome, guided by humanitarian principles and the needs of the beneficiaries.I voted in favor of the document.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: written. - We have ABSTAINED in voting on the report on the World Humanitarian Summit because, despite including positive references, such as gender and migrant rights, in line with the current trend in the privatization cooperation / aid system , the report calls for a strong push for the inclusion of the private sector in humanitarian action. Thus, the report calls for aligning action strategies with business objectives. The report also calls for an increase in public-private partnerships in humanitarian action; partnerships that have proven to be ineffective and that often result in privatization of benefits and socialization of risks and losses. We consider that the policy of humanitarian action has to be a purely public policy and not be at the service of private interests; Only in this way can we equip ourselves with a robust humanitarian policy capable of meeting the challenges we face.

name: Viktor USPASKICH
text: in writing.- I emphasize that addressing the current enormous humanitarian challenges requires the strengthening of a more inclusive, comprehensive and truly global humanitarian aid system at the World Summit on Humanitarian Aid, while recognizing the diversity of today's humanitarian response system and taking into account the complementary roles of all actors.;I call on the EU to promote a global consensus on humanitarian aid, reaffirming the principles and obligations and rights of humanitarian aid under international humanitarian law and ensuring human-centered and human rights-based safeguards, and I believe that governments have a responsibility totheir role and responsibility in protecting people.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this text because it is necessary to see and to react to the current situations in the world.  First of all it is important to recognise and acknowledge the actors and policies that led to some of the challenges we are facing nowadays. The world is being faced with humanitarian crises, unprecedented both in their number, scale and persistence. Together with continuous, protracted, man-made conflicts and recurring natural disasters, ‘Level 3’ emergencies in Syria, Iraq, Yemen, South Sudan and the Central African Republic, and the Ebola outbreak in West Africa, have fuelled a sharp increase in the number of people in need of humanitarian aid.  As the leading donor and key global player in humanitarian action, the EU has both a responsibility and the necessary leverage to take a leadership role in the quest for more efficient and effective ways to meet the needs of those affected by conflicts and disasters. The EU has good practices and innovative approaches to humanitarian aid and it should actively share its knowledge and can have added value, although it will also need to look at its own structures.

name: Derek VAUGHAN
text: in writing. ‒ Access to education must be a priority in humanitarian emergencies; young people cannot allow their education to become another casualty of a disaster, and I join the call for this to be a key point on the agenda of the World Humanitarian Summit next year in Istanbul. It is vital that this issue is not ignored in the coming years and that we move to alleviate this problem.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: written.- The Secretary-General of the United Nations has convened a world humanitarian summit for the first time ever.It will take place in May 2016. This world summit is timely, as we are facing an unprecedented humanitarian crisis.Within the ALDE Group, we would like to call for the focus from now on to focus on the prevention of such crises instead of having to react afterwards, when it is actually too late.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: in writing. - This report is part of the first humanitarian summit to be held in Istanbul on 23 and 24 May 2016 to "make humanitarian aid more efficient and more transparent". It is an emergency given the unprecedented humanitarian crisis facing the world. Sixty million refugees and displaced people in the world, according to the UNHCR, a figure never reached. So, yes, we need to improve humanitarian assistance in refugee camps, pay particular attention to vulnerable groups (LGBTI, disabled, children). Yes, we must strengthen direct aid to NGOs in the field and why not create a global fund for humanitarian aid with compulsory contributions. But this report is sorely lacking in political context, and does not question the causes of humanitarian crises. Worse, because states refuse to keep their financial commitments, it supports greater inclusion of private actors in funding and humanitarian aid, even the development of public-private partnerships - we can read in particular "when the public and private sector share values ​​and priorities which align commercial objectives with the Union's development objectives ". Absolute nonsense. I therefore abstained, privileging the humanitarian emergency.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. - The world is currently facing unprecedented humanitarian crises. In addition to the continuous and prolonged conflicts caused by the imperial strategies of interference in the internal affairs of several countries and continents, recurrent natural disasters and epidemics also emerge, as is the case of the recent case of Ebola. There are now more refugees and displaced people within their countries than after World War II. One of the consequences of this situation has been the disproportionate increase in people who try to seek refuge by undertaking sea voyages where they risk their lives. As a result of selfishness in western nations and in particular the EU, the chronic needs arising from these conflicts and disasters are pushing the humanitarian response system to its limits. In this context, the United Nations Secretary-General, Ban Ki-Moon, convened the first ever Humanitarian World Summit (CHM) ever to be held in Istanbul in May 2016. We do not deny the urgent need to address situations that require a immediate humanitarian aid. What is also necessary, but unfortunately absent from the debate, is a diagnosis of the root causes of this phenomenon, as well as a change in policies that can solve this problem at the bottom.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: written.- Due to the fact that climate refugees, LGBTI and especially HIV-infected people are also defined as “in need of protection” and that the aim is to intervene in humanitarian aid and also in the administrative sector of various Member States by integrating private funds, I reject this report.

name: Theodoros ZAGORAKIS
text: PPE), in writing. - For my part, I also voted in favor of the report on "Preparing for the World Humanitarian Summit: Challenges and Opportunities for Humanitarian Aid". People today are facing unprecedented humanitarian crises in terms of their number, their scale and their duration. The figures show the magnitude of the problem and limited funding are exacerbating the effects of humanitarian crises. The EU must take the lead at the World Humanitarian Summit, showing unity but at the same time presenting realistic proposals for tackling future humanitarian crises.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: in writing.- It is clear that the world is facing a number of humanitarian disasters in terms of number, scale and duration.The number of people in need has doubled since 2004.I support this report because I believe that it is essential for the European Union, as a globally important figure professing humanitarian values, to be present in this area and to take an active part in aid.These values should also be heard loudly at the World Humanitarian Summit in Istanbul.I also consider it important to link the debate on humanitarian aid with subsequent development aid, as one without the other is not important in the long term.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: in writing.- I abstained on the report on the preparations for the World Humanitarian Summit to be held in Istanbul in May 2016.I think that the report as a whole is moving towards good goals, more effective, transparent and organized humanitarian aid.It calls for a better exchange of information, emphasizing the role of modern technologies that will make it easier to deliver humanitarian aid to remote and disaster-stricken areas.All this, as well as the focus on longer-term solutions, prevention and disaster preparedness, and in particular on helping the most vulnerable groups, are topics that I support.On the other hand, the report also contained articles that caused me to abstain in the final vote.These included, in particular, the requirements for mandatory payments to the newly established Global Fund for Humanitarian Aid and the controversial issue of sexual and reproductive rights.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. - This report is about the World Humanitarian Summit (CHM) and aims to contribute to a common EU position at this summit. It is said that the objectives of the CHM will be to reformulate the humanitarian system and adapt it to a rapidly evolving emergency scenario, in order to make humanitarian action more efficient and prepared. There is a call for greater rapprochement between communities dedicated to humanitarian assistance and for deviating the focus of action from the response to prevention and anticipation. The world faces unprecedented humanitarian crises, both in number and scale and persistence. 2014 witnessed the dramatic increase in forced displacement caused by wars and conflicts, registering the highest level in recent history. Most of these situations are a painful demonstration of the inhuman, exploitative and aggressive character of the capitalist system and have causes and those responsible: the destabilization processes in various parts of the globe and the imperialist wars of aggression, the policy of economic domination and the plundering of resources natural. Unfortunately, none of this is mentioned in the report.

name: Jude KIRTON-DARLING
text: – Madam President, with Christmas just around the corner, many steelworkers and their families are facing a grim end of the year. Sites are closing, with thousands of well-paid, highly skilled jobs being lost – like in Redcar, in my home region – or threatened, especially in the supply chain. We have had enough summits and high-level meetings. Now we need to see real action. It is clear that the market is saturated with overcapacity, especially from China. Today I am calling on the UK Government to stop blocking the vital reform of EU trade defence measures. Edouard Martin’s report offers long-term solutions to this crisis and, if implemented correctly, could put European steel on the path to a sustainable future. That is why I supported it today. It is too late for Redcar’s steelworkers. Let us not let any more of our communities go down the same route.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: - Madam President.Metal mining has always played a huge role in European history.Historically, its systematic, centuries-long development and active innovation, together with several other industries, have largely guaranteed the good dominance and development of our part of the world.But it is clear that we must do everything we can at the moment to achieve lower energy consumption in metal production and other relevant and dependent areas, and to maximize the stability and guarantees of the supply of imported resources, at least in the short term.Not to mention the efforts to reduce the global production of such steel in the case of base metals in general, assuming, of course, the possible consequences for national economies and the workers involved.That is why this report by Mr Martha is extremely important, and I support it.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. - The common metals industry, such as steel, copper, brass and others, plays a fundamental role for many industrial sectors and activities. Currently the production and processing of these metals is experiencing a moment of crisis, caused not only by environmental policies, but also by the absence of suitable investment policies to guarantee the development and growth of this sector. The main objective of the Martin report is to create a balance between the need to invest in the base metals industry and the environmental impact, inter alia by attempting to minimize the possible damage to workers and inhabitants. In this regard, greater transparency of information about emissions, investments and the health of the surrounding population is required. I decided to vote in favor because I believe it is essential not only to improve the exchange of information on the subject, but also to reach a compromise between development needs and the related social and environmental impacts.

name: Tim AKER
text: in writing. – Today UKIP voted against the report: Developing a sustainable European industry of base metals. We believe that EU’s obsessive green policy together with a lack of regulatory coherence has created great difficulties for energy intensive industries in Europe. We believe that neither EU climate policy nor the new Energy Union proposal, with the renewed ETS system, is the solution to resolve the severe difficulties faced by the base metals industry.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: written. - I voted in favor of this report as it represents significant political support for the steel industry sector in Europe. The sector faces a serious crisis due to the full commercial opening of the borders, which prevents the maintenance of this essential industry for quality employment in Europe. The report includes certain points that we do not accept, such as the harmonization of state aid to the sector or the energy union, but at the same time it includes fundamental measures such as the adjustment of coal at the border, the unequivocal commitment to recycling and the circular economy for the recovery of the sector, the development of public investment, the promotion and maintenance of social dialogue and the promotion of regional economic cohesion. Due to all these essential points to overcome the crisis that the sector is currently facing, an indispensable industry in our commitment to a new production model that allows generating quality employment, I have decided to vote in favor of this report.

name: Louis ALIOT
text: in writing. - I abstained on the report on the development of a sustainable European base metals industry. The text aimed to reflect the reflection on the development of the base metals industry; the industry in question is the steel industry and aluminum production. If this text offers a good analysis of the state of the sector and reaffirms its strategic nature for industrial policy, we nevertheless find the rejection of protectionism and the questioning of the dogma of competition policy, thus preventing progress. the essential tools for the protection, development and modernization of this industry. Moreover, the proposed amendments have largely contributed to distorting the report, and particularly in the provisions relating to border adjustment. Finally, the issue of the ban, under competition policy, of long-term electricity supply contracts is barely addressed in this report, although it is central and structuring for the establishment of a real industrial policy in this sector.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: written.- Due to the drastic decline in demand in the iron and steel industry and the closings in the aluminum industry, there was a sharp reduction in specialist capacities and jobs.In addition, these branches of industry are also faced with the challenge of advancing their energetic and environmental modernization.Since it is important that the European base metals industry does not disappear from the industrial landscape of tomorrow, it is to be welcomed that this report proposes measures on how this sector can adapt to the new climatic, economic and social realities and in an effective wayand efficient energy and raw material consumption should lead by example.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: in writing.- The conclusion reached by this report is what the Front National has been making for many years: environmental standards are increasingly restrictive, particularly in the base metal industry sector, and are the main reason for the losscompetitiveness of European industry.The text proposes to develop an ecological adjustment at the borders, by forcing importers to buy CO2 emission quotas on the market for the rights to pollute during the introduction of products from the steel industry or primary aluminum.Let us not forget that the rapporteur, Edouard Martin, betrayed his work comrades at ArcelorMittal when he had the plan to dismantle the Lorraine steel industry accepted.At the National Front, we believe that we must go further and resort to protectionism.The diagnosis is the right one but it does not provide the right solutions, so I abstained.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ The European Union is rather tying itself in knots with this report.  On the one hand, it bemoans the high price of energy and its impact upon base metals in the European Union.  That is perfectly reasonable as a position to hold.   On the other hand, the same report suggests a position on climate change which would lead to higher energy costs.  That, too, is a perfectly reasonable position to hold. But it is not, in my view, possible to have your cake and eat it.  The two positions are logically inconsistent with each other. I therefore voted against this report.

name: Guillaume BALAS
text: in writing.- I gave my full support to Edouard Martin's report aimed at developing the conditions necessary for the maintenance and development of the base metals production industry.He formulates several concrete solutions including the introduction of a CO2 adjustment at the borders of Europe to prevent unfair competition, the development of the circular economy or the establishment of new modes of corporate governance.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: in writing.- The decrease in capacity and jobs in the European steel industry is due to the decrease in demand.demand was 40 million.tonnes less than in 2007I agree with the need to modernize the EU's steel and aluminum sectors in terms of energy efficiency and environmental protection.It is important to ensure that industrial policy is provided with the tools and resources needed for a successful transition to low-carbon technologies, which will not be possible without strategic control of the base metals industry.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: in writing.- The report that was initially presented to the ITRE committee was going in the right direction and Edouard Martin had timidly sketched out plans for protectionist measures based on a few very correct observations.Alas, after the vote in committee, this report is nothing more than a catalog of good feelings where a few good half-measures alternate with very bad ones.That's why I finally decided to abstain.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: in writing. - I have obviously approved this own-initiative report which aims to develop a sustainable European base metals industry - an industry which has been severely affected in recent decades and has lost thousands of jobs. In this regard, I would like to stress the imperative need to maintain effective trade defense instruments - and rapid implementation - in order to deal with unfair competition practices from third States because they are based on dumping practices. social and environmental.
