We know that the Commission recently had to take or confirm anti-dumping duties on metal products imported from China at discounted prices. At a time when the attribution of market economy status to China is under discussion, it is imperative to keep such instruments available. The reverse would have serious consequences in terms of competitiveness and employment on European base metal industries by worsening the repercussions of the price war waged by the world's largest steel producers and its notorious overcapacity. As such, I co-signed the amendment tabled in session on this subject.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: written.- We have abstained because we consider that the basic metals industry sector is a strategic sector in the economy, and the document contains positive aspects in terms of social, labor and defense of workers issues, and contains general lines to supportthis industry and that there is a transformation of it in environmental matters.But, on the other hand, we are radically opposed to their positioning and their tacit tolerance towards the Emissions Trading Scheme (ETS) and the TTIP.The environmental guidelines set out in the document seem totally insufficient to us.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: written.- I voted in favor of the report on the development of a sustainable European base metals industry.I have differed in various votes from the line of my group since I believe that the report has very important points such as that it is requested that it is guaranteed that future trade agreements include provisions that improve export opportunities and market access for productsEuropean base metals or to call for compensation to be harmonized and, where justified, applied at European level to ensure a level playing field with global competitors and between European producers and to ensure effective protection against carbon leakage.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: in writing. - This report is presented by the socialist deputy Edouard Martin, elected quietly after having betrayed his comrades of "fight" to ArcelorMittal, to which he made accept the plan of dismantling of our steel industry in Lorraine. This document is actually a progress report outlining the reflection of the think tank on the development of the base metals sector. The text makes a good diagnosis of the state of the sector and reaffirms its strategic character for industrial policy. The angle taken to safeguard and develop this industry is ecological border adjustment, by forcing importers to buy CO2 emission quotas on the polluting rights market when introducing steel products or primary aluminum. On the other hand, the report does not take the step of protectionism for such a strategic industry and it would have been simpler to set up a levy on the import rather than this complex system. Neither is there any mention in the report of the flight of decision-making centers outside the European Union and the weight of industries in emerging countries. I therefore abstained from this report, which has become a catalog of good feelings without proposals.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing.- While making a fair analysis of the causes of the fall in employment in the EU of the steel industry, which is destined to affect other key sectors as well, the proposals made to remedy it are too bland and lack the necessary impact and strengthturnaround.I am convinced that only by returning to the Member States the instrument of monetary and exchange rate policy and relaunching domestic demand will the conditions for a real lasting economic recovery be created.For all these reasons, I expressed myself with an abstention vote.

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: written.- I have abstained.The base metal industry is very important for Europe and especially important for Sweden.Many industrial jobs have disappeared or moved outside the EU since 2008, and the sector is facing stiff competition.It is important to preserve the industrial work in Sweden and Europe.The report criticizes, in particular, the taxes and laws that exist to protect workers and the environment, which is not the way to go.We want to see an ecologically and socially sustainable base metal industry.Although the report emphasizes the importance of energy efficiency and recycling, it does not go far enough environmentally.Therefore, I chose to abstain.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of this report because it advocates the creation of a sustainable European base metals industry. The decline in capacity and jobs in the European steel industry is due to declining demand. demand was 40 million. tonnes less than in 2007 Capacity has changed to such an extent that the recovery in European demand will lead to a historic trade deficit that will lead to dependency and the loss of know-how in the industrial sector, affecting downstream sectors such as automotive, construction and low carbon technologies. Meanwhile, European aluminum plants are closing due to the increase in demand for aluminum in Europe in recent years, and this is due to increasing imports. Parliament therefore calls for industrial policy to be provided with the tools and resources needed for a successful transition to low-carbon technologies. Although the reuse of base metals and the development of the circular economy are crucial for the European economy, recycling alone cannot be enough to meet the future needs of the European continent, which is moving to a different energy system: for example, wind turbines and solar technologies. consumes up to 90 times more aluminum, 50 times more iron, copper and glass and 15 times more concrete than more traditional thermal power plants currently installed (using fuel oil, natural gas or nuclear fuel).

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of this report which comprehensively addresses the different sensitive points for the development of a sustainable European base metals industry. Base metals (steels, aluminum, copper, tin, nickel, lead, cobalt alloys, molybdenum, magnesium, titanium) play a central role in European industry, used in various strategic sectors: automotive industry, aeronautics, production of power; for this reason it is important that incisive action is carried out in order to initiate a process that will once again stimulate the growth and competitiveness of a sector in which the European Union cannot allow the development of further relationships of dependence. The document underlines the need for greater internal integration of the energy market and the identification of investment strategies for development and innovation. It is positive that the role that the implementation of a circular economy can have on each production site is highlighted, increasing efficiency and competitiveness through the enhancement of the by-products of the secondary metals and recycled metals market. On this point it is necessary to work so that the correct economic incentives are developed, including through the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI), for the development of this new production model.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: written.- I support this resolution because the EU with its actions can alleviate the current difficult situation in the base metals sector.The European base metals industry is important for a whole range of industries down the production chain, including the automotive and aerospace industries, the energy industry, the construction industry and the packaging industry.Metal electrolysis plants such as aluminum, copper and magnesium are closing one after the other, indicating that Europe is rapidly deindustrialising in this sector.This is happening not because of falling European demand, but mainly because of rising and growing volatility in electricity prices in several Member States and dumping from third countries.On the contrary, demand for non-ferrous metals such as aluminum and copper is on the rise, despite the crisis.

name: Marie-Christine BOUTONNET
text: in writing.- If, in this report, the observation concerning the state of the steel industry and aluminum production seems correct to us, in particular when it underlines their strategic nature, the flight of decision-making centers outside Europe and the weight of constraintsenvironmental impact on the productivity of European companies, the same is not true of the solutions proposed, which are very convoluted, essentially consisting in forcing importers to buy CO2 emissions on the polluting rights market.It would suffice to set up an import levy on the basis of an entry price mechanism, and to reverse the ban on long-term electricity supply contracts, a consequence of the policy ofcompetition, to restore the productivity of this sector.However, some amendments counterbalance the protections provided for in this report and lead me to abstain from this text.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. - The European steel industry has been hit by a serious crisis caused by the drop in demand which in 2014 was 40 million tonnes lower than the data of the start of the global economic-financial crisis. The reduction in demand has led to a historic trade deficit in Europe, generating dependence and loss of industrial know-how with repercussions also on the automotive, construction and low-carbon technologies sectors. A strong European response to these events is needed because the smooth functioning of the metal industry is crucial not only for the well-being of our citizens, but also for maintaining European independence. Combining investments in innovation and research with the circular economy and sustainable production means obtaining high quality production, minimizing waste and producing knowledge and technologies that cannot be delocalized but able to cope with the fluctuations of the global market and relaunch the metal sector. basic with a renewed and functional perspective.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: in writing. - This report outlines the avenues for reflection aimed at contributing to the development of the steel industry and aluminum production. The rapporteur takes stock of the state of the sector and reaffirms that the development of this sector is strategic for the Member States of the Union, mainly in terms of jobs. He admits that the environmental standards imposed by the Commission are at the origin of the loss of competitiveness of this industry. This is why he proposes to force importers to buy emission allowances on the polluting rights market in order to fight against environmental dumping practiced by emerging countries. Even if this proposal is positive, it does not completely stop our loss of competitiveness and will help increase the volatility of these emission rights for the benefit of speculators. This report is generally in the right direction but remains unambitious. Only intelligent protectionism would help to fight effectively against unfair international competition. In addition, the amendments of the EPP and the ECR group largely emptied the report of the main interesting measures, particularly in terms of provisions relating to border adjustment. I therefore abstained on this text.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: signed up. - Approximately 160 000 redundancies took place in the steel sector and adjacent sectors. The European base metals industry is currently facing massive investment losses in favor of third countries, which are caused by the higher comparative level of energy prices and the cost of carbon dioxide emissions. On the other hand, there is a decrease in demand in this sector, but also strong global competition from third countries that do not apply the same high standards and strict regulations as in Europe. The paradox is that the reduction in capacity in the aluminum sector in Europe is taking place in the context of an increase in European aluminum demand in recent years, which leads to increased imports. I support this report, because a concrete position and a well-regulated framework are needed because otherwise the closure of factories will lead to the irreversible loss of technology and technological skills, as well as the loss of industrial workforce qualifications.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. - Abstention. The haemorrhage of capacity and jobs that has hit the European steel industry is the result of the decline in demand, which in 2014 remains 40 million tonnes below that of 2007. This capacity adjustment was one scale such that any recovery in European demand will lead to the creation of a historic trade deficit in Europe, generating dependency and loss of industrial know-how that will not fail to affect the automotive, construction and low-carbon technologies sectors . The closures in the European aluminum sector, on the other hand, take place in a context of growth in European demand for aluminum in recent years, which has led to an increase in imports. Climate policy is not at the origin of the difficulties of these industries, but it is certainly among the aggravating causes, as it has proved to be an accelerator of the relocation process. To begin to remedy this, instead of foolishly insisting on the same policies as a sorcerer's apprentice, urgent measures must be taken to combat climate dumping in third countries: for example by replacing the ETS with a permanent measure to adapt to borders ("carbon tax"). The measures required by the report go in the right direction, but they are fresh water.

name: Cristian-Silviu BUŞOI
text: signed up. - The steel sector is suffering the worst crisis in its history in peacetime, leading to a high dependence of the industrial production sector on imports from third countries and the loss of industrial technological skills, with a direct impact on millions of jobs (as a result of the reduction in steel production capacity by more than 40 million tonnes in 2008 and the loss of more than 60 000 direct jobs and more than 100 000 indirect jobs). The European base metals industry is facing massive investment losses in favor of third countries, mainly due to the higher comparative level of energy prices and the cost of carbon dioxide emissions. I support the European Parliament's motion for a resolution on the development of a sustainable European base metals industry. I believe that the EU must provide for flexible and reactive means of trade, adapted to the new global industrial realities, in which decisions can be taken in a timely manner, given the possible multiplication of flows of materials and products, as well as information and services.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. - Today I voted in favor of this report to curb the bleeding of capacity and jobs that has hit the European steel industry, largely due to the drop in demand which in 2014 remains 40 megatonnes below that of the 2007. This capacity adjustment has been of such a magnitude that any recovery in European demand will result in a historic trade deficit in Europe. Steel and aluminum are two significant examples of the difficulties encountered in these professions which must at the same time continue the energy and environmental modernization, which would require an investment policy for which few of them today have the means. However, climate policy is not at all at the origin of the difficulties of these industries but this could happen in the future if the investment crisis continues and if a European industrial policy on raw materials and base metals is not activated. This industrial policy must equip itself with the tools and means necessary to cope with the increase in the price of carbon that all international institutions involved in the fight against climate change are asking for

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. – I abstained on this report which was aimed at developing a sustainable European base metals industry. The base metals sector is one that is facing many difficulties in Europe at the moment due to competition and a fall in demand. Furthermore, multinational companies have taken advantage of lower social and environmental standards to shift production to countries outside of Europe, resulting in huge job losses on the continent.  While I could see good aspects of the report which were aimed at improving the social and employment aspects of the base metal sector, I could not support this report for its weaknesses on environmental issues. Parts of the report sought to blame regulations put in place to save the environment for the choice of these multinationals so move elsewhere. For these reasons, I chose to abstain.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. – Today UKIP voted against the report: Developing a sustainable European industry of base metals. We believe that the EU’s obsessive green policy together with a lack of regulatory coherence has created great difficulties for energy intensive industries in Europe. We believe that neither EU climate policy nor the new Energy Union proposal, with the renewed ETS system, is the solution to resolve the severe difficulties faced by the base metals industry.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report as it aims to improve and make our base metals (steel, aluminium or non-ferrous metals) industry more efficient and to address its problem of competitiveness and allow for better investments. All of this while remembering about our commitments to the environment.

name: Jean-Marie CAVADA
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of Edouard Martin's report on the sustainable European base metals industry.This report proposes concrete measures to preserve the competitiveness of this industry and of the Union's steel industry, but also to fight against climate change.This text aims in particular to introduce an adjustment of carbon emission quotas at borders, in order to prevent unfair competition from trade partners of the Union subject to standards much more flexible than ours.The measures advocated by Edouard Martin go, in my opinion, in the direction of better protection of European industrial production.They should enable the Union to impose its social, fiscal and environmental standards.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of the presented report as I believe that we have to make sure the EU base metal industry, and particularly the steel industry, has everything it needs in order to adapt to the current structural changes. That includes the possibility of using EU funds in order to raise energy efficiency through training of workers in the application of low-carbon technologies.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: in writing. - The base metals industry plays an essential role in strategic sectors of our economy such as the automotive and energy production sectors. The dumping practices carried out by third countries, such as China, have resulted in the European market being subjected to forms of improper competition, such as to create serious difficulties, in particular, for the base metals sector. This circumstance, together with other elements relating for example to contracts for the supply of electricity, pushes European companies not to invest enough in efficient and innovative long-term solutions, thus risking losing competitiveness and making the European economic system excessively dependent on others. countries. The resolution adopted aims to guarantee minimum levels of protection of the European market, modernizing the trade defense instruments to guarantee "fair" competition between European and non-European producers on the internal market and subjecting operators to equivalent rules, so as to ensure, among other things, other, respect for carbon emission quotas. The resolution, inspired by principles of transparency, also focuses on the right of access to information by civil society and local communities, and pays particular attention to environmental protection. I therefore voted in favor.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: PPE), in writing. - We voted in favor of the report because we believe that in an industrialized and resource-efficient economy it is imperative to upgrade secondary metals (resulting from a recovery and recycling process), which must be developed in a competitive and sustainable cyclical economy, although We also know that it can in no way fully meet the needs of the European economies in basic metals, either in quality or in quantity. We also know that the scrap trade balance in the EU is positive and incentives to recycle scrap in Europe.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: GUE / NGL), in writing.- The report on the development of a sustainable European base metals industry is a positive basis for the development of industry support policies.Although there are some negative elements, I decided to vote in favor, considering that companies and workers in this sector in Europe have suffered many blows in recent years due to the turmoil in the economy and any initiative to revive business will work for the benefit of all.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ The draft report stresses the need to support the base metal industry as it is particularly vulnerable to outside competition (dumping prices) and also to EU climate and energy policy. It also addresses the problem of heightened loss of competitiveness of several basic materials industries such as the steel, aluminium and non-ferrous metals industries. The EU therefore needs to help building an efficient frame for these sectors in order to re-establish their economic potential.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of this report, as we Europeans should be proud of our steel industry and should commit ourselves to defend it by applying all trade defense instruments, especially when we are talking about the growing unfair competition from outside Europe, as in the case of China. We are well aware that the exponential increase in exports of Chinese products to Europe is a fact and that recognizing the status of a market economy to China would make it impossible to apply the legal measures in defense of this country European industry. We are well aware that China has never until now managed to meet the requirements to be recognized as a market economy, which are for example the absence of state interference, the absence of state-induced distortions on businesses, the adoption bankruptcy legislation that guarantees legal certainty and stability or compliance with independent auditing standards and in line with the relevant international standards. I remember that any recognition would invalidate all anti-dumping measures to protect our industry.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. – I concur that industrial policy must comprise the tools and resources needed to make low-carbon transition a reality, and this can only be done through strategic management of base metals industries and by ensuring that the right tools and resources are available. We should avoid risks of experiencing what happened in 2008 – with the loss of no less than 60 000 jobs directly and over 100 000 jobs indirectly, resulting in dependency and losses of industrial know-how – through forward planning in the parameters of today’s climate change challenges.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. - The topic in question - although it may appear extremely technical - has innumerable implications in various sectors of primary importance, all closely connected. In fact, first of all, these metals are at the base of many industrial sectors and activities of undisputed importance. Secondly, the policies on the base metals industry are - as a direct consequence - capable of having a significant impact, both directly and indirectly, on European employment. In this regard, we cannot forget that, on the one hand, this sector is subjected to strong international pressure (how can we forget the very rapid steps taken by the Chinese government!), While on the other it is characterized by the high energy needs of such industries. The report in question - thanks also to the contribution that the rapporteur has been able to give, thanks to his great personal experience in the sector - represents a good synthesis of balance between the opposing needs. In particular, it should be noted the request to make the compensation policy for indirect emissions fair between the Member States and the introduction of the adjustment of the carbon content at the border, in order to fight against international competition that is not subject to the constraints of ETS. For these reasons, mine will be a favorable vote.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: written. - I voted in favor of this report as it represents significant political support for the steel industry sector in Europe. The sector faces a serious crisis due to the full commercial opening of the borders, which prevents the maintenance of this essential industry for quality employment in Europe. The report includes certain points that we do not accept, such as the harmonization of state aid to the sector or the energy union, but at the same time it includes fundamental measures such as the adjustment of coal at the border, the unequivocal commitment to recycling and the circular economy for the recovery of the sector, the development of public investment, the promotion and maintenance of social dialogue and the promotion of regional economic cohesion. Due to all these essential points to overcome the crisis that the sector is currently facing, an indispensable industry in our commitment to a new production model that allows generating quality employment, I have decided to vote in favor of this report.

name: Andrea COZZOLINO
text: in writing. - The European steel sector, in addition to being of considerable historical importance for European integration, plays a fundamental role in the development of the entire economy both at a technological level and in overcoming supply difficulties. However, this sector in Europe is experiencing one of the worst crises with the reduction of over 40 million tonnes of steel production capacity since 2008 and the loss of over 60,000 direct jobs and 100,000 indirect jobs. This crisis means that at the European level the industrial manufacturing sectors are more dependent on imports from third countries and that there is a loss of industrial know-how with immediate repercussions on millions of jobs and on the competitiveness of the sector. The resolution of the European Parliament, which I voted in favor, proposes actions to revive the European steel industry starting from its sustainability such as the need for immediate action against climate change and high energy prices, the support for investments in the production of low-carbon metals, European trade protection measures in base metals.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ I believe that actions aimed at safeguarding industries should focus on the reduction of operating costs in Europe rather than the introduction of imposed costs which could create further imbalances in an already uneven playing field on the global market for European manufacturers.  From a climate change perspective, I support a robust emissions trading scheme for the EU that provides a realistic carbon price signal and I consider the revision of the EU ETS Directive as an opportunity to strengthen the effectiveness of this policy instrument. However, the impact of the EU ETS (and other environment measures) in the European steel industry, compared to other factors (economic, social, labour costs, demand, lack of innovation, lack of proactive action/investment by the sector etc.) needs to be fully addressed. Free allocation should be based on clear, objective, quantitative criteria and should be targeted at the sector/sub-sector where carbon leakage is a proven reality. In my view an urgent in-depth review of existing measures together with the repercussions of any additional measures has to be swiftly undertaken.

name: Daniel DALTON
text: in writing. ‒ I am extremely concerned at the current situation in the steel sector, and the base metals sector in general. The supply of raw materials and high energy prices due to European energy policy are having an impact on the European base metals sector’s competitiveness.  However, I cannot support the introduction of a carbon border adjustment mechanism; this would encourage protectionism and potentially lead to retaliation from international trading mechanisms. Obliging Member States to provide compensation for indirect costs encroaches upon fiscal sovereignty, and indeed such harmonisation would be too burdensome to implement given the disparities that exist between Member States in terms of energy costs and intensity.

name: Seb DANCE
text: in writing. ‒ People who work in the steel industry are losing their jobs, both in the UK and across the EU as the sector confronts its most serious peacetime crisis ever, facing a combination of rising steel prices, social dumping, an influx of cheap Chinese steel and increasing energy costs.  We will not be able to solve this problem on our own – by  working together at EU level we can put pressure on the Chinese government over steel dumping and come up with Europe-wide solutions to these problems. In the upcoming work on Phase IV of the ETS, Labour MEPs will work to ensure that the system of free carbon allowances addresses the issue of carbon leakage. Should this not be sufficient, the Commission should, as a last resort, examine the feasibility of a carbon border adjustment mechanism linked to the ETS.  Labour MEPs will continue to work on this issue and to call on the UK Government to take strong and effective action at the national level to support the steel industry and stop massive direct and indirect job losses in this sector.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: signed up.- I believe that energy-intensive industries must continue their efforts to optimize recycling mechanisms and reduce CO2 emissions, in order to ensure industrial competitiveness in the future and to meet the mandatory reduction targets set by the European Union.

name: Nicola DANTI
text: in writing. - The Martin report highlights, among others, the fundamental issue of commercial relations with major global partners, which greatly influence the survival of our productive fabric in this strategic sector. The European steel industry is going through a phase of profound crisis: world production overcapacity in the steel sector alone, especially on the part of China, is already causing a huge loss of jobs in several Member States. In the report, there is an important passage that refers to the possible recognition by the European Union of the status of market economy precisely to China: this would mean "aggravating the consequences of the price war waged by the main steel producer in the world" . The acquisition of this status would, in fact, have a disastrous impact on the effectiveness of European trade defense instruments and consequently on the ability to protect businesses and jobs. At stake are geopolitics and trade policy, but, in both cases, we cannot allow our businesses, our workers, our citizens to pay. I firmly believe that European industry must be able to compete in the world, on the basis of clear rules and under the same conditions as its trading partners. That is why I voted in favor of the report.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: in writing.- This own-initiative report proposes measures to support the metallurgical industry, which is extremely vulnerable to international competition and to European climate and energy policies.The objective of the report, in line with the priorities of the PPE Group, is to reindustrialize Europe by increasing investments and promoting a level playing field with the rest of the world.The report proposes the introduction of a carbon border adjustment mechanism, the objective of which is to impose a carbon tax on goods entering the European Union framed by less ambitious environmental quality criteria.It also refers to the review of the Emissions Trading System (ETS).Considering that the metal industry remains a strategic sector for the European Union, I supported this report.

name: Rachida DATI
text: in writing.- I gave my support to this report, which aims to guarantee the competitiveness of the base metals industry, in particular by overhauling the emissions trading system.This report is notable because the base metals industry is of particular importance in Europe for a whole series of sectors such as automotive, aeronautics and construction.

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: in writing.- Since 2008, the European steel sector has been hit by a serious crisis, due to strong competition from products from third countries such as China.European producers who, unlike their international competitors, are required to meet high-level environmental and energy obligations, are struggling to remain competitive in the face of Chinese steel sold at very low cost.To protect this sector and its jobs, it is therefore essential to invest and establish sustainable European regulations for raw materials and base metals.In particular, a carbon tax system must be introduced at the borders of the European Union in order to force foreign importers to indicate the carbon content of their metals and to buy emission quotas in order to be able to sell on the Community market.

name: Angélique DELAHAYE
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of this own-initiative report, the objective of which is to contribute to the reindustrialisation of Europe and to promote conditions of fair competition at international level. We therefore call on the European Union to take into account the vulnerability of the metals industry to dumping practiced by third countries, particularly China, and to develop an effective framework to restore the economic potential of the sector. To do this, we recommend the implementation of a carbon border adjustment (ACF) and the future reform of the emissions trading system (ETS) in order to protect the competitiveness of European industries. Finally, by having voted for this report, I am pleading for a reduction and harmonization of prices in Europe through better integration of the internal market while investing in research and development so that Europe can remain a pole of excellence in the production of base metals.

name: Andor DELI
text: in writing. - The industrial metals industry in Europe has faced a number of recent challenges: on the one hand, as a result of the crisis, demand has fallen sharply, and on the other hand, global competition has intensified significantly in countries that do not have to meet high European standards. The rapporteur points out that the problems of the EU industrial metals industry, such as low competitiveness and low investment attractiveness, are largely due to the emissions trading scheme and high European energy prices. Therefore, the transformation of the current emissions trading scheme is one of the most pressing issues to ensure the competitiveness of the industrial metals industry. With regard to the circular economy, I agree with the report's objective, which is to rapidly increase the recycling of rare earths and critical metals used in the Union. It also calls for strong links to be established between the industrial metals recycling sector and other sectors in order to strengthen the size and resilience of the industry, especially in regions affected by industrial decline. As a member of the Hungarian delegation of the People's Party, I supported the report because I believe that there is a need to renew European industrial policy.

name: Jean-Paul DENANOT
text: in writing.- This is an important report on the base metals industry which denounces the scandal of brownfields in Europe, with factories abandoned when they could still produce and which recommends efficient avenues for change, in particular theCO2 adjustment at the borders of Europe in order to prevent unfair competition from those who produce in territories with lower standards than ours, but sell in Europe.We must now think about a new European reading of competition law that takes more account of European industrial interests in a context of exacerbated global competition, in particular with China, which is advancing in disguise, presenting itself in the guise of amarket while this country-continent protects its internal market and conditions its access.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: in writing. - I supported the report on the development of a sustainable European base metals industry. The base metals industry is essential for a whole series of downstream sectors, including automotive, aeronautics, energy production, construction and even packaging. Europe, already very dependent in terms of raw materials, cannot afford to allow itself to be created a new dependence on base metals. I therefore support the implementation of a carbon tax at borders. This contribution, based on carbon dioxide emissions, would put European base metal producers, forced to buy rights to pollute, and their foreign competitors, who would be exempt from it, on an equal footing. Such an approach would have the advantage of proposing a universal solution allowing each State to decide in a sovereign way the level of ambition of its climate policy, according to a careful impact assessment of the consequences. I have also defended a firm position vis-à-vis the Union's trading partners who are likely to present dumping measures.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: in writing.- This report on the development of the base metals sector, in particular on aluminum, presents good aspects, although it does not go far enough and thus loses its usefulness.The text establishes a relevant diagnosis on the disastrous industrial policy that Europe has undergone (by referring in particular to environmental standards that are much too restrictive).Mention is also made of the need for a global agreement on CO2 emissions which would harmonize scattered and inefficient texts.However, at no time does the report mention the essential trade protection measures in order to revive the European metallurgical industry.Refusing to allow decision-making centers outside Europe with regard to metallurgy to flee, as well as outside the framework of a realistic and national trade policy, but noting the advance of mentalities on the need to reindustrialize Europe, Iabstained.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: In written form. - As one of the major sectors, the steel sector is important for the European economy not only as a sector with high added value, but also as a sector that employs a large number of European citizens. For this reason, and because of the problems in this area caused by the economic crisis, the reduced demand caused by many different reasons, as well as the reduced consumption and the increase in China's own production, we have a duty to protect the European economy and therefore the people employed in this business. However, I voted against this document because, in my opinion, the change and liberalization of the quota regime will not help the development of this sector, but will only turn these quotas into a bargaining chip and a kind of security. Protecting the environment and combating climate change is of paramount importance to the Community, but also to the rest of the world. For this reason and because a number of other countries have access to much cheaper energy resources, ie. cheaper end products, we must focus the attention of this industry on the use of energy efficient and innovative production processes. Unfortunately, this report looks like a lobbyist to me, and for that reason I do not support it.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), in writing.- We are voting against because we believe that this report does not succeed in tackling the evolving and big problem of the European base metal industries, which is nothing more than China's unfair competition.

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: in writing. - The industrial metals industry in Europe (various steels, non-ferrous metals, metal alloys, rare earths) is facing a number of recent challenges: on the one hand, the crisis has led to a sharp drop in demand and a significant increase in global competition from adhere to similar high standards. The rapporteur points out that the problems of the EU industrial metals industry, such as low competitiveness and low investment attractiveness, are largely due to the emissions trading scheme and high European energy prices. Therefore, the transformation of the current emissions trading scheme is one of the most pressing issues to ensure the competitiveness of the industrial metals industry. European trade defense measures for industrial metals are characterized by too late a remedy rather than a prevention. European trade policy cannot ignore the fact that these third countries take advantage of their comparative advantage in terms of access to raw materials, often receive state aid and sometimes sell their products at prices below production costs. In the detailed vote, I supported the use of cross-border carbon offsets as an option. As a member of the Hungarian delegation of the People's Party, I supported the report because I believe that there is a need to renew European industrial policy.

name: Eleonora EVI
text: in writing. - The report by my colleague Martin, from the French socialists, focuses on the base metal industry; the role they play for European industry is very high. They are essential for many sectors and, as a result, have direct and indirect effects on employment and a large part of the European economy. Obviously, it should not be forgotten that they are used by industries that have a high energy requirement and, therefore, a balance must be found that allows the industry to remain competitive without compromising energy policies and the reduction of atmospheric emissions. Perhaps the most innovative contribution of this report consists in the request to normalize the compensation policy for indirect emissions between Member States, also introducing an instrument such as the adjustment of the carbon content at the border which aims to counter international competition which, as often happens, it operates under less stringent regulatory systems than those of the EU. I believe that this report has succeeded in balancing the environmental commitment while at the same time guaranteeing the rights of workers without compromising industrial needs. I voted in favor.

name: Fredrick FEDERLEY
text: written.- This report is less about the challenges of the base metal sector and more about the EU Emissions Trading Scheme (EU ETS).As the European Parliament has just begun work on the EU ETS bill presented by the Commission in July, it is very unfortunate to already be locking in the positions without proper discussion, and where they do not belong.We have therefore chosen to vote consistently against all writings that go into detail about the EU ETS and about carbon dioxide adjustment at borders, regardless of what we think about the content itself, and voted against the entire report.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: in writing.- I voted against this report because it does not sufficiently protect industry in European countries.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. - The decline in capacity and employment in the European steel industry is partly the result of falling demand. In 2014, it registered a decrease of 40 million tons in relation to 2007. But this decrease results mainly from decades of divestment and dismantling of this sector, as is the case of Portugal, with the dependence and loss of specialized industrial knowledge. , which are reflected in downstream sectors. The report affirms the urgency of an increase in the development of the base metals industry - iron, aluminum, copper, etc. - and the need to adapt it to the new technological / environmental paradigms, with a view to reaffirming it internationally. Some of the recommendations in this report are positive. But the approach taken is incomplete and inconsistent. Furthermore, we do not follow considerations regarding exploration and property, that is, the accumulation of capital by large multinationals that, in the end, will continue to appropriate the resources and wealth creation of this sector. A new impetus for industrial policy should continue the path of technological, energetic and environmental modernization, creating more jobs and equipping itself with the necessary instruments and means, which will not be possible without the strategic public control of the metal industries. base.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: in writing. – I voted in favour as the overall thrust is positive.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing. - Steel and aluminum are therefore two important examples of the difficulties faced by those working in these sectors, who need to continue with energy and environmental modernization, which requires an investment policy for which few have the resources today. This industrial policy must provide the necessary tools and resources to achieve a successful transition to a low-carbon economy, which cannot be achieved without strategic management of the base metals sector and without the necessary tools and resources to cope with rising carbon prices. Although it is absolutely essential for European economies to reuse base metals and develop a circular economy, recycling alone will not be able to cover the future needs of the European continent involved in switching to other energy sources. At a time when emerging countries are expanding their base metal industries, which are providing economic growth, these countries are becoming important competitors in the global steel market, in the whole base metal and rare earth industries, and have a comparative advantage in terms of access. to raw materials, which can sometimes be multiplied by public support and dumping through dumping, it is essential for the European Union to develop flexible and reactive trade defense measures.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing.- As in the previous report, also for this report the negative and more delicate aspects are not addressed with the right pragmatism.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing.- I am voting against the report on the development of a sustainable European base metal industry because I believe that this report fails to offer a solution to the evolving and big problem of the European base metal industries, which is nothing more than China's unfair competition.

name: Ashley FOX
text: in writing. – Conservatives recognise that the base metals industry is a cornerstone of our economy and recognise the increased challenges the sector has faced over recent years. We are alarmed at the surge in Chinese steel exports that have flooded the world market, often being sold overseas at a loss. There have already been a number of closures in the UK and if the current situation continues unabated further wholesale closures are inevitable. We are therefore in favour of the calls in the report backing EU-level anti-dumping measures which support the UK steel sector. However we do not support the introduction of a carbon border adjustment mechanism, which could encourage protectionism, lead to retaliation and undermine efforts to secure a global approach to climate change and emissions reduction. Conservatives also welcome the focus on the impact of high energy prices on competitiveness and agree that more needs to be done to compensate for indirect costs. However, obliging Member States to provide such compensation encroaches upon fiscal sovereignty, and harmonisation would be too burdensome to implement given the disparities that exist between Member States in terms of energy costs and intensity. Conservatives therefore voted against the report.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ The haemorrhaging of skills and jobs in the European steel industry is the result of a slump in demand. There have been such significant adjustments in capacity that any upturn in European demand will give rise to an unprecedented trade deficit in Europe that would engender dependency and the loss of industrial know-how and is bound to have a knock-on effect on the downstream automotive, construction and low-carbon technologies sectors.  On the other hand, closures in the European aluminium industry are taking place at an alarming pace against a backdrop of growing European demand for aluminium in recent years, which has led to increases in imports. Steel and aluminium are two prime examples of the difficulties faced by those working in such industries, which must continue to modernise in energy and environmental terms when this means following an investment policy which few can currently afford.  Thus, while climate change policy is in no way the root cause of the problems facing these industries, it may well be so in the future if the investment crisis continues and if no European industrial policy on raw materials and base metals is implemented.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: in writing. - The industrial metals industry in Europe has faced a number of recent challenges: on the one hand, as a result of the crisis, demand has fallen sharply, and on the other hand, global competition has intensified significantly in countries that do not have to meet high European standards. The rapporteur points out that the problems of the EU industrial metals industry, such as low competitiveness and low investment attractiveness, are largely due to the emissions trading scheme and high European energy prices. Therefore, the transformation of the current emissions trading scheme is one of the most pressing issues to ensure the competitiveness of the industrial metals industry. European trade defense measures for industrial metals are characterized by too late a remedy rather than a prevention. European trade policy cannot ignore the fact that these third countries take advantage of their comparative advantage in terms of access to raw materials, often receiving state aid, sometimes selling their products below cost of production. With regard to the circular economy, I agree with the report's objective, which is to rapidly increase the recycling of rare earths and critical metals used in the Union. It also calls for strong links to be established between the industrial metals recycling sector and other sectors in order to strengthen the size and resilience of the industry, especially in regions affected by industrial decline. In the detailed vote, I supported the use of cross-border carbon offsets as an option.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: in writing. - The European steel industry has suffered huge losses in terms of both capacity and jobs due to a drop in demand, which fell by 40 megatonnes in 2014 compared to 2007 levels. The capacity gap has reached such proportions that any re-strengthening of European demand will create unprecedented deficits and dependence in the history of European trade, and the devastating effects of losses of industrial know-how will certainly spill over to the emerging sectors, including the automotive, and low carbon technologies. We are at a time when emerging countries are developing the industrial metals industry (the production of metals for which demand is growing again), so they have become key competitors in the world market for both steel and all industrial metals and rare earths, taking advantage of their relative advantages in raw materials. which is sometimes accompanied by State aid and the pursuit of dumping (ie selling below cost of production). The EU needs to equip itself with flexible and responsive trade defense, adapting to the new global industrial environment, where the pace of decision-making needs to be accelerated in the face of the challenges posed by the potential multiplication of flows of raw materials and products and information and services. I voted in favor of the report.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: written.- I voted in favor given the difficulties faced by the steel and aluminum sectors in the EU.I am convinced that industrial policy must have the necessary tools and means to be able to carry out the low-carbon transition.The European basic metals industries must find a strategy to adapt to the new climate, economic and social situation, setting an example in terms of efficiency and effectiveness in the consumption of energy and raw materials, and not disappearing from the future industrial landscape.Emission rights, which are currently allocated following historical series, must be granted for current production, not past production.In the same way, we must incentivize with free emission rights those companies that invest the most in innovation and improvement of their facilities to reduce their polluting emissions.

name: Elisabetta GARDINI
text: in writing.- The metals industry represents a vital sector for the European economy, a world excellence that is suffering from great difficulties and that needs greater protection and support from the institutions.We need a real industrial policy for the sector and a clear no to the recognition of the market economy status of China, which is exercising forms of unfair competition from which our excellence must be defended.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the EP report on the development of a sustainable European base metals industry because I strongly support the idea of ​​a strong, innovative and competitive but also clean European base metals industry which generates jobs. of quality work. I share the need for a European industrial policy in the sector that addresses the environmental challenge and the competitiveness of products and resolves the growing investment gap in new clean technologies, which would allow European industry to innovate and establish production standards worldwide. I share the request for a border adjustment mechanism extended to the entire supply chain, which avoids the delocalization of pollution and the displacement of European production to countries with less environmental sensitivity and lower CO2 costs. I believe, in fact, that European leadership in the fight against climate change must also be exercised by making sure that competing producers apply our legislation in trade with the EU: the determination of the polluting characteristics of imported products is therefore essential. Finally, I agree with the reference to the problem of long-term energy contracts and the voluntary offsetting on a national basis of direct emissions, which generates unfair competition between European producers.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: written.- Today I voted against the report on the development of a sustainable European industry for base metals because I clearly miss the concept of sustainability in the proposed approach and I want a different approach.

name: Adam GIEREK
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of this report and I congratulate the rapporteur. He pointed to the conditions of sustainable development of European metallurgy. He assumed the irresistible fact that the cost of CO2 emission allowances threatened with a competitive shock and the transfer of energy-intensive material sectors outside Europe. As it concerns basic construction materials, especially steel - it threatens to deindustrialize Europe, lose the technological experience and specialists acquired, and abandon advanced scientific research. I agree with the rapporteur's view on the fundamental role of increasing real energy efficiency on the path to decarbonisation. Interesting and worth considering is his proposal to adjust prices at the EU borders to take into account ecological dumping in imported steel products, as the current compensation is a source of unequal competition. I caution the Commission against assuming that scrap smelting can completely replace primary metallurgy. This is a bug. It must be remembered that the steel with the highest added value is produced in the full technological cycle, as well as the increased contamination of such steel with impurities that are difficult to remove, including copper.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: written.- The industry is in particularly intense competition with international competitors.The environmental standards applicable in Europe can lead to a competitive disadvantage for domestic companies.In these cases, it is our job to protect jobs and keep companies competitive.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which seeks to develop a sustainable base metals industry in Europe.  People who work in the steel industry are losing their jobs in the UK, including in my region of the West Midlands, and across the EU as the sector confronts its most serious peacetime crisis ever, facing a combination of rising steel prices, social dumping, an influx of cheap Chinese steel and increasing energy costs.  We will not be able to solve this problem on our own – by working together at EU level we can put pressure on the Chinese government over steel dumping, and come up with Europe-wide solutions to these problems. If the existing system of free allowances of carbon emissions fails to address the issue of carbon leakage, we will need to examine the option of a carbon border adjustment mechanism linked to the ETS as a last resort.  Together with colleagues, I will continue to work on this issue and call on the UK Government to take strong and effective action to support the steel industry and combat job losses in the sector.

name: Bruno GOLLNISCH
text: in writing. - There was a specific European community for coal and steel. Britain's last mine will close this week and the European Union as a whole produces only 42% of the steel it consumes. Of course there is the crisis. But the problem is deeper: for decades, all European policies have contributed to the deindustrialization of the European Union in general and of France in particular. We cannot want generalized free trade and give up equipping ourselves with instruments of trade defense worthy of the name. We cannot both denounce the systematic dumping of China, but negotiate its market economy status at the WTO. We cannot swear by the sacrosanct free and unhindered competition, but plead for a proactive industrial policy. Request long energy supply contracts in a fully liberalized market. Talk about competitiveness and impose on our companies the heaviest constraints of climate policy. Dreaming of reviving industry and promoting austerity policies. All of this is contradictory. Mr. Martin has not entirely forgotten his background as a steelmaker. His report contains some interesting things. But by becoming a member of Parliament, Mr. Martin adopted the dogmas of the European Union. And that doom these proposals to failure.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: written.- We have abstained because we consider that the basic metals industry sector is a strategic sector in the economy, and the document contains positive aspects in terms of social, labor and defense of workers, and contains general lines to supportthis industry and that there is a transformation of it in environmental matters.But, on the other hand, we are radically opposed to their positioning and their tacit tolerance towards the Emissions Trading Scheme (ETS) and the TTIP.The environmental guidelines set out in the document seem totally insufficient to us.

name: Nathan GILL
text: in writing. ‒ Today UKIP voted against the report: Developing a sustainable European industry of base metals. We believe that the EU’s obsessive green policy together with a lack of regulatory coherence has created great difficulties for energy intensive industries in Europe. We believe that neither EU climate policy nor the new Energy Union proposal, with the renewed ETS system, is the solution to resolve the severe difficulties faced by the base metals industry.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: signed up.- The report highlights the importance of the base metals industry for the EU's internal market and the fact that this industry influences a number of sectors, including the automotive, aeronautical, construction and packaging sectors.All these sectors maintain hundreds of thousands of jobs and must be supported.I voted in favor of the report, especially for the requests in the report on the need to support the EU steel industry, by investing and ensuring fair competition in the internal market in relation to non-European steel products entering the internal market.Deindustrialization leads to job losses and rising poverty.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ This report deals with base metals, including steel, aluminium, zinc and copper, which are needed for industrial growth across Europe and seeks to develop a sustainable base metals industry in Europe. People working in the industry are losing their jobs, both in the UK and across the EU, as the sector confronts its most serious peacetime crisis ever, facing a combination of rising steel prices, social dumping, an influx of cheap Chinese steel and increasing energy costs. We cannot solve this problem on our own – but by working together at EU level we can put pressure on the Chinese Government over steel dumping and find Europe-wide solutions to these problems. In the upcoming work on Phase IV of the ETS, Labour MEPs will work to ensure that the system of free carbon allowances addresses the issue of carbon leakage. If this is not sufficient, the Commission should, as a last resort, examine the feasibility of a carbon border adjustment mechanism linked to the ETS. Labour MEPs will continue to work on this issue and to call on the UK Government to take strong, effective action at national level to support the steel industry and to stop job losses.

name: Françoise GROSSETÊTE
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of this report. The situation is critical for the base metals industry and in particular for the steel sector. Added to this is the extremely high price of energy in Europe compared to other producing regions. Our producers pay twice as much as their American counterparts! There is therefore an urgent need to fight against dumping, particularly from China, by making full use of trade defense instruments to discourage unfair behavior. A long-term border carbon adjustment mechanism is in itself a good idea, but we must be careful that it does not become a huge burden for our industries because such a mechanism would automatically increase the price of imported raw materials. So let's be vigilant! It also seems essential to me to intensify discussions with our steel partners such as China, Russia, India, Belarus and Turkey to find solutions. We are so in need of a solid and lasting industrial base! Those who predicted a service company were wrong! Industry rightly remains a sector with promising projects. We must therefore improve our factories, keep our jobs and free up our capacity for innovation!

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: in writing. - Steel production is a fundamental element for the survival of our European industries. This is why I gave my full support to the report by my colleague Edouard Martin, which proposes several solutions to the risks of relocation of metal production. Among his proposals, he invites the European Commission and the Member States to reflect on a new European reading of competition law which takes better account of the exacerbated global competition. It also proposes to favor new modes of corporate governance through public participation or a structuring encouraging reinvestment in the production tool rather than the payment of dividends. Finally, he proposes to introduce a CO2 adjustment at the borders of Europe in order to prevent unfair competition from those who produce in territories with less strict standards than ours, but sell in Europe, while fighting against climate change. . It is ultimately about saying that Europe can and must act to defend its companies, its employees, its know-how, its social and environmental standards. The European Union must impose its social, fiscal and environmental standards if it does not want to resolve itself to be, in the end, only a large market.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ My vote on Report on developing a sustainable European industry of base metals was decided by the fact that the report is talking about border carbon adjustment, which would only add more confusion to an already very difficult and heated discussion.

name: Jytte GUTELAND
text: written.- We have chosen to vote against a number of proposals that we believe anticipate the already ongoing process of considering the reform of the EU Emissions Trading Scheme (ETS).We share the rapporteur's concerns about the development of the European base metal industry, and several of these proposals are constructive, progressive proposals that we would normally have supported.However, it is problematic to take far-reaching positions on the ETS through this report, which risks anticipating the important reform of the ETS, which is a system that affects significantly more sectors than the base metal industry and covers over 13000 installations of different nature and with different needs.We have therefore chosen a restrictive line in the vote on this own-initiative report when it comes to the ETS, but have chosen to support the report in its entirety as it concerns an entire industry which is currently in a very difficult situation.

name: András GYÜRK
text: in writing. - The industrial metals industry in Europe (various steels, non-ferrous metals, metal alloys, rare earths) is facing a number of recent challenges: on the one hand, the crisis has led to a sharp drop in demand and a significant increase in global competition from adhere to similar high standards. The rapporteur points out that the problems of the EU industrial metals industry, such as low competitiveness and low investment attractiveness, are largely due to the emissions trading scheme and high European energy prices. Therefore, the transformation of the current emissions trading scheme is one of the most pressing issues to ensure the competitiveness of the industrial metals industry. European trade defense measures for industrial metals are characterized by too late a remedy rather than a prevention. European trade policy cannot ignore the fact that these third countries take advantage of their comparative advantage in terms of access to raw materials, often receive state aid and sometimes sell their products at prices below production costs. With regard to the circular economy, I agree with the report's objective, which is to rapidly increase the recycling of rare earths and critical metals used in the Union. In the detailed vote, I supported the use of cross-border carbon offsets as an option.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: GUE / NGL), in writing. - The report addresses the serious problems faced by European base metal industries due to declining demand and high competition due to the relocation of production of large multinational companies to third countries, so that they do not have to comply with environmental regulations. applicable in the EU but also collective agreements. We voted in favor of this report because it contains a number of positive points such as the need to support the European metals industry, especially in relation to workers' rights, the need to create new quality jobs, the need to protect human health and the environment, and the need to put barriers to the action and profitability of large multinational companies.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as it deals with several concerning issues that need to be highlighted in the basic material industry in Europe such as climate change, border adjustment measures, emissions policy, energy policy, transparency and merger acquisitions. The overall aim of this own initiative report is to identify new conditions under which base metals industries, such as steel, aluminium and non-ferrous metals can prosper in the EU.  I believe that a level playing field has to be ensured for the European base metal industry, however; initially it is best to focus on the upcoming ETS reform in order to come up with a well-balanced and thought through reform that benefits all.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report because it stresses the need to support the base metal industry as it in particular is vulnerable to outside competition and also to EU climate and energy policy.  The report also addresses the problem of heightened loss of competitiveness of several basic materials industries such as the steel, aluminium or non-ferrous metals industries. It is critical that the EU builds an efficient framework for these sectors in order to re-establish their economic potential. The overall target of this report is in line with the EPP Group’s priority to re-industrialise Europe through investments and to promote an international level playing field in this sector.

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: written.- The report calls on the Commission to promote the development of a functioning secondary metal market and the circular economy.The problem, however, was that the report also called for border taxes, i.e. a CO2 tax on imports.Because of the support for a non-tariff trade barrier and protectionism, I have chosen to vote against the report.I also believe that the single euro must be abolished.It leads to discord and dissension in Europe.

name: György HÖLVÉNYI
text: in writing. - The industrial metals industry in Europe (various steels, non-ferrous metals, metal alloys, rare earths) is facing a number of recent challenges. On the one hand, as a result of the crisis, demand has fallen sharply and, on the other hand, global competition has intensified significantly, especially in countries that do not have to comply with high standards similar to those in Europe. The rapporteur points out that the problems of the EU industrial metals industry, such as low competitiveness and low investment attractiveness, are largely due to the emissions trading scheme and high European energy prices. Therefore, the transformation of the current emissions trading scheme is one of the most pressing issues to ensure the competitiveness of the industrial metals industry. European trade defense measures for industrial metals are characterized by too late a remedy rather than a prevention. European trade policy cannot ignore the fact that these third countries take advantage of their comparative advantage in terms of access to raw materials, often receive state aid and sometimes sell their products at prices below production costs. Emphasizing the importance of the circular economy, the report identifies a rapid increase in the recycling of rare earths and critical metals used in the Union. It also aims to establish strong links to strengthen the industrial metals recycling sector and other sectors, especially in regions affected by industrial decline. As a member of the Hungarian delegation of the People's Party, I supported the report because I believe that there is a need to renew European industrial policy.

name: Mary HONEYBALL
text: in writing. ‒ This report seeks to develop a base metals industry in Europe which is sustainable in the long term and both maintains and develops this important sector. People who work in the steel industry are losing their jobs, both in the UK and across the EU. It faces a combination of rising steel prices, social dumping, an influx of cheap Chinese steel and increasing energy costs.   We will not be able to solve this problem on our own. By working together at EU level we can put pressure on the Chinese government over steel dumping and come up with Europe-wide solutions to these problems. In the upcoming work on Phase IV of the ETS, Labour MEPs will work to ensure that the system of free carbon allowances addresses the issue of carbon leakage. Should this not be sufficient, the Commission should, as a last resort, examine the feasibility of a carbon border adjustment mechanism linked to the ETS.   Labour MEPs will continue to work on this issue and call on the UK Government to take strong and effective action at national level to support the steel industry and stop massive direct and indirect job losses in this sector.

name: Ian HUDGHTON
text: in writing. ‒ The steel industry across Europe, including in my own country, has faced extreme hardship in recent times as a result of a combination of factors. The EU has an important role to play in supporting the industry and I accordingly voted in favour of this report.  It is shameful to note that the Scottish Government was recently barred by the UK government from attending key meetings in Brussels.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. ‒ The haemorrhaging of skills and jobs in the European steel industry is the result of a slump in demand, which in 2014 was 40 megatonnes below its 2007 levels. I have voted for this report that will equip the European Union with flexible and responsive trade protection measures to address the new global industrial scenarios where decisions must be made increasingly swiftly in response to a potential snowballing of inflows of materials, products, information and services.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: written.- I voted ABSTAINED for the motion for a European Parliament resolution on the development of a sustainable European base metals industry, because that was the position of the ALDE Group and because I believe that additional clarifications and analyzes are needed to combat climate change, improve energy policyand emissions policy and transparency.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. – Today my colleagues and I voted against the report: Developing a sustainable European industry of base metals. We believe that the EU’s obsessive green policy together with a lack of regulatory coherence has created great difficulties for energy intensive industries in Europe. We believe that neither EU climate policy nor the new Energy Union proposal, with the renewed ETS system, is the solution to resolve the severe difficulties faced by the base metals industry.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the report by my colleague Édouard Martin on the development of a sustainable European base metals industry.This report tackles the challenges of the reindustrialisation of Europe and the conditions of fair competition at international level.Indeed the base metals industry is affected by dumping from third countries and would need a framework to strengthen its economic potential.For this, harmonization of energy prices and increased investment in research and development would be beneficial.This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this report, which aims to support the base metals industry, which is vulnerable to external competition.It goes in the direction of a desire to reindustrialize Europe through investments and the promotion of equal conditions of competition at the international level.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: written.- Thanks to many amendments, the report is now much more balanced and closer to reality.The measures proposed to create a level playing field for the European metals industry are quite innovative and would also help advance the COP 21 targets around the world.

name: Krišjānis KARIŅŠ
text: in writing.- In the plenary session of the European Parliament in Strasbourg, I voted in favor of the resolution supporting the development of a sustainable base metals industry in Europe.The steel sector employs a total of around 300 000 people in the European Union.A similar number of jobs are in other metals, such as aluminum and zinc.These industries are forced to compete with similar products produced in other countries where production costs are much lower.This is where the European Union's problem stands out: the high energy costs in the EU, which are more than twice as high as, for example, in the United States.In an energy-intensive sector such as the metals industry, it is very difficult to compete under such conditions.That is why the European Union is working to create an Energy Union that will ensure security and continuity of supply, competition and also lower energy prices.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ This report seeks to develop a base metals industry in Europe which is sustainable long-term and both maintains and develops this important sector. People who work in the steel industry are losing their jobs as the sector confronts its most serious peacetime crisis ever, facing a combination of rising steel prices, social dumping, an influx of cheap Chinese steel and increasing energy costs.  We will not be able to solve this problem on our own – by working together at EU level we can put pressure on the Chinese government over steel dumping and come up with Europe-wide solutions to these problems. We will continue to work on this issue and call on the UK Government to take strong and effective action at national level to support the steel industry and stop massive direct and indirect job losses in this sector.

The rapporteur points out that the problems of the EU industrial metals industry, such as low competitiveness and low investment attractiveness, are largely due to the emissions trading scheme and high European energy prices. It also calls for strong links to be established between the industrial metals recycling sector and other sectors in order to strengthen the size and resilience of the industry, especially in regions affected by industrial decline. As a member of the Hungarian delegation of the People's Party, I supported the report because I believe that there is a need to renew European industrial policy.

name: Stelios KOULOGLOU
text: in writing. ‒ This own-initiative report is dealing with the challenges that the European base metals industry is facing. Historically, the European steel sector has played a key role in the development of the overall economy. However, the sector is struggling nowadays with a significant drop in demand and a strong global competition, as the main multinational groups that own this industry are moving their investments to third world countries where the production is cheaper.  Consequently, it is important to continue modernise in order for this sector to regain its global competitiveness and meet the social and environmental challenges. The report calls for political action on this matter, it stresses the need for the base metals industries to adapt to the new climate scenarios and for the EU to equip itself with flexible and responsive trade protection measures. Therefore, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Béla KOVÁCS
text: in writing.- It is not possible to vote on a report whose points need to be split in six for a split vote, so I abstained.It arises, of course, that chaotic editing is merely recklessness, or for some purpose.I am concerned about both carbon trading and industrial storage techniques.Nature can solve carbon sequestration very well.Deforestation should be banned, afforestation and timber should be provided from forests planted for this purpose.Emissions could be drastically reduced by building carbon-free power plants, which would also make the metal industry more competitive due to cheaper electricity.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: in writing. - This report by Édouard Martin (S & amp; D - France), a parliamentarian who arrived at his seat following the betrayal of his workmates at Arcelor-Mittal, to whom he made accept the Mittal-Hollande plan to dismantle the Lorraine steel industry.
