This document is a progress report showing the reflection of the think tank on the development of the base metals sector. The industry in question is the steel industry and aluminum production. The positive points of the text are as follows: a good diagnosis on the state of the sector, strategic; environmental standards in a totally open whole pose a problem of competitiveness; purchase proposal by importers of CO2 emission allowances. Regarding the negative points of the document: the report does not take the step of protectionism, for such a strategic industry. In addition, the issue of the prohibition, under competition policy, of long-term electricity supply contracts is hardly addressed in this report, although it is central and structuring for the establishment of a real industrial policy in this sector. We are voting in favor of abstaining because the measures recommended by the report are too weak to allow the re-creation of a metals industry.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: in writing.- I abstained on this text.Of course, he is full of good feelings to save the European steel industry.But he refuses to take the path of protectionism which would nevertheless be the logical solution to the competitiveness problems of which he draws up the report.Note that this report is written by Edouard Martin, former trade unionist of Mittal who betrayed his comrades to be elected MEP PS.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: written. - I voted in favor of this initiative report, since more than 60,000 direct jobs and 100,000 indirect jobs have been lost since 2008 in a sector with more than 500 steel mills located in 23 Member States and an annual production close to the 180 million tons. The main measure requested by the report is, in the absence of a legally binding international agreement on the reduction of emissions that establishes a level playing field for the industry, to establish a carbon adjustment at the border, that is, to subject imports to the The same rules for purchasing emission rights in the carbon market applicable to European producers on the basis of the carbon content of imported metals. Thus, importers of basic metals would be obliged to declare in customs the CO2 emitted for the production of the metals sold on the European market and would have to abide by the same rules imposed on European producers in accordance with the principle of non-discrimination between products. similar to the WTO.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: written.- This report stresses the need to support the European base metals industry as it is particularly vulnerable to external competition (dumping prices) and the Union's energy and climate policy.It also addresses the problem of the acute loss of competitiveness in various basic materials industries, such as aluminum, steel and other non-ferrous materials.In this context, it is necessary for the European Union to contribute to the construction of an efficient framework for these sectors that allows them to recover their economic potential.Therefore, reindustrializing Europe through investment and promoting a level playing field at international level in the sector are the priority of this report.Since these objectives are of great importance for the economy and the progress of our nations, I am in favor of the report and I have voted so.

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: written.- The report calls on the Commission to promote the development of a functioning secondary metal market and the circular economy.The problem, however, was that the report also called for border taxes, i.e. a CO2 tax on imports.Because of the support for a non-tariff trade barrier and protectionism, I have chosen to vote against the report.

name: Petr MACH
text: in writing.- I am concerned about the harmonization of subsidies to companies to reduce carbon dioxide.This could harm some states.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: written.- The European steel sector has a historically important role in the process of European integration.The base metals sector plays a key role in the development of the economy and technology.There is a strategic need to adapt the base metal industry to new climate, economic and social changes.Setting new boundaries is the most effective structural mechanism for preventing the risk of carbon leakage and jeopardizing climate change efforts.Setting boundaries as part of climate change policy should create a level playing field and unhindered competition between producers inside and outside the EU.I supported the report by MP Edouard Martin primarily to protect the fulfillment of the goals of the fight against climate change.However, the weakening of the metal market in the world and the falling price of metals also affected Europe and resulted in the weakening of a large part of the metallurgical industry.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing.- I vote in favor of the report on the development of a sustainable European base metal industry, because it is complete and documented, as well as for the reasons I set out in detail in my speech on 24/11/2015 before the Plenary Session of the European Parliament.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report which points out that the base metals industry is facing a significant drop in demand and strong global competition, mainly from third countries without the same high standards and strict regulations as in Europe.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: in writing.- I abstained on this vote.This text was initially positive: it marks a real awareness of managers on the need to preserve this industry, since we know full well that if heavy industry is relocated, the processing industry follows it.Unfortunately, this report refuses to call for protectionism, when this type of sensitive industry would benefit from it.The text also avoids the issue of the flight of decision-making centers outside Europe (Canada, Australia ...) for certain types of industry.Finally, no mention is made of long-term electricity supply contracts, although this is a central point that structures all industrial policy.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing.- I support Parliament's motion for a resolution on the development of a sustainable European base metals industry.The report highlights the importance of the European steel and base metals industry for a whole series of supply chains, including aeronautics and automotive, highlighting the growth in European demand for aluminum in recent years, whichled to an increase in imports.It is necessary to enhance the base metals sector in order to increase its competitiveness.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: written.- The EU needs a clear policy regarding the development of a sustainable European base metals industry.It is a sector subject to a major crisis in recent years and hence the convenience of the European Parliament report, in which we advocate for solutions for this industry, without forgetting our commitments in the fight against climate change.

name: Emmanuel MAUREL
text: in writing. - The production and processing of base metals are the driving force behind the industrialization of a territory. However, Europe has lost more than 40 million tonnes of steel production capacity since 2008, ie 160,000 direct and indirect jobs. Year after year, additional factors are added to the complex equation of maintaining these industries in our territory. I therefore enthusiastically support the many innovative proposals contained in the report by my comrade Edouard Martin, in favor of which I voted. Its irreplaceable experience in this industry has enabled it to come up with shared and effective recommendations: a "carbon adjustment" at the Union's borders for metals which have not been produced with the same respect for the environment as in Europe. ; long-term electricity contracts for manufacturers in order to smooth the cost of this major input; the development of the circular economy for scrap; and above all, the encouragement of new modes of governance that encourage reinvestment in the productive tool, such as public participation. Finally, I welcome his clear opposition to granting market economy status to China, which would constitute a real threat to our industries and our jobs.

name: Georg MAYER
text: written.- A good balanced report with some innovative measures to level the playing field for the European metal industry.I therefore agree with this report.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report to support the base metal industry, which is particularly vulnerable to outside competition and challenges.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: in writing. - This report written by a Social Democrat, formerly a trade unionist in the steel industry, explains the difficulties of the European base metals industry by the "increase in taxes, levies and costs linked to" energy networks. It starts off badly. And although the competition and dumping practiced by third countries is denounced, the report underlines "the importance of avoiding any protectionist measure". The solutions advocated by the report are based on the "emission rights allocation system", ie the carbon market. For my part, I do not believe that any solution can come from the market. The report even envisages allowing the steel sector "to benefit from completely free allowances in sectors which risk losing their international competitiveness due to high carbon costs". That is to say the right to pollute for free! I am voting against this iniquitous text which disregards the interests of European workers and which clearly goes against the environmental objectives declared by the European Union at COP21. The text is so odious that its author will undoubtedly withdraw his signature.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing.- (PT) I voted in favor of the resolution on the development of a sustainable European base metal industry.The European steel industry saw a decrease of 40 million tonnes in 2014 compared to 2007. The EU cannot and should not lose the specialized industrial knowledge it has acquired over many decades.To think that the EU can be dependent on a sector that has achieved many technological achievements is very worrying.Investment in this sector must be promoted and the EU must launch a European industrial policy in the raw materials and base metals sector.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ This draft report highlights the particular vulnerabilities of the base metal industry as well as EU climate and energy policy. I supported the report as it seeks to help build an efficient framework for these sectors and introduces the carbon border adjustment which is a temporary and flexible measure of international dimensions in line with the WTO.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: in writing.- The coal and steel sectors are the linchpin of European construction.The steel industry is fundamental to our economy.This sector is experiencing significant difficulties within the European Union.Since 2008, 40 million tonnes of steel production capacities have been closed.Dependence on imports from third countries represents a challenge for our manufacturing industries.In addition, the international market is currently experiencing global overcapacity, mainly coming from China.Faced with the economic and ecological challenges represented by this sector, I welcome this report, which has the merit of formulating a series of proposals to strengthen the competitiveness and sustainability of the European steel sector.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: in writing. - The European steel industry has historically played a significant role in the integration process, as the production of base metals has long played a key role in economic development. The importance of the steel industry lies in its use in many sectors such as the automotive, aerospace, construction and other industries. The current problem has been a significant reduction in demand, as well as global competition, where Europe is losing its competitiveness vis-à-vis third countries, mainly due to high prices and high standards. I am watching with concern the outflow of investment to other countries and, above all, I am concerned about the gradual closure of European metal production and processing companies, which is resulting in the gradual deindustrialisation of Europe. With regard to new measures introduced or under preparation in the field of climate change and environmental protection and in connection with the transition to low-carbon technologies, the modernization of the sector needs to be smooth, taking into account the specificities of the sector but also regions closely linked to steel production. this is often a significant source of employment.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of the report of Edouard Martin on developing a sustainable European industry of base metals, with some reservations on the free allocation of carbon leakage. Whilst I strongly support the European base metals industry, I also think that before comparing the impact of the EU ETS (and other environment measures) on the European steel industry, first we need to address other factors, such as economic, social, labour costs, demand, lack of innovation, lack of proactive action/investment by the sector, etc. Free allocation rules, in particular to address concerns such as carbon leakage, should not be detrimental to the availability of auctioning rights and should be based on clear, objective, quantitative criteria, targeted only if carbon leakage is a proven reality. The Commission should first undertake regular analyses before proposing any actions in that particular area. Furthermore, an urgent in-depth review of existing measures together with the repercussions of any additional measures has to be swiftly as well as carefully undertaken.

name: Angelika MLINAR
text: written. - I spoke out today against the report on the development of a sustainable European industry for base metals, for which I was the shadow rapporteur of my group. Although I believe that European industry - especially the steel industry - is in a serious crisis and that reforms and support are urgently needed at European level, the report contains many dubious claims. The most problematic here is the demand for a CO2 border tax for products that are imported into Europe from abroad. Apart from the fact that this is a legally and economically highly complex issue, the compatibility of which with current WTO law is extremely questionable, it does not represent the best solution to the problems of European industry. Instead of calling for a new, hardly feasible system, we should concentrate on the upcoming ETS reform and create a business and industry-friendly system that can cut costs for companies without endangering our climate targets.

name: Sorin MOISĂ
text: in writing. ‒ Once the backbone of European industry, steel and aluminium plants are now being closed down all over the continent. Rising energy prices, stiff and sometimes unfair global competition or excessive regulatory burdens have all contributed to a decrease in the competitiveness of the European base-metals industries in general. The Parliament’s report cautions against the risk of a further escalation of this situation in terms of job losses or the indirect negative impacts on high added-value economic sectors such as the automotive industries. It is a problem that needs urgent solutions and as a result this initiative received my full support.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: in writing. - The report of the Committee on Industry draws attention to the problems of the production and trade of industrial metals. Relatively high energy prices and the cost of CO2 emissions severely limit the competitiveness of the European industrial metals industry on the global market, and this competitiveness is not improving for the very few investments in the European industrial metals industry for the same reasons. The report cites the steel and aluminum industries as two significant examples of difficulties in professions that should be involved in their energy renewal and environmental modernization in parallel. This, in turn, would require an investment policy that few of them have the resources for today. He considers the reuse of industrial metals and the development of a circular economy to be absolutely vital, but points out that recycling alone will not be able to meet the future demand of Europe, which has embarked on an energy transition. To achieve the same built-in performance, wind and solar power plants consume 90 times more aluminum, 50 times more iron, copper and glass, and 15 times more concrete (not to mention rare and critical metals) than conventional ones currently in operation. thermal power stations (oil, natural gas or nuclear). The report seeks to address these extremely difficult problems, outlines possible solutions and recommends that Parliament, in its resolution, urge a strong increase in efforts to address these problems. I supported the report.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing.- The base metals sector is of strategic importance for the Union, but in particular for some regions.This report meets the Union's objective for the reindustrialization of the European continent by promoting investment and creating a favorable and fair international environment.This industry has to adapt to the Union's policies in terms of climate and energy, but the Union must also protect this market against dumping.The price of energy, the relocation of the industry, dumping and export subsidies, practiced by third countries, are some of the threats to this sector.I voted in favor of this document because I believe that the approach taken will have positive consequences for restoring the economic potential of this industry.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: in writing.- This text is positive because it marks an awareness within the European political class of the absolute need to preserve the base metals industry, because, when heavy industry relocates, the processing industry, ingeneral, follows her.The rejection of protectionism and the questioning of the dogma of competition policy prevents its author from having recourse to the tools essential to the protection, development and modernization of this industry.In addition, the PPE and ECR amendments in the ITRE committee have largely distorted the - imperfect - protection originally proposed by the rapporteur in the provisions relating to border adjustment.That is why I am abstaining on this report.

name: Claude MORAES
text: in writing. ‒ This report seeks to develop a base metals industry in Europe which is sustainable in the long term and both maintains and develops this important sector. People who work in the steel industry are losing their jobs, both in the UK and across the EU, as the sector confronts its most serious peacetime crisis ever, facing a combination of rising steel prices, social dumping, an influx of cheap Chinese steel and increasing energy costs. We will not be able to solve this problem on our own. By working together at EU level we can put pressure on the Chinese Government over steel dumping and come up with Europe-wide solutions to these problems. In the upcoming work on Phase IV of the ETS, Labour MEPs will work to ensure that the system of free carbon allowances addresses the issue of carbon leakage. Should this not be sufficient, the Commission should, as a last resort, examine the feasibility of a carbon border adjustment mechanism linked to the ETS. Labour MEPs will continue to work on this issue and call on the UK Government to take strong and effective action at national level to support the steel industry and stop massive direct and indirect job losses in this sector.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of this report on the development of a sustainable European base metals industry, the main objectives of which are to contribute to the reindustrialisation of Europe and to the re-establishment of fair competitive conditions at international level. It calls on the Union to take into account the vulnerability of the steel industry to the dumping practiced by third countries, in particular China, and to develop an effective framework to restore the economic potential of the sector. Among the measures recommended are the reduction and harmonization of energy prices in Europe through better integration of the internal market, the modernization of trade defense instruments against unfair practices and dumping, the prohibition of distorting practices on raw materials in regional, bilateral and multilateral free trade agreements, as well as investment in research and development so that Europe can remain a center of excellence in the production of base metals. In particular, I approved the maintenance of the state compensation system for indirect costs in the sector of high energy density industries and its harmonization at European level, with the aim of ensuring fair conditions of competition with third countries and between European producers. .

name: Luigi MORGANO
text: in writing. - Today's report addresses an absolutely central issue for the development model - economic and environmental - of Europe today and tomorrow. If Europe proceeds in the process of deindustrialisation, it will lose not only a very important economic and employment sector, but a piece of its history itself. The steel sector has been at the heart of the European integration process and still plays a key role in the development of the global economy. We are faced with a double challenge: how to keep an industrial sector, in particular the steel industry, competitive and at the same time safeguard the health of the planet. I think - and therefore I voted in favor of the text - that an excellent balance has been found, without giving in to unfair practices implemented by competition from third countries, in particular China. It is useless here to repeat the data on production overcapacity, on the conditions of Chinese workers, on the environmental conditions that allow a downward competition on prices and quality. Since 2008, the steel sector has lost tens of thousands of jobs in Europe. We need the measures taken today to support European industry, to respond effectively to the crisis in the sector and to stop the employment bleeding.

name: József NAGY
text: in writing. - The European steel industry is second in the world, producing 11% of world production. After the outbreak of the global crisis, metal prices fell by a third. For example, while iron was still selling at $ 1,000 a tonne in 2008, the price has dropped to $ 100 a tonne this summer. In addition to low demand, the EU steel industry is struggling with overproduction and low prices in China, and at home there is a problem with high energy prices and labor costs. Metals are a strategic raw material for the EU and industry is asking for direct support for technology development and would also be helped by a change in market regulation with the possibility of auctioning electricity for several years in advance. Another disadvantage for EU industry is the effort to reduce CO2 emissions compared to countries that do not push for technology modernization. That is why steelmakers are calling for an emission duty to be paid on metal imports into the EU. Strategically, in addition to steel, we must support the recycling of precious and strategic metals, for which the EU has very limited natural resources.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this report that will pursue the coordination of the carbon emissions allowance, reuse procedures of base metals, forward-looking investments with impact on health and safety, as well as the development of a circular economy, factors that are absolutely vital for Europe’s economy.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: written.- I would have voted in favor of the report because it does indeed contain a number of points which could actually help the base metals industry in all Member States to become more competitive while at the same time reducing the environmental impact.

name: Urmas PAET
text: in writing.- I abstained.The EU needs to have flexible and responsive trade defense instruments to cope with the new global industrial scenarios, where decisions need to be taken more quickly to respond to rapid changes in the markets for materials, products, information and services.However, this draft does not ensure sufficient flexibility and competitiveness.

name: Gilles PARGNEAUX
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this report written by my colleague Edouard Martin because I support the development of a sustainable and powerful European base metals industry, in particular through the implementation of innovative strategies such as a CO2 adjustment at the borders ofEurope in order to prevent unfair competition from those who produce in territories with lower standards than ours, but sell in Europe;in order to fight, too, against climate change.

name: Margot PARKER
text: in writing. ‒ Today UKIP voted against the report entitled Developing a Sustainable European Industry of Base Metals. We believe that EU’s obsessive green policy together with a lack of regulatory coherence has created great difficulties for energy-intensive industries in Europe. We believe that neither EU climate policy nor the new Energy Union proposal, with the renewed ETS system, is the solution to resolve the severe difficulties faced by the base metals industry.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: in writing. – A key goal of the Europe 2020 strategy has been to increase the contribution made by manufacturing to European GDP from 16% to 20% by 2020. The reindustrialisation of the European economy, if it is to be a globally competitive reality, faces many challenges. The EU base metals industry plays an important role for the reindustrialisation of Europe. The EU needs to help build an efficient frame for the industry of base materials in order to re-establish their economic potential. Moreover, base metals have one of the largest shares of Bulgaria’s overall exports. That is why I am supporting the report and I vote in favour.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: written. - The base metals industry in the European Union is experiencing a severe crisis and is facing a number of challenges that it is difficult to deal with on its own. The metal industry is the main source of raw materials for many other industries, especially new, technologically advanced industries. The base metal industry in the European Union is adversely affected by the fall in demand on the world market, as well as unfair competition from third countries that sell their products on the market at dumped prices, thus destroying competition. It is these movements that we are witnessing in the worst possible way, sympathizing with the workers at the Sisak ironworks. The business move of ABS entering the ironworks, which was accompanied by investments of 25 million euros, and which, after years of domestic dubiousness, more or less gave hope for a better tomorrow, unfortunately ran aground on the cliff of the relentless global market. That is why I supported this report and demand that the manufacturing industry be protected at European level, that appropriate anti-dumping measures be applied and that special measures within European energy and climate policy address the problem of carbon leakage and thus support the base metals industry. I also ask the authorities in Croatia to use the opportunities provided by the mobilization of the European Globalization Adjustment Fund or to make sure that these opportunities are used because the case of the ironworks in Sisak is a prime example of the consequences of globalization in Croatia.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: in writing.- This text is positive because it marks an awareness within the European political class of the absolute need to preserve the base metals industry, because, when heavy industry relocates, the processing industry, ingeneral, follows her.The rejection of protectionism and the questioning of the dogma of competition policy prevents its author from having recourse to the tools essential to the protection, development and modernization of this industry.In addition, the PPE and ECR amendments in the ITRE committee have largely distorted the - imperfect - protection originally proposed by the rapporteur in the provisions relating to border adjustment.That is why I am abstaining on this report.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: written. - I support the Report on the Development of a Sustainable European Base Metals Industry by MP Edouard Martin. Due to the fact that the base metals sector plays a key role in the development of the overall economy, and in the steel industry sector alone, whose production capacity has been reduced by more than 40 million tonnes since 2008, more than 60,000 jobs have been directly lost and indirectly more than 100,000. This shows that Europe is rapidly decentralizing in this sector. The problem is that this is not due to falling European demand, but to rising energy prices and carbon costs in several Member States and dumping from third countries, which means that Europe is rapidly deindustrialising in this sector. It is also a great challenge for Europe to become competitive again, and at the same time to remain a world role model in terms of social and environmental responsibility in its operations. The EU must therefore stimulate employment growth through innovation in production at all stages of the industry's business cycle. I believe that the EU's path towards stronger competitiveness of the base metals industry is in an active policy of innovation and new production processes.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: written.- I support reforms that seek to ensure the development of a sustainable European base metal industry that is both compliant with environmental standards on the one hand and highly competitive and with quality jobs on the other.Problems with demand and increased imports in the steel and aluminum industry sectors pose a threat that could have a negative impact on other sectors as well, and action is therefore needed to prevent this.Positive developments include strengthening trade defense instruments, involving the metal industry in the concept of a circular economy, transparency in the field of industrial risks, and harmonizing the compensation of indirect costs.I am sorry that these reforms did not include provisions on the rights of employees in industry, and I hope that this omission will be rectified soon.

name: Miroslav POCHE
text: in writing. - We are currently in a situation where we are witnessing a loss of capacity and jobs in the European steel industry, which may lead to a loss of industrial know-how. Although we are witnessing the development of base metal reuse and the development of the circular economy, recycling alone cannot suffice, and therefore industrial policy must have the tools and means to make the transition to low-carbon production technologies. In addition, I believe that it is now necessary for the European base metals industry to adapt to the new climatic, economic and social situation and to become a model for the efficiency and effectiveness of energy and raw material consumption. This should be done through fair regulatory measures at the borders so that we can know the carbon content of each product. The most important thing for me as a Social Democrat is for the European base metals industry to lead by example in the field of the environment and to minimize the impact on both workers and the people living in the area.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing.- In recent years, the base metals sector has been heavily penalized in Europe due to various factors that have weakened its competitiveness both in the domestic and international markets.In particular, the high direct and indirect costs of energy, high environmental standards, a policy of reducing CO2 emissions and poorly regulated foreign competition, have meant that many plants have begun to close.The fear that China could receive recognition as a market economy has further raised the alarm level from European manufacturers.My vote is in favor of this report because it elaborates some solutions for the development of a sustainable European base metals industry, such as the harmonization of indirect cost offsets, an acceleration of the draft reform of trade defense instruments and amore accessible energy market.

name: Franck PROUST
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of this own-initiative report which reflects on the means of contributing to the reindustrialisation of Europe and of promoting fair competition conditions at international level. China is sinking whole swathes of our economy into an even deeper crisis. The steel sector, for example, is experiencing the most serious crisis in its history in peacetime. However, I ask the question whether, in commercial matters, we are still in peacetime? The security of our jobs and our know-how are at stake because China alone produces more steel than world demand! I am fighting to improve our instruments of trade defense. By accepting the fact that some are fighting us, we will be able to defend ourselves better. What I regret, however, is to see that the rapporteur, because he benefited from his quarter of an hour of glory, used this report to regain the favors of his trade unionist comrades in front of cameras certainly moved by this reunion . I would have liked the cameras to come sooner to the front lines of this sector which needs economic and political support quickly.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ Today UKIP voted against the report entitled Developing a Sustainable European Industry of Base Metals. We believe that the EU’s obsessive green policy together with a lack of regulatory coherence has created great difficulties for energy-intensive industries in Europe. We believe that neither EU climate policy nor the new Energy Union proposal, with the renewed ETS system, is the solution to resolve the severe difficulties faced by the base metals industry.

name: Dominique RIQUET
text: in writing. - Since 2008, the European base metals sector has been hit hard by the effects of the economic crisis with the contraction in demand on the one hand, but also unfair competition from the rest of the world on the other. An unsuitable social and fiscal environment in the Member States in the face of globalization has resulted in the loss of more than 60,000 direct jobs and 100,000 indirect jobs for our industries. This report aims to support and restore the competitiveness of the European Union as well as to protect it against unfair competition in this sector. In order to remedy the distortion of competition generated by a unilateral application of the Emissions Trading System (ETS), the report proposes the implementation of carbon adjustment measures at the borders of the Union, in order to prevent the Union's legitimate environmental ambitions from becoming a burden on our industry. Revenues from carbon emission rights auctions could, according to the report, also be made available to fuel environmental preservation mechanisms such as the Green Fund, according to the polluter pays principle. For all these reasons, I decided in favor of this text.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: in writing. - Respecting sound competition rules is essential to ensure economic recovery, preserve jobs and ensure that the European steel industry remains competitive on a global scale. The device for adjusting carbon emissions at borders, which I voted for today, would allow the European Union to develop a quality climate policy, while preserving its competitiveness, by putting it on an equal footing. with countries that do not respect social and environmental standards. If the recent climate conference, COP21, made it possible to reach an ambitious agreement to reduce greenhouse gas emissions in the future, we must also take into account the time required for the application of these measures. Pending effective efforts, the conditions of equal competition are not met and the risk of carbon leakage from the European Union remains and weighs on our industry. It is therefore necessary to place European industries on an equal footing with their external competitors. I am also pleading for the sums to be obtained through the border adjustment system to be used, at least in part, for environmental initiatives and the fight against climate change.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. - The metal industry is extremely important for the EU, as it is the basis of many other industries that have a strong impact on the European economy, such as the automobile, aerospace, energy production or even construction. To ensure the competitiveness of the base metals industry, the report suggests that the EU should base itself on redefining its current emissions trading system. The energy-intensive industry is expected to reduce CO2 emissions, allowing the EU to guarantee industrial competitiveness and, at the same time, meet the objectives it has outlined. Supporting the base metal industry - which is so special and vulnerable to the EU's external competitiveness and energy and environment policy - should have as its ultimate aim the fight against the loss of increasing competitiveness of various basic materials industries such as steel or aluminum . The EU needs to help to (re) constitute an efficient structure for these sectors, in order to strengthen the economic potential and, above all, to reindustrialize Europe through innovation and promoting equal treatment of the sector's conditions at international level. For these reasons and because I believe it is essential to support the European base metals industry, I voted in favor of this report.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: in writing. - I supported this report which underlines the need to support the base metals industry. Indeed, it is particularly vulnerable to international competition and many industries producing base metals have lost their competitiveness (these are notably the steel, aluminum and non-ferrous metals sectors. ). It is therefore necessary and urgent to ensure that Europe is reindustrialised through investment and to promote suitable conditions of competition at international level in this sector. I also voted in favor of the implementation of a carbon adjustment at the borders and the reform of the emissions trading system, but it is important to ensure that these measures are not too onerous for our businesses and industries and that we can defend ourselves against any form of dumping. Finally, I would like to stress that this report recalls the need to modernize our trade defense instruments in order to protect our businesses and be able to fight against all forms of unfair competition and dumping; base metals suffer too often.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the report on the development of a European base metals industry as it emphasizes the importance of the European industry, the very serious risks it is running and the need to take urgent measures atEuropean to save a sector of excellence deeply in crisis due to foreign competition that is not subject to the same environmental and social standards.The main objectives of the report are the harmonization of the compensation of indirect costs, the acceleration of the reform project of the trade defense instruments and a more accessible energy market.Furthermore, in order to put European and foreign producers on an equal footing in terms of emissions, the European Parliament proposes the study of a "border adjustment" mechanism which obliges foreign producers to purchase CO2 quotas based on the emissions produced.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: written.- We have abstained because we consider that the basic metals industry sector is a strategic sector in the economy, and the document contains positive aspects in terms of social, labor and defense of workers issues, and contains general lines to supportthis industry and that there is a transformation of it in environmental matters.But, on the other hand, we are radically opposed to their positioning and their tacit tolerance towards the Emissions Trading Scheme (ETS) and the TTIP.The environmental guidelines set out in the document seem totally insufficient to us.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: written. - I voted in favor of this report as it represents significant political support for the steel industry sector in Europe. The sector faces a serious crisis due to the full commercial opening of the borders, which prevents the maintenance of this essential industry for quality employment in Europe. The report includes certain points that we do not accept, such as the harmonization of state aid to the sector or the energy union, but at the same time it includes fundamental measures such as the adjustment of coal at the border, the unequivocal commitment to recycling and the circular economy for the recovery of the sector, the development of public investment, the promotion and maintenance of social dialogue and the promotion of regional economic cohesion. Due to all these essential points to overcome the crisis that the sector is currently facing, an indispensable industry in our commitment to a new production model that allows generating quality employment, I have decided to vote in favor of this report.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this proposal because I do not believe that the EU mechanisms are the best solution for resolving many of the energy issues we have.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ The base metals that this report deals with are aluminium, copper, steel and zinc, which are necessary for industrial growth across Europe. Currently, the EU is massively dependent on imports and this report seeks to develop not only a competitive base-metals industry in Europe, but a sustainable one. People who are working in the steel industry – or related industries – in the UK and elsewhere in the EU are losing their jobs. I will strongly defend the jobs which are affected by the collapse of the steel industry in the West Midlands and I will work together at EU level so that we can put pressure on the Chinese Government over the dumping of steel. We need a European solution to these problems and if the existing system of free allowances of carbon emissions fails to address the issue of carbon leakage, we will need to examine the option of carbon border adjustment mechanisms linked to the ETS as a last resort. I will continue to work on this issue and call on the UK Government to take strong and effective action to support the steel industry and combat job losses in the sector as well as related sectors.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: in writing. - I supported the motion for a resolution on the development of a sustainable European base metals industry, as this is an important sector for economic growth and employment throughout the EU. In recent times, the base metals industry has faced significant declines in demand as well as strong global competition, especially from third countries where standards and regulations are not as high as in Europe. Given that energy prices in Europe are higher than in many other economies, in particular due to the lack of integration of the energy market, rising days, charges and network costs significantly limit the competitiveness of the European base metals industry on the world market. Therefore, the fight against climate change and high energy prices is urgent for the development of a sustainable European base metals industry. The Commission must change the system for allocating emission allowances so that it is based on the amount of tonnes of metal produced and not on the greenhouse gases produced by the installation. I consider the issues of energy contracts and supplies to be very important, which vary considerably from one EU Member State to another.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: in writing. - The base metals sector, which has played an important historical role in European integration, is the basis for creating European industrial added value and plays a key role in the development of the whole economy. Nevertheless, this industry is facing serious problems. In the first place are declining demand and strong global competition. This competition comes mainly from third countries, where there are no the same high standards and strict rules as in Europe. Investments in this sector are also moving in large numbers to third countries, mainly due to relatively high energy prices and the cost of reducing emissions. The report analyzes the current state of the base metals sector and contains proposals for measures to help develop the industry. Some positive measures can be found in the report, such as the proposal to adjust the CO2 limit and the proposal to partially redistribute auction revenues to environmental initiatives and measures to combat climate change. However, the report also calls for investment in CO2 capture and storage and CO2 capture and use, and for the allocation of indirect carbon offsets at EU level. Although I encourage the development of a sustainable European base metal industry, I do not agree with some of the proposals in the report, so I abstained from voting on the report.

name: Maria SPYRAKI
text: PPE), in writing. - I voted in favor of the report on the development of a sustainable European base metal industry, including the section on the mechanism for carbon cross-border adjustment in imports and exports. The implementation of the border adjustment mechanism will ensure equal competition between European and non-European producers, both at internal market level and at export level. By voting in favor of today's report and by implementing the border adjustment mechanism, we support the jobs created by steel in Europe, in Greece, in Thessaloniki, in Magnesia, in Eleusis. Total steel production in Greece in 2012 fell compared to 2007 by 58%. Compared to pre-crisis levels in 2007, domestic demand fell 82%. We are currently at the level of 1962. Greek exports compared to 2011 have decreased by about 60%, at a time when the debt obligations of the three largest steel companies in Greece, exceed one billion euros. For the workers in this crucial sector of Greek industry the situation is dramatic. It is necessary to exhaust all possibilities for reducing energy costs and for defending equal competition between European and foreign steel companies.

name: Joachim STARBATTY
text: written.- The report calls on the Commission to promote the development of a functioning secondary metal market and the circular economy.The problem, however, was that the report also called for border taxes, i.e. a CO2 tax on imports.Because of the support for a non-tariff trade barrier and protectionism, I have chosen to vote against the report.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: in writing.- In the context of the development of a sustainable European base metals industry, it is necessary to establish workable measures that will guarantee the sector's growth and competitiveness.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: written. - I support this report because the European metallurgical industry forms the basis for the creation of European added value in industry, as well as European value chains. The European steel sector has played a historically important role in the process of European integration. The base metals sector plays a key role in the development of the overall economy and in the development of technology and in terms of overcoming supply bottlenecks. The steel industry sector, whose production capacity has been reduced by more than 40 million tonnes since 2008 and which has directly lost more than 60,000 jobs and indirectly more than 100,000, is experiencing the worst peacetime crisis in its history, increasing dependence. industrial production sector on imports from third countries and there is a loss of experience and knowledge in the industry which has a direct impact on millions of jobs. European metal electrolysis plants such as aluminum, copper and magnesium are closing one after another, indicating that Europe is rapidly deindustrialising in this sector, not due to falling European demand, but mainly due to rising and growing volatility in electricity prices in several countries Member States and dumping from third countries.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: written. - The European steel sector has played a historically important role in the process of European integration and forms the basis for the creation of European added value in the economy. However, the base metals industry in the world is facing a significant drop in demand and strong competition, especially from third countries that do not have the high standards and strict regulations in force in Europe. It is estimated that production capacity has been reduced by more than 40 million tonnes since 2008, directly losing more than 60,000 jobs and indirectly more than 100,000. Consequently, a package of measures for the Energy Union has been defined. This package of measures would make it possible to create a secure, sustainable and competitive energy market with affordable prices, which would increase the competitiveness of the European economy on a global scale and reduce and harmonize energy prices in Europe and among Member States. I support the motion for a resolution because I believe that the development of the European base metals industry is extremely important for the development of the economy, and thus for the preservation of jobs. In this way, the industry would respond to the social and environmental challenges it faces and must overcome.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: in writing.- I voted against the proposal.The current EU climate policy is counterproductive and only technical change, without less stringent overall climate goals, will not solve the problems of EU industry.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the report on the development of a sustainable European base metal industry.In recent years, the European steel sector has faced the worst crisis in its history, with more than 40 million tonnes of steel production capacity closed and more than 160,000 jobs lost since 2008, increasing the dependence of industrial processing sectors on imports fromthird countries and are losing industrial skills, which has a direct impact on millions of jobs.I support the report, which emphasizes the importance of base metals for many industries, and in particular for the automotive, aerospace, energy, construction and packaging industries.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: GUE / NGL), in writing. - The report addresses the serious problems faced by European common metal industries due to declining demand but also high competition, due to the relocation of production of large multinational companies to third countries to not even meet the environmental rules in force. in the EU but neither are collective agreements. We voted in favor of this report as it contains a number of positive references such as the need to support the European metals industry, especially in relation to workers' rights, the need to create new quality jobs combined with the need to protect human health and the environment, as well as the need to put barriers to the action and profitability of large multinational companies.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI), in writing.- This report fails to address the evolving and major problem of European base metal industries, which is nothing more than China's unfair competition.

name: József SZÁJER
text: in writing. - The industrial metals industry in Europe (various steels, non-ferrous metals, metal alloys, rare earths) is facing a number of recent challenges: on the one hand, the crisis has led to a sharp drop in demand and a significant increase in global competition from adhere to similar high standards. The rapporteur points out that the problems of the EU industrial metals industry, such as low competitiveness and low investment attractiveness, are largely due to the emissions trading scheme and high European energy prices. Therefore, the transformation of the current emissions trading scheme is one of the most pressing issues to ensure the competitiveness of the industrial metals industry. European trade defense measures for industrial metals are characterized by too late a remedy rather than a prevention. European trade policy cannot ignore the fact that these third countries take advantage of their comparative advantage in terms of access to raw materials, often receive state aid and sometimes sell their products at prices below production costs. With regard to the circular economy, I agree with the report's objective, which is to rapidly increase the recycling of rare earths and critical metals used in the Union. It also calls for strong links to be established between the industrial metals recycling sector and other sectors in order to strengthen the size and resilience of the industry, especially in regions affected by industrial decline. In the detailed vote, I supported the use of cross-border carbon offsets as an option.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of this report because I believe that the European steel industry has played an important historical role in the process of European integration and that it is the basis for industrial added value and value chains in Europe. The report addresses the development of an important industry that plays a key role in the development of the economy as a whole, both in terms of technology and supply bottlenecks. The report describes that steel production capacity has fallen by more than 40 million tonnes since 2008, with 60,000 jobs lost in the sector directly and 100,000 indirectly, experiencing the worst peacetime crisis in the steel industry’s history. All this is happening in an environment where we have to face strong global competition, but we cannot hold high European standards to account. The industrial metals industry and its safe production have a significant impact on European automotive, aerospace, energy production, construction or packaging. That is why, in addition to the often mentioned energy dependency, we must strive to avoid dependence on industrial metals. In my opinion, as with all developments, the conscious development of the industrial metals industry can only be achieved through research and innovation and the wider use of renewable energy. In all these developments, we must also keep in mind the fight against climate change.

name: Dario TAMBURRANO
text: in writing. - We voted in favor of the Martin report on the development of a sustainable European common metals industry (such as steel, aluminum, copper, brass, nickel and lead). The industrial importance of these metals is evident and the environmental and energy impact is also significant. We voted in favor because among the parties that passed the original text there is a request to make the compensation policy for indirect emissions fair between Member States and the introduction of an innovative instrument, the adjustment of the carbon content to the border, to make competition with countries that are not part of the union and therefore not subject to the ETS system more just and equitable. In addition, energy-intensive industries are asked to continuously engage in optimizing recycling measures and reducing CO2 emissions to ensure industrial competitiveness in the future and meet the binding reduction targets set by the EU.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: signed up. - The European steel and metallurgical industry is in a difficult situation due to the significant drop in demand in recent years, which affects both the labor force in the field and other economic sectors, such as machine building, construction low-carbon buildings and technologies. The energy and environmental modernization of these sectors requires an investment policy that few of these companies can afford today. The creation of the carbon market in 2005 was in line with the EU's strategy to combat climate change, but created additional burdens for Member States' economies. Border adjustment can be the solution to avoid the abandonment of the fight against climate change by European sectors at risk of carbon leakage, by promoting fair competition between European and non-European producers. This measure can also be applied temporarily and flexibly, and carbon leakages can be prevented by taking into account the whole sector. Border adjustment is the basis of a base metal economy in which the reduction of pollutant emissions is linked to investments in reducing these emissions, which are thus profitable. This document can be an important step forward.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: in writing. - I voted for the text. In fact, the haemorrhaging of capacities and jobs experienced by the European steel industry is the result of the fall in demand which, in 2014, remained 40 megatonnes below that of 2007. This capacity adjustment was reduced. '' such a magnitude that any recovery in European demand will result in the birth of a historic trade deficit in Europe generating dependence and losses of industrial know-how which would not fail to have repercussions on downstream sectors such as automotive, construction and low carbon technologies. The closures in European aluminum, on the other hand, are taking place against a backdrop of growing European demand for aluminum in recent years; this resulted in increases in imports. Thus, steels and aluminum are two significant examples of the difficulties encountered in these professions which must at the same time pursue their energy and environmental modernization, which would require an investment policy which few of them can afford today.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ Europe needs a strong industry if it wants to definitely exit the crisis and find again sustainable growth. This is why I voted in favour of this report. Indeed, the general aim of the Report on the development of a sustainable European base metals industry is to identify the new conditions under which base metal industries, such as steel, aluminium and non-ferrous metals, can prosper in Europe. I recognise the loss of competitiveness of several basic materials industries and the crisis that needs to be addressed to re-establish the EU’s economic potential. The report however calls for very specific and detailed changes on ETS that will pre-empt the upcoming legislative discussions and is also very prescriptive. Therefore I decided to vote against those parts of the report which were too prescriptive on ETS or on boarder adjustment but I voted in favour of the report as such.

name: Isabelle THOMAS
text: in writing. - The Martin report aims to save the European steel industry in the best ecological conditions. We need industry in Europe, we must stop being the idiots of globalization, by taking control of our industrial policy to stop the haemorrhaging of relocations. This text marks a real inflection of the European Union to substitute fair trade for blind free trade. We advocate an adjustment at borders to penalize products manufactured without respecting the environment as well as a hardening of our trade defense mechanisms. The text recommends a modification of the reading of the competition code allowing to take into account the dumping carried out by certain emerging countries, in particular China to which we must refuse the status of market economy. Marked on the left and concerned about the sustainability of our productions, the report drafted by my colleague Édouard Martin also proposes to fully include employees in decision-making and to develop the circular economy of heavy metals. Parliament has taken a strong position, for the Commission to come back quickly with a credible legislative proposal.

name: Patrizia TOIA
text: in writing. - The crisis in the steel industry we are witnessing requires concrete responses and firm commitment on the part of all institutions. The positive vote on the Martin report confirms the European Parliament's willingness to continue to keep the attention of all legislative bodies high on an issue that has a direct impact on the lives of many of our fellow citizens who have lost their jobs. Steel and aluminum are two significant examples of the difficulties encountered by certain sectors that face competition from many third countries, with abundant raw materials and lower energy prices, and which require the utmost effort to create modern plants. and with low environmental impact. It is up to the European and national institutions to promote an industrial policy equipped with the tools and means to travel a path towards a low-carbon economy. However, environmental protection must go hand in hand with far-sighted and fair energy and trade policies, which make it possible to protect the European industrial apparatus and bring it back to the center of the world scene.

name: László TŐKÉS
text: in writing. - The industrial metals industry in Europe is facing a number of recent challenges: as a result of the crisis, demand has fallen sharply and global competition has intensified significantly, from countries that do not have to meet high standards like Europe. The rapporteur points out that the problems of the EU industrial metals industry, such as low competitiveness and low investment attractiveness, are largely due to the emissions trading scheme and high European energy prices. Therefore, the transformation of the current emissions trading scheme is one of the most pressing issues to ensure the competitiveness of the industrial metals industry. European trade defense measures for industrial metals are characterized by too late a remedy rather than a prevention. European trade policy cannot ignore the fact that these third countries take advantage of their comparative advantage in terms of access to raw materials, often receive state aid and sometimes sell their products at prices below production costs. With regard to the circular economy, I agree with the report's objective, which is to rapidly increase the recycling of rare earths and critical metals used in the Union. It also calls for strong links to be established between the industrial metals recycling sector and other sectors in order to strengthen the size and resilience of the industry, especially in regions affected by industrial decline. In the detailed vote, I supported the use of cross-border carbon offsets as an option.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: written.- The focus of the report is on the situation in the European base metals industry, and as a basic tool in this fight, the rapporteur emphasizes the protectionist mechanism of border adjustment of carbon.The text adopted in the report proposes that such a mechanism be established in the event that no agreement is reached at COP 21.Although I agree in principle with the statement that the issue of the sustainability of the base metals industry is a relevant issue and a problem that needs to be addressed, I do not agree that the same can be effectively achieved by the measures proposed in the report, and I therefore voted against.

name: Romana TOMC
text: in writing.- I supported the report on the development of a sustainable European base metal industry because I believe that the base metal industry is an important element in the economy and we must not allow them to become dependent on others in this area.At present, European industry is difficult to compete with imports from China, and dependence on foreign markets would have a significant impact on other sectors, such as the automotive, low-carbon and construction sectors.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: written.- We have abstained because we consider that the basic metals industry sector is a strategic sector in the economy, and the document contains positive aspects in terms of social, labor and defense of workers issues, and contains general lines to supportthis industry and that there is a transformation of it in environmental matters.But, on the other hand, we are radically opposed to their positioning and their tacit tolerance towards the Emissions Trading Scheme (ETS) and the TTIP.The environmental guidelines set out in the document seem totally insufficient to us.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. ‒ Globalisation leads the EU to adapt faster and more agile ways to constant change, and in this case, the metal industry. I support this motion to help European companies that are competing with the ones in developing countries, although the preamble is clear, there is still much work to do within the EU, which should bring some solutions more quickly and efficiently.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: in writing.- This text is positive because it marks an awareness within the European political class of the absolute need to preserve this industry because, when heavy industry relocates, the processing industry, in general, follows it.The rejection of protectionism and the questioning of the dogma of competition policy prevents its author from having recourse to the tools essential to the protection, development and modernization of this industry.I therefore choose ABSTENTION.

name: Mihai ŢURCANU
text: signed up. - I voted in favor of the report on the development of a sustainable European base metals industry, as the European base metals industry is currently facing a significant drop in demand as well as strong global competition, mainly from the part of third countries that do not apply the same high standards and strict regulations as in Europe. In this regard, the European base metals industry needs to regain global competitiveness, and a first step in this direction would be to create a common energy market, as higher energy prices in Europe significantly limit the competitiveness of this industry. . In addition, there are many sectors that depend on this industry, such as the automotive, aeronautics, energy production, construction and packaging sectors. Thus, the EU needs to improve its competitiveness and maintain its independence with regard to base metals, so as not to adversely affect the above-mentioned sectors. In this regard, I believe that the development of new energy-efficient products and new production processes is needed for the EU to withstand fierce global competition.

name: István UJHELYI
text: in writing.- The European steel industry has suffered huge losses in terms of both capacity and jobs due to a fall in demand, which fell by 40 megatonnes in 2014 compared to 2007 levels.The capacity gap has reached such proportions that any re-strengthening of European demand will create unprecedented deficits and dependence in the history of European trade, and the devastating effects of losses of industrial know-how will certainly spill over to the emerging sectors, including the automotive,and low carbon technologies.I voted in favor of the report.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: written.- We have abstained because we consider that the basic metals industry sector is a strategic sector in the economy, and the document contains positive aspects in terms of social, labor and defense of workers issues, and contains general lines to supportthis industry and that there is a transformation of it in environmental matters.But, on the other hand, we are radically opposed to their positioning and their tacit tolerance towards the Emissions Trading Scheme (ETS) and the TTIP.The environmental guidelines set out in the document seem totally insufficient to us.

name: Vladimir URUTCHEV
text: In written form. - Mr President, colleagues, we voted today on the resolution on the development of a sustainable European base metals industry, in which the steel sector is both the largest producer of such metals and most exposed to the risks of losing competitiveness and relocation. of production in third countries. The purpose of the resolution was to protect this industry with the permitted and acceptable instruments in the EU to ensure a smooth transition without cataclysms to a sustainable, environmentally friendly and cost-effective industry, with a competitive product on the world market and with technological innovation in line with the objectives and the challenges of the 21st century. I am disappointed that Parliament has not adequately supported the use of the border adjustment mechanism, which could, as a temporary and targeted measure, protect industry from external competitors who do not comply with the EU's high environmental requirements. The Paris Agreement on Climate Change does not automatically give reason to believe that all the world's metal producers will operate from tomorrow with the same environmental standards. On the contrary, we have yet to see how serious the commitments of the parties are and how long the ratification of the agreement will take. That is why we should have supported all protection mechanisms when they do not contradict our own legislation and WTO rules.

name: Viktor USPASKICH
text: in writing.- The European base metals industry is competing over time to restore global competitiveness and investment opportunities in Europe, thus addressing the sector's social and environmental challenges, which need to be addressed so that the industry remains a global leader in corporate social responsibility and accountability.for environmental damage.Global surpluses, unfair subsidies and dumping from third countries put additional pressure on the European base metals market, and production innovation has a positive impact on employment growth at all stages of the industrial business cycle.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution because I agree it is important to invest in future jobs, preferably in green jobs, and some sectors need special investment in order to do so. Industrial policy must comprise the tools and resources needed to make low-carbon transition a reality, and that can only be done through strategic management of base metals industries and by ensuring that the right tools and resources are available to cope with the increase in carbon prices being called for by all the international institutions involved in combating climate change. In this resolution we addressed the topics that highlight the importance of base metals for the European industry; the overriding need to act on climate change and high energy prices; carbon border adjustment – a temporary and flexible measure of international dimension in line with the WT, compensation for indirect emissions, the support for investing in the production of low carbon metal, financial accounting and transparency, the issue of electricity supply contracts, the transfer of skills, the supply of raw materials and European trade protection measures in respect of base metals.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: written.- The report talks about the need to support a European base metals industry that is more sustainable.It is necessary to help a sector that has to carry out important changes derived from our policy and our commitment to a stronger European energy policy and a more sustainable economy that fights against climate change.I therefore consider it necessary to vote in favor of this report.

name: Derek VAUGHAN
text: in writing. ‒ This report deals with base metals, steel, aluminium, zinc and copper, which are necessary for industrial growth across Europe. People who work in the steel industry are losing their jobs, both in the UK and across the EU, as the sector confronts its most serious peacetime crisis ever, facing a combination of an influx of cheap steel and increasing energy costs. By working together at an EU level we can put pressure on the Chinese government over steel dumping, and come up with Europe-wide solutions to these problems. It is also vital that the UK Government matches the action called for by Labour MEPs in the coming months.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: written.- The content of this report has been denatured.Discussions are held here that in themselves have little to do with the development of a sustainable European base metal industry.I have therefore decided to abstain from the vote regardless of the content of the report.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: in writing. - This own-initiative report concerns the European base metals industry, a sector which is experiencing serious difficulties due to competition between industrial groups but above all to the collapse of world demand. Multinationals in the sector have taken advantage of this increased competition to relocate production to countries with low social and environmental standards. The number of jobs lost in Europe since 2008 is estimated at 100,000, resulting in a loss of industrial know-how, which in the short term generates dependency and weakening, including other related sectors. This report calls for an ambitious industrial policy. In particular, it proposes the creation of local information and consultation committees for the prevention of industrial risks involving employees. Above all, he urges the Commission to systematically include the ban on distorting practices on raw materials in trade agreements. Despite some ambiguities on the issue of carbon markets, I voted for this report, which was widely debated with the trade unions in the sectors concerned, even if I have no illusions about its scope other than symbolic.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. - The financialization of the economy and the respective long process of deindustrialization has an eloquent testimony in this report. The hemorrhage in terms of the capacities and jobs that the European steel industry faces is the result of the drop in demand, which in 2014 saw a decrease of 40 million tons compared to 2007. This adjustment in capacities was so significant that any recovery in European demand will result in the creation of a historic trade deficit in Europe, which, in turn, will cause dependence and loss of specialized industrial knowledge that will continue to affect the downstream sectors of the automotive, construction and low technology sectors. carbon content. Any industrial policy that is implemented and that intends to break with this situation of impoverishment and dependency will not be possible without a public strategic control of its base metals industries, creating all the instruments and means necessary to face an increase in the price of carbon and outline a strategy compatible with the environmental goals we set out to respect.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: written.- A good balanced report with some innovative measures to level the playing field for the European metal industry.I therefore agree with this report.

name: Julie WARD
text: in writing. ‒ This report seeks to develop a base metals industry in Europe which is sustainable long-term and both maintains and develops this important sector. People who work in the steel industry are losing their jobs, both in the UK and across the EU, as the sector confronts its most serious peacetime crisis ever, facing a combination of rising steel prices, social dumping, an influx of cheap Chinese steel and increasing energy costs. We will not be able to solve this problem on our own. By working together at EU level we can put pressure on the Chinese Government over steel dumping and come up with Europe-wide solutions to these problems. In the upcoming work on Phase IV of the Emissions Trading Scheme, Labour MEPs will work to ensure that the system of free carbon allowances addresses the issue of carbon leakage. Should this not be sufficient, the Commission should, as a last resort, examine the feasibility of a carbon border adjustment mechanism linked to the ETS. I call on the UK Government to take strong and effective action to support the steel industry and stop massive direct and indirect job losses in this sector.

name: Dame Glenis WILLMOTT
text: in writing. ‒ This report deals with base metals, steel, aluminium, zinc and copper, which are necessary for industrial growth across Europe. Currently, the EU is dependent on imports of these and this report seeks to develop a sustainable base metals industry in Europe. People who work in the steel industry are losing their jobs, both in the UK and across the EU, as the sector confronts its most serious peacetime crisis ever, facing a combination of rising steel prices, an influx of cheap Chinese steel and increasing energy costs. We will not be able to solve this problem on our own. By working together at EU level we can put pressure on the Chinese Government over steel dumping, and come up with Europe-wide solutions to these problems. Labour MEPs will continue to work on this issue and call on the UK Government to take strong and effective action to support the steel industry and combat job losses in the sector.

name: Flavio ZANONATO
text: in writing.- I voted today in favor of the report "The development of a sustainable European industry for base metals".The closure of many base metal production plants is a problem that affects many European countries, with potentially harmful consequences for the continental production system.It is our duty to protect our businesses and workers from unfair competition and social and environmental dumping.I think the text approved today is particularly appropriate, particularly where it recalls that Europe is already heavily dependent on imports of many raw materials and a new dependence on metals would certainly have a negative impact on many industrial sectors that are strategic for the Union.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the report “Development of a sustainable European base metals industry” because I believe that Europe, already dependent on raw materials, cannot allow a new dependence on base metals to be created, an industry it currently faces a significant drop in demand and investment, driven mainly by comparatively high energy prices and carbon costs compared to third countries. Despite the difficult situation in which it finds itself, the base metals industry must, at the same time, pursue a policy of energy and environmental modernization in accordance with the existing European rules, providing itself with the necessary instruments for this transition to be successful. As such, in order to guarantee the competitiveness of this industry, a reformulation of the current European Union emission allowance trading regime is urgently needed, complementing it with other innovative instruments and strategies from the energy and environmental point of view for the effective reduction of emissions, as well as as the bet on the reuse of base metals and the development of a circular economy. Investment in research and development is still necessary if Europe is to remain a center of excellence for the production of base metals.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. - The decline in capacity and employment in the European steel industry is partly the result of falling demand. In 2014, it registered a decrease of 40 million tons in relation to 2007. But this decrease results mainly from decades of divestment and dismantling of this sector, as is the case of Portugal, with the dependence and loss of specialized industrial knowledge. , which are reflected in downstream sectors. The report affirms the urgency of an increase in the development of the base metals industry - iron, aluminum, copper, etc. - and the need to adapt it to the new technological / environmental paradigms, with a view to reaffirming it internationally.
