We do not follow considerations regarding exploration and property, that is, the accumulation of capital by large multinationals that, in the end, will continue to appropriate the resources and wealth creation of this sector. A new impetus for industrial policy should continue the path of technological, energy and environmental modernization, and, for that, it should create more jobs and equip itself with the necessary instruments and means, which will not be possible without the strategic public control of industries. of base metals.

name: Marco ZULLO
text: in writing. - The industrial importance of common metals is undisputed, in fact they are special steels and steels, aluminum, copper, brass, nickel, lead, zinc, titanium and more. They are the raw material of many industrial sectors and therefore have an enormous strategic impact on European employment, both direct and indirect. These are activities with a high energy requirement that must be considered by the energy policy and the reduction of CO2 emissions. Currently, the sector is challenged by unfair international competition, mainly from China. This is a clash on prices with economies that do not have to submit to the innumerable constraints of job protection and emission cuts to which European companies are subject. In this sense, the most innovative contents of the proposal go, which ask for the compensation policy for indirect emissions to be made fair between the Member States and introduce a device for adjusting the carbon content at the border with the aim of contrasting precisely that international competition is subject to the constraints of the Emissions Trading System. In the light of the introduction of these changes, I voted in favor of this report.

name: Milan ZVER
text: in writing.- I support the European Parliament's legislative resolution on the development of a sustainable European base metal industry, as I believe that structural mechanisms are needed to enable the European base metal industry to compete in the market, thus preserving jobs and industrial skills while respecting high environmental standards..

name: István UJHELYI
text: - I can imagine fewer impossible situations in politics than I am here in the European Parliament building, where representatives of functioning democracies in 28 countries sit, to explain what is happening in Hungary, how the Orban regime has dismantled democratic institutions and controls the public. Viktor Orbán has few more relentless opponents at home, in domestic politics and here on the European stage. However, today I could not support it, I had to abstain from the vote taken by the political groups in the joint motion, as I cannot support a proposal that would penalize Article 7, that is, Hungary as a whole. I cannot support it, because at home, the media machinery of the Orbán regime will resound everywhere that Europe has attacked Hungary. With this, the populist regime will only get stronger and the virus will continue to spread in Europe, so I abstained today, but now I say to the Orbán regime, I will continue to fight against it.

name: Marek JUREK
text: - Madam President!Europe is in a deep crisis, it makes no sense to list all its manifestations - from the perspective of British secession, to the Greek crisis, to thousands of volunteers departing from Europe to enlist in the forces of the Islamic State - and in this situation the leaders of the European Parliament have no more worries than attacking democratic decisionsHungarian people.I encourage everyone to reflect on one thing only: the first day when Art.7 of the Lisbon Treaty (and this perspective is mentioned in paragraph 9 left in this text), will be the beginning of the end of the European Union.Everyone think about whether you really want it.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: - Madam President, I also did not vote in favor of this report. I find it very unfortunate that, in this situation and at the moment, we are receiving a report against one of the Members of the European Union in the European Parliament. I am convinced that at a time when the unity of the European Union is threatened, and therefore I follow up on my predecessors, when the credibility of European integration is declining, for example in the Czech Republic but also in other Central European countries, Visegrad countries. integration and the European Union in the eyes of our constituents in Central Europe will certainly not increase. I find the move unfortunate, counterproductive. In my opinion, it doesn't solve anything, and most of all I want to react and say one more sentence. There are countries that do not fulfill Schengen obligations and do not sufficiently guard the external border. We also do not criticize these countries with resolutions here. Resolutions really cannot solve the situation of the European Union.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: - It is clear that any country has the sovereign right to pursue the policy it wants - which is pursued in accordance with national interests and so on.But this is only an internal aspect.Because it is external - in parallel with the authorities, the international obligations of their country must also be taken into account.And here is the situation with Hungary, if one of the Member States of the European Union does not live up to its obligations and refuses to settle existing disputes objectively with other Member States, then in parallel - and this resolution makes it clear - political synchronization could only be achieved through sanctions.such as the suspension of funding for various EU programs.Admittedly, on the other hand, the European Commission has done nothing more than statements.But I voted in favor of this resolution.

name: Lars ADAKTUSSON
text: written.- Today, Parliament voted on the situation in Hungary.My party group EPP presented its own motion for a resolution, which I certainly have no objections to in substance, but which is not far-reaching enough.The groups S & amp; D, ALDE, GUE and De Gröna, for their part, presented a much sharper motion for a resolution.Their motions for resolutions are more marked by an insight into the serious developments in Hungary.On the other hand, I do not agree that a so-called Article 7 procedure, as proposed by this resolution, is in this situation the right way to go.Instead, the Commission's review of Hungary should be broadened and deepened - a view I also highlighted by supporting paragraph H of the resolution.In the final votes, after an overall assessment, I chose to abstain on both the EPP resolution and the joint resolution of the aforementioned groups.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: written. - I voted in favor of this Resolution because it denounces the serious deterioration suffered by fundamental rights in Hungary and the degradation of its democracy. The text supposes an explicit condemnation by the European Parliament to the ultra-nationalist government of Viktor Orban, a prominent member of the European People's Party, which uses the steamroller of its vast parliamentary majority to impose legislative reforms that undermine pluralism, judicial independence, the separation of powers, freedom of the press and the rights of minorities. While today the European Parliament calls for sanctions for the Orban government and disavows its regrettable behavior, a little over a month ago the popular Europeans, with Mariano Rajoy at the head, applauded the performance of the Hungarian Prime Minister in the face of the refugee crisis and applauded his xenophobic message in Madrid, in which he affirmed that “refugees move like an army” and that they cannot be given access to “a European life”. The popular should be ashamed of this type of action and condemn these xenophobic and anti-European statements since with silence they become accomplices of xenophobia and racist ultranationalism advocated by the Hungarian Prime Minister, Viktor Orban.

name: Tim AKER
text: in writing. – This report seeks to penalise Hungary for its defiance of Commission rulings, in particular its rejection of the Common Asylum Policy. UKIP believes in and is fully supportive of national sovereignty for all Member States of the European Union. We therefore voted against this report.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: written.- We have supported this Resolution due to the current political situation in Hungary that could even put its permanence in the Union at risk as a large part of the fundamental rights enshrined in the Treaties are being violated.If so, article 7 of the TEU could be put into practice, which provides for the measures that can be taken in these cases.We voted in favor of the Resolution by sharing the concern about the violation of fundamental rights and the attacks on minorities living in Hungary, as well as the need to take action in this regard.

name: Lynn BOYLAN
text: in writing. – Whist I and Sinn Féin fully acknowledge the gross violations of human rights on the part of the Hungarian government, I abstained on this resolution on the basis that the recommendations, if enforced, would set a dangerous precedent in the operation of unelected bodies in the policy-making of a Member State. Sinn Féin whole-heartedly opposes the coercive and draconian policies of the Hungarian government, particularly in relation to the ongoing refugee crisis and we acknowledge their acting with impunity provides succour to neighbouring states wishing to act similarly. I fully support the LIBE committee investigating government actions and support the initiation of article 7.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: written.- I welcome the follow-up to the European Parliament's motion for a resolution on the situation in Hungary of June 10, 2015. The European Commission has subsequently taken a number of measures in relation to current developments in Hungary.It has actively monitored the situation in Hungary and in other Member States.Infringement and informal pre-litigation procedures have also been launched and it stands ready to use whatever means at its disposal to ensure that Member States comply with their EU legal obligations.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: in writing. - Unsurprisingly, the joint motion for a resolution presented by the left groups is unacceptable. It is a concentrate of the capacity of the European institutions to harm the peoples of Europe. Indeed, in this text, Hungary, a free and sovereign state, is scandalously taken to task under the pretext of human rights. The Hungarian government, which enjoys great popularity, is accused of endangering the rule of law. Conversely, we believe with my colleagues from the National Front that it is the European oligarchies who, through their immigration policies, seriously endanger the rule of law. For cultural, economic, political and religious reasons, the massive immigration that the peoples of Europe are called upon to accept is an obvious factor of serious tensions. This resolution directly attacks a State which defends not only its national interest but also that of the peoples of Europe. Everything goes: LGBTI rights which would be abhorrently violated, border protection which would be excessive, etc. Worse, the text accuses the Hungarian government of having organized a public consultation on immigration as well as the link it made between immigration and insecurity. I obviously voted against this proposal!

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ This whole report is a nonsense: are we really proposing to interfere with a democratically-elected government’s policies? I would be appalled if such a report were produced concerning the United Kingdom. By voting against this report, I do the obvious courtesy to the Hungarian people. They should be sovereign in Hungary and free to vote their current government out if they do not like their policies – or re-elect them if they do.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: in writing.- The motion for a resolution that is least scandalously hostile to Hungary is the one tabled by the EPP.However, this proposal recognizes the right of unelected European Commission bureaucrats to rule on the legitimacy of the government freely chosen by the Hungarian people.For the rest, Mr. Orbán is accused of being the first person in charge of a Member State of the European Union which made the correct diagnosis and took the appropriate measures to protect his people from the deep identity crisis that the Old Continent is going through....

name: Hugues BAYET
text: in writing. - Following Parliament's resolution of June 2015, the European Commission finally presented its report on Hungary during the plenary session on 2 December. She believes that there was no systematic violation of fundamental rights and values ​​of the European Union by the Orbán government !! I supported the resolution presented by S & amp; D, the GUE, the Greens and the ALDE because it quite rightly asks, via a report of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, the initiation of the procedure provided for in Article 7 with regard to Hungary of the Orbán government and its repeated practices which are contrary to the values ​​of the Union. Unfortunately, the EPP's vote led to the rejection of the paragraph which contained this request. This is a bad signal sent to the components of the Union because we are talking here about respect for the rule of law, freedom of expression, the protection of minorities or even human dignity.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: written.- We voted in favor because the Resolution on the situation in Hungary affects the defense of human rights and denounces that the Hungarian Government is carrying out policies that systematically violate fundamental and democratic rights in Hungary.Viktor Orban's government has launched multiple public campaigns criminalizing refugees, portraying them as criminals, invaders and terrorists.Hungary, as part of the European Union, must comply with its legal and international commitments.Likewise, it is intolerable that a country of the Union headed by its government is carrying out xenophobic policies and launching messages of intolerance in the face of the greatest humanitarian crisis in recent years, instead of being the guarantor of the human and fundamental rights of those whothey flee from war, hunger and misery.

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: written. - I observe with concern and perplexity what is happening in Hungary. Concern about the serious danger in which the rule of law finds itself and perplexity over the lack of support from many fellow MPs who claim to be defenders of rights and freedoms but who have cowered in their condemnation of Hungary. The systemic changes incorporated into the Hungarian legal framework by the Government since 2010 and which lead to the recent legal measures regarding asylum, borders or the penal code are a glaring example of the serious deterioration of fundamental rights and freedoms in the country. Through this Resolution, the European Parliament once again shows its concern but goes a step further by requesting the activation of Article 7 of the EU Treaty against Hungary, which provides for imposing sanctions in the event of a serious violation of the founding values ​​of the Union. Personally, I believe that there are, and that is why I strongly support this request.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: written.- We welcome the opening of an infringement procedure against Hungary in relation to asylum policies but we also think that in this Member State the conditions exist for the Commission to immediately apply the framework for the protection of fundamental rights, asit is producing, without a doubt, a systemic violation of fundamental rights contained in the Charter of the European Union.We believe, moreover, that it is particularly appropriate to commission a specific report from the LIBE Commission, from which a reasoned proposal should come out asking the Council to act in accordance with Article 7 (1) of the TEU.That is why we have voted in favor of these issues included in the original text of the Common Resolution.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: in writing.- This motion for a resolution on Hungary is yet another virulent attack on a state which defends its national interest.This text is reduced to an indigestible soup because it is so exhaustive.He manages to mix LGBT rights and border protection.We note in particular the criticism made against Hungary for having organized a public consultation on immigration and the criticism of making a link between immigration and insecurity.I am opposed to this text which interferes in the politics of Hungary and gives directives to a President and a government democratically and massively elected and re-elected.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing.- I find the joint resolution presented by the left on the situation in Hungary biased and not acceptable.I therefore supported with my vote the text presented by the EPP Group which endorses the political choices made by the legitimate Hungarian government.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: written. - I voted in favor of this Resolution because it denounces the serious deterioration suffered by fundamental rights in Hungary and the degradation of its democracy. The text supposes an explicit condemnation by the European Parliament to the ultra-nationalist government of Viktor Orban, a prominent member of the European People's Party, which uses the steamroller of its vast parliamentary majority to impose legislative reforms that undermine pluralism, judicial independence, the separation of powers, freedom of the press and the rights of minorities. While today the European Parliament calls for sanctions for the Orban government and disavows its regrettable behavior, a little over a month ago the popular Europeans, with Mariano Rajoy at the head, applauded the performance of the Hungarian Prime Minister in the face of the refugee crisis and applauded his xenophobic message in Madrid, in which he affirmed that “refugees move like an army” and that they cannot be given access to “a European life”. The popular should be ashamed of this type of action and condemn these xenophobic and anti-European statements since with silence they become accomplices of xenophobia and racist ultranationalism advocated by the Hungarian Prime Minister, Viktor Orban.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of this resolution because it sets out Parliament's position on the situation in Hungary. Parliament notes that constitutional, legal and political changes in Hungary have raised concerns about the rule of law, democracy and fundamental rights in recent years and that all these changes may pose a systemic threat to the rule of law in that Member State. Parliament recalls that all Member States must fully respect EU law in their legislative and administrative practices and that all legislation must be based on the fundamental values ​​of the European Union, namely democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights. Resolution Parliament also expresses its concern that the Council and the Commission recall the principle of loyal interinstitutional cooperation enshrined in the EU Treaty and recall the Commission's role as guardian of the Treaties, regardless of or failing to respond adequately to Parliament's concerns, which it regularly expresses by a majority of its component members. that national legislation complies with the principles of democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights. Parliament therefore reiterates its call on the Commission to apply the first pillar of the EU rule of law framework, thus initiating a comprehensive process of monitoring the situation of democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights in Hungary without delay and assessing whether there is a systemic threat in that Member State, which could lead to a clear risk of a serious infringement under Article 7 of the EU Treaty.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: written.- I support this motion for a resolution on the situation in Hungary.Considering that a resolution was adopted on 10 June 2015 calling, inter alia, for the simultaneous initiation of monitoring of the rule of law, democracy and fundamental rights in Hungary in order to assess the potential systematic violation of the values on which the EU is based,I would like to know whether the European Commission has carried out monitoring and whether assessments of the current situation in Hungary have been made in the light of all the above?

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing.- There are reasonable grounds to think that Viktor Orbán and his collaborators are trying to transform Hungary into a state lacking the basic elements of a free and democratic country.The continuous violations of civil rights, freedom of thought and opinion, the possibility of acting in the political context in conditions of fair treatment, together with the continuous nationalist, xenophobic, racist and sexist campaigns carried out by Orbán and his power structureconstitute an alarming fact of the authoritarian transformation of this Member State.Authoritarian transformation that cannot in any way be tolerated by the European Union which must intervene forcefully to remove the risk of dictatorships from its territory and to restore democracy, freedom and the possibility of civil coexistence in Hungary.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: signed up.- The migration phenomenon of recent months has revealed the tendency of some states to defend their borders to the maximum, which should not be viewed in a negative way if there are no facts that are likely to be in conflict with fundamental EU rights.In this context, Hungary responded to the wave of criticism from the European authorities and the Member States.I am of the opinion that the competent authorities need to pay attention to the situation in Hungary, but this attention should not go beyond normal limits, given that there are other Member States facing similar problems, which is why I voted against this resolution..

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing.- The resolution supported by the left is absolutely not acceptable for political, merit and expediency reasons.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing.- Today I voted in favor of the resolution on the situation in Hungary.The country was experiencing an internal condition of serious deterioration in matters of freedom and pluralism, with an increase in penalties and the proposal to reintroduce the death sentence.We can therefore speak of an illiberal drift for Hungary, a drift also censured by this Parliament with the resolution passed on 10 June this year.Hungary has been part of the European Union since 2004 and must be called upon to respect all the principles on which the EU is founded: freedom, democracy, respect for human rights, fundamental freedoms and the State ofright.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. – This report seeks to penalise Hungary for their defiance against Commission rulings, in particular their rejection of the Common Asylum Policy. UKIP believes in and is fully supportive of national sovereignty for all member states of the European Union. We therefore voted against this report.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: in writing. - In various European states, values ​​such as democracy, tolerance and equality are now jeopardized by an increasingly aggressive policy. This trend worries us, and we are concerned in particular by the situation in Hungary, where the government has long ago adopted concrete tones and measures that depart from the fundamental values ​​and principles of the European Union, and even from those minimum requirements. (the "Copenhagen criteria") that each country must have in order to join the Union. Ensuring that fundamental rights and the principles of the rule of law are respected in each Member State is a task that the Commission is called upon to carry out consistently and firmly in its role as guardian of the treaties. Only in this way will the Union be able to remain faithful to its founding values ​​and reaffirm its role and its raison d'etre. We cannot allow undemocratic tendencies to creep into our common life, risking to disintegrate a Europe already tested by crises on several fronts. Economic difficulties or the management of migratory flows cannot be excuses for the weakening of the Union, but tests to be overcome united and guided by common and inalienable values. For these reasons, I voted in favor.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: PPE), in writing.- We can not agree with the content of this report and for this reason we are voting against it.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: GUE / NGL), in writing. - The new resolution on the situation in Hungary describes and condemns the developments that have taken place since last June, especially in the field of asylum and border control, and describes the serious and systematic degradation of the rule of law and fundamental rights by during the last years. It further criticizes the Commission and the Council for failing to take action following the previous European Parliament resolution. Despite the rejection of paragraph 10, which would allow the Committee on Civil Liberties to proceed with the adoption of a report, the resolution nevertheless contains many positive elements and that is why I voted in favor of it.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. - In order for a candidate country to join the European Union, it needs to fulfill the so-called "Copenhagen criteria", which determine, among others, the integration of the acquis communautaire and respect for fundamental rights and the rule of law. I have long argued that once a Member State, the criteria used for membership should not be relaxed. For this we have a set of mechanisms, such as the procedure for non-compliance or, in systemic and serious cases of violation of the rule of law and fundamental rights, the so-called Article 7 procedure. In this regard, the Commission opened, among others, an infringement procedure against Hungary regarding its asylum rules. As well, he considered that there were no serious and systemic violations of the democratic rule of law. I am not unaware that problems persist in Hungary. That is why we must work to find solutions to the problems of Hungarian citizens as well as that of all other Member States where similar problems may occur. This resolution has positive points but ignores the work that has been done so far by both Parliament and the European Commission.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing.- I felt I had to vote against the joint resolution as I share the position of the Commission, which states that the conditions for activating the rule of law framework in relation to Hungary are not met.Furthermore, the Commission is constantly monitoring the situation and has already initiated infringement and pre-infringement procedures in cases where it was deemed necessary.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: written.- We have supported this Resolution due to the current political situation in Hungary that could even put its permanence in the Union at risk as a large part of the fundamental rights enshrined in the Treaties are being violated.If so, article 7 of the TEU could be put into practice, which provides for the measures that can be taken in these cases.We voted in favor of the Resolution by sharing the concern about the violation of fundamental rights and the attacks on minorities living in Hungary, as well as the need to take action in this regard.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution which firstly expresses disappointment at the failure of the Commission to respond to the Parliament’s request to undertake an in-depth monitoring process of the situation in Hungary; secondly recognises that due to the situation of breaches of fundamental rights and disregard for rule of law in Hungary which go against the EU’s principles of solidarity and human rights all criteria to activate the Article 7 procedure of the TEU are met; and thirdly, calls for a Parliamentary report into the matter in order to call on the Council to act pursuant to Article 7(1). I gave my support to this resolution because of the disregard in Hungary of democratic values such as freedom of expression and the equal treatment of persons, including Jews, LGBTI persons and Roma persons. Furthermore, I am of the view that all Member States should live up to their obligations in the refugee crisis.

name: Nicola DANTI
text: in writing. - After the resolution of last June, this text constitutes a new call from Europe to the Hungarian government of Orban to put an end to the systematic threats to freedom of the press, democracy, respect for human rights and the rule of law; today we also express our strong concern at the recent and unspeakable measures aimed at criminalizing refugees, migrants and asylum seekers, as well as at the government's increasing use of disturbing xenophobic rhetoric. In a Europe that must first of all be a community of values, it is not possible to tolerate such repeated violations of the principles and rights that underpin our Union. We have already repeatedly asked the Commission to check thoroughly the measures taken by the Hungarian government. But that's not enough: we ask for the immediate activation of the procedure provided for by the treaties in the event of a serious violation of the founding values ​​of the EU. On this point, we regret that the necessary votes have been lacking for a more courageous position by the European Parliament and that we are limited to renewing the request for in-depth monitoring of the Hungarian situation. We do not compromise on our core values: all means must be used to ensure full compliance throughout the EU!

name: Michel DANTIN
text: in writing.- This resolution reacts to the attitude of the Hungarian government towards migrants and to statements by Prime Minister Orbán aimed at stimulating a debate on the possible reinstatement of the death penalty in Hungary, considered incompatible with European principles and values.MEPs urge the European Council to take up the issue and call on the Commission to present a proposal on the creation of a Union mechanism for democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights, based oncommon indicators and objectives, in order to ensure the respect and application of the charter and the treaties signed by all the Member States.Considering that this report is balanced, I voted in favor.

name: Angélique DELAHAYE
text: in writing. - Left groups believe that the European Commission has not reacted appropriately with regard to Hungary. In reality, this resolution meets a double objective: to bring down Viktor Orbán's government and to get the European Commission to meet their demands. That is why I voted against. Indeed, the Commission has constantly reaffirmed its determination to use all existing instruments to defend European values ​​and guarantee respect for the rule of law and fundamental rights. In this sense, the EPP submitted to the votes an alternative resolution which was rejected. We called on us to remain vigilant about the situation in Hungary while underlining the guarantee given by the Commission to Parliament that it will continue to monitor the situation in Hungary and in other Member States, including as regards the functioning of the mechanisms. national protection of the rule of law.

name: Andor DELI
text: in writing.- I voted against the parliamentary resolution on the situation in Hungary because it is completely unacceptable, both procedurally and substantively.In a statement sent to Parliament and at the December plenary, the European Commission stated orally that it had examined and continuously monitored the situation in Hungary and stated that neither the rule of law mechanism nor the conditions for activating Article 7 were present in Hungary.Ignoring the findings of the European Commission, the decision now submitted is another list of lies and indictments against Hungary.The text is malicious, panting for revenge, and no longer seeks the appearance of objectivity.The European Parliament cannot afford such a voice against any Member State.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the resolution on the situation in Hungary even if the paragraph aiming to mandate the LIBE Commission to draw up a report on the violation of the fundamental values of the Union by the Hungarian authorities has not beenapproved by our parliamentary assembly.I believe that, given the actions and statements of the government that we have witnessed for several years, it is justified to activate phase 1 of Article 7 of the Union Treaty against Viktor's governmentOrbán.This involves formally calling on the Council to note that there is a clear risk of a serious violation of the values of the Union.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: In written form. - I voted against the resolution on the situation in Hungary, as the European Parliament is once again being used as a stage for criticism of Viktor Orbán's rule by the Socialists and those who do not support his policies. This resolution is a direct interference in the internal affairs of Hungary and a critique of the legislation adopted by the Orbán administration. On 10 June, we asked the Commission to monitor the situation with democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights in Hungary, precisely as a result of the new legislation. All member states must honor their commitments and protect fundamental rights. On the other hand, all politicians have a right to an opinion. However, the European Parliament should not interfere in the monitoring procedure itself undertaken by the European Commission, as this does not fall within its remit. According to Article 17 TEU, only the European Commission has the competence to conduct such a study and only it has the right to establish whether European law and treaties have been infringed.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), in writing. - This motion for a resolution refers to the adoption by Hungary of a number of amendments concerning asylum law, the penal code, criminal procedure, border law, police law and national defense law. aimed at protecting the country from migratory flows. It is considered that these amendments stop national legislation from complying with the principles of democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights; I believe that the European Union should not interfere in the internal affairs of countries, especially in matters relating to security.

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: in writing.- I voted against the parliamentary resolution on the situation in Hungary because it is completely unacceptable, both procedurally and substantively.In a statement sent to Parliament and at the December plenary, the European Commission stated orally that it had examined and continuously monitored the situation in Hungary and stated that neither the rule of law mechanism nor the conditions for activating Article 7 were present in Hungary.Ignoring the findings of the European Commission, the decision now submitted is another list of lies and indictments against Hungary.The text is malicious, panting for revenge, and no longer seeks the appearance of objectivity.The European Parliament cannot afford such a voice against any Member State.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. - This resolution builds on previous initiatives on Hungary. The forces in the government of this country have a markedly reactionary, protofascist nature, having implemented a set of measures to curtail democratic freedoms, individual and collective, which are of deep concern. It is forces such as those in power in Hungary that the EU's policies of civilization retrocession, and of affront to peoples' sovereignty, have been paving the way. The posture and nature of the Hungarian government is clear from the vile attitude assumed towards the thousands of migrants who passed through the country, through the massive exodus that brought them to Europe, with reports of mistreatment, aggression, neglect, extortion and arbitrary detentions and illegal. To which is added the wall they built along its border. This is all very clear. All of this deserves lively condemnation. But we do not accept that, in the wake of this situation, the European Parliament sets itself, itself and the EU, as a champion and reference of democracy. Not least because the facts and history, especially the most recent, deny it promptly and without question. Nor can we accept the hypocrisy of those who base their immigration policy on the expulsion of those fleeing war, misery and hunger.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: in writing. – I voted in favour as the resolution is positive for human rights. As a former ‘economic migrant’ myself, how else could I act?

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing.- Hungary has come into conflict with the European Union on several occasions.It is therefore very important for the European Commission to scrutinize and monitor the human rights, democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights situation, as it is clear that there is a systematic and serious violation in Hungary of the values on which the European Union is founded under Article2 of the Treaty on European Union.However, the European Commission incomprehensibly sees no systematic threat to democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights in Hungary, despite the recent number of contentious issues, including the treatment of asylum seekers, segregated education and discrimination against Roma, treatment of NGOs, governance and governance.Norwegian funds, dubious court judgments and others.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing.- The joint resolution advocated by left-wing groups is absolutely not acceptable as it is a clear invasion and violation of jurisdiction against the legitimate Hungarian government.

name: Anna FOTYGA
text: in writing.- I voted against the motion for a resolution "The situation in Hungary: follow-up to the resolution of the European Parliament of 10 June 2015" as I believe that the situation in Hungary does not warrant interference by the European Parliament in their internal affairs.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing.- I believe that the European Union should not interfere in the internal affairs of countries, especially in matters relating to security.That is why my vote was against all the reports on the situation in Hungary, such as the one that follows the European Parliament resolution of 10 June 2015.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ Hungary worries us and not only on the issues of migration and border control management but also, more generally, on the rule of law and democracy. I strongly believe that we have to distinguish between Orban’s actions and words and the Hungarian people. Our aim has to be to protect the Hungarian citizens and not to penalise them for the severe infringements carried out by the Prime Minister.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: in writing.- I voted against the parliamentary resolution on the situation in Hungary because it is completely unacceptable, both procedurally and substantively.The European Commission stated in a statement to Parliament and at the December plenary that it had examined and continuously monitored the situation in Hungary and stated that neither the rule of law mechanism nor the conditions for activating Article 7 were present in Hungary.Ignoring the findings of the European Commission, the decision now submitted is another list of lies and indictments against Hungary.The text is malicious, panting for revenge, and no longer seeks the appearance of objectivity.The European Parliament cannot afford such a voice against any Member State.

text: in writing.- I voted against the parliamentary resolution on the situation in Hungary because it is completely unacceptable, both procedurally and substantively.The European Commission stated in a statement to Parliament and at the December plenary that it had examined and continuously monitored the situation in Hungary and stated that neither the rule of law mechanism nor the conditions for activating Article 7 were present in Hungary.Ignoring the findings of the European Commission, the decision now submitted is another list of lies and indictments against Hungary.The text is malicious, panting for revenge, and no longer seeks the appearance of objectivity.The European Parliament cannot afford such a voice against any Member State.

text: written. - I voted in favor of this Resolution because it denounces the serious deterioration suffered by fundamental rights in Hungary and the degradation of its democracy. The text supposes an explicit condemnation by the European Parliament to the ultra-nationalist government of Viktor Orban, a prominent member of the European People's Party, which uses the steamroller of its vast parliamentary majority to impose legislative reforms that undermine pluralism, judicial independence, the separation of powers, freedom of the press and the rights of minorities. While today the European Parliament calls for sanctions for the Orban government and disavows its regrettable behavior, a little over a month ago the popular Europeans, with Mariano Rajoy at the head, applauded the performance of the Hungarian Prime Minister in the face of the refugee crisis and applauded his xenophobic message in Madrid, in which he affirmed that “refugees move like an army” and that they cannot be given access to “a European life”. The popular should be ashamed of this type of action and condemn these xenophobic and anti-European statements since with silence they become accomplices of xenophobia and racist ultranationalism advocated by the Hungarian Prime Minister, Viktor Orban.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. - I shared the EP resolution on the situation in Hungary: follow-up to the European Parliament resolution of 10 June 2015, as I am very concerned about the developments and the current political situation in this EU Member State. In fact, I believe that EU membership cannot be just membership of the internal market, much less a free trade area, but it also means adhering to those fundamental values ​​that the EU protects and represents, including respect for human rights and the duty of solidarity stand out. The initiatives taken by the Hungarian authorities had already aroused concern and prompted Parliament to make a statement last June: I must sadly point out that the recent measures have worsened the situation, prompting the Commission to open an infringement procedure. I express strong concern about the behavior of the Hungarian authorities in managing the migration flow, both in relation to the measures taken and the rhetoric used, and I particularly reject the decision to block the mechanism for allocating asylum seekers. Indeed, this form of populism is not only contrary to EU values, but fuels the rise of Eurosceptic parties in other member states. I therefore share the request for activation of the procedure referred to in Article 7 of the TEU.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: written.- We must stand together as Europe to face the challenges of the current crises.Individual accusations are not helpful here.With a view to Hungary, one must act with the necessary objectivity.

name: Nathan GILL
text: in writing. ‒ This report seeks to penalise Hungary for its defiance of Commission rulings, in particular its rejection of the Common Asylum Policy. UKIP believes in and is fully supportive of national sovereignty for all Member States of the European Union. We therefore voted against this report.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: written.- We voted in favor because the Resolution on the situation in Hungary affects the defense of human rights and denounces that the Hungarian Government is carrying out policies that systematically violate fundamental and democratic rights in Hungary.Viktor Orban's government has launched multiple public campaigns criminalizing refugees, portraying them as criminals, invaders and terrorists.Hungary, as part of the European Union, must comply with its legal and international commitments.Likewise, it is intolerable that a country of the Union headed by its government is carrying out xenophobic policies and launching messages of intolerance in the face of the greatest humanitarian crisis in recent years, instead of being the guarantor of the human and fundamental rights of those whothey flee from war, hunger and misery.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ I strongly supported the resolution, as I believe that all Member States have to comply fully with EU law in their legislative and administrative practice, and all legislation has to reflect and be in accordance with basic European values, namely democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: in writing. - This is not the first time that Parliament has had the opportunity to adopt a resolution on the situation in Hungary. For years, we have indeed multiplied the alerts and recommendations, but nothing helped: the Hungarian Prime Minister continues in the path of provocation and the response of the Commission still remains, to this day, lukewarm and insufficient. However, in my opinion, it is time to initiate strong acts, both symbolically and concretely, which in particular involves the request for the activation of Article 7 (1) of the EU Treaty and closer monitoring of the use of European funding in Hungary. If I therefore supported this resolution, I strongly regret that some elected officials, most of them conservative, opposed the paragraphs on the activation of Article 7 of the Treaty and the reference to the citizens' initiative recently. recorded. The Orbán case - and the threats hanging over elsewhere in Europe - demonstrates the urgent need for the European Union to equip itself with a comprehensive mechanism to ensure respect for democracy. As it does on budgetary matters, Europe must conduct an impartial assessment of the situation of fundamental rights every year, with common and objective indicators.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ The Commission, in its reply to Parliament’s oral question adopted on 10 November 2015 by the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs (LIBE), which was not forwarded in due time to the members of the LIBE Committee by Parliament’s administration, stated that the conditions for activating the Rule of Law Framework as regards Hungary have not been met at this stage. I strongly hope that Member States will cooperate and stand together in times of crisis, tackle these crises and strengthen the rule of law.

name: Sergio GUTIÉRREZ PRIETO
text: written. - I voted in favor of this Resolution because it denounces the serious deterioration suffered by fundamental rights in Hungary and the degradation of its democracy. The text supposes an explicit condemnation by the European Parliament to the ultra-nationalist government of Viktor Orban, a prominent member of the European People's Party, which uses the steamroller of its vast parliamentary majority to impose legislative reforms that undermine pluralism, judicial independence, the separation of powers, freedom of the press and the rights of minorities. While today the European Parliament calls for sanctions for the Orban government and disavows its regrettable behavior, a little over a month ago the popular Europeans, with Mariano Rajoy at the head, applauded the performance of the Hungarian Prime Minister in the face of the refugee crisis and applauded his xenophobic message in Madrid, in which he affirmed that “refugees move like an army” and that they cannot be given access to “a European life”. The popular should be ashamed of this type of action and condemn these xenophobic and anti-European statements since with silence they become accomplices of xenophobia and racist ultranationalism advocated by the Hungarian Prime Minister, Viktor Orban.

name: András GYÜRK
text: in writing.- I voted against the parliamentary resolution on the situation in Hungary because it is completely unacceptable, both procedurally and substantively.The European Commission stated in a statement to Parliament and at the December plenary that it had examined and continuously monitored the situation in Hungary and stated that neither the rule of law mechanism nor the conditions for activating Article 7 were present in Hungary.Ignoring the findings of the European Commission, the decision now submitted is another list of lies and indictments against Hungary.The text is malicious, it does not even seek the appearance of objectivity.The European Parliament cannot afford such a voice against any Member State.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: GUE / NGL), in writing. - This new resolution, which we as a Group has supported, seeks to describe and condemn recent developments in Hungary in the areas of political asylum and border guarding. It also describes the significant and systematic deterioration of the rule of law and fundamental rights. The resolution reiterates that the Commission must implement the first stage of the EU Rule of Law framework, which we called for in June, without the Commission and the Council doing so. Finally, the resolution calls on the LIBE Committee to prepare a special report on Hungary with a view to activating Article 7 (1) of the Treaty.

name: Brice HORTEFEUX
text: in writing. - We may have questions about certain decisions of Hungarian domestic policy. However, I dare to believe that the Hungarian people are sufficiently enlightened and their institutions informed to take the appropriate measures if they notice a drift of political power. The European Commission has been ordered to carry out an analysis of respect for the rule of law and fundamental rights in Hungary. When questioned in writing and orally, she never ceased to respond to requests from the European Parliament and reaffirmed that she was ready to use all the instruments at her disposal to ensure respect for European law and values. In addition, infringement proceedings have been opened in relation to Hungarian asylum legislation. Despite these detailed responses, left-wing groups continue to demand sanctions, questioning the lucidity of the Hungarian people and the vigilance of its National Assembly. I have therefore decided to reject this excessive resolution in its content, but I do not forget that it is up to everyone to exercise all the vigilance necessary to guarantee respect for democracy.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of this motion for a resolution on the situation of Hungarian legislation’s compatibility with EU asylum and borders acquis and the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: written. - I voted in favor of the European Parliament resolution on the situation in Hungary - further action following the adoption of the EP Resolution of 10.6.2015, given the concerns about social and political processes taking place in recent years, and in particular the changes in in the area of ​​legislation that has intensified in recent months. Legislative and political changes give rise to concerns about the rule of law, democracy and fundamental rights. There is a trend of deviation from the fundamental democratic values ​​on which the concept of the European Union is based. Within its remit, the Commission should pay attention to ensuring that national legislation is in line with fundamental values ​​and EU documents. The Commission's current approach to the situation in Hungary is unsatisfactory and limited to marginal, technical aspects of legislative change. I support the European Citizens' Initiative initiative to launch Article 7 of the EU Treaty. In addition, more attention needs to be paid to the problems associated with the migrant crisis and growing xenophobia.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. – This report seeks to penalise Hungary for its defiance of Commission rulings, in particular its rejection of the Common Asylum Policy. My fellow UKIP MEPs believe in and are fully supportive of national sovereignty for all Member States of the European Union. I therefore voted against this report.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: in writing.- I voted against the joint resolution of the left parties on the situation in Hungary, which implicitly aims to bring down the government of Viktor Orbán, highlighting the inaction of the Commission and the Council.However, the European Commission has already reaffirmed several times its determination to use all existing instruments to defend European values and ensure respect for the rule of law.It also carried out an analysis which concluded that the conditions for activating the rule of law framework with regard to Hungary were not met.On the other hand, I supported the balanced text presented by the EPP.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: written.- I am voting against this motion for a resolution.Hungary's democratically elected government makes use of its constitutionally guaranteed rights and should not be restricted in its sovereignty.

name: Jan KELLER
text: in writing. - When voting on the motion for a resolution on the situation in Hungary, I decided to abstain. On the one hand, I acknowledge that some allegations against what is happening in Hungary are justified, which does not allow me to vote against the proposed resolution. On the other hand, I cannot fail to see that, especially in the area of ​​access to migrants, some of the countries criticized by Hungary are gradually adopting some methods that were condemned in the case of Hungarians (building fences, tightening asylum procedures, efforts to discourage migrants from coming to Europe). At the same time, I am opposed to the attempt to use the case of Hungary to flatly condemn countries such as Slovakia or the Czech Republic and to ignore the important nuances that distinguish them from the negatives of Hungarian politics. I am afraid that if the proposed sanctions are applied to Hungary, the risk of stigmatizing all the countries of Central Europe will increase further, which is not in line with the right to equality of all the countries of the European Union.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I strongly supported the resolution, as I believe that all Member States have to comply fully with EU law in their legislative and administrative practice, and all legislation has to reflect and be in accordance with basic European values, namely democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights.

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: in writing.- I voted against the parliamentary resolution on the situation in Hungary because it is completely unacceptable, both procedurally and substantively.In a statement sent to Parliament and at the December plenary, the European Commission stated orally that it had examined and continuously monitored the situation in Hungary and stated that neither the rule of law mechanism nor the conditions for activating Article 7 were present in Hungary.Ignoring the findings of the European Commission, the decision now submitted is another list of lies and indictments against Hungary.The text is malicious, panting for revenge, and no longer seeks the appearance of objectivity.The European Parliament cannot afford such a voice against any Member State.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: In written form. - I supported the resolution because the European Union is based on the values ​​of respect for freedom, equality, the rule of law, respect for human rights, and we must not close our eyes but oppose the departure from our principles, especially when it is in within the Union. Recent initiatives and interventions by the Hungarian government have led to a systematic deterioration of the rule of law. At a time when a record number of people are leaving their homes due to war and oppression, it is unacceptable for Hungary, which is a full member of the EU and international organizations, to want to isolate itself and refuse to deal with asylum applications. The country is obliged to comply with European and international laws such as the Geneva Convention. These acts by the Hungarian government in recent months should serve as a red light that freedom and democracy are being fought for on a daily basis. I therefore consider it necessary for the Council of the European Union and the European Council to discuss and adopt conclusions on the situation in Hungary.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing.- The legislation of each Member State must be in line with the principles of democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights.I have a deep respect for universal human rights and human dignity, however I believe that what happened in Hungary needs a careful and objective evaluation, which is not influenced by political or personal evaluations.For this reason, I hope that any conduct contrary to international or Community law will be judged in the appropriate forums.At the same time, considering further assessments necessary, I do not support today's proposal.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: in writing.- I voted against the resolution of the left groups on the situation in Hungary, and against that of the EPP.Neither of these two resolutions respects the national sovereignty of Hungary.The Hungarian opposition is using the European Parliament to settle scores with the government of Mr Viktor Orbán.However, he was democratically elected.The democratic choice of the Hungarian voters must be respected.The European Union cannot interfere in the internal affairs of Hungary or any other member state.The European Parliament must therefore stop producing these resolutions which serve absolutely nothing.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: in writing.- I voted against this resolution because the European Union is fighting it once again against the nationalist regime of Viktor Orbán.Yet this is a regime which is supported by two thirds of Hungarians!But the Union has never understood the meaning of the word "democracy".

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: written. - I voted in favor of this Resolution because it denounces the serious deterioration suffered by fundamental rights in Hungary and the degradation of its democracy. The text supposes an explicit condemnation by the European Parliament to the ultra-nationalist government of Viktor Orban, a prominent member of the European People's Party, which uses the steamroller of its vast parliamentary majority to impose legislative reforms that undermine pluralism, judicial independence, the separation of powers, freedom of the press and the rights of minorities. While today the European Parliament calls for sanctions for the Orban government and disavows its regrettable behavior, a little over a month ago the popular Europeans, with Mariano Rajoy at the head, applauded the performance of the Hungarian Prime Minister in the face of the refugee crisis and applauded his xenophobic message in Madrid, in which he affirmed that “refugees move like an army” and that they cannot be given access to “a European life”. The popular should be ashamed of this type of action and condemn these xenophobic and anti-European statements since with silence they become accomplices of xenophobia and racist ultranationalism advocated by the Hungarian Prime Minister, Viktor Orban.

name: Ernest MARAGALL
text: in writing. ‒ The recent developments over the past few years in Hungary have led to a serious deterioration with regard to the values of respect for human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality, the rule of law and respect for human rights. It is significant that the Commission is activating the first stage of the EU framework to strengthen the rule of law and to initiate an in-depth monitoring process concerning the situation of democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights in Hungary. I have voted in favour of this report so as to get the attention of the Commission to focus on these issues and to consider the possibility of activating Article 7 of the Treaty on European Union.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing.- I abstain from voting on the report on the situation in Hungary because it is neither complete nor substantiated.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. ‒ The EU should start immediately to monitor threats to democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights in Hungary. The Commission should assess whether the combined effect of government measures there has led to a ‘systemic deterioration’, which, if the Commission fails to address it, could trigger similar developments in other Member States too.

name: Emmanuel MAUREL
text: in writing. - Faced with the repeated violations of the rule of law and fundamental freedoms in Mr Orban's Hungary (suffocation of the independent media and the opposition, use of war methods against asylum seekers and threats of reinstatement of the sentence death), the European Parliament had the opportunity to send a strong response. The text voted on sends positive signals. He thus calls for better control of European funds which currently only serve to fatten the Orban dynasty. Overall, however, the text looks like a real missed opportunity. All the very symbolic requests for recourse to "Article 7", which would allow the Commission to initiate a procedure which could lead to the provisional exclusion of a Member State guilty of violating European values, were rejected. However, it was necessary to act quickly and strongly to remind everyone - in particular the new Polish government - that the European Union, before being a large soft market, is a community of values. While it is the duty of the Socialists to be at the forefront on this subject, I regret the attitude of the European conservatives who did everything to cover up the actions of Fidesz, in power in Hungary and member of the EPP (right European).

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: S & amp; D), in writing. - In the midst of a serious humanitarian crisis affecting the whole of Europe and watching tragic events take place on the borders of many Member States, the EU must safeguard its principles and values ​​because they are part of our interests. Democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights are the cornerstone of the EU's founding treaties. However, contrary to the European acquis, the Hungarian government, wanting to control the flow of refugees across its borders, has declared the country a and at the same time adopted strict deterrent measures to reduce the number of refugees fleeing its territory seeking asylum. This policy includes, inter alia, amendments to criminal law and procedure, the mobilization of the army and the arrest of refugees at the border, acts which are a clear violation of the EU Fundamental Principles under Article 2 TEU. I am therefore in favor of this resolution, which advocates an immediate response to the current worrying situation in Hungary through systematic monitoring and intensive monitoring by the Commission, leaving open the possibility of implementing Article 7 TEU, which allows the Council to make recommendations to a Member State at risk of a serious breach of the rules of European primary law.

name: Georg MAYER
text: written.- With its effective border protection, Hungary has proven that this is possible.Hungary should be seen as a trailblazer, but the motions for resolutions take an anti-Hungarian stance.Therefore I reject them.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: in writing. - The hard right-wing Hungarian government is not at its first misdeeds in terms of failure to respect fundamental rights. Since 2011, Parliament has been asking for the Charter of Fundamental Rights to be respected and thus to activate Article 7 of the Treaties, which provides for the possible suspension of the right to vote of a government which violates democracy. But this article is a decoy. Evidenced by its complexity. And the European Commission has so far stuck to an injunction to respect the European economic order. Faced with the new Hungarian law amalgamating migrants and terrorists, this resolution recalls this legal possibility. This situation underlines how much the European Union is built solely on respect for neoliberal orthodoxy. The Commission is now frowning on the more than obscure public procurement in Hungary when at the same time the Hungarian leader calls for the reintroduction of the death penalty. I support this report in order to see if the Commission will be able to do better than words on the subject.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the resolution on the situation in Hungary.The policy pursued by Prime Minister Orbán raises several doubts in terms of fundamental rights in Hungary.The eventual reintroduction of the death penalty in the country, and a controversial public consultation on immigration, gave rise to an EU reaction.The European Commission has stated that the reintroduction of the death penalty would be contrary to the values enshrined in Article 2 of the Treaty on European Union and would lead to the application of Article 7, which allows, in the event of a serious and persistent violationEU values, the suspension of certain rights of the Member State concerned, including the right to vote of the representative of the government of that Member State in the Council.It is extremely important that the Commission continues to monitor the situation in Hungary closely.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: in writing.- I deeply regret that the request to entrust Parliament with the drafting of a report aimed at activating the first phase of Article 7 against the Hungarian authorities was rejected by 9 votes.The activation of this phase would have made it possible to ask the Council to determine the existence of a risk of serious violation by the Hungarian authorities of European values such as democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights.In view of the authoritarian drift in which Prime Minister Orban has been leading his country for several years already, this is a minimum.Blocked by the overwhelming majority of EPP deputies, Parliament has failed to assume its responsibilities.I strongly condemn this lack of political will, which only reinforces Viktor Orban's impunity once again and sets a dangerous precedent.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of a resolution calling for an investigation into violations of fundamental rights by the government of Viktor Orbán in Hungary, because with this Resolution we are sending a strong message to the Hungarian people that we stand up for their basic rights. The resolution urges the Commission to activate the first stage of the EU framework to strengthen the rule of law, and therefore to initiate immediately an in-depth monitoring process concerning the situation of democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights in Hungary, assessing a potential systemic serious breach of the values on which the Union is founded as per Article 2 TEU.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: in writing. - The PPE, S&D, ALDE, Verts / ALE, ECR and GUE / NGL Groups have tabled draft resolutions on this subject. The proposal of the PPE tries to excuse the Hungarian policy of Fidesz, which is part of their ranks, as much as possible, and the ECR's is rather meaningless. The drafts of the other four political groups condemn recent developments with more or less the same force and point out that the situation and measures taken in Hungary over the last few years have led to a significant systemic deterioration of the rule of law and fundamental rights, the functioning of the constitutional system, the independence of the judiciary and other institutions, and a number of worrying allegations of corruption and conflicts of interest. On this basis, these four groups managed to draft a joint compromise resolution; I voted in favor of this.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: in writing.- I voted against the joint resolution of the S & amp; D, ALDE, Verts and GUE groups on the situation in Hungary.I do indeed disapprove of this text which calls for the initiation of a process of in-depth monitoring by the European Commission of all the policies and measures taken in Hungary.The European Commission has reaffirmed its determination to make use of all existing instruments to defend European values and guarantee respect for the rule of law, but considers that the conditions for activating Hungary's monitoring mechanism are not met.

name: Alessandra MUSSOLINI
text: in writing.- I have decided to vote against this resolution, as I trust the communication from the European Commission that the conditions for the application of the EU framework for strengthening the rule of law do not exist for Hungary.I also consider inappropriate the request, made through this document, to activate, to the detriment of Hungary, Article 7, which provides that, on a reasoned proposal from a third of the Member States, the European Parliament or the European Commission, theThe Council can note that there is a clear risk of a serious breach by a Member State of the values on which the European Union is founded.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this report that reiterates the position expressed in the resolution of 10 June 2015 on the situation in Hungary, by initiating an in-depth monitoring process regarding democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights, in order to prevent a systemic threat.

name: Urmas PAET
text: in writing.- I supported.Hungary has faced many challenges, such as the migrant crisis and economic difficulties.However, it is important that Hungary respects fundamental human rights, the rule of law and the fundamental values of democracy.

name: Maite PAGAZAURTUNDÚA
text: written. - We observe with concern and perplexity what is happening in Hungary. Concern about the serious danger in which the rule of law finds itself and perplexity over the lack of support from many fellow MPs who claim to be defenders of rights and freedoms but who have cowered in their condemnation of Hungary. The systemic changes incorporated into the Hungarian legal framework by the Government since 2010 and which lead to the recent legal measures regarding asylum, borders or the penal code are a glaring example of the serious deterioration of fundamental rights and freedoms in the country. Through this Resolution, the European Parliament once again shows its concern but goes a step further by requesting the activation of Article 7 of the EU Treaty against Hungary, which provides for imposing sanctions in the event of a serious violation of the founding values ​​of the Union. From UPYD we consider that there are, and that is why we firmly adhere to this petition.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: NI), in writing. - The KKE MEP condemns the reactionary and anti-popular policy of the Hungarian bourgeois government which targets refugees, immigrants and attacks workers' rights and freedoms in order to serve the interests of the monopolies. Employees from bourgeois governments and the EU in all its Member States are subject to a similar anti-popular attack in many ways. But the joint resolution of the Social Democrats - GUE - Liberals and Greens hypocritically uses the reactionary Hungarian government to legitimize the EU and its institutions and the subjugation of the peoples to the chains of the Euro-road and to declare this imperialist transnational union protector of the people's freedoms, in an "honorary" and body for the enforcement of the "democratic values" and "principles" of the EU, ie the interests of the bourgeoisie. The KKE does not legitimize and does not recognize any right to self-proclaim defenders of popular rights and freedoms, the EU, governments and civil management parties that crush the lives and rights of working peoples. Only the Hungarian people, like any other people, have the exclusive right to overthrow anti-popular policies, to free themselves by force and struggle from the shackles of the exploitation of capital and its wolf alliances, and to seize power and wealth it produces.

name: Gilles PARGNEAUX
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this resolution.With this resolution, we wanted to sound the alarm once again: all of Europe is concerned.Because what is happening in Hungary threatens to happen in other Member States, our response must be firm.In order to reach one million signatures, we invite Europeans to sign this citizens' initiative on a massive scale, recorded on November 30, which calls on the European Commission to use all the means at its disposal to ensure that European values are respected everywhere.

name: Margot PARKER
text: in writing. ‒ This report seeks to penalise Hungary for its defiance of Commission rulings, in particular its rejection of the Common Asylum Policy. UKIP believes in and is fully supportive of national sovereignty for all Member States of the European Union. We therefore voted against this report.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: written. - Having regard to the previous statement of the European Commission stating that the conditions for activating the rule of law framework in the case of Hungary are not met, I cannot support this resolution which unjustifiably and without new elements calls on the Commission to reactivate the first phase rights. It is clear that Member States must respect and implement EU law, and the Commission is already monitoring the situation in Hungary and other Member States and reacting if violations of the rule of law, democracy and fundamental rights are identified and proven. There are problems with the implementation of migrant policies, but given the refugee and migrant crisis we are facing, and which we still do not know how to deal with, I believe that Hungary is no exception. I consider this resolution to be an extremely dangerous and very hasty decision that calls into question the sovereignty of the member states. To activate the instruments required by this resolution, we must have much more serious arguments and stronger evidence. These measures are strong and should not be taken lightly.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: written.- It is obvious that democracy and the rule of law in Hungary have been at a lower level in the last few years, and that the European Commission should submit its assessment of the situation as soon as possible so that further measures can be taken.When we talk about the fundamental values of the European Union, any hesitation in sanctioning their violation is a dangerous precedent.In particular, media freedom and pluralism, the independence of the judiciary, the principle of non-discrimination and tolerance, the protection of marginalized and minority groups, and the particularly devastating treatment of members of the Roma minority, LGBT persons and refugees have been seriously questioned in Hungary.In view of all the above, I support the adoption of this resolution.

name: Franck PROUST
text: in writing. - I voted for the EPP resolution and not for the joint resolution because it meets a double objective: to bring down Viktor Orban's government and to get the Commission to apply Article 7 of the EU Treaty. However, despite the Commission's analysis concluding that the conditions for activating the rule of law framework with regard to Hungary were not met, left-wing groups consider that the Commission has not reacted in such a way. appropriate. I also reject the accusations leveled against the PPE Group, which is complacent towards Hungary. We support the justified criticisms on the respect of certain rights in Hungary, but, on the question of migrants, I see that other States have applied the methods of Hungary in the face of the threat to their own stability! It is by the yardstick of actions and their success that we must judge. So far, only Hungary has managed to stem the flow of migrants. We should constructively support Hungary by scrupulously following the application of fundamental rights.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ This report seeks to penalise Hungary for its defiance of Commission rulings, in particular its rejection of the Common Asylum Policy. UKIP believes in and is fully supportive of national sovereignty for all Member States of the European Union. We therefore voted against this report.

name: Christine REVAULT D'ALLONNES BONNEFOY
text: in writing. - For years we have witnessed a serious deterioration of the rule of law and fundamental rights in Hungary. The government of Viktor Orbán multiplies provocations and affronts to democracy. Refugees, stigmatized and assimilated to criminals, find it very difficult to access international protection. The independence of the judiciary and the media is threatened. The specter of the death penalty reappears dangerously. Racism, anti-Semitism and xenophobia are increasing. This worrying situation constitutes a real test to assess the Union's capacity to react firmly when one of its Member States acts in flagrant contradiction with its values. If we remain passive and inactive, similar phenomena could spread like wildfire to other European states. The aim of this resolution was to call on the European institutions to take strong action in the face of what is happening in Hungary. I deeply regret that, because of the European right, the text voted on does not ask for the activation of Article 7 of the Treaty - which could lead to the suspension of some of the rights of a Member State - and does not support the European citizens' initiative on the same demand.

name: Dominique RIQUET
text: in writing.- Since the accession to power of Prime Minister Viktor Orban, Hungary has adopted authoritarian measures, as demonstrated by the adoption of laws restricting fundamental rights and individual freedoms, in particular vis-à-vis minorities and foreigners.Hungary in particular restricted freedom of religion and opinion.These measures go against the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union, which led to the sending of a letter of formal notice by the European Commission.The European Union being a community of law, breaches of the treaties must be penalized.That is why I voted in favor of this motion for a resolution, which aims to encourage the European Commission and the European Council to take full account of the recent abuses in this country.Democracy and the rule of law must therefore be preserved by taking adequate measures.

name: Robert ROCHEFORT
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of this resolution which deals with the situation in Hungary. The situation in this country is extremely worrying. The legislative measures adopted concerning refugees, migrants and asylum seekers are unfortunately only the last step in a long series carried out for several years by the Hungarian government. We had already alerted on this subject with our resolution of June 10. The Commission, the Council and the European Council must assume their responsibilities. The Council and the European Council must organize a debate and adopt firm conclusions on the situation in Hungary. The Commission must activate the first phase of the Union framework to strengthen the rule of law and immediately initiate a process of in-depth monitoring in the areas of democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights. It must assess the emergence of a systemic threat in Hungary which could give rise to a manifest risk of a serious breach within the meaning of Article 7 of the EU Treaty. The infringement procedure concerning the asylum acquis is not sufficient. A fire is not extinguished with a glass of water, especially when it threatens to spread.

name: Claude ROLIN
