text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the joint resolution on the situation in Hungary, because I am particularly concerned by the series of legislative measures adopted by this country and by the statements by its Prime Minister. The European Union is a community of inalienable universal values. They form the basis of the European project and it cannot be waived. The reports that come to us from Hungary show clear violations of fundamental rights and discrimination against minorities. We cannot accept it. This is why the Commission is asked to continue its investigations, while ensuring the transparent and adequate use of the Union funds allocated to Hungary. The Council must also be able to react to the worrying development of the situation, by considering the possibility of triggering the procedure provided for in Article 7 of the EU Treaty. Beyond the strict application of Union law, the European reaction to the deviation of a Member State must be firm, because it is a question of demonstrating that the rights of the citizens of the Union cannot in any way cases be flouted.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. - In June of this year, a motion for a resolution was adopted on the need for all Member States to have to fully respect EU law, its common basic values, including democratic principles, the rule of law and fundamental rights themselves. To that extent, this proposal does not add anything substantive, not even new, to the proposal previously presented in terms of measures to protect the rule of law and European values. Hungary has made an effort to fulfill and respect fundamental rights and other obligations under EU law. I consider it important for the Commission to continue to monitor, on an equal and non-dual basis, all Member States with regard to migration, democratic principles and fundamental rights, as well as the need to promote greater cooperation and unity between States Member States at this time of crisis and the need to strengthen the rule of law. However, I do not share the restrictive view contained in this joint motion for a resolution by the political groups: ALDE, GUE / NGL and Verdes / ALE (which is not part of the PPE motion for a resolution, which was previously rejected during this voting period - before vote on this joint proposal), which is why I voted against.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing.- I voted against the motion for a resolution as I believe that, if on the one hand Hungary is wrong in pursuing a policy in stark contrast to the guidelines dictated by the European Union, it is also true, on the other hand,that a large part of the European left continues to express an attitude of total closure and ideological criticism towards the government of Viktor Orbán.This behavior, far from favoring the achievement of a common solution, only worsens relations and freezes dialogue with a member country of the European Union in a very difficult historical moment in which reciprocal and virtuous collaboration between the States is clearly preferable.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: written.- We voted in favor because the Resolution on the situation in Hungary affects the defense of human rights and denounces that the Hungarian Government is carrying out policies that systematically violate fundamental and democratic rights in Hungary.Viktor Orban's government has launched multiple public campaigns criminalizing refugees, portraying them as criminals, invaders and terrorists.Hungary, as part of the European Union, must comply with its legal and international commitments.Likewise, it is intolerable that a country of the Union headed by its government is carrying out xenophobic policies and launching messages of intolerance in the face of the greatest humanitarian crisis in recent years, instead of being the guarantor of the human and fundamental rights of those whothey flee from war, hunger and misery.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: written.- We have supported this Resolution due to the current political situation in Hungary that could even put its permanence in the Union at risk as a large part of the fundamental rights enshrined in the Treaties are being violated.If so, article 7 of the TEU could be put into practice, which provides for the measures that can be taken in these cases.We voted in favor of the Resolution by sharing the concern about the violation of fundamental rights and the attacks on minorities living in Hungary, as well as the need to take action in this regard.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this as I believe Hungary’s national sovereignty should be respected and it is not for the EU to criticise a sovereign nation.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ We are not ready to accept politics which go against the EU’s fundamental aims and values. The government of Hungary is treading the line of what constitutes authoritarian and I am worried about the state of democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights in Hungary. It is for this reason that I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution on the situation in Hungary.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: in writing. - At the European Parliament, we are addressing the situation in Hungary for the second time this year. Viktor Orbán promotes a policy that does not always correspond to the fundamental values ​​of the EU, such as the values ​​of respect for human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality, the rule of law and respect for human rights, including the rights of persons belonging to minorities. The beginning of the whole process in Hungary is still in 2011, when we drew attention to the problematic wording of the Hungarian constitution, which talked about Hungary's responsibility for all Hungarians, the united Hungarian nation, collective rights, self-government abroad on the principle of ethnicity, granting the right to vote to foreign Hungarians. Viktor Orbán's government amended the constitution several times, which deprived its own citizens of its provisions with provisions on students, the homeless, restrictions on freedom of speech, discrimination against churches and, most importantly, restrictions on independent justice. Today, when the whole of Europe is facing a serious migration crisis, Hungary is once again in the talks of European officials, because not all the provisions of the law in Hungary are still in line with European law.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: in writing.- I supported the PPE motion for a resolution on the situation in Hungary.This text is balanced and assumes that the Commission is monitoring the situation in Hungary, but has not yet found reasons to activate Article 7 (1) of the EU Treaty, which deals with situations of breach of the rule of law and may lead to sanctions against the Member State concerned.Unfortunately, the PPE proposal did not pass and was replaced by a resolution from the workshop of the left, albeit by an unconvincing majority.I could not support them because this wording goes too far.It is very vague in terms of facts and analysis of legislation and measures in Hungary, but contains clear judgments that Hungary is violating the rule of law and Article 7 (1) should therefore be activated. This position contradicts the Commission's statements.and it cannot be understood other than as purely politically motivated.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: in writing. - On 15 September 2015, the Hungarian government officially declared a "crisis situation due to mass immigration" in connection with migration on the basis of a law that entered into force on the same day. The Commission then assessed the legislation of Hungary and other Member States on migration and the implementation of the legislation in the light of compliance with the EU acquis in the field of asylum and borders. The Commission shall also regularly monitor the situation in Hungary and other Member States and, where it deems it necessary, initiate infringement proceedings and pre-infringement proceedings. The resolution on the situation in Hungary highlights support for the Commission to address existing concerns through infringement and pre-infringement proceedings against a number of Member States. I believe that it is essential that, in times of crisis, the Member States come together, cooperate and respect democratic principles, the rule of law and fundamental rights. Member States must thus participate constructively in the debate on the European Agenda on Migration. As I agree that all Member States must fully respect EU law in their legislative and administrative practice, and that this legislation must reflect fundamental European values, I supported the resolution in plenary.

name: Bart STAES
text: written. - Hungary passed a number of new laws on asylum earlier this year that are in breach of EU law as well as international law. The Greens called on the European Commission to investigate this, but the Commission's approach is currently insufficient; it does not sufficiently address concerns about violations of basic rights and values ​​as described in the EU Treaties. The resolution adopted today criticizes this and pressures the Commission to take effective action. For example, the Commission could invoke Article 7 of the EU Treaty under which a country that violates the fundamental values ​​of the EU can be punished. Unfortunately, this amendment did not make it, nor our request to have it examined by the EP Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs. Nevertheless, I voted in favor of this resolution because it further increases the pressure on the Commission and we urgently need to set an example in this case if we are to continue to defend our fundamental rights in the EU.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: in writing.- We are currently witnessing the activity of politicians who know the answer to current challenges only through radicalism and exaggerated nationalism.This trend is spreading among EU member states.It is necessary to counter these efforts using the tool at our disposal.

name: Helga STEVENS
text: written.- The N-VA delegation voted against the S & amp; D / ALDE resolution RC8-1351 / 2015 as it supported the ECR resolution B8-1360 / 2015 as a more balanced text.The resolution, which has since been adopted, puts the European Parliament forward as a guardian of compliance with European law, while this is a task for the European Commission in the Treaties.The reference to the European Commission is relevant because it recently made it clear that it does not consider that the conditions for the application of an intervention are met.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: in writing.- I voted against the resolution on the situation in Hungary.The resolution proposed by the European People's Party contained many points that were not taken into account in the joint resolution of some political groups.In response to an oral question from Parliament in the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, the European Commission stated that the conditions for activating the rule of law framework in the case of Hungary were not currently met and took a number of measuresfor Justice, Consumers and Gender Equality, presented a review of these measures to Parliament in plenary on 2 December 2015.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: GUE / NGL), in writing. - Hungary has indeed violated the Copenhagen criteria on the basis of which it joined the EU and has indeed violated both European law and international treaties with a treatment of refugees, migrants and asylum seekers that is a continuation of the anti-democratic actions of the current Hungarian government. However, the political guidelines on the use of European funds to deal with refugee flows remain controversial, when the EU itself refuses to address the real causes of the refugee crisis. It is true that Article 7 creates a mechanism for monitoring the implementation of the obligations of the Member States, as they derive from Article 2 of the EU Treaty, but the generality that characterizes it leaves room for different treatment by the Member States. At the same time, the reasonable question arises as to why the procedure was not activated in cases of other states that committed violations. For these reasons we decided to abstain.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI), in writing.- The European Union must not interfere in the internal affairs of countries, especially in relation to matters relating to their internal security.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the adoption of the resolution, in the preparation of which I myself took an active part as a Member. The most important political goal of the democratic opposition in Hungary, to which I belong as an MEP, is to restore the country's democratic functioning in accordance with European standards, and to replace the anti-EU, authoritarian and corrupt Orbán government. The EP cannot take over this task from the Hungarian electorate, but its current resolution is an important stimulus, a clear demonstration of the solidarity and values ​​of the European democratic forces. The decision points out the contradiction between Hungarian government practice and European norms and rules on several points and calls on the Commission to closely monitor the development of the rule of law in Hungary and, if necessary, to take possible steps within the framework of European law. For my part, I could have adopted a stronger and more specific EP resolution in this regard. At the same time, I consider it an outstanding virtue of the resolution that, compared to previous documents with similar purposes, it pays special attention to the phenomenon of systemic corruption linked to the Hungarian government, and thus to the financing of the anti-democratic regime. I hope from the tighter EU scrutiny urged by the EP and the political attention that goes with it, that it will help to ensure that in the future EU support funds do not enrich the regime's political and family ties, but serve the goals of Hungarian businesses, communities and citizens. .

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: signed up. - It is unfortunate that Hungary, through the voice of its representatives, considers that the current interest justifies the repeated infringement of Article 2 TEU. The reintroduction of the death penalty and the institutional attitude towards the phenomenon of migration are sufficiently serious reasons to determine a common and firm position on the part of the Member States against the position of the Prime Minister of Hungary, Viktor Orbán. I believe that, in the case of Hungary, we are in a situation where the statements of ephemeral leaders affect the reputation of an entire people. Viktor Orbán's vision does not correspond to European principles, but, I am sure, neither do those of the majority of Hungarian citizens. That is why we need to pay close attention to the impact that an action by the European Parliament or the European Commission has on the lives of citizens of an EU Member State, regardless of whether it is a state whose leaders do not live up to the commitments made by other states.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: in writing.- The repeated violations of human rights by the government of Viktor Orbán are unacceptable.Before his lamentable behavior towards refugees, we had already denounced the obstacles to press freedom, human rights abuses, the criminalization of the most disadvantaged and the questioning of abortion rights.Orbán does not embody any of the European values;Europe and even more the European party of which it is a member cannot turn a blind eye indefinitely!

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the joint motion for a resolution of the European Parliament on the situation in Hungary. Indeed I believe that the Commission should start immediately to act on the threats to democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights in this country. So far, the Commission’s assessment of developments in Hungary are far below the reality of the country and I regret that it focuses on marginal, technical aspects of the legislation, while ignoring the trends, patterns and combined effect of measures.

name: Isabelle THOMAS
text: in writing. - As the situation has deteriorated in Hungary since the election of Victor Orbán in 2010, the European Parliament adopted a resolution in June 2015 inviting the European Commission to conduct an in-depth investigation into the abuses of this government. Despite the obvious attacks on the rights of the opposition and freedom of the press, the violation of the independence of the judiciary, state xenophobia, corruption and arbitrary detentions, the Commission of Jean-Claude Juncker seems paralyzed . Against this inertia, we urge the Commission to act. The Socialists advocated activating Article 7, paragraph 1, of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, which makes it possible to severely punish a country that violates the fundamental texts of the Union, as the government of Victor Orbán does. , by welcoming the launch of a European citizens' initiative in this direction. However, we lost by a dozen votes because the PPE group, which includes Fidesz, the party of Victor Orbán, and the French "Republicans", mobilized to prevent the vote in favor of article 7. For them, once again, human rights and the future of Europe take precedence over their immediate partisan interests.

name: László TŐKÉS
text: in writing.- I voted against the parliamentary resolution on the situation in Hungary because it is completely unacceptable, both procedurally and substantively.In a statement sent to Parliament and at the December plenary, the European Commission stated orally that it had examined and continuously monitored the situation in Hungary and stated that neither the rule of law mechanism nor the conditions for activating Article 7 were present in Hungary.Ignoring the findings of the European Commission, the decision now submitted is another list of lies and indictments against Hungary.The text is malicious, panting for revenge, and no longer seeks the appearance of objectivity.The European Parliament cannot afford such a voice against any Member State.

name: Valdemar TOMAŠEVSKI
text: in writing.- On the situation in Hungary, I voted against the PE resolution.The vocabulary used in the resolution, which gives the impression of condemnation, is not acceptable.The Hungarian parliament and government have been elected in a democratic way, and the resolution gives the impression that this is being forgotten.The public supports the recovery of this state and the improvement of the economic situation.The European institutions should not ignore this fact, nor should they brutally interfere in Hungary's internal affairs, as this shows a lack of respect for the will of the majority of Hungarian citizens, which is the foundation of democracy, to rebuild the state.That should be noted before biasing someone.The content of the resolution is not objective, it is full of prejudices and stereotypes.For these reasons, it is not worth endorsing.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: written.- The European Parliament adopted a resolution on Hungary on 10 June 2015, asking the Commission to urgently investigate the situation regarding respect for democracy and fundamental human rights, and the potential threat that could lead to a violation of Article 7 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union -with this resolution, Parliament asks the Commission to provide an answer to the previous one.Since the task of maintaining compliance with and ensuring compliance with the Treaty by the Member States of the Union is the exclusive competence of the European Commission (according to Article 17 of the same Treaty), I believe that it shouldcertain groups in the European Parliament.

name: Romana TOMC
text: in writing.- I did not support the resolution on the situation in Hungary, as it did not take into account the facts proposed by the ELS political group.I think the resolution of the ELS was much better and contained the facts that I am defending.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: written.- We voted in favor because the Resolution on the situation in Hungary affects the defense of human rights and denounces that the Hungarian Government is carrying out policies that systematically violate fundamental and democratic rights in Hungary.Viktor Orban's government has launched multiple public campaigns criminalizing refugees, portraying them as criminals, invaders and terrorists.Hungary, as part of the European Union, must comply with its legal and international commitments.Likewise, it is intolerable that a country of the Union headed by its government is carrying out xenophobic policies and launching messages of intolerance in the face of the greatest humanitarian crisis in recent years, instead of being the guarantor of the human and fundamental rights of those whothey flee from war, hunger and misery.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: written.- We voted in favor because the Resolution on the situation in Hungary affects the defense of human rights and denounces that the Hungarian Government is carrying out policies that systematically violate fundamental and democratic rights in Hungary.Viktor Orban's government has launched multiple public campaigns criminalizing refugees, portraying them as criminals, invaders and terrorists.Hungary, as part of the European Union, must comply with its legal and international commitments.Likewise, it is intolerable that a country of the Union headed by its government is carrying out xenophobic policies and launching messages of intolerance in the face of the greatest humanitarian crisis in recent years, instead of being the guarantor of the human and fundamental rights of those whothey flee from war, hunger and misery.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution because I agree that the situation in Hungary does not seem to be in line with European values and there is a need to stress the importance of the basic principles applied in the European Union. The EU is founded on the values of respect for human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality, the rule of law and respect for human rights, including the rights of people belonging to minorities, and these values are universal and common to all Member States. Recent developments and measures taken over the past few years in Hungary have led to a serious systemic deterioration in the situation as regards the rule of law and fundamental rights, inter alia freedom of expression, including academic freedom, the human rights of migrants, asylum seekers and refugees, freedom of assembly and association, restrictions and obstructions to the activities of civil society organisations, the right to equal treatment, the rights of people belonging to minorities, including Roma, Jews and LGBTI people, social rights, the functioning of the constitutional system, the independence of the judiciary and of other institutions and many worrying allegations of corruption and conflicts of interest.

name: Derek VAUGHAN
text: in writing. ‒ The situation Hungary is becoming increasingly concerning. Therefore I backed a resolution calling on Hungary to remember its position in the EU in regard to Human Rights and particularly with regard to its responsibilities for the humane treatment of refugees. All Member States are required to comply fully with EU rules and all legislation must be compatible with this overarching framework – it is concerning that some legislation in Hungary that has recently gone through may fall short of these standards. We in the Parliament have frequently called the Council’s attention to this issue and believe that the Commission and the Council are undermining the principle of mutual and sincere cooperation by not moving to meet these concerns. The Commission must continue its investigations and use all of its tools to solve this problem.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: written.- Hungary is confronted daily with the problems that the refugee crisis entails.However, this can never be an excuse for not respecting basic human rights and adopting laws on asylum that are contrary to European law.This resolution criticizes these violations and increases pressure on the European Commission to take effective action.We urgently need to set an example that we do not accept this in our European Union and that we will continue to defend our fundamental rights.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: in writing. - I welcome the adoption of this new resolution on the situation in Hungary presented by the GUE / NGL, Verts / ALE, S & amp; S and ALDE groups (327 for, 293 against and 67 abstentions). However, I deplore the rejection, by a very small majority, of the possibility for the LIBE committee to draw up a new report allowing progress to be made in the possible sanctions for those who violate the fundamental rights of the Union. This resolution once again calls on the Commission, as in June 2015, to finally carry out an assessment of the situation of fundamental rights in Hungary, criticizing it for limiting itself to technical procedures that are often ineffective. The attacks and violations committed over the years by the Hungarian government are an illustration of the deterioration of fundamental rights in Hungary, as in many other countries of the Union. The Union's ability to respond to threats to the rule of law and fundamental rights in the Union is more than a symbol of the viability of the Union. Both the Commission and the Member States through the Council and the majority political parties should be aware of this and move on from words to action.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. - The Hungarian government's actions have, over the years, severely deteriorated the situation in terms of democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights. With regard to the treatment of the right of asylum, refugees or even, hostile actions and hate speech directed at groups such as Roma, Jews, the LGBTI community, migrants, homeless people and other poor people, emerges the need for a position that condemns these practices that violate the values ​​of human dignity. The hasty measures passed in recent months, which made access to international protection extremely difficult, criminalized, without justification, migrants and asylum seekers, as well as the growing recourse to the detention of asylum seekers and xenophobic speeches associating migrants social problems or security risks, reach the limits of the tolerable and cannot be tolerated. However, it is also important to denounce the hypocrisy of the EU which, in this matter, has been building a policy for migration that, in practice, is based on repressive measures that end up at the root of all this humanitarian drama that the world is witnessing and that they demand measures that this EU clearly has no political will to take.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: written.- With its effective border protection, Hungary has proven that this is possible.Hungary should be seen as a trailblazer, but the motions for resolutions take an anti-Hungarian stance.Therefore I reject them.

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: NI), in writing. - The KKE MEP condemns the reactionary and anti-popular policy of the Hungarian bourgeois government which targets refugees, immigrants and attacks workers' rights and freedoms in order to serve the interests of the monopolies. Employees from bourgeois governments and the EU in all its Member States are subject to a similar anti-popular attack in many ways. But the joint resolution of the Social Democrats - GUE - Liberals and Greens hypocritically uses the reactionary Hungarian government to legitimize the EU and its institutions and the subjugation of the peoples to the chains of the Euro-road and to declare this imperialist transnational union protector of the people's freedoms, in an "honorary" and body for the enforcement of the "democratic values" and "principles" of the EU, ie the interests of the bourgeoisie. The KKE does not legitimize and does not recognize any right to self-proclaim defenders of popular rights and freedoms, the EU, governments and civil management parties that crush the lives and rights of working peoples. Only the Hungarian people, like any other people, have the exclusive right to overthrow anti-popular policies, to free themselves by force and struggle from the shackles of the exploitation of capital and its wolf alliances, and to seize power and wealth it produces.

name: Kosma ZŁOTOWSKI
text: in writing. - Stigmatizing member states and censoring the actions of a democratically elected government is a very bad practice and action that cannot be justified. EU institutions financed by taxpayers' money cannot be used as a tool to discipline those states that express legitimate doubts about European federalism. This resolution is not just bad for its content, but bad because it proves that the European Parliament is trying to usurp the right to discipline and review the policies of democratically elected authorities. Such action is neither in line with the Treaties nor with the spirit of the model of European integration that we have adopted. I would like to emphasize that every action of this type and any attempt to transfer the discussion about internal affairs of sovereign states to the European forum will result in a further drop in trust in European institutions. We already know that the European Parliament is planning to take similar steps towards Poland and to review the reforms carried out by the new Polish government. Such an action must be objectionable, as it violates the principle of sovereignty, which is a fundamental value for states that have liberated themselves from the yoke of communism. I would like to assure our European partners once again that neither in Hungary nor in Poland the political situation requires intervention at the EU level and the adoption of similar resolutions. Of course, I voted against this text.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: in writing. - (PT) I voted in favor of the joint motion for a resolution on the situation in Hungary because I believe that Member States must fully respect EU law. It is based on respect for human dignity, human rights, freedom, democracy, equality, and the rule of law, universal and common values ​​for all full EU Member States. In view of recent developments and measures adopted over the past few years in Hungary, particularly with regard to limitations on freedom of expression, the human rights of migrants, asylum seekers and refugees, freedom of assembly and association, restrictions on the activities of civil society organizations, the right to equal treatment and minority rights, I see Hungary as a test for the EU to demonstrate its capacity and political commitment to react to threats and cases of violations of its own values fundamental by a Member State and, as such, I consider the Commission's 10 December infringement procedure to be important to ensure that Hungary - or any other Member State - fulfills its obligations under EU law and respect their underlying values, returning to the usual procedures when revoking the adopted emergency measures.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. - This resolution builds on previous initiatives on Hungary that have been promoted in the European Parliament. Country with a reactionary, proto-fascist government, which has implemented a set of measures to restrict democratic freedoms, individual and collective, imposing an authoritarian regime towards its own. This posture extends even more vile to those who arrive in that country, due to the mass exodus of thousands of migrants, with reports of mistreatment, aggression and neglect, to which is added the wall that shames everyone, but that does not it is already a unique reference among Member States. Following this framework, the European Parliament voted this resolution, which is a treaty on interference on the one hand, with an unacceptable call for the activation of Article 7 of the Treaty on European Union, and hypocrisy on the other, when it vehemently criticizes the Hungary's stance in the migratory crisis, at a time when the entire European Union's policy on migration is based on the return of the vast majority of migrants it receives, without being able to respond in a dignified manner, immediately, to its most basic needs.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: That concludes the explanations of vote.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: The next item is the report by Cristian Dan Preda, on behalf of the Committee on Foreign Affairs, on the 2014 Annual Report on Human Rights and Democracy in the World and the EU's policy on the matter (2015/2229 (INI)) (A8-0344 / 2015).

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: Rapporteur. - Commissioner Stylianides, I would first like to welcome your presence and that of the Special Representative for Human Rights, Mr Stavros Lambrinidis, in today's debate on the report on human rights and democracy in the world and the Union's policy in this regard. I strongly believe that interinstitutional dialogue is essential for increasing the effectiveness of external action to promote respect for human rights and the democratic principles of the Union in third countries. In this interinstitutional dialogue, but especially in communication with citizens, the report I have written and negotiated with other political groups aims to explain Parliament's vision of how the European Union has promoted human rights and democracy. in its external relations in 2014. I also took the opportunity to explain Parliament's vision of the steps the Union should take to improve its foreign policy on human rights and democracy. In the following I will dwell on several aspects of the report, a very broad one, with more than thirty pages. One of the key messages that the report conveys is that the time has come to focus on implementing the European Union's human rights and democracy policy. Over the last four years, the Union has developed a number of instruments to promote these values, inter alia in response to numerous calls from the European Parliament. We currently have a very good strategic framework that guides the actions of the European Union. A second action plan was adopted this year, which translates into action the axes set out in the strategic framework. The Union regularly organizes human rights dialogues with third countries, as well as political dialogues, in which rights are addressed. The Union has, again as a result of numerous requests from Parliament, a very good special representative for human rights. The Union also developed strategies for the promotion of human rights for each country, and delegations set up coordination centers for the same issues. We have an enlargement policy that promotes rights, just like the recently revised neighborhood policy. It is time, I think, to use all these tools effectively to maximize their impact on respect for human rights in various third countries. We must have the courage to fully assume the objective set out in Article 21 of the Treaty, which is to place the protection of human rights at the heart of the Union's external action. In this regard, we have proposed in the report some courses of action that can be followed. Among them, I think it is essential to allocate sufficient resources to human rights and democracy policy. Resources can be used, among other things, to support those who fight every day for respect for democratic values ​​and rights and principles in third countries. In this regard, I welcome the new support mechanism for human rights defenders working in risky contexts, announced a few days ago by Commissioner Mimica. A second key message I wanted to convey is that supporting and promoting democracy in external relations must not play a secondary role in Union policy. On the contrary, I believe that respect for democratic principles and human rights go hand in hand and can hardly be thought of separately. I have also drawn attention to the fact that, in order to truly promote democratic principles, the Union cannot limit itself to observing elections in third countries, although this is certainly an important tool for promoting democracy. In conclusion, I would like to return to the interinstitutional relations we were talking about, as well as the communication with European citizens. From this perspective, I consider it important that the report which the Commission draws up each year to take a more analytical approach and to highlight efforts in this area.

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, it is a great honour for me to take the floor at this discussion on behalf of High Representative Federica Mogherini, a discussion which coincides with the Sakharov Prize ceremony, an occasion that testifies to the strong commitment of this House to human rights and freedom of expression. As your report states at the outset, Mr Preda, human rights and democratic freedoms are increasingly under threat in many parts of the world. Defending human rights is becoming an ever harder challenge for all of us, in particular, promoting and helping to protect a healthy space for civil society organisations. We are confronted with unprecedented global challenges, with instability and conflicts just beyond our borders, and with a humanitarian crisis even within our borders. Terrorist attacks were brought into the centre of our cities, and they are posing an ever—growing challenge to our free and open societies. However, while the years ahead will continue to be challenging for the European Union, our approach cannot change. We need more equality and more human rights, not less.  To defeat terror, we surely need to improve law enforcement tools. But, at the same time, we need to work harder to secure inclusion. While we need to address conflicts at the roots of the immigration crisis, we also need to build inclusive societies and equality of rights. While receiving asylum seekers and migrants, freedom of expression remains the most powerful weapon against radicalisation and terrorism.  Mr Preda, honourable Members, your call for placing human rights and democracy at the heart of the EU external relations will not go unheard. The protection of human rights is, and will remain, one of the major priorities of our external action, and it is the foundation that defines all our relations with third countries.  This is precisely the rationale of the EU’s second Action Plan on Human Rights and Democracy, which the Council adopted just five months ago. This new Action Plan shows the common will of the EU, not just of the institutions, but also of the 28 Member States together: to continue and enhance their global efforts on defending and promoting human rights and on mainstreaming human rights into all EU policies. This includes development cooperation, migration, counterterrorism and trade.  The Action Plan puts high on the agenda the promotion of gender equality also, women’s empowerment and women’s and girls’ rights. It will serve to measure coherence and coordination between our internal and external policies. Overall, it outlines our priorities on human rights in external action and details our strategy for the years to come.  The Action Plan gives a very special focus to empowering local actors and civil society organisations in an increasingly challenging landscape. We need civil society organisations to play an active role in the lives of their countries to the benefit of everyone. During the last years, efforts to bar, restrain, or control the work of civil society organisations have been frequent. Restrictive laws have emerged, imposing unjustified and complicated procedures for the registration of associations, or restrictions on their funding, in particular from foreign sources. Civil society organisations in our neighbourhood and beyond need our support more than ever. Just two weeks ago, we devoted the yearly NGO Forum, jointly organised by the EEAS and civil society, to the issue of protecting and promoting the space of civil society. Hundreds of NGOs attended and Federica Mogherini addressed the closing session. She conveyed the relevance that the Commission and the EU as a whole attach to the essential cooperation with civil society in the protection and promotion of Human Rights in the world, and within the European Union.  This was a first step in a long-term process of cooperation. The EU will continue engaging on this issue. Of course, the Action Plan looks at a number of other priorities. This includes a number of topics that you recall in your report and which we have many times discussed together. For example, we will continue to work on a responsible trade policy, or on promoting the EU agenda on business and human rights. We also want to make social and economic rights increasingly part of our human rights policy. And last but not least, we will use the full range of the policy instruments we have at our disposal. In this context, let me thank you again for the great and extensive contribution of your report.  Regarding proposals, suggestions and constructive criticism: these are of great value to us. As you suggest, we are working on improving our human rights strategies, making the human rights dialogues and consultations more result-oriented, and assessing the implementation of the guidelines. As regards the annual report, we have already advanced in making it clearer, more analytical and user-friendly from next year. I understand that you are also working on enhancing the EP actions on human rights. I very much welcome, for example, your work on reviewing the guidelines for the EP interparliamentary delegations. It is very welcome. Our work does not end, but begins, with the adoption of the Action Plan. Putting it into practice will be a living process where all actors will make their contribution. In that regard, you are, of course, our privileged partners. Our actions on human rights and democracy are mutually reinforcing. As just one example, I can mention the role Members of Parliament play as chief observers of election observation missions. Together with you are the other EU institutions, our Member States and our EU Special Representative Stavros Lambrinidis, who is sitting next to me and who is doing a great job. Thank you, Stavros. (Applause)  We all need to join forces and cooperate even further in pursuing the ambitious objectives of our Action Plan. Despite the severe challenges ahead of us, I am sure that we can make further progress, always together.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: The next speaker  is the third speaker, but the second from Romania – it is Romanian domination here this afternoon! – on behalf of the Committee on Development.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Development. – Mr President, above all unity, I think, is very important for all of us. I welcome the final agreement reached on the opinion on the Annual Report of Human Rights and Democracy in the World 2014. Negotiations had been positive and enriching and I believe the opinion will support the work of our colleagues from other committees, especially from the Committee on Foreign Affairs (AFET). We made a strong connection between insisting on human rights, gender equality, good governance, peace and security, and the goal of eradicating poverty and inequalities as well as achieving the social development goals in the world. Moreover, we recalled that cultural diversity cannot be invoked for infringing human rights which are guaranteed by international law. Human rights must be at the core of our development agenda. We therefore stressed the need to ensure that the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development is underpinned by the human rights-based approach. We mentioned the importance of the Addis Ababa Action Agenda. And we decided to strongly condemn, in the opinion, the use of  harmful practices on women and the use of rape as a weapon of war. Last but not least, we reminded the Commission and Member States that agreements concluded with developing countries must include binding clauses on human rights and that the Commission must conduct systematic human rights impact assessments of trade and investment agreements. Îl felicit pe raportor și pe toți cei care au contribuit la acest raport.

name: Andrzej GRZYB
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr Chairman! Today's ceremony of presenting the Sakharov to Mr Raif Badawi, or rather to his wife Haidar, how strongly she confirmed our - the European Parliament - strong commitment to human rights. At this point, I would also like to thank my colleague Cristian Dan Preda for continuing this path of annual and multi-dimensional reports on human rights in the world. I would like to point out that the main aim of the reports is to ensure coherence between the internal and external policies of the Union in the field of respect for human rights and democratic values, which is why we attach so much importance to this cooperation, which works between the European institutions and its delegations abroad to ensure that all these the institutions spoke in one coherent voice. I would like to welcome the adoption of the new Human Rights Action Plan up to 2019. The adoption of these five strategic areas represents a renewed commitment to a systematic and focused approach on human rights and democracy. I also want to highlight the human rights dialogue with third countries. It is an important tool that enables not only involvement and cooperation for the promotion of human rights, but also a significant change in many member states. Here I thank Mr Stavros Lambrinidis, who mentioned a number of countries at a meeting in the Subcommittee on Human Rights, where significant progress has been made. I would like to emphasize the importance of the issue of freedom of thought, conscience, religion and belief. It remains a constant challenge. Many minorities, especially Christians in the Middle East, are persecuted, wounded, tortured and killed in numerous places in the world, and their gathering places, not only Christians but many other religious minorities, are being destroyed. I would like to remind you that the right to believe is a fundamental human right recognized in the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, which is guaranteed by the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights.

name: Pier Antonio PANZERI
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I thank Mr Preda and I thank Stavros Lambrinidis for the work that has been done in recent times. I hope that we all agree in considering the European Parliament's annual report on human rights not an empty and rhetorical ritual, but the fact that it represents an important moment of evaluation of the policies implemented by the European Union and of indication of what it is necessary to do for the future. Commissioner, we live in a time in which rights are indicated as a luxury incompatible with the economic crisis, with the reduction of financial resources, with free trade agreements, with the need for stability and the urgency of ensuring protection and security. to a public opinion increasingly lost and frightened in the face of the terrorist wave. But we must ask ourselves: when the promise of rights is not fulfilled or removed, what are we taking our leave of? We must be aware that when individual rights, civil rights, those concerning work, health, education are restricted, well, it affects the premises of a democracy. So, let's be clear, and let's try to say things for what they are, it is not the rights that are insatiable, it is instead the claim of the economy to establish which rights are compatible with it. Hence the reflection on rights takes us to the heart of a cultural discussion that goes beyond contingency and reveals how the references to the economic crisis or the new geopolitics have only made more evident a much deeper transformation and conflict concerning the very node in which we must look at the evolution of our societies and of global society itself. We have no doubts. Precisely in such difficult times, more rights are needed, not fewer rights, and the criteria for their distribution must be based on the obligation to make their implementation possible. Because the problem we have is not the excess of rights, but their denial, determined by inequalities, poverty, conflicts, discrimination and violence against women, which erase the very dignity of the person. Here a problem arises for us, a problem arises for our consistency. It would be appropriate to demonstrate that we are not afraid to affirm the rights towards anyone, that we do not profess excessive realism and that we do not have guilty hypocrisy on ourselves. To meet this challenge everywhere, there must be a great capacity on the part of the European Union to insist on these issues and truly demonstrate the necessary coherence; to win this challenge on rights and to win it everywhere and to affirm the fact that this context, which is the civil, democratic context represented by Europe, still has something to say in the world.

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, as a long-time member of Amnesty International I have to come to the conclusion that this Parliament can be the most effective advocate of human rights in the world. The Annual Report shows us that globalisation does not only send goods and money and investments around the world, but also values and good ideas. Today there are more democracies in the world than ever before. By the way, I do not know of any democracy which does not have a market-driven economic system implemented, and more countries than ever have abolished the death penalty.  However, let me be quite frank here today. In the course of the discussions with members of other political groups, I have come to the conclusion that some of them misuse human rights to ride their ideological hobby horses. What do the Raif Badawis in the prisons of the world think when they hear that this report elaborates on financial transactions and labour standards? What do they think when they hear that there are demands of social dialogues and labour standards, medical policies and climate change?  Of course, in the end, all committees of this House have dealt and deal with issues which have something to do with humans. But if the Subcommittee on Human Rights keeps on ever expanding the definition of human rights, then we might as well close down all other committees of this House. More importantly, we divide and divert the attention given to those who really need our engagement for human rights. Therefore, in order to send a signal, the ECR political group will this time abstain. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Blue card question.- Honorable Member.You mentioned that one of the greatest European values that we have, moreover, succeeded in adopting more widely is the abolition of the death penalty, and indeed I think so.At the same time, I believe that the credibility of the European Union is greatly undermined by the fact that there are Member States where this is set up as a legitimate debate over and over again.I ask you what means, in addition to the rhetorical changes, you see so that we can suppress such voices once and for all within the European Union, that is, those that impose the death penalty.

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: blue-card answer. – To my knowledge, no country in the European Union has the death penalty, and I am quite sure that in Europe it is only Belarus which still has the death penalty. All other countries in Europe have abolished it. Unfortunately, that is not the case for most Islamic states, where I think only Turkey has abolished the death penalty. Even the abolition of the death penalty in Turkey is basically due to pressure from the European Union.

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, 2014 was certainly not a good year when it comes to human rights and democracy in the world. 26 pages of the European Parliament’s Annual Report, I believe, is a sad manifestation of this. To me, this only proves two main things.  First of all, it is for us, the European Union and its Member States, to make sure that we will remain an example to be followed. 2014, and now even more so 2015, proved the opposite. The tendencies are rather worrisome. Secondly, it is time to come back to the very basics. It is a primary responsibility of the European Union to find the ways and means of how to be more effective in dealing with freedom of expression, freedom of thought, conscience and religion and freedom of assembly and association.  If it continues like this we may end up with a 2015 report containing 70 pages, I am afraid.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr President, I largely agree with this report, and in particular with its holistic approach. I welcome the importance given to the coherence between internal and external policies which is, in my view, fundamental if we want to continue to defend the universality, but also the indivisibility of human rights. The rhetoric still needs to be put into practice, especially by the Member States. We must also avoid a relativism that we denounce elsewhere and refrain from favoring trade, including that of arms, over the universal values ​​of the declaration of the same name. The ideological hobbies are not necessarily where you think they are. I am surprised that our rapporteur has tabled an amendment aimed at distorting recital U of the report. Yes, the world economy is going through a serious crisis that has serious repercussions on economic and social rights, here and elsewhere. This crisis is not over and economic and social rights are being violated, it is a fact. I also regret the obsessions of this European Parliament on a number of countries, admittedly less pronounced than in the past. I recognize the human rights abuses that are committed in these countries, but I think of all those who are forgotten and where the situation is often even more serious. I am thinking of the Horn of Africa, and in particular of Sudan and Eritrea. I am thinking of Turkey and Egypt, where the situation continues to worsen, but also of the Gulf countries, on this day when we have just awarded the Sakharov Prize to Raif Badawi. I am also wondering what the reference to the EUNAVFOR Med operation is, which we know will not solve much and which poses new risks for migrants. That is why, Mr President, the GUE / NGL group will abstain on this report.

name: Barbara LOCHBIHLER
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - Mister President! As every year, this annual report on human rights and democracy in the world 2014 and EU policies in this area is a comprehensive report that gives a good overview of the EU's many-faceted engagements. Keeping human rights in the heart, at the center of EU politics, is a guiding principle that is very often found in Commission and parliamentary papers. This is also an important alignment for all EU policies. However, looking back at 2014 and 2015, this principle seems to me to have become a bit stale. The images of desperate war refugees at the EU's external borders are too memorable, the refusal to accept refugees into the EU is too shameful. Even the High Representative Mogherini has warned that this could damage the EU's reputation for pursuing value-based policies. EU refugee and migration policy would do well to strictly adhere to international law and not to water down protection standards. As foreseen in the Juncker Plan, we must expand the possibilities of legal admission and, with generous humanitarian aid, alleviate the plight of the people in the refugee camps around the war zones in the Middle East and Africa. I would like to briefly address two subjects in the annual report in particular. There is the issue of sport and human rights, an issue of increasing importance, especially in view of the upcoming soccer world championships in Russia and Qatar and the Olympic Games in Beijing. It is good that we are talking about sport and human rights in the report and expressing our concern that some of the biggest sporting events are often held in authoritarian states with devastating human rights records. Major sporting events should be consistent with human rights. The assessment of the specific human rights situation in a country must be the decisive criterion for the award of a major event. It is very regrettable that there is no reference whatsoever in the European Union's new human rights action plan on sport and human rights. The final topic: the fight against impunity. The EU and its member states have long-standing and proven supporters of international law and, in particular, of victims' rights. This is shown, for example, by the support of the International Criminal Court and the guidelines for the promotion of international humanitarian law. Support for the International Criminal Court at the highest political level is more important than ever. My question to the Commission and the EEAS is now: How do you see your role in warning of serious violations of international law and in advocating that perpetrators are brought to justice?

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: Do you accept a blue card from Mr Lucke?

name: Barbara LOCHBIHLER
text: (Verts / ALE Group).- No, I think it makes more sense to continue the discussion.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, again this year we are debating and voting on the report on human rights and democracy. A considerable effort for which I am going to thank Mr Preda, rapporteur, also done with the best of intentions. Indeed, we call for the promotion of human rights outside and inside the EU and we also ask for support for democratic states and the rule of law. We applaud our ambitious action plans, dust off the always betrayed conditionality and also compassion for the atrocious fate of refugees and migrants. But it is enough to glance at the concrete choices of the EU and the Member States to see how the usual applications of the principles with two weights and two measures are according to the usefulness and importance of the interlocutor; to see the criminal work in Africa, South America and Asia, of our multinationals who grab land and natural and human resources without even looking their victims in the face. Moreover, austerity policies deny human rights, even in our countries. So again this year, I am afraid that the actions of the Union will be far from our intentions and will fade again in the hypocritical application we have seen so far, just like the Christmas we will celebrate. Best wishes to everyone and especially to those who can not be ashamed of "business as usual" and above all still manage to lie to themselves. Many uncomfortable and hypocritical wishes.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: on behalf of the ENF group. - Mr President, European civilization is at the origin of the proclamation of human rights, it is one of those titles of glory of which we can be proud. But to effectively protect human rights, it is still necessary to be able to identify real priorities, which is not the case with the European Union. Its 2014 report on human rights in the world indeed retains four false priorities, presented in point 4 as the major internal challenges of the Union, namely: the situation of the Roma, the treatment of migrants, LGBTI people and racism would be victims. The Union thus gives in, once again, to its immigrationist whims and to the LGBTI lobby. In my opinion, the real priorities lie elsewhere. It is first of all the fight against Islamist terrorism. Not to say so amounts to disrespecting the memory of the 130 victims of the Paris attacks. It is then about the fight against extreme poverty. Due to the economic crisis, there are more and more homeless people in Europe. In France alone, there are more than 30,000 homeless children, but who cares? The 2014 report also affirms that the Union places human rights at the center of its international relations. But why is she then making a pact with states like Turkey or Qatar, whose attitude is equivocal towards the Islamic State group? In reality, the Union exploits human rights for two reasons: first, to give itself a semblance of respectability and to try to make people forget that it is above all at the service of banks and international lobbies; then, to justify its enlargement policy, which is analyzed in point 46 of the report as "one of the most powerful tools for strengthening human rights". But the peoples of Europe are understanding the fraud. The Union's deadly supranationalism will not pass.

name: Udo VOIGT
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen! We heard a lot about freedom of expression today at the Sakharov Prize. I can fully support what President Schulz said, including what is here in Mr Preda's report. But I ask myself: where is the implementation of human rights and freedom of expression in Europe? Do you actually know that in Germany alone there are over 1,000 patriots in prison just because they have given their opinion? Well, Mr Badawi was imprisoned for ten years, but in Germany my friend Horst Mahler was imprisoned for ten and a half, twelve and a half years just because he freely expressed his opinion. His leg was amputated in the seventh year of his imprisonment because he was diabetic and did not have sufficient freedom of movement. In the spring of Greece, I was able to see for myself how seven national MPs for the Golden Dawn were imprisoned in a prison that was unworthy of Europe. To date, no charges have been served on these seven people. We are currently witnessing a party being banned in Greece. Does this have anything to do with freedom of expression? My party, the NPD, is to be banned in Germany. Does this have anything to do with freedom of expression? If so, then freedom of expression should apply to everyone in Europe before we look to Third World countries.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: - Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Rapporteur Predi on this report, which I think has improved the quality of these annual reports on human rights in the world, and Article 21 of the Lisbon Treaty commits the European Union to a common foreign and security policy. , the universality and indivisibility of human rights. In this regard, I particularly welcome the adoption of the ambitious Sustainable Development Plan for 2013, as well as the leading role played by the European Union in this process. It is now, of course, necessary to ensure that this program, its monitoring measures and its implementation are truly based on a human rights-based approach. That is why the EPP Club within the Committee on Development insists on guaranteeing the promotion of human rights through development policy. We insist that together with our partners we annually monitor the progress and results related to sustainable development goal no. 16 which promotes the building of inclusive societies based on respect for human rights and democratic principles. It is this sustainable goal that must be the priority of our foreign, and thus development policy, and that is where we need to focus funds from the European Development Fund and the Development Cooperation Instrument. In this sense, I think we should not hesitate to use a “more for more” approach, but of course implying that we interpret this principle in such a way as to guarantee the basic human rights and dignity of every human person.

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: - Mr President, I would like to start by congratulating Mr Preda on his report, of course, and I would also like to regret that Mr Lambrinidis cannot speak in this plenary, in this House. I really liked the Commissioner's speech, but I think it is very important that we take the appropriate decisions so that Mr Lambrinidis - whose task is recognized by all - can express himself in this House. It is time for us to change some of the very outdated mechanisms that we have; We would all be delighted to hear from Mr Lambrinidis who, as I say, is recognized by all and whose task is being essential to promote human rights in the world. Since Mr Lambrinidis cannot take the floor, I will repeat a phrase that I have heard him these days: 'no one will respect Europe if we only care about money'. I think that phrase by Mr Lambrinidis pretty much sums up what many of us want to express. The problem, Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, is that the very concept of the universality of human rights is in question at the moment. This is precisely why the European Union has to be stronger in defending this value. In many regions of the world it is questioned that the values ​​that we defend are universal values, and I believe that in this we cannot lower our guard. I believe that the world needs a strong and rearmed European Union more than ever in its defense of human rights. I also believe that it benefits us enormously to be energetic in the defense of human rights and democracy. Not all benefits are measured in millions of euros. There are many benefits that are measured in dignity, in political force when it comes to being consistent with what we think. If we don't really stand up for what we think, I don't really know what we're going to become. This has not been a good year. The disaster of managing the crisis of immigrants and refugees will remain on everyone's mind and in the history of Europe. I know that the European Union is not responsible. Rather, the Member States are, but in any case I believe that it is something that must be urgently corrected because it is very difficult to teach the world lessons if one is not able to even set an example in one's own space of responsibility. So refugees and women, who continue to need, as has been demonstrated today, our support, are the protagonists of this report, on which I congratulate myself at this time.

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: – Mr President, it is pleasing indeed that this year’s Preda report has remained far more focused on fundamental core human rights issues, in stark contrast to previous annual reports – and I have spoken on many of them – which included a host of less pressing and somewhat divisive issues, way beyond the fundamental civil and political rights, to include all sorts of new social and economic areas which undermine and dilute the basic message we should be propagating.  Our main focus in the European Union should be to continue to stop people from being tortured, unjustly imprisoned or executed and to intervene in countries run by extreme and brutal dictators, not to constantly push the limits of the definition of human rights to include less significant economic and social dialogues. Increasingly, the human rights concept is being extended and linked to the larger context of interdependence with other domains of EU activity and ambition, including things such as trade negotiations. I believe that this broadened scope of the EU human rights endeavour is debatable in itself, but we must, however, not lose sight of the need to forcefully address and prioritise gross violations as our priority. The challenge is how to mainstream human rights into other areas of activity without losing our focus and risking our credibility.

name: Marietje SCHAAKE
text: – Mr President, the list of real problems and threats to people’s universal rights is long and daunting: restrictions on speech, discrimination against women, threats to civil society. On the other hand, European instruments, guidelines, programmes and budget lines offer many opportunities for solutions. In reality, their success and the ability of the EU to push for real change depends on our willingness to lead politically. We can only lead credibly if it is by example. As we speak, in Europe today refugees and asylum seekers are treated and talked about in inhumane ways. That does not do justice to the painful lessons we have learned in history or to the promise this continent has for the next generation. Human rights are too often treated as a soft issue while I believe it is in our interest, and of course it is our responsibility, to be a beacon for those who are facing repression, intimidation, violence, torture or even death. Particularly the young generation growing up in, for example, North Africa and the Middle East, looks to Europe and sees a lot of deal making – deals with Turkey on refugees, deals with Iran on the nuclear problem. We cannot allow these deals and our interests to overshadow the key issue of human rights. I really want to object to this kind of cynical deal-making and urge all of us to recognise that we are at a critical moment in a changing world and it is important that we give meaning to our responsibilities. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: Ask about the “blue card” procedure.- Ms. Schaake, thank you very much for accepting my question after Ms. Lochbihler just pinched - which I have seldom experienced.But I would like to ask you the same question: you are right to point out that there is inhuman behavior in the EU, that refugees are treated inhumanly, and it is Greece in particular that is at the center of the criticism there.The European Court of Human Rights and the ECJ have referred to this in many judgments since 2009.The other European states are not allowed to return refugees to Greece.Do you agree with me that the European Union should then make its aid payments to Greece conditional on Greece treating its refugees with human dignity?

name: Marietje SCHAAKE
text: blue-card answer. – I understand that you are seeking a kind of provocation to express your criticism of Greece, and you are free to do that, but I really think that we are at a critical moment where we have to look for real solutions. I see that in more cooperation, in giving humane shelter to asylum seekers and people fleeing violence in the Middle East, but also in finding solutions to those wars. It cannot be that we only recognise the importance of doing something when the challenge of violence through terrorism, or the challenge of asylum seekers through refugees, touches our own territory. Our role in this world is connected to that of others, and we have to work together in Europe to come up with real solutions.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: GUE / NGL). - Mr President, the defense of human rights must be the crowning achievement of this Parliament. Defending the wronged must be the goal of our lives, especially as representatives of the peoples of Europe. Today we honored Raif Badawi but at the same time we maintain our financial relations with this existing caliphate of Saudi Arabia. Isn't this hypocrisy? Ms Mogherini went to Iran, said various things about oil, but did not utter a word about the public hanging there of dissidents from cranes and lampposts. At present, part of southeastern Turkey is occupied by the government itself. Roadblocks, home confinement, hand-to-hand combat. I call on every member of this Parliament to raise the bar of dignity, defending, regardless of any other facts, every human right in every corner of the globe, a planet that watches over us because we once gave the message that we are different, and ultimately we have a part of responsibility. for babies who drown with their manades in the sea. Personally, I am ashamed and sad, but being part of this scene, I am waiting with great interest for the answer of Mr. Stylianidis.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: The Prefect of the Congregation for the Doctrine of the Faith, Cardinal Gerhard Ludwig Müller, is in the tribune. Welcome, Monseigneur.

name: Jordi Vicent SEBASTIA TALAVERA
text: - Mr President, we thank the author of the report for his work - as always very illustrative and exhaustive - and we also appreciate the opportunity to be able to debate here, albeit briefly, on the situation of human rights in the world and the involvement of the European Union. But we miss some points. To begin with, some points about our own house, about the European Union, within which there are also problems of violation of fundamental rights. I will focus on two. The first, the European inaction against violence against women, the real cancer of our society that causes victims every day, and, second, the situation of freedom of expression. I really liked the report that Commissioner Stylianides has made on freedom of expression as the pillar of democracy, on its use as a fundamental weapon to fight fundamentalism. I wonder what the commissioner thinks of the "gag laws" approved by the Spanish Government, which prevent such simple things as photographing demonstrations and publishing police actions in public places on the Internet. Are we not violating freedom of expression there, in our own home? We feel that we have missed an important opportunity in this report to be critical, to be critical of the terrible situation that asylum seekers are suffering in our European Union, to whom we are not granting the refuge that our own laws have. recognize. And I do not want to stop making a clear reference to the cynical European attitude towards countries in which human rights are clearly violated, but with which we maintain good relations - whether political or commercial - because they help us with the excuse of security or of economic progress. That is cynical, that is irresponsible and makes us accomplices of that attitude against human rights, of torture, of prisons and of the deaths that citizens are suffering there.

name: James CARVER
text: – Mr President, as we are today discussing human rights, I feel it is most appropriate to highlight one of the more shameful episodes of recent British history. Nearly 40 years ago, back in 1966, an agreement was reached between my country and the United States relating to the Chagos Islands in the British Indian Ocean Territory granting America a military lease on the island of Diego Garcia. This led to the forcible removal of inhabitants from the archipelago. Many Chagossians were sent to Mauritius; some came to the UK. They had no choice. None have been allowed to return. Their case has as yet been unsuccessful before the British courts and the creation of a marine protection area (MPA) in 2010 has further complicated matters, despite the court of arbitration ruling that this MPA breaches the rules of the UN Convention on the Law of the Sea. I support the desire of Chagossians to return to their home, especially as definitive studies have underlined that they could re-establish an economically viable community away from the main island and military base of Diego Garcia. It seems that, for once, we can ‘have our cake and eat it’. Her Majesty’s government quite rightly supports both Falkland Islanders and Gibraltarians in a right to self-determination and to remain British overseas territories, whilst, at the very same time, shamefully neglecting our duty of care to the Chagossian people,  Successive British governments, both Labour and Conservative, should hold their heads in shame. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: blue-card question. – I hate to embarrass you on this one, but I have been active on the issue of the return of the Chagossians for many years and pursued it in the previous Parliament. How would you react to the fact that the European Union and the Commission were prepared to make funds available to settle the Chagossians back on their rightful territory, but the argument which the British Government came up with was that it was not economically viable to do so, in spite of the fact that the EU was prepared to pay for it? So surely this is a case in which the EU has got it right for once and the British Government has got it wrong?

name: James CARVER
text: blue-card answer. – As someone who opposes British membership of the European Union, I believe in a sense of fair play. We do not have a level playing field in the European Union. Actually, I wish to embarrass the British Government, because it is your government and, as I said, the Labour government before it, which have been completely unfair with regard to this approach to the Chagossian people. I applaud your work on this, but we have to have the right mindset at the Westminster Parliament, not to go cap-in-hand to the European Union or the European institutions to try to get some of our monies back. I think that returns the sense of fair play and better value for money for the British people.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: - Mr President, after the Tarabella, Ferrara, Panzeri, Noichl, Rodrigues reports, here is still a report with the misleading title: human rights and democracy in the world. Who could indeed oppose freedom of expression, thought, conscience and religion? Nobody, of course. It would still be necessary that this same freedom can already be expressed within the nations of the European Union, starting with my country, France, where the electoral campaign that we have just experienced was not a model of democracy. Republican, far from it. So now, through your report, you want to give lessons in democracy to other countries, to the whole world, for example, to Russia. You hold it responsible for the sufferings of the Ukrainian people when the policy pursued by the European Union is largely at the root of it: you have fueled the Ukrainian conflict instead of appeasing it. Likewise, your destructive ideology of nations, but also of the family, urges you, once again, to focus on LGBTI and Roma minorities and, of course, on the alleged benefits of your immigrationist policy. But what do you do with all these forgotten people of globalization, all these invisible ones, the victims of mass immigration, the threat of Islamist fundamentalism, our sieve borders, the children confused by your gender ideology, to whom? we should now explain that a family is a dad and a dad or a mom and a mom? Our compatriots are not in search of universal and global compassion. No, they urgently need us to bring them back to the fore, they need a job, they need the balance of a family. They are not in search of minorities stacked on top of each other, leading to deadly communitarianism. No, on the contrary, they need reunified and protected nations. And this is indeed our first concern.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: - There are extremely serious manifestations of human rights violations, which we mostly encounter outside the European Union, but which, if hit in one of the countries of the European Union, must be taken most decisively immediately and rooted out. Such is the arbitrary arrest, when someone is abusing their power in power and, in our case, abusing people's fear of terrorism ... I apologize, I would like you to ask the President to continue the loud conversation, if possible, because it is very difficult to do so. speak. I kindly ask you to stop the clock, and ask Mr. Tannock, who is constantly entertaining his audience very loudly, to get tired and talk there, because that way I cannot go through what I have to say. Thank you very much. So, a phenomenon seems to be biting, or at least has already begun, the essence of which is that some Member States are pursuing their vile political intent by imprisoning their political opponents or those who are undesirable for them, abusing people's fear of terrorism.
