This happened to a Szekler Hungarian man, István Beke in the Romanian member state of Kézdivásárhely, who is one of the leaders of the indigenous Hungarian community. He was abused, without evidence, in violation of the rights of the defense and the right to a fair trial, in preparation for terrorism, as sparklers and firecrackers were found in him. I would like to hand over a summary of the case to the Commissioner present in the European Union and ask that this matter be investigated immediately and that the phenomenon be rooted.

name: Francisco José MILLÁN MON
text: - Mr President, I congratulate Mr Preda on his report, which analyzes the human rights situation from many important angles; for example, the instruments of the European Union to promote its protection in the world. And it is that respect for human rights is a feature that defines the European Union and its member states, but we want these rights to be universally respected as required by the Charter and international covenants sponsored by the UN. The international community has made great progress in this area, but there are still serious setbacks, violations and difficulties. Today's globalized world and new technologies facilitate the dissemination of information on the situation of human rights, their violations and the defense of those who promote these rights from civil society, often in very difficult situations. This Parliament is strongly committed to human rights; the Sakharov Prize, which is in its twenty-seventh edition, is an example of this and which we presented this morning. In this context, I would also like to particularly remember those in Venezuela who defend human rights and a multi-party society. They won the elections on the 6th, but unfortunately a large group of political prisoners remains in jail. From this Parliament I want today to join Lilian Tintori's demand for "Freedom before Christmas." In our immediate neighborhood, many are fleeing war and the murderous fanaticism of Daesh in Syria and Iraq. The tragic situation of the millions of displaced people, the brutality of violence against women and girls in these and other conflicts are matters of particular concern. And I also want to highlight the difficult situation of Christians in these countries. Europe has to raise its voice in favor of Christians, because precisely this religion has played an essential role in forging the values ​​and principles that are at the basis of European civilization and of the integration process itself. Freedom of religion and conscience is precisely one of the many topics addressed in the comprehensive report on human rights in the world by Mr. Preda, to whom I also reiterate my congratulations today.

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: - Mister President! This debate is always a very important event for the European Parliament - every year. It is especially important to have this debate at a time when people are starting to make fun of human rights more and more. It is very positive to note that European foreign policy is taking a different course and that human rights have a strong focus in the work of the delegations. We can reassure ourselves of this again and again: in the international treaties and in their instruments. I would particularly like to thank the Special Envoy Stavros Lambrinidis for the excellent work. It would be really important that he should have the right to speak in this House on urgent human rights issues. He is an important ally for us. I would also like to congratulate Cristian Dan Preda on the excellent work he has done on this report. After the Panzeri report, it has once again become a very systematic, clear human rights report in which all important areas are identified. It also seems particularly important to me that the area of ​​refugees and migration is dealt with clearly here, because refugees and migrants are often double victims of human rights violations.

name: Anna FOTYGA
text: – Mr President, I really appreciate the work of Mr Preda, but I have to mention two important issues that are missing in the report.  Firstly, there is Iran. Despite the deal, we have to mention one of the most oppressive governments in the world and its activities in terms of human rights. Hopefully, it is not linked with the recent the visit of President Schulz to Tehran and his intention to intensify dialogue. Secondly, there is Crimea. It is obvious that more than 60 international and national human rights laws were violated after the annexation of Crimea. It was a matter of complaint by minorities of various types, both national and religious minorities. It has to be taken into account.

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: - Mr President, Mr Stylianides, Mr Lambrinidis, thank you Mr Preda for your work. I was going to focus my speech on the importance of making full and proper use of all the instruments that we have in the European Union to advance human rights and democracy, but I cannot help but draw attention to paragraph 114 of this report, in which In an extemporaneous and unjustifiable way, surrogacy is condemned, practically comparing it to prostitution, sexual slavery or even organ trafficking. I ask all groups to vote against this section because, gentlemen, surrogacy is simply a form of in vitro fertilization that allows many citizens to access paternity when they cannot do it by other means. In Europe, this practice is legal in some countries and not in others. In some, it is allowed altruistically; in others, their citizens have to travel abroad if they can afford it. Here, in this report, we talk about Union policies to guarantee human rights and democracy, and the political coherence that concerns us implies, as established by the European Court of Human Rights, that children born by surrogacy are recognized and legally registered and are not subject to discrimination on grounds of birth, as established in the Universal Declaration of Human Rights in its article 2. Therefore, we must harmonize the legal frameworks of States to protect the rights of their citizens, with children always first And that is what for me this report must guarantee: that we do in political coherence what we are called to do. (She agreed to answer a question asked under the "blue card" procedure (Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: "blue card" question.- Mrs. Becerra Basterrechea, don't you think surrogate motherhood can lead to exploitation of the bodies of the poorest women?

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: "blue card" response.- Mrs Valenciano, what I believe is that we have to protect the rights of citizens and, as I said, first of all, those of children.Surrogacy can be regulated in many ways and what you need to have is precisely that regulation.We do not have to lead to exploitation;we do not have to cause it to be slavery.We have to allow it to be a right that can be exercised by those citizens who legally and freely agree between adults and have that regulation - as I have said - legal and agreed.And our duty as the European Union is to harmonize its regulation and protect the children who are the fruit of this motherhood.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: - Mr President, the Treaty on the European Union says that the EU's external action must be based on the principles of universality and indivisibility of human rights and respect for human dignity. Are we respecting these obligations? Obviously not. Our commercial policy only seeks business profit; environmental degradation and rights violations are its collateral damage. The attempt to block the binding United Nations treaty on multinationals and human rights is just one example of this, of this cynicism. The clauses of our trade agreements, especially those for investor protection, undermine human rights - and this is not said by me, the United Nations says it. In addition, we sell weapons to countries that systematically violate these rights, such as Saudi Arabia or Israel - the United Nations also says so. What does Europe export to the world? Well, a lot of hypocrisy. The incoherence between what we say and what we do is intolerable and, within our borders, austerity policies are a noose around the neck of European citizens - or the management of the migration crisis: absolutely despicable. This is not yet the Europe of human rights, however much we talk about them. We need binding frameworks and not empty statements.

name: Ernest MARAGALL
text: - Mr President, there are plenty of reasons to vote in favor of this Annual Report, perhaps incomplete but, of course, ambitious, with an action plan that is also a good expression of the commitment of this European Parliament. The question that arises, however, is one of coherence between words and deeds. That is why I ask you, Commissioner, Mr Lambrinidis: 1. After what we have seen and heard this morning, will there be any change in the relations between the European Union and Saudi Arabia? Will we stop buying their oil or selling our weapons to them? 2. Will the European Commission promptly inform us of suspended trade agreements with one country or another, of embargoes or sanctions against Israel, in view of its systematic violation of human rights in Palestine? 3. Based on the Resolution passed today on Hungary, will the European Union apply the provisions of Article 7 of the Treaty? Or, will we hold the Spanish State accountable for its continued restrictions on basic rights? Finally, how is it possible that Turkey is not mentioned in this report, not a single case of the serious attack in that country on the life and basic rights of the Kurdish people or of certain citizens and journalists? This agreement, more than positive, can only continue ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, the tool of the human rights report should be the tool we use to consolidate, strengthen and control human rights in the world, but also to affirm leadership in that direction. Yet although I recognize that Mr Preda has done an excellent job of sharing, with all the shadow rapporteurs of all the groups, we still remain far from acceptable standards. Because it is true that there are ambitious things in this report, we are talking about commercial issues such as sanctioning the human rights violations done to our companies, protecting minorities, but from another point of view there are the words from a side and the facts that go completely in another direction. And then we have two misaligned hands, the words or the prizes we deliver, like the Sakharov Prize this morning, and on the other side there are our trade policies which is the real aggressive policy of the European Union and they continue to do big business with the sheikhs and argue quite the opposite of what we say here. Let us remember that the human rights of other men are also ours.

name: Matteo SALVINI
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, it is curious how we have heard, beyond the intentions of the rapporteur whom I thank, about the rights of all the others, of Roma, migrants, surrogate children, then there are 25 million European citizens unemployed who, however, are not far enough away to have guaranteed human rights and democratic spaces. It is curious how this Parliament insists on bringing Turkey to Europe, which has occupied a member state of this European Union for forty years militarily and does not recognize the Armenian genocide. It is curious how for many of these MEPs the enemy is Putin and Russia against which we are waging an economic and political war, without any kind of sense, while it would be more useful to have him at the table for collaboration against those who truly deny human rights, because speaking of homosexual minorities, I remember that in nine Islamic countries there is the death penalty for the crime of homosexuality. Islamic countries with which many of the MEPs who sit here love to talk. We help those who bring stability. I have personally visited Morocco. I think it is an absolutely interesting example of religious and ethnic coexistence, let's help this country stabilize the area of ​​Western Sahara which is under the influence of Islamic terrorism, let's help it develop it, not with the Iraqi Libyan model. Here, I kindly ask this Parliament and this Commission not to export rights and democracy as it tried to do in Libya in Iraq, because we are still reaping the disastrous results.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI). - Mr President, the European Union is particularly concerned about the protection of human rights and democracy around the world, and is even making sure that this issue dominates its talks with third countries. This is right and it should be done. The only thing the European Union is not interested in is protecting the human rights of European citizens in its Member States. In Greece and other southern European countries, for example Spain, a large number of residents have lost their homes because they do not have to pay their debts to the banks, due to the unacceptable austerity measures imposed in these countries. In Greece, the provocation of international moneylenders has reached an unacceptable level. The homes of poor Greeks are being confiscated to be given and inhabited by illegal immigrants who have flooded the country by the hundreds of thousands. The homeless Greeks now even want to put them in a container. Has the European Union become aware of this unacceptable situation?

name: Eduard KUKAN
text: - Thank you to my colleague Cristian Pred for very good news. I have experience in preparing such a report and I know that it is not an easy task at all. Today, more than ever, Europe is facing new challenges. At these critical moments, what the European Parliament has been calling for for several years needs to be reiterated. In matters of human rights and democracy, the Union and its Member States must speak with consistency and unity. We therefore need to improve the coordination and coherence of our policies. Otherwise, we risk not only losing credibility, but also losing the fundamental values ​​on which the European Union is built. I am glad that this report mentions the means and instruments of the European Union's external policy. We must use them as effectively as possible. Especially when it comes to our close neighborhood. It is clear that the deteriorating human rights situation in our immediate vicinity has very specific negative effects on the EU. The migration crisis is one of the manifestations of this situation. We need to pay more attention to these issues and fully involve them in our relations with our partners. Recently, there has been a tendency to distort and underestimate human rights in many regimes, including in Europe. In these cases, we should express a clear concern. Indeed, when institutions and international agreements begin to be underestimated, the essence of the fundamental values ​​that we follow in Europe is also underestimated. Our priority must be to promote and strengthen democracy in the world and in Europe as a whole. It is important that we continue to support freedom of expression and strengthen civil society, as well as giving direct support to human rights defenders. The European Parliament has a key role to play in this.

name: Richard HOWITT
text: – Mr President, I was in Geneva recently, on behalf of Parliament, at the UN Forum on Business and Human Rights and I welcome paragraph 58 which reaffirms our own Parliament’s commitment to that issue. The Commission, in its action plan on Corporate Social Responsibility (CSR) in 2011, invited all Member States to bring forward national action plans. It is regrettable that we approach the end of 2015 and only seven have done so.  It is slightly ironic that we led the argument on this in the world and that countries like Argentina, Chile, Colombia, Mexico and, last year, the United States agreed to follow our example and yet some of our own Member States are failing to do so. I invite Mr Lambrinidis and the Commission to do everything possible to get Member States to honour this commitment, perhaps by getting those who have made action plans to help those that have not in a peer review process.  Secondly, in Geneva I was dismayed that we are still continuing, as Europe, not to attend the working group on a binding legal instrument. I know there is strong opposition on this issue, but on other issues, like the working group on private security companies, we may not agree but we attend. This is not right for European diplomacy and once again I ask for us to review that policy.

name: Bas BELDER
text: - Mr Lambrinidis, as rapporteur for EU-China relations, I had good consultations with you in the preparation of this report, and with that I actually have two things that I would like to put to you. One case is about China, the other is about another issue. Paragraph 36 of this report talks, if I summarize it, of fruitless human rights dialogues with the People's Republic of China, and actually urges you and your staff to review the human rights strategy. I understand that you cannot answer me directly in this setting, but if you would be so kind as to provide a written answer to these two questions, I would be very grateful. Because yes, we have to go further. What exactly is the status of the human rights dialogue with China? For the second case I appeal to you: a truly disconcerting interview was recently published in the Netherlands about a Palestinian doctor in Gaza, a Christian. Palestinian Christians are in parity in Gaza. I would like you to research that and tell us what we can do about it.

name: Charles GOERENS
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank our colleague Preda for his excellent report, but it is current events that give me the following reflections: the European Union aims to ensure respect for human rights everywhere in the world. Let me remind you that the world begins at home, at our doors and in our countries. As far as the Mediterranean is concerned, the indifference and stingy side of certain Member States are not unrelated to the tragedies that have occurred there. However, there are texts to which all the Member States of the European Union have subscribed and which make it necessary for us to come to the aid of people in danger. Among these texts, let us quote the Geneva Conventions, which oblige us to grant the right of asylum to those who have no other solution than to flee terror and barbarism. Consequently, it is not the texts which miss, it is on the method that it is necessary to look. Member States which refuse to accept refugees on their territory or those which cannot speak of anything other than an upper limit in matters of reception are failing in their obligations, dishonoring politics, not to mention the fatal blow they risk to bring to Europe. Rights and solidarity go hand in hand in matters of immigration and reception of refugees. The codification of rights in this area will remain a dead letter as long as there is no shared desire by all to side with the weak. Everything therefore invites us to do our examination of conscience before lecturing the rest of the world. The coherence of the European Union's external action prevents us from tolerating at home what we do not fail to stigmatize in others.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: - Mr President, I think it is hypocritical to come here to talk about human rights, presenting the European Union as a defender of them, when the European Union maintains preferential trade relations with Israel, one of the world's greatest human rights violators, with the occupation, with the apartheid of the Palestinians, with the bombs in Gaza. A criminal government that assassinates the Palestinian people and maintains an illegal and inhumane blockade on the Gaza Strip. And, in Gaza, there is the candidate to the Spanish Senate for the United Left-Popular Unity Jaldia Abubakra: she is being held by the Government of Israel. A European citizen who is not allowed to leave, like thousands of Palestinians who are in the largest prison in the world: the Gaza Strip. Jaldia, a candidate for the Spanish Senate, has not been able to campaign nor will she be able to vote on Sunday. We demand that the authorities of the European Union stop being complicit in the violation of human rights in Israel, and we want freedom for Jaldia and for all the Palestinian people.

name: Peter LUNDGREN
text: - Mr President! Approximately 200,000 migrants are expected to come to Sweden this year. The zeal for goodness and a paralyzed naive government can no longer handle the situation. Tent camp is the latest invention. Tent camp! In our Nordic climate, where sub-zero temperatures and snow are a common ingredient, we offer tent camps. A mass immigration of biblical proportions with no control whatsoever over which we let in and where the vast majority are also economic migrants who paid very large sums to be able to enter Europe. Those who are in the greatest need and need help, yes we leave them there for the benefit of those who have been able to afford to pay to come here. Is it democracy to leave the weakest in the lurch? Those who really need our help in the areas close to the conflict hotspots. In addition, human rights should also include being able to feel safe and secure in one's own home country. Without control and border protection, it is unfortunately no longer possible to guarantee this, as we have seen in connection with the recent terrorist attacks.

name: Ramona Nicole MĂNESCU
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to begin by congratulating the rapporteur and recalling that Mrs Mogherini stated that human rights and democracy will be major priorities for his term of office and a benchmark in relations between the European Union and third countries and society. civil. So, it created expectations and hopes in this regard. I welcome the adoption by the Council of the 2014 Annual Report on Human Rights and Democracy in the World and the new action plan for 2015-2019. However, I believe that the Council's report should contain not only the results achieved but also the challenges facing the European Union in its efforts to promote democracy in third countries, thus identifying concrete actions that could be implemented in the coming years. Events in recent years have shown the need for a new approach, redefining priorities and introducing new ways of working, as the policy of the single measure has not always yielded the expected results and the methods used have not always been the right ones. We have examples of the failure of such an approach in the states of North Africa, where the effect was devastating, but also in the eastern neighborhood of the European Union. We need to understand that we can be more effective, including from the perspective of human rights support measures, if we approach this relationship with third countries on the basis of common interests, but at the same time taking into account what differentiates us. We therefore need an integrated approach, including policies for development, migration, trade, support for third countries in developing the administrative capacity of the rule of law, transparent and fair electoral processes and, last but not least, ensuring access to education. , because education is the door through which values ​​such as respect for human rights, tolerance and freedom can enter. Education and universal values ​​are the pillars on which modern civilization has been built, and where they are lacking, extremism, intolerance and terrorism take their place.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: - Mr President, over the year 2014, deaths from terrorism increased by 80%: Raif Badawi's sentence was aggravated in the worst possible way;female Indonesian police recruits were subjected to virginity tests;in India, 10 women died after mass sterilization;Saudi Arabia, in the first half of 2014, executed 37 people;ISIS did the same to 700 Syrians in fifteen days;the United Nations Commissioner condemned Israel and Hamas for possible war crimes;in São Paulo, Brazil, 66 public officials were charged with 26 cases of torture;in the space of a year, 41,000 people were arrested, accused and sentenced in Egypt, among them is Ibrahim Halawa;Equatorial Guinea, Mozambique and Angola were accused of human rights violations.Hundreds of cases could be listed, my question is: what is the European Union doing about human rights with regard to its trade policy?

name: Marek JUREK
text: - The annual human rights report unfortunately continues the practice of exporting the revolution so far.We want to impose laws on the world that Robert Schuman, Konrad Adenauer and Alcide de Gasperi would not even be able to imagine.State sovereignty is not above natural justice, but is part of it.It is the law of nations.The financing of abortionism by the European Union compromises our policy.And in a situation where the vast majority of our countries are abortion states, we should probably write a human rights report about ourselves first.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: - Colleague Preda has prepared a weighty and interesting report. Year after year, reports on human rights and our European political practice, in cases where human rights are evidently violated, involve bias when it comes to certain countries. Most of the time, these are always the same countries - like Israel, Morocco, Armenia, Turkey, Saudi Arabia, Qatar, Iran. Developments at Europe's borders, in the countries where refugees come from, should seriously warn us where such selective criteria lead in countries that violate human rights. I will give the latest concrete example. The response of the European Commission and the Council to the ruling of the European Court of Justice, which annulled the European Union's agricultural and fisheries agreement with Morocco a week ago, was unacceptable and completely incomprehensibly quick. This agreement includes the occupied territory of Western Sahara. Morocco there violates international law and the human rights of the Sahrawi people. This was stated by the Court in the reasoning of the judgment. Instead of implementing and complying with the Court's decision, the Commission and the Council announced an appeal. Why? By doing so, they merely testified to the disrespectful and - I would say - shameful attitude towards the European Court of Justice and its role in defending human rights.

name: László TŐKÉS
text: - As can be seen from the European Union Action Plan on Human Rights and Democracy 2015-2019, the issue of human rights one of the most important pillars of our cooperation with third countries. At the individual level, no one today disputes the need to enforce fundamental human rights worldwide and to protect the disenfranchised, the persecuted, the human rights activists. The case, on the other hand, has a collective dimension. Millions and millions of people are persecuted in the world because of their ethnic and / or religious affiliation, and their minority collective rights are violated. The rights of indigenous national minorities are not even regulated in some countries of the Union. Even less so in the former communist states of the Eastern Partnership, or in the societies still under communist rule, as well as in most Islamic countries. A striking example is the plight of Tibetans and Uyghurs living in China, as well as the unsustainable situation of Christians persecuted on a mass scale worldwide. Cristian Preda's excellent report identifies, among other things, the EU's enlargement policy as an important tool for the effective enforcement of human rights in the countries concerned. The countries of the Western Balkans aspiring to Europe, as well as the successor states of the former Soviet empire, have a fundamental interest in getting rid of the legacy of communism and guaranteeing their human and community rights to all their citizens in accordance with EU requirements.

name: Arne LIETZ
text: -  Mister President! The areas of human rights and democracy should be more closely integrated in all policy areas such as foreign, security, trade and development policy. This is particularly important for the implementation of the 2030 goals set in New York this fall. I also welcome High Representative Federica Mogherini's joint action plan on human rights and democracy. I would like to emphasize that the Additional Protocol on Social and Cultural Human Rights has not yet been signed by most of the European states. That has yet to be done with the implementation of the 2030 Agenda. Binding standards in companies are also important: social standards and compliance with the ILO core labor standards. This means that the principle of good work must be implemented worldwide in relation to the 2030 Agenda. The rights of women and girls - especially the right to education - have also been severely restricted so far. That has to be changed. The gender equality action plan urgently needs to be upgraded.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: - I am pleased to release human rights activist Leyla Yunus from prison on December 9, after she was imprisoned for promoting human rights and criticizing the government. We are talking about Azerbaijan. I encourage the Azerbaijani government to follow this path and release the other journalists and human rights activists who are still in prison, including Khadija Ismailova. Khadija Ismailova is an investigative journalist and human rights defender who was arrested in 2014 and then sentenced this year to seven years in prison. I invited Khadija Ismailova to a public hearing on investigative journalism in the European Parliament in 2013, but she was banned from leaving Azerbaijan by the government, so she was unable to attend. Without a free press, there is no democracy and politicians must understand that they can be criticized. Freedom of the press and freedom of journalists are non-negotiable.

name: Urmas PAET
text: – Mr President, our debate today is very timely and necessary, considering that we are continually witnessing human rights violations, impunity and increased attacks against independent civil society, especially human rights defenders. The situation of human rights defenders worldwide is of great concern and I believe that stronger EU action is urgently required.  Although the EU strategic framework on human rights and democracy is big on words, the EU has to step up its efforts if it wants to live up fully to its pledge of being an advocate of liberty, democracy and human rights all over the world. The deliberate targeting of human rights defenders is not acceptable. There are just too many cases to be naming just one or two. There should not be any targeting of people who stand up for the rights of others; not a single case. The EU must be at the forefront of the protection and support of human rights defenders who are silenced, attacked, harassed, put behind bars and murdered. Human rights must have an important place in the upcoming EU global strategy.

name: Mariya GABRIEL
text: - Mr President, first of all congratulations to Cristian Preda for his relevant work. Next, I would like to emphasize six essential elements for me. First, I will insist on consistency, on the one hand, between our various external policies and, on the other hand, between our internal and external policies. We must avoid having two weights and two measures and this consistency can only be reinforced by the full support of the Member States to the action plan and the strategic framework of the Union. My second point concerns the unity and visibility of the Union's action, facilitated by the work of the Union's special representative for human rights. This mandate must become permanent in order to complete the process. Third element: the role of electoral observation missions. Once again, the follow-up of these missions is essential. And I think this is the case even when the conclusions of the mission are positive, because it also constitutes political support for those who are determined, in their country, to advance democracy. Union delegations can take an even more active part in this monitoring. Fourth element: the role of parliamentary cooperation through delegations and joint assemblies, which provide significant support to countries in democratic transition. The fifth element deals with human rights, democracy and development. I would like to highlight the need to define a limited number of priorities per country, which could be a strategic and pragmatic approach to better achieve and quantify our results. Finally, the treatment and situation of migrants and refugees, including in Europe, is rightly included in the report. Let us not forget that in addition to terrorists and armed groups, migrant smugglers and criminal networks for trafficking in human beings willfully violate human rights. The smuggling of migrants is a crime and a violation of human rights. We must do more to dismantle these networks, in a good spirit of cooperation.

name: Ana GOMES
text: - Mr President, the working conditions of human rights activists, accused and persecuted for terrorism, or restricted through legislation on registration and funding of NGOs, are worsening throughout the world. The European Union and the Member States continue to have contradictory, inconsequential, counterproductive policies and not to be heard in unison. The Special Representative for Human Rights must be able to speak publicly on behalf of the Union. European Union delegations and embassies must resist political interference and intimidation by local authorities in human rights programs. That was not the case for Ms. Concetta Tirzi, expelled by the Angolan authorities with unacceptable European complicity, for having promoted meetings with activists such as Luati Beirão and other prisoners, subject to farcical trials. Not to mention the European Union delegations that shamefully self-censor, as in Ethiopia, where the regime is repressing and killing oromo students and the delegation remains silent and burying its head in the sand.

name: Mirosław PIOTROWSKI
text: - Mr Chairman! The 2014 Annual Report on Human Rights and Democracy in the World and the EU's policy on the matter was drawn up on behalf of our Parliament. It is quite a long document, almost 40 pages long, but I see a serious disruption of the thematic proportion in it. All forms of discrimination on the basis of sexual orientation are discussed many times and in different ways. LGBTI people are mentioned first when calling for non-discrimination. These matters are mentioned, inter alia, in sec. 4, 37, 48, 91, 98, 108, 111, and sec. 92 and 93 have the subtitle "LGBTI rights". The author of the document escapes the discrimination and persecution of Christians in the world who, according to Open Doors, are the most persecuted religious group in the world. In this document, somewhat half-mouth, it is mentioned only once in paragraph 82. Taking the document as a whole, there is more than an asymmetry. For this reason, I believe, not only conservative MPs, but (...). (The chairman cut off the speaker)

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: - Mr. President, today's report on the Annual Report on Human Rights and Democracy in the World 2014 and the European Union's policy in this area was prepared by our colleague Preda and I congratulate him on this report and negotiations with all groups. I believe that the practice of adopting annual reports on the state of human rights is a very useful mechanism for screening the human rights situation in the world and I believe that human rights must be an integrated part of all instruments of our foreign policy and promoting our influence towards third countries. in those countries that are subjects of our development policy. I also appreciate the efforts of the Special Rapporteur on Human Rights and the representative of Mr. Lambrinidis. We saw that he was also active in choosing the awards for this year’s Sakharov Prize. Our resolution also clearly underlines the European Union's commitment to the Human Rights and Democracy Action Plan 2015-2019, in which we must be a responsible leading player on the global stage when it comes to protecting human rights and implementing our foreign policy. At the same time, I expect that in the context of the long-term process of accession of the European Union to the European Convention for the Protection of Human Rights, this process will be completed and their protection will be strengthened internally as well. When it comes to some special countries, I would like to single out the situation in Ukraine, especially in the occupied areas of Crimea and Donbas, where we, as a delegation for Ukraine and the Subcommittee on Human Rights and the Committee on Foreign Affairs, have repeatedly warned about worrying human rights violations. occupied territories. We also keep in mind that 60 million people are on the move. The refugee-migrant crisis is one of the biggest problems in this context. We saw how many human rights violations there were. Finally, I am glad that our resolution from last year regarding the Seselj case was mentioned in the annex to this report. It is good for a country that has opened negotiations to think about the importance of protecting human rights and combating hate speech.

name: Andi CRISTEA
text: - Mr President, I would like to congratulate the rapporteur, Cristian Preda, on his work, on his balanced and substantial report. Given that respect for human rights continues to be undermined and threatened around the world, we, the European Union, have a duty to be actively involved at international level, including in obtaining financial allocations, the necessary and appropriate resources to promote human rights. I will point out some major human rights violations that continue to require sustained international efforts to find effective ways and methods to address them. All states must be held accountable, end impunity and bring to justice those responsible for genocide, crimes against humanity and war crimes, including crimes involving violence - such as rape, sexual slavery, prostitution. forced sterilization - and it is necessary to recognize and convict these crimes as crimes against humanity and war crimes.

name: Pavel SVOBODA
text: - Mr President, first of all, thanks to Cristian Dan Pred for the excellent work done on this report. Unfortunately, we are living at a time when the human rights situation is deteriorating worldwide, and the European Union and the individual Member States must respond to this, because the protection of human rights is at the heart of European identity. We must preserve this identity of ours and not back down from our principles in the face of various authoritarian regimes or terrorist organizations. Our values, on which respect for human rights is fundamental, are now being called into question, and it is therefore necessary to invent new strategies and allocate sufficient money to promote them. Human rights need to be promoted in the world through targeted strategies, these strategies properly evaluated and then the consequences drawn and, where appropriate, strategies adjusted. It must be made clear at all times that human rights, such as freedom of expression, freedom of assembly, freedom of religion, are a precondition for the provision of development aid. This tougher approach in negotiations with the authorities of third countries does not have to be an obstacle to concrete assistance to civil society representatives in those countries. I would like the European Commission to emphasize, above all, respect for the right of Christians to religion, because this is the most persecuted group of people in the world. Every year, thousands of dead and millions of people who are variously harmed deserve special attention from Europe. Asia Bibi, a Pakistani Christian woman we have spoken of here several times, is still in prison awaiting a suspended death sentence for blasphemy. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162 (8))

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: Question "blue card".- I wanted to ask my colleague, I agree with everything he said, but the question is this: but if what you say this morning was rewarded, unfortunately only the wife came because we know that he is in prison, who is in prison because he cannot express his ideas and is in prison in Saudi Arabia where the European Union does business all the time.Then it is useless for us to say one thing and then do another.What do you think about this aspect?

name: Pavel SVOBODA
text: answer the question posed by raising a blue card.- The fact that politicians have to talk to each other does not mean that we have to compromise in this dialogue on the emphasis on the protection of human rights, including vis-à-vis Saudi Arabia.

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: I would like to remind visitors that no applause is allowed in plenary.Only members can do that.

name: Francisco ASSIS
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the European Union, despite all its limitations, which have been widely recognized here, continues to have an irreplaceable and predominant role in monitoring, denouncing and intervening in the field of human rights. Therefore, I want to emphasize the importance of the annual discussion of this report and, in the specific case, of the one that is now under discussion, to emphasize the complete and constructive way in which it was prepared, covering all areas related to human rights. These, as we know, have seen, in recent years, very worrying setbacks in various parts of the world, immediately as a result of wars, terrorism and the persecution of minorities to which the current exodus of migrants is directly linked, with tragic consequences in European soil. There is, however, an issue that I wanted to ask and that I think should be dealt with in more depth in this report and that has to do with the articulation between our trade policy and our policy for the promotion of human rights. As we know today, the commercial treaties that we have established with other regions of the globe are absolutely fundamental for the integration of clauses for the enhancement of human rights to promote them worldwide.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: - Mr. President, dear Mr. Stylianides, a few days ago we marked the International Human Rights Day, the day when the Universal Declaration of Human Rights was signed. Then, for the first time in history, the right to life, liberty, security was recognized and we consider this date a turning point in modern history, because the world united to put an end to the genocide that took place during World War II. Unfortunately, many countries quickly forgot what they had signed, which is what the wars in the second half of the 20th century are all about. But it was not only the suffering of the war that called into question the essence of this Declaration. Both the economic collapse and the financial crisis that hit the world a few years ago have raised the issue of human rights again. These are all unavoidable topics that we encounter on a daily basis. So I want to thank Mr. Predi who is continuously working on this report and who has made one solid report for 2014. We are witnessing a large number of refugees fleeing their homes due to violence and the poor economic and political situation, all in order to find refuge. It is these situations that can be easy prey for human rights violations. I express my concern and solidarity with the large number of refugees and immigrants who suffer serious human rights violations as victims of conflict, in networks of illegal immigrants, in human trafficking, etc. I believe that we urgently need peace, security, sustainable growth in all countries, free and fair trade poverty rates and the protection of human rights, and I emphasize in particular the rights of children under the United Nations Charter, but also the protection of women's rights, which we should not forget in this situation. As for freedom of expression, we know that it is the foundation of democracy and I thank Mr Predi once again for taking all these issues into account in his report. I hope we continue on that trail.

name: Cécile Kashetu KYENGE
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, a few hours ago, Parliament awarded its highest award for freedom of thought and expression, once again testifying to its commitment to promoting human rights and democratic values ​​in the world. Raif Badawi's chair was empty, unfortunately not unusual in the history of the Sakharov Prize. Here, perhaps this fact more than any other political consideration is the testimony of how today many human rights and fundamental freedoms are increasingly threatened in many parts of the world. Suffice it to consider the fact that over half of the world population still lives in undemocratic and repressive regimes and the situation of minors, privileged victims of violence, trafficking, exploitation, mutilation, early marriages, as well as girls and women who in too many countries of the world they still do not enjoy the same economic, social, cultural, civil and political rights as men and which are still poorly represented in local and national decision-making bodies. We have the tools available to promote democratic values ​​in the world and our commitment to supporting electoral processes is proof of this, we just try to be more ambitious in the development of our policies and we do not hesitate in the face of individual measures such as economic sanctions aimed at prosecuting those responsible…. (The President withdraws the floor from the speaker)

name: Barbara MATERA
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I too would like to congratulate Mr Preda on the excellent work he has done. The European Union is founded on respect for principles such as freedom, democracy, human rights, the rule of law, incorporating both the internal and external policies of our institutions, rights won through a tortuous and dramatic history, with decision and sacrifice. I strongly believe in the role of the European Union and its External Service as a guarantor of human rights in other parts of the world as well. We need a more incisive role of our institutions and humbly propose alternatives without being arrogant and proud. We cannot be indifferent to the cry of those populations subjugated by Daesh terrorists such as the Yazidis and the Assyrians, of the children held hostage by Boko Haram and of the Kenyan populations constantly threatened by al Shabaab. There are 230 million children in the world living in regions where armed conflicts endanger their lives and their most basic rights such as access to water and there are women and girls who are still victims of brutal customs such as mutilation. genitals. The EU can and must do more. So I join the chorus of those who congratulate the adoption of a European Union action plan to support democracy and human rights on a global scale, by allocating adequate resources. I conclude with the words of Pope John XXIII, who told us not many years ago that "in human coexistence every natural right of a person entails a respective duty of all other people", that is, the duty to recognize and respect that right.

name: Elly SCHLEIN
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, a difficult year ends, in which the economic crisis and wars have aggravated human rights violations around the world. The European Union must do more to promote the universality of human rights, a fundamental element in all relations with third countries. Let us not forget that the defense and promotion of human rights are not only a means of guaranteeing security and stability worldwide, but are also the basis of the new universal agenda for sustainable development, approved in September, and if we want to be credible actors on the scenario international, we cannot fail to address internal human rights challenges, such as the situation of Roma and Sinti, discrimination against LGBTI people, violence against women and their rights, but above all the treatment of refugees and of migrants who too often in our European Union see their rights trampled on every day, as I was able to find in a recent visit to an identification center in Italy. Finally, in paragraph 114, I am concerned to see a no-appeal condemnation of gestation for others. We need a balance between the fight against exploitation and the freedom of women to decide on their own body and one cannot dismiss such a complex debate in one paragraph.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: - Mr President, I would also like to begin by thanking my colleague Dan Pred for his exceptionally good work. I personally consider the human rights agenda to be one of the key agendas of the European Union. This agenda is as important to me as the development of the internal market or the other, say, economic benefits of cooperation between the countries of the European Union. Who but the European Union should guard human rights in the context of world peace and warn countries where human rights are not being respected that human rights are being violated. I consider it particularly important to have an international debate with third countries on fundamental human rights, that is, the right to life, health, dignity, but also on fundamental political rights, such as the right to free expression. After all, it has already been mentioned here several times today. As I said, I'm really glad that the material is on the table here today, I consider it balanced. I say this also because I am a Member of Parliament for the Czech Republic, where the first freely elected President, Václav Havel, considered the human rights agenda to be an important instrument of international politics and international diplomacy. As a lawyer and a former Minister of Justice, I consider one issue to be particularly important, and that is the issue of combating the death penalty. I am very pleased that this topic is mentioned separately here, that the fight against the death penalty has a separate chapter. It is very sad that, unfortunately, the death penalty has been increasing in recent years in the world and that the three largest countries where the death penalty is most commonly used, such as China, Iran and Saudi Arabia, are using it more and more, not less. It is worth criticizing Saudi Arabia, which is cooperating with the European Union but has done nothing in the field of humanity in criminal law, and the death penalty is being carried out in a medieval, particularly repulsive way. The case of al-Nimra, who is sentenced to death by crucifixion, has already been mentioned today.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: –  Mr President, the Human Rights and Democracy Report before us is one of the most comprehensive that has been produced on the subject globally and is the result of hours of work by experts in the European institutions. I am proud that we in Europe take a stand on behalf of those whose rights are denied around the world. Ask Raif Badawi and Leyla Yunus, two individuals who benefitted because we in Europe decided to act.  However, the struggle for human rights continues. It is a story of long campaigns and uneasy victories against conflict and poverty, against prejudice and ignorance and against crime and justice and repression. Today, at the close of 2015, it is a sobering fact that millions suffer in Syria and more refugees knock on our doors. Plenty of work awaits us in 2016. We must ensure that we ourselves first reflect the very values we seek to promote globally.

name: Gilles PARGNEAUX
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the first violation of human rights is having to leave your country, your roots because of the war, because of dictatorial regimes, but also because of climate change. In 2014 - and the Preda report addresses it in paragraph 72 - 17.5 million people were displaced as a result of disasters caused by climatic hazards. These displacements mainly concern the southern regions which are most exposed to the effects of climate change; 85% of them take place in developing countries. I have two proposals, Commissioner. First, to oblige the Member States of the Union to finance development aid to the tune of 0.7% of GDP, as they have promised. Second, we must set an example by including measures related to the fight against climate change in all of our international development agreements in order to contain the increase in the planet's temperature to 1.5 degrees. It is our fight of the century if we do not want to have 200 million climate refugees in the world tomorrow.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: - Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, I am glad that the rapporteur recognized the problem of persecution of Christians because in 2014 we reached a sad record. Nearly one hundred million Christians live in fear of the consequences they may face just because they practice their faith. Data for 2015 could be even worse. Therefore, we need to do everything in our power to stop the genocide of Christians. I would also like to draw attention to the protection of the rights of national minorities, within the policy of enlargement and opening negotiations with Serbia, since the position of Croats in Serbia is worryingly difficult, and a few days ago Serbia abolished the only radio in Croatian. Viewed from a value perspective, I find in the report some controversial points that I feel have no place here. The promotion of gender ideology and abortion as an integral part of women's sexual and reproductive rights is not in line with the values ​​inherited by the peoples of Europe. The right to life is a fundamental human right and we need to protect that right in the first place.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). - Mr President, human rights abuses are not limited to poor countries but are becoming more common within the European Union, especially in countries where a Memorandum has been imposed. The Commission, which is also a member of the Troika, in response to a question, admits that human rights are not protected under the Memorandum of Understanding, as they are not allegedly related to European Union law. Merkel's austerity, which the European Commission serves with religious reverence, leads to a massive and persistent violation of the human rights of the citizens of the Union. In addition, the memoranda have seriously damaged the collective rights and social acquis of the peoples, as well as democracy itself. The technocratic, authoritarian diversion of the Republic, through the invention of an emergency regime sometimes imposed by the terrorist threat and sometimes by the economic crisis, should be of serious concern to the members of the European Parliament. So let the Commission first look at ensuring that human rights are protected within the European Union before giving lessons to the rest of the world.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: - Mr. President, there are many human rights violations in the world.This report makes that clear.However, thank God, there are a lot of human rights activists in the world and we have to join them.We must remain faithful to our foundations, the foundations on which we build our European Union, the foundations of the protection of classical human rights, minority, linguistic, religious, everything that is in the foundations of the European Union, but we must also have the strength to recognize new dimensions of human rights.And especially when we talk in today's current times about the rights of migrants, about climate migrants, about what climate change brings as a need for human rights, about the extreme poverty that we have in the European Union.These are all new dimensions of human rights for me.

name: Alessandra MUSSOLINI
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the Preda report is very good, but consider that in Italy 170 women a year are killed in the family, one every two days, child soldiers who are violated in their innocence, salaries, there has been talk, of women who, for the same job, are still fewer than those of men.And then I would like - given that the Commissioner is here - to appeal for our two marines, the fusiliers of the Navy, who have been in India for three years, this too must be resolved.We are talking about sanctions on Russia, I would take them off Russia and put them on India.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: - The protection of human rights is often called a priority for the European Union.However, I call on everyone to be honest with themselves and others.For geopolitical reasons, we often sacrifice human rights.A good example is the human rights situation in Belarus and Turkey.Today, relations with Belarus are becoming warmer, but have there been any significant changes in the country's human rights record?No, it didn't happen.The situation is the same with Turkey.There is also no guarantee of freedom of expression, persecution of the media inconvenient for the regime, but Turkey has become an important partner simply because of the refugee crisis.I find it strange that there is a constant desire to choose which area to sacrifice: the economy and security or human rights.I call on the Commission and Parliament to stop playing the games and to continue to fight against human rights violations when negotiating cooperation with other countries.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: - Respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms must be at the heart of the European Union's external action.Human rights are often violated by those who fight for them and by the weakest in our society - children and women.The European Union therefore has a great responsibility and duty to constantly draw attention to the many human rights violations in third countries and to monitor and encourage all stakeholders - government, civil society and the private sector - to strive for respect for human rights, including the fight against corruption, taxation and taxation.tax evasion, avoidance and tax havens.Human rights defenders in third countries and civil society, for which public space must not shrink, play a major role in this process.In countries without civil society or with a poorly functioning civil society, the authorities are more likely to disrespect human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: – Mr President, I would like to draw attention to paragraph 114 of this excellent report. However, I think there is a problem. It condemns the practice of surrogacy and actually calls for the prohibition of this practice. I believe that it is too early to say whether it should be prohibited or regulated in another way. I just want to draw your attention to the fact that it is being discussed in several international institutions, including the Hague Conference on Private International Law.  If we go directly towards a prohibition of surrogacy, we may endanger the rights of children that are nevertheless going to be born into the world through this practice. So we have to be very cautious with it. It needs to be regulated, but it should also be dealt with by parliamentary committees before we jump into a final decision on whether to prohibit it or regulate it in another way.

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: Thank you very much, a very important observation. (End of catch-the eye procedure)

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank you for this very fruitful debate, and for your very productive and very constructive remarks and comments. I would like to again congratulate the rapporteur, Mr Preda, for his very comprehensive report. I cannot agree more that maximising our internal and external coherence is of vital importance. Our credibility abroad as a champion of human rights depends on what we do here at home. If we do not guarantee the highest human rights standards in Europe, our external action will also become weaker. In this process, the role of the European Parliament is also vital. Mainstreaming human rights into all our external policies is an ongoing process, and despite progress made so far, we must continue with our efforts. Our new action plan is intended to go right in that direction. In this very strict time framework of only two minutes, I would like to say a few words about impunity. In our human rights dialogues and our country strategies, this is always systematically part of accountability. Most importantly, that the European Union is a strong supporter of the International Criminal Court, and this is very important. Finally, let me once again express my deep appreciation for the very constructive cooperation with this House. Together we can speak with one voice in upholding the universality of human rights and in supporting the democratic aspiration of our partners. Of course, we look forward to the upcoming debates on human rights in this Parliament.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: protractor. - Mr President, I would like to thank all colleagues for their speeches and reactions. I was happy, in particular, to see that many of them highlighted the need for consistency between our foreign policy and the internal situation of the Member States. At the same time, I have somewhat regretted the fact that some of our colleagues have started, on this basis, to enter into a debate of the internal politics of their Member States or, as is also often the case, to criticize this happening in some Member States. These issues are the responsibility of another committee, the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs. It is for this reason that we wanted to prepare this report, which represents an analysis of rights as an instrument of foreign policy. In the DROI committee, we do not carry out an analysis for which members of another committee are responsible. What better proof, moreover, than to examine this annual report on human rights just after the Sakharov Prize ceremony. This is a very good example of what we can do in our relationship with this country. I would also like to point out, in view of the interventions criticizing the fact that the report does not look at specific situations or countries, that it is not a geographical report, but a thematic report. We discuss very specific countries and cases at every plenary session in Strasbourg. It is good that our colleagues know that now. Better late than never! Finally, I am pleased with the remark made by my colleague Tannock who stressed that we have tried to be more rigorous in the definition of rights, because consistency, mentioned by several of our colleagues, has as a sine qua non intellectual consistency. If we put everything in perspective, if we go in all directions, we will not be able to be coherent in our policies.

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: The debate is closed.The vote will take place on Thursday, December 17, 2015.Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: in writing. - I would like to remind you that the EU's enlargement policy is one of the most effective means of strengthening respect for human rights and democratic principles. I welcome the application of the new approach to the chapters on justice and fundamental rights and freedom, security and justice in the accession negotiations, which takes due account of the time needed to properly implement the relevant reforms. The report shows that freedom of expression and freedom of the press are being weakened in some of the accession countries and in many of the countries involved in the neighborhood policy. Freedom of expression and the media must continue to be monitored during the accession negotiations. Proper implementation of the legal framework for the protection of minorities remains a challenge. Accession countries need to step up their efforts to strengthen a culture of acceptance of minorities, for example by improving the involvement of minorities in decision-making processes and increasing their involvement in the education system. The report notes with concern the deterioration of democratic political culture in some candidate and potential candidate countries, as well as in many countries participating in the European Neighborhood Policy. I would like to remind you that good governance, the rule of law, freedom of expression, respect for human rights, political dialogue, compromise and the involvement of all stakeholders in the decision-making process are at the heart of democratic systems.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. - The same European Union which, whether domestically or externally, tramples democracy and human rights, asserts itself to the right to teach democracy and human rights lessons to the rest of the world, as attested once again , this debate. The Universal Declaration of Human Rights lists rights and principles that aim to ensure respect for human life and dignity, including, among others, freedom, rights of expression, opinion, religion and participation in the life of communities, equality in birth regardless of social class and race, equality before the law and justice, the right to access for all to health, education, social security, work and a reasonable salary to guarantee a dignified life for all families , clothing, decent accommodation and food, equal pay for equivalent work, including equality between the sexes, the right to privacy, advocating the elimination of any forms of discrimination. The impoverishment of democracy is always linked to the failure to respect some fundamental human rights. We feel it today as never before in the EU. It is the defense of these rights - conquered and today threatened - that pulsates in the struggle of the workers and peoples of Europe and the world.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing. - This is an important issue with a direct impact on the level of quality of life and democracy in individual Member States as well as in the European Union as a whole. Such documents are needed for discussions on how to ensure the protection of human rights. However, in terms of practical performance, they will not help much. They would be more useful if they included a concrete assessment and analysis of the impact of existing policies on respect for human rights, both within and outside the borders of the European Union. Unfortunately, there are also many pages out there, despite the description. It is the effectiveness of current regulation and its existing instruments that is important to know. Whether we look at the situation of the rights of women, minorities, including people with different sexual orientations, hate speech and xenophobic manifestations are becoming more and more common towards them. At the same time, they are not punished in any way. Aggressors gain a sense of impunity and discrimination within society just flourishes. Woefully little is being done about this trend. The topic is also important from the point of view of the setting of foreign policy and trade relations in the European Union. Member States and their representatives, when establishing trade relations, for example in the field of energy, but especially security, have absolutely no regard for the approach to the protection of human rights of their trading partners from third countries.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: in writing. - I am pleased that we are also adopting the annual human rights report by Mr Preda in plenary. Congratulations to the rapporteur, as the draft report was already a balanced and comprehensive text that provided a good basis for our further work. I would like to welcome the confirmation in the text of the protection of vulnerable groups such as women, children, religious, linguistic and national minorities. These groups also deserve special attention when dealing with burning issues such as migration or the situation of people living in refugee camps. We must work with the countries concerned to ensure that children and young people in refugee camps receive adequate education and that girls and women enjoy adequate protection. The final text also pays special attention to the issue of national minorities. Ensuring equality in practice between national minorities and the majority nation is essential. This is true of all areas of life - be it social, economic, political or cultural. Special attention must be paid to ensuring the protection of national and linguistic minorities during the accession process. We celebrated World Human Rights Day a few days ago. I would like to welcome the fact that, on this occasion, the European Commission has announced a new, comprehensive mechanism to support human rights defenders. In doing so, we can support human rights defenders who risk their lives defending human rights in even the most dangerous parts of the world.

name: David McALLISTER
text: in writing. – The European Union is founded on a shared determination to promote peace and stability and to build a world founded on respect for human rights, democracy and the rule of law. These principles underpin all aspects of the internal and external policies of the European Union and are also applicable to our enlargement policy. The European Union’s enlargement policy in the Western Balkans shows that this policy is the strongest tool for reinforcing respect for human rights and democratic principles in our closest neighbourhood. I welcome that this has clearly been stated in the report. In the recent past, the Western Balkan countries have adopted important reforms to strengthen human rights. However, we must not get tired of emphasising that the best reforms are worth nothing if they are not implemented. The European Union should continue to actively support democratic, effective and independent institutions, civil society and free media in the Balkans to ensure that human rights remain at the centre of our enlargement policy.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: in writing. - The Annual Report on Human Rights and Democracy in the World 2014 and the EU's policy on the matter is very extensive, and the rapporteur should be thanked for his good work. It is only understandable that it also brought a heated debate in the EP plenary. More than half of the world lives in undemocratic, authoritarian and repressive regimes, so the protection of human rights must be included in all EU policies - development, economy, environmental protection, cross-cutting, impossible to separate and do alone. Perhaps the time has come for us to make a hierarchy of human rights, where the human rights of children must come first, because they are the most vulnerable, they cannot defend themselves, then it is women, the elderly and the poor. The number of people in need, people living without water, without a roof over their heads, has doubled in the last 10 years. Over the other period, the number of war conflicts has increased, with children and women again suffering the most. Next must be fundamental rights, such as freedom of expression, freedom of thought, conscience and religion, the right to vote and to be elected, ... We must realize that if we cannot guarantee human rights, we are threatening democracy in the world and in Europe.

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the Council and Commission statements on the detention of asylum seekers and the use of force against them (2015/3021 (RSP)).

name: Nicolas SCHMIT
text: President-in-Office of the Council. - Mr President, Ladies and Gentlemen, from the beginning of our Presidency, we have been actively engaged in seeking solutions to the humanitarian crisis caused by migratory flows. We have shown our firm determination to act without delay to find effective, united measures that respect human rights. The policy pursued by the Council aims to combine all efforts with a view to preserving the rights of people in need of international protection and, at the same time, to improve the control of external borders and thus guarantee the security of people living in the country. Union territory. Respect for fundamental rights is at the heart of the Union's migration policy and of the common European asylum system. We must respond effectively to the humanitarian emergency and guarantee the right to seek international protection in accordance with our international obligations. As far as detention is concerned, the basic rule of international and European law is that a migrant, like any other person, enjoys the right to liberty. Retention can only be exceptional and not arbitrary. It is only justified for a series of specific reasons and in specific situations. These are described in detail in the instruments of the acquis on asylum and migration, and in particular the Return Directive and the Directive on the conditions of reception of asylum seekers. The Return Directive provides, as a general rule, that Member States may only resort to detention after other sufficient but less coercive measures have been applied. It is Article 15, paragraph 1. Any detention should be as short as possible and can only be extended as long as the removal arrangement, which should be carried out with all due diligence, is in progress. Likewise, the directive on reception conditions for asylum seekers provides, in article 8, that no one may be placed in detention for the sole reason that he is seeking international protection. Detention is only possible when necessary, and on the basis of a case-by-case assessment, if other less coercive measures cannot be effectively applied. In accordance with their international commitments and the rules of the European Union, Member States must guarantee the human rights of refugees and migrants, including the obligations contained in the directives. In the event that European legislation is not applied by the Member States, it would be up to the Commission, as guardian of the Treaties, to take appropriate measures. To improve the efficiency of the Union's return system, the Council has indicated on several occasions in recent months that the use of detention can only be a measure of last resort, and therefore cannot be put implemented only if other measures are not possible. In its conclusions of 9 November last, the Council decided that Member States, in cases of lack of cooperation on the part of migrants on their arrival in the European Union, could effectively take advantage of the possibilities offered by the The union. These may include coercive measures, including, as a last resort, detention for a period not exceeding what is necessary for the completion of the underlying proceedings. However, this is only possible if the authorities fully respect fundamental rights and the principle of non-refoulement. In the recent Council decision on the relocation of 120,000 people from Italy and Greece, Member States agreed that when a voluntary return is not possible and other measures foreseen by the return directive are not appropriate to prevent secondary movements, detention measures in accordance with the said Directive should be able to be applied urgently and effectively.In this context, I would like to point out that migrants do not have a choice of place of protection and that their full cooperation is required to make relocation work.Finally, with regard to the use of force in the context of taking fingerprints, I refer to the checklist published by the European Agency for Fundamental Rights, dated October 22, which should henceforth guide theaction of experts in the field.In conclusion, the subject of detention will remain an important question, the exceptional nature of which must be underlined, and we will continue to follow this question closely, especially since clarifications from the Court of Justice of the UnionEuropean Commission on this subject are expected shortly.

name: Nicolas SCHMIT
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, the Commission fully shares with Parliament the objective of ensuring the full compliance of our policies with human rights and human dignity. This was at the centre of the debate on the report on human rights and democracy, which was just discussed some minutes ago.  This is also a key concern when it comes to asylum seekers. Having said this, I turn now to the topic of the statement: detention and the use of force against asylum seekers. The rights to liberty and security of person are fundamental human rights. The right to asylum is also a fundamental right. In the past few months, as you remember, we have made a lot of effort to communicate, and deliver on all fronts, the fact that EU legislation has to be respected. This means the respect of all aspects of the asylum legislation.  In this context, as long as there was a prior non-refoulement and proportionality check, countries could refuse entry to individuals who did not express a wish to apply for international protection. As you also know, we make efforts to ensure the proper registration of migrants, irrespective of their status. This is a precondition for appropriately managing the flows and setting the rights and duties of migrants.  Let me clarify what EU law requires. With the recast directives on asylum adopted in codecision, the EU acquis contains clear rules on detention of asylum seekers that strike a balance between those rights. It is therefore essential that persons are only detained in full compliance with these rules. Detention can only be applied as a measure of last resort, and only after all alternatives to detention have been duly considered. We all agree that a person should never be detained for the sole reason that he or she is an asylum seeker. At the same time, when there is a significant risk of absconding, a Member State should place a migrant in detention where that is necessary and proportionate. Moreover, the Directive on Reception Conditions provides that the detention conditions of asylum seekers must fully respect human dignity and meet their needs.  Having a solid legal framework is only going halfway, though. The challenge now is to ensure the correct and coherent transposition and implementation of these rules. The Commission is closely monitoring the respect of Member States for the EU rules on detention. Member States had to transpose the Reception Conditions Directive by July 2015.  The Commission has sent letters of formal notice to those Member States that did not communicate the transposition measures. In addition to legislation, the Commission also pays attention to Member States’ practice in this area. The Commission has also provided guidance to Member States to facilitate the systematic fingerprinting of migrants. The aim is to ensure better management of migration flows, via a better implementation of the Eurodac Regulation, while fully respecting the fundamental rights of the migrants.  Thank you for your attention. I would like to ask for your understanding because, as you know, the previous debate lasted longer than planned, and I have to catch the last flight to Berlin in half an hour from now. Thank you very much for your understanding. Commissioner Stylianides will replace me.

name: Monika HOHLMEIER
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! First of all, thank you very much for this brief overview. It is particularly important to me that there are a number of Member States in the European Union in which human rights vis-à-vis refugees or economic migrants are not adequately respected.
