Regardless of who immigrates, there is no reason to use excessive force or even for prison-like structures, some, as the UNHCR has called it, are even worse than is the case in prisons: no food, little to drink, no medical Supply, poor sanitary conditions, sometimes daily use of tear gas. This sometimes happens in Greece, it can be in Hungary, it can be in Slovakia, it can be in different member states of the European Union. I have to say: In spite of all the critical debates we have about who is entitled to immigrate and how, there has to be a proper way of dealing with the people who come to us. Then we can agree on procedures and discuss all kinds of issues. But these things must be guaranteed. When it comes to the obligation to register, it is certainly necessary to start the investigation very early on. Because especially with children and adolescents who come who have been misinformed by human traffickers, people are often afraid of registration and do not want to be registered under any circumstances, so that a very early education - also to protect children in particular - is absolutely necessary . There are dozens of children who have disappeared and who for this reason can quickly become victims of crime again, because in this defenselessness they are then exploited by organized crime and the like for sometimes the worst and most brutal purposes. Let's really work together and be sensible on this issue.

name: Enrique GUERRERO SALOM
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - Mr President, if in all the Member States of the Union what Mr Schmit and Mr Avramopoulos have told us were fulfilled - that freedom is the fundamental principle, that deprivation of liberty is an exception, that it can only be done for example, that there must be some justification and there must be no other less harmful measure, that it cannot be returned, that human rights must be respected and, furthermore, international laws - we would not be debating this issue this afternoon. But the truth is that this is not the case: there are countries that have erected fences, there are countries that have aggressively welcomed refugees and there are countries that do not respect these rights and that apply some type of police violence; And the reason is not to mistreat those who are deprived of liberty at that time, but to send a message to those who want to reach those countries, a dissuasive message so that they renounce to request asylum in the countries where they are treated in this way . That is why we are debating here, and that situation we have to change. Dublin does not solve the problem. We all agree that new rules must be found to regulate this situation in a different way. What is certain is that humanitarian principles cannot be abandoned when it comes to protecting people who flee in some cases of war, because it can kill them, and in other cases hunger, which kills with the same or even greater intensity than the war itself. Therefore, the Member States must ensure proper management of this asylum policy, which has been so generously described by both the Council and the Commission, but which is so little respected by some of the Member States of the Union.

name: Timothy KIRKHOPE
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, I know I have already said it more than once this week, but properly implementing the rules we already have in place is the key to dealing with the challenges we face. The more these challenges grow, the more we need those rules to be properly enforced. On dozens of occasions I have stood in this chamber and pointed out that some Member States have been getting away with flouting those rules, and that includes long before the extent of the current crisis hit us. We all know who those Member States are, and we all know the Commission should have done far more before now in addressing these problems. We understand that funding, and the ability of Member States to allocate the necessary resources is, of course, proving very difficult. But that should never be allowed to stand in the way of basic human dignity and upholding the laws to which we are all subject. This forms part of a wider discussion which we need to start having if we are to tackle the migrant crisis effectively. Border control, fingerprinting, processing upon arrival, and improving detention conditions – there are rules on all those issues, and it is high time the Commission started reminding certain Member States, in the strongest terms, that they have to play by them too. Lots of new ideas and new proposals are coming, but let us try to get things sorted out with those currently at our disposal before we move on any further. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Tim AKER
text: blue-card question. – You talk about the migrant crisis. The migrant crisis could be settled if free movement was challenged head-on. David Cameron had the opportunity for this with the renegotiation package. He said in his Bloomberg speech he was going to renegotiate free movement. All of a sudden, when it is crunch time, he shied away from this. Why has he done this? Why has he given up the opportunity to settle this issue once and for all and cowed to the European Union?

name: Timothy KIRKHOPE
text: blue-card answer. – Can I just say that is a bit pathetic, really. I have not had time to be able to talk more broadly on migration issues. I have absolute confidence in the leader of my party and the leader of the UK in negotiating matters which are to the benefit not only of the UK, but also in terms of the order which is necessary in the migrant situation in the European Union for the future. It is rather sad that this sort of slanging, which comes from extreme parties in my country, really does not contribute at all to the major debate that we all need to have for the future.

name: Cecilia WIKSTRÖM
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. –  Mr President, the debate today is a very good opportunity to start putting facts back in a debate that is getting more and more surrealistic by the day. The most flagrant example is the proposal made by the President of the European Council, Mr Tusk, who put forward the idea that all asylum seekers should be detained for 18 months to screen if they are potential terrorists. The most bizarre thing is that he does not seem to even realise that this would be completely against existing EU legislation. Let me say it again: the President of the European Council is proposing that all persons seeking refuge in Europe, fleeing war and persecution, from the smallest baby to the oldest man or woman, should be put in prison-like camps for a year and a half. Mr President, this equals the darkest periods in European history that we do not want wish to see again. I think that it is shocking to the point that I personally think that Mr Tusk should be asked to publicly apologise for this. In the media today we hear talk about refugees illegally entering the Union. This is a narrative that is not only dangerous, it is incorrect. It is not in any way illegal to enter a country in order to ask for asylum. This is a recognised human right in all of the EU’s Member States.  Now, if we were to work together we would be able to offer shelter to those in need, but instead of that, rampant nationalism has taken over the public debate. This crisis has not been caused by refugees or the European institutions; it has been caused by nationalist governments and populists that are actively preventing a European solution to the situation. It is high time that we realised that the best way to solve the situation is to do it together. (Applause) (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Kazimierz Michał UJAZDOWSKI
text: question asked by picking up a blue card.- Madam, I think that you have presented the words of the President of the European Council very bias and untruthfully that he is proposing some kind of draconian procedure.Then if you do not like the proposal of the President of the European Council, what procedure do you propose?After all, no one will accept the automatic admission of all immigrants and their qualification as refugees.What is your proposal for security in Europe?

name: Cecilia WIKSTRÖM
text: blue-card answer. –  My proposal is very simple and it goes for a large majority of the LIBE Committee, of which I am coordinator. It is a common responsibility sharing, a distribution key to Member States that is based on quantitative data such as population, GDP, employment rate, etc. It should also be taken into account which countries did the most for refugees up until now – like Sweden, Germany, Austria and others. It is high time that the countries that did not participate stood up and took full responsibility because today there is a situation we have to handle. Tomorrow it will be a different situation and we will all be stronger together.

name: Josu JUARISTI ABAUNZ
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr President, a month ago we spoke with a young Afghan on the border between Serbia and Bulgaria; After crossing Iran and Turkey, Bilal went through hell in Bulgaria. I want to report abuses against refugees and migrants at the hands of the Bulgarian police. GUE / NGL has collected in the Balkans testimonies of beatings, extortion and shootings that have taken place in Bulgaria. Like Oxfam, Amnesty International or UNHCR, we saw cuts and bruises and even bite marks from the dogs that the Bulgarian police had prodded. We note the harsh conditions of the people who crossed Bulgaria, where they were forced to register their fingerprints, and later entered Serbia through Dimitrovgrad, where some also suffered beatings and extortion. There is a sinister pattern. These people are detained, sometimes they are beaten and the agents steal money and valuables from them. They are then transferred to places of detention with poor sanitary conditions and little water and food. I want to show you photos of a group of Afghans resting as they can in a forest and some of the few images that exist of a detention center in Bulgaria. Ladies and gentlemen, this cannot happen, not in the Union, not anywhere else. But it is happening here. We are talking, in Bulgaria and in other states, of police violence, corruption, fences and returns at the border. We are talking about inhumane conditions and an asylum policy that does not deserve that name. These facts are unacceptable and we demand an independent investigation. (He agreed to answer a question asked under the "blue card" procedure (Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: question asked by raising a blue card. - Ladies and gentlemen, first of all, I think that these accusations are absolutely slanderous and untrue, and secondly, I think that the people who come from Afghanistan are somehow not refugees from Syria, simply because they are from Afghanistan. And now let me ask you, when was the last time you were at the Bulgarian-Turkish border and when was the last time you saw with your own eyes the situation faced by our border police services, which, among other things, protect the European Union's external border from what happens in many places in Europe, for example in Paris?

name: Josu JUARISTI ABAUNZ
text: "blue card" response.- You will agree with me that Afghans are people too.It doesn't matter where they are from, and the testimonies we collected did not correspond only to Afghans, and reality is reality and we do not report it or denounce it only in the GUE / NGL Group.Watch and read the reports that Oxfam, UNHCR or Amnesty International have issued and you will see what the reality is.

name: Judith SARGENTINI
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - The newspapers across the ocean are full of reports about "the Donald", the presidential candidate Donald Trump. He wants to close the American borders rigorously to Muslims. His response to the attack in San Bernardino is to blame the supporters of a religion and denounce them all as suspects. We have our own Donald, the President of the European Council, Donald Tusk. And our Donald thought it necessary to give an interview in Europe's most influential newspapers in which he states that all migrants entering the Union must first be detained for 18 months in order to be thoroughly screened. He said it's not just about limiting the flow of refugees, don't underestimate the security aspect, international and European laws have an 18-month rule. You can and should detain migrants for as long as their screening lasts. In addition to displaying incredible ignorance, I am particularly concerned about the way Donald Tusk puts refugees and migrants here primarily as a security risk. The difference with Trump is not that big. Do you know where the real difference is between "the Donald" and our Donald? In contradiction! Trump got a reply. He was made clear in his own conservative circle that they did not speak in that party, that they did not accept stigmatizing remarks like this and that it was in violation of Article 1 of the US Constitution. Where were our leaders with their corrective comments? Why didn't I hear Cameron, Renzi, Hollande, Rutte? They should have said: Donald, you're setting the wrong example. That's not how we treat refugees and that's how we spread fear among our population. Mr President, you know the law, I know the law, the Commissioner knows the law, Mr Schmit knows the law. Donald didn't know the law, but who was Tusk actually speaking on behalf of? Minister Schmit, can you clarify that? Does Luxembourg support the statements of the President of the Council? Is locking up migrants on arrival a proposal that we can join the summit tomorrow as one of the last things you want to give us for Christmas? President Tusk is legitimizing the indolence of the member states here. Do nothing and wait for it to blow over. Mr President, it will not blow over, but one thing we know for sure: we cannot expect anything from Donald Tusk, the President of the Council, before Christmas, and unfortunately not after Christmas either. [The speaker addressed a "blue card" question under Rule 162 (8).]

name: Janice ATKINSON
text: blue-card question. – Madam, do you not think that Mr Renzi, Mr Tusk and even Mr Cameron are actually listening to the people that they represent? They do not magic this out of the air; they are actually listening to their citizens’ concerns. I suggest, actually, that you start doing that too.

name: Judith SARGENTINI
text: blue-card answer. – I think the question is: ʻDo you not agree with me, Madam?ʼ, and the answer is: ‘No, I don’t!’ I think also your Prime Minister has a certain decency in himself, not going about saying that we should lock up every migrant that comes here – a decency that leads to not putting more fear in people, fear that is illustrated by you, that will lead to more poverty and more terror in Europe. That is my opinion. (Applause)

name: Diane JAMES
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, an aspect of the logic and coherency of the European Union’s migration policy and resettlement programme is in the spotlight in that we now have to deal with the direct consequences of Mrs Merkel’s siren call to anyone, which has delivered unforeseen numbers seeking a home and a future within the European Union. Now, while some of those may be genuine asylum seekers or refugees, it is not yet possible to identify and confirm those who are masquerading as such. Dictated quotas, unreasonable deadlines and relaxed processing systems to resolve the resettlement logjam have only exacerbated the problems caused by Mrs Merkel’s ill-judged siren call, and the United Kingdom media and press have covered the instances of German and Swedish communities overwhelmed by resettled migrants, with stories of arson, street violence and increasing crime levels. In my own South-East region of the United Kingdom, the proposed forced settlement of 200 migrants near Chichester is viewed with fear, apprehension and mistrust, and that is totally understandable from a community of reportedly only 197 people. The importance of national and citizen consent should be paramount, not overridden or ignored by European Union forced numbers imposition, a dictatorial policy and an ill-considered ultimate control over asylum and refugee resettlement. Where detention or force has happened, it is because the level of pressure has become more than a Member State can bear or tolerate. The European Union needs to learn from its mistakes and also change direction completely. If you want newcomers to be welcomed, to smooth the process of acceptance and reintegration, to stop the community backlash and halt the instances of violence, then immediately stop behaving like a dictator, tell Mrs Merkel to rescind her siren call, and retract the freedom of movement principle. It is called getting a grip of the problem.

name: Vicky MAEIJER
text: - Hundreds of thousands of asylum seekers have found their way to the European Union in the past year and the asylum sunami is also engulfing my country.So far, more fortune seekers have arrived in the Netherlands than in the whole of 2013 and 2014 combined, with all the consequences that entails.This has to stop.The Netherlands is a functioning constitutional state where suspects, criminals, terrorists and also asylum seekers are treated properly.And yes, we reserve the right to place asylum seekers in immigration detention.Immigration detention is important.If it is up to my party, the Party for Freedom, then the safety of the Dutch citizen comes first and we apply this both to asylum seekers who have not been screened for safety and to those who have exhausted all legal remedies or illegal immigrants.We turn them off or we fix them.And we determine that ourselves, not the European Union.The PVV would rather not see these asylum seekers coming at all.The Netherlands must close its borders.

name: Mariya GABRIEL
text: - Mr. President, Bulgaria was quoted. Bulgaria has a great responsibility as an external border of the European Union to ensure the security of the Union. The country works closely with European agencies and international institutions and takes action in accordance with international and European law. In this context, I would like to point out 4 factors: first, we should use a uniform methodology when preparing monitoring reports assessing national reception systems for asylum seekers. This is definitely missing in the cited reports. Persons accusing them of committing violations should stand by their names. Second, the UN High Commissioner for Refugees and the Bulgarian Helsinki Committee carry out daily monitoring of compliance with the principle of non-refoulement. From February 2015, it was decided to carry out unannounced inspections. So far, no signs of physical violence or degrading treatment have been identified. The presence of a Frontex employee during all proceedings with detained third-country nationals is a guarantee of compliance with the principle of non-refoulement. We should also show our respect for our own agencies, such as Frontex. Moreover, law enforcement officers receive special training on asylum issues. They conduct daily briefings, are subject to constant monitoring for compliance with the instructions. It is right to take into account the difficult conditions in which they work. Thirdly, the formal procedure in the event of an accusation of non-compliance with European law by a Member State requires that an official document be drawn up requesting an explanation from the relevant national authorities. Only in this way, having complete information from the parties concerned, can we be objective. Finally, colleagues, the key role of NAFTA is in the European Parliament. The LIBE Commission sends delegations which clearly state the reception conditions. But it is very important for us not to lose sight of the fact that countries that are making efforts should be encouraged and, above all, to treat this problem as part of our overall migration management strategy.

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: -  Mister President! The events of summer 2015 will keep us busy for a very long time. They met us unprepared, but not unexpected. It was the largest refugee movement since World War II, and nothing will be the same as it was before. We have experienced an uncanny hectic pace, we have seen barbed wire fences, we have seen camps - real and informal - we have seen the use of force. Much could have been avoided if one had followed the ideas that this House has long represented. In April we spoke of a holistic approach, we spoke of a differentiated approach, one would have to differentiate between migration, flight and displacement and asylum. Everything is lumped together, but we need different instruments. And that is also the problem: that the purpose of the asylum procedure is lost in the process of offering protection seekers, carrying out an individual examination, guaranteeing fair and speedy procedures. Internment is only an exception procedure and may only be necessary in certain circumstances. We have admission guidelines, we have talked about standards, we have talked about the fact that it cannot be a prison situation, as we have decided. We spoke about the special vulnerability of children and young people. We certainly haven't talked about the systematic use of force. I wonder why this package has not yet been implemented in all Member States. Many Member States may have doubts about the usefulness of the Dublin procedure. We should seriously ask ourselves how we can replace Dublin with something more sensible, more workable. We should talk about humanitarian entry corridors, i.e. legal legal avenues, then we would avoid a lot. And we should also ask ourselves: How to deal with Turkey? Because if we already have such difficulties here, how problematic will it be when dealing with Turkey?

name: Helga STEVENS
text: - After the Paris attacks, President Tusk stated that illegal migrants should be able to be held for as long as necessary to carry out identity checks. Unfortunately, it is a fact that at least one of the perpetrators entered Europe with a suspected false Syrian passport. Asylum seekers are certainly not terrorists, but some terrorists also travel along the Balkan route, as do most refugees. Besides, only 30 percent of the refugees are from Syria. That says a lot. Do we really find it that shocking to briefly detain people who cross the border illegally to check their identity and origin? We are talking here about an uncontrolled mass influx of refugees. Colleagues, therefore, rather ask the question why our external borders are as leaky as a sieve and why Greece and Italy are not taking more action. And why until recently the Commission looked the other way in all of this. Gentle healers make smelly wounds.

name: Nathalie GRIESBECK
text: - Mr President, how is it possible that in the 21st century, we still have to explain and remind the European states, cradles of democracy, that it is inadmissible to detain children - children fleeing war, fleeing from atrocities none of us have ever experienced? I think this is unacceptable. The right to liberty, the right to protection against arbitrary detention are fundamental human rights that are enshrined in the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, and they apply to every human being, without exception. However, we see more and more often - as was recalled a moment ago - that refugees are detained. There are reports of violence, brutality, secret detentions, and I would like, like some colleagues, to be able to explain to me how the President of the Council, Mr. Tusk, who basically speaks on our behalf and represents us all , was able, just a few days ago, to say that refugees should be detained for up to 18 months upon arrival in Europe. To avoid flouting our values ​​and to ensure that we respect the fundamental rights that we brandish all the time, we must organize ourselves together through effective border control, by sharing responsibilities - it is a necessity -, and to ensure that dignity is guaranteed for everyone, in the European area and beyond.

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: - Mr President! Together with a delegation from GUE / NGL, we went to the Balkans and met refugees. We met with organizations, and we also met with border police. It is obvious that people who are on the run have gone through more than any human being should have to go through. They have the right to seek asylum and they have the right to a dignified reception here in Europe. They are not illegal and they should not be locked up, and they should not be subjected to violence. Despite this, we have documented the brutality and imprisonment of refugees in Turkey. We have an Amnesty report on that. We also have reports from Hungary that they lock in asylum seekers, so that the asylum seekers themselves think they have been in prison if they come from there. What refugees and medical staff tell us about police brutality and robbery by the police in Bulgaria is a reality. My question to the Commission and the Council is: What will you do to stop this? Is it okay for a Member State's police force to rob and use violence against refugees? How are you going to demand that Turkey stop using violence against refugees, or are you going to keep turning your back on it? Do you intend to call on the Commission to call on Member States to stop Dublin transfers to Hungary and Bulgaria, where refugees have been subjected to violence? I want concrete answers, because if you do nothing then it will be the case that we who should provide protection, instead of providing protection, allow a continuation of the violence and trauma that no one should have to experience.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: Mr Björk there is a question for you, do you accept it?The Honorable Buonanno.(Mrs Malin Björk refuses to answer a 'blue card' question from Mrs Buonanno).According to the regulation, it is the right of deputies to accept the application, if one does not want to accept it he is free to do so.

name: Ska KELLER
text: – Mr President, I had a look at President Tusk’s job description and helpfully he publishes it on the website, and it reads that he is supposed to help to ‘facilitate cohesion and consensus within the European Council’. Now, I am not sure Mr Tusk looks at this job description and website very often. Maybe he should, because the interview that he has been giving to the Guardian and other newspapers was surely not very helpful in this regard. President Tusk unfortunately also does not seem to be very firm on EU legislation or else he would not have made proposals that go against European law and also against any sort of humanitarian sense. But then again, it is not he who is Guardian of the Treaty. This is not his task, it is the task of the Commission, so I am very sure that Mr Juncker had a good talk with Mr Tusk and that we will in future be hearing more, let us say, consensual and more forward-bringing issues and descriptions from our President of the Council.

name: Laura FERRARA
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the challenge facing the European Union today is to find the right balance in the balance between freedom and security. Security should be a tool for achieving and guaranteeing freedom, which is a fundamental right. Today, however, it seems that this balance tends increasingly towards security at the expense of freedom. It is right and proper to identify migrants and asylum seekers, this is to the benefit of the safety of the European citizens they welcome and also to the benefit of the security and rights that are guaranteed to the citizens of third countries who ask to be received. So what's the solution? The solution is certainly not the use of force. The solution is certainly not administrative detention, unfortunately we have seen in Italy, for example, the extremely negative examples of the CIE concentration camps, the identification and expulsion centers, where riots have often occurred due to the conditions in which migrants live. who are being held and detained in these centers. So what's the solution? What the 5 Star Movement has been proposing for some time: modification of the Dublin regulation, creating humanitarian corridors, humanitarian visas, so that you already have a title, these people are already identified before and greater security for citizens is guaranteed Europeans and for the citizens who are welcomed.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, when it comes to immigration, Europe always repeats the same words to us: welcome, solidarity, integration. Supinely, the Italian government of the tragic couple Renzi-Alfano opens the doors of houses and hotels to host all those illegal immigrants who are only minimally refugees. And what does Europe do? First he praises the great heart of Italy which welcomes hundreds and thousands of illegal immigrants and then sanctions Italy for its inability to manage migratory flows. Shame on you, all of you, European Commission and Italian government! I ask the Commission: why are identification centers not set up in Africa to identify and assess who is entitled to refugee status there? Why then are the refugees not really distributed in all 28 countries of the Union without having them die at sea on the rubber dinghies of human traffickers who leave for Italy? Why leave the incapable Italian government managing what is now an out-of-control invasion? Commissioner, the infringement against Italy will be of no use and will not serve to control the arrival of new illegal immigrants, perhaps terrorists. It will not help those who are truly fleeing the war. It will not serve to appease the anger of Italian citizens, of those pensioners who survive on 400 euros a month, while for illegal immigrants everything is free: food, accommodation, cell phones, services. The Italians reduced to hunger, the illegals all in the hotel as if they were on vacation. No, no and still no!

name: Emil RADEV
text: - Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen, in a number of its reports and assessments, the European Commission claims that Bulgaria is successfully guarding Europe's external borders. For the most part, the region on the border of Bulgaria with Turkey, which has been under strong migratory pressure for several years, is characterized by heavily rugged and difficult to access terrain. Bulgarian border police successfully work in harsh conditions and guarantee European security every day by breaking up networks of human traffickers, apprehending people accused of committing criminal or terrorist activities and rescuing migrants in distress when crossing the border. Despite the constant efforts of the Bulgarian border police, my country has once again been wrongfully accused by foreign NGOs of ill-treating asylum seekers. I would like to emphasize that a number of checks have been carried out on compliance with European legislation and on the work of the border police - none of which proves these allegations. The admission of illegal crossing of the state border through the unspecified places creates preconditions for entry into the territory of the Republic of Bulgaria and the European Union of accomplices and members of Islamic terrorist organizations. In view of this, Bulgaria is taking and will continue to take the strictest measures permitted by national and international law to ensure a high level of border security and to control the passage of the flow of illegal migrants and asylum seekers. That is why I would like to call on all those who criticize the countries on the European Union's external border who are experiencing the pressure of the migrant wave - before you point a finger at us, get acquainted with the conditions under which our staff is trying to deal with the situation. only asylum seekers. Also talk to those who meet thousands of migrants face to face every day, and only then, based on the views of both countries, write reports!

name: Iliana IOTOVA
text: - Mr President, in 2015 we wrote many documents, we talked about many strategies on how to deal with the refugee crisis, but we seem to have forgotten the most important thing - the human face of this crisis, the many conflicts, the many wars and human tragedy, the loss of human rights. And that is why today is this debate in this Chamber. But all this would not have happened if the measures we had proposed earlier this year had been implemented. That is why the Member States somehow felt alone, they started to build borders and on the borders themselves, on the walls themselves, there was a huge tension. Dublin has not worked for a long time. The temporary refugee distribution mechanism has stalled. The hotspots have just started and the results are more than scarce. The criteria for their distribution in the Member States are not clear. As of today, a message has been added for a new methodology for 80,000 Syrian refugees, who must come annually from Turkey to European countries. At the same time, the majority of immigrants do not want to stay in the countries of the European Union's external border. They go to northern and western Europe. The lack of emergency measures and a clear outlook reinforces fears among both refugees and European citizens. And now I will say something about those who have repeatedly mentioned the name of my country Bulgaria. The most wrong message in this room today is to point the finger at one country or another. We all face the same difficulties, we all have to deal with them. It is not violence when you have to identify and when you have to take your fingerprints, because these are European rules and laws and all of you in this Chamber have voted on them. Therefore, when a country like Bulgaria implements them, it is not a violation of the rules and it is not a violation of human rights and freedoms. I have to add one more thing. Monitoring reports are made each year to monitor how countries are coping with the refugee crisis. So far there have been no remarks on my side. That is why, when we base these accusations in vain, when we call certain European citizens xenophobes, we are only feeding more on xenophobia and populism in Europe.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, colleagues, the basis of this another meaningless debate on the subject was several, or are several reports, which are full of false allegations, with slanderous conclusions in them. I categorically reject them and claim that they are not true. Because such things can be written by people who are either ill-intentioned or have never seen this European border and do not know at all where the border between Bulgaria and Turkey is. I claim, ladies and gentlemen, that this border, in addition to ours, is also an external border of the European Union and we have the obligation and the right to guard it so that we can guarantee our citizens the necessary security and ensure that they live normally and will not live. to be threatened by one or another terrorist and other attacks. But something else impresses me in this debate. Obviously, more and more colleagues do not understand what it is about and continue to say the same things that have nothing to do with living life. Anyone who calls fingerprinting violence is clearly not aware that it is in fact a European document that has been signed. And once again I will turn to all those who fall into some strange dichotomy of personality. Those who are greeted with teddy bears will send with candles. It must be clear. And those who wish to be related to the so-called illegal immigrants, to be so good - there are planes, there are airports in Turkey - to transport them directly. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question) (Rule 162 (8)).

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), blue card question.- Colleague, I would like to ask you if you agree that the complaints are made at the urging of some NGOs and lawyers who win against immigrants and that their suspicious role should be investigated?

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: answer a question asked by picking up a blue card.-  Thank you for the question.As you can see, unlike other colleagues who make unproven accusations, we do not hesitate to answer.Yes, I think these NGOs have a specific benefit, they work for specific interests and they are a little ashamed and afraid to say who is to blame.They are afraid to say the name of German Chancellor Merkel and ask her how she will take responsibility for what she has done to Europe.

name: Angelika MLINAR
text: -  Mister President! I am concerned that some Member States deliberately criminalize asylum seekers. Crossing the border illegally, especially if there is no legal possibility of applying for asylum, is certainly not a worse offense than parking wrongfully. So it is not a criminal offense, and yet we arrest asylum seekers. Like Article 5 of the European Convention on Human Rights, EU law stipulates that deprivation of liberty is only permitted as a last resort in an asylum procedure. Deprivation of liberty and thus imprisonment for the purpose of identification or to take fingerprints must therefore not be an automatic immediate measure. We are mostly dealing with traumatized and vulnerable people and even children here and we should never forget that. Quite apart from the fact that this type of treatment is extremely costly and poses a moral dilemma for the officers who intervene because they have to arrest and detain people who have not committed a crime. It is time to change this practice and make refugees more humane.

name: Barbara SPINELLI
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I read in the Commission's communiqué on Italian hotspots that Rome must provide a legal framework for the use of force for fingerprinting and prolonged detention. It is difficult, say the jurists, unless you violate two articles of the Constitution. I wonder how we intend to deal with detentions and violence against refugees that extend to Hungary, Bulgaria, Poland, France, Spain. In Italy, forced expulsions are also implemented when the judges suspend repatriation. The Danish government has confiscated the refugees' jewels, excluding wedding rings, since Sunday to pay the costs. It is serious that such measures are presented as urgent and mandatory to save Schengen, that President Tusk recommends eighteen months of refugee confinement, again to save Schengen, that non-refoulement, habeas corpus, non-coercion are not considered mandatory. on vulnerable people or minors. We cannot limit ourselves to imposing only repressive measures, while the Charter and the Treaties provide for very binding rights and discretionary clauses. If this is the Schengen price, no thanks! As a citizen I renounce Schengen without hesitation.

name: Eva JOLY
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, the plight of refugees no longer seems to move anyone. Worse, the President of the Council goes there with his security and dangerous statements, as if to better stick to the populist remarks that we hear everywhere and too often in Europe. I don't know what shocks me the most: that Mr. Tusk raised the possibility of detaining the migrants for 18 months for security reasons or that the request of the Greens asking him to explain his words in plenary was rejected by other political groups. Move around, there is nothing to see, nothing to complain about. As far as migrants are concerned, we can therefore say everything, offer everything, do everything. In Europe, the walls are rising one by one, but the dikes have completely failed. This is the irresponsible message we are sending to European citizens. No more international law, humanitarian aid, solidarity! Now we are talking about borders, security, war. Migration is further criminalized, a human right recognized by international law. This is Europe in 2015! I tell you today: we will have to go beyond wishes and good resolutions to reorient Europe in the right direction.

name: Kristina WINBERG
text: - Mr President! Of course, detention and coercion are something that should be avoided as far as possible. However, we must be aware that a large proportion of those who come to Europe to seek asylum do not have valid grounds for asylum. The only chance these people have to stay in Europe is if they manage to cheat, e.g. by refusing to leave fingerprints or in any other way sabotaging the asylum process. Then we have the people who have had their asylum application rejected but nevertheless refuse to respect this and instead choose to become illegal migrants. We must be able to detain these people and also use force to send them back. In both these cases, we must be able to use an appropriate level of coercion to make these people respect our asylum process and the decisions that are made. The truth is that a large proportion of migrants cheat and use our systems. We must have the tools to deal with these cheaters. The use of coercion in some cases must be included in that toolbox, otherwise we will be inundated with these cheaters.

name: Janice ATKINSON
text: –  Mr President, I would actually like to see more detention, particularly in Calais. Every day we receive reports about violent and aggressive migrants, some with jihadist backgrounds, including the Paris attackers. In Calais British truck drivers are threatened and attacked on a daily basis whilst trying to do their job. We hear appalling stories of British lorry drivers who are threatened with weapons including knives, baseball bats and even guns. Their safety and lives are at risk. Hundreds of migrants arriving in Norway have been found with jihadi pictures on their cameras. Who is checking the Calais migrants? Nobody has a clue what these migrants are doing in the Calais jungle. When are the French authorities finally going to act against these criminals who are threatening the safety of our citizens? Do the authorities really want to risk the first truck driver getting killed before they take appropriate action? If police forces are not able to control the situation, make the army step in to ensure security in Calais just as they do in the rest of France. If the Front National had won the Calais region last weekend a better solution would have been found for the lawlessness in the Calais jungle. Those migrants that commit criminal acts need to be arrested, detained and deported straightaway before it is too late.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: - Commissioner, colleagues, I might like to begin by thanking you for opening this subject and for this very interesting debate. It is a reflection of what is happening in society. Not everyone can agree with everything. Not all of us can see things the same way. And it's not always the only truth, it depends on the point of view. But to begin with, let's say that before we start criticizing anyone, let's admit that we all made a mistake. We all somehow don't follow the rules, either on one side or the other. Only then can we rationally solve the problem of refugees. Today, we are talking here about the appalling situation of refugees and asylum seekers waiting at the European Union's external border or directly inside. Yes, their situation is appalling. But let's ask why this is so? Who are these people? And how do these people behave? Do they always follow all the rules? I could analyze the experience of refugee camps, from the borders, for a long time, but I don't think it's worth it. These things have been said many times here. From my own experience, I know that there are people everywhere who do not follow the rules, and the asylum application itself is not relevant to them. The legitimacy and length of their detention is therefore very debatable, and it is necessary to look at the whole matter from many angles. Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to conclude by inviting you all to one. Let us not just criticize, but let's think about how to deal with the whole situation, and please, let us deal with it positively, for the benefit of those who need our help the most.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: - Dear ladies and gentlemen! If we try to look at this thing here, in this Chamber, and not just here in this Chamber, but in the press environment surrounding the European Parliament in general, then I have to say that this debate is correct. Only European public discourse is much more complicated and much rougher than that, what's more, reading the central media and looking at it again, I can only say that opinions can scatter, but we have no idea what's in the end. This is a terrible public discourse that is also generated by some governments, such as the Hungarian Government, which, strange as it may be, has built that terrible fence on the ears of those sitting here in this room, partly with European money, and continues that government propaganda with partly European money. , which does not literally suggest on radio, television, he says, to be afraid of refugees. Refugees are terrorists, everyone get ready, everyone get ready for self-defense, there is a flood and the rest and the rest. Well, the European Union needs to be able to show more power than that, and in that sense it is really necessary to unify the rules, and we demand them, that we are talking about here today. And along with this case, I would mention the PNR regulation, the passenger name record system. So it is not possible to do this by checking each other, the European citizens living here, from head to toe, but at the same time hundreds of thousands can cross two Schengen borders in, say, Greece when they enter and when they leave without any control. So in Hungarian, I think we really need a much more cohesive and unified point of view, which in turn we adhere to by everyone.

name: Jussi HALLA-AHO
text: – Mr President, one important defect in our migration policy is that Europe is unable to return those people whose asylum applications have been rejected. It is clear that this fact encourages the use of the asylum system as a channel of economic migration. In most cases, applicants wait for the decision in open reception facilities. When they learn that their application has been rejected they very often disappear and remain in the Schengen area as illegal immigrants. Sometimes they vanish from reception centres before they are even registered and fingerprinted. All this undermines the credibility of the asylum system. It would be a good idea to always detain asylum seekers for as long as their case is being processed. If this is against the existing EU law, then we should change that EU law.

name: Maite PAGAZAURTUNDÚA
text: - Mr. President, the parents of Jesus of Nazareth escaped to Egypt fleeing from the persecution of the innocent.If he had depended on Mrs. Bizzotto, Mrs. Winberg, or Mrs. Atkinson, Jesus of Nazareth would not have been born even in a stable;They would have been deported, and Maria would have given birth in any gutter and surely the child would have died.Hard-hearted!Commission and Council, if you do not verify the suspicions that there may be a violation of fundamental rights with people who are fleeing the war, you will be guilty.Check it out and, if it's true, be very tough, because today Mr Juncker told us what history we are prepared to tolerate and write.I do not intend to be an accomplice, of course, that that is written.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: – Mr President, ʻgive me your huddled masses yearning to breathe freeʼ is written proudly on the base of the Statute of Liberty. What would be written if she stood in Lampedusa? Maybe, ‘get in line, prepare for internment and deportation, or return to war zones’. Fortress Europe wants authorities to forcibly register and detain asylum seekers to protect the failed Dublin Regulation, identify hotspots and deploy rapid-response units. The EU is complicit in serious human rights abuse. Yesterday, Amnesty International published a report condemning how Turkey has unlawfully apprehended, detained and pressurised refugees and asylum seekers to return to war zones. Hungary and Bulgaria are no better. Europe is not faced with a deadly invasion. Refugees are people like you and me who, along with their children, are fleeing desperate conflicts in the Middle East and North Africa – conflicts made worse by the bombs of Member States. Offering simple, safe and legal routes and de-escalating conflict will help alleviate the conflicts and the crisis. From 1892, Ellis Island, without computers, neither internet nor modern-day sophistication, offered safe and legal access to millions. So I leave you with a quote from an Irish conservative philosopher, Edmund Burke, who said: ʻthe only thing necessary for the triumph of evil is for good men to do nothingʼ.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: – Mr President, the President of the European Council should facilitate bringing together different Member States’ positions in order to find sustainable and humane solutions. He should also stand up for common European values, and he should not give way to using his position as a tool for advancing national politics. His proposal to detain refugees arriving in the EU for 18 months goes not only against EU law, but also against international law. Talk of detaining refugees further deepens the gaps and divisions between Member States and is thus very harmful at times when common EU asylum and migration policies are needed. Instead of populist responses like this, a comprehensive approach is needed in order to tackle the humanitarian crisis the world is currently facing.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: - Mr President, ten days after the attacks of November 13, two committees of the European Parliament dared to vote, in accelerated procedure, a text which intends to facilitate the lodging of complaints by illegal immigrants. While the Commission announces the arrival of more than three million new illegal immigrants by 2017, the right and left of this hemicycle adopted on December 2 this resolution which encourages illegal immigration. Indeed, this text aims to prevent border guards from doing their job, by inciting illegal immigrants to file a complaint against them. Worse, the heavily subsidized NGOs, which have made the systematic defense of foreigners their business, will be able to launch legal proceedings on behalf of these immigrants who entered our countries illegally. While your priority must be to guarantee the security and prosperity of the Europeans who elected you, you always give more priority to the illegals than to the citizens, the others before our own. To irresponsibility, you added indecency, by inviting us to drink champagne to celebrate the adoption of this fatal resolution. But while you whistle your bubbles, it is our compatriots who clink glasses. Sooner or later you will be held to account!

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The public is welcome, but they can do anything in this House except applaud and disagree and show approval or disapproval.This is a very serious fact!And I ask the tribune services to intervene.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the commitment made in managing the migratory flows that have specifically affected some European countries has been characterized by actions taken on several fronts, in order to guarantee the best possible reception for all migrants, refugees and asylum seekers . In the context of the reception devices activated, the necessary checks carried out on those entering Europe must be based on respect for rights and must be carried out in the shortest possible time because the fight against traffickers and exploiters, as well as the prevention of other forms of crime, including terrorism, first of all involves the correct application of the relevant laws. Controls, in fact, must be reconciled with full respect for the dignity and fundamental rights of the person, in order to no longer have to witness situations of migrants crammed into unsuitable structures for periods longer than those provided for by law, in a state of evident psychophysical distress and without adequate forms of assistance, including legal. It should always be kept in mind that, on the basis of European legislation and in accordance with Article 5 of the European Convention on Human Rights, deprivation of liberty for reasons related to immigration is a measure that can only be used as a last resort and is important consistently address the issue relating to the system of reporting possible violations of the human rights of migrants hosted in reception centers, also taking into due consideration the indications that can be derived from the interventions of the European Ombudsman. In my opinion, the new European Border and Coast Guard Corps that will be formed shortly should already be able to include an office responsible for fundamental rights, which works closely with all relevant actors to support vulnerable groups such as minors, especially unaccompanied minors, exposed to the greatest risk of becoming victims of organized crime.

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: -  Mister President! As a long-time member of Amnesty International, I was delighted that so many correct things were said about refugee rights today and I would add that it is a shame how refugees are often attacked or refugee homes set on fire in my country. But in the interests of those who have the right to stay in the country, one must also talk about their duties. Refugees who destroy their identity documents before the border with the EU or who give false information about their identity behind the border and who want to continue their religious and ethnic disputes with violence in Europe should be sent back home without any ifs or buts. The same applies to those who stay: integration is not only an obligation of the Europeans, it is also an obligation of the refugees to collect. This is another message that should come from this Parliament. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the blue card procedure under Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: Question "blue card".- Thank you, honorable, you are much more democratic than the honorable Member who didn't let me speak before.I wanted to ask you, I completely agree with what you were saying a moment ago.Would you agree to do a Guantánamo in Europe?

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: Answer to a question about the “blue card” procedure.- As a member of Amnesty International, I have always campaigned for the closure of the prison in Guantánamo and can therefore only say: No.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: GUE / NGL). - Mr President, in recent weeks there have been alarming reports from international human rights organizations of the mistreatment of migrants and refugees by the police authorities of the Eastern European Member States, as well as by the Turkish authorities. The European Union, however, must defend its constitutional values, namely fundamental rights and the rule of law, and condemn their violations, wherever they come from. We must not forget that the refugees are not criminals, but left their homeland for fear of persecution or in search of a better life. We need to find a fair balance between guarding the external borders, which is necessary to prevent crime, and protecting fundamental rights. The Union must also do its utmost to bring peace and order to its region and especially to the Middle East, with respect for international law, in order to end the forced displacement of people.

name: Ana GOMES
text: - Mr President, in advocating the detention of migrants and refugees, President Tusk embarrassed the European Union, mirroring the "orbanesque" drift with which European leaders have been riding citizens' insecurity in the face of the growing threats of unemployment, inequality and terrorism. We will not be effective in combating terrorists if we continue to deny, speaking of foreign fighters, to deceive that they, the ones who have beaten us, are Europeans. And not to acknowledge that austerity policies have only aggravated the Molenbeeks in which terrorist attacks are being prepared, just as they have incapacitated the security agencies that should share information and do not share it. And that they have not even been strengthened in recent months, sufficiently, to make reception hot spots operational and to speed up the registration and resettlement of asylum seekers, when there are Member States, such as mine, waiting to welcome them. Refugees that we have a legal and moral obligation to welcome and migrants that we have an economic and social interest in receiving in our aging societies will only stop coming massively and uncontrollably if the European Union is committed to resolving conflicts and fighting terror against that they flee and where they flee from. The only way to control, in fact, who comes in the massive wave of refugees and migrants is to create safe and legal channels for the organized analysis of their requests for entry into Europe. It is also the most effective way to profit from the networks of human traffickers, but these channels have been ignored by our leaders. There is no reinforcement of controls that can lock every meter of the European Union's border. Turning one's back on those in need of protection means ending the European project, playing the game of traffickers and terrorists. It will neither stop the influx of refugees nor give security to our citizens. Europe is what we need most to share information and prevention against terrorism and to share the effort of welcoming those who ask for asylum.

name: Zdzisław KRASNODĘBSKI
text: - Mr Chairman!Some colleagues, it seems to me, mean anarchy when they talk about law, and in their admirable idealism they lose a sense of reality.However, I would like to ask the representatives of the Council, the Commission and honorable colleagues how they envision a reallocation mechanism without an element of coercion, since the compulsory fingerprinting and detention of refugees in places of detention are also criticized here in this Chamber.The reallocation could not take place without the use of coercion, refugees would have to be forcibly transported from one country to which they were not going at all, and detained in countries where they did not intend to live, because, as we all know, they strive and choose certain types of countries.They do not want to live in Bulgaria, Poland, Lithuania, only Sweden and Germany.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: - Mr President, the use of force against asylum seekers is a disgrace, as is the use of force against migrants in general. May this discussion not serve to select human beings who are or are not likely to be violated. Assaults and arrests in Hungary, Poland, Bulgaria are heinous. People who crossed Bulgaria by land denounce the use of dogs, night-vision equipment and firearm shots, in addition to arrests and imprisonments in infrahuman conditions for several days. But it is also hideous how Turkey, for example, has been forcibly pushing Syrians into Syrian territory, a war zone, after detaining them in isolated and secret places. Turkey, whom the European Union wants to pay millions to care for the refugees it rejects. In the Aegean, vessels carrying migrants and refugees were attacked violently, allegedly by forces from a coast guard, with engines removed and punctured hulls. Who are these forces? Member States or the European Union?

name: Soraya POST
text: - Mr President! I would like to start with a statement. No human is illegal. The ongoing discussion on refugee policy within the EU is not favorable to our view of other people. Statements that we must strengthen borders and that the EU must set a ceiling on the number of fleeing people, and that we are talking about fleeing people in volumes, mean that they easily lose their human value in the eyes of the public. We have a responsibility to lead - not to be affected. It affects how fleeing people are treated, not least in border areas. We know that it happens that fleeing people are treated as criminals and cattle at border crossings. It is a shame for the EU and it is also illegal. Every country is obliged to respect the human rights of all individuals who are in its territory, and it is illegal to detain people for no reason. It is illegal to use force against people who want to exercise their right to seek asylum. It is illegal not to treat people as human beings. The EU has a major responsibility in this matter. We have a common asylum policy, and the Commission must ensure that the countries comply with this legislation. There is a need for a functioning and independent monitoring of the countries' and the EU's border guards, who should work preventively and deal with complaints. EU authorities must give priority to respecting human rights where they work and disseminate good practice in this area. If we are not able to treat fleeing people as human beings, sooner or later it is our own human value that is at stake.

name: Nikolaos CHOUNTIS
text: GUE / NGL). - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, this year, in 2015, we are celebrating the 65th anniversary of the conclusion of the European Convention on Human Rights, in the shadow of war, terrorism and thousands of refugees. Repression, police violence against refugees, fences, the creation of hotspots - concentration camps are a disgrace to the European Union and its Member States. They refer to other, dark times in Europe that no democratic citizen wants to revive. The Dublin system violates rights, countries like Italy and Greece have been turned into warehouses of people and the question of the present and the future of Europe, with the decisions adopted, is becoming more and more painful. For example, does the creation of the new Frontex guarantee the rights of asylum seekers? Second, against whom can those who have been wronged or mistreated appeal? Third, how are national sovereign rights secured? Unfortunately, the truth is tragic, the European Union is moving marginally in international law, shifting responsibilities and targeting its Member States. The European Union's political responsibilities and guilt cannot be met under the pressure of micropolitical interests, nationalist entrenchments and extreme rhetoric.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: - Mr. President, what we need to say simply once is that we were all surprised by this migrant crisis and that, of course, in that context we often knew how to improvise and make decisions that were not systematic.Because we have to tell ourselves that the Dublin system doesn’t work, it doesn’t exist.That is completely clear.But here I want to say very clearly that because we were unprepared we can not accept everything that is happening on the Hungarian border or what was happening on the Hungarian border, everything that is happening today on the Slovenian border with Croatia.We cannot accept Mr. Tusk's statements, which are completely inappropriate.In this context, I expect to reward countries such as Croatia, as well as Serbia and Macedonia, which have done very good things for the arrival of migrants in Europe.After all, every man really has the right to freedom and the right to asylum.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). - Mr President, Greece is flooded with thousands of refugees and illegal immigrants. More than 500,000 refugees have entered my country. In the summer I visited Samos, last Sunday Eidomeni at the Hellenoscope border, on Saturday I will visit Mytilene, therefore, I have a picture on the spot, "on the spot", of what is happening and I tell you that the Greek people impoverished by the memoranda did superhuman efforts to host thousands of refugees. The criticism that was heard about Greece is not only unfair but also malicious. Ladies and gentlemen, the number of refugees and immigrants has multiplied since Merkel invited refugees to Germany. Of the 160,000 refugees to be relocated, states have initiated proceedings against only 2,000 of the migrants and only 8 out of 28 states have responded. the wars in the Middle East.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: - Excellent parallel was used by dr. Our lawyer colleague Zsolt Zétényi at the recent conference of the National Rights Protection Service. Imagine a very rich company inviting a huge foreign delegation to its beautiful luxury palace revolving around the duck. When the huge foreign delegation arrives, it happens to be the weekend and only the porter is there in the building rotating on the duck. When they call their bosses in horror, they say it’s no problem, take them home to their own apartment, accommodate them, feed them, and make sure they feel good. This is exactly what happened to us, a country where people live on monthly salaries and incomes of 200-300 euros. You were kind enough to bring in many, many millions of refugees here, led by Mrs Merkel, their boss and Germany, and now they want the countries in need to take the bad luck. We don't ask for it, thank you.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: - Mr. President, we have often discussed the rights of refugees and migrants and asylum seekers during this crisis, and now is the time to finally discuss the obligations that come with those rights.The most important obligation is certainly to respect the constitution and the law of the Member State in which asylum seekers are currently located.I am aware of what a horrible situation these people have escaped from.I also understand that some of them are not adapted to our way of life and the laws that follow it.But, despite that, I think that we should treat them the same as our own citizens, without special treatment.The law must be the same for everyone.Although the situation with migrants and asylum seekers is very chaotic at the moment, there is no reason why we should suspend our own laws or tolerate offenses.All those who want to live in Europe must know that their adaptation to our way of life begins the moment they set foot on our soil.

name: Elly SCHLEIN
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, what we have heard about the detention of asylum seekers and the use of force to register them is worrying. I visited an identification and expulsion center in Italy last week and found that people arriving are not adequately informed about their rights, including the right to seek asylum. They are divided, discriminating them on the basis of nationality between illegal immigrants and relocatable, and translated into centers where they are told that since the request is late they can be withheld for up to one year. The living conditions in these centers are very bad, there are also minors who shouldn't even be there and the method of calculating their age with the wrist examination has a very high margin of error and is completely inadequate. Ultimately, people would register if they were given a clear perspective on their future. For this reason, the overcoming of Dublin and the relocation plan is very late and should have already started.

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank colleagues for this very fruitful debate, for the very constructive and productive discussion. You know that my colleague Dimitris Avramopoulos, who is in charge of this subject, has already covered all aspects of these very challenging matters in his opening remarks, so I shall say a few words only.  The Commission is taking action to ensure full compliance with EU law in the area of asylum, and the right to asylum is a fundamental right and of course this means respect of all aspects of the asylum legislation. This is very important. The Commission during the last semester has sent four reasoned opinions, 42 letters of formal notice and eight administrative letters in the field of asylum concerning the implementation of the Eurodac Regulation, and the transposition of compliance with the recast Asylum Procedures and Reception Conditions Directives. I would like to stress and to focus on this. The right to asylum is fundamental and of course this means respect of all aspects of the asylum legislation. The Commission remains fully committed to ensuring respect by Member States of human rights and dignity when they apply European Union law.

name: Nicolas SCHMIT
text: President-in-Office of the Council. - Mr President, Ladies and Gentlemen, I cannot set myself up as an interpreter of what the President of the European Council said, but I read in the letter he sent for the European Council tomorrow - I quote him, in English: 'The protection of our external borders is not intended to scare off those who flee wars or persecution. Europe is a community of freedom and will always provide shelter for those in danger. 'As the Commissioners did, I have outlined the law on detention, and it is clear that the detention of asylum seekers cannot not to be seen, nor interpreted, in any case, as the rule. If there are abuses, if there are situations where the European rules that have just been recalled by the Commissioner or international rules are not respected, measures must be taken, since human dignity and human rights of man cannot be violated with impunity. As we are somewhat in this crisis situation, it would perhaps be useful to reread our fundamental texts, those which make the European Union what it is, what it should be. These texts are, among other things, the charter of fundamental rights. Article 1 of this charter, what does it say? He says that "human dignity is inviolable. It must be respected and protected". What does article 18 say? That "the right to asylum is guaranteed in accordance with the rules of the Geneva Convention", etc. Here are our guides, and of course that everyone must respect our laws, our rules, including those who seek asylum.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The discussion is closed.Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: in writing. - Every crisis is an opportunity. The migration crisis is an opportunity for us for the EU to take ownership and put things that matter to us first. However, it is important that we are not controlled by events, but by us responsibly. I am convinced that if we put our heads in the sand and start pointing at each other, this will not lead us to chaos, but to chaos. Schengen must remain, say, while more and more Member States are calling for the temporary reintroduction of border controls. Free movement is a huge value. After that, I just don’t understand why it is a problem for someone to comply with the EU law that we have brought together and to protect the Schengen border. That is why infringement proceedings are being initiated against us. Overzealousness, stupidity, command? Not knowing what the starting point was. But I know one thing! Contradictory speech and action are harmful. Our common goal is not to be afraid of criminals and terrorists. This requires strict and fair, observable and enforceable rules. In the current process, under migratory pressure, destabilization of the EU must be avoided. It’s okay to be honest and name things, only that can give you the opportunity to work together. The measures taken are not common enough and are therefore unworkable. If something is not a good answer, it is not necessary to force implementation, but to find real joint action.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. – Asylum seekers are forced to flee their homes in hope of a better future, only to end up in detention centres which are severely overcrowded with appalling living conditions, offering inappropriate shelter. The lack of information about people’s cases and the lengthy application process leads to people being detained endlessly. Conditions and safeguards available to detainees who have committed no crime are, in many cases, worse than those of criminal detainees. Their plight is moreover aggravated by the numerous incidents wherein officers have abused their existing powers and used excessive force against detainees. All this has a negative impact on their well-being, especially after the hardship endured during their journey. We should better protect against unjust and abusive treatment in detention facilities, as well as other human rights violations. While promoting human rights, we in Europe must ensure that we ourselves reflect the very values we seek to promote globally.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. - The refugee humanitarian crisis takes on several dimensions. This debate exposed an action that has been recurring in the different Member States that receive this flow of refugees, the arrest and the use of arbitrary force, for the simple reason of being an asylum seeker. Asylum application is a human right enshrined in the Geneva Convention for refugees. Therefore, detention should only be used as a last resort and within a limited period of time. The conditions for the detention of asylum seekers, pending the examination of their application, are described in the Directive on conditions for the reception of asylum seekers. It should be noted that, in the case of unaccompanied minors, they can only be detained in exceptional circumstances and should be placed in places appropriate to their needs and separate from adults. Therefore, if Member States do not comply with these conditions, the European Commission should initiate infringement proceedings against the States concerned. In such a humanitarian situation, Member States and competent authorities should be aware of the weaknesses and marks that these people carry with them. We must enforce existing instruments in this area.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: Pursuant to Rule 198 of the Rules of Procedure, the Conference of Presidents received a request from 283 Members to set up a committee of inquiry on the measurement of emissions in the automotive sector. At its meeting this afternoon, the Conference of Presidents noted that the request had been validly submitted by more than a quarter of the Members of Parliament and decided to present in plenary a proposal for a decision concerning the establishment of a committee of inquiry, the its powers, its numerical composition and the duration of its mandate. The proposed decision, which bears the initials B8-1424 / 2015, is available on the Parliament's website. Plenary will vote on this proposal at the start of tomorrow's first round of voting. Amendments to the proposal of the Conference of Presidents concerning the numerical composition of the committee of inquiry can be tabled by 8 pm this evening. The plenary will vote on the nominations to the committee of inquiry on 19 January 2016.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). - Mr President, I heard your announcement in which you said that we have the right to propose what we deem appropriate by eight o'clock. I do not think this is a democratic process, because, as you can see, very few colleagues are here, the time you give is one hour, and I do not think that these procedures are appropriate for a Parliament. I believe that there should be time comfort and I also believe that at a time when we do not have much participation and you tell us, however, that within an hour we should make a specific proposal, that you should look at the issue again.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: I am interrupting you because we do not have the possibility to debate this, as you know, under the rules and this decision was made by the Conference of Presidents which also set the time frame for tabling the amendments.And of course, as regards the decision of the Conference of Presidents, we take note of it.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The next item is the debate on the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the 20th anniversary of the Dayton Peace Agreement [2015/2979 (RSP)].

name: Nicolas SCHMIT
text: President-in-Office of the Council, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, 20 years after Dayton, it is time we all looked ahead. Looking ahead means looking at a common future inside the European Union. The 20 years since 1995 have now proven beyond doubt that Dayton has delivered on its main objective of bringing peace and stability to Bosnia and Herzegovina and enabling post-conflict reconstruction. But many challenges remain. Much remains to be done to consolidate reconciliation. The Dayton Peace Agreement has also become fundamental to rebuilding peace and advancing reconciliation in the broader region. It has played an important part in the efforts to rebuild dialogue and cooperation in the Western Balkans. Some of the countries of the region, once enemies, have become signatories to the Agreement and over time have become friends and close partners investing in their joint future in the European Union. The Western Balkans region has moved a long way forward in the two decades since Dayton. Many countries of the region are candidates for EU membership, and Bosnia is a potential candidate. Bosnia has made considerable progress in its relations in the region – good neighbourly relations. The EU has been one of the largest donors to Bosnia, both during the war and in the post-war reconstruction period. Its presence largely focused on advancing political and economic reform and establishing a framework for the implementation of the EU’s Stabilisation and Association Process, following the Thessaloniki summit in June 2003 and the eventual integration of Bosnia into the EU. In addition, at the end of 2004, Bosnia also became the first country where instruments of both the CFSP and the ESDP were deployed on the ground. The EU continues today to safeguard the Dayton Agreement through EUFOR Althea. However, Bosnia is no longer a security consumer state, but a security provider. It has effectively contributed to UN and NATO missions and, since 15 September 2015, it can also effectively contribute to EU CSDP missions after signing its framework participation agreement in the EU crisis management operations. Progress may be uneven at times, but the strong desire of the majority of the country’s citizens will continue to guide political leadership in the right direction. The country’s citizens demand socio-economic and other reforms to improve their daily lives. They call for progress on the EU path to give themselves and their children the perspective of life in a free, democratic, stable and prosperous society, a society which protects minorities and fully respects human rights and freedoms. These are European values which the people of Bosnia and Herzegovina share. We in the European Union are fully committed to assisting Bosnia and Herzegovina in achieving this goal. In December 2014 the EU Council agreed to engage in a renewed approach to overcome the stalemate that then hindered Bosnia and Herzegovina’s EU path. Political institutions and leadership across the country have given their clear and unequivocal commitment to taking forward the reform required for progress on the EU path. Much has been achieved in 2015 on the basis of this commitment. The Stabilisation and Association Agreement entered into force on 1 June 2015. Subsequently, Bosnia and Herzegovina’s various government levels agreed the scope and depth of reforms to be undertaken. In this respect, the first ever EU-Bosnia Stabilisation and Association Council took place last week with positive results, as indicated in the joint communiqué published on the day.
