The initial focus has been on the socio-economic area, but the reform process already covers a much broader agenda. We have worked closely with international partners – in particular with the US and international financial institutions – to help make these reforms happen. We will continue these joint efforts to empower the authorities in Bosnia to take forward the transformation process effectively. This will not be easy, but it is certainly possible, and its success is fully in the hands of Bosnia and Herzegovina. At this point, Bosnia and Herzegovina is considering a possible application for EU membership. This is an achievement in itself and would have been difficult to think of only a year ago. But to make an application credible, Bosnia will need to continue to prove its credibility by delivering on commitments made. Over the last 12 months, together with the Bosnian authorities, represented today by the Chair and the members of Bosnia’s Presidency, we have engaged effectively. In this process the EU has responded with concrete deliverables to positive, constructive and concrete efforts undertaken by Bosnia. It is now up to Bosnia to give us good reasons to take a further step. In Dayton the future of Bosnia and Herzegovina was shaped by the country’s leaders, together with the neighbours and the international community. 20 years after Dayton the responsibility falls on Bosnia and Herzegovina and, following the steady steps of the past year, it is important not to jeopardise all that has been achieved so far. We truly hope that we will soon be able to open a new chapter in the history of Bosnia and Herzegovina. The EU is committed to doing all that is necessary on our side as soon as Bosnia makes a credible step towards us. Thank you for your attention. I am looking forward to hearing your views.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: Thank you, Minister Schmit, who will stay with us in the reply.This is his last speech on behalf of the Luxembourg Presidency. We thank you for his availability in recent months.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr President, in recent months, with the approach of the twentieth anniversary of the Dayton Agreements, everything or almost everything has been said about the positive and negative aspects of this text and their development in practice. We, in turn, wanted to mark this anniversary with a debate and a resolution: first of all, to solemnly commemorate the conclusion of a text that put an end to the most brutal conflict that Europe has known since the Second World War; secondly, to encourage Bosnia and Herzegovina to look to the future. A future which, in our opinion, is without a shadow of a doubt in Europe. It is therefore an opportunity to encourage, twenty years after Dayton, the authorities of Bosnia and Herzegovina to continue on the path of reforms in order to be able to submit a credible membership application. Firstly, this implies the implementation of the agenda for reforms and the socio-economic measures contained therein, but also the adoption of the coordination mechanism for issues related to European integration. Then, constitutional reforms will have to be carried out which will transform Bosnia and Herzegovina into a democratic and functional state. I would also like to mention a point of great concern and likely to stand in the way of this European future for Bosnia and Herzegovina. This is the referendum on the judiciary in the Serbian Republic of Bosnia. This poses a serious threat to the cohesion, sovereignty and integrity of the country. And as I said before, the country does not need such initiatives, which only distract from the ongoing socio-economic reforms. Bosnia and Herzegovina must remain focused on reforms. In other words, it must stay on the path to Europe.

name: Knut FLECKENSTEIN
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen! 20 years after the Dayton Agreement was signed, memories come back: memories of the hatred, of the crimes, of the many dead, sons and daughters, brothers and sisters, but also of the late victory, the very late victory of the Diplomacy about war. We are pleased that this agreement has been concluded because it has shown that there is a future for this country too. Since then there has certainly been progress in Bosnia and Herzegovina and some steps towards Europe, the EU. We urge and we encourage, encourage the authorities there to make further and greater efforts to improve the situation in the country. We support the EU's new approach towards Bosnia and Herzegovina because, as Federica Mogherini said, it is a real chance and opportunity for this country and for the European Union to move closer together - not just in words, but also in deeds - and to test whether there is really a real will - not with the population, but especially with the political leadership - to begin a new phase. Dayton brought the end of the war. But a real peace, especially in Bosnia and Herzegovina, requires more togetherness and in no way an attempt to split up the judiciary. We cannot accept that without comment when we are dealing with a partner who is on the way to the European Union. It is up to the political leadership to strive for clear progress - not for the EU but for their own citizens, for their country. And it's our job to help them do that. We adopted a short resolution together because we believed that it was right to address this point specifically. We can discuss everything else when we discuss the report.

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, we in the ECR are also delighted to remember the 20th anniversary of the Dayton Peace Agreement, a framework agreement which put an end to the bloody Bosnian civil war two decades ago. Whilst Dayton did indeed succeed in ending a genocidal conflict which pitted Bosniaks, Croats and Serbs against each other, regrettably Bosnia remains burdened by many of the same issues that triggered the war in 1992. Divisions remain pervasive and the internationally recognised Bosnia and Herzegovina state is still contested by some of its constituent national groups in the country. Instead of Bosnia and Herzegovina becoming a well-functioning federal state, it remains heavily plagued with internal disagreements between different national components and is unable to overcome the constitutional and political problems – for instance, resolving the Sejdić and Finci case and the return of the IDPs. As the EU continues to focus attention on other regional and global priorities and foreign policy, the challenge for Bosnia remains of striking a balance between the need to promote ongoing reform processes to prepare Bosnia and Herzegovina for application for EU accession, and the capacity to quickly respond to challenges, particularly the one from Republika Srpska to Bosnia’s territorial integrity without the military presence of the EU’s EUFOR Althea, during a period of accelerating EU challenges in other theatres well away from the Western Balkans.

name: Jozo RADOŠ
text: on behalf of the ALDE Club. - Mr. President, colleagues, the main goal of the Dayton Agreement was to stop the bloody war, and just peace, building a modern state was the second, secondary goal and so it actually happened. The war was stopped, but the conditions for a stable and functional state in Bosnia and Herzegovina were not created. The central institutions of a state are very weak and often contested, which further complicates the functioning of the central institutions of that state. The return of refugees in Bosnia and Herzegovina is marginal. Thus, according to church data, only 4% of the pre-war number of Croats live on the territory of the Republika Srpska. The number of Bosniaks in the territory of the Republika Srpska is a bit more favorable, but far from being satisfactory. A similar situation, not as difficult as in the Republika Srpska, is with the return of refugees to the entire territory of Bosnia and Herzegovina. I welcome the new approach of the European Union that should enable Bosnia and Herzegovina to become a member of that elite society. I also welcome the reform plan adopted in Bosnia and Herzegovina with the help of the European Union, and I look forward to the implementation, proper implementation and enforcement of these reforms. It is certain that public administration reforms, economic reforms and reforms in other sectors of public life will help Bosnia and Herzegovina become a better state, but for real stability and unity of this asymmetrically made state, constitutional changes are needed, ie changes to the Dayton Constitution on the principles of federalism. decentralization and subsidiarity.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr President, ever since the Balkans, with their national diversity and strategic positioning, were the target of imperialist cobbleness. Its real intentions have always been to divide the Balkan peoples in order to dominate. It was in the Dayton agreements, in November 95, that the Kosovo issue began to be prepared, indeed, under the tutelage and pressure of the United States of America and also on its military base. These agreements enshrined the division of Bosnia and Herzegovina into three regions: Croatian, Serbian and Muslim. The Dayton agreements did not end a war, they opened other wars. As of 1998, it was understood that the United States government was preparing public opinion for an attack on Yugoslavia from Kosovo. Whatever the Yugoslav Government did, NATO would attack. Unfortunately, the war against Yugoslavia ended with a UN Security Council resolution that enshrined the occupation of Kosovo by NATO forces, in clear violation of its own Charter which states, and I quote: "that all Member States abstain in their international relations the threat or the use of force against the territorial integrity or political independence of any State ". It was a sad story, but a story that was also the beginning of a new era, a list of aggressions in Europe.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - Twenty years ago, the Dayton Accords ended one of the bloodiest wars in Europe since World War II. At that time, of course, the agreement was urgently needed to ensure peace in Bosnia and Herzegovina and to stop the bloodshed in the country. Unfortunately, the agreement failed to create, to form a functional, well-functioning state, as was also conceived, and these were also the wishes of many. That is why, unfortunately, Bosnia and Herzegovina today still faces a difficult economic situation, a high unemployment rate, a brain drain, as well as corruption, discrimination and I could go on and on. And I think that after twenty years, it is time to look at the constitution and look at these founding acts, which in a way make the normal functioning of the state impossible. That is why the Group of the Greens proposed that we have a debate on this topic at the meeting and, above all, use it as a positive moment to shape the post-Dayton future of the country. Already in 2005, the Venice Commission prepared a comprehensive, detailed and very good proposal on how the existing Constitution of Bosnia and Herzegovina can be reformed in such a way that it will work in the true sense of the word. Therefore, it is not necessary to re-invent complete reforms, but to use already existing documents and proposals, which are excellent and certainly welcome. The state, as it is composed, of course divided into entities, cantons, districts, prevents efficient and normal functioning. Also, among other things, because of various institutes, such as the veto, which is sometimes used more often than the search for compromises. Dayton, of course, needs to change, it needs to be considered. However, I am convinced that, of course, there are documents, that there is a will that can perform these tasks or these changes. The Venice Commission has been very clear in its writings, and one of these is that, of course, the entities should in some way transfer part of their sovereignty to a state that could be more effective in this way. We cannot force Bosnia and Herzegovina to change, we can only propose them. It is up to the political authorities and citizens to decide whether they want change and thus a more efficient and promising country.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, two federated entities and ten cantons with their own government, one district and 143 municipalities, for a total of four levels of government and fourteen different parliaments and governments. An indispensable agreement to freeze a conflict that has also frozen every concrete possibility of the country to get out of a political paralysis, the result of crossed vetoes and an administration of colossal size and weight. Bosnia must have a European perspective, but today, beyond the inevitable socio-economic reforms, its constitution, which among other things is the fourth annex to the treaty, is contrary to the European Convention for Human Rights, discriminates citizens who do not belong to one of the three ethnic groups and risks imploding under the blows of the future referendum of the Republika Srpska. If we really care about Bosnia's future and European path, we need to put back on the table a serious constitutional reform for the equality of all citizens, for a modern and fully democratic state, starting from the interesting draft of the Venice commission. To say that all is well is to condemn Bosnia to be the black hole of the Western Balkans for years to come.

name: Georg MAYER
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. - Mister President! Even 20 years after this terrible war in the middle of Europe, Bosnia and Herzegovina is still one of our biggest problem children. The forced coexistence of different denominations and different peoples de facto does not work locally, while the Dayton interim solution is now part of the Federation and the Republika Srpska and forced local measures - above all those by the institution of the High Representative - the country and the tense situation do not improve on site. On the contrary, the scars of war have not healed to this day. In addition to the internal borders between the Republika Srpska and the Federation, there are still imaginary borders between the individual denominations. Nevertheless, this Dayton Agreement is and was essential for the peaceful coexistence of all parties. In the light of this, I urgently advise against experimenting with these agreements. I think it would be to the detriment of everyone involved.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: NI). - Mr President, twenty years after Dayton and the NATO imperialist intervention that led to the protectorate of Bosnia and Herzegovina, life has confirmed the communists who said that imperialist peace - with the gun to the temple - only brings imperialist wars, poverty, ethnic divisions and refugees. From Bosnia-Herzegovina, from the dirty war in Yugoslavia, to the present day in Syria, Ukraine, Libya, Iraq and elsewhere, the imperialists are redrawing the borders with the blood of the peoples. The so-called "border guarding" without the agreement of the Member States, which is being proclaimed by the European Union with its new Border Guard, poses great dangers. Borders that open and close when and as much as capital needs cheap labor, borders that become "rubber" depending on the competition for control of energy sources. The peoples in their struggle must not accept to shed their blood for the monopolies. The people must decide their own destinies, with their own power, with the release of the European Union and NATO.

name: Elmar BROK
text: - Mr President, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, ladies and gentlemen! The Dayton Accords was good for stopping a war, but it is obviously not good enough for building the future. For this reason, the necessary reforms are needed here, which all party leaders have promised. But that has been going on for so long that we are increasingly asking the question: is there the political will to do so? How long should that take? Then it is necessary to create a federal system with clear central authority so that such a state can function. This is a decision that the citizens and politicians of Bosnia and Herzegovina alone have to make. But we have to see that the attempts, for example in the Republika Srpska with a legally unclean referendum, to destroy this country, the measures that take action against Community legal systems as in the last few days are all measures that do not strengthen the country . I think we should make it clear here that the necessary reforms are being carried out, that the SAA must be adapted, that sensible coordination mechanisms must be used, that action should be taken against high youth unemployment. But we also have to see that a country in which there are 14 governments and 14 parliaments cannot really be managed and that is why a sensible mix of centralized state and federal system with decentralization has to be found. This is an important prerequisite for this country to come to rest together with the different ethnic and religious origins that exist there, with the difficult history, and to find an inner unity despite all the differences. I think that it is also important that we have to see that everyone agrees that Europe is the goal. But they also have to know that the European goal can only be achieved if the internal problems of this country are resolved in a sensible way before accession. They cannot be resolved after joining. Therefore, one should quickly come to the constitutional changes that are necessary for this.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: –  Mr President, the Dayton Peace Agreement signed 20 years ago brought an end to the war but is not allowing Bosnia to progress. Dayton was envisaged as a transitional compromise among parties in conflict, not a long-term solution, and would create a democratic inclusive and modern society that the people of Bosnia deserve. Initially, Bosnia made terrific progress rebuilding and reforming rapidly after a brutal four-year war. It was only in the last decade that we have seen the deterioration of progress. This is because some Bosnian politicians exploit Dayton, promoting old ethnic divisions and undermining efforts to move the country forward. Bosnia has been held back while neighbouring states have moved ahead towards the EU and NATO. Constitutional change will eventually be needed for the country to transform it into a fully functional state. However, let us not use Dayton as an excuse to say that no progress can be achieved under it. Let us not use it as an excuse to stall reform and keep Bosnia from moving closer to EU membership. As an S&D rapporteur for Bosnia, I will, together with colleagues in the Group, do my utmost to help Bosnia apply and then negotiate EU membership. For me, addressing the socio-economic problem is key. This has also been repeatedly promised by all Bosnian politicians, and we need to hold them to their word. Also, I would like to see more civil society, minorities and youth engaging to be part of an open dialogue. Out duty is to promote education and remembrance. It is essential to break down the ethnic barriers so that the next generation does not inherit the prejudices of this one. That is what building democracy is all about. Meanwhile we must be firm against those that attempt to undermine Bosnia’s judicial institutions and promote secession. The changes moving Bosnia forward will have to be driven from within. However, we on the outside have a responsibility to continue encouraging and supporting this process. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: blue-card question. – Mr Khan, I think that we can all join together in praising the historic progress that was made 20 years ago in Bosnia and Herzegovina. Point 2 of the joint motion for a resolution states that ‘successive governments have failed to build a fully-functioning, self-sustainable state’ in Bosnia and Herzegovina, and indeed your speech reflects this. You then go on to say that you believe that Bosnia and Herzegovina should be moving towards EU membership. What timescale do you envisage for this, please?

name: Afzal KHAN
text: blue-card answer. – The time envisaged really depends on the Bosnian Government and the Bosnian people and how quickly they want to go forward, so it is really up to them. We are there to help them and facilitate the best we can.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: - Mr. President, twenty years have passed since the signing of the agreement that stopped the war in Bosnia and Herzegovina. Dayton was a temporary solution that was to stop the bloodshed and then, in peacetime, experience an upgrade that would allow Bosnia and Herzegovina to develop into a normally organized state. Many even today invoke such an upgrade unaware of the fact that it has already happened on several occasions. Namely, with more than 300 directives that have never been ratified by any body in the state of Bosnia and Herzegovina, various high representatives have significantly changed what was signed in Dayton without the possibility of appeal from citizens and their legitimate representatives. Therefore, if we already want to revise or significantly upgrade the Dayton Peace Agreement, we must first of all revise the role of the High Representative, who, without any democratic legitimacy, passes directives that have greater force than the original agreement. I hope that in the joint resolution we will adopt my formulation by which I demand that any future reorganization of Bosnia and Herzegovina guarantees true equality to all three constituent peoples. This means that there will be no more room for the High Representative in that country, at least not with the previous powers, because he most often and without any consequences violated the principle of equality and disturbed the difficult political balance between the representatives of the three nations.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: - Unfortunately, I will repeat one of the variations we have already heard today on the topic of Bosnia and Herzegovina. The Dayton Accords brought peace or better to Bosnia and Herzegovina, ended the war and opened a new chapter in a country that had never been before. At the time it was concluded, Dayton was a metaphor for peace, today it is a symbol and excuse for the poor functioning of the state. It was a diplomatic achievement. It brought together the actors of the Balkan wars and conflicts, but unfortunately it sealed and legalized ethnic cleansing and generates today, in completely different circumstances, mutual distrust and unconstructive behavior of nations and their political representatives. Bosnia and Herzegovina, which we knew, was the source of bright ideas, sparkling humor, rich culture. Yes, even dynamic coexistence in diversity. Today, Bosnia and Herzegovina must be recognized as an adult, the responsibility for its development must be handed over to its people, and patronage over the state and external interference must be stopped. With this interference, the drama of Bosniaks, Croats and Serbs in BiH began. Let us give Bosnia a chance to start its European story.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: - Mr. President, 20 years after the signing of the Dayton Agreement, we can say that its achievement is a peaceful coexistence of the citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina. It is crucial to continue to make efforts to preserve peace in Bosnia and Herzegovina through regional cooperation, which will guarantee peace in the region and thus support its European integration. However, today in Bosnia and Herzegovina we must look for a solution to social and economic problems. During my recent visit to Sarajevo as part of the delegation of the Club of Representatives of the Greens / European Free Alliance, on the occasion of the anniversary of the signing of the General Agreement for Peace in Bosnia and Herzegovina, I met with young people, regardless of their nationality. their peers face it every day because of the unpromising political situation in which the country finds itself. We are all aware of the burden of the past that overshadows the burning problems of the present. The political system, burdened with itself, so complicated that even the citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina do not understand it, and probably not even its politicians to the end, does not leave much-needed space for the fight against unemployment and poverty. Every day, Bosnia and Herzegovina loses its young people who leave the country in search of a secure future that they do not find in their country. Bosnia and Herzegovina is experiencing demographic decline. The European Union must therefore call on the political elite of Bosnia and Herzegovina to take responsibility and reform the political system in order for Bosnia and Herzegovina to finally embark on the path to membership in the European Union.

name: James CARVER
text: – Mr. President, the Dayton Accords must not be ignored in the name of political ambition. Humanity has a duty to ensure that they remain a tragic reminder of the fragility of the futile situation that led to the Balkans War and a return of war crimes in the European backyard, just 47 years after the liberation of Auschwitz. Fortunately, NATO and the United Nations – organisations tasked with maintaining peace since 1945 – cooperated to restore stability. Regrettably the potential causes of conflict remain, so we must respect the internal political structure of both Bosnia and Herzegovina based on two internal republics separated, unfortunately, along ethnic lines. I fear that further EU influence and expansion into the Balkans risks unsettling this particularly fragile situation.

name: Jean-Luc SCHAFFHAUSER
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the Dayton accords were a success in a way, even if they were carried by the president, also Serbian, Milošević, who was later accused of all the evils.They are also the consequence of the disintegration of Yugoslavia, wanted somewhere by Germany, the Americans and Turkey.Pandora's box was opened on the basis of ethnic and religious conflicts.Let us not question this compromise which, for twenty years, has maintained peace.The Serbian people, among others, want to speak out on a local referendum on legal issues.Let us not deny him this right.Let's stop humiliating the Serbian people if we want peace.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI). - Mr President, after the violent break-up of Yugoslavia by the interests of Germany and the United States and the implementation of "divide and rule", twenty years after the signing of the Dayton Peace Accords, the situation in Bosnia and Herzegovina is exactly as it was in beginning of the war in 1992. There is a country with economic erosion, with hatred and divisions of ethnic origin and a dysfunctional state where corruption and illegality thrive. We are talking about Bosnia and Herzegovina joining the Union while the agreement is in force - which is paradoxical and impossible. Twenty years later, the agreement still defines the political and institutional framework of the country but urgently needs to be revised because, while it would have prevented further conflicts, it nevertheless froze them rather than resolved them. Really, how is it possible for Orthodox Serbs to reconcile with Catholic Croats and fanatical Bosnian Muslims directly funded by Turkey and Saudi Arabia? Bosnia and Herzegovina must be abolished as a single state and Croats and Serbs must be united with their motherlands. As for the remaining Muslim Bosnia, it must be completely isolated and the umbilical cord connecting it to Turkey and Saudi Arabia must be cut so that it does not develop into a new Islamic state within Europe.

name: Eduard KUKAN
text: - The Dayton Peace Treaties had a dual function. Firstly, they had the task of stopping the war, and secondly, they had to resolve the state order of Bosnia and Herzegovina. There is a lot of talk today about the second task. But that is why this debate should not overshadow the positive historical role of Dayton, which stopped and ended the civil war. No one should take this into the Dayton Peace Treaties or question them. Bosnia and Herzegovina is still dealing with the consequences of this devastating war, such as the return of refugees or the grief of those who have lost their loved ones. We also want to express our sincere condolences to them with this resolution. We have been evaluating twenty years since 1995. However, I would like to take this opportunity to look to the future. What awaits Bosnia and Herzegovina? First and foremost, it is a country whose future lies in the European Union. To do so, however, they need to be a country in which all its citizens have the same rights and where the state equally protects the human rights of all citizens without exception. Secondly, Bosnia and Herzegovina needs to focus on addressing socio-economic issues. These are the hottest in the country. Its political leaders must take seriously the so-called Reform Agenda. Thirdly, I would like to see a state that does not have to live in constant fear for its territorial integrity or in fear of existence itself. Bosnia and Herzegovina deserves to be a normal European country on its way to the European Union.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: - Dear President, With this Resolution in the European Parliament, we are marking an important anniversary for Bosnia and Herzegovina, the European Union and the international community. And it is a compromise between thinking that Dayton is still a good enough framework for Bosnia and Herzegovina and attitudes that see it as an increasingly narrow framework for the country's development. The signing of the Dayton Peace Agreement is a victory of diplomacy over war, but it was a very belated and costly victory. One hundred thousand killed, two million displaced persons and enormous material destruction are direct consequences of the war in Bosnia and Herzegovina and the war against Bosnia and Herzegovina. The failure of the international community to recognize the causes, motives and protagonists of the war in time significantly affected the character and course of the conflict and the circumstances of concluding the peace agreement. The consequences of what was done, but also what was missed, are still felt today. However, the real political challenges for Bosnia and Herzegovina at the moment are in the country itself. Unlike twenty years ago, there is clear support from her neighborhood today. The prospect of membership, as we well know in Croatia, implies a serious job of change and adjustment to European standards. Especially in a multinational, extremely complex state union where there is always a need to talk about upgrading the system, especially if there are obvious shortcomings. Bosnia and Herzegovina is not, and cannot be, an exception. Analyzes show that they have weakened almost all the institutions of the international community created to implement the peace agreement and oversee the country's key processes of reconstruction and functioning. But the new institutions are not yet functional, primarily those that will be formed to adapt to accession to the European Union. How long the often mentioned transition from the Dayton to the Brussels phase will take depends on whether the European Union will keep Bosnia and Herzegovina in the focus of its policy, as well as whether the authorities in Bosnia and Herzegovina will confirm the accession to the European Union with a significantly different policy.

name: Anna FOTYGA
text: - Mr Chairman!Former High Representative of the international community, Lord Ashton, said the Dayton Accord was great for ending war, but it was bad for building a functioning state.I will add to this - a country that will heal wounds, overcome ethnic divisions, meet the challenge of territorial disintegration, and implement a program of reforms, including constitutional reform.On this path, Bosnia and Herzegovina must be supported by the European Union.The prospect of membership is an incentive.I see a light in the tunnel in the form of the agreement signed this year, under which Bosnia and Herzegovina will already be assisting the European Union in the field of CSDP missions.This is an important change.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: - Mr. President, I once said: "If Bosnia and Herzegovina cannot survive, then the European Union cannot survive either, because it is possible to live in diversity and diversity is wealth."Perhaps that statement was too strong and too optimistic because the divisions are deep.Even today, the divisions are very deep among the peoples and citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina.However, these divisions can be overcome.I am deeply convinced of that.Bosniaks, Serbs and Croats clash over many issues.However, their conflict is no longer hostility, their main enemy today is unemployment, social problems, the departure of young people from Bosnia and Herzegovina.These are the key enemies of Bosnia and Herzegovina.If Dayton brought peace, then we;The European Union, we must bring a perspective to Bosnia and Herzegovina, and a European perspective.

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: – Mr President, as some have said before, Dayton was good to end the war but it was not good to make a sustainable peace. So now, 20 years after the signature of the Dayton Peace Agreement, I think it is time to evaluate the agreement and also all the 12 annexes, and the level of implementation, and to make a plan on how to proceed with each and every one of the 12 annexes. Let me specify one of them: Annex No 7. I am glad it made it in our common resolution in Article 3, which ensures the safe and sustainable return of internally-displaced persons. We welcome the process achieved, but we all know that there are still around 84 000 internally-displaced persons in Bosnia. In a country with 3.8 million inhabitants, this still is a lot. I am also glad to mention another part. In paragraph 3 we mention different degrees of vulnerability when it comes to displaced persons and other victims of the war. 20 years after Dayton it is high time to make an extra effort and to address the tens of thousands of war-related victims of sexual violence in Bosnia. We all know that one structural element in the war in Bosnia, as in all other wars worldwide, was rape: widespread sexual violence aimed at hitting the respective enemy hard by raping the enemy’s women. These women have not yet received proper attention or appropriate social and economic support and health assistance. I think that 20 years after Dayton it is high time to do this – to make reconciliation work also for the victims of war rape who have for too long been silenced.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, as many have already mentioned, it is clear that the Dayton Accords were probably needed to put an end to one of the dirtiest and ugliest wars we can remember here in Europe, which left us 110 000 dead, 2.2 million displaced, the concept of ethnic cleansing bequeathed to us. Probably a mistake was made in not planning in the long term, because if twenty years have passed and we are still discussing ethnic divisions that actually exist in Bosnia and Herzegovina something else had to be done and was not done by the international community. It is clear that the ideal solution, which however is unattainable, would be an endogenous process within Bosnia-Herzegovina, which leads precisely to a new constitution, to a new reorganization, however, I repeat, it is something impossible today that we it should make us think about how to think of a totally different approach towards this country and this community that is geographically located in Europe and that it is important that it is stable for us.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: - Mr. President, esteemed Minister Schmit, esteemed colleagues, in the summer of 1995, after joint operations of Croat and Bosniak forces, the strategic situation on the ground was reversed, a new Srebrenica in Bihać was prevented, and the end of the war in Bosnia and Herzegovina was made possible. signed and initialed, first in Dayton and then in Paris, a peace agreement ending the war in Bosnia and Herzegovina. The extremely complex institutional structure established by the Agreement makes its upgrading necessary for the transformation of Bosnia and Herzegovina into a modern and functional European state that will be able to integrate into the European Union. We organized a major conference last week to mark the 20th anniversary of this Agreement. Colleagues Picula, Šuica, Radoš, Preda and Stier participated, and we invited the President of our People's Party Daul, High Representative Mogherini, Commissioner Hahn and representatives of the US administration, and sent a strong message that Bosnia and Herzegovina must be high on the European Union's list of priorities. . The reforms to be undertaken through the implementation of the Stabilization and Association Agreement should create an atmosphere in which Bosnia and Herzegovina will very soon submit a credible application for membership in the European Union, and we will wholeheartedly assist it in this process. We also want to remove the taboo from discussions on a better constitutional structure of the country on the principles of federalism, decentralization, subsidiarity and legitimate representation, to which a fair, new election law will contribute. It is crucial to protect the equality of all constituent peoples and other citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina and to ensure the return of all displaced persons and refugees, and especially Croats and Bosniaks, to the territory of the Republika Srpska. I strongly condemn any undermining and endangering of territorial integrity, and in particular the announcement of a referendum that would destabilize the country, leading to its further disintegration. Therefore, I believe that we must support Bosnia and Herzegovina on its path to the European Union, as well as all its constituent peoples and citizens.

name: Tanja FAJON
text: "If we fail, the war will continue and future generations will accuse us of being responsible for all the consequences," Secretary of State Warren Christopher said at the signing of the Dayton Accords. Admittedly, the agreement ended a bloody Balkan assassination, but in the same breath it institutionalized ethnically motivated interests, cemented the nation's national division and - as many say - gave Bosnia and Herzegovina a straitjacket. The country made some progress in the post-war years, but far from enough. It is still institutionally disabled, poisoned by corruption and reconciled to the fact that benevolent ideas inhibit decisions that are in the interests of individual ethnic groups. Dayton’s twentieth anniversary could be a turning point. There is no doubt that the country needs a new arrangement that will primarily serve the people and allow the country to make rapid progress towards the Union. In the last year, when we have focused on economic and social reforms, positive changes have taken place. Leaders ’commitments to implement them inspire hope that 2016 may be better. It is crucial that Bosnia and Herzegovina, taking into account the demands of its citizens and in cooperation with civil society, works hard to achieve the goal of gaining candidate status for membership in the Union. And I strongly condemn tendencies to strengthen the nationalist spirit, consolidate autonomy or form our own state. At the moment, this behavior is completely irresponsible. Bosnia and Herzegovina deserves, dear colleagues, to succeed and I will do everything in my power to help it along the way. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question) (Rule 162 (8)).

name: William (The Earl of) DARTMOUTH
text: blue-card question. – Thank you very much for taking the question. You said in your speech that Bosnia is full of corruption, and that may have been just the translation. Is the corruption in Bosnia a qualification or a negative in its application to be a Member State of the European Union?

name: Tanja FAJON
text: The answer to the question posed by raising a blue card.- Dear colleague, Bosnia and Herzegovina, as I said, has made significant progress and corruption is a problem of the countries of the Western Balkans and is common ... not only in the countries of the Western Balkans.That is why we also have a negotiation process, chapters 23, 24, which bring the country tremendous progress.By opening the door to the country, the European Union is also opening ... or closing the way to corruption.And I think that the leaders there are very well aware that they will be able to be part of the European Union when they also meet all the conditions for that.And we are here to help them.

name: Amjad BASHIR
text: – Mr President, the recent discovery of yet another mass grave linked to the Srebrenica massacre serves as a stark reminder of the sheer savagery of the Bosnian War. While the Dayton Agreement deserves praise as an example of post-conflict peace-building, it provided a template that led to the formation of a dysfunctional state mired by a culture of segregation and patronage. Endless internal bickering has hamstrung essential reforms, while young Bosnians lack the employment opportunities they desperately need. In the United Kingdom, legislation like we see in Bosnia that discriminates against anyone on the basis of ethnicity and religion is unthinkable. In the interests of their people, I urge Bosnia’s leaders to move forward and put Dayton’s constitutional legacy behind them.

name: Jasenko SELIMOVIC
text: - Mr. President, this whole discussion about the future of Bosnia and Herzegovina is very strange. Here we hear how the Dayton Treaty is dysfunctional, how it paralyzes the country, etc. All of this is true, but let me remind you how we came to this situation. We first forced Bosnia to accept the Dayton Accords, and then we complain that Bosnia is not functioning because of that agreement. Well that's great. The problem is not that Bosnians do not want to implement the reforms needed to join the EU. The problem is that there is strong resistance in Bosnia from nationalists who do not want to see the country in the European Union, and we, the European Union, have not done enough to help Bosnia cope with these nationalists. Reforms are, of course, necessary. These funds approved by the Commission are very important funds, but if the European Union does not help implement these reforms, we will again soon complain that the reforms have not been implemented and that this European future of Bosnia will be even further than it is today.

name: Tamás MESZERICS
text: – Madam President, my colleagues have already ably and wisely listed the political lessons and constitutional complications emerging from a peace accord which, at the time of its making, was both necessary and reasonable but which became dysfunctional over time. I would like to direct our attention to a different, and maybe even more broadly relevant, story and lesson from the 20-year history of the peace negotiations. We should bear in mind that the Dayton process was the first resolution of a brutal – very brutal – war in the post-World War II period in which international humanitarian law was not pushed into the background for the sake of a political deal. This was the first case of its kind after the Second World War. Indeed, no impunity was offered to those suspected of war crimes and crimes against humanity. Had, for example, Radovan Karadžić not been indicted by the tribunal, he would have led the Republika Srpska delegation, and that would have meant that the peace negotiations would have collapsed before they started. So, for me, the lesson we should bear in mind is this: the policy of no impunity is not only the right policy – we all know that – but it is very often, at the same time, the best policy.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: - Mr. President, we all agree that the basis for establishing peace in BiH was the Dayton Agreement, but it is not a solution for the future of BiH. There are a lot of elements that speak in favor of that. It is unacceptable for one nation to elect its representatives to another nation. (interruption) That is why it is necessary to establish equality of all three peoples, Croats, Bosniaks and Serbs without domination. The state must function at full capacity and that is why an amendment to the Constitution is needed in order to resolve a case that no one mentions today, Sejdić-Finci. It should also be said without complex that a new election law is needed. There are also positive developments, such as the Stabilization and Association Agreement and its implementation. We need to make it possible to ensure economic progress so that young people can get a job in their country as soon as possible, which I am convinced has enough capacity and natural resources to make this happen. For us here in the EU, it is important to keep BiH high on the agenda. I am personally convinced that the Euro-Atlantic path is the only path for BiH. As far as our neighbors, specifically Croatia, are concerned, we offer a hand of friendship and genuine support in the reform process on that path to the EU, but the key lies in BiH politicians themselves. I notice that mostly all the representatives from the Croatian delegation came forward and I can freely say that we know the situation in BiH best. We are all convinced and agree that BiH has a future and that it is time to talk about the future of BiH, and not constantly about the causes.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Madam President, as we mark the 20th anniversary of the peace agreement, we must acknowledge that, beyond formal diplomacy, real peace is built by real people and engaged communities. Having listened to the debate, I believe several crucial elements are missing. Firstly, we must remember the important role of grassroots civil society in the process of peace-building and reconciliation. We must also acknowledge how disenchanted Bosnian young people are with both politics and politicians, and how absolutely crucial youth participation is to the country’s future. Bosnian young people need to be actively engaged. As proved by the Complete Freedom of Truth, a project that won this year’s European Citizens’ Prize, cultural activists, artists, writers and academics all have a role in building cultural dialogue and exchange. There must be significant investment in education for democracy, fundamental rights and citizenship in Bosnia. My S&D Group colleagues and I put these points into our resolution and I deeply regret that they were removed from the joint draft.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: - Madam President!The Dayton Accords are a bit like the constitution - it's good, it serves for years, but at some point it has to be changed - and of course we need to look to the future, not all the time talking about the turn of two decades ago.My friend Mrs. Fajon quoted such beautiful words here that if we do nothing, it will be war.Let me put it differently: if we do something stupid or do something too slowly, it will also be a war.It is about doing something smart.I think we have to say a very hard text here, in order to support Bosnia and Herzegovina, while looking at how this country is supported by other states, for example Islamic states, which export radical imams there and build mosques there.There is, of course, a certain danger and you should know and talk about it too.

name: Michael GAHLER
text: - Madam President! Unfortunately, we have to recognize that even 20 years after Dayton, the political parties that exist along the ethnic lines have not developed the spirit of community to strengthen the state as a whole. I am also acutely and relatively concerned about recent events, and I am amazed that the Presidency has said nothing at all. At the end of November the Constitutional Court ruled that a national holiday on January 9th in the Republika Srpska was illegal. Then Mr. Dodik in the Republika Srpska used that as a pretext to decide some drastic things. The Parliament of the Republika Srpska has decided to no longer cooperate with the institutions of the state of Bosnia and Herzegovina on several levels. It has been forbidden that the Federal Criminal Police Office, to put it this way, of Bosnia and Herzegovina in the Republika Srpska, can no longer be active and it has been declared an unconstitutional institution of the Public Prosecutor of the Court of Bosnia and Herzegovina, which is active in the field of Republika Srpska is illegal. It was decided that the Republika Srpska would no longer cooperate with the State Prosecutor's Office and the Constitutional Court. In this context, Mr Dodik also speaks of demanding that, for example, the international judges in the constitutional court must be withdrawn. My question to the Presidency: how are we reacting to this? Are we just letting this happen? Do we have a handle? My specific question: Are you asking the High Representative Inzko to exercise his Bonn Powers to prevent another escalation from taking place there? I think we have to give a very specific answer to that.

name: Eugen FREUND
text: – Madam President, I remember vividly the days 20 years ago when I was reporting from Dayton on how often and how close the negotiations were to breakdown – like at 04.00 on the morning of November 22, when the Americans were celebrating the conclusion of the talks, but then the phone rang. It was the Bosnians calling to tell them that the deal was off again. Now, 20 years later, where do we stand? Peace has been established, but only with NATO troops on the ground. The bureaucracy is like an octopus, except that those creatures are not corrupt, and the three ethnic groups still mistrust each other. But the people of Bosnia are demanding more. They want decent jobs, they want a European perspective. 20 years ago, when all seemed set to fail, the Americans had the plane turbines revving to make clear that they were ready to leave no matter what. Perhaps we should do the same now: show the authorities that the European plane will take off without them unless they get their act together and do so quickly.

name: Bogdan Brunon WENTA
text: – Madam President, the Dayton Agreement ended the bloodiest armed conflict in post—war Europe. However, Bosnia and Herzegovina, inhabited by free constituent peoples, is still facing many political, economic and social problems.  Is the Dayton Agreement still meeting expectations after 20 years? There is no single answer to this question. The political system of Bosnia and Herzegovina, which was intended to ensure the coexistence and mutual respect of free constituent peoples, maintains divisions within the country and hinders effective governance. The economic situation is severe. According to estimates, unemployment ranges from 27% to as much as about 50% and among young people aged between 15 and 24, the figure is about 60%. Oversight and public administration absorbs up to 40% of GDP. The economic situation of the population deteriorated dramatically last year after the biggest flood in a century, which affected the whole of the Balkans. In Bosnia and Herzegovina alone over 100 000 houses were destroyed. Society wants change and does not accept the status quo. This was shown by last year’s demonstrations. In this context, I welcome the agreement between the politicians in Bosnia and Herzegovina negotiating with the European Union. Social and economic reforms that bring Bosnia and Herzegovina closer to Europe must be carried out. On constitutional arrangements, the leaders of Bosnia and Herzegovina should be encouraged to find solutions that will end discrimination and guarantee equal rights to all free constituent peoples and all citizens.

name: Goffredo Maria BETTINI
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the Dayton peace remains decisive today as a diplomatic solution to a horrendous war.Since then the territorial integrity of Bosnia-Herzegovina has been preserved and we must not underestimate this and since then a slow, difficult and contradictory path has begun.In recent months, however, a willingness has emerged from all Bosnian political leaders to engage more seriously on the path of reform.Thus, the association and stabilization agreement with the European Union was signed.We need to move forward, overcoming the nationalist upsurge that exist, the attempts at division that exist, and making the functioning of institutions less complicated, inefficient and closed in the logic of ethnic groups.We must do our part and the Bosnians theirs if we want to open Europe's doors to this troubled country.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: - Madam President, I have listened very carefully to this debate and I want to join those who have said that the Dayton Peace Agreement was a success twenty years ago. It ensured peace, it was a kind of pillow between the various ethnic groups. It is a little naive to think that such an international agreement could help to ensure the prosperity of a given region, it is really up to the citizens and politicians there. It was also said here that the situation today is not very pleasing, that there is a huge level of unemployment, especially of young people, an overall rather rising rate of poverty, the region is not prospering and there is also a lot of corruption. The European Union can hardly actively resolve these issues on behalf of the citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina. In my opinion, we can offer a helping hand and offer them a clear, possible perspective, a clear, possible vision of future membership of the European Union. I think that is key. We should talk about how to support the reforms that have been called for several times here, how to help the youngest generation in particular, who - if they were able to get a job, if they were able to function in some peaceful coexistence - could be a hope for the future. for this region. Here, I personally think that the European Union should have a primary interest, it should support such reforms and changes in Bosnia and Herzegovina. I say it for myself, I also say it for the Czech Republic. We welcome the growing efforts in Bosnia and Herzegovina to apply for membership of the European Union in the future, and we therefore support the Association Agreement. I also think that in the future it will be necessary to negotiate with Serbia itself in order to also become a member of the European Union in the future. In short and well, this area of ​​the Balkans should be a very primary area of ​​interest for us, we should support these countries' efforts to join the European Union and help them with reforms. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162 (8))

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: blue-card question. – Mr Pospíšil, we are talking about the 20th anniversary but, you know, the Bosnia-Herzegovina symphony is an unfinished symphony. It will be an unfinished business – and maybe you agree with me here – for as long as Bosnian society is still divided along ethnic lines, divided between the institutions of the Serbs and the institutions of the Bosniaks and Croats, and for as long as the federal institutions are so weak. How is this state going to have a European Union future with this kind of situation?

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: answer the question posed by raising a blue card.- Colleague, I agree with you.The future is uncertain, we must offer a helping hand and offer that vision for the next generation.But I am convinced that the international community can do no more than separate the hostile ethnic groups and stop the war.We cannot, in my opinion, resolve the constitutional order of this country and impose any constitutional or other changes, impose changes to the electoral code, and so on.It is really up to the individual citizens and political leaders of this country.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: - Madam President, today is the day to commemorate twenty years of the Dayton Accords, which made it possible to end a terrible war in Europe, but today is also the day to remember that those Accords have not allowed to raise a country, that Bosnia and Herzegovina continues to be mired in a permanent crisis with highly flawed inter-ethnic relations, a diabolical institutional architecture and serious corruption cases. It is one more example of our failures to be a transformative force, like the European Union, in the region. But we must celebrate that the European Commission has had a new approach to the country; the entry into force of the Stabilization and Association Agreement must be celebrated. For what? To give a boost to the implementation of the rule of law, to give a boost to a very deteriorated economy, with massive immigration and a very, very worrying unemployment, and to make inclusive constitutional reforms, which also reject the political positions of some actors, such as the Republika Srpska, and that allow the country to have as its horizon the entry into the European Union. That is what to celebrate and what to remember on a day like today, twenty years after the Dayton Accords.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: - Madam President, integration into international organizations is a key way to ensure the stabilization of Bosnia and Herzegovina. Accession to the European Union and NATO brings a number of institutional reinforcements. It is necessary to use the perspectives offered by membership in these organizations in order to implement serious reforms and adjustments in order to establish a quality institutional framework for peaceful coexistence and progress of all citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina. The Dayton Agreement is far from perfect and therefore an agreement is needed on all sides to upgrade it, which will solve the problem of institutional stalemate and the position of Croats, who according to the current arrangement are a constituent people only on paper and who suffer the most from inability to exercise their rights. The only acceptable path for the development of Bosnia and Herzegovina is a system in which all peoples will be able to exercise all their rights and in which two peoples will not outvote or overpower one people. The upgrade of the Dayton Agreement must be carried out in such a way that the Croatian people in Bosnia and Herzegovina are truly constituted in political and socio-economic life without subordination to other constituent peoples.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: - The Dayton Convention was created by necessity. His main goal was to put an end to the bloodshed on ethnic grounds. It worked, but neither side was happy with it. It was typically a compromise-like solution. Since then, it has become clear that the two entities operating in Bosnia, the weak central government that connects them, are unable to solve and sometimes even cause problems. Of course, the system created by the Dayton Treaty cannot be blamed for all the country’s concerns. As a result, Bosnia has taken the first steps towards the rule of law. However, 20 years after Dayton, it would be time to review the convention. And the European Union has a moral obligation to help Bosnia in its commitment to democracy, and that is the main concern. At moral duty. There are EU Member States where governments create ethnic tensions. It is enough to think only of my country, Romania. It is the moral duty of the Member States to settle the relationship between ethnic minorities and the majority in an exemplary manner within their country.

name: Anneli JÄÄTTEENMÄKI
text: I have received eight motions for resolutions tabled in accordance with Rule 123(2) of the Rules of Procedure. The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday, 17 December 2015. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: in writing. – Although the Dayton peace negotiations ended four years of war, the Dayton Agreement failed to create a framework for a lasting peace. Bosnia has sadly not progressed to the level it should have 20 years later. Rather than paving the way from a war-torn country to a unified and functional state, the constitution agreed at Dayton laid out a post-war political system of power-sharing that reflects the ethnic divisions that had fuelled the war.  As the Sejdic-Finci case demonstrated, the ethnic provisions in the constitution are improperly discriminatory and must be revised. If Bosnia wants to become self-sustainable and avoid political paralysis, there needs to be a comprehensive constitutional reform. Bosnia is Europe and its future lies with the EU. We are willing to support Bosnia throughout all stages of the process to reform. To truly make meaningful reforms though, all Bosnians must move forward together.

name: József NAGY
text: in writing.- Even from a 20-year perspective, the Dayton Peace Agreement seems to be the most acceptable solution at the time to end the bloodiest phase of the South Slavic conflict, the Bosnian war.The agreement has been very sharply criticized by all three nations involved, as it does not settle the situation of either ethnic group satisfactorily, but two very important facts should not be overlooked!Firstly, the most important goal in this situation was to stop the bloodshed in Bosnia as soon as possible, which was achieved with the agreement.The other most important merit of the peace agreement is that it has given equal rights to all three affected nations, including Bosniaks, Croats and Serbs.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: in writing. - I consider it important and symbolic that today we in the European Parliament also remember that two decades ago, with the help of the international community, we managed to end a bloody Balkan European civil war and prevent its flame from spreading throughout Europe. At the same time, the anniversary should remind European leaders that security, stability and European integration in the Western Balkans are now clearly the EU's responsibility and overriding interest, and that the world and the people concerned expect us to take active, effective action. . The most important tool for this is the dynamic continuation of the accession process in the Western Balkans, which offers the countries of the region, and possibly the government and society of Bosnia and Herzegovina, the prospect of democratic transformation and economic prosperity, limited but realistic. An active commitment to the accession process will give EU and Commission negotiators the credibility to welcome the progress made by the BiH government and people and to take further steps towards the full functioning of the European rule of law. In the light of all these considerations, I believe that this anniversary would also be a good opportunity to acknowledge that it was a mistake in the Commission's program to weaken the credibility of the process, the integration motivation of the countries concerned, by pushing the accession perspective.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: in writing. - The Dayton Peace Agreement, signed in Paris on December 14, 1995, ended a conflict that led to the death of 250,000 and the displacement of over 2 million people, and seriously threatened the stabilization of Europe. After weeks of difficult negotiations, a compromise was reached, which is, however, heavily criticized today. The situation in Bosnia and Herzegovina remains politically unstable. Hopes for a prosperous society, free from ethnic tensions, are getting weaker. In addition, the Balkans are facing a new crisis - a wave of refugees heading towards Europe. In summary, the system that emerged from the peace agreement does not seem to work. We cannot look indiscriminately at our own actions. The more so because criticism is often justified. However, despite the shortcomings, it is important to note that in a 2013 IPSOS survey, in each of the three main ethnic groups - Bosnians, Croats and Serbs - a majority would vote again for the Dayton Accord today. Bosnian citizens accepted them as the best possible compromise. Therefore, even if this compromise is not perfect, after 20 years we can say that without the Dayton agreement there would be no peace in the territory of the former Yugoslavia. Bosnia and Herzegovina's efforts to join NATO and integrate with the European Union should continue to be supported, and the economic and constitutional reforms that have already begun should continue.

name: Anneli JÄÄTTEENMÄKI
text: The next item is the report by Bodil Valero, on behalf of the Committee on Foreign Affairs, on arms export: implementation of Common Position 2008/944/CFSP (2015/2114(INI)) (A8—0338/2015).

name: Bodil VALERO
text: rapporteur. - Madam President! I would like to begin by thanking all the shadow rapporteurs who have been very helpful in drafting this report. It has been several years since Parliament presented its latest arms export report, and my ambition now is for the annual review to resume. Not least because we live in a completely new security policy environment with major changes in our world. We have both wars and conflicts in our immediate area and armed violence at home linked to them. In this perspective, Parliament has an increasingly important role to play in examining how well Member States are complying with the common acquis on arms exports. Therefore, the report is based on three pillars: the changed security situation, the application of the common acquis and openness and transparency. The other day, less than a month after the horrific attacks in Paris, Amnesty International released a report, this report. The report describes how Daesh got his weapons. These include weapons that were exported to Iraq during the war against Iran and later to the Iraqi army and which then became too easy a prey for Daesh when they captured large parts of all Iraqi defense weapons. The report mentions a number of European weapons types from e.g. Germany, Belgium, the Czech Republic and Croatia. My home country Sweden is not mentioned, but considering that Swedish munitions have also been exported to Iraq, both via licensed products and indirectly via the US, I think it is too likely that they have appeared or may appear in Daesh's ruthless war against all dissidents . The question we have to ask ourselves is why does Daesh have so many European weapons and if the Member States have not lived up to the common position? Today we have a situation where our own once legally sold weapons end up completely out of our control, and we do not know who has them, what they are to be used for or if they risk being turned against ourselves. For many years in peace, virtually all arms-exporting countries sold munitions to the dictators of the Middle East and North Africa without any major concerns, either over the lack of respect for human rights or the situation in the country as such. The dictators were seen as stable, and they became an important market for European armaments. The area is now on fire, while many individual Member States have long-term contracts and promises of follow-up deliveries for many years to come. We can therefore state that the risk assessments have not worked, nor has the end-user control, but also that the Member States have stretched the regulations to the limit in order to be able to sell. Today, Raif Badawi has been awarded the Sakharov Prize, and in this House we have heard about the horrific punishments Badawi and many other Saudis are subjected to simply for expressing an opinion, but despite the total lack of respect for human rights, Saudi Arabia is still the country to receive buy most European munitions even though the country is obviously not only using them for its own defense but also now in a war of aggression in neighboring Yemen, where civilians are hard hit. Our role as parliamentarians is to ensure that the Member States live up to the common position. Weapons are not just any commodity. Weapons that were exported ten, twenty, thirty years ago are as dangerous today as when they were sold. Our role is also to suggest improvements. Today we propose i.a. a stricter risk assessment with a focus on the situation in the recipient country, a better follow-up with inspections of end users and not least a greater openness and democratic scrutiny of arms exports.

name: Nicolas SCHMIT
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, honourable Members, on behalf of the High Representative, Ms Mogherini, we very much welcome the preparation and discussion of the report prepared by the honourable Ms Valero. This is a testimony to parliamentary scrutiny over arms exports, which is a sound follow-up to transparency applied at EU level on arms export issues. Interaction channels with Parliament, and with NGOs and civil society, on arms export issues have been opened and have developed over the years. This is an invaluable achievement, and it illustrates that transparency and dialogue can fruitfully take place without prejudice to the respective responsibilities of national and EU stakeholders. At a time when we advocate further transparency worldwide, notably via the arms trade treaty, we believe it is important to flag that transparency does not run counter to national and regional security. The EU framework governing arms exports mainly revolves around the EU common position on arms exports adopted in 2008. This framework is unique. It is based on national responsibility of EU Member States, on licensing decisions, together with well-developed information sharing on licence denials and risk assessment. The risk assessment criteria laid down by the EU common position are comprehensive and far-reaching, notably in terms of respect for human rights and international humanitarian law, risk of diversion and impact on internal and regional stability. The daily application by national licensing officers is supported by common EU guidelines that have just been revised in 2015, notably in order to align them with the arms trade treaty. Against this background of national responsibility exercised within common risk—assessment criteria, the overarching objective of the EU common position is to promote convergence of national arms export policies. In support of this objective, the Council and the European External Action Service provide an information sharing platform which is the dedicated Council working group on arms exports, and an IT platform enabling to exchange details on license denials. Like the EU guidelines, these information sharing components have been recently overhauled as a result of the review of the EU common position achieved in 2015. This should further contribute to convergence of arms export policies as they are now being put into practice.  Let me now briefly widen the picture outside the EU. Firstly, in our close neighbourhood, a number of third countries – mainly in the eastern neighbourhood – have aligned with the criteria of the EU common position. To assist them in their daily operational implementation, the EU has had an outreach programme funding technical cooperation in place since 2009. The new phase covering 2016-2017 has just been adopted by the Council. Secondly, and moving to an even larger picture, I have to refer to the Arms Trade Treaty. It sets unique and widely accepted standards to achieve greater responsibility and transparency in the arms trade. The ATT entered into force in December 2014, and so far 130 states have signed it and 78 have ratified it, including 26 EU Member States. We urge the two remaining countries to ratify it as quickly as possible. Of note, however, is that some of the largest arms exporters and importers, such as Russia, China, India and Pakistan, have not signed or ratified it. Here again the EU does a lot to support the effective implementation and universalisation of the ATT. Today the dedicated EU assistance programme, with its EUR 6.4 million budget, is active in 10 countries in Latin America, the Caribbean, Africa and Asia. In addition to this tangible action on the ground, all diplomatic opportunities are used to encourage countries that have taken no steps towards the treaty to join it, possibly enabling them to benefit from the EU assistance programme where needed and requested. The arms trade is getting more and more globalised. It is our duty to lead by example when it comes to arms exports from the EU. It is equally our duty to encourage and support other arms manufacturers and traders to apply the ATT standards.

name: Michael GAHLER
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Madam President! It is good that the European Union has such a common position that the Council has agreed on it. We are the only large region in the world that has something like this. We have heard from the presidency that this also obviously has positive effects in the eastern neighborhood, that there are also countries there that have adopted the content of this common position. I also support what you have said with regard to the arms trade treaty and I endorse the request that the two remaining Member States, which are still missing, ratify this treaty. We have a changed security situation, as the rapporteur has also pointed out. The need to pursue more common foreign, security and defense policy will also mean that our export behavior will converge, i.e. there will be convergence with regard to where we export weapons, because of course the assessment of the security situation and the risks have to get closer and closer if we also pursue common politics there. For example, if the security situation changes, my country Germany is supplying weapons to a region for the first time - to the Peshmerga in northern Iraq - in order to make a contribution to the fact that they can defend themselves there, but also a threatened population group like the Yazidis, for example. I think we have to go into that too, and I hope that, based on this common position, we will continue to deal responsibly with our exports in the future. All in all, the basic tone of this report is still not quite balanced for me, and I suspect that our governments have bad intentions. I do not share this. I trust that our governments will apply the common position there.

name: Inés AYALA SENDER
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - Madam President, first of all, I want to thank Mrs. Valero for the work she has had - let's say - of cooperation and acceptance to a great extent of our proposals and, furthermore, I believe, setting up a good report, where everything or almost is all. In other words, all the issues have been dealt with with great success and, furthermore, not only that, but also with concrete proposals and quite rigor, or sufficient rigor to be taken into account. I believe that this exercise is going to be really positive and, therefore, I also encourage others to support this report, with the necessary caveats, but in any case, the report itself is very positive. Allow me also to state that there are two developments in this report that seem fundamental to me and they are the following: first, the proposal to create the Arms Export Control Authority, under the auspices of the High Representative, ―which can precisely prevent the weak points in the acceptance and implementation of the Common Position that we are seeing in the Member States, as there are no coercive or sanctioning elements for non-compliance with the different clauses of the Common Position - and, secondly, the configuration in the proposal of lists of natural and legal persons not only who have been convicted, but also who have been involved - and we know it from the intelligence services - in situations of illicit export or illicit manipulation of weapons. I think they are important elements that can also help us. In addition, we have also taken into account that there are weapons that pass through Europe, but for non-military skills or activities, but hunting and sports activities, and that many times they have to do with popular collections - as is the case in my country. - and, therefore, I believe that hunters in the mountains of my land do not have to have concerns or problems. But, on the other hand, your report also clearly shows the criticisms that we must continue to take into account for future reports and for the Commission's future report. And it is that, this time, it was a very late report, because the information was not there. Very little transparency in this information. I see that Mr. Gahler has left because he does not accept that, in some cases, his country is named precisely because, being one of the large exporters, he does not provide enough information. So I congratulate you, Mrs Valero, and I hope that tomorrow we will finally be able to have this report that shows very good manners with regard to the control of this export and of traffic.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Ladies and gentlemen, the report on arms exports that has come to your attention seems to me to be extremely hypocritical. I agree that in no case should countries and organizations that have armed conflicts be armed. But the meaning of this report is not in this direction at all. It mixes without any connection the legal and illegal export and trade in weapons. The control mechanism itself is a good wish and nothing more. I call this report largely hypocritical because the big Member States have not stopped and do not stop producing and selling weapons to third countries, including in high-risk war zones. On the other hand, countries like my homeland Bulgaria were pressed, our military-defense and industrial complex was destroyed. The big Member States are taking over our markets, and now it is in this report that we are being told about rules, morality and peace in relation to arms exports. There is a double standard here. I do not accept it. I also do not accept the thesis that European countries should impose restrictions on themselves and that our competitors in the sector should occupy an empty niche due to our own short-sightedness. This will cost us dearly in economic, social and defense terms. I do not support this report because it is a symbol of a double standard and not well-defined goals and objectives.

name: Jozo RADOŠ
text: on behalf of the ALDE Club. - Madam President, at the outset I would like to say that this report is indeed coming at a current time when the security circumstances of the European Union in its southern and eastern neighborhoods have deteriorated significantly and dramatically. Of course, it is possible to say that in this sense this report comes too late. The foreign policy of the European Union and its trade policy should serve the achievement of its goals, but also the affirmation of those democratic values ​​on which the European Union is based. If this is the case, and it is, then this is especially the purpose of the arms export policy of the European Union member states. But even in this area, as in the field of arms standardization, joint procurement and production of weapons and research in the field of armaments, the European Union unfortunately does not have a clear unified and common policy. Europe must set high standards for the sale of arms so that, in the same way as those other countries, large arms exporters can advocate compliance with those high standards and so that these arms do not fall into the wrong hands.
