I therefore welcome the call on the Member States for a uniform interpretation and stricter application of common positions, as well as the establishment of an independent European arms control administration.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Madam President, the countries of the European Union speak in public about building peace or avoiding conflict, but at the same time, silently, they do a great deal of business with the sale of arms in conflict zones. I note the concern of this Parliament to control and prevent it. We have the Common Position governing the control of exports of military equipment and the Common Position on the export of conventional arms, in addition to the Code of Conduct on arms exports. The principles are clear: respect for the country's human rights at the final destination; the internal situation regarding tensions or armed conflicts; the maintenance of peace, security, stability in the regions; the behavior of the buyer regarding terrorism, respecting international law; and no re-export. But let's get to reality. In the annual report on arms exports, we see that we are the third largest exporter in the world: more than 24 billion euros. France, Germany, the United Kingdom and Spain stand out. And what is the second destination of the sale of our weapons? Middle East: Saudi Arabia, Qatar, United Arab Emirates, countries that do not meet the requirements of the Positions or the eight criteria. It is clear that we are using weapons as a foreign policy, supporting political and geostrategic interests of Israel or the Gulf countries. The modification in May 2013 of the embargo on Syria to sell arms to a supposed opposition is the last straw. Supposed opposition that has become Daesh, and in a video of December 14 we saw that arsenal of weapons, the majority coming from the European Union. It is an obvious transfer of our exports to terrorism. That is why I welcome this report, because the Common Position has to be applied with independent control and sanction mechanisms.

name: Mike HOOKEM
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President, in August of this year, my staff and I were threatened with a pistol in northern France – i.e. not in the unstable areas of the EU mentioned in this report. Just as the single market and the free movement of people facilitates legal trade, by greater measure it also facilitates illegal trade. The reality of this means that those with the will to carry out horrific attacks like those in Paris are free to move almost anywhere in Europe, and the weapons of terror they rely on remain easy to obtain. All the EU can do in response is to propose to ban antique and deactivated firearms. I certainly do not remember the Paris attackers raiding the Tower of London to gain access to their high—powered AK—47s. But, since the EU refuses to act in stopping criminal gangs having the free run of the eurozone, are we at all surprised that the traffickers and some migrants are armed? Despite the British Prime Minister, David Cameron, claiming credit for the stricter application of COARM criteria, this will do nothing to limit the use of illicit weapons by those who wish to challenge our very existence. In fact, none of the hand—wringing proposals in this document will stop the flow of weaponry into the hands of terrorists without definitive action to put proper checks in place at borders and limit the flow of people to Europe. At the same time as criminal gangs are free to use unlicensed weapons across Europe, in Syria groups like the Peshmerga are starved of weaponry and ammunition and training. Now is the time to stop talking and act. We must arm the Peshmerga, close our porous borders and regain control of our own security so that the principles espoused in this House are not used as a weapon against us.

name: Janusz KORWIN-MIKKE
text: - Madam President!I am pleased to note that Mrs Valero's report was not consulted with pacifists and also with the Salvation Army.As for the common position, however, I could only ask one question.How many Russian, Chinese and Pakistani companies have given you the hand that you have done an act that is to affect the arms industry in Europe?Of course this is not true.You do it out of your own stupidity.You write that human rights are to be respected and that you want to check the end users of your weapons.I understand that you will be checking that half of your weapons are used by women and half by men according to the principle of equality.This is such a scandal, destroying our industry in such a way that it just takes my breath away and I'll be over it.Besides, I think that the European Union must be destroyed if the countries of Europe are to survive.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: - Madam President! Let me start with an overall assessment, which unfortunately is not positive, and here the agreement is quite common. I would like to emphasize that the report for the period 2013-2014, which is the source of this report, is a report that mainly describes the mechanisms and processes that take place at the interface between the legal and the alleged legal distributor. I am also very interested in everything related to the target countries to which the weapons are to be sent, because this means that we are currently dealing with an extremely key element, i.e. the credibility of this effect of transporting weapons from Europe to the outside. I would like to emphasize, however, that such a general belief, which very often prevails, that tightening the criteria here in Europe, both in terms of licensing as regards the release for distribution, as regards controlling the country of destination of transport, will result in an increase in safety, however, is in fact certain naivety. Today Europe itself has a gigantic problem with the ease of access to conventional weapons, which can be bought online and can be put together. And, of course, we are dealing with access to this weapon not from the licensed or those who apply for a license, but very often from complete amateurs who deal with this distribution of weapons. Therefore, those citizens who are right-minded respect the law and do not have access to this weapon. Everyone else has easy access to weapons and it's worth talking about. The gigantic business related to the trade of conventional weapons must finally also meet the security business, because security in Europe, the security of an individual citizen, is also an economic value and we must remember this. Finally, I would like to emphasize that the further tightening of export criteria, if it is to make sense, is only in tandem with strengthening internal control, the distribution of weapons, and also financial strengthening of those institutions that control the possession of weapons in Europe.

name: Arne LIETZ
text: - Madam President! I thank the rapporteur for this annual report and welcome the key call for an independent European arms control authority under the auspices of the High Representative of the European Union. I also regret - as described in the report - that only 21 Member States with data made a full contribution to the 16th annual report. Unfortunately, Germany is not there either. In my opinion, the urgently needed Europeanization of security and defense policy and the pooling and sharing of armaments products that are to be strived for must go hand in hand with the creation of common restrictive standards in export policy. In doing so, we must ensure that existing national export guidelines are not relaxed. It cannot be that economic interests or the financial basis for arms research serve as a drive to export as many weapons as possible to countries outside the EU. That is why we should deal with the question of public co-financing of armaments in the pooling and sharing debate. Exporting weapons to war and crisis areas or states in which human rights are not guaranteed or EU development projects are undone is contrary to a coherent foreign and trade policy. Only if it is certain that European weapons do not fall into the wrong hands can we take responsibility for co-financing defense research projects from EU funds. I share the report's concern that EU export controls can be circumvented with license manufacturing in third countries or with branches of EU companies. I therefore support the approach of the German federal government that the transfer of licensed products of small arms to third countries will be banned in the future. I also support the report's aim of including the situation in the next annual report in a European comparison. The fact that the German government is already offering companies in the armaments industry funding programs so that they can use their technical intelligence to manufacture something other than weapons is, in addition to increased arms export controls, a step in the right direction, a step towards the biblical image of “swords to plowshares” .

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: - Madam Chair, thank you very much.It was high time we got this report and a proposal for new regulations.They are killing us with our weapons.I am aware that every criminal and every terrorist can come up with a weapon that does not have to be just our weapon, but kills us with our weapon.Our people in the European Union are being killed with weapons produced in the European Union.That is why I strongly welcome the fact that we want to create a body that controls weapons, which will, if nothing else, create the preconditions that everything produced in the European Union at least ends up where we think it can end up, much safer than it is today.In this context, I believe that the High Commissioner will know how to manage this policy and this body and bring more security among our citizens.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, without a doubt the most rugged and opaque chapter of the European Union's foreign policy is that of security and defense policy. Only from the data that are known, in the European Union arms exports worth 36,712 million euros were authorized in 2013, which places us as the third world exporter of arms, only behind Russia and the United States , and ahead of China. As you know, this morning in this plenary session the Sakharov Prize was awarded to blogger Raif Badawi, persecuted and convicted in Saudi Arabia for exercising his freedom of expression. A country, Saudi Arabia, that does not respect the most fundamental rights and freedoms of the human being, but to which we sell arms every year. Member states should not only draw up and ratify, but above all comply with international treaties on the arms trade, ensuring full respect for international human rights standards, as required by organizations such as Amnesty International. For this reason, it is essential to quietly stop doing business with the sale of weapons while speaking in public about peace, human rights and democracy. Hopefully this report is a point to end the double standards that have ruled for so long in the European Union.

name: Petr MACH
text: - Ladies and gentlemen, the report before us says that illegal and smuggled weapons often end up in the hands of terrorists.The problem is that criminals always get their weapons and illegal weapons so that the police cannot track them down.Citizens should therefore have the right to defend themselves against criminals with guns in their hands.The European Commission is coming up with a proposal to completely ban commonly held weapons.The proposal, which is not yet before us, but will be discussed, states that conventional self-loading weapons, which resemble police weapons, automatic weapons, should be completely banned.Without a firearms license, it will not be possible to hold ordinary sports airsoft pistols.The European Commission's proposals are simply aimed at disarming law-abiding citizens.And we shouldn't like that.

name: Tunne KELAM
text: – Madam President, I would like to thank my colleague, Mr Valero, for his constructive cooperation and good will. I am sure this report is needed, especially in the new security situation. We are treading in an important and sensitive area. Therefore, we have to be balanced and realistic. Arms by themselves cannot be considered good or evil. It is up to their users. So the important thing is to prevent arms from reaching evil or irresponsible hands. The EU has a good basis for preventing this from happening: the common position, which is unique in the world, and its eight criteria. I appreciate that we were able to balance the report by pointing out that arms are needed for self—defence, as defined by Article 51 of the UN Charter. It is important to make sure that nations facing armed aggression, like the Ukrainians or the Kurdish Peshmerga, should be able to have defensive arms. It is also positive that the role of the EU defence industry has been highlighted. We need the industry in question for our security, but also for the development of modern technological bases in Europe.  The EPP stands strongly behind the common position. The latter needs, first of all, efficient implementation, not necessarily an extension of its powers. More transparency and information sharing, for example about persons whose licences for exporting arms have been denied, is important. Problems for the EPP emerge mainly from attempts to cross into the subsidiarity domain, because national defence remains in the competence of the Member States. The EPP has identified four proposals which, in our opinion, exceed the EU competences, for example the proposed mechanism of sanctions for violations of the eight criteria. Therefore, if our four key points are not supported, the EPP will remain neutral.

name: Janusz ZEMKE
text: - Madam President!Well, I would like to thank you very much.I would like to signal that two problems should be highlighted on the basis of this debate.First, arms export controls are an integral part of the EU's security policy.If so, then the European External Action Service must have real arms export control instruments.The point here is not only to control the permits that are issued, but to check where the weapons actually arrive and on what scale.And the second problem, it is finally necessary to create a list of dual-use items: civil and military.The lack of such a list today leads to various prohibitions being circumvented.I think it is very urgent.

name: Ramona Nicole MĂNESCU
text: - Madam President, I congratulate the rapporteur on this fairly balanced report. Current legislation provides Member States with a set of eight criteria on the basis of which they can decide on the authorization of arms exports. This tool provides both the necessary flexibility and the rigor needed to prevent the use of weapons against the civilian population or by terrorist organizations and totalitarian regimes. The beneficial effects of the eight criteria contained in the common position of the Member States are to be found in France's welcome decision to return to the contract for the export of mistral vessels to Russia and to stop deliveries. It was a right decision, motivated by flagrant violations of international law by Russia. The arms export control procedure is an important aspect of the European Union's foreign and defense policy, and it is therefore necessary to properly include the European Union's new foreign and security policy strategy, especially in view of the current challenges and risks to Europe's security. I draw attention to the importance of concrete cooperation between Member States, Europol, Eurojust and third countries. To this cooperation must be added working procedures on the monitoring of illegal arms trafficking by the police forces, together with the border authorities. The exchange of information and good communication between databases always reduces and even eliminates these risks. We also need a common and coordinated approach by the European Union to floating arsenals, and we need to include in the common position a mechanism for the automatic blocking of arms export licenses to countries against which a European embargo is imposed.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: –  Madam President, the unprecedented spread of armed conflicts is a huge threat to stability and security and has created a less stable and less secure neighbourhood for the EU area. Arms transfers to states in conflict are significantly contributing to these conflicts and this unstable situation. I therefore strongly support the report, which will allow a better regulation of arms exports. We have a key role in preventing irresponsible exports of arms to countries that violate human rights and fundamental freedoms, and regulating the international arms trade must be a global ambition. It is fundamental to support transparency and to promote adherence to the highest regional and international standards, such as the Arms Trade Treaty and the EU Common Position on arms export control. The legally binding framework demonstrates the determination, or at least a first step towards determination, of EU Member States to prevent the export of military technology and equipment that might be used for undesirable purposes such as internal repression or international aggression, as happened recently in Ukraine, or contribute to regional instability. We therefore have to fully support its implementation in the nearest future.

name: Jaromír ŠTĚTINA
text: - Ladies and gentlemen, in its report, the European Parliament assesses the state of implementation of the Council's common position establishing common rules governing control of exports of military technology and equipment. The authors were also led to a dramatic change in the global security situation in the eastern and southern neighborhood of the European Union. A light breeze of pacifism hovered over the authors' original text. Pacifism is well and honestly meant, pacifism, which, however, is still not suitable for the pursuit of peace. Thanks to the shadow rapporteur, Mr Kelam, and other colleagues, the report succeeded in assessing the security risks in which Europe finds itself. The report is thus based on Article 51 of the United Nations Charter on the Right to Individual or Collective Self-Defense and Article 8 supports the supply of arms for defense purposes. It is based, for example, on the real situation in Ukraine, to which the article of the United Nations Charter on the Right to Self-Defense fully applies. It also reflects the real policy of the European Union. This summer, the European Union essentially lifted the arms embargo on Ukraine and opened the way for Ukraine to self-defense. In a situation where the Minsk agreements are dead, it is precisely the weapons that are opening the way to peace. No treaty with Russia will guarantee peace. The defeat of the aggressor will bring peace to Ukraine. Wars are not won without weapons.

name: Ana GOMES
text: - Madam President, I congratulate colleague Bodil Valero on this report, which identifies the persistent problems in the arms export control regime in the European Union, in particular in the application of the common position, and which lists solutions that the Commission, the European Action Service And the Council should adopt. The Union is responsible for more than 1/4 of the arms exports worldwide and for more than 1/3 of the world arms trade to third countries and continues with an extraordinarily opaque and corrupt defense sector, due to the inaction or design of governments Member States. There is an urgent need to create an independent supervisory authority and a standardized reporting and reporting mechanism for all Member States with sanctions for violations of the common position. It is essential that governments provide detailed accounts of exports, including quantities, values ​​and destinations. It is the security of our citizens, of our neighborhood and globally, that is at stake, as demonstrated by the recent terrorist attacks in Paris, carried out with weapons and explosives produced and easily acquired here in Europe. It is essential that the Council and the Commission ensure transparency in the defense sector, not tolerating allegedly national security explanations, so often invoked to protect private interests that serve neither our security nor our industry. In addition to curbing exports to unstable regions and countries, stoking conflicts, Member States may not transfer weapons or military or dual-use equipment to countries that can use them in the repression of civilians or can divert them and traffic them for purposes illegal acts, namely by reaching terrorist groups. This is the case of Saudi Arabia, which has already been mentioned here several times today. The exception to this rule exists within the framework of the Common Security and Defense Policy, under the guidance of the High Representative and resulting from coordination between Member States in military support and assistance, such as that which should be provided to the Peshmerga in Iraq and Syria, if there was a European articulation to fight Daexe, which unfortunately has not been there. The European defense industry must also correctly apply the 2009 defense markets directives if it wants to survive and be competitive worldwide, but as the Valero report says, it must not forget that it must serve Europe's security, guarantee its strategic autonomy in military equipment and technology, including to ensure cybersecurity, the security of critical infrastructure and security in space.

name: Lara COMI
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the global context of internal security in the European Union has changed drastically in recent years, precisely because it is also aggravated by the fact that the Member States are the main exporters of arms worldwide. We are talking about over 36 billion exports in 2013. Weapons that can hardly be traced back to legal trade flows, this is the real problem, which are aimed at the security of the European Union, but not actually intended to fuel what can be a trade legal with due if and due but. All these arms and trade have fueled and are fueling terrorism and armed conflict. Conversely, rampant corruption within third countries has repercussions on the security of our citizens, with smuggling and trafficking of arms entering Europe quietly due to an almost absence of checks at points of entry. It is absurd that we close the borders, we say no to Schengen, but at the same time we manage to have an illegal quantity of weapons within our European territory with a certain degree of tranquility. So I am certainly in favor, as my colleague also said previously, of more checks, of certainly having greater sharing of information within the various European structures. Furthermore, I am also of the opinion that a separation must be made between military and civilian weapons, as technologies such as remote piloting systems, applied robotics and surveillance technologies could not only be harmful to human rights, but they could also pose a significant threat to Europe's strategic interests and to our digital infrastructures. I take the liberty of concluding by saying that ISIS uses, as we have seen, European passports and weapons in various attacks and I believe that we should carry out a trade blockade with the countries that buy and sell weapons to ISIS.

name: Sergio Gaetano COFFERATI
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the sale of arms is always a difficult issue to tackle, very delicate, even more so in these years in which Europe has seen the resurgence of wars and has seen the phenomenon of terrorism return with such virulence . I believe that we need to look very carefully at two phenomena that have occurred in recent times. The first is that which concerns the constant increase in the turnover of companies that produce weapons, not only those that are exported, but also those that are supplied in Europe. The second is the systematic, blatant violation of the eight criteria of the 2008 common position. They are violations for all to see. For this reason, a regulation capable not only of establishing authorities, but of restricting the space for those who produce and sell weapons and above all of dictating rules to the states that are affected by this process, is welcome. For this reason, I would like to highlight four aspects among those that have already been addressed. The first is that which concerns transparency: it is unacceptable that large European countries do not provide data on the sale of arms, unacceptable, also because behind there is the hypocrisy of those who say they want to fight war and terrorism and then do not the bare minimum to be able to govern this process. The second is that which concerns brokerage: brokerage has grown, it must be hit and disintegrated, obviously in political terms. Third thing, which is very important, is that along with the sale of weapons there is the sale of technologies, which are equally dangerous. Finally, the sanctions. Without sanctions, Member States will continue to have casual attitudes and behaviors contrary to the theses they support.

name: Thomas MANN
text: - Madam President! The report on arms exports rightly focuses on the worrying global security situation. The civil wars in Syria, Yemen and Libya and the armed conflict between government troops and separatists in eastern Ukraine urge the responsible use of weapons. Their uncontrolled spread is a serious threat to peace, security, human rights and sustainable development. Arms deliveries to conflicting states increase the likelihood of an escalation of violence. The regulation of the international arms trade is therefore an absolute necessity, since without controls, terrorists and repressive regimes can also be strengthened in neighboring EU countries. In 2008 the EU created a catalog of rules. Since then, the export of weapons in crisis regions has been strictly regulated. The same applies to the transfer of sensitive knowledge and armaments technology to third countries. However, the right to self-defense must be taken into account. The Peshmerga in northern Iraq and the Ukrainian troops were able to protect themselves against the attackers thanks to European weapons. Demands for significantly stronger export criteria and more extensive sanctions are very ambitious, as the EU member states already provide detailed data in the arms control reports. One more point: arms smuggling plays a major role in the international security structure. To combat illicit trafficking, police cooperation between the Member States must finally be expanded - just like the capacities of Europol and Eurojust.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: - Madam President, I personally support the idea of ​​giving a clear concept on arms exports. A common policy on arms exports to the European Union with clear rules is essential for us at the moment. As an important instrument for combating terrorism and combating local conflicts that threaten European interests. However, we need not only a framework for controlling arms exports from individual Member States, but also a coherent arms embargo policy and, above all, more effective cooperation with our two agencies, Europol and Eurojust. But also, in the first place, we must start fighting against ourselves against the illegal arms trade in the European Union. In my opinion, the first step in this fight is to reduce the illegal possession of weapons. I would like to point out another fact that has not yet been mentioned here. There are a huge number of weapons circulating and trafficked among the citizens of the European Union, for example in the Balkan countries, after the wars. I see a solution in the so-called weapons amnesty, which would allow these holders of illegal weapons to return them without penalty. This amnesty was a great success in the Czech Republic. That is why I think it should be supported not only in the European Union, but also in neighboring countries. It is through such meaningful steps, albeit small ones, that we can reduce the volume of the illegal arms trade, which often ends up in the hands of terrorists.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Mr Valero's report underlines that today it is even more necessary to speed up the adoption of new European measures on arms exports by the Member States. I believe it is essential that the European Union develop an effective and coordinated control system in the field of arms, capable of bridging the profound differences between national legislations. Common Position 2008/944 / CFSP offers a comprehensive legal framework on arms exports, but more efforts are needed by Member States to apply all eight criteria set out in the document. Moreover, I would also like to highlight that today there is a lack of common control procedures in specific technical areas, such as the conversion of military weapons into civilians, the treatment of deactivated weapons and weapons intended for stage use, also in relation to their possible trade. On these aspects my country, Italy, has adopted strict technical and administrative prescriptions in order to avoid illegal practices in the treatment of weapons. These aspects, too, should be considered when drawing up a common and effective legislation on arms for export purposes, and all the more so at a particular moment in terms of security such as the one we are experiencing.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). - Madam President, arms exports are one of the most serious issues for the European Union to address with particular attention, as developments over the last two years have shown that arms end up in the hands of terrorists or oppressors. regimes, either in countries where minors are recruited and used in hostilities, as is the case in many African countries, Nigeria and elsewhere. I have repeatedly denounced in the Plenary Session of the European Parliament, here in Strasbourg, the continuous supply of weapons and ammunition from Turkey to Daesh, which is known to destroy Syria and is responsible for the terrorist attacks in Paris and elsewhere. Turkey is also arming jihadists in Libya. The European Union must immediately take a number of steps to set up a framework for arms exports, so that their outcome is ultimately controlled. At the same time, measures must be taken to protect civilians, as an estimated half a million people die each year in armed conflict.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI). - Madam President, arms exports from EU countries are a serious and complex issue with many parameters and peculiarities, because they concern both the economy of the European Union and the promotion and implementation of the objectives of the Common European Policy and Civil Defense; Security. I have in mind the common position taken by the Member States on this issue but I believe that this position will remain a simple wish list. When Germany, France, the United Kingdom, which are global arms suppliers and competitors, and Greece and Cyprus, on the one hand, are members of the European Union, and on the other hand, countries threatened by Turkey with war and therefore forced to be constantly equipped, how is it possible to implement the common position? Who will carry out and, above all, who will receive real checks? How will there be transparency and, if there is no transparency, how is it possible that small arms and ammunition are not illegally sent to ISIS, the Kurds and other terrorist organizations? Finally, we must look at the matter in its true dimensions and achieve a minimum degree of cooperation if we do not want to undermine the European Union's Common Foreign Policy.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, on the day we deliver the Sakharov Prize to Raif Badawi's wife, for the umpteenth time, several tons of bombs and ammunition leave Cagliari airport, destination Saudi Arabia. Yes, the very country that has been bombing Yemen for seven months, waging a war of four thousand dead and twenty thousand wounded. Not even the hospitals of Doctors Without Borders have been spared. Those bombs are Italian, they are one of the many cases in which our guilty conscience of a Europe allows the arms lobbies to prosper its "business as usual" by exporting happily in violation of the 2008 criteria and in particular of criterion two of the common position which continues to be completely not respected. This is because there is a lack of independent checks on exports and violations do not involve consequent penalties. With an amendment of mine to this report, which is a truly exceptional work by Mr Valero, whom I sincerely thank, we can correct this shortcoming and I appeal to the colleagues of the groups who would like to bury it and who are not even in the Chamber now. , Raif is also watching you and you too will have to look in the mirror if you vote against this report.

name: Bodil VALERO
text: rapporteur. - Madam President! Yes, it is clear that we have different views on this issue, and that was also the case when we started working on the report, but I still felt that together with the shadow rapporteurs we managed to find a common line, and that was also a very strong one. support in committee when we voted on the report. Since then, obviously, something has happened, and what I am most amazed at in the debate here is that some of those who have been up and speaking on behalf of their parties have not really talked about what we are really talking about. We are talking about the control of legal arms exports, which the Member States actually carry out vis-à-vis the companies in their countries. We are not talking about any illegal trade, but it is the legal trade we are talking about, and that is where Parliament has a role to play, because that is what we can go in and control and make sure that weapons like ourselves so that say sellers for various reasons do not end up in the wrong hands. The illegal trade in weapons, we handle it with completely different regulations. It is not this set of rules that we can use for that. One of the speakers clearly did not talk at all about the arms export control of legal weapons, but talked about the Commission's new proposal which deals with a completely different issue, what is hunting weapons, shooting sports, etc., so we are talking about two completely different things. I still hope that tomorrow, when we vote, we can have sufficiently broad support for the report in this House, and that we can move forward so that we also have a new annual report next year, so that this will be the annual review that Parliament makes the legal sale of arms, and the one for which we have common rules.

name: Anneli JÄÄTTEENMÄKI
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday, 17 December 2015. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Laurenţiu REBEGA
text: signed up. - I consider this motion for a resolution absolutely necessary to control arms exports as closely as possible. Establishing sound control of arms exports at EU level can be the solution to reducing the loss of life. It is to be appreciated how this motion for a resolution raises the issue of taking into account the export of innovative technologies, with a view to licensing them, and transferring them to the category of dual-use materials and technologies, such as robotics and software. The speed of technological development of the century we live in means that, in addition to the illegal export or at the limit of the classic weapons law, robotics or the expansion of software capabilities make available to groups defined as aggressive whole series of civilian applications that can be used as weapons. assault. Moreover, these technologies can easily become tools to collect information to be used for terrorist purposes. In this context, the introduction of these tools in the list of dual-use technologies in order to control their use much better becomes a necessity. I hope that this resolution will be only the first step in stopping the supply of weapons to the limit of the law or dual-use technologies to groups considered aggressive.

name: Alyn SMITH
text: in writing. – This report is vital in order to understand how Member States do business, selling arms to countries at war with their neighbours and often at odds with international humanitarian law. I congratulate my colleague, Bodil Valero, on this dossier. Europe’s security environment has changed drastically and, of course, EU rules on arms exports must be tightened.  But if the rules are not implemented then they mean nothing. We must name and shame Member States for failing to meet their legal obligation to supply arms export data to the EU and not complying with the existing legal framework. I am afraid this includes the UK. France and Greece have also not provided any data at all. This vicious circle must be stopped. It is a modern day tragedy – we do not know where these weapons end up and there is a real risk that they will fall into the hands of repressive regimes, criminals and terrorists in Europe, and be used against us. We can never be sure how the political and security situation may change in the countries we do business with; this is why a stricter risk assessment is so important and I call on my colleagues to back this report.

name: Anneli JÄÄTTEENMÄKI
text: The next item is the joint debate on – the report by Barbara Lochbihler, on behalf of the Committee on Foreign Affairs, on  the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the Union, of the Framework Agreement on Comprehensive Partnership and Cooperation between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and the Socialist Republic of Vietnam, of the other part (05432/2015 – C8—0062/2015 – 2013/0440(NLE)) (A8—0339/2015), –  the report by Barbara Lochbihler, on behalf of the Committee on Foreign Affairs, containing a motion for a non-legislative resolution on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the Union, of the Framework Agreement on Comprehensive Partnership and Cooperation between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and the Socialist Republic of Vietnam, of the other part (2015/2096(INI)) (A8—0342/2015), and – a report by Sandra Kalniete, on behalf of the Committee on Foreign Affairs, on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union and its Member States, of the Protocol to the Framework Agreement on Comprehensive Partnership and Cooperation between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and the Socialist Republic of Vietnam, of the other part, to take account of the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union (13079/2014 – C8—0282/2014 – 2014/0222(NLE)) (A8—0340/2015).

name: Sandra KALNIETE
text: rapporteur. - I call for support for the European Parliament resolution approving the Protocol to the Framework Agreement on Comprehensive Partnership and Cooperation between the European Union and Vietnam, to take account of the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union. This year marks the 40th anniversary of the end of the Vietnam War, and this year we can mark the 25th anniversary of relations between the European Union and Vietnam. European-Vietnamese relations have grown rapidly. It is therefore time to develop the regulatory framework for our relationship. It will now consist of a Framework Agreement between the European Union and Vietnam. It is important for us to remember that Vietnam is part of the Pacific Partnership, a new, newly established trading bloc that accounts for 36% of the world's gross domestic product and could have a very far-reaching impact on world trade. It is also strategically important for the European Union to resolve tensions with the countries of the South China Sea basin in order to maintain peace and stability there and to ensure the stability of major maritime transport routes. This is very important for European trade. That is why Vietnam has a strategic role to play as an important partner for the European Union in South-East Asia and ASEAN. I firmly believe that the EU-Vietnam Comprehensive Partnership and Cooperation Agreement and the Free Trade Agreement must also help to strengthen prosperity and human rights in Vietnam. The agreement will also promote cooperation on good governance, the fight against corruption, sustainable development, disarmament and the non-proliferation of weapons of mass destruction, as well as the fight against terrorism. That is why I, colleagues, are asking for my support for the protocol.

name: Barbara LOCHBIHLER
text: Rapporteur. - Madam President! In Parliament, we only discussed the framework agreement on comprehensive partnership and cooperation between the EU and Vietnam, and in the Committee on Foreign Affairs we came to the recommendation that the agreement should be approved. In order for this framework agreement to come into force, we call on the Member States France, Ireland, Greece and Italy to ratify this agreement as soon as possible. We agreed across political groups that Vietnam-EU relations are on the right track and should intensify in the areas of trade and development, anti-corruption, human rights protection, environment and climate change, science and technology, education and culture, peace and security. Vietnam has transformed in recent years from one of the poorest countries in the world with the difficult legacy of two cruel wars to a middle-income country with rapid economic growth. The poverty rate fell from 58% in 1993 to 11.8% in 2011. In the achievement of the Millennium Development Goals, Vietnam has excelled in the areas of right to education, right to housing and right to food. In Vietnam's socio-economic development strategy for 2011 to 2020, structural reforms are at the center, including macroeconomic stability, social justice and ecological stability. The fight against corruption is also part of macroeconomic stability. The damage to the economy caused by corruption is estimated in an official Vietnamese report from 2012 at 1.7% to 3.3% of the gross domestic product. In Transparency International's corruption perception index, the country ranks 119th out of 175 countries. The Vietnamese government has taken countermeasures, but more consistent and far-reaching steps need to be taken. The EU-Vietnam human rights dialogue will take place this week in Hanoi. In the present framework agreement, too, we are calling for the government to take a significant turnaround in order to allow freedom of expression, even if it includes criticism of government action. There is censorship on the internet, social media and websites are often blocked. Almost all print and radio channels are state controlled. Vietnam is currently a member of the United Nations Human Rights Council and has undergone the general human rights review. It would go too far here to list all human rights violations. I just want to underline that Vietnam has promised to implement improvements in the right to freedom of expression and also to allow an independent civil society. Last week in Strasbourg we discussed the now ratified EU-Vietnam free trade agreement with Commissioner Malmström. There will be an institutional link between the free trade agreement and the partnership and cooperation agreement. This ensures that principles of human rights and the rule of law are an essential part of the relationship between the EU and Vietnam - also with regard to trade between the two parties. The Commission still needs to complete the human rights impact assessment requested by the EU Ombudsman. In 2014 there were also conflicts between Chinese and Vietnamese fishermen in the area of ​​foreign and security policy in the South China Sea. We very much welcome the fact that the heads of state of both states have agreed to settle the maritime dispute by peaceful means. We also welcome the fact that in spring 2015 Vietnam declared its official support for the application by the Philippine government to appeal to the Permanent Court of Arbitration in The Hague on the Chinese territorial claims in the South China Sea. All in all, we have a very extensive resolution here with specific areas of work for the joint EU-Vietnam cooperation.Once again, I would like to thank all the shadow rapporteurs for a very constructive and good cooperation.

name: Andrus ANSIP
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, I am pleased to speak here in Parliament today before the vote on concluding the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement between the European Union and Vietnam, as well as on the Protocol for Croatia’s accession to the Agreement. This Agreement will provide a modern and comprehensive framework for the EU-Vietnam relationship, which has deepened and broadened over the past few years. Twenty-five years ago the then European Community and Vietnam established diplomatic relations. In these 25 years, our ties have grown from their humanitarian origins to a multifaceted partnership with trade and development at its core. The Partnership and Cooperation Agreement, together with the Free Trade Agreement concluded two weeks ago, will allow us to go even further. Today’s debate is an opportunity to acknowledge Vietnam’s role as a close partner for the European Union in South—East Asia and for our relations with ASEAN in particular. As ASEAN’s coordinator for relations with the European Union, Vietnam has provided valuable support in bringing our two regions closer together. In South—East Asia, Vietnam is one of the fastest growing economies today. Social and economic progress in the last two decades has been impressive as millions have been lifted out of poverty. Its foundations were laid in the late 1980s through an ambitious economic reform programme. Today, the EU, in turn, is Vietnam’s second largest trade partner, the largest development donor and one of Vietnam’s largest foreign investors.  Vietnam is now entering a new phase of national development and aims to become an industrialised country by 2020. To do so it needs to move from a growth model based on low—cost labour to one based on innovation and productivity. This calls for major structural changes and continued investments in infrastructure and human capital.  The European Union wants a strong and prosperous Vietnam, a Vietnam that respects the rule of law and human rights. Our persistent message to our Vietnamese counterparts is that good governance, human rights and the rule of law are the driving force for development, that a free media and a free internet provide huge benefits for Vietnam to succeed in the new knowledge-based economy and to meet the myriad of challenges that come with a modernising society, and that greater openness and opportunities for people to participate and actively engage with the institutions are needed to support Vietnam’s vision of becoming an inclusive and modern society. It is therefore in Vietnam’s best interests to honour its international commitments regarding human rights. Let me be clear. The European Union and Vietnam enjoy a close and ever—expanding partnership but, as in any relationship, there are areas where we have differences. These are, first and foremost, in the critical area of human rights and Mrs Lochbihler’s report rightly places much emphasis on this. In this respect we noted with concern the arrest today, just one day after the EU-Vietnam human rights dialogue, of Mr Nguyen Van Dai, a lawyer and human rights activist. We have expressed this clearly to our Vietnamese partners. The Partnership and Cooperation Agreement provides us with a much better basis to address issues such as the rule of law and human rights than the Framework Cooperation Agreement of 1996. Respect for human rights and democratic principles constitutes an essential element of the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement, with a much broader and more comprehensive set of commitments when compared with the previous instrument. The rule of law features among the fundamental principles covered by Article 1 of the Agreement. Let me assure you that these principles will guide us in our relations. The enhanced human rights dialogue that we agreed to establish in 2012 is the most visible evidence of our commitment here. The latest session was held just yesterday in Hanoi.  I trust that with the new Partnership and Cooperation Agreement, and thanks to the strong ties between the European Parliament and the National Assembly of Vietnam, we stand a better chance to support Vietnam’s transition towards a more open society.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr President, first of all I would like to thank Mrs Lochbihler and the other shadow rapporteurs for their good collaboration on this resolution. This cooperation and partnership agreement between the Union and Vietnam is a good example of the growing assertion of Parliament's power, including in matters of foreign policy. Parliament's approval is an important step for the ratification of the agreement which we must of course support. Vietnam is now an essential partner of the Union. A closer relationship with this country will not only allow the European Union to have privileged access to a dynamic market of more than 90 million inhabitants, but also to consolidate its strategic position in Asia, while pursuing its objectives. peace, rule of law and democracy. I would also like to highlight the conclusion of the negotiations on the free trade agreement with Vietnam. We must not forget, however, that this country still has many challenges to meet, particularly in terms of respect for human rights. The recommendations contained in the resolution will, I hope, help Vietnam to support the necessary reforms, such as respect for minority rights, the fight against corruption or the reform of the judicial system. Throughout the work on this resolution, I tried to find compromises with my colleagues in order to obtain a balanced text, which could be a tool to support the implementation of the partnership agreement. In this sense, Mrs Gill and I are proposing two amendments for tomorrow's vote, so that the text is legally correct. It is only through a resolution containing realistic and concrete proposals that Parliament will also be able to play a decisive role in the development of relations between the European Union and Vietnam.

name: Neena GILL
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, firstly I would like to congratulate the co-rapporteurs. EU—Vietnam relations are of vital importance in the current geopolitical context, especially with Asia leapfrogging to global prominence, the US and China each spearheading mega trade deals in the region, and tensions in the South China Sea threatening stability in that region. So the EU needs to get actively involved in all of these developments to ensure we keep peace in the region. That is why I wholeheartedly support this partnership and cooperation agreement. I believe it provides a basis for strengthening relations in fields that are of major importance from both a global perspective and our own bilateral perspective. I also welcome the agreement on free trade. I believe this gives Vietnam the opportunity to invest the benefits of trade for all groups within its society, reform its governance system, improve its human rights and join the global fight against climate change. I welcome the fact that my political group was able to secure the inclusion of important language on the need to step up efforts in all these fields, and particularly on human trafficking. It is a key migration policy, and the fight against trafficking and organised crime needs to be strengthened. However, this is not just something that Vietnam has to deal with. It is also the EU’s responsibility to look at why – and how – we can stop a large number of Vietnamese children from being exploited across different parts of the EU. A specialised working group on cooperation in this field should be set up to address this. The Commission has to be mindful that the success of any deal hinges on its implementation. Firstly, this means keeping in mind that Vietnam is still a developing country and we cannot ask it to do more than is realistically possible until we further step up capacity support. The European External Action Service also has to address shortcomings in relation to the information available to this House on international agreements to allow us fully to carry out our monitoring role and help us make this agreement a basis for a successful strategic relationship in the wider region too. I hope that we will be using this to build on progress achieved, thanks to coordination with Vietnam, to kick-start the re-launch of region-to-region FTA negotiations.  Finally, I would like to thank the rapporteurs, especially Ms Lochbihler, and the shadow rapporteurs for their excellent cooperation, as well as all the teams that supported us, who worked very hard to make this agreement achievable.

name: Amjad BASHIR
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, the conclusion of the EU—Vietnam Free Trade Agreement is excellent news. Although I appreciate the concerns raised by some of my colleagues – property rights, child labour and access to education are obvious examples that come to mind – we should ensure that a carefully calibrated political message is sent to Vietnam. Comprehensive reforms should be encouraged, but threatening language could be counterproductive. Considering the distraction caused by the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) and the newly formed ASEAN Economic Community, we should not overplay our hand by giving Vietnam an excuse to focus elsewhere. By all means let us be firm, but at the same time let us show flexibility and pragmatism whenever possible. Remember that governments do not do business with each other, people do. Fostering trade links is the quickest way to create wealth and prosperity for both Europeans and the Vietnamese.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: on behalf of the ALDE Club. - Mr. President, my generation in Croatia forty years ago looked with sympathy on the desire for freedom of the Vietnamese people. Later, a lot changed and many of us were very disappointed with everything that was happening in Vietnam and that region. Today, fortunately, we have hope again that things are changing for the better, because we see a desire to open Vietnam, to cooperate in the wider circle of countries in which it is located, including the EU and the US, which is of course a great shift in Vietnamese politics. That is why I support this agreement and everything that the Commission is doing in its efforts to bring our two economies closer, and I look forward to Vietnam's economic growth, the scientific cooperation we expect with EU and Vietnamese scientists, I look forward to the announced cultural cooperation. I think such a comprehensive agreement can be beneficial for both parties. However, we must keep in mind that Vietnam is still very far from the foundations of the EU, such as media freedom or human rights issues. I support the agreement, I wish it a successful realization, but let's keep in mind everything that does not suit us nowadays.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, first of all I would like to congratulate Mrs Barbara Lochbihler for having presented a report that is truly geared towards strengthening human rights, which is not often the case. Of course, we must not forget the reality of the facts, namely that Vietnam is a state dominated by a single party and is experiencing a situation that is far from a true democracy and a true rule of law. The violations in this sense are innumerable and it is undoubtedly a strategic country for the West, given that it is one of the pieces of the containment strategy of China carried out by the United States and this explains the great interest not only economic towards it. But we don't care about this. What matters is that the EU-Vietnam relationship is voted to promote not only human rights but also political participation, to have greater protection of workers and to safeguard the environment and to allow true freedom of expression. There is really a lot to do, we will not support the free trade agreement but instead support the hope of this political relationship like that of the Vietnamese people. But we also ask for concrete and above all immediate steps because today's trust can be revoked tomorrow.

name: Goffredo Maria BETTINI
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the partnership and cooperation agreement with Vietnam is a fundamental step in relations between the European Union and this decisive country. Vietnam has an ancient history, troubled and rich in traditions and culture and still, as the report recalls, bears the marks of the bombings it suffered by the Americans, who dropped more bombs on that land than in the entire Second War world. Vietnam has been experiencing vigorous economic growth for some years, civil society has been set in motion, important reforms have been implemented or initiated. I happened to see directly how much European investments are increasing, the spread of our products, the respect we enjoy and, as far as Italy is concerned, I say it with a pinch of pride, my country, true love for our lifestyle. Certainly there are many things still to be done, in terms of freedom and human rights the path is very long. This path will be pushed forward and verified, as the European Commission said, in its speech here in the Chamber, by increasing our commercial, economic and cultural relations with all the Vietnamese people, also in the awareness of the conditions in which they are was forced to operate, also because of the errors or, in some cases, of the real horrors that the West has committed.

name: Jan ZAHRADIL
text: – Mr President, as Chairman of your Parliamentary Group ‘Friends of Vietnam’, and also as standing rapporteur for the EU-Vietnam Free Trade Agreement, I am very glad that Vietnam is once again is at the forefront of EU attention. While we are dealing with that partnership and cooperation agreement, I hope that it will be approved as soon as possible. We also have to stress that we have already negotiated a free trade agreement, and those negotiations were finalised in August. The Treaty itself was signed two weeks ago by the Commission President and the Vietnamese Prime Minister. So it is good news. I think that it is also good news in the year where we are celebrating the 25th anniversary of EU-Vietnam relations. I have to say, however, that this report of Ms Lochbihler contains some elements with which I am not entirely happy. In particular, paragraph 33 seems to me a bit unfair and unjust towards the Vietnamese side, as it calls on Vietnam to ensure that fees set by the Vietnamese Ministry of Finances for the issue of documents are the same. It raises some doubts about the procedure. I do not think that this paragraph should be included in that report. I have serious concerns about that, and if that paragraph is there still tomorrow my position will probably be that I cannot support this report at all. However, I hope that we can find a solution for that.

name: Jozo RADOŠ
text: - Mr. President, I welcome any agreement by which the EU expands its cooperation, especially the agreement concerning the Socialist Republic of Vietnam as a country that is very poor and developing, but at the same time very important in Southeast Asia, 25 years after the establishment of official relations.I am pleased that this part of the world is also opening up to international cooperation through the Trans-Pacific Partnership Agreement, ie by enabling foreign direct investment in Vietnam.I expect that the signing of this agreement will improve relations between Vietnam and the EU, enable the democratization and progress of that country, but also improve the EU's cooperation with the wider area of Southeast Asia.

name: Seán KELLY
text: –  Mr President, at the beginning of November I had the privilege of being part of a small delegation from the European Parliament who visited Vietnam; I see some of the colleagues who also went are here and will probably be speaking later. It was a wonderful occasion. We were well received and Vietnam was very appreciative, particularly of the EUR 400 million we are giving under the present framework programme, much of which is going to combat climate change. That is certainly to be commended. They also expressed a desire to see the Free Trade Agreement come into being as soon as possible and, as has been said, it has now been signed by us and by their Prime Minister a few weeks ago in Brussels. The people of Vietnam are, I think, lovely people. They ride around on little motorbikes, which is lovely to see, in their rather strange and chaotic traffic management system, but it works. We can certainly do an awful lot to help them. One area which we also need to focus on is the provocative actions by China in the South China Sea. This is not good enough and building artificial islands and so on is contrary to the international law of the sea and we have to stand with Vietnam in trying to bring China to heel on that matter.  I am very pleased to say that in my own country of Ireland we have had diplomatic relations with Vietnam since 1996 and have had an embassy there since 2005. We have an excellent ambassador, Cáit Moran, who does tremendous work, particularly in helping to oversee the Irish aid programme in Vietnam, and indeed we have some Gaelic football teams there as well, which is my background. So I think we can say that Vietnam is a country that is going places quickly. We can certainly help the Vietnamese regarding human rights. Sandra Kalniete said that with the FTA that will improve over time. Certainly, as a strategic partner I think we can make a lot of progress, from both a business point of view and a human rights point of view and particularly for improving the quality of life of the Vietnamese people in the future.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Mr President, when I was a little boy, on occasion I was treated with a medicinal balsam called ‘Little Star’, which was imported from Vietnam and could be bought at any local pharmacy. Nowadays, Vietnam itself is a rising star of the Asian region. The positive results in many areas have been achieved thanks to the country’s openness to the world. Vietnam is actively participating in the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum (APEC), in the Association of South-East Asian Nations (ASEAN) and has recently signed a free trade agreement with the Eurasian Economic Union. Now we are moving towards the EU-Vietnam Framework Agreement on Comprehensive Partnership and Cooperation. Officially established a quarter of a century ago with an initial focus on trade and development, modern EU-Vietnam relations have now become much broader, incorporating energy, science, technology, culture and ecology. The Partnership and Cooperation Agreement has been especially beneficial to our relations. Vietnam has become the EU’s major partner in South—East Asia. The principal objective of the Vietnamese people, which the star on their flag symbolises, is to build upon the existing successes and continue on their path towards greater progress and development. The EU can undoubtedly assist Vietnam on this path, on occasion with a bit of friendly but constructive criticism on human rights, ecology, or the social sphere, but most importantly with productive cooperation. I fully support the conclusion of this agreement and hope it opens a new chapter of much more productive cooperation with Vietnam and its hardworking people.

name: Richard ASHWORTH
text: – Mr President, this partnership will bring real economic benefit to both parties, but it has a lot more to offer than trade alone. This is a time of great challenge in South-East Asia, not least the anxieties over the South China Sea. By working constructively with Vietnam, the EU can help build a peaceful, prosperous region which is founded on free trade and mutual recognition of international law. We do acknowledge the progress that has been made by the Government of Vietnam in its continued efforts to confront issues like corruption, human rights and good governance. To that end, this Parliament must reach out in a spirit of friendship and constructive dialogue to encourage and support that progress. Unfortunately, I cannot agree with some of the rapporteur’s comments, specifically, for example, paragraph 33, and in consequence would not be able to support that.

name: Olga SEHNALOVÁ
text: - Mr President, on the twenty-fifth anniversary of the establishment of diplomatic relations between the European Union and the Socialist Republic of Vietnam, we will approve the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement. There are many areas to be covered and they have already been discussed here. However, cooperation between people is most important for cooperation between countries. We have to clear the way for it and give it much more space. As an important step in this direction, I therefore welcome the Vietnamese side's decision to liberalize the visa regime for citizens of the five major European countries. But we should not end here. In order to develop and intensify further cooperation, I consider it important that this relaxation be extended soon to other, albeit smaller, Member States of the European Union. One of the countries that has a long tradition in cooperation with Vietnam is the Czech Republic. The large Vietnamese minority has recently been officially recognized as an ethnic minority. It is therefore natural that there are a number of joint projects. Cooperation in the field of education, for example, seems to be promising; a recent example is the project of the Czech Tomas Bata University in Zlín and the Vietnamese University in Ho Chi Minh City. I believe that these forms of cooperation can establish good, long-term partnerships, inter alia, by helping to get to know each other and understand real life in our countries.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: - Mr President, I am honored to address my colleague, Mrs Sehnal. I also had in mind a few things from the Czech reality, she already said it. Therefore, I would like to focus on the fact that not only are we celebrating twenty-five years of liberalization of trade relations, but that in 1996, a representative representation of the European Union was inaugurated in Vietnam. I think that the relaxation, the liberalization of trade relations, always has major effects, and that is why I support this draft agreement. I will admit that Article 33, so I will still study what the ECR colleagues are criticizing for this agreement. On the other hand, I would like to say that there is already a multiannual indicative program within the framework of Vietnam-European Union relations, which has undoubted results. We focus as the European Union on supporting energy, infrastructure. This is also evidenced by trade between the European Union and Vietnam, although there has been some decline in European Union imports into Vietnam. In any case, I support the further deepening of relations between the European Union and Vietnam.

name: Marek JUREK
text: - (PL) Mr President, according to the Open Doors institute, which studies anti-Christian persecution, Vietnam is a country where the situation for Christians is worse than in communist China than in Mali, than in Qatar or Egypt.Many of us who remember communism are familiar with these methods: permanent surveillance, punishing people for claiming their rights, for example for the return of taken property, propaganda campaigns awakening anti-Christian populism.What can we do in this situation?First of all, monitor the situation and show Vietnamese Christians that their situation is important to us.To show the Vietnamese authorities that the situation of Christians in their country is important to us - and therefore it is a pity that we have said so little about it in our debate, it is a pity that so few comments on this have been included in the relevant report.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). - Mr President, the new European Union-Vietnam Partnership is particularly important for European multinationals that have established and invested in Vietnam, where of course starvation wages apply. At the same time, in Vietnam, and especially in its factories, basic labor and social rights are not respected, and there is an escalation of child labor. In addition, corruption, human rights violations, and the persecution of Christians are on the agenda. The European Union-Vietnam Partnership Agreement, as well as the Free Trade Agreement, will hit the vulnerable SME sector in the Member States of the Union and increase unemployment. Vietnam must establish the rule of law, respect freedom of expression, religious freedom and freedom of the press, and the European Union, for its part, must not turn a blind eye to human rights abuses in the name of the profitability of European companies. in Vietnam, much less when the same partnership acts only in the interests of large companies.

name: Andrus ANSIP
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, this has been a very useful exchange and I thank the Members for the clarity of their interventions. Once again, I would like to thank our rapporteurs, Sandra Kalniete and Barbara Lochbihler, for their sound analysis. I have listened carefully and taken note of the Members’ expectations and concerns regarding the implementation of the partnership and cooperation agreement and, beyond that, regarding the overall relationship between the European Union and Vietnam. Let me conclude by emphasising that, with the partnership and cooperation agreement and the free trade agreement, we are laying solid foundations for a maturing political partnership.

name: Sandra KALNIETE
text: rapporteur.- I would like to reaffirm my support for this protocol and I hope that its Member States will also speed up the ratification process of the agreement in order to ensure that it enters into force as soon as possible, so that EU-Vietnam relations enter a new phase.

name: Barbara LOCHBIHLER
text: Rapporteur. - Mister President! I just wanted to comment on some of the last speakers who are here now. It goes without saying that the report lists that we demand that there should be free trade unions, and the persecution of various religious groups, including the Christian minority, is also explicitly mentioned in the report. In my opinion, the entire terminology and the presentation of human rights violations are not threatening - that is how I understood Mr Bashir - but actually reflect the vocabulary and discourse that the Vietnamese government itself cultivates, for example within the United Nations. The colleague who said that it might be a threat to medium-sized companies in Vietnam should be pointed out to the fact that in this agreement we are calling for a human rights assessment of the consequences of this free trade agreement, which is currently intended to assess whether large European companies entering the Vietnamese market come, displace small SMEs. And now to Article 33, which has been mentioned several times and which is particularly criticized not only by the ECR Group, but also by others. We consulted informally this afternoon and I think most of the political groups will be voting against this article which deals with corruption and visa waiver. But maybe I have to briefly express my astonishment that I received an email this afternoon from Mr. Zahradil, the chairman of the Vietnamese Friendship Group, in which he actually indicated that he would not agree to this agreement. So that - I hope I have now understood it correctly - only relates to Article 33. Because the approval of this agreement is very essential and is also demanded by the Vietnamese government, because otherwise it cannot be implemented at all. Here I can again advocate that we get a large approval for the agreement as a whole, and of course you can disagree with individual articles.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: I close the debate.The vote will take place on Thursday 17 December 2015. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Remo SERNAGIOTTO
text: in writing.- Vietnam is one of the fastest growing markets in the world and currently one of the EU's most important partners in South East Asia.Suffice it to recall, for example, that the EU is the second largest export market and aid donor for this country and the fifth largest investor.It is therefore of great importance to identify areas where cooperation should be improved, in order to maximize the benefits for both sides and at the same time support the development of Vietnam's capacity to promote respect for good governance, the rule of law.and human rights.
